name: Der Präsident. –
text: The first item on the agenda is the debate on the statements by the Council and the Commission on the Luxembourg Presidency's balance sheet (2015/2964(RSP)). I would like to begin by welcoming the Prime Minister of the Grand Duchy of Luxembourg, Mr Xavier Bettel, and Mr Juncker, President of the Commission.

name: Xavier Bettel
text: President-in-Office of the Council. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I thank you for giving me the opportunity to present you with a brief and short assessment of the Luxembourg Presidency of the Council. As you know, this presidency took place in a particularly difficult and often dramatic context.  The Union is facing unprecedented challenges, including finding answers to the financial and economic crisis, where things are getting better, but where caution remains, the growing instability at its borders and the temptations to retreat to the national square, which are taking on worrying dimensions in Europe. As if that were not enough, two particular phenomena were added, in an already very difficult context, namely: the migration crisis and the rise of terrorism in the world, but also particularly in Europe, during the attacks in Paris last year. On these two issues, the Presidency has endeavoured to react quickly and concretely.  With regard to the migration crisis, I will not go here in detail to the various measures taken both on the responsibility of the Member States and on the aspect of solidarity between the Member States, knowing that it was appropriate and that it will still be necessary to ensure a dignified reception for refugees in need of international protection. These measures cover the resettlement and relocation of refugees, the establishment of a new return and readmission policy and a reception mechanism through hotspots, the definition of a new framework and, finally, the strengthening of our Union's external borders. All of these measures have been put in place as a whole as a whole as a whole as a whole. Some are only starting to produce their effects now; they are the indispensable part of a reform of our migration policy, which is certainly not complete. In this regard, we also welcome the proposals made by the Commission in December 2015.  That said, the spring migration campaign is likely to resume with the same magnitude this year as last year. It is absolutely necessary to implement the measures already decided, because, even with the best will of the co-legislators, we can only weigh in favour of a reduction in flows if what has already been decided is also actually implemented. As we all know, the integrity of the Schengen area is at stake; it will only work if the rules governing it are respected. From this point of view, we have called as early as November 2015 for a communitisation of the introduction of internal border controls, as long as it is necessary and that Member States are not left with the initiative or last resort of national and disorderly reintroduction of controls. Not all the instruments offered by the Schengen Code have been used and this will probably have to be done quickly. For the time being, the priority is certainly to do everything possible to substantially reduce the flow of refugees at the risk of losing our public opinion if we do not. It is also high time to operationalise relocation, and all Member States must participate without delay. If real progress has been made in this context, more needs to be done and everyone must live up to their commitments and responsibilities. It is also a question of solidarity between the Member States, a solidarity that is expressed at the political level and not legally. Solidarity is not, in the history of our Union, only one-way solidarity: we must know how to give and not expect to receive. This solidarity must also be extended with the partner states of the Balkans and Turkey. The Balkan Road Conference and the Action Plan with Turkey are leading the way, even if the realities on the ground are not yet up to each other's legitimate expectations. We must not forget Lebanon and Jordan either.  The Paris attacks in 2015 were the most dramatic moment in a security situation severely degraded by terrorism in Europe and beyond. The confusion between migration and terrorism must be avoided. We must also ensure that these amalgams cannot be made too easily. We have, on the Presidency side, tried to implement a whole series of measures already taken in the wake of the Charlie Hebdo attacks, but the Union may not have been quick enough to react at first. We should also welcome the fact that, after three years of discussions, the PNR directive has finally been adopted by the co-legislators. In this extremely difficult context where action has been taken in an accelerated fashion, I must say that that we have always been able to count on the European Parliament, in particular the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs. More generally, the european Union has been able to move forward, thanks to the support and constructive approach of the European Parliament. I would therefore like to take this opportunity today to thank you, not only for this excellent cooperation over the last six months, but also for making a decisive contribution to moving the Union forward on a range of key issues at the very heart of the Presidency's programme. Of the 36 cases concluded in codecision, let me mention above all the agreement on the 2016 budget, an agreement on the reform of the European Court of Justice, the establishment of a European passenger data collection system, the directive on strengthening the presumption of innocence, the simplification of the circulation of certain public documents, an agreement on the proposed regulation on benchmarks or the agreement on the data protection.  The Luxembourg Presidency organised the first political dialogue on respecting and promoting the rule of law in our Union. The discussions of the last few months, and especially weeks, the events of the last weeks, even the last days, demonstrate the relevance of this process. This dialogue is only in its infancy, it needs to be deepened in the coming months. It is not only in the area of home affairs that we have had to resolve to hold extraordinary meetings; this has also been the case in dealing with the crisis in the dairy and pork sectors, as well as the difficulties faced by the European steel industry due to unfair trade policies in third countries.  As far as trade is concerned, some progress has been made: it has been possible to make progress on the mechanism for the settlement of investor-state disputes, the future TTIP agreement, and I would also like to thank President Schulz for the meeting we organised together in Brussels with the social partners to discuss this TTIP. We have put the social partners of the 28 European countries around the table, because for us TTIP must not be an agreement that sells off the values and trust that citizens have entrusted to us through all these years, but it must also be seen as an opportunity and it is therefore important to conduct the necessary negotiations in a transparent manner.  While the WTO Ministerial Conference in Nairobi marks the end of the Doha Round, some progress has also been made at the multilateral level. We wanted to modernise the working methods of competitiveness and to focus our work on putting in place a stable regulatory framework that favours investment in line with the Juncker plan. It is with the aim of mobilising investment financing that we have also adopted, in record time, a general approach by the Council on securitisation as the first brick of the capital markets union. It was also in a very short period of time that the Council was able to agree on the directive on the exchange of information on tax rulings. This agreement is a strong signal to the rest of the world on tax transparency. Also on tax matters, the Council adopted important conclusions on the OECD's BEPS initiative to combat base erosion and profit shifting.  The deepening of the social dimension of the Union and the establishment of genuine social governance, as is done in economic and financial matters, has been and remains a goal of Luxembourg. We have been able to move in this direction over the last six months, although much remains to be done. I also believe that we have made progress on sustainable development by coordinating European efforts towards the 2030 agenda, but also, of course, through the contribution of our Union, in close cooperation with our French friends, at COP 21 in Paris: a first universal and binding agreement on combating climate change. We have also worked to establish reliable, transparent and robust governance of the energy union and to promote a sustainable energy transition. We have completed some projects, such as the two important components of the fourth rail package, namely the one that deals with the liberalisation of passenger rail services and the one that aims to strengthen the governance of rail infrastructure.  We started the huge the project of the Digital Single Market initiated by the Commission. The establishment of the latter is a condition for the completion of the internal market, a completion which will also require a wider application of the principle of mutual recognition. Let me also mention a small personal satisfaction, as Minister of Telecommunications of my country, namely the agreement reached between the co-legislators on the proposal for an NIS directive that will strengthen the security of computer networks in the Union. There is still a lot of work to be done at this level. It is sad to see that the European Union is in fact caught between the United States and Asia, and that our young talents who want to be successful are often forced to leave our continent - which imposes 28 different regulations on young people who want to get started - in order to gain recognition.  Mr President, I have said above how good cooperation between the Council and the European Parliament has been under our Presidency. We finalized the budget reconciliation five days before the deadline; as far as we can remember, it's a record. I believe that we, Parliament, the Council and the Commission, have also put in place the conditions for a more harmonious functioning of the institutional triangle through the inter-institutional agreement 'Better Legislation' of December, a political agreement at this stage, but which we hope will come into force soon after your assembly has spoken before the beginning of spring. With this agreement, it is also a question of modernising European legislative and regulatory processes in the direction of greater transparency, but also of reducing the administrative and budgetary burden on what constitutes the heart of the European economy, namely small and medium-sized enterprises.  In these times of crisis, it is a good idea to denigrate the European project, and even for the most enthusiastic, to question the way forward. Let us not forget, and especially for the younger generations, to recall the peace project that we have been living on a daily basis since 1957. I was lucky enough to be Luxembourgish, to study in France, to do an Erasmus in Greece, to have discovered things that I would not have known if I had been born later. As a student in Thessaloniki, take the car to go to Skopje, to go to Bulgaria, to go to Turkey, to have closed borders, to have to disinfect the car, to have to stop at a customs, to have customs closed: things that young people today do not know. To have known the bureaux de change, to have to exchange. We complain, but we forget to remind our young people of what Europe is also: rights, freedoms, the chance to fall in love with someone who does not have the same passport, to be able to be cared for, to be defended. It is very important to remember all this on a daily basis, especially to the younger generations, and to stop denigrating all this project we are fighting for.  From my country's point of view, there is an urgent need to continue the path of European integration, because that is where the solutions to the crises that Europe must face are. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, there is certainly more to say, but time is running out. My country is pleased to have been able to chair the Council of the Union for the twelfth time. He has been able to count on your support, I thank you and let me also thank all the civil servants, whether they are at your side, on the side of the Commission or on the Luxembourg side, for the work done. I am making this speech today, but they are the ones who have worked masterfully over the last six months and let me thank them on behalf of all of us.

name: Jean-Claude Juncker
text: Commission President. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Prime Minister, since we last saw each other, further atrocities have been committed in Istanbul and Jakarta. Our democracy, represented by this Parliament, and the values that underpin it are stronger than terrorist threats. Such acts will never dictate our course of action, and the terror that awaits us will certainly not intimidate us. We will continue to work to preserve our freedoms, our way of life, our way of being together, in short, the whole of humanity. With regard to the Luxembourg Presidency, Mr President, I would once again like, and in a very pronounced way, to sing the praises of the Luxembourg Government, its Prime Minister and all the ministers who accompanied it. His Presidency has done a very good job and has demonstrated - for the rest, in the case of Luxembourg, this is always true - that the main thing is not in quantity but in quality, certainly perfectable, but nevertheless in the remarkable quality that was that of the Luxembourg Presidency. This has always been the case throughout history. Remember, in 1985, the Luxembourg Presidency was able to conclude the Single European Act that gave birth to the internal market. The Luxembourg Presidency in 1991 led the first part of the Intergovernmental Conference on Economic and Monetary Union. In 1997, it was the great decision on enlargement that allowed the two lungs of Europe to breathe together, and so on. The tradition was therefore strongly established, and the government that exercised the presidency proved worthy of the rich past it inherited. The Presidency had to be exercised under particularly difficult conditions. It has succeeded on the issue of migration by bringing about a constructive dialogue between 28 different and often diametrically opposed national realities. It also concluded key files that had been stalled for too long, whether on the subject of air passenger files or data protection. And I could, Prime Minister, continue the enumeration: the intergovernmental agreement that you mentioned and whose importance and scope are underestimated, the elegance with which the Luxembourg government was able to lead the work at the climate conference in Paris; all performances that we do not often mention but which are part of the recent history of the European Union. With regard to the refugee crisis, under the expert and often enlightened authority of Minister Asselborn, and with the support of your Parliament, agreements were quickly reached on the Commission's proposals for the relocation and resettlement of refugees - agreements, alas!, adopted by the Council but not yet translated into reality. We have also made progress, albeit too little and too slowly to the liking of some, on other points: the operational implementation of the first "hotspots", better coordination between countries on the Balkan route, or in terms of an action plan with Turkey, and we have been able, through the Presidency, to establish greater virtuous, necessary and useful cooperation with our African partners. Today, ladies and gentlemen, we have new tools to deal more effectively and effectively with the urgency of migratory pressure. Other innovative tools, including those relating to common external borders, will still need to be put in place, with European agreements, border guards and coastguards. But let us not be fooled: better management of migration in all its aspects is a long-term work. We must not give up and we must continue the work that the Luxembourg Presidency has usefully begun. "Hotspots", relocation, European coastguard and border guard corps: all these elements go together. They are inseparable from each other. It is all of these measures that will enable us to reduce the flow of migrants and thus to remove the risks to the Schengen area, because there are very great risks, even risks of survival, in this area. Today, we are happily reintroducing border controls. Tomorrow we will find that the economic cost is considerable and, the day after tomorrow, we will ask ourselves why we have a single currency, when we no longer have freedom of movement or the internal market. Therefore, the European Union is threatened, in some respects, in its foundations and in its extensions, which could have gone much further than what we are seeing today. Trotz go dieser Schwierigkeiten, trotz go dieser Probleme hat die luxemburgische Presidentschaft ihren Vorsitz im Rat mit Bravour gemeistert, auch, weil sie nie das groe Ganze aus den Augen verloren hat. Sie hat manchen gordischen Knoten durchtrennen kunnnen, mit sehr viel Verhandlungsgeschick und mit der Hilfe vieler Hànde und vieler Kàpfe. Die Fluggastdatenspeicherung ist ein Beispiel, die neue european datenschschutzgrundverordnung ist ein anderes Beispiel. Aus dieser Datenschutzgrundverordnung ist im 'brigen ein schuns rundes luxemburgisches Ei geworden. Frau Reding hat die Datenschutzverordnung 2012 vorgeschlagen, die Kommission hat dies in ihre programmatischen Priorit-ten aufgenommen, und die luxemburgische Regierung hat die Datenschutzgrundverordnung zum Fliegen gebracht. Das ist also eine exemplarische, fast patriotische Leistung der Luxemburger, wofàr ich mich im Namen der Kommission sehr herzlich bei Premierminister Bettel bedanken mechte. Alles in Allem: Dieser Ratsvorsitz war ein voller Erfolg Es gibt nicht einen einzigen Abstrich zu machen, und die luxemburgische Regierung plus die vielen Hànde, die ihr zugearbeitet haben, kunnnen stolz sein auf das Erreichte. Dat hutt Dir gutt gemaach!

name: Viviane Reding
text: on behalf of the EPP group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, small countries are capable of making good presidencies. Luxembourg has just given proof of this once again, with decades of institutional experience.  Of course, the character of the presidencies has changed a lot since the Lisbon Treaty, which replaced the rotating presidencies with the permanence of the President of the European Council and the Presidency of the Foreign Affairs Council. But there is still the European legislation, proposed by the Commission, which must then be negotiated, patiently, article by article, and there, the solid work of Luxembourg civil servants has been able to advance dozens of issues. I am thinking, among other things, of the reform of the European Court of Justice, of the inter-institutional agreement, of the railway package, of data protection, of the PNR dossier, and so on. It was a perfectly mastered work, executed with know-how, with commitment, carried out in the interest of Europe. That the Luxembourg civil servants and those who assisted them - there were many of them - should be thanked.  The government has been able to manage the files. Foreign Minister Jean Asselborn was on all fronts. His commitment was noticed and appreciated, as was that of the Minister for European Affairs, Nico Schmit, who was at the disposal of the European Parliament. Let us also note COP 21, where the Luxembourg Presidency was supporting the excellent work done by France, by ensuring that Europe speaks with one voice. A big thank you to all. For the rest, they were unprecedented and endless crises. Greece's has almost been overshadowed by refugees and terrorism. In many Member States we have seen the rise of nationalist populism, selfishness and a clear lack of accountability for the common future of our continent. In the face of these serious problems, presidencies can do little. They pass, but crises remain. May 2016 produce a change of course in line with the founding texts of the Union. The texts speak of coherence, respect, solidarity; they are talking about a Europe moving forward, and that is what we are calling for.

name: Mady Delvaux
text: On behalf of the Group of the S-D. - Mr President, Prime Minister, ladies and gentlemen, as a Luxembourger and a socialist whose comrades are in government, I will of course say good things about the Luxembourg Presidency - we did not expect less. As an MEP, I would like to thank the Luxembourg Presidency for the past six months. At a time when the Union was and still faces enormous challenges, we had to respond to the crises that threaten our European values and the cohesion of the Union. This was done with panache by Luxembourg Ministers Jean Asselborn, a tireless traveller for peace and for our freedoms, and Nicolas Schmit, who spent his nights here in the European Parliament. It was done well. But I especially appreciated the work that has been done on the less spectacular issues. I will not list all the files that could have been concluded, but they were spent for months or even years. The work and collaboration between the Council, represented by the Presidency, and the European Parliament have been exemplary. This is probably due to the commitment of the Luxembourg Government, but so much, and perhaps more so, to the commitment of the civil servants, those who worked in Luxembourg and those who have been at work here in Brussels, to the permanent representation, which I would particularly like to thank. All that remains is for me to hope that the following presidencies will show the same availability, the same commitment and the same spirit of solidarity in the interests of the European Union, which is in great need of it.

name: Helga Stevens
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Luxembourg had placed the security issue high on the agenda when he took office and the result may be there. For example, an agreement was reached in the long-standing EU-PNR dossier and, in concrete terms, the intelligence services will be able to use passenger data, which is important in the fight against terror.  In addition, there will be an anti-terrorism cell within Europol that will be able to detect and have jihadist content removed on the Internet, among other things. However, the privacy of the citizen is not forgotten. This is evidenced by the compromise text on the Data Protection Directive on police matters. In terms of migration, the result is meageny. The pilot project on the redistribution of asylum seekers among European countries is the only tangible result and even undermined by the refusal of Eastern European countries to assume their responsibility. Europe's inability to effectively guard Europe's external borders has made it difficult to deal with the migration crisis. That is why I hope that a systematic push-back policy can be implemented under the Dutch Presidency. We must stop the unbridled influx by systematically returning smuggling boats at sea. Moreover, asylum seekers who have already received de facto protection in a transit country are no longer allowed to receive asylum in Europe. Of course, Europe must do its part, but Europe cannot solve all the problems. That is why we need to set a maximum number of asylum seekers to be taken in, after which only the most vulnerable can come to Europe through resettlement. That's how we take out people smugglers.  In conclusion, I would like to say that we are actually very disappointed that you have not made any mention of the British demand for REFORM of the EU. However, this is important for the future of Europe.

name: Charles Goerens
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. Mr President, Mr President of the Commission, Mr President of the Council of the Union, when you presented the priorities of your Presidency, many of us told you that the six months of work of the Luxembourg Presidency would coincide with a precarious internal situation and an extremely difficult external situation.  At the end of your presidency, we see that the crises already in place in July have become existential for the European Union. They remain existential because our Member States are not prepared to equip the European Union with the powers and means to solve them. It is all the more comforting to see how successful your presidency has been in meeting the significant challenges. One example is the 2016 budget, which was unanimously adopted in record time. Nor should we forget the successful efforts in the areas of home affairs and justice. The Presidency has also helped to change the issue of combating climate change; the same is true of the agricultural and social issues.  Your great merit, however, will have been to show that you can move the lines, even if the results are not acquired in advance. It is true that, despite the efforts and progress mentioned, some of our Member States are holding back when it comes to solidarity in the face of major crises such as refugees. The indifference, if not the refusal, of many of our Member States increases the burden on those who are prepared to assume their responsibilities for taking in refugees. We are ashamed to see many Member States questioning important achievements such as Schengen. There are no words to describe the homeopathic contributions of some in search of a solution to the problem of asylum seekers. While Germany is hosting 24,000 refugees in one weekend, others of roughly comparable size say they want to take in the same number of refugees over a two-year period.  The real crisis at the beginning of 2016 is a crisis of solidarity. The inability to distribute efforts equitably among the 28 does not bode well. The end of the presidency of a country known for its European commitment will not end, I am sure, its commitment to a more united and united Union.  We rely on you, on your talent, on the competence of your employees, whom no one is questioning, on the experience of the Member State you represent, on to move Europe forward and to give it a more federalist imprint. The future is sufficiently mortgaged by the inability to overcome the intergovernmental, with its crippling effect in which sovereignists and nationalists of all stripes recognize themselves above all.  Our old continent deserves better. It deserves a free, strong, united and effective European Union. If for some it remains a dream, Mr President, I would like to tell them that this dream can only be realized by making a great federal leap forward.

name: Δημήτριος Παπαδημούλης
text: On behalf of the GUE/NGL Group – Mr President, Mr Bettel, Mr Juncker, I am sorry, but I, nor my political group, the optimism, the praise, the courtesy among Luxembourgers, can share. The Luxembourg Presidency has tried, but now we are counting the Council's results after six months and the figures and events call for concern, alertness, responsibility and not complacency. In September you decided to relocate 160,000 refugees with a proportional distribution across Europe. What's the report? How far have the decisions been implemented? A few hundred people relocated, not even 1%. You left Greece alone and virtually helpless to lift the burden of 85% of refugee flows. You signed a framework agreement with Turkey, but Mr Timmermans says that nothing has changed in terms of reducing refugee flows because the Turkish authorities are waiting for the money without implementing the commitments they have made. And in this environment of egos, nationalisms, xenophobia, the cries are growing: 'It is Schengen's fault!'  So because unemployment and poverty are also increasing and because economic growth remains poor, it is not time to congratulate each other but to take major initiatives, at the same time, to tackle the two major problems, in order to finally achieve growth by combating unemployment and to tackle the refugee problem in a single European way.

name: Reinhard Bütikofer
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, Prime Minister, Mr Bettel, I would like to thank the President-in-Office of the European Parliament for his excellent work and for his excellent work. Your presidency, Prime Minister, was, like any, made up of plans and events.  You are not solely responsible for the implementation of the plans – not in the case of events anyway. You could now compare what you had set out to do and what was done. There are at least a few points where you have not been particularly successful: for example, the new necessary balance sheet between European trade policy and industrial policy or the small buisness act or the greening of the European semester.  For me, however, the positive achievements of the Presidency outweigh the positive achievements of the Presidency. The two I would like to highlight in particular are the General Data Protection Regulation, which has brought you to a conclusion, and the contribution of your Presidency – your personal and also that of your Minister, Mr Dieschbourg, to the Paris climate conference. So thank you very much for this presidency. At the same time – and this is now the view of the great picture that has been mentioned – it can be said that we are experiencing a new normal in Europe. This is characterised by many overlapping challenges and crises, and this state of affairs will not change them so quickly. We have to prepare for this new normal, with much more headwinds than we were used to. This leads to fears among citizens of the loss of security and stability. If we do not want the policy of fear to grow in this situation, then we must oppose a successful policy of hope. But this is not just a rhetorical challenge. Talking about hope and change so often does not mean that we have the services that we need. We are judged by this whether we are putting these solutions in place.  You said at the beginning of your presidency: we must listen to the citizens. I believe that this is a very central principle. But that also means that we must listen to the citizens where they may not say what we want to hear. If you say today, Mr Bettel, that TTIP must be treated as an opportunity, then it does not mean to listen to the fact that, according to Eurostat, the citizens are increasingly criticising and saying that they are not doing so. Listening to the citizens means making a difference here. You said that solidarity is crucial. I share that, but solidarity is not only where we demand something, but also where others demand something. Expecting solidarity from Poland on refugees also means showing solidarity with Poland, for example, in Nord Stream.  Thirdly, you said that we must not hide into the national. In this new situation, we need to re-measure the balance between the national, between the Union of States, and the common, the Union of Citizens, that is at the heart of the Brexit debate.  And with regard to refugee policy, however, one thing is clear: there is an incompatible European strategy and a national strategy. So far, the possibility of a European solution has essentially been defended by the German position. If Germany were to go down the national path on this issue, it would be a disaster for Europe.

name: Marco Valli
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would say that today we are witnessing yet another European paradox with the Luxembourg Presidency, which even boasts that it has achieved great successes in the field of justice and tax transparency. I am thinking, for example, of the directive on the automatic exchange of information for tax agreements, the so-called tax rulings. Why is it not said that the agreement reached in October in the Council is extremely limited and lacking in relation to the proposal of the Commission and this Parliament? We will then have to talk about the Fiat affair, where the European Commission itself has established that Luxembourg has given us unlawful State aid. Well, because of the paradox of the absurd state aid rules, Luxembourg will be the country that Fiat will have to compensate and not, for example, Italy and the other European countries to which it has taken the resources away. Gramegna spoke on this matter and promptly said that the Brussels decision should be criticised for, in his opinion, creating uncertainty for businesses, thus showing what the real face of Luxembourg is. So you can keep telling us all the fairy tales you want, but that's your reality, the reality of a country that for years has thrived on the shoulders of its European partners, subtracting billions of legitimate taxes that multinationals would have to pay. I would also like to take advantage of Mr Juncker's presence to tell him that we are waiting for him with open arms in the TAXE Committee, because he has yet to clarify his position on the krecké report. Do not shield behind the two large groups that support it, come and clarify once and for all in a real contradiction, otherwise you will never be worthy of any credibility.

name: Marine Le Pen
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, Prime Minister of Luxembourg, Members, this Luxembourg Presidency has started under the fire of the LuxLeaks revelations, this tax evasion knowingly organised by Luxembourg in favour of multinationals and to the detriment of other European countries. We will know little more about this scandalous case, since MEPs have decided to bury it by refusing any parliamentary committee of inquiry. Silence, we cheat, we strip. European countries are stripped of their tax matters. All honest taxpayers - SMEs and individuals - have to pay more taxes and compensate for this looting organised by Luxembourg and other tax havens, while this sad European Union is doing nothing to stop this. This presidency is coming to an end, at a time when the influx of migrants is dramatic and is on a considerable scale; considerable by the frightening number of people marching towards Europe, also considerable by the terrible shock caused by the sexual assaults of 200 German women in the centre of Cologne. These acts of sexual predation mark a regression of our civilization. We must all defend the freedom of women to move without fear in our cities. The arrival of millions of people from radically different cultures will lead to violent shocks and conflicts within our societies. It is time to stop this madness. My country has suffered too much this year from conflicts and tragedies. Organized Islamist terrorist attacks have been repeated relentlessly. The fight against Islamism and the control of our national borders are absolutely necessary to ensure the security of our compatriots, but we need greater change. Our nations are falling apart. Everything must be done to re-weave and reform them. Multiculturalism divides. The united nation soothes, brings citizens together, offers them a common future. His return is inevitable: the sooner the better.

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI).
text: – The Presidency-in-Office of the Union cannot be expected to solve the accumulated problems. However, it can be expected to provide the right answers to the main questions. The presidency's slogan was One Union for Citizens. The intention is to focus on the citizen. We need a Europe that is closer to the expectations of its citizens. Well, that's not true.  The migrant crisis has shown how far this so-called political elite is from the will of the European population. Among the priorities he named migration as: controlling migration. The quota system is a means of doing this. He didn't want to solve and stop the invasion, he just wanted to manage it, regulate it. It is also a great responsibility of this Presidency that 1.5 million immigrants have arrived, putting European culture, identity and citizens' security at risk. The only positive step would have been the relationship with Turkey. There, he stopped immigration, but failed to enforce the agreement. Another area of failure is relations with Russia. Extend sanctions, both in time and in content. The intended goal of weakening President Putin has not been achieved, but sanctions have caused enormous damage to many EU member states and companies. The scales: failure.

name: Tunne Kelam (PPE).
text: – Mr President, Luxembourg took the Presidency at the time of the biggest crisis Europe has faced. However, it did not falter or panic. Instead, Luxembourg provided a professional, credible, even elegant leadership continuing, together with the current Commission President, the long-established Juncker tradition. The advantage of smaller Member States is to play more convincingly the role of honest broker. Estonia, which will take the Presidency in two years’ time, is eager to learn from the Luxembourg experience. I will make three observations. Firstly, in terms of cybersecurity, there were two major achievements: the informal agreement on the NIS Directive and the political agreement of the data protection package. Both constitute the backbone not only of cybersecurity, but also for the further integration of a digital Europe. Secondly, I am satisfied that, under the Luxembourg Presidency, sanctions to counter Russia’s aggressive activities were maintained, despite what is happening with ISIS in Syria. I think it is crucial for EU credibility to maintain these sanctions until the Minsk agreements have been fully met. Thirdly, it is very good that the Council has supported the simplification of European structural and investment funds, facilitating access, especially for SMEs.  There were also attempts to simplify of the common agricultural policy rules. However, the major challenge the following Presidency continued to face is the fact that there is still no common agricultural policy in the true sense of that word. Instead, we have 28 different national agricultural policies, the common denominator of which is that they are all eager to get money from the same EU source. In such a form CAP also continues to be a source of mistakes and complications, but well done Luxembourg.

name: Alfred Sant (S&D).
text: – Mr President, in the second half of 2015 the Luxembourg Presidency and the Commission showed great determination in trying to steer the Union out of the crisis that broke out in rapid order. However, from the smoothing over of the most recent Greek crisis to the refugee crisis, everything was done in firefighting mode. Events, not the Union, were in charge. Unfortunately, the events may have shown that the assumptions of the models we follow no longer fit the realities. They referred to the economic and social realities of the past.  The results of national elections over the past six months show that European peoples may have realised this. Clearly, when you operate in firefighting mode there is no time to undertake strategic reviews. Yet the signs are that the time has also come for such strategic reviews. We need a strategic reflection regarding the assumptions, not the values and the models, not the methods, of the European project; the reach and soft power of the Union; a new design for political coherence in Europe; immigration policies; the effects of globalisation; the mix of state and private sector; and not least in the areas of job creation.

name: Timothy Kirkhope (ECR).
text: – Mr President, I would like to thank the Presidency for all their work and cooperation in helping reach a conclusion on the EU PNR agreement. This is one of the most challenging files that Parliament has seen, and in the most challenging of times. I would like to ask the Parliament to adopt the Directive as soon as possible. There is no need for more delays and the sooner we adopt the instruments, the sooner Member States can start implementing them. Lives, liberties and security are of course at stake. I also speak as the rapporteur of the EU Permanent Relocation Mechanism. This next Presidency will guide us on a number of issues: Dublin, the border force and ECRI. Of course we need fresh and new ideas and I welcome them in a system which is bogged down in complexity and compromise. I urge the President of the Commission to do the thing we need most though – to implement the things we already have available. Many of the issues we face are a direct result of the breakdown of applying existing rules, and there are inevitably consequences. Laws without meaningful implementation are useless, but I hope that there will be a focus in the next few months on implementation.

name: Νικόλαος Χουντής (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President, Mr President of the Commission, Prime Minister of Luxembourg, objectively your presidency has also been identified – not only for the Greeks but also for all those who believe that the European Union is an area of democracy – with the imposition of a political coup d'état in Greece.  During your presidency, the European Central Bank illegally closed Greek banks and created the threat of bankruptcy in Greece. During your presidency you threw away the will of the Greek people who refused with 62% in the referendum to impose a new economic disaster programme – a new memorandum. During your presidency, the imposition of such a programme continued, unfortunately with the tolerance of the government today, a programme that destroys the country's productive base, sells public property and eliminates all traces of social state in Greece. During your presidency, all traces of humanism have been lost, as migrant refugees continue to drown in the Aegean and mediterranean while you do absolutely nothing. Therefore, Mr President of Luxembourg, your presidency has also denied those who hope that the European Union can be built on the values of democracy, solidarity and humanism. I would therefore like to stress to you that in the future of the European peoples there cannot be such a European Union which, even in this limited role, you have been running for six months. The future of the European peoples cannot be poverty, recession, racism, or the non-management of humanitarian crises.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, today we are debating the insults of the Luxembourg Presidency, what I would describe as a disaster: in these six months there have been an increase in immigrants, terrorists, fear, the events in Paris and Cologne and Europe under this Presidency has remained inert. And in my house, those who do nothing are complicit. The scandal of the Luxembourg Government's aid to multinationals remains shamefully open. We all know that Mr Juncker is embroiled in this affair, as he was the Prime Minister of Luxembourg when the scandal broke. Yet in these six months, nothing has been done to shed light on this shame. What credibility can the European Commission have if a suspect sits at the summit? Shame on you, Mr Juncker, your colleagues and your fellow snacks who hide all your misdeeds. We are fed up with the Europe of strong powers playing into the game of the big banks and multinationals! We are sickened by this way of doing things! I say NO to this Union, which starves honest citizens and fattens the pockets of the usual known!

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – Mr President, it is never easy being a small country, especially one whose territory has historically been marched through back and forth numerous times simply as a result of being surrounded by more influential and larger neighbours. Nonetheless, Luxembourg has managed to overcome these obstacles, emerging as a major actor in the process of European integration with much greater weight than its size might otherwise suggest.  The previous semester has undoubtedly been a difficult one, especially due to the severe worsening of the migrant crisis and the terror attacks in Paris. I hope that the recently approved measures aimed at strengthening external borders and combating internal radicalisation will very soon produce viable long-term results. The data protection package, the setting up of the European PNR system and the reform of the Court of Justice of the EU are also among the more positive outcomes. I can only regret that my own country, Latvia, was not able or willing enough to emerge with results of the same scale and long-term impact during its Presidency of the Council of the EU just before Luxembourg.

name: Gerolf Annemans (ENF).
text: The Luxembourg Presidency has ended like all these presidencies here - we hear it again today - with congratulations, with pats on the back and with cries of how good it all has been and how well we have all done. But above all, an ode to the progress that has been made, so you say it here. The European Union must always make progress, always more european union, and you have, unfortunately, succeeded in this.  You have put the fiscal Union, the tax union on track, probably out of frustration at the accusations surrounding the LuxLeaks scandal. You have also continued the open borders policy of the European Union more than ever before. So I can't possibly congratulate you. The only glancing of hope is that here with the Eurocrats in this hemisphere and among the EU fanatics in this hemisphere, you will be criticised for the fact that the Council has been too much on the brakes. I wish it had been true, if I had had a reason to congratulate you.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D).
text: Madam President, Prime Minister, Mr Juncker, ladies and gentlemen, Unlike some of my fellow Members, I would like to thank the Luxembourg Presidency for the cooperation it has had with this Parliament, but above all for the commitment and attention it has shown on issues that are fundamental to the future of the Union. First of all, I would like to highlight the important support for institutional issues. What we have heard this morning tells us that it is increasingly necessary in Europe to have leaders who have courage, distant vision and awareness of our common destiny. And you, Prime Minister, have shown us this morning once again.  At the same time, I would like to highlight the work that has been done to deepen the social dimension of the Union, for example to include social parameters in the construction of economic and monetary union. This has not yet been achieved, but progress has been made in the right direction and we are counting on your willingness to continue.  Finally, I believe that the work done to make the issue of refugees and migrants common is essential, and the July agreements were a fundamental step towards having a common policy in this area, which the next Presidency will, however, have to implement. We must now move towards a single common security and defence policy, it is – I believe – more Europe that we need and not less Europe, as some colleagues continue to call for.

name: Andreas Schwab (PPE).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which I would like to take a positive view of the Luxembourg Presidency from three points of view. The first is that I would like to congratulate you, Prime Minister, and your staff, for having managed, with real brilliance, perhaps from the tradition of a slightly smaller country in the European Union, to reach a compromise for the European IT security structure. A compromise that was not easy, because we have, of course, together – Council and Parliament – significantly improved the Commission's proposal. I have to say that the President of the Commission was not jean-Claude Juncker at the time. And we have succeeded in creating a genuine European proposal that adds value to European rules for cross-border infrastructure in the digital age. It was not easy, i thank you for that. Secondly, the issue of tax policy has already been raised on several occasions. In fact, the Luxembourg Presidency has been somewhat overshadowed by this. The conclusion we must draw is that we must look at how we can combine Member States' competence for tax policy with a need for European solidarity. All those who have now strongly criticised the Luxembourg Presidency and Luxembourg in this House must be careful, because they do not know whether the European Commission will not discover their country any distant day and classify fiscal independence not as independence, but as non-solidarity behaviour. I am, of course, also very pleased, Mr Bettel, that it was not necessary, after your election, to have a special summit in Brussels with the President of the Commission from Luxembourg.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D).
text: – Mr President, there has been talk in this debate of the achievements of the Luxembourg Presidency, but not enough of the issues which are dragging its feet and are blocked in the Council, not only for more than a long year, but for several years. This is the case with the proposal for a Directive on combating fraud affecting the financial interests of the European Union through criminal law, which unfortunately could not be unlocked in the Luxembourg Presidency. The key issue is the discussion on value added tax, which the Council considers to belong to the Member States, while the Commission and the European Parliament, above all, consider it to be a major resource of the European Union. This is supported by a recent judgment of the Court of Justice of the European Union: the judgment in Taricco, delivered in December, which determines that fraud in the interests of the European Union must be prosecuted through criminal law by the Member States. This has to have a consequence and an impact on the proposal for a Directive on combating fraud affecting the financial interests of the European Union (the 'PIF Directive') and, therefore, we are urging that trio dynamic, which now links with the Dutch Presidency, that this proposal for a Directive for the protection of the Union's financial interests should be unlocked.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Mr President, the Luxembourg Presidency's handling of the refugee crisis is a monument to failure since, through its manipulations, it has turned Greece into a warehouse of souls. Thousands of refugees and illegal immigrants are now in the Aegean islands and other parts of Greece. The policy of the famous 'relocation' of 160,000 refugees has failed, Prime Minister of Luxembourg, Mr Juncker. Only a few refugees have been moved through this system. According to calculations, by December it was only a hundred and eighty-four.  What about Turkey? You are supporting Turkey, although it is well known that Turkey and the Turkish leadership are encouraging slave trade. You have not taken action despite the complaints that exist, despite the evidence we have. At the same time, what you are doing by promoting the new Frontex is to create a mechanism that has the potential for operational intervention and action above and beyond the will of states and governments, which violates Greece's sovereign rights and automatically turns it into a protectorate.

name: Pervenche Berès (S&D).
text: Mr President, Mr Bettel, Mr Juncker, you are both members of a country which is fundamentally driven by community spirit and you have been extremely mobilised during this period to ensure that the Union makes progress in the fight against terrorism, the PNR affair was an element on this path. But, in your mind, don't you think we need to go beyond that? Should we not allow real cooperation between the intelligence services to finally take place? And, above all, should we not work hard to combat the financing of terrorism, an issue which, if I remember correctly, was considered an absolute priority by the Americans after 9/11 and which, finally, is now mentioned as a priority only by my country, France? Prepaid cards, for example, which are one of the most practical aspects for our citizens, are also a formidable weapon for terrorists.  So, Mr Bettel, as the outgoing presidency, are you going to leave this torch as a legacy to the Dutch Presidency? Mr Juncker, what are you prepared to do to really tackle this essential aspect of the conditions for the development of terrorism, unfortunately, on our territory?

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – A Uachtaráin, go raibh maith agat as ucht mé a ghlaoch. Cheapas nach nglaofaí orm. They say in English that the best goods come in small parcels. That applies normally to people like myself, I can say tongue in cheek, but can also apply to countries. In this regard, it fits the bill for Luxembourg – one of the smallest, but at the same time, most central and most committed Member States of the European Union. I would like to compliment them on the excellent job they did over the last six months. They made wonderful progress in many areas and worked very efficiently, particularly in the area in which I was involved – data protection trilogues.  I must say that Laura Wagner, who represented the Council, was very confident, competent, fair and firm and I think that at the end of the day we did succeed in getting the Data Protection Regulation finalised. While not everybody is happy, that is probably a good outcome for a regulation. We have done it and I have no doubt it will stand the test of time. Former Commissioner Reding, who initiated it, is also, of course, from Luxembourg.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI).
text: Mr President, with all due respect to you, I would like to stress that the unregistered MEMBERS of the European Parliament have not been elected in a different way than all other Members. Unfortunately, in the process of 'catch the eye', we never get airtime. Already, our time as unregistered is very limited. It has also been observed that they take the floor in 'catch the eye' always themselves and ourselves from the political groups and we are excluded. Thank you and I think you should take up the matter.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: I am sorry, sir, that there have been no speeches from non-attached Members for the catch-the-eye procedure. For the non-attached Members, the floor has been given to Mr Balczé. In this respect, your criticism is not true.

name: Costas Mavrides (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I am going to discuss something that we have all observed over the last few months, which is the persistent, intensive defiance by Erdoğan and Turkey, its refusal to implement its obligations with regard to basic and fundamental human rights and the rule of law, the continued occupation of Cyprus and, of course, the ongoing attack against its own people. I am referring to the academics, to the Kurds in the Kurdish provinces of Turkey, and so on. My question is very simple, and refers to the Commission itself: do you think that our policy towards Erdoğan over the last few months has been effective? Is it based on the principles of the European Union and morals, or on something else?

name: Jean-Claude Juncker
text: President der Kommission. Herr President! Es wurden nicht irrsinnig viele Fragen an die Europeische Kommission gerichtet, sodass ich mich auch mit den wenigen, die an uns gestellt wurden, nicht allzu lange besch-ftigen muss, weil die meisten Bemerkungen, die gemacht wurden, sich eigentlich durch Unfl-tigke Insofern und weil ich schon den au-ergew-hnlichen Vorteil hatte, 'fters darauf eingehen zu derfen, erspare ich mir und Ihnen dies fer heute ausnahmsweise einmal. I would like to answer a couple of questions that have been addressed to the Commission, including the one relating to the cooperation between the secret services. It's a real problem, a real subject and we're not really moving forward. It would seem that the secret services are so secretive that we cannot see their way and their mode of cooperation. Already in 2001, at the time of the events in New York and Washington, a European Council - under the presidency of Guy Verhofstadt - had concluded that there was a much needed enhanced cooperation between the secret services of the Alliance member countries and the Member States of the European Union. Nothing has been done, or very little, and we find day after day, as a result of the discoveries that are being made and the revelations that are coming to us, that there have been shortcomings in cooperation between the secret services, as well as between the police, and it is obvious that we must make an extra effort on this point. Second, we were asked about the fight against the financing of terrorism. This is an issue that deserves attention. The Commission will present an action plan to combat the financing of terrorism in February.

name: Xavier Bettel
text: President-in-Office of the Council. Mr President, first of all, I would like to thank all the Members of the European Parliament who have spoken on the Luxembourg Presidency. So there is a first question that has been asked about relations with the United Kingdom. We are waiting for a final text. This is not within the competence of the six-year presidency, and it is up to President Tusk to continue negotiations with the British government. It is therefore normal that I did not insist on this subject. Mr Papadimoulis, you have talked about migration problems, as have a number of other Greek colleagues. I agree that solidarity is not one-way, and the commitments that have been made by both must also be respected. Today, we have the impression that only Greece is the one that is coming up with the costs. We have taken the example of Germany today, each final country also has a very significant cost to cover. So we can't just talk about a country. But it is important today to say that we see that "hotspots" do not work ideally and that we must also help Greek colleagues to make it work more effectively. We have not left Greece alone, and Greece and the other countries concerned also know that the Luxembourg Presidency, for example, has asked the European Commission to see, with regard to the Stability Pact, whether there is a possibility for migration expenditure which could also be discussed. Ms. Le Pen arrived at 9:25 a.m., left at 9:47 a.m., so she did not hear my speech. I will make a copy of it, but I cannot answer it, because it is not there now. With regard to tax rulings, the Luxembourg Presidency could have gone further, in particular by taking into account all tax rulings, including exclusively national ones. For the terms that have been used for Luxembourg, I will not comment on them, it does not deserve it. Ms. Bérès, you asked a question about the financing of terrorism. I fully agree that this must be a priority for 2016, and Luxembourg fully supports it as well. As far as the PNR is concerned, President Juncker has just said that cooperation between the intelligence services must exist and must work. We're talking about it. It would be important to move forward. Finally, with regard to the question of THE Member of Parliament, Mr. Lopez Aguilar: yes, VAT fraud should be criminalised. Mr. Speaker, let me just say that I want to thank you for the praise that has been given to the government and to the public servants. Of course, some would have preferred us to go further, while others felt that we had gone too far. Above all, we have succeeded in doing something which today is one of the great problems we have both within our countries and within the Union. These are, Mr President, the bridges that are much weakened, whether between nationalities, ages, religions, citizens or generations. I therefore think it is very important to rebuild these bridges between us, at home, and also between ourselves in the Union. I wish the Presidency of the Netherlands, in any case, good luck in continuing in this direction. We need it.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The debate is closed. Written declarations (Article 162 OF the CRP)

name: David McAllister (PPE)
text: in writing. – The Luxembourg Presidency contributed in an impressive way to the European Union’s enlargement policy. Under its Presidency, the first negotiation chapters in the EU-accession process with Serbia have been opened. This was another important step for the country on its path towards the European Union and a well-deserved recognition of the progress made over the past months. The European Parliament, the European Commission and the Member States have always stressed that in order to move towards the opening of the first chapters, parallel and sustainable progress in the framework of the dialogue with Kosovo and rule of law issues is needed. The opening of the first chapters under the Luxembourg Presidency sends the clear signal that EU accession is a comprehensible and transparent process. On 25 August, Serbia reached key agreements with Kosovo on the establishment of the Association/Community of Serb majority municipalities in Kosovo, and on energy, telecoms and the bridge in Mitrovica. On 14 December the country reaped the fruits when the first negotiation chapters were opened.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. – I welcome the Luxembourg Presidency and all the work they have done in the last 6 months. The pressure on the European Union, on our citizens and governments has increased dramatically since you have taken over the presidency. Europe had to face the worst ever refugee and humanitarian crisis, inhuman efforts to keep Greece away from bankruptcy and in the euro, talks about a potential BREXIT, terrorist attacks, the growing problem of radicalisation and all that topped with an extremely hostile attitude in many Member States forcing governments to close down their borders and to threaten the very existence of the Schengen Agreement. This is a crucial time for Europe to determine its future direction, a direction that will lead the EU and its citizens towards more integration or more disintegration! Therefore, I think that the Presidency lacked the adequate political will and leadership skills to push Member States towards a common European narrative and to help bridge the differences and growing polarity in Europe on all those urgent issues, starting with the migration crisis.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – At the end of another rotating presidency, the same policies and, of course, the same problems affect Europe, its people and its workers persist. In the face of the disastrous effects of austerity, we are witnessing a flight forward, with the deepening of the most harmful aspects of economic integration. At the same time, this EU is totally insensitive and ineffective in the face of the pcry of refugees fleeing an EU-backed war. In tax matters, this presidency, the responsibility of a country with a sinister record on the promotion of fraud and tax evasion, we have continued to assist in the mechanisms of concealment of all relevant and necessary information to promote a consequent fight against tax havens and other tax evasion tools. In this sense, the balance can only be negative. Of course, it does not surprise us, since we do not see ourselves in this process of capitalist integration, which promotes the concentration of wealth at the expense of exploitation and impoverishment.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D)
text: in writing. – The Luxembourg Presidency faced a very difficult political context. The effort to maintain lines of dialogue between all European countries and the European institutions in responding to the challenges posed by migration and refugee flows should be highlighted. There have been progress in cooperation with a view to common security, while addressing threats to the free movement of people and goods. These results are also the result of a good relationship between the Presidency and the European Parliament. In the area of creating conditions for financial robustness in the European Union and in particular in the Euro zone, the Luxembourg Presidency has not been achieved. The Banking Union did not start with the structure and resources needed to cope with the difficulties of the European financial system, regulation has shown signs of great fragility and the fight against evasion and aggressive fiscal policies has not advanced. The Luxembourg Presidency failed where it had an obligation to have succeeded. strengthening the transparency and robustness of the European financial system and its relationship with economic competitiveness and job creation.

name: Presidente. –
text: The next item is the report by Kaja Kallas and Evelyne Gebhardt, on behalf of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy and the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection, on 'Towards an Act on the Digital Single Market' (2015/2147(INI)) (A8-0371/2015). Let's wait for this photograph to be there and then we're going to take it back. We salute President Junker.

name: Kaja Kallas
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, first of all I would like to thank all those who were involved in this report, especially the co-rapporteur Ms Gebhardt and all the shadow rapporteurs. I am very happy that this report clearly states that we need pro-innovation and pro-digital policies in Europe. If we want to give companies the chance to innovate, we have to give a clear signal that we support innovation. Companies are very often advised to let go of their old products in order to make room for new ones. I think this also applies to us. If the rules are no longer fit for purpose, then we have to let them go and simply review them.  I am happy that this report gives strong support to the sharing economy, but it also expresses concerns at the existing barriers that are created by Member States, hindering its growth instead of adapting their existing framework to ensure competition. We must keep in mind that the big multinational companies have the tools to comply with the different sets of rules, but Europe’s economy is based on small- and medium-sized companies, and these are the companies that are hurt the most by the barriers. I expect the Commission to be proactive in keeping the integrity of the single market. This is not only needed for the sharing economy, but also for the next wave of innovation, such as big data and the internet of things. If Europe does not have a plan for this, if we fail to have a joint approach on standardisation, cyber-security and also the free flow of data, then we will miss out on its potential. It is vital for growth and competitiveness.  I also expect the Commission to work hard to preserve the internet as an open and neutral platform for innovation and communication. By clearly backing the limited liability of the intermediaries, we state that internet providers should not do the work of law enforcement agents. It is crucial to prevent censorship and also to protect freedom of expression, but everything relies on the empowered users, which is also an important aspect of this report.  We need to make sure that citizens have better control over the use of their data and that switching between service providers is facilitated, but also that users are pushed to have basic levels of security such as end-to-end encryption and software updates. It is our responsibility to empower citizens, but it is certainly not our responsibility to tell people how they should live their lives, what to do and which services they should use. This is why our Group is strongly against paragraph 8, and I hope that colleagues can support our Amendment 24, because at the end of the day it is the individual who decides when to put down their phone. Instead, we should focus on how to make life easier for the citizens, and e-government is a good example of that. The principle of providing information to the public authorities only once is a good example of this. It is so important that Parliament is asking for it to be applied.  There is so much to tell on such a broad report, but I will stop here. Thank you again. I look forward to the debate.

name: Evelyne Gebhardt
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, I would like to thank the Thank you for the good cooperation to Mrs Kallas. I also find it remarkable that the sharing economy has now taken on such a great importance in her speech, when she did not want to talk about it at the beginning. It turns out, then, that discussions are always very good. I would also like to start with this. This is a subject area that is totally absent from the European Commission's communication. And in this area, labour law, social law – when we think of crowdworking and so on – is an issue that we must not neglect, in which we really need to move forward. Ladies and gentlemen, it is very important that we establish this digital single market very well and very Europeanly, because this internal market is simply boundless. When it comes to purchases, we say very clearly: yes, we think it is good that the European Commission made proposals on 9 December on how we can move forward in this area. However, and we will decide this afterwards, this does not mean that we will accept that there are different rights for offline and online purchases. This is only a cause for confusion for consumers and, above all, for small and medium-sized enterprises, which we want to support in these areas. Here, too, we cannot proceed as the European Commission imagines. We will have to work very this once again. Ladies and gentlemen, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. Where we agree with the European Commission, where we would also like to thank Mr Ansip very much, is that we must combat geo-blocking. It is absolutely unacceptable for citizens to be prevented from using the internal market because they have the wrong address, because they have the wrong nationality, or because their credit card has been issued in the wrong country. This is not the Europe of citizens, the Europe of freedom of movement that we need and that we want to take forward. Here, too, we will have to work very closely together in order to be able to move forward with everything that is possible. In the area of digital content, too, the fragmentation of the law that we have is unacceptable. That is why we must ensure that some of the business models that we currently have lead to monopolies, because there can be no competition at European level. And we also want citizens to be able to use it throughout the European Union simply and simply, if they have bought a subscription somewhere. Otherwise, we will not have a European Union, no freedom of movement, which is so important to us and which we always say must be taken forward. Another area – I cannot mention all of us in four minutes, but I am counting on my fellow Members: there was also a point of contention in our discussions, that was the principle of electronic administration, of public services. We must ensure that we really take forward the simplifications that the digital world brings us. However, the once-only principle is a principle that needs to be reconsidered very carefully, because it is also a matter of data protection. There will also be constitutional problems in some states, and we will then have to proceed very, very carefully in these areas. Yes to simplification, but in such a way that the data protection and the constitutions of the Member States in these areas are still genuinely respected. We still have a lot of work to do. Unfortunately, my time is already over. We would have had much more to say about this report. However, I would like to thank you once again for the good cooperation with all the rapporteurs, shadow rapporteurs and the staff who have also brought their customs. I have to say that the work was really fun because it was so complicated.

name: Renato Soru
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in the ECON Committee we have tried very extensively on this very broad issue to focus on a few points, also considering the extraordinary economic importance of this sector, which can be worth over EUR 400 billion per year and has the capacity to create, it has been estimated, around EUR 3 million and 800 thousand new jobs in Europe. We have focused on a number of key issues such as ensuring equal access; ensuring that governance systems around Europe and services to citizens are primarily digital according to a policy we have called digital first; ensuring tax harmonisation, which is certainly a priority if we really want a normal trend in business location and e-commerce growth; ensure that the delay in the development of digital skills, which are so important both on the fruition side and on the production side of digital services, is overcome. We have focused on supporting innovation, on innovators who then have a responsibility to create new businesses in Europe or to grow them, some possibly at important levels, capable of being a beacon, even visible in the global market. We have drawn attention to the danger of new monopolies being so easy and thriving so easily, also due to the very specific characteristics of networked services and digital services. I'm done with my minute.

name: Jutta Steinruck
text: Rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs. Mr President, I would like to thank the If it had been for the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, we would have had much stronger emphasis in this report on the digital labour market. Its consequences for our society, its opportunities, are clearly identified. I would like to express my thanks to Evelyne Gebhardt for having really thought very much about the issue of the digital labour market and its consequences for social security in her area, and for fighting very hard for it. It is clear that digital change is not sustainable, but it is manifold. However, clear analyses must also be carried out. What are the implications for the work of the future, as well as for future social systems? The Commission still has a lot of homework to do. We need to think about education and training, about lifelong learning, about institutionalised lifelong learning. We have to see: crowd working, the sharing economy, what impact does this have today? What do we also need to change with new legislative frameworks or legislation so that we can continue to ensure good and sustainable jobs in the digital age in the future?

name: Merja Kyllönen
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Transport and Tourism. – Mr President, my warmest thanks go to the rapporteurs and to all those who have been involved in the preparation of the report. It is good to see that Parliament is able to find common guidelines on an important issue. Transport is one of the sectors to which digitalisation has a great deal to offer. I believe that it will make day-to-day transport and logistics smoother, safer, more resource-efficient and more sustainable. Although the transport sector has been improving the collection and usability of traffic data for a long time, this decade is an unprecedented redefinition of mobility, supply and demand as various mobility services based on digital platforms and traffic automation arrive. I welcome this development and want to ensure that steps towards digital, digital transport and service are made on customers' terms through common rules of play and controlled practices.

name: Petra Kammerevert
text: Rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Culture and Education. Mr President, I would like to thank the The profound change caused by digitalisation can also be observed well in radio and television and is far from over.  Mobile phones and the Internet have pushed young people's television use into third place in the preferred media. Audiovisual content is more in demand than ever, has gained in suggestion and opinion-forming power, but is increasingly being disseminated via the Internet.  If we want public and private and television providers to continue to be relevant to public opinion, to contribute to the promotion of freedom of expression and media pluralism, we must further open up access to the non-linear online world.  That is why the revision of the audiovisual media services directive is essential and overdue. Our important key points in this report are laid down by a large majority.  But we also need to ensure that digitalisation is a success for the diverse cultural and creative industries. The key to this is copyright, which properly and fairly enshrines the change in value creation and strikes a fair balance between users, intermediaries and authors. Flat-rate demands are rather not appropriate here. Finally, we also call for a much greater commitment from everyone to the development of media literacy, which must be a cross-generational task, despite the emphasis on young people.

name: Ангел Джамбазки
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Legal Affairs. – Dear Mr President, honourable Members, as rapporteur for the opinion on the Digital Single Market in the Committee on Legal Affairs, I would like to congratulate my rapporteur and my ECR group colleague Vicky Ford on the hard work on this dossier.  Thanks to our combined efforts to achieve a targeted and balanced solution to the Digital Single Market Strategy, we now have a report outlining not only the main priorities, such as the portability of online content and innovation, but also issues that need more analysis and discussion. As regards copyright, the European Commission's proposal gives us a good basis and proper guidance. However, there is still much work ahead of us to avoid over-regulation of issues that need ever more in-depth analysis. And we don't have to rush just to satisfy someone's expectations or someone's external pressure. I believe that the outcome of today's vote will reflect precisely this, and just as in the legal committee, the report will enjoy great support.

name: Michał Boni
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs. – Mr President, I would like to thank everyone for the report, which is well-structured and with a balanced approach, including in the area of the competences of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, and with a clear message that we need digital harmonisation in Europe. What does a ‘balanced approach’ mean? It means that we have not achieved the real turning point, to say that we need stronger solutions, more harmonised in some areas, as decisions on 5G spectrum development and text and data mining development have been scarce. On the other hand, however, we have made progress in the right direction, have begun working faster on the e—Privacy Directive and have established equilibrium between privacy protection, security needs and business opportunities in the era of big data. It shows that we understand how important data privacy is in the light of the data-driven economy. In that area, we need future—proof solutions. Now we can start work on issues such as how to share data, what ownership of data means and how to make data much more secure, also using the solutions of security and privacy by design.

name: Andrus Ansip
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, the European Parliament’s own-initiative report on the Digital Single Market is a significant document which covers a wide variety of important themes for Europe.
