We need to ensure European people, consumers, companies and industry can benefit from a truly functioning Digital Single Market. This is a top priority of this Commission. It is also an area where Europe and the European project have many positive stories to tell. That is why working closely and early enough with the co-legislators is key for success. I would like to thank the rapporteurs and all other Members of the European Parliament involved in this report. The Digital Single Market strategy identifies 16 key initiatives. In December 2015, we already presented a Communication on copyright with a legislative proposal on cross-border portability. This means that we want to ensure that subscribers to online content services can access what they have paid for while temporarily present in another Member State.  The copyright communication sets out political objectives and areas of action, with concrete measures and a timeline. We have also made legislative proposals for new rules to improve protection for consumers who buy digital content or goods online across the European Union and to help businesses to expand their online sales. As you can see, we are already delivering important elements of the Digital Single Market. This will continue through 2016. In addition to a common and comprehensive solution to geo-blocking, we want to simplify VAT payments for companies and also promote efficient and affordable parcel delivery. Geo-blocking goes against the very idea of a single market, without borders or discrimination based on nationality or place of residence. Beyond consumers, start-ups and SMEs, we also want to support European industry in embracing digital transformation. This is key for growth and jobs. Industry is a pillar of the European economy. It is also important to focus on the skills of the workforce. In the next month, we will review the rules which apply to telecoms, audiovisual and e-privacy. We will improve cybersecurity, leverage cloud computing activities, support the development of a European Science Cloud and enable free flow of data. I am looking forward to hearing your views during the debate and to working with you to make the Digital Single Market a reality, and a success story for Europe.

name: Henna Virkkunen
text: On behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, I would also like to thank all the rapporteurs and the other committees for their very good cooperation during this process. The EPP supports this report and wants to speed up the digital single market in Europe. We attach great importance to it from the point of view of competitiveness, growth and jobs.  We are worryingly losing out on Asia and the USA in the digital economy. Europe needs more investment in high-speed networks. We must ensure that new digital services are on the same page as traditional products and services. This applies, for example, to electronic books. They must be taxed in the same way as a traditional book.  We must also create a regulatory environment that encourages the development of new innovations and services in Europe. We must ensure that we do not create too much regulation, but that we are agile and flexible enough to take advantage of all these new opportunities that the Internet brings. I am particularly pleased that Parliament, in its own report, wants to get rid of unjustified geo-blocking, that is, the use of land restrictions. It is important for consumers and businesses that digital services should also move across borders in Europe, just like other services.  A digital single market with a population of 500 million is a great opportunity for European businesses, and we should now encourage all SMEs to tackle this and also ensure that industry becomes digitalised and exploits these opportunities.

name: Presidente. –
text: We are at a stage where the political groups are expressing their opinion, so asking questions, practising the logic of the blue card, at this stage it is truly anachronistic, we are waiting for the debate and of course there will be the blue card procedure.

name: Miapetra Kumpula-Natri
text: On behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, the European Union is facing challenges: where is investment from? Where is Europe growing from? Where do Europeans get jobs? Where are the more functional public services? And where do European young people believe in the future?  In the midst of these challenges, opportunities must be seizened, and here we have one possibility. For the S&D Group, it is an opportunity to create new jobs and growth through the digital market. Over the past few years, the digital economy has grown clearly faster than many other sectors. High-quality jobs have been created in the digital sector. In this respect, the Commission's priorities are in line. The position now taken by the committees sees the digital single market strategy as an opportunity to create a fairer and safe digital society. We can bridge the digital divide that has already emerged - be it infrastructure or the skills of citizens. All citizens must have access to the digital service – both public and private services must be available. We must ensure that digitalisation does not become a new area of social exclusion; Europe must climb back to the forefront of digitalisation with the fifth generation of 5G telecommunications networks. Sensible solutions must aim to make Europe the most advanced and secure infrastructure in the world. The package now being adopted supports the emergence of European innovation, the construction of critical infrastructure in Europe and the guarantee of a secure and open Internet for citizens and businesses.  European funds play an important role, both in research and development and in accelerating investment in infrastructure where the market does not cover connectivity. European solutions are needed, because what good is the internal market or digital services if they are always at the borders of countries. European content must be made available to Europeans, and we believe that fair value added distribution can also be found through new applications.  The potential of digitalisation must also be exploited in industry. Investments in high-speed networks lay the foundations as the industrial internet and the Internet of Things bring new solutions to production and everyday life. In order to succeed in international competition, existing European industry must also become digitalised. According to the Commission's research, companies doing so are moving fewer jobs abroad or letting people go.  As an engineer, I could only talk about technological change, but digitalisation is first and foremost a change in society that requires strong political leadership.  Parliament is heavily involved in the creation of digital society rules through a number of new legislative projects. And what is important to us in the S&D Group is that digitalisation is a natural new beginning for growth, health services, education, the development of peripheral regions, forms of energy efficiency services and so on. It is important to do this in cooperation with the rest of society, so that change is safe for everyone.

name: Vicky Ford
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, if we are to succeed in a competitive world, we must embrace the benefits of the digital revolution. The sharing economy brings huge opportunities and platforms which enable economic growth and help us to address societal issues and even to help solve environmental problems. Yes, there are changes. Traditional distinctions between businesses and consumers and between market incumbents and new entrants are evolving and mutating. This brings new challenges, but any rules we set must help underpin the digital economy, not undermine it. We should work with existing rules where possible, address the risks and not put a handbrake on the innovators or add more costs. Most of Parliament’s report follows this positive tone, which I support. Unfortunately, some of the Commission’s recent actions are not quite so sensible. Their proposal for digital purchases creates a two—tier structure between online and offline sales and, just at a time when we wanted to build consumer trust, this risks creating confusion. Data is key. We do need clear rules and we need to be able to harness the benefits from big data, whilst also respecting privacy. But I am a bit concerned about the impact of our new regulation on small businesses and I know that late—night, last—minute rushed negotiations are not the way to achieve clear, coherent legislation. Our single market has 500 million consumers in 28 countries. They want to be able to trade online with companies all across the world. The digital world is a borderless world. We need to work together across Europe and across the world as well. Protectionism will not work.

name: Dita Charanzová
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, just as the Industrial Revolution once made us leaders in the world, I think the Digital Single Market can help create more growth and jobs in Europe. This digital revolution is in fact the new industrial revolution and, just as we feared the unknown then, we see fear now in the voices of digital protectionism and the conflicts between traditional industries and new innovative business models, and between those who can adapt and those who worry they might be left behind. But today, if we want to continue our standard of living, we must, as a society, embrace the digital revolution that is happening all around us. We must take steps to create a true Digital Single Market. We must support a policy where innovation, new business models, new products and new supply chains are welcomed. We need a policy that acknowledges that platforms and shared economy are not fringe parts of our economy, but the future engine of it. We must accept that the analogue days of protected state-owned industries and over—regulated business and consumers markets are over. Commissioner, in your Digital Single Market strategy you have set out sixteen ways to help Europe succeed in this digital revolution. I can confirm that you have the full support of the ALDE Group to get this done. We must fully implement the whole strategy, because otherwise Europe will fall behind. Whether we succeed or fail relies solely on us, and we can act now. I have no doubt that our vote tomorrow will confirm the political mandate for the Commission to use all its power in this field. Commissioner, please use your political capital, because we are already late.

name: Cornelia Ernst
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the First of all, I would also like to thank the rapporteurs for their fair cooperation – and that is what we must do here. It is not an easy report, but I wonder whether the Commission's plans are really sufficient to ensure equal access to the Digital Single Market for all. That is still open to my terms and that is what we have to fight for. There is always talk of citizens' trust in the digital environment. That is certainly important. But that is not a matter of course. Our aim is to create confidence in data security for consumers. Trust, if you like, in the honesty of the provider and in the protection of its fundamental rights. I believe that this must be felt everywhere if we really want to develop the internal market fairly for all those involved. Three things are important to us. Firstly, we believe that the dinosaur geoblocking belongs in the museum, and completely. We believe that this does not, for example, ensure cultural diversity, but on the contrary prevents it when we think, for example, of minorities and access to TV channels. Geoblocking leads to the end of illegal downloads being made – which is another reason why it has to go. Secondly, we have been committed to free software from the very beginning. Unfortunately, this has not been reflected. However, it would be important to promote this, to promote it more, because it will be associated with greater control, including for users. Thirdly, broadband expansion is important to us. A great deal needs to be done here, not only for the big ones, but also for the little ones. Last but not least: Without consistent net neutrality, everything is ultimately nothing.

name: Julia Reda
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, the Commission has titled this project ‘The Digital Single Market’ but we must not lose sight of the reason for tearing down the digital borders and for promoting the exchange of knowledge, goods and services in Europe. It is to empower people and to ensure that the technological projects of globalisation benefit all, and not just the few. Parliament recalls in this report that is not just the market and profit-seeking enterprises that can provide solutions. The strategy will not be comprehensive if it does not take into account solutions based on the commons. There is open-source software that improves interoperability, security and control over technology. Community WiFi projects provide connectivity, even in remote areas, and crowd-funding allows communities to fund innovation without the dependence on big investors. Finally, net neutrality and universal internet access are the basis for the Digital Single Market to function, so some regulation of the market is necessary to ensure that new technologies in commercial undertakings safeguard fundamental rights. But it is not necessary to reinvent the wheel when dealing with online intermediaries. In many areas, such as liability, we already have functioning legislation. We must recognise that the internet is more than just a big shopping centre. The successful digital strategy emphasises the strength of the internet: the free exchange of knowledge and collaboration. In summary, we must complement the digital single market with a digital commons strategy. This report makes a good step in this direction, and I would like to thank the rapporteurs for their important and collaborative work in this area.

name: David Borrelli
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, this report sets the stage for a whole series of legislative proposals that will arrive this year. My personal judgment is that we could certainly have been a little more ambitious: we are convinced that in the creation of the digital single market the citizen must be put at the centre. And if the European Parliament, which is the only institution directly elected by the citizens, does not do so, we cannot expect this to be done by the European Commission and the Council. Pending the proposal for a review of telecommunications, which will be an essential element of this strategy, it is now essential to be ambitious and to do a good job, starting with the Commission's proposal on the sale of goods online. The full potential of online sales is not yet fully exploited in the European Union, only 14% of Europe's small and medium-sized enterprises use the Internet as a sales channel. We must work to ensure that citizens and businesses can buy and sell online more easily and with confidence across Europe. This is a new frontier for our businesses and a key step in creating new jobs.

name: Mylène Troszczynski
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, we all agree that digital development represents a strong growth potential for our SME/SMEs, and if European cooperation can promote the economic context, then we say yes. But, as usual, you are wrong in trying once again to silence national interests by imposing on Member States the integration of the single market and its digital component.  Apart from the fact that we doubt that the well-being of Europeans, especially the French, depends on the creation of a European "big data" or by the deregulation of services, we are also very concerned for the security of the strategic data of states and the personal data of users.  All the amendments that we have tabled are in line with what I have just outlined and we hope that they will receive broad support in the vote. So yes to European cooperation, to consumer protection, to efficient and accessible services, to logistics cooperation, to ICT development. But not to the supremacy of federalist interests over national interests, which is part of a political, economic and financial strategy.  The future of Europe depends on a balanced cooperation between nations and not on their dismantling.

name: Janusz Korwin-Mikke (NI).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I just draw attention to the horrific gibberish and explain the vagueness of the notion, because every market is single and the goods sold on it do not have to be uniform. If I read, for example, in the introduction, point 1.1, that the creation of the Digital Single Market can revive the Single Market, that is nonsense, because if we revive the market, it means that it exists and, as it exists, it cannot be created. This is EU-wide gibberish. We read, for example, that the internet has a huge impact on women's emancipation. Why is nothing said about homosexuals, zoophiles or redheads? Robins, as you know, are fake, and on the internet you can not see whether there are or not orched, so the internet also favors the emancipation of redheads. Ladies and see, this is gibberish – I repeat – but we will vote in favour, because the free market is the most important for us.

name: Andreas Schwab (PPE).
text: Mr President, Mr Vice-President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has all been very much about. I too would, of course, like to thank all the Members of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats, on behalf of the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats, who have worked very well on this report, which was very broad at the beginning, and who have reached a real compromise that can ultimately take everyone with them. It is important that, at the beginning of the debate on the Digital Single Market here in the European Parliament, we make it clear once again that we are talking about an approach that will have an impact on almost all policy areas. That is why we in the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats have attached importance to ensuring that all the committees that wish to take part in this work have their place in this report. That is why amendments have been adopted from all areas, which, admittedly, made the report a little broader than it was planned in the end, but which have helped to ensure that all the committees, all those involved, feel taken with them. On data protection, on the use of data: big data has already been clearly illuminated by Mr Boni from our point of view. We need a genuine digital single market that actually creates all opportunities for consumers across borders, but also for workers. Secondly, there is the impact on tax law, on the world of work, and, of course, on the question: 'What is innovation?' I would like to make it quite clear here that, of course, innovation is also linked to disruption, i.e. the demolition of existing markets, but disruption alone is not yet innovation. We will have to have some important discussions on this. Geoblocking starts and will continue with tax law. I hope that we can pass on the similarities that we have achieved in this report.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Thank you, Mr Schwab. I ask for your indulgence. I took over and just cuddled up in the speaking times.

name: Dan Nica (S&D).
text: – Mr President, in order to have a truly integrated digital market and to make progress in the digital field, investments in infrastructure and in fast and very fast communications networks, including in rural and remote areas, are needed. I also strongly support the prevention of unjustified geographical blocking. Ambitious and specific measures are needed to improve access to goods and services by eliminating unjustified geographical blockage practices and price discrimination based on geographical location or nationality. A first step towards stopping geo-blocking is the Commission's proposal, which aims to strengthen portability and interoperability, in order to stimulate the free movement of legally acquired and available content or services, as well as the accessibility and cross-border operation of subscriptions. I see no contradiction between the principle of territoriality and measures to remove barriers to content portability. The Digital Single Market report is just the beginning in the direction of eliminating geo-blocking, and we support you with all ... (The President interrupted the speaker)

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which Before I entered politics two years ago, I spent my entire professional life in this industry. When I set up home terminals for the employees of IBM-Deutschland home terminals 25 years ago, this was strongly opposed by trade unions, churches, but also by politicians and the media.  It was always said at the time that people had to be protected from self-exploitation. Let me then make it quite clear that this report also had to swallow some toads – as good as it is otherwise. In the preparation, there have been time and again Members who have said that people want to be more and more involved and less and less self-determined. I think that's completely wrong in this industry in particular. I believe that private initiative leads to more creativity than government patronising, and that too many regulations actually harm our businesses. If we ask ourselves today why digital Europe has long lagged behind the United States and, more recently, Asia, the answer is that we have not trusted our citizens enough and have given our businesses too little freedom. Only with freedom and self-responsibility will we be able to experience the creativity we need in the Digital Single Market.  Incidentally, and here comes my ceterum censeo, I believe that the single euro must be abolished. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Liisa Jaakonsaari (S&D)
text: blue card question. – You said that Europe has lagged behind in digital development because we have had too little confidence in businesses and individuals. I don't think that's the point, but a pretty general analysis is that we're lying behind because all 28 Member States have their own data protection and other digital regulations.  Do you not understand this importance of the European perspective in global competition?

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. I do believe that you are right that the fragmentation of the European internal market is one of the reasons, but that is not the main reason. The main reason is that here in Europe we have always believed too much in the state. I can no longer count the number of public funding programmes for information and communication technology in the last 30 years. All these European companies – take Nixdorf, take Olivetti, take Siemens, take Bull, take ICL – are all gone. But the Americans and the ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Yana Toom (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, we all agree that our life is turning increasingly digital. Electronic government and electronic commerce have become our everyday reality. Unfortunately, European legislation and policies are not always up to date, and some Member States are not doing very well. In my native country, Estonia, you may establish a company online within half an hour and administer it with the use of the internet from anywhere in the world. But online registration of companies is not yet available in all Member States and only handwritten signatures are accepted by many registers. In Estonia, digital signatures and digitalised documents are in use in almost all spheres of public life, but outside Estonian borders it is still limited, even in the European Union and even here in the European Parliament where we are discussing this extremely important topic. Commissioner Ansip listed 16 main directions to move on with this important issue, but we still need to address very basic issues in order to ensure the proper functioning of the digital single market.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President, the digital single market will unfortunately enlist new technologies to serve the interests of multinationals and large capital. Instead of the primary objective of prosperity and enhancing people's quality of life, the potential of technology will unfortunately be exploited mainly to increase business profits and competitiveness.  The reforms being promoted to complete the single digital market will have a particularly negative impact on small and medium-sized enterprises, labour rights and consumers themselves. It is therefore necessary to redefine the objectives of the digital agenda in order to put the interests of society at the heart. Our position is clear: the realisation of the digital market must contribute to the creation of new quality jobs and to the strengthening of labour and consumer rights. It is equally important to ensure both free and free access to the Internet and the protection of personal data.  Technology must also be used to help small and medium-sized enterprises, particularly in terms of their access to finance and their market position. The amendments tabled by the European United Left are also moving in this direction.

name: Indrek Tarand (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, as the President of the Estonian Union of Persons with Mobility Impairment and Vice-President of the Disability Intergroup in this Parliament, I am happy to see that some of the main concerns of persons with disabilities are addressed in this report. I am pleased to see that the report brings out accessibility and exclusion challenges faced by people with disabilities, as well as their integration into the labour market. Furthermore, the report rightly points out the deplorable fact that the Commission’s digital single market strategy for Europe takes no account of the need to ensure full, equal and unrestricted access for disabled people to all new digital technologies. There is one small caveat: the accessibility and interoperability aspect should have been emphasised more. For example, we can have brilliant reading software for the blind and visually impaired, but its use can be severely limited if it is not interoperable with most devices, websites, content, etc. This is one of the reasons why free and open standards should be used across all domains of a digital single market. Commissioner, this report has almost four and a half pages consisting solely of references to the former documents adopted by co-legislators, which might prove that successive Commissions do not use the full potential of those texts. Please try to make a difference this time.  (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: question by raising the blue card. – I thank the Chairman, I thank my colleague for accepting the question. Indeed, Estonia is one of the countries leading the way in E-services at all levels. I would like to know how it would help Member States that are less developed and less advanced, what mechanisms do they really converate and thus put this important topic of establishing a Digital Single Market and strengthening the Single Market as a whole into practice?

name: Indrek Tarand (Verts/ALE)
text: blue-card answer. – Thank you for this question. Actually, I am not the right person to answer it. Mr Ansip, who has been dealing with it as Prime Minister for almost a century – well, at least nine years – is perhaps better placed to reply, but for my part if  someone has an interest in this experience we have developed, come and ask, we never refuse to reply.

name: Marco Zullo (EFDD).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, thank you to the rapporteurs for the work they have done on this balanced and largely acceptable report. I believe it is essential that in our work we have identified three pillars to make what we can call 'digital citizenship' feasible. The first pillar is that of equality, that is, the possibility of giving the same rights to all users, whether they are moving online or offline and, in particular, we absolutely must and for this reason eliminate all that may be discrimination, especially geographical discrimination. The second pillar is participation, because we must ensure that citizens, administrations and businesses move by being able to exchange information and make this market effective. Finally, there is the concept of trust: we have put in the report various instruments for the citizen, the user, to move in this area, but we also want to stress that the existence of these instruments must be perceived.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has The digital economy is a hugely important area for growth and jobs in Europe. We are talking about growth potential of over EUR 400 billion and 3.8 million new jobs. That is why the rapporteurs are particularly grateful, because they have managed to take good account of this very complex and comprehensive issue, as well as the many committees that have been involved in this report, and for producing a very balanced and comprehensive report with which we can continue to work well. Allow me to make one or two points of criticism. On the one hand, this would be to regulate the ever-new anger, whether this is the liability standard for the field of e-commerce, whether it is geo-blocking, whether it is text and data mining, whether this is the ex ante regulation in the telecoms sector, whether this is the media framework for the 21st century or platforms. More regulation is not always better regulation. Before new regulation, let us take stock and evaluate it. A second area that is very important to me: competition and investment in the development of broadband infrastructure. More competition does not always lead to better ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Krišjānis Kariņš (PPE).
text: – Mr President, Commissioners, colleagues, i would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Sánchez-Ney Single digital market. Big names. We probably understand in this Chamber, but what do they really mean – these words?  We think practically – we can go to Munich, say, and buy a Munich white sausage. I can go to Riga, another can go to London, Stockholm, to Lisbon and there to eat it. It seems perfectly normal. At the same time, from Riga, I cannot enjoy it either in Munich, in London or in Dublin, with a paid subscription, say, on television or on the internet. Why?  With goods, we have greatly removed barriers, borders between Member States, but in the digital sphere, which will become increasingly important in our economy, we still have these barriers, which are largely based on copyright issues, including patents. So what do we have to achieve?  We need to break down these barriers, ensure that copyright and also patents are valid throughout Europe, not just in one Member State. Otherwise, it will be that to eat Munich sausages, we could only go to Munich. This seems absurd to us. It is equally absurd that in order to enjoy internet content, we must be in one country and we cannot be in the other country. Thank you for your attention. (The speaker agrees to answer the blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure).)

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Blue card question. - Mr President, I would like to thank you for your support. Although I would also like to ask my former colleagues in the People's Party whether there is a particular reason why you, although quite rightly and I agree that there are many elements of the digital market mentioned here in terms of the importance of this issue, are constantly leaving out the elements of education and education on the part of the People's Party, as if this were not important to you, I ask respectfully.

name: Krišjānis Kariņš (PPE)
text: answer to the blue card question. – Colleagues, thank you for your question. If we are talking about the single market, we are talking about the single market in the digital aspect. This is already the case, and on the part of the European People's Party, we are arguing that we need to break down barriers in all areas that restrict trade. So, in this case, we are debating the digital sphere today, which is very important. Of course, this is also very important in education. And we also have barriers in the market for goods and services. So, on the side of our faction, we are arguing that barriers need to be broken.

name: Lidia Joanna Geringer de Oedenberg (S&D).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by The creation of a fully integrated Digital Single Market is one of the main priorities of the current European Commission, arising from the need to make better use of the huge opportunities offered by digital technologies to create strong economic growth and jobs. It is estimated that this additional increase could amount to up to four hundred and fifteen billion euros, which would open the way for several hundred thousand new jobs. A barrier from the point of view of the Committee on Legal Remedies is the existing rigid national regulations in the telecommunications market and the lack of harmonisation of copyright law, in particular its exceptions and limitations. It is therefore necessary to modernise copyright rules in the light of the digital revolution and changes in consumer behaviour, creating a level playing field in which all economic operators offering their goods and services within the Union will be subject to the same harmonised rules, including data protection and consumer protection. Intensive efforts are also needed to promote an entrepreneurial culture and more innovative business models.

name: Daniel Dalton (ECR).
text: – Mr President, the digital revolution is here. It will transform every aspect of life in the same way the agricultural and industrial revolution transformed life before it. It will change the way we work, play and live, but to take advantage of it we need to recognise that we have a global market of 3 billion connected people. This is not about a European internal market; it is about a global market and therefore we should not be putting up new barriers. For example, this debate is streamed all over the world, yet content we buy online is blocked. Technologically, this is nonsense as you have to add something to the internet in order to block it. It feeds piracy and consumers do not understand it.  Therefore I welcome the portability proposals, but we do not need pan—European licences. We also need to support the sharing economy. People want to share. Let us let them share and build businesses which can go global, but let us be clear: for digital to work it needs to disrupt and challenge existing business models and vested interests. We should embrace and welcome this. The internet is global by default. Let us not cut Europe off: whether it is in cloud security, data or digital content or the sharing economy, the digital tsunami is coming. Let us embrace it.

name: Morten Helveg Petersen (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, let me first of all thank the two rapporteurs for the great work on this important file. With more and more Europeans now online, new problems arise. For example, how can we protect our data and information? How can we protect ourselves without compromising our fundamental rights and freedom of speech?  I am happy that the report emphasises the importance of encryption as a tool to provide privacy and to ensure a basic level of security. The report also calls for us to ensure that we prevent censorship and that we prevent compromising our freedom of speech on the internet by limiting the liability of service providers. We should not oblige service providers and platforms to constantly monitor their content for illegal content. Different platforms should not be substitutes for law enforcement authorities. We also have to remember that, even though we address the Digital Single Market of Europe, we do not limit our online behaviour and interaction to just European platforms. For precisely this reason, we have to ensure safe international data transfers. I have to emphasise that an agreement is urgently needed – not least with the Americans – on this topic, in order to create legal certainty for European consumers and businesses.

name: Jiří Maštálka (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, as has been stated, the Internet has become the most widely used means of communication. But the expansion of digital services often encounters numerous restrictions that hinder development. While our left-wing faction of the Confederal Group of the European United Left -Nordic Green Left generally supports the digital single market strategy, it also points to some of the problems that it will demand to be removed or mitigated. A sensitive issue is the protection of the personal data of consumers entering the digital market or when communicating with the state administration using the so-called eGovernment. The issue of digital market employees working from home without social-legal protection or the fact that strengthening the digital market will mean objectively greater replacement of human power, work with technology must not be left aside. In other words, the digital single market must also have a social dimension.

name: Michel Reimon (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I would like to make a point of something new at the late stage of the discussion. Namely, that we should not just have an economic discussion and not just an internal market discussion on this issue. It is not only about our rights as consumers, but also about our citizens' rights. When it comes to geo-blocking, the debate about whether European women can see content and content in every country can be not just an economic issue, not just a consumer protection issue. This is a question of censorship and free speech, whether we can see, read, hear or do anything else in all of Europe. We must be much more the representatives of civil rights on this issue, because the media world has changed. It used to be impossible to produce content and then stop individuals from consuming it. The issue of free speech has focused exclusively on broadcasting. We need to redesign this, because it is now possible for corporations to discourage people from receiving data. We need to say a serious word about this.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, the discussion and vote on this report today is, quite frankly, a complete and utter waste of parliamentary time: not solely because I disagree with many aspects in the creation of this digital single market, but because before this report has even gone to vote, the Commission has already been solidly working behind the scenes to create and rush through legislation to achieve its goals. It is in this great rush that errors are made and it is we, the consumers and businesses of the EU, who have to bear the burden of poor legislation. Take, for example, the recent changes to VAT rules for the sale of digital services, a scheme thought up by the bureaucrats of the Commission, who have little to no experience of running a business. Unsurprisingly, one year on from its introduction, this EU proposal has forced thousands of small businesses across Europe to cease trading within this internal market. Yet, rather than admit defeat, this report has the cheek to suggest that, overall, the VAT rules have been a success. At a time when faith in the European Union is at an all—time low, it is embarrassing to see the suggestion in this report that the EU trustmark for online sales will induce consumer trust.

name: Sabine Verheyen (PPE).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the The Digital Single Market is essential for economic development in the European Union and has huge potential for preserving and disseminating cultural and creative content and the dissemination of knowledge.  This potential must be exploited in the right way, so that cultural diversity in Europe is preserved and disseminated, that we can further develop the knowledge society and that Europe remains competitive in the digital economy in the future.  The cultural and creative sector in particular is characterized by its diverse structures, by large and small players in the market. The convergence of the media has led to major changes in the entire media landscape. It is important to create a fair framework for all, because in the field of audiovisual media, a distinction between linear and non-linear media services has become obsolete.  Minimum standards for all audiovisual media services will be established at EU level, so that all actors can apply these rules and standards in a uniform manner and prevent distortions in competition.  In its opinion, the Committee on Culture also stresses that Member States may introduce special rules to protect cultural and linguistic diversity of opinion and media in order to preserve the discoverability of audiovisual content of public interest. The protection of minors also plays a special role. In the area of copyright, we must find fair and balanced positions. The Digital Single Market strategy aims to remove barriers while protecting consumers and their data in the best possible way. Portability is essential to allow legal access to content. However, the economic framework for the professional production of audiovisual content must not be destroyed. The principle of territoriality must therefore not be abolished altogether.  With regard to intermediaries and platforms, we call on the Commission to consider options for achieving fair balance with authors in the context of value creation ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Emilian Pavel (S&D).
text: – Mr President, as rapporteur of the Social Democratic Group, in the Committee on Civil Liberties, I too have been fighting for a digital Single Market report that is as beneficial to Europe's citizens, innovation and economy as possible. In addition to creating a more inclusive and efficient society, the Digital Single Market and technology advances also offer smaller firms the chance to compete with big companies and create new jobs. This is a big step for young European entrepreneurs with tremendous potential in countries like Romania, and beyond.  At the same time, respect for citizens' fundamental rights, in particular the protection of personal data and the right to privacy, is a key element. Both European legislation and technology itself must be developed, putting the citizen at the centre and in control of his data. Strict penalties should be imposed for the misuse of personal data or for invasion of privacy by private, public and government institutions, especially in the case of the transfer of data to third countries. The Digital Single Market has tremendous potential for Europe, but without being properly implemented, only a number can reach the list of EU laws. If we work together, we can develop and bring innovation to Europe. (The speaker agreed to answer a question put in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: Blue card question. Yes, thank you, Mr President, I would like to ask my colleague: when he talks about important sanctions, what sanctions do you think can be adopted for those who use the Internet criminally?

name: Emilian Pavel (S&D).
text: – Herr Präsident! Darf ich erst einmal richtigstellen: Mein Name ist Emilian Pavel, und nicht Tošenovský. Mr President, in order to reply to my colleague: we must ensure that those who willfully transfer personal data, thus violating citizens' rights, are punished. I am convinced that public-private partnerships will ensure this, because it is in the interest of both private individuals and the State and the Member States to protect the fundamental rights of citizens.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Thank you, Mr Pavel. I was a bit confused. I slipped in the line and called Mr Tosenovska and then Thought that Mr Tosenovska was also speaking.  Mr Pavel for a minute.  No, No. Tosenovska. Now the worm is in it. Mr Tosenovska, please.

name: Evžen Tošenovský (ECR).
text: – Mr President, as has already been said today, the digital market in its various forms strongly affects economic growth in the global economy. It is now one of the main attributes of the development of the economy. Therefore, action at European level is important to help the digital single market as much as possible. I would like to applaud the great efforts made by all the committees on this issue. I think we have succeeded in highlighting the most important areas needed for the further development of the digital market. The question remains how to unify prices and charges at EU level, especially in the area of taxation, which can be a significant problem in some areas. We should certainly resist efforts at excessive administrative regulation. On the contrary, we should help to increase coverage and, above all, to promote increased speed and security of the digital market itself. The enormous strength of the private sector is clearly being shown, pushing this area forward all the time. Rather, we should relax some restrictions preventing further development and assess legislative intervention accordingly.

name: Marietje Schaake (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, under the excellent leadership of Kaja Kallas we are presenting an ambitious list of wishes and details to swiftly develop the digital single market or, rather, a digital single space in Europe. Especially in these difficult times, we must deliver on the optimistic promise of room for innovation and a strong knowledge economy. These are key for internet users but also for start-ups, so that they can upscale and do not leave en masse for Silicon Valley. We list practical solutions to end geo-blocking and to harmonise 28 different laws on copyright, parcel delivery and consumer protection.  But more importantly, principles such as respect for fundamental rights, fair competition and security must be robust and remain, despite the changes of the technological revolution. The open internet, open data and open access, net neutrality and the free flow of data, but not privatised law enforcement, are all important not only for Europeans but also for people worldwide. So we must also prioritise the international components such as internet governance, and strengthen people’s rights online while not allowing this to become a zero-sum relationship.

name: Roger Helmer (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, there are elements in these proposals which will be popular with voters – I should certainly be very pleased if I could access the BBC’s iPlayer service while I am in Brussels and Strasbourg – but we must bear in mind that if we dismantle existing copyright arrangements we may deny media companies the resources they need to produce the new content that viewers also want.  We in my party are concerned that the Commission’s inflexible top-down model of regulation is inimical to innovation and too often fails to meet the needs of individual Member States. We recognise that a degree of cross-border coordination is required to ensure that the internet and digital communications work efficiently across Europe, but we believe that such coordination would best be achieved by independent nations cooperating and negotiating with each other, rather than by the EU’s central planning approach. As several colleagues have said, what we actually need is a global – not merely a European – solution.

name: Pilar del Castillo Vera (PPE).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, many things have been said and I will focus my speech on an area which is crucial for the digital economy and for the digital market, which is therefore the great context, the large scale on which that economy can be developed in Europe, and it is data. Data is essential in the development of the digital economy; massive data analysis: Big Data. Data exchange is the cornerstone, the cornerstone, to the point that the profession of data analyst is now the most in demand in the world – according to a study from the World Economic Forum a few weeks ago.  In this sense, that being the case, it is necessary to take into account the transport of data: the data is transported, circulated, arrives through networks; networks that are the infrastructure of the digital economy. Transport used to be by road, it was by air, it was by sea. In the digital economy, transport is carried out through networks that rely on a radio spectrum and priority must be given to the entire development of mobile networks through pro-innovation, pro-investment policies, in a context of competitive markets.

name: Olga Sehnalová (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I am speaking as shadow rapporteur in the Committee on Transport and Tourism. As in other areas, the opportunities and challenges of digitalisation are intertwined. The transport sector is one of the pioneers in the use of new information technologies, as confirmed, for example, by intelligent transport systems.  Digitization means greater security and comfort of travel, it has its place in the field of more efficient logistics or tourism. The challenges of education and staff requirements, as well as those related to the availability of new technologies, are also current in the transport sector, as is the requirement that we do not create new barriers instead of facilitating life. I will also raise the issue of discrimination on grounds of geographical location or country of origin. It cannot be approached differently in the world online and offline, and I am glad that the report takes this into account. Finally, let me congratulate and thank the two rapporteurs, Evelyne Gebhardt and Kaja Kallas, for their excellent work.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, this dossier remains, in my view, a missed opportunity. We confined ourselves to the union minimum, without exploiting the potential it offered. In this respect, I believe that the debate on the single digital market cannot be separated from putting the European citizen at the centre of attention. What does that mean to me? It means that the focal point of the debate must be the dignity of the human person, as well as the whole range of fundamental rights enshrined at European level in the Charter of the Union.  I am thinking here of the right to privacy, freedom of expression and information, non-discrimination, to give just a few examples. I also believe that the effective completion of the digital single market opens up new prospects for the democratic life of the European Union. I see, however, that all too often the single digital market is seen only as an opportunity for economic growth, which I believe is also highly questionable from a theoretical point of view, and too little as democratic and social growth.

name: Lara Comi (PPE).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, after a great deal of parliamentary work, we are today having adopted this important report, which is a good result, a first step. Of course we can never be satisfied, we must always improve. It is certainly a highly democratic result, since it is also the result of broad negotiation and, above all, with a fair balance of all the many interests at stake and the various points of view. As rapporteur for the strategy for the single market in goods and services, I also strongly support Mr Juncker's proposals that the political priority of the digital single market should also be one of the focus of this Commission, and I think that the path we have started is the right one, but we still need to continue it more strongly. These are key areas: e-commerce, geo-blocks, copyright, VAT legislation, the regulatory framework for telecommunications, media and audiovisual media; I do not want to make a list that is too long, but there are still items on the agenda.  I believe that everyday life is linked to digital and can no longer be done without professionals up to entrepreneurs, associations and public bodies and we must keep up with the times, we must not be out of competition that can be transversal with other states. I am talking about the United States, which is a long way ahead of us on this. That is why I congratulate you on your work and move on.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D).
text: – Mr President, it is very fortuitous that this report is being debated on the co-rapporteur Evelyne Gebhardt’s birthday, and  I should like to start by wishing her a very happy birthday. I think that the Digital Single Market, as we have heard, is full of potential. We have 500 million citizens, 28 countries and an estimated worth of EUR 415 billion. But with regard to accessibility, skills and mind-set, we must make sure that, whether you live in the Highlands of Scotland or you live in the urban centres of Glasgow or Edinburgh, you have accessibility to superfast broadband. That is really important, but so are accessibility and affordability. We have seen that and heard about that, and about equality. On skills: we must make sure that the digital skills gap does not become a digital chasm. We must ensure that our citizens have ICT. Let me give an example, 55 000 job vacancies exist in the UK just now in ICT, and that is set to grow to 171 000 vacancies by 2020. We must ensure that our citizens have the skills and mind-set. We are, as many have said, going through a third industrial revolution. We have to have the mind-set to capture the potential, and I think we can do that today.

name: Angelika Niebler (PPE).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has First of all, I would like to thank the rapporteurs, the shadow rapporteurs and all those who have worked on this report. It has become a very, very good report. I would like to join the previous speaker in saying that I would like to congratulate you, Mrs Gebhardt, also on your birthday today. Digitisation must be and remain a priority in 2016. We need to create the framework to fully exploit the potential of the European Digital Single Market. We know there is still a massive need to catch up. If I can say on my own that 44% of households do not have access to fast Internet, that means that we still have massive catching up to do, especially in terms of infrastructure development. Only 14% of SMEs sell over the Internet because there are barriers to the market and market barriers. We need to dismantle them. Colleagues had raised the issue of geo-blocking. Tax legislation is important. We need more coordination, especially in the area of VAT payments, which we must simplify. We also need to make it easier to make payments where possible. In other words, the relevant directive, the Payment Services Directive, must be implemented quickly. But it is equally important – a second comment – that we create an ecosystem for start-ups and venture capitalists. We are currently running the DLD conference in Munich. This is one of the major international conferences dealing with trends and developments and the digital lifestyle. We must – and I keep hearing this from the conference and those who are there – give young creative minds the chance to realise their ideas here in Europe and prevent them from migrating to the United States. I think that is a key issue.

name: Patrizia Toia (S&D).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that the development of the digital market with all the important commitments that the road map contains is a prerequisite for the development and real application of a single, integrated and functioning market in telecommunications service networks. That is why, pending the new telecommunications framework, I call on the Commission – I do not miss an opportunity to officially request – that the commitments contained in our approval of the telecommunications regulation be honoured, first and all the review of the wholesale market. If we do not do that of wholesale charges, I wonder, we will not be able to meet the roaming commitments and I wonder how we can talk about the fall in geoblocking, a whole series of things, the portability of Internet services, if we have not solved that problem that is a prerequisite, is one of the prerequisites. So, Commissioner, I appeal to you in particular. Also, I just want, in the few seconds I have left, to recall the importance, the implications of this digital single market for industry and manufacturing. We have a series of services that integrate between industry and digital that is a forum of serious ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Ева Паунова (PPE).
text: – With a lot of effort and work in an extremely limited time frame on this report, the European Parliament has proven its strong will and determination towards completing the digital market in Europe. This is one of the Most Ambitious Projects of the European Union, but unfortunately the report has failed to fully respond to this ambition. However, it will serve as a useful guide to the Commission's future legislative proposals under its digital strategy.   The main objective of the new legislation must be the merging offline and online markets. It is especially important that consumers have the same rights and protections when buying their things on the Internet or in traditional stores.   Unfortunately, this priority is not advocated in the Commission's first legislative proposals. I believe that increasing consumer confidence in online services and online stores will also increase confidence in digitalisation in general. This will allow Europe to innovate and impose eGovernment systems and applications, internet of things, eHealth. As MEPs, we have expressed our commitment to a digital Europe and now I think it is also the turn for national governments to promote trust in member states. This trust is vital for economic growth, as well as for the imposition of a more competitive Europe, for a Europe of the young, for a Europe of skills, for a Europe of creativity, for a Europe of digital technologies on global markets. I would like to thank my colleagues in the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection, as well as Mrs Callas and Mrs Hena Virkunen, for their wonderful work.

name: Silvia Costa (S&D).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the important digital strategy taken by the Commission through this report, and in particular by Mrs Gebhardt and Mrs Kallas, is being strengthened in favour not only of consumers, but of citizens, not only for the better circulation of services and products, but also for the attention to training and the production and use of cultural, creative and audiovisual content as a resource for growth and competitiveness. In this context, the revision of the copyright directives, the AVMS Directive, will be decisive in order to clarify some important aspects. The definition of unjustified geo-blocking, the compatibility between portability and territorial licences for the financing of cinematographic works, a balanced review of copyright and exceptions, the overcoming in the AVMS Directive of the distinction between linear and non-linear services, the clear difference between platforms and the provision of providers of online media and audiovisual platforms and user interfaces to be brought under the AVMS Directive if it is an audiovisual media service in order to preserve European cultural diversity.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, it is indisputable that the rapid evolution of the Internet and communications has changed the way we communicate, how we do business and how we consume within the internal market. It has become urgent to monitor this reality and it is urgent that European legislation monitors the transition to digitisation of our market, with all the benefits and every opportunity it represents for businesses, especially small and medium-sized enterprises, the labour market and, above all, consumers. I congratulate the Commission for putting in its priorities the digital single market strategy, which overall is a good strategy but needs to be worked on, reducing the legal fragmentation of the single market, and that all 16 proposals are put into practice as soon as possible and in a harmonised way. Otherwise, we run the risk of being a digital island and in this area Europe has no time to waste.  I applaud the proposals made last December on the provision of digital content, the online sale of products and the cross-border portability of online services and content. Finally, I believe that particular attention should be paid to data portability, online security and the processing of personal data. A digital Europe that does not protect its citizens will surely be a failed Europe.

name: Marita Ulvskog (S&D).
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr As several speakers have already pointed out, the digital revolution is a fact that affects not only how we consume, but also how we work and gain knowledge. Digitalisation is completely changing the way we live. However, the Commission communication focuses only on the travelling consumer and thus lacks complete analysis of, for example, the impact on the labour market and working conditions.  As well as the fact that digitalisation and the sharing economy present opportunities, they also present challenges. The boundaries between workers and contractors are blurring. As a result, labour law and collective agreements are becoming more difficult to apply. It may be very unclear what really applies. Teleworking and crowd working give rise to new challenges and risks, both in the mental and physical working environment.  More flexible working arrangements can be very positive, but we can never accept that the trend towards more flexibility through digitalisation also leads to more precarious employment or poorer worker protection.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Mr President, there is no doubt about it: start-up after start-up, idea after idea, app after app, the digital sector is becoming more and more prominent in our lives, but we have not kept pace with it. In fact, it is 22 years since Amazon was set up, 18 years since Google, and 12 years since Facebook, and yet it is only now that we are really getting down to the business of trying to complete the Digital Single Market. It is no wonder that we are well behind the United States and Asia, but it is better late than never. The important point now is that we do so rapidly, but also extensively, and get it right, because 28 different markets are not going to suffice anymore.  We have to harmonise what can be harmonised and look particularly at issues like geo—blocking, which is holding up a lot of development. We also have to look very carefully at bringing consumers with us. That is why I welcome the Data Protection Regulation, for which I was honoured to be rapporteur for the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy (ITRE) and part of the trilogues. That should now give consumers trust that their data is safe, that they are in control of it, and also of course to allow start—ups to develop and businesses to grow in Europe.  The Digital Single Market, if we get it right, is estimated to make EUR 415 billion for the European economy. That is a lot of money in any man’s language, and certainly it requires us to make sure that we work hard and ensure that we get the Digital Market complete so that we will once again be the most competitive in the world.

name: Nicola Danti (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the digital revolution has already changed our lives and, like all epochal changes, presents us with risks and opportunities. It is up to us to meet this challenge by trying to exploit the opportunities it offers us for the growth of the economic system and the lives of citizens and consumers. Digital has already produced small and great innovations in our daily lives and in our productive and social fabric, but Almost never is Europe associated with this great process of transformation.  If we talk about digital, we spontaneously think of Silicon Valley and not of somewhere on our continent. Yet we are betting that, thanks to strong investment and coordinated policies, the European Union will be able to relaunch itself, give new expression to its traditional excellence, confirming itself as a place of exercise of freedom, of the use of culture, of expression of beauty and of quality production. I hope that today's resolution will be a first step towards making Europe make up for lost time on the road to modernity and to lead this revolution, with courage and vision.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE).
text: – First of all, I would like to congratulate the report-takers and join those who wished Mrs Evelyne Gebhardt a happy birthday. This is a very comprehensive and very thorough work carried out by the reporters. As the shadow reporter of the ECON commission, I would not like to highlight the aspects that have been raised so far, but I would like to talk about tax aspects.  I think that the world has basically passed by us, and we, Commissioner, are lagging behind in regulation. It would be important for the Commission to be absolutely proactive in this area, precisely so that consumers are adequately protected and safe in this digital market. When I think of the tax aspect and I look at e-commerce, I see that this is an umbrella concept, any part of which, any element, can be a priority for tax purposes. However, there is too much bureaucracy in this area. I would like it to be much, much less, and we would support SMEs in this. I would like the digital internal market strategy and the internal market strategy to work together harmoniously.

name: Virginie Rozière (S&D).
text: Mr President, I would first like to thank the rapporteurs, with a special word for Evelyne, not only because it is her birthday, but also for the quality of the sustained exchanges we have had during the carrying out of this report.  I would like to talk about a very special area for the European Union: culture. It is true, and we all experience it, that it is a little annoying not to be able to satisfy our desires for culture everywhere, immediately and for free, as we wish. I think that as leaders, we have a duty to go beyond the bad mood and to ask ourselves the question of the consequences of our choices. We ask whether it is right to abolish territoriality and thus lead to a situation where an artist will not necessarily receive remuneration for his art, even if a viewer appreciates his work. What are the consequences of our choices? Today, we know the unbalanced balance of power between internet giants and creative actors. So our responsibility for tomorrow, rather than thinking in the short term, is to strengthen the conditions for the sustainability of creation and culture in Europe and that is what must be our priority in this area.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I am speaking as a shadow rapporteur from the Committee on Transport and Tourism. Digitalisation, interoperability and intelligent transport systems are the key to efficient and effective transport systems for consumers, passengers and businesses – whether they be SMEs, start—ups, larger companies – all those that are moving goods and services across Europe. Digitalisation can help make better use of existing capacity and make those businesses more efficient and more effective – and, of course, that all results in the creation of jobs. It is very important in helping to overcome the challenges and the burdensome obligations of red tape – particularly for those delivering goods – and logistics. We need to get a point where we have e—Customs and do not have drivers of heavy goods vehicles dealing with paper customs clearance forms and all the copies that go with that. This is burdensome, affects competition and reduces the potential for job creation. We also need to get to the point in the tourism sector and the sharing economy where we regulate in this area.

name: Liisa Jaakonsaari (S&D).
text: – Mr President, the Kallas and Gebhardt report is important and I look forward to Commissioner Ansip's response to these speeches. One of the things that has not yet been very much raised here is that the Commission should continue the investigation and open up new investigations. What are the social dimensions of digitalisation, how does it affect work, how does it affect income sharing, how does it affect culture? Why is this study important? So that we can prevent the undesirable effects that may come, and in order to have a basis of trust in terms of technical standards and controls.  In particular, I think it is important to have confidence in algorithms and so-called big data and the Internet of Things. Trust is extremely important if we are to be able to make the most of the digital revolution.

name: Anna Maria Corazza Bildt (PPE).
text: – Mr President, to complete the single market is the highway to jobs and growth. Let us have the courage to be disruptive and to stand up for an open, free and global internet. We liberate the forces that exist and boost trust by removing the digital barriers and borders. Consumers should not pay twice for the same service, depending on where they live in Europe, and our SMEs should not abide by 28 sets of rules. To create scale, they need one digital market. I support this report as it addresses national exceptions and protectionism. Europe will become competitive through simple, modern and clear rules, not through shutting out others. Our problem is fragmentation, not innovation. We should not slow down the shared economy but ensure that transparency and a free flow of data is as important as the other four freedoms. The same rule should apply online and offline. Let me conclude by saying that swiftly reaching an agreement on safe harbour is crucial in order to avoid a legal vacuum. Time is running out.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, aligning the European Union with the digital revolution means creating a single market, but it means going far beyond that. It is essential to lay the foundations for a European Digital Identity, incorporating into it the common values we share: freedom of expression, equal opportunities in access for people and businesses, the free movement of goods and services, the sharing of data, ensuring individual privacy, and the collective efficiency of public security services. All these are values, part of a European heritage, which we have to transpose into the digital Union.  This report makes a good contribution on a path that we must continue to follow – I congratulate the rapporteurs. It is important to give more Europeans access to digital services and resources, and this will open up new opportunities for investment, growth and jobs. It will also open up new opportunities for people's requalification and for research and technological innovation. In a time of dismay, here is a mobilizing agenda. We have to make it happen as soon as possible.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: We come to the catch-the-eye procedure. I have almost 20 requests to speak, including written interventions from colleagues, which have only arrived at the end of the debate. So I have to stay in time to some extent. I will take six colleagues. I will confine myself to colleagues who have not yet spoken in other debates and who, as far as we have seen, have been here throughout the debate. Catch-the-eye procedure

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: – Mr President, the digital market, as has been said many times, is a great opportunity for the development of entrepreneurship, services, education and culture. The European Parliament and the European Commission must give both a strategic and legislative framework, as this European Parliament report proposes and also contains a number of specific tasks. I would mention two priorities. I am glad that the Commissioner has also focused on the protection of copyright, namely, of course, the availability of content is a right of users, but users also have the right to the quality of these content and it is not possible to fulfil this quality without copyright protection. So it was one of the main priorities.  The second is child protection. The Internet is a good service but a very dangerous master. Therefore, the protection of children from online abuse should also be a priority for both technical and legislative proposals that the Commission should put forward, and I call on it to do so.

name: José Blanco López (S&D).
text: – Mr President, digitisation has flooded everything and Europe must harness the full potential of digital society. We need to boost the portability of services and content and eliminate unwarranted geoblocking online, as we have done with the elimination of roaming. We have to plan uses and award spectrum bands without delay. We need to boost Industry 4.0 or the Internet of Things and create a secure and reliable network. We need to help our SMEs get the most out of digitisation and we need to protect and boost our creators and our cultural production, without which We cannot talk about Europe itself. We therefore have a chance. And Europe cannot waste it.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: - Mr. President, the potential of the Digital Single Market is enormous. Trade development, new jobs, more efficient and modern governance are just some of the benefits we would witness. It will take great support for innovation and investment in technologies to achieve our goals, but I have no doubt about the end result, especially if politicians understand by then the importance of reducing market regulation for development and growth. But I would draw attention here to another dimension, which is crime, which is also rapidly becoming digital. The digitisation of the sale of narcotics and weapons, the sale of counterfeit products online and the use of new media for the dissemination and coordination of various criminal and terrorist organisations are already widespread.  With the creation of the Digital Single Market, the challenges in the fight against crime will become even greater, so accordingly, our methods must evolve, but always with a touch of caution not to be late in restricting the civil liberties of those people who have not sinned against the law.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE).
text: – Parliament's resolution on the Digital Single Market Strategy contains many welcome slogans about competitiveness, consumer protection, jobs, trade development and gdp growth. Of course, this is important. I would also like to draw attention to what is not in the document. These are the negative effects of digitisation of markets. I am thinking of the decline of local markets, the uniformity of products, the deterioration of quality and, of course, the climate consequences of human activity focused solely on GDP growth. Of course, some may say that these are the natural consequences of globalisation. And they will not be very wrong, but we should also, when considering the Digital Single Market strategy, provide for measures to encourage the consumer's decision to buy goods online to be accompanied by information about the impact of his decision on small producers and the climate.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE).
text: – Mr President, a segmented European landscape in the field of cross-border access to digital content and services clearly shows how far we still are from the expectations we have had of a common digital single market of the 21st Century. The market is full of selective distribution practices, unjustified geo-blocking and discrimination based on IP and postal addresses or credit card issuing countries, the use of which significantly distorts competition. As a result, European consumers are still not able to purchase the content that their neighbour can. Often they cannot use their content legally acquired in one Member State when they cross the border into another. I am glad to see that the report takes into account that, besides economic gains, the other most obvious benefit of opening up these markets would be a more multilingual Europe and the flourishing of cultures, especially minority ones whose survival often depends on the accessibility of cultural goods from neighbouring States.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
text: – Mr President, First of all, I would like to congratulate the rapporteurs and all the colleagues who have contributed to such an important report. The fact that more than 2 000 amendments have been tabled shows the importance and interest shown by our colleagues. The Digital Single Market is extremely important and good regulation can allow new opportunities to emerge for users, and for entrepreneurs, just as poor regulation can block them. The rules of the digital single market must lead to an increase in the number of SMEs.  Commissioner, there is still much to do. The Commission is forecasting growth potential that exceeds the 100 billion of the collaborative economy, but there is still much to be done. Personally, I have seen in this report whether the balance between digital market development and consumer protection is respected. I have to tell you that European regions are very differently developed in terms of connectivity and this is where you need to focus. I support and vote on the report, but in order to materialise, the Commission must harmonise how investment funds are spent to reduce regional disparities.

name: Andrus Ansip
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank you all for this very fruitful debate. In Europe we were able to create a single market in a physical sense. We were able to tear down all those barriers dividing our Member States. But a digital single market does not exist. Our economy is becoming more and more digital every day, so we can see how those barriers are coming back. Those barriers get higher and higher every day.  There is a sense of urgency here in Parliament and in the Commission. We made our first two proposals in December. We have to give legal access to digital content to our people, and that is why we have made the portability proposal. The second proposal concerned digital contract rules. Instead of having potentially 56 different rules, we proposed establishing two different rules dealing with online sales of tangible goods and online sales of digital content.   We will make our next proposal on 700 MHz in February. I hope that in March we will be able to make our first proposal about industries. We will propose our industrial package, which will also deal with the usual cloud communication and ICT priority standards. In April, I hope that we will propose a new e-government action plan, and in May, the regulation on consumer protection cooperation, including the e-commerce package, measures in the area of parcel delivery, and geo-blocking.
