In June, we will make a second copyright proposal on improving cross—border access to digital content, but we will also deal with libraries, educational exceptions, disabled people and of course text and data mining. We will also make a proposal in June on the review of the Satellite and Cable Directive, the review of the Audiovisual Media Services Directive, and on the ‘follow the money’ principle, which will be part of our copyright reform, as well as on the role of platforms in the market, including illegal content on the internet. In June and July, there will be proposals about the Cybersecurity PPP (Public—Private Partnership) and the reform of telecom rules. This will also be about infrastructure. In November, there will be proposals on the free flow of data, the review of the e-Privacy Directive, and VAT regimes. I hope in that in December we will not make any new proposals on the basis of the Digital Single Market strategy.  I am looking forward to having really fruitful cooperation with you in creating a Digital Single Market for Europe.

name: Kaja Kallas
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, I think it is very important that so many Committees have been involved in drafting this report and giving their opinions and that so many Members have been involved in voicing their concerns. I would like to reflect on a few issues that were touched upon here.  First of all, I think we should all understand that the internet is not just a big shopping centre. It has so many layers regarding cultural diversity, innovation and research. E-commerce is also important, but it is not all about that. Some Members have complained that some topics are not emphasised enough in the report. I think what is important is that we have achieved a balance; all the topics are covered and they strike a balance in the report.  Some have voiced concerns about the once-only principle in regard to data protection. Actually, I think it has a positive effect on data protection because data is not kept in one single big database but similar small databases communicating with each other, so that is important. This is how things should work in the digital age: people should be in charge of their data when they talk to the public authorities.  Also, I think, what is very important is that the user and the citizen is at the heart of the system and they have the control. On the sharing economy, it changes employment rules, that is for certain, but we have to see the positive effects as well. It increases autonomy for people, people are not working under control of somebody but for themselves. So this is a positive thing which we should also embrace. So thank you all and I look forward to the cooperation.

name: Evelyne Gebhardt
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, I would like to thank the Thank you for the many congratulations I have received. I think that we are here at the beginning of a work on the Digital Single Market – we still have a great deal ahead of us. I would also like to thank the European Commission for informing us of the steps that are to be taken, and that is right and proper. We must be clear about one thing time and again: we do not want the Digital Single Market to be an end in itself, but we want an internal market that is there for the people, for the citizens. Whether they are cultural workers, consumers, workers or service providers. We must always focus on this: to make the best of it, to make the most of it, to succeed, to really seize the opportunities that we need in global competition with the digital market, so that we really have good and sensible growth and, in fact, the creation of good jobs in the European Union. That is what we have to achieve, what we have to achieve. That is why we must be ambitious, much more ambitious than the European Commission. Some of my fellow Members have already done so. We will all work together to ensure that this is the case. Finally, I would like to make one more comment, so that no false impression is given. Mrs Troszczynski has boasted of the many amendments she has tabled, both in committee and here in plenary. That's right. But she was not present at the work on the report. We have not seen a single meeting of her, or any of her colleagues, and I do not want to give the wrong impression that she has worked where she has not worked.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The debate is closed.  The vote will take place today, Tuesday, 19 January 2016, at 12.30 p.m. Written declarations (Article 162 OF the CRP)

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. – We support the digital single market because we believe that the EU must finally be able to face the digital competition of the US and Asia and create growth momentum with thousands of jobs and billions of investments. It is a fact that many young people with great talent in this area are leaving Europe because in the EU we have 28 different arrangements. We expect that the advantages of the single digital market and digital development will also be enjoyed by isolated island regions, such as Cyprus. I believe that, in this context, it is time to also focus on the very important issue of the Internet. Small and isolated countries, such as Cyprus and other island regions, pay high costs for low quality and low-speed Internet services. The European Parliament takes the view that access to the Internet is a human right and therefore considers that this right should be guaranteed to all European citizens. But while we support this position, what have we done in this direction? I am restoring my proposal and calling, for island regions such as Cyprus, for them to become zones of free and free Internet access.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. – The digital single market strategy is about the small family business in one of Malta’s villages opening itself up to many more consumers; about giving each one of us as consumers more choice of goods and of service providers from the comfort of our own sitting room; also about giving our creative sector a new platform. It is a strategy that reflects how we are already taking our lives online and ensuring that this is done without unnecessary limitations. The strategy does not want to diminish the physical commercial market and is not only about commerce. It addresses data protection, protection of creators and users, research processes and needed skills. Most importantly of all it seeks to facilitate a more inclusive society and has the potential of making interaction – commercial, educative, cultural and social – more accessible to all. To facilitate access to online content, we need enhanced portability measures; this is why the Commissions’ portability proposal is of key importance, and we need to work towards a better recognition of the potential of the creative industry as well as facilitate accessibility to cultural content for consumers.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. – We are living in a world where digital technologies are offering a new world of opportunities. They can expand our economy and help small and medium-sized companies tap into a potential customer base of 500 million customers within the EU alone. They can provide individuals with the opportunity to develop entrepreneurial ideas and business models. I would like to emphasise once again that the EU and the different Member States need to provide the possibility for entrepreneurs to access financing possibility.  Once again I call upon the Commission to ensure that crowdfunding can become a reality. This approach, together with more initiatives to boost entrepreneurship, will help change our culture on what is success whilst promoting an entrepreneurial and innovation culture. It is time to adapt really and truly to the digital age. Existing barriers online mean that our citizens are missing out on buying the goods and services they want. Self-employed people and start-ups are unable to tap into a wider market. Entrepreneurs from all Member States need to be provided with the possibility to sell their products on Europe’s online marketplaces. Practices that forbid our entrepreneurs from registering and selling on specific online marketplaces should not be allowed.

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: Writing. – I welcome the strategy developed by the Commission and the Kallas-Gebhardt report before Parliament. Removing barriers to a single digital market is in the interest of all European consumers, not to mention the positive impact of the digital revolution on the European economy. I would like to highlight one issue: proportionality. In some cases, I get the impression that we are trying to set targets that are not entirely safe for the consumer or even for the trader. Examples include e-commerce, such as achieving the highest online trading rate. Or we can mention the requirement for online retailers to provide all European citizens with the same discount. Of course, if there is a regulatory problem or a market barrier, we have to deal with it, that is not an issue. However, as policy makers, we must propose standards that are really necessary and enforceable.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I will of course vote in favour of this report, which I have been particularly involved in. The establishment of a digital single market will enable the European Union to catch up with the United States by strengthening the competitiveness of our companies against the web giants. In addition, the digital revolution will offer immense growth potential for European businesses and consumers in the order of 415 billion euros for European GDP.  I am particularly committed to ensuring that the confidence of consumers who buy online is a pillar of this text so that they have real legal certainty, without additional costs. Finally, intellectual property and the fight against counterfeiting and piracy have been the subject of particular attention to protect our European champions of the cultural and creative industry.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D)
text: in writing. – E-commerce moves millions of euros per year. And it will continue to increase in a global borderless market. Except in the Canary Islands, where imports and exports are subject to payment of the Single Administrative Document of Customs. This tax makes up to 40% more the final amount of the product purchased online, thus restricting e-commerce in the archipelago. Only 27% of the Canarian population bought online in 2013, compared to 37% of the Spanish average and 50% of the European average. As a result, many companies have decided not to sell through the network in the Canary Islands, despite the obligation of European and Spanish legislation to do so throughout the national territory for any company that trades within the EU. It is therefore necessary to take measures aimed at removing existing barriers to electronic commerce in the Canary Islands in order to have the same conditions in the traffic of goods as in the rest of the Member States. Ultra-peripherality cannot be an impediment to competitiveness and is crucial to achieving a true digital single market.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. – Europe's digital backlog is becoming more and more prominent in global competition. How can none of the world's 10 largest internet companies be European? Or that while grey matter is traditionally strong in Europe, there are 30 patents per million people in Europe, while in the United States there are 350 patents? I am convinced that if we were to create the right digital backdrop behind the world's leading European industry, we would not be talking today about Europe's declining share of the world economy. We therefore need Europe's digital catch-up and digital system change! If the EU Digital Single Market Strategy is implemented, the results will be measured in four million jobs and hundreds of billions of euros in economic growth. In a Borderless Europe in the 21st century, there is no right to digital walls, roaming charges, restrictions on internet content or taxation of internet use. Brussels and several Member States have recognised this and started to digitise public administration, education and the economy unconditionally. I'm convinced we have to go even further. We must entrep the fundamental right of access to the Internet in the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights. In the interests of digital development in Europe, we must prohibit the taxation of the Internet at EU level so that it never happens that the folding of budgetary holes is more important than the interests of European citizens. The Digital Single Market Strategy is the key to economic growth and job creation. Europe cannot rest on its laurels, the digital transition is a prerequisite for preserving the Union's role as a great power.

name: Емил Радев (PPE)
text: in writing. – Dear Colleagues, negotiations on this report have been difficult, but I think we have reached a balanced text acceptable to most political groups. Union policies and legislation in the digital single market should aim at creating new opportunities for consumers and businesses and innovative cross-border online services at competitive prices.  I believe that with our work as a legislator, we must contribute to removing barriers between Member States and facilitating access for European small and medium-sized enterprises to a single cross-border market. Currently, only 1.7% of EU businesses take full advantage of advanced digital technologies, and 14% of SMEs use the internet as a selling opportunity. That needs to change because e-commerce is the future. It generates $500 billion in revenue. eur 100 million per year in the EU.  The EC's initiatives of the Digital Single Market Strategy need to be proposed and adopted swiftly. I believe that proposals on content portability and online sales will help remove barriers for citizens who shop online and who will now be able to watch their favourite movies, listen to their favourite songs when travelling. This is a first step in the right direction, but I believe there is more we can do for a better functioning digital market.

name: Evelyn Regner (S&D)
text: Writing. – Digital change is creating a completely new world of work. This is the biggest upheaval since the Industrial Revolution. We must and do this 'digital revolution'. We in the European Parliament have clear, clear positions. The following points are particularly important to me: - Workers' rights and social protection for all workers must also be maintained at the same level in the digital world of work. Existing collective agreements must apply the same to digital workers. Member States must ensure this and, where appropriate, adapt national labour and social rights. We want to avoid that Work 4.0 does not become a family 4.0. The right to unreachability and rest periods must apply to every EU citizen. The explosion of atypical employment contracts and precarious employment must be avoided, minimum wages (where available), rules for participation, health and protection at work must be guaranteed. Employee data protection needs to be further developed. In this respect, the regulation falls short of expectations and the proposals of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs should be taken up, especially in view of increasing digitisation. The EU Commission and the Member States still have some ideas for future implementation. Ultimately, we parliamentarians want digitalisation to be an opportunity for all that Europe actively shapes with clear and fair rules.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – The expansion of large commercial areas had a devastating effect on local production and small and medium-sized trade, thereby destroying thousands and thousands of jobs. We are now presented as a major objective of the European Digital Single Market as an instrument to promote competitiveness and to generate jobs in the European Union. From experience we already know that the competitiveness proposed by the European Union is totally incompatible with employment and labour rights. This proposal is made to promote consumerism at the out of the question by making available to consumers the products of large companies that will be the ones that have the capacity to do business. It is totally irresponsible that the Commission and the Council continue to delve into proposals of this kind and it is a sham for us to be presented as job-generating when what they do is destroy it. It is hidden that the employment that can be created with this type of trade for large enterprises and large multinationals is always much lower than that which is destroyed in small and medium-sized enterprises, in trade and in local production.

name: Theodor Dumitru Stolojan (PPE)
text: in writing. – Europe is still far from a digital single market. We have much different regulations in the Member States, we have tax policies that are not adapted to a digital market.  Any delay in achieving the Digital Single Market will be seriously damaging the European economy in terms of jobs and profits. The digital revolution is in full swing. It fundamentally transforms the business model in all areas, including activities financed mainly from public budgets, such as health, education, national defence, etc. Who ever stays behind now stays for a long time.  That is why the European institutions have a duty to put the achievement of the Digital Single Market at the heart of the priorities for the development of the Single Market.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. We want to improve European consumers' access to online goods and services, eliminate differences in treatment between offline and online purchases or discrimination related to geographical blocking. So many obstacles for SMEs and consumers remain: they explain the distressing figures of e-commerce in Europe. While only 4% of European online transactions are cross-border (for 42% of domestic transactions and 54% from the US), 45% of European households do not have fast internet! There is an urgent need for an effective digital market for the economy, employment and social integration. We European socialists have also worked hard to recall the societal and not just commercial issue of the text by adding many references to social law, labour law and the participatory aspect of digital. These projects should not only be a good opportunity for large companies but represent an improvement for all citizens and SMEs.

name: Владимир Уручев (PPE)
text: in writing. – Mr President, colleagues, I congratulate the authors of the Digital Single Market report and everyone who has worked on it and contributed to the EP's strong and comprehensive position on this crucial issue. More than 315 million Europeans use the Internet every day, but more than half of the e-marketplace is based on American online services, and the rest are mainly national online services, not cross-border pan-European ones.  Existing barriers to e-commerce must be removed by stopping unjustified practices to restrict EU consumers' access to e-goods and e-services between Member States, ensuring an equivalent level of data protection, and finding appropriate solutions to reduce the cost of cross-border parcel deliveries.  Every third EU citizen would like to hear and watch things from their own country when abroad. I therefore welcome the proposal to strengthen the portability of online content as an important step towards improving consumer access to e-services, but must be followed by new models for e-commerce and services.  It is of particular importance to remove barriers for SMEs and start-ups to take advantage of the opportunities of renewed ICT, data sets, cloud services and e-government.

name: Presidente. –
text: The next item is voting time.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Mr President, on 17 December 2015, our Parliament adopted a resolution condemning human rights violations in Burundi and calling for the immediate release of Greek national Spyros-Richard Hagabimana, who had been imprisoned at the end of June because, as a police officer and head of a repression force, he refused to order his men to shoot at the demonstrators. I would therefore like to inform the House today of the happy end of the adventure of Spyros, who last Friday 15 January was found not guilty by the court and will soon be free to be with us.  This development demonstrates the considerable influence that the decisions of the European Parliament can have and confirms that we must continue our efforts in a way that is inseable.

name: Presidente. –
text: Thank you very much, Mr President. Marias, we are all convinced that this Parliament has and will have an important role to play precisely because it represents 500 million European citizens.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I simply wanted to ask the House not to put to the vote the draft Legislative Resolution with a view to immediately starting negotiations with the Council.

name: Julie Ward
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, thank you, and I would like also to thank all the colleagues, staff, education experts, civil society, faith groups and young people themselves, with whom I have consulted throughout this process, for helping me to put together a report that presents a positive future for young people, for our future communities, through a process of talking to one another. Dialogue is about conversations.

name: Syed Kamall (ECR).
text: – Mr President, I thought we were checking on part 2 of 62, not part 2 of 60. Our screens showed 60, part 2.

name: Evelyne Gebhardt
text: Rapporteur. I have been made aware that, in this amendment, the translation into French is wrong, namely the opposite. The original English text is the correct one, and we are voting on it, not on what has been wrongly translated into French. I just wanted to draw attention to that.

name: Presidente. –
text: Thank you, Mr Mc8, we will have the translation from the European Parliament to German checked and corrected French if there have been errors.  (This concludes voting time)

name: Presidente. –
text: I would like to inform you that I have received a number of requests for explanations of vote. We can only continue the sitting until 2.45 p.m. at the latest, so that the services can prepare for the resumption of the sitting at 3.00 p.m.  All the remaining explanations of vote will be dealt with tomorrow after the votes.  Any further explanations of vote may be submitted in writing.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the suspension of the parliamentary immunity of Mr Czes-aw Adam Siekierski since the facts for which he has to stand before the court are not related to his activity as an MEP.

name: Martina Anderson and Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – The MEP in question accepts his immunity being waived and is not contesting it and there is no question of political interference. Therefore, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. This is an alleged violation of the Polish traffic law, for speeding. There is no indication that there is any intention to interfere with Mr. Adam Siekierski's business. Polish law requires a waiver of immunity in these cases. In accordance with national legislation, I voted in favour of this request.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I believe in democracy and transparency, and therefore I believe that my vote on this matter should be a matter of public record. In that spirit, I wish to confirm that I voted to waive the Parliamentary immunity. I do wish to note, however, my annoyance at the amount of public time spent dealing with a minor speeding offence. However, ultimately, that is a matter for the people of Poland rather than the United Kingdom.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendations of the Committee on Legal Affairs.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. It is on the grounds of an alleged violation of the traffic law, in this case a speeding offence allegedly committed in Poland, that Mr Siekierski's parliamentary immunity is lifted. Polish law requires the lifting of his immunity so that he can pay his fine. There is no indication that there is any intention to interfere with his political activity, so I have seen no reason not to accept this request from the Polish justice system.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. Following the unanimous opinion of the Committee on Legal Affairs, I approved the lifting of Mr Siekierski's parliamentary immunity.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this immunity suspension plea. Czes-aw Adam Siekierski accepts the suspension of his immunity, which eliminates considerations of political persecution or harmful use for the institution of pleadings. The vote in committee was in favour unanimously. I follow the commission's proposal.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. The Polish Attorney General has submitted a request from the Polish General Inspectorate of Road Traffic requesting the lifting of the immunity of Mr Siekierski, a Member of the European Parliament elected for Poland, for a driving offence. The alleged offences relate to a speeding offence recorded by the Polish Traffic Inspectorate on 10 January 2015, in an area where he should have been travelling at 50 km/h (not 77 km/h as recorded by radar). The alleged offence is not directly related to Mr Siekierski's exercise of his duties as a Member of the European Parliament and that the Parliamentary Committee also finds no evidence of fumus persecutionis, i.e. sufficiently serious and precise indications that these proceedings were initiated with the aim of harming the political career of the Member concerned, it is necessary that his immunity be lifted in order for him to pay his fines.  So I voted for this report.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. As the report prepared by the Committee on Legal Affairs points out, the Attorney General of the Republic of Poland requested on 13 August 2015 to suspend the immunity of Czes-aw Adam Siekierski in relation to an infringement referred to in Article 92a of the Code of Administrative Infringements of 20 May 1971 in relation to Article 20 , paragraph 1, of the Traffic Act of 20 June 1997, consisting of exceeding the speed limit allowed in an urban area. In so far as the alleged infringement is not directly or manifestly related to the exercise of the functions of Member of the European Parliament of Czes-aw Adam Siekierski and that there is no evidence of fumus persecutionis, the European Parliament has decided to suspend parliamentary immunity, which is why I voted in favour of this decision.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report, in which the European Parliament deals with the issue of immunity from Czesław Adam Siekierski. On 13 August 2015, the Public Prosecutor General of the Republic of Poland referred the President of Parliament to the Polish Inspector General for Road Traffic Inspectorate for permission to bring the european Parliament Member Czesław Adam Siekiersk to justice for an administrative offence of speeding. According to the General Road Inspectorate of Poland, at 20.22 on 10 January 2015.C A. Siekierskis did not comply with the prescribed speed in the village while driving the car and drove at a speed of 77 km/h at a speed of 50 km/h. The Inspector-General further states that, in response to the summons sent to Mr Siekierski on 19 January 2015, Mr Siekierski sent copies of his MEP's IDENTITY card, a certificate of election to the European Parliament and a statement in which he acknowledges that he was driving the vehicle at the specified time. It is apparent from the case-file that Mr Siekierskis admitted that he was driving the vehicle at the specified time, but did not indicate in the form in question whether he accepted or opposed the imposition of the fine. It is apparent from the circumstances of the case that the suspicion of an administrative offence and further administrative prosecution have nothing to do with mr Siekierski's duties as a Member of the European Parliament.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this request for the waiver of Mr Syrendt's immunity. Mr Sikierski, because I believe that the infringement committed by Mr Sikierski is a violation of the rules of procedure. Mr Sikierski is not covered by the rules on parliamentary immunity of the European Parliament.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. The Attorney General of the Republic of Poland has submitted two motions calling for the lifting of the immunity of MEP Czes-aw Adam Siekierski for committing two alleged offences related to speeding in an agglomeration. In order for this MEMBER of the European Parliament to be able to avoid his fines, it is necessary to withdraw his parliamentary immunity. Since this request was clearly not submitted with the intention of harming the political activity of this Member of the European Parliament, I have spoken in favour of the lifting of his parliamentary immunity.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Vote in favour, these are two violations of the highway code. There is no reason to guarantee the protection of immunity.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ The MEP in question accepts his immunity being waived and is not contesting it, and there is no question of political interference. Therefore, I voted in favour of this report.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted to waive the immunity of Mr Siekerski, a Polish MEP (EPP/Polish People’s Party; Chairman AGRI) who is alleged to have committed an offence of speeding (exceeding the permitted speed limit in a built-up area). The alleged offence has no evident link of any kind to his duties as an MEP. In those circumstances the Polish Courts should have jurisdiction over his case.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The request for authorisation to proceed by the Attorney General of the Republic of Poland against Mr Syderman is not a good one. Czesław Adam Siekierski is involved in proceedings relating to speeding offences. I therefore voted in favour because these infringements go beyond the guarantee of parliamentary immunity.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 We are voting in favour of the report on the request for waiver of the immunity of Mr Czesław Adam Siekierski.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 We voted today on the prospect of the waiver of the immunity of MEP Adam Siekierski. As the legal proceedings initiated against him do not concern political activities, I believe that we have no reason to oppose the request of the competent authorities and that is why I voted in favour of the waiver of immunity.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the measure. On 13 August 2015, the Attorney General of the Republic of Poland forwarded to the President of Parliament a request from the Polish Inspectorate-General for Road Traffic for authorisation to initiate legal proceedings against a Member of the European Parliament Czesław Adam Siekierski in relation to an infringement of the Highway Code.

name: David Coburn (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted to waive the immunity of Mr Siekerski, a Polish MEP (EPP/Polish People’s Party; Chairman AGRI) who is alleged to have committed an offence of speeding (exceeding the permitted speed limit in a built-up area). The alleged offence has no evident link of any kind to his duties as an MEP. In those circumstances the Polish Courts should have jurisdiction over his case.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. Having regard to the fact that the Committee on Legal Affairs of the European Parliament has correctly followed the procedures for verifying the conditions for invoking immunity by Mr Siekierski and that this verification has shown that immunity has no legal basis for being invoked in this specific case, I agree with what the Committee on Legal Affairs has assessed and I am in favour of the withdrawal of immunity.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Parliamentary immunity is not a Member’s personal privilege but a guarantee of the independence of Parliament as a whole and of its Members. The case in question does not have a direct and obvious connection with the Member’s performance of his duties as a Member of the European Parliament nor does it constitute an opinion expressed or a vote cast in the performance of his duties as a Member of the European Parliament for the purposes of Article 8 of Protocol No 7. I have thus voted in favour of the report to waive the immunity of the Member.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the suspension of the parliamentary immunity of Mr Czes-aw Adam Siekierski since the facts for which he has to stand before the court are not related to his activity as an MEP.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Article 7 on the Privileges and Immunities of the European Union states that MEPs enjoy immunity in the territory of their own State. This report requests the removal of the parliamentary immunity for an MEP. As I have always done in these cases I agree to the removal of immunity so that an MEP can prove his innocence or otherwise according to the judicial system of the relevant Member States.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. The facts alleged against Mr Siekierski relate to an alleged violation of the Polish traffic law. These are not prosecutions aimed at undermining our colleague's parliamentary activity and political engagement. The lifting of immunity being necessary for the judicial process, I decided to support it.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 Parliamentary privileges must under no circumstances lead to unequal and privileged treatment of Members vis-à-vis law and justice.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Last August, the Attorney General of the Republic of Poland transmitted to the President of the European Parliament a request from the General Inspectorate of Road Traffic of Poland, requesting permission to take action against Mr Czesław Adam Siekierski for a traffic offence. As the Polish Constitution stipulates that it is not possible to criminal action against Members and Senators of Parliament or the Senate without the prior authorisation of Parliament or the Senate of which they are members, a decision of the European Parliament is necessary determining whether criminal proceedings can be brought against Mr Siekierski. In this case, the request for waiver of the member's immunity was submitted as a result of an alleged infringement consisting of an excess of the speed limit applicable to urban agglomerations. It is inferred from the case that Mr Siekierski admitted that he was driving the vehicle at the time of the infringement, although he did not state in the relevant form whether or not he accepted the fine. The facts are not related to your activity as a Member of the European Parliament, agreeing to the waiver of parliamentary immunity.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this deliberation because it is a matter of enforcing a sanction in the Member's country.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report focuses on the request for the waiver of parliamentary immunity of Mr Czesław Adam Siekierski. Here are the facts: The General Inspectorate of Road Traffic in Poland claims that on 10 January 2015, When driving a vehicle, the Member did not respect the speed limit applicable to urban agglomerations – which is 50 km/h – when driving the vehicle referred to at a speed of 77 km/h. The facts of which he is accused constitute an infringement of Article 92(a) of the Polish Code of Contratomes, together with Article 20(1) of the Road Traffic Act of 20 June 1997. The alleged infringement does not have a direct and obvious link with the exercise of Czesław Adam Siekierski's duties as a Member of the European Parliament, and Parliament has also found no reasoned evidence that the request is intended to undermine the political activity of the Member. That is why we voted in favour of the waiver of immunity.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour as the offence had nothing to do with their political activities.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 Parliamentary privileges must in no way lead to unequal and privileged treatment of Members vis-à-vis law and justice, which is why I am voting in favour of the report on the request for the waiver of the parliamentary immunity of Czesław Adam Siekierski.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the waiver of the parliamentary immunity of MEP Czesław Adam Siekierski, so that he will be able to pay his speeding ticket.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In deciding whether or not to waive the immunity of a Member in a particular case, the European Parliament applies its own permanent principles. One of these principles is that immunity is normally waived if the offence is governed by Article 9 of Protocol 7, provided that there is no serious and substantiated suspicion that the case was brought before the court for the purpose of causing political damage to the Member.  In that case, the request for the waivey of the immunity of Czesław Adam Siekierski was made in relation to a suspected infringement, exceeding the speed limit applicable to the populated area. Czesław Adam Siekierski admitted that he was driving the vehicle at the time in question, although he failed to indicate on the relevant form whether he would accept or refuse to pay the fine. In the circumstances of the case, it appears that the alleged offence and the resulting criminal liability are clearly not related to czesław Adam Siekierski's position as a Member of the European Parliament. On the basis of the foregoing considerations and in accordance with the Rules of Procedure, the Committee on Legal Affairs proposes that the European Parliament suspend the parliamentary immunity of Czesław Adam Siekierski.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of waiving the immunity of Mr Siekierski, given that he was not performing any parliamentary duties at the time of the incident for which he is facing charges in Poland.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this immunity suspension plea. Czes-aw Adam Siekierski accepts the suspension of his immunity, which eliminates considerations of political persecution or harmful use for the institution of pleadings. The vote in committee was in favour unanimously. I follow the commission's proposal.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 The appropriate attitude is that of voting in favour because the issues on which immunity is requested have nothing to do with parliamentary activity and because the MEP himself agrees with the waiver of his immunity.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report in relation to the request for the waiver of the parliamentary immunity of Czeslaw Adam Siekierski.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a proposal for a Decision of the European Parliament on the application for the waiver of Czeslaw Adam Siekierski's immunity on the basis that this is in accordance with Article 9 of the European Convention on Human Beings. Protocol No. 7 on the privileges and immunies of the European Union, and the fact that there is no reasonable doubt that immunity is lifted with a view to causing political harm, but is an infringement of exceeding the permitted speed in a populated area. In addition, Mr Siekierski allegedly admitted to driving the vehicle, and such a vote is also the position of the ALDE Group.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. This is an alleged violation of the Polish traffic law, for speeding. There is no indication that there is any intention to interfere with Mr. Adam Siekierski's business. Polish law requires a waiver of immunity in these cases. In accordance with national legislation, I am voting in favour of this request.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. – My colleagues and I voted to waive the immunity of Mr Siekierski, a Polish MEP (EPP/Polish People’s Party; Chairman AGRI) who is alleged to have committed an offence of speeding (exceeding the permitted speed limit in a built-up area). The alleged offence has no evident link of any kind to his duties as an MEP. In those circumstances the Polish Courts should have jurisdiction over his case.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the decision on the request to waive the parliamentary immunity of Czesaw Adam Siekierski. This procedure is a formality which, without deciding on the merits of the case, is intended to enable the judicial authorities to carry out their investigative work. This decision was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. I am voting in favour of waiving Mr Siekierski's immunity. It is important for Parliament's integrity and reputation that immunity can be waived for offences committed before the mandate was adopted.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted to lift the parliamentary immunity of Mr Czeslaw Adam Siekierski, because this is not a political matter but an alleged breach of the Polish traffic code for speeding. There is no indication that there is any intention to interfere with Mr. Siekierski's political activity. Polish law requires that his immunity be waived so that he can pay his fine.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted to lift Mr Siekierski's parliamentary immunity because the speeding charge has nothing to do with his parliamentary mandate.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour, as this is not an extradition of a political nature, but speeding, I trust the Polish judiciary to judge the act fairly.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. I supported the request for the waiver of Member Siekierski's immunity because parliamentary immunity should serve solely as an instrument of protection against political persecution. Parliamentary immunity cannot be used for the purpose of placing above the law. The Attorney General of the Republic of Poland forwarded the request of the General Inspectorate of Road Transport for the waiver of the immunity of Representative Siekierski, since the alleged infringement is specifically linked to exceeding the permitted speed in a populated area. The European Parliament should decide whether to lift immunity or not, as the alleged infringement is not directly or manifestly linked to the performance of Czesław Adam Siekierski's duties as a Member of the European Parliament.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 This vote to waive the immunity of a Member of the European Parliament concerns the fact of a breach of the offence of speeding by Polish MEP Česlav Aam Shekirski on 10 January 2015 in a built-up area. Mr Shekirska himself admitted that the offence took place a year ago, but chose to apply the immunity legally granted to its MEPs so that the Public Prosecutor's Office of the Republic of Poland could not legally investigate this speeding, bringing the relevant criminal proceedings. Although it is by no means necessary to abolish the practice of granting members' immunity, any person – especially an official as important as an MEP – who has not only done something illegal but has also acknowledged it himself must be responsible for his or her own actions on the basis of the principles of the rule of law. It was consequently logical to vote in favour of the waiver of immunity.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ MEPs enjoy the immunity granted to members of their national parliament on the territory of their state. Under the laws of the Republic of Poland, it is not possible to initiate criminal proceedings against a Member without the prior consent of Parliament. In order to properly investigate and evaluate the road traffic offence to be committed by the MEP, the MEP agreed to waive the Member's parliamentary immunity.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the request for waiver of the immunity of Czesław Adam Siekierski following the positive recommendation of the European Parliament's Committee on Legal Affairs.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this waiver of immunity. Parliament has received two requests from the Polish General Inspectorate of Road Traffic requesting the lifting of Czes-aw Adam Siekierski's immunity for an alleged speeding offence in an agglomeration. This first request for the waiver of immunity does not appear to have been made with the intention of interfering with the Member's political activity. We are therefore in favour of this waiver of immunity.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted to lift the immunity of Czesław Adam Siekierski as from the circumstances of the case it appears that the alleged offence and the ensuing prosecution clearly have nothing to do with the position of Mr Siekierski as a Member of the European Parliament and that there is no evidence of fumus persecutionis.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I expressed my opposition to the request for waiver of the immunity of Czeslaw Adam Siekierski because I believe that parliamentary immunity is not a personal privilege of a Member but a guarantee of the independence of Parliament and its Members as a super partes institution. I remain convinced that a guarantee line must be followed in these cases, so I will continue to vote against this type of report in defence of the institutional role conferred by this Parliament.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. The offence alleged is an administrative offence which is unrelated to the political activity of the Member. I therefore agree with the waiver of immunity.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The request concerns the lifting of the immunity of Czes-aw Adam Siekierski, a Member of the European Parliament elected for Poland. The Attorney General of the Republic of Poland has submitted a request from the Polish General Inspectorate of Road Traffic for an offence of speeding in an agglomeration.  Indeed, the Polish General Inspectorate of Road Traffic claims that on 19 April 2015, at 11:19 a.m., in the town of Stopnica, Mr. Siekierski was photographed by a radar while driving a vehicle travelling at 79 km/h on a stretch of speed limited to 50 km/h.  Since the offence is unrelated to his parliamentary activity and Czesaw Adam Siekierski does not object to the lifting of immunity, I vote For.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. This is an alleged violation of the Polish traffic law, for speeding. There is no indication that there is any intention to interfere with Mr. Adam Siekierski's business. Polish law requires a waiver of immunity in these cases. In accordance with national legislation, I am voting in favour of this request.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I have presented my vote in favour of the request for waiver of the parliamentary immunity of Czeslaw Adam Siekierski. The waiver of immunity shall be carried out where the case falls within the form of Article 9 of Protocol No 7, provided that there is no serious suspicion that there is an intention at the origin of the criminal proceedings to harm the Member concerned politically.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I chose to support this report regarding the waiver of the parliamentary immunity of Czesław Adam Siekierski as the alleged offence and the ensuing prosecution have nothing to do with the position of Mr Siekierski as a Member of the European Parliament.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of waiving the parliamentary immunity of Mr Czesław Adam Siekierski because on 13 August 2015 the Prosecutor-General of the Republic of Poland forwarded to the President of Parliament a request made by the Polish General Inspectorate of Road Traffic to grant authorisation to take legal action against a Member of the European Parliament, Mr Czesław Adam Siekierski , in connection with a speeding offence

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 According to the Polish Transport Police Inspectorate, MEP Czesław Adam Siekierski exceeded the maximum speed allowed in a populated area at 8.22am on 10 January 2015 and made an application to the European Parliament for the member's immunity to be suspended. In its report, Parliament's Committee on Legal Affairs stated that the alleged infringement was not directly or manifestly linked to the performance of the duties of Czesław Adam Siekierski MEP and that there was no serious and well-founded suspicion that the request had been made for the purpose of causing political damage to the Member and therefore requested that immunity be suspended. I voted accordingly.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. The Attorney General of the Republic of Poland has submitted two requests from the Polish General Inspectorate of Road Traffic calling for the lifting of the immunity of Czes-aw Adam Siekierski, a Member of the European Parliament elected for Poland, concerning two alleged offences relating to speeding in an agglomeration. In this case, Parliament did not establish that there was a sufficiently serious presumption and specified that the application was submitted with the intention of interfering with the political activity of the Member concerned. For a Polish MP to pay his fines in Poland, his immunity must be waived. There is a need to vote in favour of lifting it.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report deserves my vote in favour, once all the legal procedures required have elapsed and because the offence in question is not in any way related to the performance of the duties of a Member and because there is no evidence or suspicion that, at the origin of the criminal proceedings, the intention to harm the Member concerned is politically impaired.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. The lifting of the immunity of MEP Czes-aw Adam Siekierski is requested by the Polish Public Prosecutor's Office following two offences related to the alleged speeding of the speeding offence. The record shows that this is not a procedure designed to interfere with the member's political activity. Moreover, according to Polish law, the lifting of immunity is essential for an MP to pay his fines.  Taking these elements into account, I have decided to vote in favour of this text.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of lifting the parliamentary immunity of Czesaw Adam Siekierski. Any request made to the President of the European Parliament by the authorities of a Member State to waive a Member's immunity is heard by the relevant parliamentary committee. I voted in accordance with the opinion of this committee.

name: Renaud Muselier (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of Mrs Hautala's reports on a standard procedure for lifting parliamentary immunity in connection with traffic offences. The reports were supported by the EPP Group and adopted by the European Parliament.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 On 13 August 2015, the Attorney General of the Republic of Poland forwarded to the President of Parliament a request from the Polish Inspectorate-General for Road Traffic for authorisation to initiate legal proceedings against Czesław Adam Siekierski in relation to an infringement of the Highway Code. I voted in favour of the measure.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. – I have voted for this report according to the evaluation made by the JURI Committee.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted to waive the immunity of Mr Siekierski, a Polish MEP (EPP/Polish People’s Party; Chairman AGRI) who is alleged to have committed an offence of speeding (exceeding the permitted speed limit in a built-up area). The alleged offence has no evident link of any kind to his duties as an MEP. In those circumstances the Polish Courts should have jurisdiction over his case.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Given the action taken by Czesław MEP Adam Siekierski, elected MEP for Poland, I am voting in favour of the request for waiver of parliamentary immunity.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. The Attorney General of the Republic of Poland has submitted two requests from the Polish General Inspectorate of Road Traffic calling for the lifting of the immunity of Czes-aw Adam Siekierski, a Member of the European Parliament elected for Poland, concerning two alleged offences relating to speeding in an agglomeration.  In this case, Parliament could not establish that there was fumus persecutionis, that is, a sufficiently serious presumption, and specifies that the application was submitted with the intention of interfering with the political activity of the Member concerned. So I voted for this report.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ I respect the rapporteur's recommendation to lift the immunity of my colleague Czesław Adam Siekierski because, although prosecution is not related to the opinion expressed or voted in the performance of his or her duties as a Member of the European Parliament within the meaning of Article 8 of the EIA, it is not related to the opinion expressed or the vote to serve as a Member of the European Parliament within the meaning of Article 8(1) of the EEA. Protocol No. 7 on the privileges and immunies of the European Union, the alleged offence is clearly not in any relation to the performance of his duties as a Member of the European Parliament. It is a traffic offence of speeding in a populated area and there is no reason to assume that the prosecution was initiated with the intention of causing political harm to the member concerned (fumus persecutionis).

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Pursuant to Rule 9(3) of the Rules of Procedure, the Committee on Legal Affairs recommends that the European Parliament waive The honourable Member's parliamentary immunity. Czesław Adam Siekierski. I voted in favour of waiving the immunity of Czesław Member of the European Parliament Adam Siekierski because I believe it is appropriate to allow the Polish Attorney-General to carry out the appropriate investigations. Czesław Adam Siekierski is accused of speeding in his country.  The indictment relates to January 10, 2015. In any case, I would like to stress that my vote in favour of such a revocation does not involve a judgment as to the guilt or innocence of the Member.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the waiver of immunity because I agree with the view that Mr Siekierski is not an act related to the exercise of his mandate.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the requests to lift the parliamentary immunity of Czesaw Adam Siekierski. In this case, it is a common procedure.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 On 13 August 2015, the Polish Attorney General requested the waiver of the parliamentary immunity of Czesław Adam Siekierski in the context of a criminal procedure opened by the General Inspectorate of Road Traffic of Poland, in which the Member of the European Parliament is accused of a traffic offence relating to failure to comply with the speed limit applicable to urban agglomerations. Under Article 9 of Protocol No 7 on the Privileges and Immunities of the European Union, Members of the European Parliament shall benefit, in their own State, from the immunities granted to members of their national parliament. In this context, and in view of the provisions of the Constitution of the Republic of Poland, a decision of the European Parliament is necessary to determine whether criminal proceedings can be brought against Mr Czesław Adam Siekierski.  However, according to the report of the Committee on Legal Affairs, in view of the circumstances of the case, it can be concluded that the alleged infringement is not related to the activity of Czesław Adam Siekierski as an MEP and there is no further evidence of fumus persecutionis. Accordingly, and in the light of that report, I voted in favour of this Decision to lift the immunity of Czesław Adam Siekierski.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted to waive the immunity of Mr Siekierski, a Polish MEP (EPP/Polish People’s Party; Chairman AGRI) who is alleged to have committed an offence of speeding (exceeding the permitted speed limit in a built-up area). The alleged offence has no evident link of any kind to his duties as an MEP. In those circumstances the Polish Courts should have jurisdiction over his case.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. This is the waiver of the immunity of the Member of the European Parliament elected by Poland, Czesław Adam Siekierski, due to a traffic offence. The Polish General Road Traffic Inspectorate alleges that on 10 January 2015, while driving a vehicle, Mr Siekierski did not respect the speed limit applicable to urban agglomerations (50 km/h) when driving at a speed of 77 km/h.  I voted in favour of this report to give my colleague the opportunity to normalise this situation.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 This is a matter of Polish internal justice, unrelated to the status of Deputy of Czesław Adam Siekierski.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. As the report prepared by the Committee on Legal Affairs points out, the Attorney General of the Republic of Poland requested on 13 August 2015 to suspend the immunity of Czes-aw Adam Siekierski in relation to an infringement referred to in Article 92a of the Code of Administrative Infringements of 20 May 1971 in relation to Article 20 , paragraph 1, of the Traffic Act of 20 June 1997, consisting of exceeding the speed limit allowed in an urban area. In so far as the alleged infringement is not directly or manifestly related to the exercise of the functions of Member of the European Parliament of Czes-aw Adam Siekierski and that there is no evidence of fumus persecutionis, the European Parliament has decided to suspend parliamentary immunity, which is why I voted in favour of this decision.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. On 7 September 2015, the Attorney General of the Republic of Poland sent a request to the President of the Parliament from the Polish General Inspectorate of Road Traffic requesting permission to prosecute Mr Czes-aw Adam Siekierski in relation to speeding.  The Polish General Inspectorate of Road Traffic claimed that on 19 April 2015, at 11:19 a.m. in the town of Stopnica, Mr. Siekierski was photographed by a radar while driving a vehicle travelling at 79 km/h on a stretch of speed limited to 50 km/h. The facts alleged against Mr Siekierski constitute an offence within the meaning of Article 92a of the Polish Code of Administrative Offences, in connection with Article 20, paragraph 1, of the Polish Road Traffic Act of 20 June 1997.  On 5 October 2015, the President of the Parliament announced, in accordance with Article 9, paragraph 1, of the regulation, that he had received a letter from the Attorney General of the Republic of Poland requesting the lifting of immunity. On 27 October 2015, in accordance with Article 9, paragraph 1, of the Regulation, the President referred this request to the Committee on Legal Affairs. We voted on this case yesterday.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In the context of an alleged traffic infringement of Poland's road rules, the Polish Attorney General has forwarded to the President of the European Parliament a request from the Polish Road Traffic Inspectorate-General requesting authorisation to take action against Mr Czesław Adam Siekierski. This is a situation which fulfils the requirements for the application of Article 9 of Protocol No 7 on the privileges and immunities of the European Union, and therefore a decision of the European Parliament determining the possibility of criminal proceedings against that Member is necessary. However, since such an offence is not related to his activity as an MEP, nor is there evidence of persecutory intent, I agreed with the request for the waiver of the parliamentary immunity of Mr Czesław Adam Siekierski, giving my vote in favour of the report.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this immunity suspension plea. Czes-aw Adam Siekierski accepts the suspension of his immunity, which eliminates considerations of political persecution or harmful use for the institution of pleadings. The vote in committee was in favour unanimously. I follow the commission's proposal.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the suspension of the parliamentary immunity of Mr Czes-aw Adam Siekierski since the facts for which he has to stand before the court are not related to his activity as an MEP.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this as I do not believe the alleged offence was in line with his duties as an MEP.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ On 9 September 2015, Mr Czesław Adam Siekierski had been caught speeding in Poland, and given that the Polish constitution provides that Deputies and Senators must not be subject to criminal accountability without the consent of their respective chamber – in this case the European Parliament – I have voted in favour of waiving the immunity of Mr Sierkierski. It is clear that, at the time of this incident, Mr Sierkierski was not performing any parliamentary duties and there is no evidence of fumus persecutionis. I do not wish to stand in the way of the rule of law, and I see no reason not to waiver his immunity at this time.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: in writing ‒ the European Parliament received two requests for waiver of the immunity of Czesław Adam Siekierski, which were submitted to the European Parliament by the Attorney General of the Republic of Poland. Applications were made in connection with criminal proceedings brought by the Polish Inspectorate-General for Road Traffic. Both requests were unanimously received by the Committee on Legal Affairs (JURI). Furthermore, Mr Siekierski himself expressed his understanding that his immunity should be lifted in order to carry out further legal action in this case. For this reason, I voted in favour of adopting this proposal to waive immunity.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ I supported the request to waive the parliamentary immunity of Czeslaw Adam Siekiersky, an MEP for the Republic of Poland. The request was made by the Attorney General of the Republic of Poland to the President of the EP so that proceedings could be initiated against an MEP in relation to speeding offences. Poland's chief traffic inspectorate says that on January 10, 2015, Mr Siekierski failed to maintain the highest speed limit in the built-up area while driving. The Chief Inspectorate also stated that, in response to the summons, the Member had sent copies of his parliamentary licence, a certificate of his election to the European Parliament and a statement admitting that he had driven the vehicle at the appropriate time. The acts of which Mr Siekierski is accused constitute a misdemeanor within the meaning of Polish law on administrative offences. Although Mr Siekierski pleaded guilty, he did not indicate on the relevant form whether he was accepting or refusing a fine, so it was necessary to waive the Member's immunity in order for the competent authorities of the Republic of Poland to bring the offence to an end.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒As the alleged infringement is not directly or manifestly linked to the performance of Czesław Adam Siekierski's duties as a Member of the European Parliament and since there is no reason to assume, i.e. sufficiently serious and reasonable suspicion that the application was made with the intention of causing political harm to the member concerned (fumus persecutionis), I supported the request for the waiver of immunity.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The rule of law is necessary for society as a whole to function in a safe and reliable manner. In front of the authorities, we all need to be equal and we must obey the laws. I support the waiver of Mr. Siekierski's immunity because he was speeding and thus violated the legal limit of 50 km/h. He is to prove his innocence before the authorities in a case in which he is charged with breaking the law or applying sanctions with dignity. As a representative, he can thus send a positive message to society, because he is a member of a group whose behavior creates the morale of the community.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 Parliamentary privileges must under no circumstances lead to unequal and privileged treatment of Members vis-à-vis law and justice.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I did vote for my colleague's immunity to be waived so that he could pay his driving fine.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ The Polish General Inspectorate of Road Traffic accuses Mr Siekierski of failing to respect the speed limit on 19 January 2015. This accusation does not impact Mr Siekierski’s capacity to perform his duty as an MEP nor is it intended to cause him political damage. Therefore I voted in favour of waiving the immunity of MEP Czesław Adam Siekierski.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. In this case, the request for waiver of immunity of Czesław Adam Siekierski was made on the basis of an alleged offence – speeding the maximum speed limit in the populated area.  From the circumstances of the case, the alleged offence and the resulting criminal prosecution appear to be in no way linked to the situation of Czesław Adam Siekierski as a Member of the European Parliament. I supported the report on the request for waiver of the parliamentary immunity of Czesław Adam Siekierski.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this immunity suspension plea. Czes-aw Adam Siekierski accepts the suspension of his immunity, which eliminates considerations of political persecution or harmful use for the institution of pleadings. The vote in committee was in favour unanimously. I follow the commission's proposal.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. The Attorney General of the Republic of Poland has submitted two requests from the Polish General Inspectorate of Road Traffic calling for the lifting of the immunity of Czes-aw Adam Siekierski, a Member of the European Parliament elected for Poland, concerning two alleged offences relating to speeding in an agglomeration. In this case, Parliament could not establish that there was fumus persecutionis, that is, a sufficiently serious presumption, and specifies that the application was submitted with the intention of interfering with the political activity of the Member concerned. For a Polish MP to pay his fines in Poland, his immunity must be waived. So I voted for it.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 On 13 August 2015, the Chief Prosecutor of the Republic of Poland forwarded to the President of Parliament a request from the Polish Inspector General for Transport Police to allow Czesław Adam Siekierski MEP to be prosecuted in connection with a speeding offence. The Polish Transport Police Inspectorate claims Siekierski was driving at 77km/h in a residential area and admitted to driving the car and sent his European Parliament id in a photocopy. Following the S&D group's decision, I supported the waived immunity.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of waiving the immunity as the alleged offence amounts to exceeding the permitted speed limit in a built-up area.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the suspension of the parliamentary immunity of Mr Czes-aw Adam Siekierski since the facts for which he has to stand before the court are not related to his activity as an MEP.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. 'The Polish traffic authorities accuse Adam Siekierski of speeding on 19 January 2015. I voted in favour of the decision to lift his parliamentary immunity as this waiver cannot affect his work as an MP and it must be clear that MPs are not above the law.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report focuses on the request for the waiver of parliamentary immunity of Mr Czesław Adam Siekierski. The General Inspectorate of Road Traffic of Poland submits that, on 10 January 2015, when driving a vehicle, Mr Siekierski did not respect the speed limit applicable to urban agglomerations. The alleged infringement does not have a direct and obvious link with the exercise of Czesław Adam Siekierski's duties as a Member of the European Parliament, and Parliament has also found no reasoned evidence that the request is intended to undermine the political activity of the Member.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. The offence alleged is an administrative offence which is unrelated to the political activity of the Member. I therefore agree with the waiver of immunity.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report focuses on the request for the waiver of parliamentary immunity of Mr Czesław Adam Siekierski. The General Inspectorate of Road Traffic in Poland submits that, when driving a vehicle, Mr Siekierski did not respect the speed limit applicable to urban agglomerations. The honourable Member admitted that he was driving the vehicle at the time of the infringement. The facts of which he is accused constitute an infringement of Article 92(a) of the Polish Code of Contratomes, together with Article 20(1) of the Road Traffic Act of 20 June 1997.  The alleged infringement does not have a direct and obvious link with the exercise of Czesław Adam Siekierski's duties as a Member of the European Parliament, and Parliament has also found no reasoned evidence that the request is intended to undermine the political activity of the Member. We voted in favor of withgoing immunity.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the suspension of the parliamentary immunity of Mr Czes-aw Adam Siekierski since the facts for which he has to stand before the court are not related to his activity as an MEP.

name: Martina Anderson and Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – The MEP in question accepts his immunity being waived and is not contesting it and there is no question of political interference. Therefore, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. This is an alleged violation of the Polish traffic law, for speeding. There is no indication that there is any intention to interfere with Mr. Adam Siekierski's business. Polish law requires a waiver of immunity in these cases. In accordance with national legislation, I am voting in favour of this request.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I believe in democracy and transparency, and therefore I believe that my vote on this matter should be a matter of public record.  In that spirit, I wish to confirm that I voted to waive the parliamentary immunity. I do wish to note, however, my annoyance at the amount of public time spent dealing with a minor speeding offence.  However, ultimately, that is a matter for the people of Poland rather than the United Kingdom.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendations of the Committee on Legal Affairs.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. It is on the grounds of an alleged violation of the traffic law, in this case a speeding offence allegedly committed in Poland, that Mr Siekierski's parliamentary immunity is lifted. Polish law requires the lifting of his immunity so that he can pay his fine. There is no indication that there is any intention to interfere with his political activity, so I have seen no reason not to accept this request from the Polish justice system.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. Following the unanimous opinion of the Committee on Legal Affairs, I approved the lifting of Mr Siekierski's parliamentary immunity.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this immunity suspension plea. Czes-aw Adam Siekierski accepts the suspension of his immunity, which eliminates considerations of political persecution or harmful use for the institution of pleadings. The vote in committee was in favour unanimously. I follow the commission's proposal.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. The Polish Attorney General has submitted a request from the Polish General Inspectorate of Road Traffic requesting the lifting of the immunity of Mr Siekierski, a Member of the European Parliament elected for Poland, for a driving offence. The alleged offences relate to a speeding offence recorded by the Polish Traffic Inspectorate on 10 January 2015, in an area where he should have been travelling at 50 km/h (not 77 km/h as recorded by radar). The alleged offence is not directly related to Mr Siekierski's exercise of his duties as a Member of the European Parliament and that, in addition, the Parliamentary Committee finds no evidence of fumus persecutionis, i.e. sufficiently serious and precise indications that these proceedings were initiated with the aim of harming the political career of the Member concerned, it is necessary that his immunity be lifted in order for him to pay his fines.  So I voted for this report.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. As the report prepared by the Committee on Legal Affairs points out, the Attorney-General of the Republic of Poland requested on 7 September that Czes-aw Adam Siekierski's immunity be suspended in relation to an infringement referred to in Article 92a of the Code of Administrative Infringements of 20 May 1971 in relation to Article 20 , paragraph 1, of the Traffic Act of 20 June 1997, consisting of exceeding the speed limit allowed in an urban area. In so far as the alleged infringement is not directly or manifestly related to the exercise of the functions of Member of the European Parliament of Czes-aw Adam Siekierski and that there is no evidence of fumus persecutionis, the European Parliament has decided to suspend, with my favourable vote, parliamentary immunity.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, in which the European Parliament deals with another issue of the immunity of Czesław Adam Siekierskis on road traffic offences. On 13 August 2015, the Public Prosecutor General of the Republic of Poland referred the President of Parliament to the Polish Inspector General for Road Traffic Inspectorate for permission to bring the european Parliament Member Czesław Adam Siekiersk to justice for an administrative offence of speeding. According to the General Road Traffic Inspectorate of Poland, at 11.19 am on 19 April 2015, the Polish General Inspectorate of Road Traffic was 11.19. The speed camera in the city of Stopnikos recorded that C. A. Siekierskis was driving a car at 79 km/h in the area with a speed of 50 km/h. The Inspector-General further states that, in response to the summons sent to Mr Siekierski on 29 April 2015, Mr Siekierski sent copies of his MEP's IDENTITY card, a certificate of election to the European Parliament and a statement in which he acknowledges that he was driving the vehicle at the specified time. It is apparent from the case-file that Mr Siekierskis admitted that he was driving the vehicle at the specified time, but did not indicate in the form in question whether he accepted or opposed the imposition of the fine. It is apparent from the circumstances of the case that the suspicion of an administrative offence and further administrative prosecution have nothing to do with mr Siekierski's duties as a Member of the European Parliament.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this request for the waiver of Mr Syrendt's immunity. Mr Sikierski, because I believe that the infringement committed by Mr Sikierski is a violation of the rules of procedure. Mr Sikierski is not covered by the rules on parliamentary immunity of the European Parliament.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Vote in favour, these are two violations of the highway code. There is no reason to guarantee the protection of immunity.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ The MEP in question accepts his immunity being waived and is not contesting it, and there is no question of political interference. Therefore, I voted in favour of this report.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted to waive the immunity of Mr Siekierski, a Polish MEP (EPP/Polish People’s Party; Chairman AGRI) who is alleged to have committed an offence of speeding (exceeding the permitted speed limit in a built-up area). The alleged offence has no evident link of any kind to his duties as an MEP. In those circumstances the Polish Courts should have jurisdiction over his case.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that immunity should not be regarded as a personal privilege, but as a safeguard to ensure that every Member of this Parliament carries out his mandate in freedom and independence. The events in which the Polish Attorney-General is asking to be allowed to proceed have nothing to do with the conduct of Mr Syp.'s parliamentary mandate. Czeslaw Afam Siekierski and I have therefore chosen to vote in favour of the request for waiver of immunity.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the report on the request for waiver of the immunity of Mr Czesław Adam Siekierski.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I chose to vote in favour of the measure. On 7 September 2015, the Attorney General of the Republic of Poland forwarded to the President of Parliament a request from the Polish Inspectorate-General for Road Traffic for authorisation to initiate legal proceedings against Czesław MEP Adam Siekierski in relation to a traffic offence.

name: David Coburn (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted to waive the immunity of Mr Siekierski, a Polish MEP (EPP/Polish People’s Party; Chairman AGRI) who is alleged to have committed an offence of speeding (exceeding the permitted speed limit in a built-up area). The alleged offence has no evident link of any kind to his duties as an MEP. In those circumstances the Polish Courts should have jurisdiction over his case.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Whereas the Committee on Legal Affairs of the European Parliament has followed correctly the procedures for verifying the conditions for the invocation of immunity by Mr Siekierski, and i therefore felt that I should vote in favour.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
