text: in writing. ‒ Parliamentary immunity is not a Member’s personal privilege but a guarantee of the independence of Parliament as a whole and of its Members. The case in question does not have a direct and obvious connection with the Member’s performance of his duties as a Member of the European Parliament nor does it constitute an opinion expressed or a vote cast in the performance of his duties as a Member of the European Parliament for the purposes of Article 8 of Protocol No 7. I have thus voted in favour of the report to waive the immunity of the Member.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the suspension of the parliamentary immunity of Mr Czes-aw Adam Siekierski since the facts for which he has to stand before the court are not related to his activity as an MEP.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Article 7 on the Privileges and Immunities of the European Union states that MEPs enjoy immunity in the territory of their own State. This report requests the removal of the parliamentary immunity for an MEP. As I have always done in these cases I agree to the removal of immunity so that an MEP can prove his innocence or otherwise according to the judicial system of the relevant Member States.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. The facts alleged against Mr Siekierski relate to an alleged violation of the Polish traffic law. These are not prosecutions aimed at undermining our colleague's parliamentary activity and political engagement. The lifting of immunity being necessary for the judicial process, I decided to support it.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 Parliamentary privileges must under no circumstances lead to unequal and privileged treatment of Members vis-à-vis law and justice.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Last September, the Attorney General of the Republic of Poland transmitted to the President of the European Parliament a request from the General Inspectorate of Road Traffic of Poland, requesting permission to take action against Mr Czesław Adam Siekierski for a traffic offence. As the Polish Constitution stipulates that it is not possible to criminal action against Members and Senators of Parliament or the Senate without the prior authorisation of Parliament or the Senate of which they are members, a decision of the European Parliament is necessary determining whether criminal proceedings can be brought against Mr Siekierski. In this case, the request for waiver of the member's immunity was submitted as a result of an alleged infringement consisting of an excess of the speed limit applicable to urban agglomerations. It is inferred from the case that Mr Siekierski admitted that he was driving the vehicle at the time of the infringement, although he did not state in the relevant form whether or not he accepted the fine. The facts are not related to your activity as a Member of the European Parliament, agreeing to the waiver of parliamentary immunity

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This is the second report on a request for the waiver of the parliamentary immunity of Mr Czesław Adam Siekierski. In this case, it is again an infringement of the Polish Code of Contraortism. The difference, this time, lies in the speed at which the Member was moving: at 79 km/h in an area with a speed limit of 50 km/h. Once again, the alleged infringement has no direct and obvious link with the exercise of Czesław Adam Siekierski's duties as a Member of the European Parliament, and Parliament has also found no reasoned evidence that the request is intended to undermine the political activity of the Member. That is why we voted in favour of the waiver of immunity.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour as the offence was not related to his political activities.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 Parliamentary privileges must in no way lead to unequal and privileged treatment of Members vis-à-vis law and justice, which is why I am voting in favour of the report on the request for the waiver of the parliamentary immunity of Czesław Adam Siekierski.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the waiver of the parliamentary immunity of MEP Czesław Adam Siekierski, so that he will be able to pay his speeding ticket.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In deciding whether or not to waive the immunity of a Member in a particular case, the European Parliament applies its own permanent principles. One of these principles is that immunity is normally waived if the offence is governed by Article 9 of Protocol 7, provided that there is no serious and substantiated suspicion that the case was brought before the court for the purpose of causing political damage to the Member.  In that case, the request for the waivey of the immunity of Czesław Adam Siekierski was made in relation to a suspected infringement, exceeding the speed limit applicable to the populated area. Czesław Adam Siekierski admitted that he was driving the vehicle at the time in question, although he failed to indicate on the relevant form whether he would accept or refuse to pay the fine. In the circumstances of the case, it appears that the alleged offence and the resulting criminal liability are clearly not related to czesław Adam Siekierski's position as a Member of the European Parliament. On the basis of the foregoing considerations and in accordance with the Rules of Procedure, the Committee on Legal Affairs proposes that the European Parliament suspend the parliamentary immunity of Czesław Adam Siekierski.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this immunity suspension plea. Czes-aw Adam Siekierski accepts the suspension of his immunity, which eliminates considerations of political persecution or harmful use for the institution of pleadings. The vote in committee was in favour unanimously. I follow the commission's proposal.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 The appropriate attitude is that of voting in favour because the issues on which immunity is requested have nothing to do with parliamentary activity and because the MEP himself agrees with the waiver of his immunity.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report in relation to the request for the waiver of the parliamentary immunity of Czeslaw Adam Siekierski.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a proposal for a Decision of the European Parliament on the application for the waiver of Czeslaw Adam Siekierski's immunity on the basis that this is in accordance with Article 9 of the European Convention on Human Beings. Protocol No. 7 on the privileges and immunies of the European Union, and the fact that there is no reasonable doubt that immunity is lifted with a view to causing political harm, but is an infringement of exceeding the permitted speed in a populated area. In addition, Mr Siekierski allegedly admitted to driving the vehicle, and such a vote is also the position of the ALDE Group.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. This is an alleged violation of the Polish traffic law, for speeding. There is no indication that there is any intention to interfere with Mr. Adam Siekierski's business. Polish law requires a waiver of immunity in these cases. In accordance with national legislation, I am voting in favour of this request.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. – My colleagues and I voted to waive the immunity of Mr Siekierski, a Polish MEP (EPP/Polish People’s Party; Chairman AGRI) who is alleged to have committed an offence of speeding (exceeding the permitted speed limit in a built-up area). The alleged offence has no evident link of any kind to his duties as an MEP. In those circumstances the Polish Courts should have jurisdiction over his case.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the decision on the request to waive the parliamentary immunity of Czesaw Adam Siekierski. This procedure is a formality which, without deciding on the merits of the case, is intended to enable the judicial authorities to carry out their investigative work. This decision was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. I am voting in favour of waiving Mr Siekierski's immunity. It is important for Parliament's integrity and reputation that immunity can be waived for offences committed before the mandate was adopted.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted to lift the parliamentary immunity of Mr Czeslaw Adam Siekierski, because this is not a political matter but an alleged breach of the Polish traffic code for speeding. There is no indication that there is any intention to interfere with Mr. Siekierski's political activity. Polish law requires that his immunity be waived so that he can pay his fine.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted to lift Mr Siekierski's parliamentary immunity because the speeding charge has nothing to do with his parliamentary mandate.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour, as this is not an extradition of a political nature, but speeding, I trust the Polish judiciary to judge the act fairly.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. I supported the request for the waiver of Member Siekierski's immunity because parliamentary immunity should serve solely as an instrument of protection against political persecution. Parliamentary immunity cannot be used for the purpose of placing above the law. The Attorney General of the Republic of Poland forwarded the request of the General Inspectorate of Road Transport for the waiver of the immunity of Representative Siekierski, since the alleged infringement is specifically linked to exceeding the permitted speed in a populated area. The European Parliament should decide whether to lift immunity or not, as it is in accordance with Article 9(7) of the Regulation. The Rules of Procedure of the Committee on Legal Affairs cannot, under any circumstances, enter a plea to the Member's guilt.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 This vote to waive the immunity of a Member of the European Parliament concerns the fact of a breach of the offence by a Polish MEP, Ceslava Aam Shekirski, concerning speeding, which took place on 19 April 2015 at a place where the legal speed limit is 50 km/h, compared to 79 km/h recorded for Mr Šekirska's driver in the car. In other words, this case coincides completely with the previous speeding precedent, which took place three months before. As in the case of a previous vote, Mr Shekirska confessed to the fact of the offence, but chose to use his parliamentary immunity so that it would not be possible to prosecute him. I believe that, at least from a moral point of view, such action was not very acceptable in this case, so I voted in favour of the waiver of the immunity of a Member until all relevant criminal procedures are fully implemented and the case is closed following a formal resolution.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the request for waiver of the immunity of Czesław Adam Siekierski following the positive recommendation of the European Parliament's Committee on Legal Affairs.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this waiver of immunity. Parliament has received two requests from the Polish General Inspectorate of Road Traffic requesting the lifting of Immunity from Czes-aw Adam Siekierski for a second alleged speeding offence in an agglomeration. This second request for the waiver of immunity does not appear to have been made with the intention of interfering with the Member's political activity. We are therefore in favour of this waiver of immunity.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted to lift the Member’s immunity as there is no suspicion that the matter is being brought before a court with the intention of causing political damage to the Member concerned.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against the request for waiver of the immunity of Mr Czeslaw Adam Siekierski because I believe that parliamentary immunity is not a personal privilege of a Member but a guarantee of the independence of Parliament and its Members as a super partes institution. I remain convinced that a guarantee line must be followed in these cases, so I will continue to vote against this type of report in defence of the institutional role conferred by this Parliament.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. The offence alleged is an administrative offence which is unrelated to the political activity of the Member. I therefore agree with the waiver of immunity.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The request concerns the lifting of the immunity of Czes-aw Adam Siekierski, a Member of the European Parliament elected for Poland. The Attorney General of the Republic of Poland has submitted a request from the Polish General Inspectorate of Road Traffic for an offence of speeding in an agglomeration.  Indeed, the Polish General Inspectorate of Road Traffic claims that on 10 January 2015, at 20:22, Mr. Siekierski failed to comply with the speed limit in agglomeration, namely 50 km/h, and drove at a speed of 77 km/h.  Since the offence is unrelated to his parliamentary activity and Czes-aw Adam Siekierski does not object to the lifting of immunity, I vote For and I urge Mr.  Siekierski to be a little more cautious behind the wheel.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. This is an alleged violation of the Polish traffic law, for speeding. There is no indication that there is any intention to interfere with Mr. Adam Siekierski's business. Polish law requires a waiver of immunity in these cases. In accordance with national legislation, I am voting in favour of this request.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. I have presented my vote in favour of the request for the waiver of the parliamentary immunity of Czesław Adam Siekierski. The waiver of immunity shall be carried out where the case falls within the form of Article 9 of Protocol No 7, provided that there is no serious suspicion that there is an intention to politically harm the Member concerned at the origin of the criminal proceedings.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I chose to support this report regarding the waiver of the parliamentary immunity of Czesław Adam Siekierski as the charges concerned were not filed with the intention of causing political damage to the person concerned.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of waiving the parliamentary immunity of Czesław Adam Siekierski because on 7 September 2015 the Prosecutor-General of the Republic of Poland forwarded to the President of Parliament a request made by the Polish General Inspectorate of Road Traffic to grant authorisation to take legal action against a Member of the European Parliament, Mr Czesław Adam Siekierski , in connection with a speeding offence.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 According to the Polish Transport Police Inspectorate, MEP Czesław Adam Siekierski exceeded the maximum speed allowed in a populated area at 8.22am on 10 January 2015 and made an application to the European Parliament for the member's immunity to be suspended. In its report, Parliament's Committee on Legal Affairs stated that the alleged infringement was not directly or manifestly linked to the performance of the duties of Czesław Adam Siekierski MEP and that there was no serious and well-founded suspicion that the request had been made for the purpose of causing political damage to the Member and therefore requested that immunity be suspended. I voted accordingly.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report deserves my vote in favour, once all the legal procedures required have elapsed and because the offence in question is not in any way related to the performance of the duties of a Member and that there is no evidence or suspicion that, at the origin of the criminal proceedings, the intention to harm the Member concerned is politically impaired.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. The lifting of the immunity of MEP Czes-aw Adam Siekierski is requested by the Polish Public Prosecutor's Office following two offences related to the alleged speeding of the speeding offence. The record shows that this is not a procedure designed to interfere with the member's political activity. Moreover, according to Polish law, the lifting of immunity is essential for an MP to pay his fines.  Taking these elements into account, I have decided to vote in favour of this text.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of lifting the parliamentary immunity of Czesaw Adam Siekierski. Any request made to the President of the European Parliament by the authorities of a Member State to waive a Member's immunity is heard by the relevant parliamentary committee. I voted in accordance with the opinion of this committee.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 On 7 September 2015, the Attorney General of the Republic of Poland forwarded to the President of Parliament a request from the Polish Inspectorate-General for Road Traffic for authorisation to initiate legal proceedings against Czesław Adam Siekierski in relation to an infringement of the Highway Code. I voted in favour of the measure.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. – I have voted for this report according to the evaluation made by the JURI Committee.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted to waive the immunity of Mr Siekierski, a Polish MEP (EPP/Polish People’s Party; Chairman AGRI) who is alleged to have committed an offence of speeding (exceeding the permitted speed limit in a built-up area). The alleged offence has no evident link of any kind to his duties as an MEP. In those circumstances the Polish Courts should have jurisdiction over his case.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Given the action taken by Czesław MEP Adam Siekierski, elected MEP for Poland, I am voting in favour of the request for waiver of parliamentary immunity.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. The Member himself has asked for his immunity in this matter to be lifted, and I am voting in favour of the report, which calls for this lifting.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ I respect the rapporteur's recommendation to lift the immunity of my colleague Czesław Adam Siekierski because, although prosecution is not related to the opinion expressed or voted in the performance of his or her duties as a Member of the European Parliament within the meaning of Article 8 of the EIA, it is not related to the opinion expressed or the vote to serve as a Member of the European Parliament within the meaning of Article 8(1) of the EEA. Protocol No. 7 on the privileges and immunies of the European Union, the alleged offence is clearly not in any relation to the performance of his duties as a Member of the European Parliament. It is a traffic offence of speeding in a populated area and there is no reason to assume that the prosecution was initiated with the intention of causing political harm to the member concerned (fumus persecutionis). At issue is compliance with the regulations of the member state from which fellow Siekierski comes, as stipulated in Article 9 of the European Union. Protocol No. 7 on the privileges and immunies of the European Union.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 On 7 September 2015, the Attorney General of the Republic of Poland forwarded to the President of Parliament the request made by the head of the municipal police to grant permission to initiate legal proceedings against Mr Syderman. Czesław Adam Siekierski. The reason for this request would be a high speeding while driving a car. Pursuant to Rule 9(3) of the Rules of Procedure, the Committee on Legal Affairs recommends that the European Parliament waive the parliamentary immunity of Mr Sleyn. Czesław Adam Siekierski. I voted in favour of waiving immunity so that the Polish authorities can proceed with the verification of whether or not the traffic code has been breached.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the requests to lift the parliamentary immunity of Czesaw Adam Siekierski. In this case, it is a common procedure.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 On 7 September 2015, the Polish Attorney General requested the waiver of the parliamentary immunity of Czesław Adam Siekierski in the context of criminal proceedings opened by the General Inspectorate of Road Traffic of Poland, in which the Member of the European Parliament is accused of a traffic offence relating to failure to comply with the speed limit applicable to urban agglomerations. Under Article 9 of Protocol No 7 on the Privileges and Immunities of the European Union, Members of the European Parliament shall benefit, in their own State, from the immunities granted to members of their national parliament. In this context, and in view of the provisions of the Constitution of the Republic of Poland, a decision of the European Parliament is necessary to determine whether criminal proceedings can be brought against Mr Czesław Adam Siekierski. However, according to the report of the Committee on Legal Affairs, in view of the circumstances of the case, it can be concluded that the alleged infringement is not related to the activity of Czesław Adam Siekierski as an MEP and there is no further evidence of fumus persecutionis. Accordingly, and in the light of that report, I voted in favour of this Decision to lift the immunity of Czesław Adam Siekierski.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted to waive the immunity of Mr Siekierski, a Polish MEP (EPP/Polish People’s Party; Chairman AGRI) who is alleged to have committed an offence of speeding (exceeding the permitted speed limit in a built-up area). The alleged offence has no evident link of any kind to his duties as an MEP. In those circumstances the Polish Courts should have jurisdiction over his case.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. This is the waiver of the immunity of the Member of the European Parliament elected by Poland, Czesław Adam Siekierski, due to a traffic offence. The General Inspectorate of Road Traffic in Poland submits that on 10 January 2015, when driving a vehicle, Mr Siekierski did not respect the speed limit applicable to urban agglomerations (50 km/h) when driving at a speed of 77 km/h.  I voted in favour of this report to give my colleague the opportunity to normalise this situation.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 This is a matter of Polish internal justice, unrelated to the status of Deputy of Czesław Adam Siekierski.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. As the report prepared by the Committee on Legal Affairs points out, the Attorney General of the Republic of Poland requested on 13 August 2015 to suspend the immunity of Czes-aw Adam Siekierski in relation to an infringement referred to in Article 92a of the Code of Administrative Infringements of 20 May 1971 in relation to Article 20 , paragraph 1, of the Traffic Act of 20 June 1997, consisting of exceeding the speed limit allowed in an urban area. In so far as the alleged infringement is not directly or manifestly related to the exercise of the functions of Member of the European Parliament of Czes-aw Adam Siekierski and that there is no evidence of fumus persecutionis, the European Parliament has decided to suspend parliamentary immunity, which is why I voted in favour of this decision.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. On 7 September 2015, the Attorney General of the Republic of Poland sent a request to the President of the Parliament from the Polish General Inspectorate of Road Traffic requesting permission to prosecute Mr Czes-aw Adam Siekierski in relation to speeding.  The Polish General Inspectorate of Road Traffic claimed that on 19 April 2015, at 11:19 a.m. in the town of Stopnica, Mr. Siekierski was photographed by a radar while driving a vehicle travelling at 79 km/h on a stretch of speed limited to 50 km/h. The facts alleged against Mr Siekierski constitute an offence within the meaning of Article 92a of the Polish Code of Administrative Offences, in connection with Article 20, paragraph 1, of the Polish Road Traffic Act of 20 June 1997.  On 5 October 2015, the President of the Parliament announced, in accordance with Article 9, paragraph 1, of the regulation, that he had received a letter from the Attorney General of the Republic of Poland requesting the lifting of immunity. On 27 October 2015, in accordance with Article 9, paragraph 1, of the Regulation, the President referred this request to the Committee on Legal Affairs. We voted on this case yesterday.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report concerns the request for the waiver of the parliamentary immunity of Mr Czesław Adam Siekierski. This is a request made by the Attorney General of the Republic of Poland, concerning a case relating to a traffic offence where, allegedly, on 19 April 2015, when driving a vehicle, Mr Siekierski did not respect the speed limit applicable to urban agglomerations – which is 50 km/h – when driving the vehicle referred to at a speed of 79 km/h. There is no reason to doubt the legitimate intention underlying this legal action, and i voted in favour of the requirements of Article 9 of Protocol No 7 on the privileges and immunities of the European Union.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this immunity suspension plea. Czes-aw Adam Siekierski accepts the suspension of his immunity, which eliminates considerations of political persecution or harmful use for the institution of pleadings. The vote in committee was in favour unanimously. I follow the commission's proposal.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the suspension of the parliamentary immunity of Mr Czes-aw Adam Siekierski since the facts for which he has to stand before the court are not related to his activity as an MEP.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this as I do not believe the alleged offence was in line with his duties as an MEP.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Mr Siekerski was caught speeding in a built—up area on 5 October 2015. This is the second vote that the European Parliament has tabled against Czeclaw Siekierski for his traffic offences, and again I do not wish to stand in the way of the course of justice and so I give my consent to waiver this MEP’s parliamentary immunity at this time for this offence.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: in writing ‒ the European Parliament received two requests for waiver of the immunity of Czesław Adam Siekierski, which were submitted to the European Parliament by the Attorney General of the Republic of Poland. Applications were made in connection with criminal proceedings brought by the Polish Inspectorate-General for Road Traffic. Both requests were unanimously received by the Committee on Legal Affairs (JURI). Furthermore, Mr Siekierski himself expressed his understanding that his immunity should be lifted in order to carry out further legal action in this case. For this reason, I voted in favour of adopting this proposal to waive immunity.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ the Attorney General of the Republic of Poland has submitted a request for the waiver of the parliamentary immunity of Czeslaw MEP Adam Siekierski in connection with a speeding offence.  Poland's Chief Traffic Inspectorate says that on April 19, 2015, at 11.19am in the town of Stopnica Mr Siekiersky, a speed camera was recorded driving at 79km/h in a zone where speeds are limited to 50km/h. The Inspectorate of Inspectorate further states that, in response to the summons sent to him on 29 April 2015, Mr Siekierski sent copies of his parliamentary card, a certificate of his election to the European Parliament and a statement admitting that he was driving the vehicle at the appropriate time. The acts of which Mr Siekierski is accused constitute an offence under Article 92a of the Polish Law on Administrative Offences in conjunction with Article 20(1) of the Polish Road Traffic Act of 20 June 1997. In order for the proceedings to be brought to an end, it was necessary to waive the Member's immunity, for which I also voted, because I believe that MEPs must also abide by the law and regulations and have to bear the consequences of violating them.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒As the alleged infringement is not directly or manifestly linked to the performance of Czesław Adam Siekierski's duties as a Member of the European Parliament and since there is no reason to assume, i.e. sufficiently serious and reasonable suspicion that the application was made with the intention of causing political harm to the member concerned (fumus persecutionis), I supported the request for the waiver of immunity.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. I support the request to lift Mr. Siekierski's parliamentary immunity, as all disputes with the law need to be resolved before the authorities. Mr. Siekierski was driving at an unadjusted speed, which was charged by the Polish authorities. He admitted that he was at that place in Poland at that time. It is necessary to establish the facts and respect decisions taken on the basis of facts. If he is innocent, the suspicion will be removed from his name, if he is found to have actually broken the law, he should bear adequate sanctions in order to send a message to society. We all need to be equal before the authorities and respect laws that are the same for all citizens.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 Parliamentary privileges must under no circumstances lead to unequal and privileged treatment of Members vis-à-vis law and justice.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I did vote for my colleague's immunity to be waived so that he could pay his driving fine.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ The Polish General Inspectorate of Road Traffic accuses Mr Siekierski of failing to respect the speed limit on 19 April 2015. This accusation does not intend to cause political damage to Mr Siekierski. Without prejudging his guilt, I voted in favour of waiving the immunity of MEP Czesław Adam Siekierski.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ I supported a request to lift the parliamentary immunity of Polish MEP Czesław Adam Siekierski, who is accused of having twice last year committed the offence of exceeding the speed limit in a populated area. The Attorney General of the Republic of Poland forwarded the request of the Polish Inspectorate General of Road Transport for the waiver of Siekierski's immunity. Since that offence is not directly or manifestly linked to the performance of the duties of a Member of the European Parliament, I consider that there is no reason to assume, i.e. a sufficiently serious and reasonable suspicion that this procedure was initiated with the intention of causing political harm to the Member concerned. That is why I consider it right that an MP's immunity be lifted and that he be given a fair and impartial trial.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. In this case, the request for waiver of immunity of Czesław Adam Siekierski was made on the basis of an alleged offence – speeding the maximum speed limit in the populated area.  From the circumstances of the case, the alleged offence and the resulting criminal prosecution appear to be in no way linked to the situation of Czesław Adam Siekierski as a Member of the European Parliament. I supported the report on the request for waiver of the parliamentary immunity of Czesław Adam Siekierski.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this immunity suspension plea. Czes-aw Adam Siekierski accepts the suspension of his immunity, which eliminates considerations of political persecution or harmful use for the institution of pleadings. The vote in committee was in favour unanimously. I follow the commission's proposal.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 On 7 September 2015, the Chief Prosecutor of the Republic of Poland forwarded to the President of Parliament a request from the Polish Inspector General for Transport Police to allow czesław Adam Siekierski MEP to be prosecuted in connection with a speeding offence. Siekierski was driving at 79km/h in a residential area and admitted driving the car and sending a photocopy of his European Parliament id. Following the S&D group's decision, I supported the waived immunity.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of waiving the immunity as the alleged offence amounts to exceeding the permitted speed limit in a built-up area.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the suspension of the parliamentary immunity of Mr Czes-aw Adam Siekierski since the facts for which he has to stand before the court are not related to his activity as an MEP.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. 'The Polish traffic authorities accuse Adam Siekierski of speeding on 19 April 2015. I voted in favour of the decision to lift his parliamentary immunity as this waiver cannot affect his work as an MP.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report focuses on the request for the waiver of parliamentary immunity of Mr Czesław Adam Siekierski. The General Inspectorate of Road Traffic of Poland submits that, on 10 January 2015, when driving a vehicle, Mr Siekierski did not respect the speed limit applicable to urban agglomerations. The alleged infringement does not have a direct and obvious link with the exercise of Czesław Adam Siekierski's duties as a Member of the European Parliament, and Parliament has also found no reasoned evidence that the request is intended to undermine the political activity of the Member.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. The offence alleged is an administrative offence which is unrelated to the political activity of the Member. I therefore agree with the waiver of immunity.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report focuses on the request for the waiver of parliamentary immunity of Mr Czesław Adam Siekierski. The General Inspectorate of Road Traffic in Poland submits that, when driving a vehicle, Mr Siekierski did not respect the speed limit applicable to urban agglomerations. The honourable Member admitted that he was driving the vehicle at the time of the infringement. The facts of which he is accused constitute an infringement of Article 92(a) of the Polish Code of Contratomes, together with Article 20(1) of the Road Traffic Act of 20 June 1997.  The alleged infringement does not have a direct and obvious link with the exercise of Czesław Adam Siekierski's duties as a Member of the European Parliament, and Parliament has also found no reasoned evidence that the request is intended to undermine the political activity of the Member. We voted in favor of withgoing immunity.

name: Richard Corbett (S&D).
text: – Mr President, while we were discussing this yesterday Mr Farage raised an issue which had nothing to do with this report but which concerned the issue of sea bass and the measures taken to protect sea bass, with which he was dissatisfied, and he launched a tirade against the Commission. Yet I would have thought that somebody who had been a Member of this Parliament for so many years would know a little bit about how decisions are taken in this European Union. The Commission merely made a proposal on this. It was the elected Ministers of the national governments of the Member States who took the decision to which he objected, including the British Conservative Minister, Mr George Eustice, but rather than turning his fire on those responsible for the decision, he twists it and turns it into an attack on the Commission, displaying either his ignorance or his cynicism in trying to use this as an issue in the forthcoming British referendum. It is a deplorable way of behaving.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, it is a little difficult to speak here, with so much noise and so little respect for the people who have to intervene at the moment, but well, what I wanted to highlight, even though the adoption of this report has been postponed, is that the bluefin tuna stocks have improved considerably and that, however, the quota will not do so in the same way , because it seems that the work that fishermen do at sea every day is not important for many of the people who vote and decide here the future of all. That, not to mention the distribution of quotas made by the People's Party in the State after the quota for fishermen arrives. Because, if we talk about bluefin tuna today, we could also talk about the fence or we could talk about other fishing that drown every day, like the longline. Patting yourself on the back with your fisheries policy is not honest and, moreover, I believe that the word 'sovereignty' is very great for those who pass these kinds of measures against and with their backs on the general public. In this report we found that there was no position that valued the weight of fishermen's socio-economics and, moreover, we found it disgraceful precisely because of that. Now the report is going to continue to be studied and we are happy, but for our part, we are going to continue to fight for the bluefin tuna fishermen of the Mediterranean and the Canary Islands, the Atlantic, to recover a quota that corresponds to them by right.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – Mr President, i would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur The main objective of this draft legislative resolution was to promote a more effective overall fisheries policy for bluefin tuna stocks in the Atlantic and Mediterranean. It is planned to be implemented through support for traditional fishermen who use different types of amatzveja tools, such as almadraba traps, whose principled plus is their low impact on ecosystems. Given that bluefin tuna is classified as an endangered species, a number of measures will be implemented so as not to damage their rather fragile balance, thereby making it even weaker. Recreational and sport fishing will clearly have to take into account various rules, such as the surely exempting and re-admitted to the sea juvenile fish. In general, the amendments introduced, in parallel with the repeal of the Regulation, should become another mechanism for the standardisation of the European Union's fisheries policy, which is to be welcomed. Thank you!

name: Daniel Hannan (ECR).
text: – Mr President, it always makes sense to judge an organisation on the basis of its record. We have had the President of the Commission coming before this Chamber and explaining how the EU needs to expand into having a common military policy and a common tax policy and so on, so the first question we should ask before we make those steps is: how has it performed in the fields where it already has jurisdiction? Now the Common Fisheries Policy was introduced in 1972. Let us look at that record, look at the way in which, having hoovered up the stocks from the once teeming waters of the North Sea, we are now, as we see in this report, having to go further and further afield, exporting the ecological catastrophe and destroying what ought to have been a great renewable resource. Is there anything in that record that tells us that these are the same institutions, the same men and women, that we should put in charge of policing, or the army, or tax, or any new area of policy? Let us infer from what we can see.

name: Steven Woolfe (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, today a single man, a single Commissioner from Malta is introducing a regulation – not a directive – but a rule that will impact on 800 000 anglers in the United Kingdom who spend their leisure time seeking fish but who are being told now by one man, unelected by them, and unelected by anybody in Europe, that they can only catch one fish. It does not matter in this European Union about democracy; it does not matter about people power; it only matters about what the elites believe is right for them. Abraham Lincoln once said ‘no man is good enough to govern [...] without the other’s consent’. Oh pray, if only the European Union would understand the principle that ‘governance is by the people, for the people, and of the people’ to borrow another quote, not by themselves, for themselves, and only for themselves.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The International Commission for the Conservation of Tunas (ICCAT) is the international organization responsible for the protection of tuna species in the Atlantic area. In 2006, ICCAT adopted a 15-year plan for the recovery of bluefin tuna stocks in the Eastern Atlantic and mediterranean, which was periodically modified on the basis of stock assessment, control experience and new technologies. In order to make the measures taken for the recovery of bluefin tuna more effective, the Commission has proposed that the ICCAT recommendations be incorporated into Community law. I voted in favour.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it proposes a strategy for the recovery of bluefin tuna involving fishing communities that depend on the exploitation of this fishing resource. Many peoples in southern Europe have historically engaged in the exploitation of tuna, and they are the main stakeholders in the recovery of their population. In this sense, the report includes several specific references to the art of almadraba and the need to protect it in the context of conservation plans and the sharing of quotas of this species, favouring these traditional arts without industrial exploitation that harms populations much more and which are not linked to any territory. Because of the absolute need to recover this very important species and the need to do so with the communities living in it is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text to amend the regulation on the multi-year plan to rebuild bluefin tuna stocks in the East Atlantic and the Mediterranean.  Indeed, although this plan has some shortcomings, notably on the waste generated by the technique of sending boats to feed the tuna with mackerel or on stocks that benefit only a few tuna fishers, this text aims to support traditional bluefin tuna fishing methods.    Respectful of the environment because they are very selective, and involve very little energy consumption, I am in favour of these fishing techniques which must benefit from a specific advantageous regime.

name: Martina Anderson and Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – Multiannual recovery plan for bluefin tuna in the eastern Atlantic and the Mediterranean. On the Mato report, for Ireland it is not of particular relevance as we do not have a commercial quota for bluefin. However, we supported all the amendments to the proposal, and the subsequent text as amended.  However we did not support the original unamended Commission proposal and legislative resolution. In the original Commission proposal, it sought to immediately transpose future amendments to this recovery plan through delegated act on what could be considered arbitrary grounds. ‘On duly justified imperative grounds of urgency, the Commission shall adopt immediately applicable implementing acts’. This would result in further limited Parliamentary power and input, which we could not accept.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 In this report, Parliament has shaped its negotiating policy by incorporating the measures of the multiannual bluefin tuna recovery plan in the Eastern Atlantic and mediterranean into Union law. These measures, which I voted in favour of, were adopted by the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas in 2012-2014 and are aimed at the sustainable management of tuna stocks and respect for quota provisions in the Atlantic Ocean and adjacent seas. Furthermore, in addition to voting in favour of the measures, we were also able to pass our amendment, which concerned the owners of large fishing vessels and the negative consequences of their activities for the sustainability of fishing. We await the outcome of the negotiations with the European Commission and the Council.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. We are talking about a transposition of the ICCAT Convention (International Commission for the Conversation of Atlantic Tunas) and defending the prerogatives of the European Parliament by proposing the codecision procedure, in the face of the European Commission, which is asking for the possibility of doing delegated acts. It's a lesser evil.  However, this report allocates quotas, which is unfavourable to fishing in the Mediterranean. However, other traditional fishing methods, such as the Madrague, should be able to benefit from a specific advantageous regime. I therefore voted in favour of this text.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of an S&D amendment which seeks to review quotas to ensure that large vessels do not have a monopoly; even though such a matter should be in the domain of the member states I felt that it was important to make the resolution less bad. However, although I want to see bluefin tuna numbers recover, I do not believe that the EU should be adopting international agreements in its own name. That should be the responsibility of sovereign governments. Furthermore, the CFP has been a disaster for British fisheries and for management of fish stocks. I therefore voted against the report as a whole.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this deliberation because it aims to ensure the long-term conservation and optimal use of fisheries resources for sustainable fishing in Europe.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on the proposal for a multiannual recovery plan for bluefin tuna in the eastern Atlantic and Mediterranean. In order to ensure uniform and effective application of all measures of the Recovery Plan adopted throughout the European Union, this proposal aims to incorporate them into the Regulation. The proposal includes technical measures such as measures relating to carry-over and caging operations for live bluefin tuna, catch reporting requirements and the implementation of the Regional Observer Programme of the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. This is the transposition of a convention of the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas (ICCAT) on the replenishment of bluefin tuna stocks.  The Commission has asked to be able to do delegated acts, but the rapporteur defends the codecision procedure in order to maintain Parliament's prerogatives.  I voted in favour of this text calling for an increase in quotas for artisanal fishermen using traditional and selective fishing methods, a decision which would protect both stocks and jobs, as my colleague Sylvie Goddyn had asked in committee by tabling several amendments.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. I have endorsed this point, which aims to incorporate into a regulation the provisions of the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas (CICTA) in order to replenish bluefin tuna stocks.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the proposal for a regulation on the multiannual recovery plan for bluefin tuna in the Eastern Atlantic and the Mediterranean. This is a mainly technical measure aimed at transposing into Community law the measures of the recovery plan drawn up by ICCAT between 2012 and 2014. Bluefin tuna is an important fish resource for several EU countries, including Italy, and this project, alongside important measures, raises the issue of quotas. The current mechanism, which is managed at state level, has given priority and continues to favour large shipowners to the detriment of small-scale operators. Europe can and must work to overcome the current situation which, in addition to penalising small-scale fishermen, risks undermining the sustainability of fisheries. That is why the Group of the Party of European Socialists and Democrats has tabled and adopted an important amendment, which I supported, calling on the Member States to adopt fairer criteria in the distribution of quotas in order to favour small-scale fishermen.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. While no vote has been taken, what we would vote on is little more than the transposition into European legislation of the management plan for bluefin tuna produced by ICCAT. We do not agree with the quotas allocated and consider that States can put pressure on the Commission and the Council to have the EU position in ICCAT proposed as high as possible depending on the state of the tuna population, since our fishing fleets are in a critical socio-economic situation.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 While I agree with the objectives of rebuilding the bluefin tuna populations, there are still technical steps that I do not agree with and that leave me sceptical about a positive vote on this report, which is why I have decided to abstain.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. In order to ensure uniform and effective implementation throughout the EU, this proposal aims to incorporate into EU law the latest measures, adopted between 2012 and 2014, for the recovery plan for bluefin tuna adopted by the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tuna (ICCAT). While the Commission correctly transposes ICCAT's recommendations in most cases, it sometimes goes beyond what is decided by ICCAT and from EU law, EU operators cannot be penalised by stricter measures than agreed. The socialist amendment requiring a quota system for bluefin tuna with small-scale fishing would be incorporated into the report. It also addresses the absence of the European Parliament in international negotiations.  In short, I support the initiative that reviews existing regulations in this area, which was obsolete with regard to ICCAT's recommendations in recent years, while resolving some poor technical aspects, and was therefore dealt with broad consensus within the Committee on Fisheries of the European Parliament.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on a multiannual recovery plan for bluefin tuna in the eastern Atlantic and Mediterranean. The European Union is a Contracting Party to the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas (ICCAT), a regional fisheries management organisation (RVO) responsible for the management of tuna and their related species in the Atlantic Ocean and adjacent seas. ICCAT has the power to take decisions/recommendations on the conservation and management of fishery resources in its area of competence; these acts are binding; they must be transposed into European Union law. Bluefin tuna is the most important species regulated by ICCAT. In order to ensure uniform and effective application of all measures of the Recovery Plan adopted throughout the European Union, this proposal aims to incorporate them into the Regulation. The proposal includes technical measures such as measures relating to carry-over and caging operations for live bluefin tuna (including measures relating to the use of stereoscopic cameras for the evaluation of bluefin tuna quantities and quantities released), catch reporting requirements and the implementation of the ICCAT Regional Observer Programme.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Multi-annual recovery plan for bluefin tuna in the Eastern Atlantic and Mediterranean I supported the proposed report, as, in my opinion, it properly transposes into the European acquis the recommendations of the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas (ICCAT) and the Regional Fisheries Management Organisation (RFMO), which are originally responsible for the management of tuna and similar species in the Atlantic Ocean and neighbouring seas. Indeed, scientific data show that the quantity of bluefin tuna in the seas under the responsibility of ICCAT and RFMO is increasing, so the recovery of the stock and the allowable catch is the only logical step. The proposed Regulation thus ensures the uniform and effective implementation of all recovery plan measures that were otherwise adopted by ICCAT in 2012. The proposal also includes technical measures such as measures relating to the transmission and rearing of live bluefin tuna in a caging cage, including measures concerning the use of stereoscopic cameras to estimate the quantity of bluefin tuna and emissions, catch reporting requirements and the implementation of the ICCAT Regional Observation Programme.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. Given that parliament's role in the Commission's role with regard to these tuna stock conservation issues is strengthened by the transposition of the ICCAT Convention into European law and that this plan aims to protect traditional bluefin tuna fishing methods which are highly selective and environmentally friendly, I vote for this report , although some problems such as the exclusion of small-scale fishing or the effects of the quota allocation system are still unresolved.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. This multi-year plan to replenish bluefin tuna stocks in the East Atlantic and Mediterranean focuses on the transposition of the ICCAT (International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tuna) Convention. Although bluefin tuna stocks have been restored, some issues remain unresolved, as is the fact that quotas remain unfavourable to small-scale fishing. Nevertheless, the European Commission still wants to protect traditional bluefin tuna fishing methods, such as the environmentally friendly Madrague, which should benefit from a specific advantageous regime. I am committed to the defence of the environment and small-scale fishing, and I have spoken in favour of this text.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tuna (ICCAT) is the authority that takes decisions for the conservation and management of fishing activities in its area of competence. These acts are binding and must be transposed into EU law.  In 2006, the ICCAT adopted a multiannual plan to restore bluefin tuna stocks, which will end in 2022. This plan was successively amended by the ICCAT at its annual meetings. The purpose of transposing the ICCAT recommendations is to apply uniformly throughout the EU, which should aim to ensure a level playing field for all operators engaged in tuna fishing and in particular to operators in third countries. Otherwise, i.e. if different rules apply to foreign fleets, all the efforts made and all the restrictions imposed on EU fishermen will have no result.  I was in favour of this report because we need to ensure that the latest measures in the multiannual bluefin tuna recovery plan adopted by the ICCAT are applied uniformly and effectively throughout the European Union.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Vote in favour. The measure frees up the current monopoly mechanism for large shipowners and favours more sustainable fishing systems such as those relating to small-scale fishing.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted for Gabriel Mato's report on the Multi-Year Plan to Rebuild BlueFind Tuna Stocks in the East Atlantic and the Mediterranean. The report aims to transpose into EU law the measures of the multi-year recovery plan for bluefin tuna in the East Atlantic and the Mediterranean adopted by the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas (CICTA) between 2012 and 2014. CICTA is an international organization responsible for the management of tuna, to which the European Union is a contracting party. THE CICTA recommendations are binding acts, which must be transposed into EU law. The CICTA recovery plan includes: limiting fishing in certain areas and periods, the new minimum size, recreational fishing measures, livestock measures and strengthening inspection measures. They are valid until 2022.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Today the European Parliament adopted by a very large majority the amendment I tabled on the redistribution of bluefin tuna quotas. This measure is very much felt by small-scale artisanal fishermen because it calls on the Member States to review quotas on a fairer basis, without favouring the monopoly of a few shipowners, as is the case today. Not forgetting that, if a tuna is accidentally caught, the small fisherman is in danger of being severely penalised.  In 2015 there was a 20% increase in the overall fishing quota for bluefin tuna, an increase due to the progressive recovery of the stock, as certified by ICCAT. Unfortunately, this increase in the overall fishing quota for bluefin tuna decided at ICCAT has been applied according to discretionary distribution criteria by the individual Member States. A "flaw" that has led in many cases to the benefit of these quotas only a few shipowners at the expense of small artisanal fishermen. Large shipowners run out of quotas in a short space of time and take tuna to the places used for fattening, ensuring very high profits. The adoption of our amendment means that we want bluefin tuna to be able to reach our tables as well, and no longer just on Asian tuna.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which concerns the adjustment of fishing quotas for bluefin tuna in the Eastern Atlantic and Mediterranean in light of reports by the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas (ICCAT) that stocks have increased. Since there is scientific data proving that stocks are at healthy levels of abundance, it is justifiable that the total allowable catch is allowed to increase. The countries that have quotas (and that this report concerns) are Cyprus, France, Greece, Italy, Malta, Portugal and Spain.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this, not because we do not want bluefin tuna numbers to recover – we do – but because the report, by adopting an international agreement, endorses the EU’s right to operate the common fisheries policy – a behavioural-economic, long-term catastrophe, especially for the UK.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report as it introduces viable amendments to the text proposed by the Commission. For example, it supports traditional and artisanal fishing gear which has a fairy low impact on the ecosystems and the environment in general and also, among others, provides new methods for the allocation of quotas for each Member State. These, and other proposed measures will ensure the effectiveness of the recovery plan adopted by the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Since 2008, bluefin tuna biomass has been on a markedly positive trend. In 2014, the regional organisation decided to increase the TAC by 20% for the next three years (from 2015 to 2017), as well-founded scientific data attest that stocks are at optimal levels of abundance. In this text, the rapporteur welcomes this Commission proposal which aims to transpose the recommendations of ICCAT (International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas) into Community law. ICCAT has the power to take decisions on the conservation and management of fisheries in its area of competence. These acts are binding and must be transposed into UNION law. I voted in favour.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union is a Contracting Party to the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas (ICTAT) and the Regional Fisheries Management Organisation (SEA), which is responsible for the management of tuna and related species in the Atlantic Ocean and adjacent seas. ICTAT has the power to adopt decisions ('recommendations') on the conservation and management of fishery resources in its area of competence, acts which are binding on their transposition into Union law. That is why we support the report which stresses that uniform application must aim to ensure a level playing field for all operators involved in tuna fishing, including in particular non-EU operators, otherwise all efforts made and restrictions imposed on EU fishermen will not work if different rules apply to foreign fleets. EU bodies should not be harmed by the imposition of stricter than agreed measures because the Commission has not been able to impose such measures in the ICTAT negotiations.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because, in addition to sharing its content, I was pleased to see that sometimes the policies that this European Union imposes work. I hope that the development of the bluefin tuna stock will be a good anticipation of what will happen with the real economy: after years of deprivation and cuts, I hope to soon be able to enjoy the fruits of renewed growth. We really need it.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The current proposal for a regulation aims at transposing into Union law measures of the multiannual bluefin tuna (BFT) recovery plan in the Eastern Atlantic and the Mediterranean adopted by the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas (ICCAT) at its annual meetings between 2012 and 2014.  In 2006 ICCAT adopted a multiannual recovery plan for bluefin tuna, ending in 2022. In order to rebuild  the  stock, the plan sets up a gradual reduction in the total allowable catch level from 2007 to 2011, restrictions on fishing within certain areas and time periods, a new minimum size, measures concerning sport and recreational fishing activities, farming and fishing capacity measures and reinforced the ICCAT scheme of joint international inspection. The proposal contains technical measures such as those on transfer and caging operations of live bluefin tuna, including also measures on the use of stereoscopic cameras to estimate the quantities of bluefin tuna and releases, catch reporting requirements, and the implementation of the ICCAT regional observer programme.

name: David Coburn (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this, not because we do not want bluefin tuna numbers to recover – we do – but because the report, by adopting an international agreement, endorses the EU’s right to operate the common fisheries policy – a behavioural-economic, long-term catastrophe, especially for the UK.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the report by Mr Gabriel Mato on the Bluefin Tuna Recovery Plan. It is up to the European Commission to draw up proposals that comply with the recommendations of iccat (International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas). We are taking the necessary measures to work together with a multiannual bluefin tuna recovery plan, which ends in 2022. After several years of compressing the maximum number of authorised catches, there seems to be some growth, as there is scientific evidence to prove that stocks have healthy levels of abundance. I agree with the Rapporteur that he underlines the objective of ensuring a level playing field for all operators participating in tuna fishing, including third-country operators. Otherwise, if other rules are applied to foreign fleets, all efforts and restrictions applied to EU fishermen will have been in vain. I also appreciated the reference to craft frames, such as traditional frames ('almadrabas'), in the conservation of stocks. The European Union should pay particular attention to these traditional frames, which contribute to the reconstitution of tuna stocks, as they are extremely selective. In addition, they have very little impact on marine ecosystems, thanks to the low level of energy consumption and accidental catches.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the proposal for a regulation on the multiannual recovery plan for atlantic bluefin tuna fish stocks as the new measures providing for an increase in maximum fishing levels are sufficiently supported by scientific data on the current optimal level of abundance. For Italy, in particular, this will mean a 20% increase in the maximum allowable catch limits for the year 2016, significantly increasing the amount of fish caught without compromising the balance of our marine environment. Finally, it is hoped that these measures to be included in the reconstruction plan adopted from 2012 to 2014 will be transposed uniformly within the European Union and that all fish operators will be able to benefit from them without discrimination of any kind.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The rapporteur welcomes this Commission proposal which aims to transpose ICCAT's recommendations into Community law. ICCAT may take decisions ("recommendations") for the conservation and management of fisheries in its area of competence; these acts are binding and must be transposed into UNION law. Bluefin tuna is the most important species. Fishermen have made considerable efforts to adapt their catches to a reduced total allowable catch (TAC) as a result of the decisions taken in 2006 in accordance with the fishing conditions laid down in the plan. In view of the positive development of the state of stocks, ICCAT decided to increase the total allocation slightly. The current TAC for 2015 is 15 821 tonnes and the quota allocated to the EU is 9 372.9 tonnes. Since 2008, the biomass of bluefin tuna has tended to be clearly positive. In 2014, the regional organisation decided to increase the TAC by 20% for the next three years (from 2015 to 2017), as well-founded scientific data, attest that stocks are at optimal levels of abundance, which is why I am voting in favour of the report.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it proposes a strategy for the recovery of bluefin tuna involving fishing communities that depend on the exploitation of this fishing resource. Many peoples in southern Europe have historically engaged in the exploitation of tuna, and they are the main stakeholders in the recovery of their population. In this sense, the report includes several specific references to the art of almadraba and the need to protect it in the context of conservation plans and the sharing of quotas of this species, favouring these traditional arts without industrial exploitation that harms populations much more and which are not linked to any territory. Because of the absolute need to recover this very important species and the need to do so with the communities living in it is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 This is a sensitive issue, especially for our country, because the issue of bluefin tuna opens up the debate on the criteria for the distribution of quotas among fishermen. Tuna quotas are decided at ICCAT but internal distribution is managed at the discretion of individual Member States. In our case, we need to review criteria that have forced many small-scale fishing operators to divest their gear because they did not have access to quotas, despite the increase decreed by ICCAT. That is why I supported the amendment challenging the current mechanism from the monopoly of large shipowners, which aims to promote more sustainable fishing systems, such as those used by small-scale fishing. The Member States must do more to review the quota system, which is to the detriment of small-scale fishermen and their future.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The proposal aims to transpose into EU law the measures contained in the Multiannual Bluefin Tuna Recovery Plan in the Eastern Atlantic and the Mediterranean, adopted by the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas (ICCAT) at its annual meetings in 2012 and 2014. The multi-annual plan for the recovery of bluefin tuna stocks is a response to the significant decline in the stocks of this very valuable fish. According to data cited by experts, over the last 50 years the population of this species in the western Atlantic has decreased by 83% and in the Mediterranean. Currently, only 25% of the tuna population lives in these waters. In view of the above, I supported the motion for a resolution.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ As a contracting party since 1996, the European Union is bound to adhere to decisions taken by the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas (ICCAT) in order to ensure the conservation of underwater eco-systems under the EU’s Common Fisheries Policy. In the light of ICCAT’s previously proposed 15-year recovery plan, Parliament has been called upon to review proposed legislation based on a number of new ICCAT amendments to European Legislation to further safeguard the conversation of bluefin tuna in the Eastern Atlantic, and more specifically, in the Mediterranean. For this reason, I voted in favour of Gabriel Mato’s report on the implementation of a legislative replacement for EC 302/2009 concerning a multiannual recovery plan for bluefin tuna within the aforementioned areas as his recommendations follow the ICCAT recommendations.

name: Daniel Dalton (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome this report, bringing EU legislation into line with measures enacted by the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas (ICCAT), the overarching organisation responsible for the management of tuna. Although the UK has no direct fishing interests in tuna, it is important that the EU, as a member of ICCAT, respects its measures, and helps uphold international agreements on fishing, which is in all our interests.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This legislative report responds to the binding recommendations of the CICTA (Regional Fisheries Management Organisation to which the EU is a party) on the recovery of bluefin tuna stocks in the Atlantic and Mediterranean.  In 2006, CICTA launched a multi-year action plan to replenish stocks and end in 2022. In particular, it foresees a reduction in catches from 2007 to 2011, fishing limits by zones and periods, a new minimum size.  The aim is also to strengthen the international inspection programme through new surveillance techniques, such as the use of stereoscopic cameras to estimate the status of stocks. The report points out, however, that it is essential that these rules apply equally between European and third-country operators.  Sharing these conclusions, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported this report, which aims to transpose into EU law the measures adopted by the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas (CICTA), of which the EU is a contracting party. This regulation is intended to ensure the uniform application of the rules on the fishing and rearing of bluefin tuna in the EU, and thus to ensure equal conditions for all operators.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. Bluefin tuna remains at serious risk in the eastern Atlantic and Mediterranean. Of course, the introduction of quotas has improved the situation, but overfishing still threatens, as these quotas are the subject of bitter struggles between large tuna and small-scale fishermen. It is therefore necessary to find the right balance to safeguard the marine ecosystem while preserving artisanal fishing.  This is the meaning of the measures of the multi-year recovery plan for bluefin tuna in the East Atlantic and the Mediterranean, adopted by the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas (CICTA). In this context, special support and attention will be given to artisanal devices, such as traditional madragues ("almadrabas"), which have a very low impact on marine ecosystems due to their low level of energy consumption and accidental catches and their high level of selectivity.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. The purpose of this report is to support the transposition of the International Convention for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas. However, the rapporteur suggested curbing the Commission's eagerness by defending the codecision procedure rather than the delegated acts. The negotiating position of the European Parliament is thus strengthened, which I support and considers to be a democratic guarantee. For these reasons, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I decided to abstain for several reasons. It is very important that we do everything we can to address the damage done to the marine environment. Moreover, I would like to recall that we are talking about the easternmost regions of the Atlantic and the Mediterranean. Tuna and other organisms are also of great importance to the Black Sea region. Due to ineffective regulation, a serious lack of foresight and impartial management, in addition to continuous destruction of the marine environment by pollution. Overfishing natural resources oblige us to impose stricter environmental protection rules and to propose measures to ensure sustainability, not an increase in quotas on the advice of experts. Moreover, if we are not more careful and critical, we may find ourselves in a situation of economic and biological bankruptcy, which would create dependence on imported goods.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 We disagree with the logic of quotas in the various productive sectors of the economy of the Member States. We believe that quotas reduce the self-sufficiency of the Member States and cause withering in the South, where the economy traditionally relies heavily on primary production. The EU must indeed be interested in the conservation of these fish, but it must also be equally interested in maintaining the fishing profession itself, which we consider impossible with ICAT, as shown by the plethora of complaints from scientists, international organisations and NGOs sounding the alarm about its policies. It is the Member States that need to strengthen efforts to conserve biodiversity and their own economy. The necessary steps must be taken to strengthen the tuna population, but we believe that its general reduction was not caused by traditional fishermen but by the industrialised fishing of certain multinational companies.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Commission has proposed to incorporate the recommendations of the Atlantic Tuna Fisheries Commission (ICCAT) in order to maintain the stock of bluefin tuna in European fisheries legislation. In line with the Group of the European People's Party, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report. 30% of the earth's seas are overfished and marine fish stocks are at risk. It is therefore understandable that, in order to maintain marine fish stocks, the European Union is being forced to impose appropriate restrictions on sea fishing. Thus, the amount of marine fish fish fished is steadily and significantly reduced. Therefore, the common fisheries policy should pay much more attention to sustainable fish farming, i.e. aquaculture, and in particular freshwater fish farming. A significant number of fish ponds in Hungary are located in Natura 2000 sites. These farms do not pose any threat to the natural assets of these areas. Moreover, in many cases it is precisely because of our closed-system fish ponds that they have created or preserved individual wetland associations. Consequently, freshwater aquaculture should be prioritised and given as much EU support as possible. Furthermore, this area should be freed from unduly stringent and unnecessary sustainability standards, which are justified only for marine fishing and aquaculture.

name: Eleonora Evi (EFDD)
text: in writing. The Commission's proposal aims to transpose the ICCAT recommendations (i.e. the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas). Bluefin tuna in particular is certainly the most important species and the catch is regulated by ICCAT, which, having established a total allowable catch, has forced fishermen to make considerable logistical efforts to bring the tonnage of fish into line with the permitted limits. However, a positive evolution of the available stock, evidenced by scientific data, has led to an increase in total allowable catches for the EU, which has increased from 7939 tonnes in 2014 to 9372 tonnes in 2015. I voted in favour.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union is a Contracting Party to the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas (ICCAT), which has adopted a multiannual tuna recovery plan—bluefin, which ends in 2022. To allow the reconstitution of the stock, the plan provides for a gradual reduction in the level of total allowable catches between 2007 and 2011, fishing restrictions in certain areas and periods, a new minimum size, measures related to sport and recreational fishing activities and fishing and crop capacities, and strengthens iccat's joint international inspection programme. The current TAC in 2015 is 15 821 tonnes, with the EU at 9 372.9 tonnes. The proposal contains technical measures, such as those relating to the transfer and cageoperations of live bluefin tuna, including also measures on the use of stereoscopic cameras to estimate the quantities of bluefin tuna and releases, the requirements for the declaration of catches and the implementation of the ICCAT regional observation programme, with which I agree.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this deliberation because it is about protecting traditional fishing methods that are more concerned with environmental protection.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 After the species has reached a critical state, the multiannual bluefin tuna recovery plan adopted by the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas (ICCAT) in 2006 has enabled a positive evolution of its stocks. The biomass of this species has been trending positive since 2008. In 2014, ICCAT decided to increase the TAC by 20% for the subsequent three years (from 2015 to 2017). We generally follow the rapporteur's positions. We also follow the criticism of a more sustainable small-scale fishing quota system for the benefit of the major shipowners of europe's main fishing powers, and we have voted in favour of its amendment. Portugal does not currently have extractive fishing for bluefin tuna. In the Azores, only by-catches in the fishing of other tunas are allowed.
