The annual Portuguese quota of Tuna-Bluefin, of 332 tons in 2016, is almost completely exhausted by the existing frames in the Algarve. It was justified to change this situation, taking into account the most favourable context in the nature of species conservation, increasing the national quota and recognizing to azorean fishermen, the art of jumping and pole vault, the right to exploit this resource, now more abundant in the waters of the archipelago.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 This proposal aims to transpose into European Union law all measures of the bluefin tuna recovery plan in the Eastern Atlantic and mediterranean adopted by ICCAT. The project lays the foundations for a greater sensitivity towards small-scale fishing and for an implementation of the technicality of the tools used. However, I believe that some crucial points deserve more detailed clarification, such as the measures proposed in the regulation with regard to specimens of bluefin tuna accidentally caught and confiscated by the Authorities of the Member States. In most cases, the main focus is on punishing the fisherman who unwittingly caught the tuna specimen, for example by not dealing with the possible use of confiscated fish. Such clarifications, even following the introduction of the landing obligation, would ensure better application of the new provisions.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ The recovery plan for bluefin tuna appears to be very successful and efficient and therefore a real consideration is given to moving the 2017 TOTAL allowable catch to 2016. In order to ensure the uniform and effective application throughout the European Union of all the measures of the recovery plan adopted between 2012 and 2014, this proposal aims to integrate them into the Regulation. However, the problem of the European Parliament's non-participation in international negotiations still persists. The European Commission proposes to transpose future changes into this recovery plan by means of delegated acts. The withdrawal of this – already very limited – power that Parliament has at the last stage of approving international agreements would, in practice, mean that Parliament will have no say in ICCAT or in future in other international for a.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting against the multiannual bluefin tuna recovery plan in the Eastern Atlantic and the Mediterranean because I disagree with the logic of quotas in the various productive sectors of the Member States' economy. I believe that quotas reduce the self-sufficiency of the Member States and cause withering in the South, whose economy is traditionally and largely based on primary production. Indeed, the EU must be interested in the conservation of these fish, but it must also be interested in maintaining the fishing profession itself. I do not think that this can be done with ICAT, when there are such a plethora of complaints from scientists, international organisations and NGOs sounding the alarm about their policies. It is the Member States that need to strengthen efforts to conserve biodiversity and their own economy. The Member States must take the necessary steps to strengthen the tuna population, but I believe that the general reduction is not the responsibility of traditional fishermen but of the industrialised fishing of certain multinational companies.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ When dealing with this fishing sustainability, we must safe-guard long term productivity, promote local employment opportunities, encourage the development of a sustainable fisheries policy and a responsible exploitation of fisheries resources. Unfortunately, the current bluefin tuna fishing quota system penalises small-scale fishermen, and needs to be reviewed. Large vessels owners are too dominant and might harm the fishing sustainability.  I therefore support transposal into Union law of the measures of the multiannual bluefin tuna recovery plan in the Eastern Atlantic and the Mediterranean adopted by the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas (ICCAT) at its annual meetings between 2012 and 2014. I believe that the technical measures included in the multiannual recovery plan will lead to positive developments for environment, nature and local employment.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The new basic Regulation on the Common Fisheries Policy introduced a landing obligation covering bluefin tuna as of 1 January 2015. However, this landing obligation does not affect the Union's obligations under international recommendations, such as the ICCAT recommendations.  In this connection, the rapporteur would like to recall that the transposition of the ICCAT recommendations is intended to ensure uniform application throughout the EU and not to re-open debate on issues that have already been decided, often after lengthy negotiations covering all words and commas.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour considering that the European Union is responsible for the management of tuna and related species in the Atlantic Ocean and adjacent seas. A multiannual bluefin tuna recovery plan was adopted in 2006 and will be completed in 2022. However, the dramatic recovery seen in bluefin tuna stocks in recent years could justify a decision to advance to 2016 the total allowable catches planned for 2017 (23 155 tonnes), which would remain much lower than the TAC in force before the entry into force of the recovery plan. We must continue to work to achieve the sustainability of fisheries resources while ensuring the maintenance of an economic activity as important as fishing, not forgetting other actors in the sector who need detailed attention.

name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 With this report we have clearly expressed the European Parliament's support for small-scale fishing activities and the most artisanal and sustainable types of gear, such as traditional tuna, and we have clearly called for european consumers to be given European bluefin tuna, quality tuna, preventing the finest products from ending up on foreign markets. We will monitor the Council and the Member States to ensure that our words do not remain words but are soon turned into action.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the EP legislative resolution on the multiannual recovery plan for bluefin tuna in the Eastern Atlantic and the Mediterranean because I consider it to be a very important act in defence of sustainable fishing, the interests of territories, such as southern Italy, and economic operators often sacrificed in the face of the needs of big business. I am thinking of small-scale fishermen, who have often felt strangled by an excess of rules and regulations on quotas, which have so far benefited large industry at the expense of small local vessels. The S&D Group has fought to establish new quota systems for bluefin tuna fishing that eliminate the monopoly of large shipowners, promote sustainable fishing, and promote small-scale fishing. With the adoption of the Socialist amendment, The Member States will be able to use objective socio-economic and environmental criteria in the allocation of quotas and pay particular attention to the prosperity of small-scale, traditional and small-scale artisanal fishermen, encouraging their fishing techniques. This is an important step, born from listening directly to the territories and operators. It is now up to the Member States to review the course and find a high degree of synthesis between the economy, employment protection and respect for ecology.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted today in favour of the multiannual recovery plan for bluefin tuna in the East Atlantic and the Mediterranean. Maritime environmental protection and the preservation of our biodiversity are an important task for the EU, which must be used, above all, in the area of the common fisheries policy. All these measures also support small and medium-sized enterprises and family farms in fisheries and the blue economy.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. Bluefin tuna is an important component of biodiversity in the East Atlantic and the Mediterranean. I therefore support the efforts to achieve a uniform and, above all, sustainable fishing regime throughout Europe.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I  voted in favour of this report. I am pleased to see measures of the multiannual bluefin tuna recovery plan in the East Atlantic and Mediterranean, adopted by the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas (ICCAT) between 2012 and 2014, being transposed into EU law.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, but above all I voted in favour of my group's amendment against the monopoly of large shipowners to protect small-scale fishing and traditional techniques, the old tuna: all sustainable systems that disappear. It is a heritage that must be protected as much as the precious bluefin tuna

name: Sylvie Goddyn (ENF)
text: In writing. This project involves a transposition of the ICCAT Convention (International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas). The European Commission, wanting to act very quickly, and asked to be able to do delegated acts, but the rapporteur rightly defends the codecision procedure, in order to safeguard the prerogatives of the European Parliament.  Some problems are not solved by this plan: there is a lot of waste, thanks to the technique of sending boats to feed the tuna with mackerel.  Similarly, only a few tuna fishers benefit from the stocks; artisanal fishing is excluded, even though everyone claims to defend it. The allocation of quotas is still unfavourable to it, especially in the Mediterranean.  On this point, however, I note that an amendment in favour of a rebalancing of quotas in favour of small-scale fishing, close to an amendment which I myself had tabled in committee, has been adopted. Finally, both the European Commission and MEPs in the Fisheries Commission want to protect traditional bluefin tuna fishing methods, such as madrague. These fishing methods are very selective and therefore environmentally friendly. They should benefit from a specific advantageous scheme.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Although it has not been voted on, what we would vote on is little more than the transposition into European legislation of the management plan for bluefin tuna produced by ICCAT. We do not agree with the quotas allocated and consider that States can put pressure on the Commission and the Council to have the EU position in ICCAT proposed as high as possible depending on the state of the tuna population, since our fishing fleets are in a critical socio-economic situation.

name: Beata Gosiewska (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on a multiannual recovery plan for bluefin tuna stocks in the Eastern Atlantic and the Mediterranean repealing Regulation (EC) No 302/2009. I strongly support the plan to restore bluefin tuna stocks in the Eastern Atlantic and the Mediterranean. The application throughout the European Union of all measures contained in the recovery of bluefin tuna stocks is essential for uniform and effective action in this field. The current proposal aims to transpose technical measures into EU law contained in the multiannual bluefin tuna recovery plan.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I, alongside my fellow Labour MEP colleagues, voted in favour of this report. With this report we can transpose into Union law measures of the multiannual bluefin tuna recovery plan in the Eastern Atlantic and the Mediterranean as adopted by the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas (ICCAT) at its annual meetings between 2012 to 2014.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 The proposal aims to transpose into Union law the measures of the multiannual bluefin tuna recovery plan in the Eastern Atlantic and mediterranean adopted by the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tuna at its annual meeting between 2012-2014. The proposal includes technical measures and measures for the transport and trapping of live tuna catches. We believe that the appropriate attitude is that of voting in favour.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as I believe there is a need to rebuild bluefin tuna stock in order to make it sustainable into the future. The application of the ICCAT recommendations will help to ensure a uniform application of the management of tuna stocks across the EU. I also strongly agree with the amendments to support small-scale and traditional tuna fisheries, especially in the inter-institutional negotiations where a review of the quota system takes place. This will help to ensure that large vessel owners will no longer have a monopoly of the quotas.  Likewise, I fully supported the Parliament preserving its competencies regarding the transposition of the Regional Fisheries Management Organisation recommendations into EU law. Parliament, as an elected institution, has a right to input into legislation rather than the Commission using delegated or implementing acts which severely restricts the level of scrutiny over the Commission.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as I agree with the opinion that rules should be applied in a uniform way in order to ensure a level playing-field for all operators engaged in tuna fishing, including, most importantly, non-EU operators. Otherwise, all the efforts made and restrictions imposed on EU fishermen will have no result if different rules apply to foreign fleets. EU operators should not be penalised by the imposition of stricter measures than those agreed, because the Commission could not impose such measures in the negotiations in ICCAT.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ This proposal calls for the transposition into Union law of the measures of the multiannual bluefin tuna recovery plan, which entered into force in 2007. This plan, set forth by the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic, would require uniform application throughout the EU of the measures set forth by the recovery plan between 2012 and 2014 and would incorporate technical measures into a regulation. I have voted in favour of it.

name: Ian Hudghton (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which is necessary to ensure that the EU complies with international regulations relating to bluefin tuna.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome this report.  It mentions that fishermen have made considerable efforts to adjust their catches by complying with the strict fishing laws from the past and bluefin tuna biomass has been showing a dramatically positive trend since 2008.  This report contains technical measures such as those on transfer and caging operations of live bluefin tuna. All in all, this report aims at transposing into Union law measures of the multiannual bluefin tuna recovery plan in the Eastern Atlantic and the Mediterranean adopted by the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the proposal for a regulation by Parliament and the Council on a multiannual bluefin tuna recovery plan in the Eastern Atlantic and Mediterranean Sea and the repeal of Regulation (EC) No 100/2013. 302/2009 because I support the European Commission's proposal and the prompt implementation of international provisions in European legislation. In my view, it is necessary to ensure the restoration of tuna stocks, to determine a sustainable amount of possible catches, to limit fishing in certain areas and periods, and to establish clear rules for sport and recreational fishing. Such a thing leads to the preservation of biodiversity and marine ecosystems, which are seriously endangered, which is why harmonised and strong rules certainly contribute to the efficient protection of bluefin tuna.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. This is a transposition of the ICCAT (International Commission for the Conversation of Atlantic Tunas) Convention. The rapporteur wishes to defend the prerogatives of the European Parliament by proposing the codecision procedure, in the face of the European Commission, which is asking for the possibility of doing delegated acts. However, there are some flaws in this report, such as the allocation of quotas which is unfavourable to fishing in the Mediterranean. I voted for it.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. – I voted against this, not because we do not want bluefin tuna numbers to recover, we do, but because the report, by adopting an international agreement, endorses the EU’s right to operate the Common Fisheries Policy – a behavioural-economic, long-term catastrophe, especially for the UK.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Gabriel Mato's report on the multi-year plan to rebuild bluefin tuna stocks in the East Atlantic and the Mediterranean. The aim is to transpose into EU law measures adopted by the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas (CICTA), an organisation to which the European Union is a contracting party.  A gradual reduction in the capture of this species is planned, with increased inspections. The proposed regulation also calls for uniform enforcement so as not to penalise European fishermen. Finally, the specifics of some artisanal fisheries are taken into account, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which aimed to transpose into EU law a multi-year plan to replenish bluefin tuna stocks in the Atlantic And Mediterranean Seas.

name: Jarosław Kalinowski (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 During the period of economic growth following the end of World War II, fish consumption – including tuna – has increased in raw or canned form in developed countries, and Japanese sushi and sashimi dishes have become extremely popular in Europe and around the world for more than 15 years, and bluefin tuna is extremely popular. A side effect of this trend is a reduction in tuna stocks in the Eastern Atlantic and the Mediterranean, so this problem directly affects the European Union. The main countries involved in tuna fishing are Spain, France, Italy, Croatia, Greece, Portugal, Malta and Cyprus. Overfishing has led to a drastic reduction in the abundance of this species in the ecosystem.  In 2006, the first long-term, 15-year plan was established to protect stocks and increase the tuna population. According to scientific research, the tuna population first increased in 2015. Thanks to the high level of supervision required by the EU (more and more inspectors, vessels, aircraft and other control measures), the allowable number of tuna catches has been increased by 20% compared to 2014.  Sustainable fisheries, resource regulation and fruitful cooperation between Community countries are a source of success that has contributed to the development and conservation of the valuable bluefin tuna species.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. I am abstaining from the report on the multiannual recovery plan for bluefin tuna in the Atlantic and Mediterranean. It is an important undertaking, but not all technical changes are actually effective.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report, as it aims to transpose into Union law measures of the multiannual Bluefin Tuna recovery plan in the Eastern Atlantic and the Mediterranean adopted by the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas (ICCAT).

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on the multi-year plan to rebuild bluefin tuna stocks in the East Atlantic and the Mediterranean. This text deals with a transposition of the ICCAT Convention (International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas). The European Commission has asked to be able to do delegated acts, but the rapporteur defends the codecision procedure, in order to defend the prerogatives of MEPs.  I also supported Amendment 41, which echoes Sylvie Goddyn's proposed amendment in the Commission and called for Member States to ensure that quotas for artisanal fishermen using traditional and selective fishing methods are increased in order to protect stocks and increase employment.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this multi-year plan because this type of plan has proven its effectiveness in replenishing bluefin tuna stocks in the East Atlantic and the Mediterranean. I regret, however, that it is not favourable enough for small-scale fishing, which should be defended more.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. The debate was not about the text itself (these stocks have already been replenished), but about the transposition of the ICCAT Convention (International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas). The aim was therefore to defend the codecision procedure, and thus to prevent Parliament from being short-circuited. Moreover, while this plan is not perfect, it tends to protect traditional, selective and environmentally friendly fishing methods. Notwithstanding some unsatisfactory aspects of this plan (waste, eviction of artisanal fisheries, quotas), I voted in favour, in order to defend the overall spirit of the text.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. This report is of some importance as bluefin tuna is the most important species regulated by ICCAT (International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tuna). In this area, it should be noted that in 2006 ICCAT adopted a multiannual bluefin tuna recovery plan to be completed in 2022. To reconstitute the population, the plan establishes a progressive reduction in the level of total allowable catches. The fishermen have made an enormous effort that has materialized in a spectacular recovery observed in the bluefin tuna population. For the same reason, an increase in catch volumes would be justified. In fact, in 2014, the regional organization decided to increase the level of total allowable catches by 20% for the next three years.  Uniform implementation by the EU as a whole is considered necessary. In the event that different rules were applied to foreign fleets, all efforts made and restrictions imposed on fishermen shall have been in vain. On the basis of the events since 2006, I consider it necessary to approve this report which will benefit fishermen by the efforts they have made previously.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I abstained, saying that I respect that fisheries policy is a matter for Member States with access to the sea.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The multiannual bluefin tuna recovery plan, planned for implementation by 2022 and adopted in 2006, has so far yielded positive results. All activities undertaken with the aim of preserving bluefin tuna have resulted in a reduction in the risk of disappearance of this animal species. By implementing this plan by 2012, bluefin tuna fishing decreased by almost 2/3, which has a positive impact on the recovery of the species and maintaining balance in the marine animal world.  I supported the multiannual bluefin tuna recovery plan in the Eastern Atlantic and Mediterranean Sea due to the fact that the activities undertaken so far have led to significant developments in the species recovery process.  I believe that all the proposed measures relating to the recovery and monitoring of the development of bluefin tuna are good and enforceable. Given that 7.5% of all marine fish species in European waters are at risk of extinction, all possible activities must be undertaken to avoid such a scenario.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: In writing ‒ the proposed Regulation unifies the application of all measures of the bluefin tuna recovery plan in force from 2006 to 2022.In view of the positive evolution of the stock, the catch quotas for 2015 to 2017 are adjusted and the technical measures for monitoring their situation are modified. The Commission shall be delegated to adopt acts which take over international obligations under Union law.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of postponing the vote on the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing a multiannual bluefin tuna recovery plan in the Eastern Atlantic and the Mediterranean and repealing Regulation (EC) No 1782/2003. I agree with the rapporteur's proposal.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this plan. It is in fact a simple transposition of the ICCAT (International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Thonids) convention. Although this plan does not solve all the problems (allocation of quotas, waste, etc.), it is nevertheless necessary to protect traditional modes of fishing: these modes are selective and environmentally friendly, they should benefit from a specific advantageous regime.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome this recovery plan for Bluefin tuna in the eastern Atlantic. I am pleased that it states that ‘When implementing the recovery plan, the Union and Member States should pay particular attention to non-industrial fishing activities and to the most artisanal and sustainable gear types, such as traditional traps (“almadrabas”, “tonnare”), which contribute very positively to the rebuilding of tuna stocks, due to their high level of selectivity and low environmental impact in marine ecosystems , and which are valuable in scientific terms.’

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on a multiannual recovery plan for bluefin tuna in the Eastern Atlantic and the Mediterranean and on the repeal of Regulation (EC) No 302/2009. Bluefin tuna is the most important species regulated by the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas (ICCCAT), to which the European Union is a contracting party and whose decisions on the conservation and management of fisheries are binding under Union law. The aim of the proposal is to include in a regulation a series of measures adopted between 2012 and 2014, such as technical measures on the transfer of live red tuna or provisions concerning the declaration of catches, in order to ensure uniform application throughout the European Union and to ensure a level playing field for all tuna operators.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In order to ensure that our bluefin tuna stocks can be repopulated, it is very important to maintain the limits in the quotas of fishing vessels. I voted for this report because I agree with the rapporteur on the need for greater supervision of fisheries activities in order to safeguard an important part of the European economy.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. The reconstruction of the tuna stocks is an important concern. The rapporteur agrees that in some cases the Commission's proposal goes beyond what was decided by ICCAT, but also beyond what the EU legislator has provided for. However, not all of the rapporteur's technical proposals are effective. That is why I am abstaining from voting.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in support of this report. The report outlines technical measures that aim to bolster tuna fish stock and ensure a level playing field for all stakeholders in the tuna fishing industry.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The EU is a contracting party to the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas (CICTA). In 2006, CICTA adopted a multi-year plan to replenish bluefin tuna stocks, which will end in 2022.  To restore stocks, the replenishment plan calls for a gradual reduction in the level of the total allowable catch from 2007 to 2011, fishing limitations in certain areas and during certain periods, a new minimum size...  In view of the positive developments in the state of stocks, CICTA has decided to slightly increase the Total Eligible Capture (TAC) to 15,821 tonnes, of which 9,372.9 tonnes are allocated to the EU, up from 13,400 tonnes in 2014.   The aim here is to transpose CICTA's decisions on fisheries conservation and management into EU law within its jurisdiction. I vote for this text.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. In this report, the report refers to a transposition of the ICCAT Convention (International Commission for the Conversation of Atlantic Tunas). The rapporteur wishes to defend the prerogatives of the European Parliament by proposing the codecision procedure, in the face of the European Commission, which is asking for the possibility of doing delegated acts. However, there are some flaws in this report, such as the allocation of quotas which is unfavourable to fishing in the Mediterranean. However, other traditional fishing methods, such as the environmentally friendly madrague, should benefit from a specific advantageous regime. Therefore, I voted in favour.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing a multiannual plan for the recovery of bluefin tuna in the Eastern Atlantic and the Mediterranean, which repeals Regulation (EC) No 302/2009. The EU, contracting party of the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas (ICCAT), adopted in 2006 a multiannual tuna plan, which only ends in 2022. Bluefin tuna is the most important species regulated by ICCAT. Every effort is needed to ensure that bluefin tuna continues to increase its stocks

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this plan because it helps rebuild the dwindling bluefin tuna population. The plan encourages more sustainable fishing practices such as restricting fishing within certain areas and within certain time periods, and using methods that have a low impact on the general marine ecosystem.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. I welcome the adoption by the European Parliament of its position on the proposed regulation on a multi-year plan to rebuild tuna stocks in the East Atlantic and the Mediterranean. This regulation aims to incorporate into EU law the recommendations of the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas with the aim of ensuring the preservation of tuna stocks and thus the sustainability of fishing opportunities.  The recommendations in this report take into account the positive developments in tuna stocks that have been observed in recent years as a result of management measures to ensure the sustainability of these stocks. The incorporation of such measures decided on the international stage into EU law is a crucial step in enabling their uniform application at European level and thus ensuring the coherence of the common fisheries policy.  In addition, I support Parliament's request to preserve the powers of this House in terms of transposing measures decided in international fisheries management bodies into EU law.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: in writing – the ICCAT Commission adopted a recovery plan for bluefin tuna in 2006. Since the adoption of the plan, European fishermen have done a great deal of work by taking a responsible approach to the rules adopted and in a gentle way of fishing to raise the bluefin tuna stock to a healthy level. It is essential that fishermen from outside the EU also comply with these rules, thus avoiding fluctuations in the growth of the bluefin tuna stock. I also consider it important to point out the importance of promoting the traditional method of hunting using traps that have been used in the past and which protect fish stocks and ecosystems. The use of these traditional methods will avoid unnecessarily increased hunting.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report, which aims at transposing into Union law measures of the bluefin tuna recovery plan in the Eastern Atlantic and the Mediterranean. The aim of this report is to transpose into Union law measures of the multiannual bluefin tuna recovery plan in the Eastern Atlantic and the Mediterranean adopted by the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas (ICCAT) at its annual meetings between 2012 and 2014. In principle, I agree on the contents of the report, but there remain some reservations that go beyond the transposition exercise.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. The fact is that the stocks have been replenished. The debate is about a simple transposition of the ICCAT Convention (International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas). The European Commission wanted to act very quickly, and asked to be able to do delegated acts, but the rapporteur defended the codecision procedure, in order to defend the prerogatives of the European Parliament. Some problems are not solved by this plan: there is a lot of waste, thanks to the technique of sending boats to feed the tuna with mackerel. Similarly, only a few tuna fishers benefit from the stocks. Small-scale fishing is excluded, even though everyone claims to defend it. The allocation of quotas is still unfavourable to it, especially in the Mediterranean. However, the European Commission, like MEPs on the Fisheries Committee, want to protect traditional bluefin tuna fishing methods. These fishing methods are very selective and therefore environmentally friendly. They should benefit from a specific advantageous scheme. Nevertheless, it will be voted in favour of this report.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This proposal aims to ensure uniform and effective application throughout the European Union of all measures of the recovery plan adopted between 2012 and 2014 by the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas. I endorse the rapporteur's position that uniform application should be based on ensuring a level playing field for all tuna fishing operators, including, in the main case, third-country operators. The rapporteur warns that, if other rules apply to foreign fleets, all the effort and restrictions applied to fishermen in the European Union have been in vain. Operators in the European Union should not be penalised with more severe measures than those agreed. I also endorse the rapporteur's position on the specificities of the different tuna fishing gears. The role of craft frames, such as traditional frames, in the conservation of stocks and that, in the implementation of the recovery plan, the European Union should pay particular attention to these traditional frames, which contribute to the reconstitution of tuna stocks, as they are extremely selective.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. The issue here is to transpose the Convention on the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas. The report stresses that the Commission should have used the codecision procedure rather than acting by delegated acts.  On the substance, if certain problems persist, notably the heavy waste by the technique of sending boats to feed tuna with mackerel, or the fact that artisanal fishing is excluded (since the allocation of quotas is unfavourable to it), the European Commission and the European Parliament's Fisheries Committee want to protect traditional fishing methods of environmentally friendly bluefin tuna (such as madrague). So I decided to vote for this text.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report, as it transposes very well the decisions made at International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the multi-year recovery plan for bluefin tuna in the East Atlantic and the Mediterranean. The aim is to transpose into EU law the plan adopted by the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas (CICTA), of which the EU is a contracting party. Measures to replenish the stocks of this species provide until 2022 for limiting fishing in certain areas and at certain times, a new minimum catch size, and strengthening inspection measures.

name: Elisabeth Morin-Chartier (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the MATO report on the multi-year plan to rebuild bluefin tuna stocks in the East Atlantic and the Mediterranean. The report aims to transpose into EU law the measures of the multi-year recovery plan for bluefin tuna in the East Atlantic and The Mediterranean adopted by the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas (CICTA) between 2012 and 2014.La CICTA is an international organisation responsible for the management of tuna, to which the European Union is a contracting party.  THE CICTA recommendations are binding acts, which must be transposed into EU law. The CICTA recovery plan includes the following measures, valid until 2022: limiting fishing in certain areas and periods, new minimum size, recreational fishing measures, livestock measures and strengthening inspection measures.

name: Renaud Muselier (PPE)
text: In writing. The report on the multi-year plan to replenish bluefin tuna stocks in the East Atlantic and Mediterranean outlines the measures adopted by the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas. I voted to postpone it in committee to allow the negotiation of a trilogue.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Commission's proposal incorporates overall the recommendations of ICCAT, the regional fisheries management organisation responsible for the management of tuna and related species in the Atlantic Ocean and adjacent seas, which has adopted a multiannual recovery plan for bluefin tuna, which is expected to be concluded in 2022. I agree and support the rapporteur's position that the aim of transposing the ICCAT recommendations is to ensure uniform application across the EU and not to reopen the debate on what has been decided following lengthy negotiations. Uniform application should ensure a level playing field for all tuna operators.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 As I have stressed many times before, we must place the greatest emphasis on sustainable development in the EU on economic issues! In particular, responsible management of our natural resources is of paramount importance. The multiannual recovery plan adopted by ICCAT in 2006 was established to halt the further decline in the stock of bluefin tuna in our seas and to keep its quantity at a sustainable level. I support the measures necessary to achieve these objectives, such as territorial and periodic fishing restrictions and the reduction of TACs.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. – I have voted for this report that aims to contribute to the rebuilding and conservation of tuna stocks, through fishing operations with low impact on marine ecosystems.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported this report in my vote today because it concludes the procedure for transposing the latest measures on the multiannual bluefin tuna recovery plan adopted in 2012-2014 at the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tuna (ICCAT). Given that the results of the latest studies show that bluefin tuna stocks are recovering, thanks to the measures under the 2006-2022 Multiannual Plan, I believe that it is the EU's duty to contribute to this effort by transposing these new measures into European law.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. In implementing the recovery plan, the European Union should pay particular attention to traditional tonals. This selective reconstruction of tuna stocks supports the extremely important regeneration of our marine ecosystems. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Younous Omarjee (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which approves the multi-year plan to rebuild bluefin tuna stocks in the East Atlantic and the Mediterranean. This multi-year plan includes a number of control measures to improve monitoring and implementation of restrictions on the types of fishing gear that can be used or on how and during which they can be deployed for fishing.  This multi-year plan makes it possible to translate into European law the recommendations adopted by the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Thonids (CICTA).

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The aim is to ensure the uniform and effective application of tuna recovery plan measures across the EU by integrating them into the Regulation.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this, not because we do not want bluefin tuna numbers to recover, we do, but because the report, by adopting an international agreement, endorses the EU’s right to operate the Common Fisheries Policy – a behavioural-economic, long-term catastrophe, especially for the UK.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 If the common fisheries policy was originally part of the common agricultural policy, it gradually acquired a distinct identity in the course of Community developments. For this reason, referring to the issue proposed by the rapporteur on the multiannual recovery plan for bluefin tuna and considering that it has been on a very positive trend in recent years, I consider the European Union's proposal to transpose them into European law by means of a special regulation to be appropriate. European fisheries production is also about 3.3% of the world's, which should not be underestimated for the economies of our countries. Of course the Union will continue to commit itself to this, I am voting in favour.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The proposal for a Regulation on a multiannual bluefin tuna recovery plan ensures that the common fishing policy objective is promoted, i.e. the objective of the common fishing policy. regulating the use of living marine resources, while ensuring a sustainable economy, social conditions and environmental protection. It should be noted that the Union is part of the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tuna (ICCAT), which has the right to adopt decisions concerning the conservation and management of fisheries, making all adopted decisions binding.  The purpose of this proposal is to introduce into Union legislation measures adopted in 2012-2014 under the Multiannual Bluefin Tuna Recovery Plan in the Eastern Atlantic and Mediterranean Seas adopted by ICCAT. The plan includes the regulation of technical measures that would help achieve the end goal, measures such as transport regulation and the use of a stereoscopic camera to monitor the amount of catches. This proposal also introduces provisions empowering the Commission to adopt delegated acts pursuant to Article 290 TSO. treaty on the functioning of the European Union. I believe that the protection of bluefin tuna can have a positive impact on the marine world, the sustainability of harvesting and the recovery of the species in order to ensure the long-term economic use of this species, to protect fisheries and fishermen who depend on the catch of bluefin Atlantic tuna.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. Stocks have been replenished. The debate is about a simple transposition of the ICCAT Convention (International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas). The European Commission wanted to act very quickly, it asked to be able to do delegated acts but Gabriel Mato defends the procedure of co-decision, in order to defend the prerogatives of the European Parliament.  Some problems are not solved by this plan, including a lot of waste, through the technique of sending boats to feed the tuna with mackerel. Similarly, only a few tuna fishers benefit from the stocks; artisanal fishing is excluded, even though everyone claims to defend it. The allocation of quotas is still unfavourable to it, especially in the Mediterranean.  However, both the European Commission and MEPs on the Fisheries Committee want to protect traditional bluefin tuna fishing methods, such as the Madrague. These fishing methods are very selective and therefore environmentally friendly. They should benefit from a specific advantageous scheme. So I voted for this report.

name: Pina Picierno (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The multiannual recovery plan for bluefin tuna, adopted in 2006 by the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas (ICCAT), to which the European Union is a contracting party, is bearing fruit. Since 2008, bluefin tuna stocks have started to grow again and, according to experts, have been at optimum levels of abundance since 2014. Thus, after years of hard sacrifices for European fishermen, who had to accept severe restrictions on total allowable catches (TACs), an increase in the TAC of 20% was decided in 2014 for the next three years. I welcome the report's proposal to include in a regulation all the measures in the recovery plan adopted in order to ensure their uniform and effective implementation throughout the EU. I also think it is important to ensure a level playing field for all operators in the tuna fishing sector. Finally, I welcome the adoption of the amendment calling on the Member States to distribute tuna fishing quotas more fairly, not only for the benefit of large shipowners, but also for small-scale fishermen who adopt sustainable fishing techniques.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ I support the proposal for a regulation by the European Parliament and the Council on a multiannual bluefin tuna recovery plan in the Eastern Atlantic and Mediterranean Seas and on the repeal of Regulation (EC) No 2012/2013; 302/2009 The International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas (ICCAT) has the power to take decisions concerning fisheries conservation. These acts have binding force and are part of EU law. In 2006, ICCAT adopted a multiannual bluefin tuna recovery plan aimed at recovering the species by reducing the allowable level of catches. The plan introduces a gradual reduction in allowable catches and measures related to areas and the catch period. Before the plan, the allowable catch was around 33,000 tonnes, gradually reduced and reached 12 900 tonnes in 2012. The measure had a positive impact on the species' sleuth and reached 13,400 tonnes in 2013. Sustainable fisheries are one of the fundamental principles that we must adhere to, while implementing an equal distribution of available quotas.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I support colleague Gabriel Mata's draft legislative resolution on the proposal for a regulation by the European Parliament and the Council on a multiannual bluefin tuna recovery plan in the Eastern Atlantic and Mediterranean Sea and on the repeal of Regulation (EC) No 1000/2013. 302/2009 For the sake of clarity, simplification and legal certainty, Regulation (EC) No 102/2009 should be repealed. 302/2009. Certain provisions of Regulation (EC) No 202/2013 302/2009 are outdated, in particular as they are now covered by other EU acts, and need to be deleted. Other provisions need to be updated for the purpose of showing changes in legislation.  The aim of the proposal is to transpose into Union law measures of the Multiannual Bluefin Tuna Recovery Plan (BFT) in the Eastern Atlantic and Mediterranean Seas.  Last year (2015) for the first time since the bluefin tuna recovery plan was established in 2006, the fishing quota set by the European Union (more than 9,372 tonnes) increased significantly. This is due to the scientifically proven restoration of the fund, which resulted in a twenty percent overall increase in the quota for bluefin tuna fishing. The International Commission for the Protection of Atlantic Tunas (ICCAT) is satisfied with the efforts achieved so far and the results of tuna recovery, but it is very important to continue to follow scientific advice and the overall plan. In 2015, ICCAT also increased its catch quota by 71 tonnes compared to 2014 to 461.16 tonnes.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In 2006, ICCAT adopted a multiannual recovery plan for bluefin tuna, which is expected to be completed in 2022. Fishermen have made considerable efforts to adapt their catches to a total allowable catch (TAC) imposed by ICCAT, which in 2014 was increased by 20% for the next three years (from 2015 to 2017). Efforts rewarded because the extraordinary recovery of bluefin tuna stocks in recent years could justify ICCAT's decision to bring forward the 2017 TAC (23,155 tonnes) to 2016. In addition, the ICCAT recommendations take into account the specificities of the different tuna fishing gears, in particular traditional, more artisanal and sustainable gear. These tools have a very small impact on marine ecosystems due to their low level of energy consumption and accidental catches. I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to include in a regulation all the measures of the recovery plan adopted between 2012 and 2014 in order to ensure their uniform and effective implementation throughout the EU. This will ensure that the transposition of the ICCAT recommendations has uniform application across the EU and a level playing field for all tuna operators.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted for the multi-year plan to rebuild bluefin tuna stocks in the East Atlantic and the Mediterranean, as fishing remains a central issue for the European Union and our coastal and artisanal economy.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This proposal for a Regulation aims to transpose into Union law the measures of the Multiannual Bluefin Tuna Recovery Plan in the Eastern Atlantic and mediterranean adopted by the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas (ICCAT) at its annual meetings between 2012 and 2014. ICCAT is the regional fisheries management organisation (ORGP) responsible for the management of tuna and related species in the Atlantic Ocean and adjacent seas, and has the authority to adopt binding recommendations, which should subsequently be transpose into Union law. The proposal in question here contains technical measures relating, for example, to the transfer and cage operations of live bluefin tuna, the use of stereoscopic cameras to estimate the quantities of bluefin tuna and releases, the requirements for the declaration of catches and the implementation of the ICCAT regional observation programme. In general, the rapporteur considers that the proposal constitutes a correct transposition of iccat recommendations. However, amendments have been tabled to ensure that the recommendations are uniformly applied and that their transposition remains a joint competence of Parliament and the Council.  I voted in favour.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this, not because we do not want bluefin tuna numbers to recover, we do, but because the report, by adopting an international agreement, endorses the EU’s right to operate the Common Fisheries Policy – a behavioural-economic, long-term catastrophe, especially for the UK.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Bluefin tuna is the most important species regulated by the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas which, in 2006, adopted a multi-annual plan for the recovery of bluefin tuna—bluefin ending in 2022. I voted in favour of this report, which currently sets out the total allowable catch at 15 821 tonnes, with the EU being 9 372.9 tonnes, considering its importance for the fishermen of my region, the Azores. Fishermen have made considerable efforts to adjust their catches, complying with the strict conditions set out in the plan. For this reason, and with a view to ensuring uniform and effective application throughout the European Union, the proposal contains technical measures, including measures on the use of stereoscopic cameras to estimate the quantities of bluefin tuna and releases.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. According to the rapporteur, the recovery in bluefin tuna stocks in recent years justifies the decision to bring forward the 2016 TAC (Total Allowable Catches) planned for 2017 (23155 tonnes), which will remain well below the current TAC before the recovery plan comes into force. Even so, because it is a penalty for small fishermen, the S&D group has succeeded in making an amendment of its own, aimed at safeguarding small fishermen against any kind of monopoly, to be approved.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. In order to ensure uniform and effective implementation throughout the EU, this proposal aims to incorporate into EU law the latest measures, adopted between 2012 and 2014, for the recovery plan for bluefin tuna adopted by the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tuna (ICCAT). While the Commission correctly transposes ICCAT's recommendations in most cases, it sometimes goes beyond what is decided by ICCAT and from EU law, EU operators cannot be penalised by stricter measures than agreed. The socialist amendment requiring a quota system for bluefin tuna with small-scale fishing would be incorporated into the report. It also addresses the absence of the European Parliament in international negotiations.  In short, I support the initiative that reviews existing regulations in this area, which was obsolete with regard to ICCAT's recommendations in recent years, while resolving some poor technical aspects, and was therefore dealt with broad consensus within the Committee on Fisheries of the European Parliament.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. Yesterday, the European Parliament took over the proposed regulation incorporating all measures to rebuild bluefin tuna stocks in the East Atlantic and the Mediterranean adopted between 2012 and 2014.  In the plenary vote, we also adopted by a large majority an amendment by the group calling on Member States to re-examine "the bluefin tuna fishing quota system, which penalises small-scale fishermen, in order to remove the monopoly currently exercised by large shipowners and to promote more sustainable fishing systems such as small-scale fishing".  With this vote, the European Parliament's Fisheries Committee will now be able to launch negotiations with the Council of the EU on this issue.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I fully support the plan proposed by the Commission. I would even say that the Commission is proposing overly controversial measures. The multi-year, poorly controlled fisheries in the Atlantic, the Mediterranean and elsewhere lead to the fact that we will soon see many food-valuable fish and ecosystem-based fish only in textbooks and museums. It is time to limit your appetites, and especially the industry. At least in order to have something to fish for in the future. And it's time to think about more environmentally friendly and responsible food sources.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which aims to transpose into EU law the measures of the multi-year recovery plan for bluefin tuna in the East Atlantic and the Mediterranean adopted by the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas (CICTA) at its annual meetings between 2012 and 2014. In 2006, CICTA adopted a multi-year plan to replenish bluefin tuna stocks that will be completed in 2022. These multi-year plans include a number of technical measures.  In particular, the report stresses the need to apply the rules consistently to ensure equal conditions for all operators involved in tuna fishing, including, in particular, third-country operators. Indeed, EU operators should not be penalised by being required to apply measures that would be stricter than those agreed on the grounds that the Commission has failed to impose such measures in the CICTA negotiations.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. While no vote has been taken, what we would vote on is little more than the transposition into European legislation of the management plan for bluefin tuna produced by ICCAT. We do not agree with the quotas allocated and consider that States can put pressure on the Commission and the Council to have the EU position in ICCAT proposed as high as possible depending on the state of the tuna population, since our fishing fleets are in a critical socio-economic situation.

name: Alfred Sant (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I qualify as follows my vote in favour. This proposal provides another opportunity to signal that beyond participating in international conservation efforts of fish stocks, and implementing agreed rules, the European Union has another duty: it has to safeguard the way of life and earnings of traditional fishing communities, especially in isolated or peripheral regions and where fishing activities are small scale, conducted by families. Applying to them the logic used to regulate corporations is wrong. Such a logic makes traditional fisheries appear not to be viable, when they are. Speaking from the experience of Malta, this has needlessly disrupted the work of fishing communities and weakened the social fabric that kept them cohesive. In recent years, the traditional fishing community has been decimated. Quotas, new licences and rules were applied on its operations according to Union directives. Aquaculture as a source of additional fish supplies is welcome. But economically and socially, it offers no compensation for the loss of traditional fishing. A new effort is needed to create a better framework for the operations of small scale, traditional fishermen. I would urge that this be given priority, before further losses of manpower and resources are experienced in the sector.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it proposes a strategy for the recovery of bluefin tuna involving fishing communities that depend on the exploitation of this fishing resource. Many peoples in southern Europe have historically engaged in the exploitation of tuna, and they are the main stakeholders in the recovery of their population. In this sense, the report includes several specific references to the art of almadraba and the need to protect it in the context of conservation plans and the sharing of quotas of this species, favouring these traditional arts without industrial exploitation that harms populations much more and which are not linked to any territory. Because of the absolute need to recover this very important species and the need to do so with the communities living in it is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 The new bluefin tuna recovery plan aims to incorporate into European law some recommendations adopted by ICCAT for better management of this precious fish resource, present in the Eastern Atlantic and the Mediterranean. I supported Parliament's position at first reading that more attention should be paid to small-scale fishing and the more sustainable types of gear that contribute to achieving the objectives of the plan, thanks to their high level of selectivity and their low environmental impact. Although I agree with the general approach of the proposal, I would nevertheless have thought it appropriate to clarify the monitoring measures provided for in the regulation with regard to specimens of bluefin tuna accidentally caught and confiscated by the authorities of the Member States. Unfortunately, the interpretation of this measure often results in the fisherman being penalised for fishing for tuna, albeit unintentionally. I hope that we will move in a different direction on this point, for example by establishing the possible uses of confiscated fish. I believe, in fact, that following the entry into force of the landing obligation, this clarification would ensure better implementation of the new provisions.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The rapporteur, Gabriel Mato, has carried out important work and which refers to Parliament a number of decisions which, as he rightly points out, belong to Parliament. This, reconciled with the importance of protecting bluefin tuna and its protection plan, led me to vote favorably. I would like to stress that the amendment proposed by the Socialists & Democrats, in which I also voted positively, stresses the importance of combating monopolies in fisheries. Although the internal allocation of fishing quotas is a prerogative of states, it is also up to the European Union to make a commitment to positively favour artisanal fisheries, such as those practised in regions such as the Azores and Madeira. If we continue to benefit from major initiatives, we will strangle jump and pole fishing, such as that in the Atlantic Outermost Regions. I reiterate the need to respect scientific recommendations and to use the precautionary principle without parsimony. In tuna fishing, too many fish aggregation devices continue to be used without a serious environmental impact study.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ While I am in favour of making sure that our fish stocks are protected for future generations, I am against the EU acting like a State by trying to regulate in this area. Nation States should control their own waters and fish stocks.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Although my constituency has a very limited stake in the fisheries industry, being completely landlocked, I do believe that an organised approach for the industry is important for the conservation of this planet. I supported this legislative proposal as it has transposed quite well the decisions that were made at the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tuna; the proposal mostly contained technical measures relating to the transfer and caging operations of live bluefin tuna and catch controls for this species.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted positively for this report, but this explanation of the vote is a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ Thanks to the European Union's measures taken, it has also been possible to help rebuild the bluefin tuna stock, the species of which has been endangered in the Mediterranean and the Atlantic. However, despite the positive trend that bluefin tuna biomass has shown since 2008, I believe that in order to maintain the current satisfactory situation, it is essential to continue to regulate and control tuna fishing. On the other hand, I am pleased that, on the basis of reliable scientific data, the Regional Organisation decided in 2014 to increase the total catch for the next three years (from 2015 to 2017) by 20%. I supported the rapporteur's proposal for the report to be returned to committee so that further negotiations can take place between the Commission, the Council and the EP. I am convinced that, thanks also to the multiannual recovery plan for bluefin tuna stocks in the Eastern Atlantic and the Mediterranean, we will be able to successfully meet all the objectives that we have set ourselves for this area by 2022. However, I appeal to all stakeholders to apply all recovery plan measures uniformly and effectively and to ensure a level playing field for all tuna operators, including non-EU operators.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. The EU is a Contracting Party to the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas (ICCAT) and the Regional Fisheries Organisation (RFMO). These two organisations are responsible for the management of tuna and species of tuna in the Atlantic Ocean and adjacent seas. ICCAT is thus responsible for making recommendations for the conservation of fisheries, which are binding and must be transposed into EU law.  Bluefin tuna is the most important species regulated by ICCAT. In 2006, this organisation adopted a multiannual recovery plan for bluefin tuna, in force until 2022. The 500 tonnes reached a minimum level of 12,900 tonnes before the adoption of the recovery plan and reached a minimum level of 12,900 tonnes in 2012. This points to the extremely positive results of the said multiannual plan.  The report deals with the proposal for a regulation to ensure the uniform and effective implementation across the EU of all measures of the recovery plan. In particular, the Commission's proposal contains technical measures such as measures relating to the transfer and rearing activities of live bluefin tuna in the caging cage, catch reporting requirements and the implementation of the ICCAT Regional Observer Programme.  I believe that the uniform implementation of the ICCAT recommendations is extremely important throughout the EU. For these reasons, I voted in plenary in favour of the report.

name: Renato Soru (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour today on the proposal for a regulation on the multiannual plan for the recovery of bluefin tuna in the Eastern Atlantic and the Mediterranean, in order to ensure a more sustainable development of the stock and to introduce support measures for small-scale fishing. The regulation aims to transpose into the Union the binding protection and conservation measures approved internationally by the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tuna (ICCAT) and contained in the recommendations adopted at the annual meetings in 2012-2014. Although the regulation regulates purely technical aspects, the issue of bluefin tuna fishing is particularly important for Italy, from the point of view of the criteria for the distribution of quotas among fishermen. These quotas are decided at ICCAT but distributed at national level by the individual Member States. That is why I voted in favour of an amendment calling on the Member States to review the system for the distribution of bluefin tuna fishing quotas in order to favour small-scale fishing operators, who can ensure a more sustainable system than large shipowners.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The European Union is part of the International Atlantic Tuna Conservation Commission (ICCAT) and part of the Regional Fishing Organisation (RFMO) which is in charge of managing tuna as a species in the Atlantic Ocean and surrounding seas. I supported this proposal because tuna catches (in this case bluefin) adopted by ICCAT at annual meetings between 2012 and 2014 should be regulated.  The interest is to restock the tuna. I support this by limiting catches for a certain period of time, in certain places, to determine the amount of catches, but to limit catches used for recreational purposes. This rule should apply to all those engaged in tuna catches. I support ICCAT's proposal to use traditional traps because such a way of catching has a minor impact on the marine ecosystem.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which will ensure the correct transposal into EU law of uncontroversial measures which were agreed at the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The European Union is a contracting party to the International Commission for the Protection of Atlantic Tunas (ICCAT). Accordingly, ICCAT adopted a multiannual bluefin tuna recovery plan in the Eastern Atlantic and Mediterranean Seas between 2006-2022. Tuna is the most important species regulated by ICCAT. Fishermen have made significant efforts to bring their catches in line with decisions taken in 2006 and 2007.  I support this proposal from the European Parliament and the Council.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing a multiannual recovery plan for bluefin tuna in the Eastern Atlantic and Mediterranean and repealing the Regulation.  The multiannual plan, which would be completed in 2022, sets quotas for the allowable catches of bluefin tuna. Until now, fishermen have adapted their catches to the allowable catch, which has also led to a positive shift in the recovery of the stock.  I support an additional increase in the allowable catch. This is particularly important for those fishermen who deal with the catching of bluefin tuna in the traditional way with traditional traps, which have a limited impact on marine ecosystems due to low energy consumption and little incidental catches. As the quota achieved forced them to stop catching, fishermen were put at risk.  I also welcome the rapporteur's clear position that regulations and restrictions everywhere must be respected in the same way.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 The proposal aims to transpose the measures of the multiannual bluefin tuna recovery plan in the Eastern Atlantic and mediterranean into the European acquis, adopted by the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tuna (ICTAT) at its annual meeting between 2012 and 2014.  We voted in favour of the proposal as it includes technical measures such as those concerning the use of stereoscopic cameras for the calculation of tuna quantities and measures for the transport of live tuna catches, measures favouring the development of the blue economy and, above all, because it supports small Mediterranean fishermen and businesses dependent on tuna fishing.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Catches of bluefin tuna are one of the significant components of Member States' fishing activity in the waters of the Atlantic Ocean and the Mediterranean Sea. Their uniform regulation at European Union level contributes to the recovery of stocks and the maintenance of an adequate level of economic use.  The EU is a contracting party to the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tuna (ICCAT), a regional organisation for the management of tuna fishing and similar species in the Atlantic Ocean and adjacent seas, for which it must apply its decisions.  In view of the positive developments in stocks in recent years, the ICCAT decided in 2013 to increase the quota allocated to Member States. However, it must be properly transposed by the Commission in order to guarantee a level playing field for all operators engaged in tuna fishing and, in particular, operators in third countries. The quotas set should encourage small fishermen, who are currently disadvantaged and who are an additional guarantee to keep stocks at an acceptable level. The European Parliament must be involved in the international negotiation of these quotas, on the basis of its powers by the European citizens it represents. The adoption of this document is a first step in the right direction.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the text. The recovery plan takes into account the specificities of the different types of machines. In its implementation, the EU and the Member States should pay particular attention to artisanal fishing activities and the most artisanal and sustainable gear, such as traditional madragues ("almadrabas", which contribute very positively to the recovery of tuna stocks, due to their high level of selectivity, their low environmental impact on marine ecosystems and their importance from a scientific point of view.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Mato report on the multiannual recovery plan for bluefin tuna in the Eastern Atlantic and the Mediterranean. The report aims at transposing measures recently adopted by the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas to which the European Union is party. At the beginning of the 2000s, the bluefin tuna stock drastically dropped, leading to the adoption of a multiannual recovery plan to help rebuilding the stock. Those new measures include provisions on the catch reporting requirement, the fishing seasons and restrictions on the types of gear to be used. In addition, I also supported the amendment calling for a review of the bluefin tuna fishing quota system in order to encourage sustainable fishing and enable the protection of small-scale fishermen against the monopoly of large vessel owners.

name: Isabelle Thomas (S&D)
text: In writing. This report was intended to include in one regulation all the measures on bluefin tuna adopted internationally since 2012. It should be noted that the Treaty entrusts the Council and itself with the setting of quotas for all species, so there was no question here of negotiating the quantities of catches allowed. The report enabled the implementation of particularly restrictive management and control measures, following the bluefin tuna crisis in which we saw the biomass of the species fall dangerously. For example, observers will have to be flown on all ships without exception. Today the stock has returned to an encouraging level in European waters and international scientific bodies have authorised the increase in quotas in 2015. This is a demonstration of the effectiveness of the safeguards implemented so far. Finally, we voted almost unanimously on a Plenary amendment calling for quotas established fairly between artisanal fishermen and others. For bluefin tuna as for all species, it is essential that the diversity of fishing trades is preserved.

name: Valdemar Tomaševski (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 Mr President, I voted in favour of the report because bluefin tuna is the most important regulated species. In order to restore tuna stocks, a gradual reduction of allowable catches is foreseen. The recommendations made aim at their uniform application across the EU, rather than updating the debate on decisions that have already been taken after lengthy negotiations. Importantly, the proposal includes technical measures such as rules for transport operations for live bluefin tuna, as well as requirements relating to the reporting of fishing and the implementation of the regional observer programme. These provisions deserve to be supported.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing a multiannual recovery plan for bluefin tuna in the Eastern Atlantic and Mediterranean and repealing Regulation (EC) No 302/2009, as I believe that this leads to an even more uniform and effective implementation of all actions taken in this area throughout the EU.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. Bluefin tuna stocks have been replenished. The debate is about a simple transposition of the ICCAT Convention (International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas). Some problems are not solved by this plan: there is a lot of waste, thanks to the technique of sending boats to feed the tuna with mackerel. Similarly, only a few tuna fishers benefit from the stocks; artisanal fishing is excluded, even though everyone claims to defend it.  The allocation of quotas is still unfavourable to it, especially in the Mediterranean. However, both the European Commission and MEPs from the Fisheries Commission want to protect traditional bluefin tuna fishing methods, such as madrague. These fishing methods are very selective and therefore environmentally friendly.  They should benefit from a specific advantageous scheme. So I'm voting for it.

name: Mihai Ţurcanu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on a multiannual plan for the recovery of bluefin tuna stocks in the Eastern Atlantic and Mediterranean aims to ensure uniform and effective application of the measures recently established by the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tuna with a view to reconstituting bluefin tuna stocks.  The EU is part of the ICCAT, which has the authority to take decisions for the conservation and management of fishing activities in its area of competence. As regards the recovery of bluefin tuna stock, ICCAT has taken measures such as a gradual reduction in the level of the total allowable catch, restrictions on fishing in certain areas and periods, measures relating to sport and recreational fishing activities, measures relating to growth and fishing capacity, and the establishment of quotas at European Union level.  To date, the decisions taken under the ICCAT have led to a spectacular recovery of bluefin tuna stocks, and in this respect the application of these measures must continue for a complete recovery. I therefore voted in favour of the Multiannual Plan for the recovery of bluefin tuna stocks in the Eastern Atlantic and the Mediterranean.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union is a Contracting Party to the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas (ICCAT), the regional fisheries management organisation (RFMO) responsible for the management of tuna and tuna-like species in the Atlantic Ocean and its bordering seas. In 2006, ICCAT adopted a multiannual recovery plan for bluefin tuna with a maturity of 2022. The transposition of the ICCAT recommendations aims to ensure uniform application throughout the EU; and not to reopen debate on issues that have already been decided, often after lengthy negotiations involving all words and commas. I voted in favour of the document.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour as this is the transposition of international law and the report is faithful to the ICCAT plan.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. This is a proposal for a Regulation transposing into European Union law the measures of the multiannual recovery plan for bluefin tuna from the eastern Atlantic and the Mediterranean, adopted by the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tuna (ICCAT). I therefore think it is necessary to vote in favour of this plan, although it should also be noted that the EU's commitment to these rules must also take place by other third countries because, without uniform application of ICCAT measures, they will not work.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it proposes a strategy for the recovery of bluefin tuna involving fishing communities that depend on the exploitation of this fishing resource. Many peoples in southern Europe have historically engaged in the exploitation of tuna, and they are the main stakeholders in the recovery of their population.
