In this sense, the report includes several specific references to the art of almadraba and the need to protect it in the context of conservation plans and the sharing of quotas of this species, favouring these traditional arts without industrial exploitation that harms populations much more and which are not linked to any territory. Because of the absolute need to recover this very important species and the need to do so with the communities living in it is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. 'I voted in favour of this decision because the recovery plan is aimed at the conservation and optimal use of fish stocks in the Atlantic and The Mediterranean, so that we can achieve sustainable fisheries in Europe in the long term.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The bluefin tuna populations have been trending positive since 2008. In 2014, the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas decided to increase the TAC by 20% for the subsequent three years (from 2015 to 2017). For our part, we are following the criticism of a more sustainable system of fishing quotas that penalises small-scale fishing for the benefit of the major shipowners of europe's main fishing powers. It is important to recognize the role of handmade frames, used in the South of Portugal, in the Algarve, as well as their potential and selectivity, and it is also important that island fishermen who use the art of jump ing and rod, who today see bluefin tuna pass without being able to fish, see recognized their right to fish this species.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. The reconstruction of the tuna stocks is an important concern. The rapporteur agrees that in some cases the Commission's proposal goes beyond what was decided by ICCAT, but also beyond what the EU legislator has provided for. However, not all of the rapporteur's technical proposals are effective. That is why I am abstaining from voting.

name: Pablo Zalba Bidegain (PPE)
text: in writing. As we know, Spain is a country with a great tradition of fishing and consumption of bluefin tuna. However, in view of the alarming reduction of this species in recent years, it was decided to control its catch by setting fishing limit quotas across the EU. Given the success of these multiannual plans for bluefin tuna, which have made the species much larger than expected, I believe it is entirely lawful to request an increase in the fishing quota limit of this specimen and I fully support this report. In addition, I also very much agree on the need for the EU to promote a plan to standardise conditions in all Member States in this regard and, above all, those countries outside the European Union. Otherwise, all our efforts would have been in vain. In addition, and finally, I hope that the different types of fishing will be taken into account, taking into account especially the traditional practices used in almadrabas or the Canary Islands, because they have always carried out sustainable fishing and have certainly been adversely affected by limitations.

name: Flavio Zanonato (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the multiannual plan for the reconstruction of bluefin tuna in the Eastern Atlantic and the Mediterranean. The resolution contains technical measures such as those on the transfer and cage of live fish, including measures on the use of stereoscopic cameras to estimate the quantities of bluefin tuna and the requirements for declaring catches. I am particularly pleased with the adoption of the report, particularly with regard to the provision of new distribution quotas. The current system penalised small fishermen in particular and damaged the sustainability of fishing.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Report on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and the Council establishing a multiannual plan for the recovery of bluefin tuna in the Eastern Atlantic and the Mediterranean and repealing Regulation (EC) No 302/2009, as I believe that the European Commission's proposal correctly transposes the recommendations of the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas (ICCAT). ICCAT adopted in 2006 a multi-annual tuna recovery plan—bluefin which provided for a gradual reduction in the level of total allowable catches between 2007 and 2011. This proposal aims to incorporate into a single Regulation all measures adopted between 2012 and 2014 by ICCAT, based on the proven increase in bluefin tuna since 2008, which was reflected in the gradual increase in total allowable catches at international level. However, it is important that the bluefin tuna quota system be revised under the new proposal and that iccat recommendations are transposed into Community law and applied uniformly throughout the EU, ensuring a level playing field for all operators participating in bluefin tuna fishing, in particular for artisanal fishing fishermen.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We generally monitor the rapporteur's positions. We also follow the criticism of a more sustainable small-scale fishing quota system for the benefit of the major shipowners of europe's main fishing powers, and we have voted in favour of its amendment. Portugal does not currently have extractive fishing for bluefin tuna. In the Azores, only by-catches in the fishing of other tunas are allowed. The annual Portuguese quota of Tuna Rabilho, of 332 tons in 2016, is almost completely exhausted by the existing frames in the Algarve. It was justified to change this situation, taking into account the most favourable context in the nature of species conservation, increasing the national quota and recognizing to azorean fishermen, the art of jumping and pole vault, the right to exploit this resource, now more abundant in the waters of the archipelago.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal to establish a multiannual recovery plan for bluefin tuna in the Eastern Atlantic and Mediterranean and repealing Regulation (EC) No 302/2009, as this will enable the European Union to fulfil its contractual obligations arising from international treaties with the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas (ICCAT) and the Regional Fisheries Organisation (RFMO).  The proposal for a regulation will ensure the uniform and effective implementation across the EU of all measures of the bluefin tuna recovery plan, maintain the survival of this type of fish and allow controlled fishing.

name: Richard Corbett (S&D).
text: – Mr President, this report has covered a wide range of things linked to competition policy in its broadest sense and there is one issue which is highly topical at the moment, which is the competition faced in our steel sector by what looks like dumping from Chinese steel producers and which is, of course, a competition matter as well as a trade matter. The Commission some time ago proposed to strengthen our defence measures when facing a situation like this but, lo and behold, which is one of the countries that has been blocking that in the Council, which has been holding it up, which has been preventing us from taking more effective action? Why, the United Kingdom! The British Conservative Government is one of the culprits in allowing this situation to arise, without strengthening our hand in dealing with a situation like this. That compounds their failure to take action nationally, which they, like other governments, could have done within the competition rules of the Treaty. They have failed to do so, and some of them seem tempted from time to time to do what they always do, which is to blame Brussels.

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI).
text: – Although I voted 'no', I like point (c) very much and unfortunately it is very topical, especially in some post-socialist countries. Competition policy alone is a means of preserving European democracy in so far as it prevents economic and financial power from being concentrated in the hands of the few. The latter means that, on the basis of quasi-feudal prerogatives, holders of the economic and political power that merged with each other are handing out, for example, EU money and other opportunities. On the other hand, there is a real democracy, where there is civilisation, and where a competitive policy is maintained and enforced by the state, where entrepreneurs have equal opportunities, regardless of the circles of friends and networks they belong to.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – Mr President, i would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur The European Union's competition policy is, to some extent, one of the crucial sectors at Community level. It affects the economic development of the EU, including the promotion of progress in the social sphere and international relations. In trade, it has one of the most important roles. But finding the most effective balance between defending consumers' interests and improving the business climate in the internal and external markets is the objective that this report seeks to achieve in the perspective through the recommendations included, addressed primarily to the European Commission. Reforming the digital economy, promoting social cohesion, stimulating closer cooperation through national antitrust authorities, streamlining the role of the banking sector and taxation policies – not only all this, but also more effective antitrust patent policies and much more have been mentioned in this report. This is welcome. All these things must be part of the implementation of our Union's competition policy, so that both our internal consumer interests and internal competition can be guaranteed. Thank you!

name: Monica Macovei (ECR).
text: – Mr President, I voted differently in this report from the ECR Group and this is because I believe that healthy tax competition is at the heart of the Union's single market. At the moment, it is estimated that tax evasion, tax fraud and tax havens cost us, the citizens of the European Union, around EUR 1 000 billion each year. Basically, we can't talk about competition when some firms pay taxes and other firms don't pay taxes. Companies must be prevented from sending their profits to tax havens and must be obliged to keep it in the country or countries where they made this profit, precisely so that they can be taxed. Also, companies that have their tax office in tax havens should not be allowed to participate in auctions. We need a common database, with information about all companies in the Union, precisely to force them to pay taxes in the Union, in the Union countries where they make this money.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – In Uachtaráin, dar ndóigh vótáil mé i bhfabhar na tuarascála seo agus tá a lán graní maithe ann agus má chuirtear and bhfeidhm iad cabhróidh siad linn san Aontas jabanna a choimeád agus jairtena a chothúach am anseo. Ba mhaith liom cúpla rud a rá faoi chuid de na leasaithe atá ann. Níor vótáil mé ná mo chomhghleacaithe and bhFine Gael leis an ngrúpa and cúpla ceann. And leasu 76(3) agus leasú 89, staonamar sa vóta sin mar baineann sé le CCCTB agus ní aontaímid leis sin. Is dóigh liom gurb é dualgas an Bhallstáit, agus dualgas an Bhallstáit amháin, curd cánach a rialú. Freisin staonamar and vóta ar leasú 81(2) mar is dóigh liom go bhfuil an tAontas ag dul níos faide ná an tionscnamh BEPS by chuid OECD. Ach, tá a lán much maithe ann mar a dúras. Go háirithe, cuirim fáilte roimh na pointí fheirmeoirí agus na praghsanna a fhaigheann siad ag geata na feirme agus an slabhra bia a eagrú amach anseo.

name: Daniel Hannan (ECR).
text: – Mr President, according to the IMF, the share of world GDP taken up by the 28 members of the EU fell from 30% in 1980 to 17% in 2015. What accounts for that extraordinary shrinkage? It will not do to say that it is just developing countries catching up. You do not have any similar shrinkage or any equivalent one in North America or Australia or other advanced economies. I think we all know what the problem is, it is the over-regulation.  I am not just talking about job-destroying directives like the REACH directive, the AIFMD or the ham-fisted attempts at tax harmonisation and so on, I am talking about the institutionalised corporate lobbying which is based around raising barriers to entry and setting the rules in a way that favour the mega-banks and the multinational corporations and squeeze out their smaller competitors , thereby driving many wealth creators and entrepreneurs into exile if they want to succeed. As long as this system remains, the European Union economically is fated to continue its genteel decline.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I welcome this report and have supported it and, in particular, it is noteworthy that Parliament supported paragraphs 104, 105, 106 and 107. As the rapporteur for an opinion on the unfair trading practices in the food supply chain, I think this will feed into our work with the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection on what proposals we might come forward with to solve the problem of unfair trading practices, and indeed help us to look at whether they are anti—competitive. I very much welcome that these are embedded in the document.

name: Diane Dodds (NI).
text: – Mr President, I voted against this report while agreeing with the authors that we, as legislators, have a duty to promote an economic environment that is competitive. However, this should be one which allows businesses across Europe to enter new markets and which removes barriers to growth in national economies. I would like to deal with the issue of state aid specifically.  In Northern Ireland, the quarrying industry has been beset for many years by an investigation by the Commission into exemptions from the UK aggregates levy given to local operators. While it is positive that the Commission ruled that the majority of these were lawful, its decision to retrospectively collect a decade’s worth of levy from those who extracted shale continues to loom large over the future of our industry. In counties Armagh, Down and Fermanagh specifically, this reality has the potential to put small quarry operators out of business. It is important to remember that these companies acted in good faith and are now facing penalties through no fault of their own. I have met with the Commissioner to highlight their plight, but it is important that this should never happen again and that companies can act in good faith.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, this report on competition policy contains many positive suggestions, and these include the issue of state aid in the financial sector, which can lead to the distortion of competition in this sector. Crucially, I agree with the statement in the report which says that ‘care must be taken to ensure that regulation does not distort competition to the benefit of large banks’.  Indeed, in Ireland we have a situation in which, since the beginning of January this year there have been limits on the deposits that can be placed in credit unions. Credit unions are not-for-profit, member-owned financial institutions. A cap of EUR 100 000 is in place for those who want to invest in credit unions. Nonetheless, I believe the effect will be to freeze credit unions out of the mortgage market and limit their ability to compete on a level playing field. This, I believe, is anti-competitive, and such regulation is in conflict with EU competition policy. Finally, I welcome and strongly support the call for binding action in the food supply chain against retailers harming farmers and consumers. This is long overdue.

name: Steven Woolfe (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, Milton Friedman once said that the greatest advances of civilisation, whether in architecture, painting, science, literature, industry or agriculture, have never come from centralised government. Well, here we are sitting in the European Union epicentre of centralised government: centralised in the Council, centralised by unelected Commissioners. And in competition – and this policy in particular – we see once more how this centralised government wants to take control of business and how it acts.  The EU has centralised currencies in the euro, and we now see the damage in the Eurozone and how much unemployment for young people exists. It has centralised rules and regulations, and we can see what the impact on trade of the European Union is. What we must take as a lesson from this is that the European Union should not be centralised any more. Give it back to the nation states and make them free to compete on the world stage.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Among the EU's objectives, ensuring fair competition and a level playing field between all companies, it certainly plays a key role in the management and proper functioning of the internal market. Parliament's annual report sets out the most significant initiatives and decisions taken by the Commission in the application of competition law, with the aim of making the necessary improvements for consumers and businesses. In the text presented, a number of important aspects have been correctly addressed, such as the need to prevent excessive market concentration or to penalise cases of abuse of a dominant position. Although I believe that the report presented is well focused on the right priorities, I have chosen to abstain in the hope that the EU will take further and stronger action in this area.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report on competition policy as key objectives have been achieved for the Socialist and Democratic Group, such as asking the Commission for a more belligerent position against social dumping in the labour market (paragraph 5), for services of general economic interest to be excluded from competition rules (paragraph 46) , addressing the problem of fragmentation of the EU digital market (paragraphs 55-59 and 79), for the Commission to maintain a priority approach to tax evasion or illegal corporate tax practices (paragraphs 62, 68-89) and, finally, for Parliament to be able to co-decide in the latter field (paragraph 110).  Useful references have also been made in the report to the need to incorporate flexibility in compliance with competition rules for the outermost and island regions. Also included in the report, on the proposal of Jonás Fernández and Ramón Jáuregui, a reference to the need to regulate ATM commissions because it is the price of a service whose market value is difficult to fix, which is very relevant for Spain at the moment.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I have not been able to vote in favour of this report because, despite containing very positive aspects, it continues to develop the neoliberal conception of the economy that perceives the market as the main agent of the European economy. This report has included numerous amendments tabled by my group and more aspects of central importance to the European economy: from supporting decisions to sanction tax-evading multinationals, to the crisis that has arisen in order to milk quotas or the investigation of the connections between certain former governors and large power companies. However, it is not recognized that services of general economic interest must be provided by the State, the internationalisation of public procurement and the European economy as a whole is called in clear reference to TTE. That is why, despite the important positive aspects, I have not been able to vote in favour of this report.

name: Martina Anderson and Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – By way of background information, this is  an own-initiative report oriented to set the vision of the European Parliament on the implementation of competition policy by the General Directorate of Competition of European Commission. The Competition Working Group of the Economic and Monetary Affairs Committee drafts every year this report with its analysis of the actions taken during the past exercise and setting its main priorities for the next year. There were some positive provisions contained within this report such as a focus on abuses of dominant positions and cartels. Moreover, there were progressive  provisions in relation to addressing the issue of  state aid particularly in the financial sector  However, there were many other provisions which overstepped the competitiveness of the EU, for example a call for a European legislative framework and also the focus on the introduction of the CCCTB. It was for these reasons, that I abstained on the report.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the annual report on Competition Policy because I believe that, on a general level, it is quite positive and highlights all the points that need improvement. Together with fellow MEPs from the Socialist Group, we tabled an amendment on the need to support the aluminium industry in Europe, which was sufficiently supported by the other Members and adopted by Parliament's plenary.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. This resolution on the annual report on EU competition policy in 2014 provides the Commission with clear guidelines on how Parliament enheads future competition policy. Above all, I welcome the fact that one of the main points of the report is to promote fair tax competition in the EU. I also support a stronger role for Parliament in the legislative process on competition issues, which can therefore create a broader democratic basis. For these reasons, I fully support the report.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. Important problems such as social dumping, the digital economy, social cohesion, public procurement, telecommunications, unfair and illicit practices used by the banking sector are raised in this text.  In particular, it is requested to incorporate into a legislative instrument rules on fines that would have a real deterrent impact in the event of anti-competitive cartels and practices. With regard to state aid to the banking system, it should no longer exist after the establishment of the banking union and should be linked to conditions for granting credit to SMEs. MEPs call for the creation of a legislative framework for the European Union to prevent distortions of competition through aggressive tax planning and tax evasion. While some observations are correct, this report is in line with the creation of the single market. So I abstained.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I opposed this report because it calls upon the Commission to take action on matters which should be within the remit of Member States; it seeks to extend the power of a protectionist European Parliament into competition law. However, a more pressing reason to oppose the report as a whole was that it calls for the introduction of a Common Consolidated Corporate Tax Base. Harmonisation across all 28 Member States is rarely in the interests of all, and specifically in the United Kingdom – which prides itself on being a good place to trade – this can only be bad for business.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which allows the European Parliament to place in Commissioner Vestager its hope for a European Union competition policy that guarantees its leading role in enforcing the market economy and competition in Europe and advancing them at the international level, and to avoid leading to a multitude of sectoral and national exceptions and uncontrollable exemption thresholds.

name: Inés Ayala Sender (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report on competition policy as key objectives have been achieved for the Socialist and Democratic Group, such as asking the Commission for a more belligerent position against social dumping in the labour market (paragraph 5), for services of general economic interest to be excluded from competition rules (paragraph 46) , addressing the problem of fragmentation of the EU digital market (paragraphs 55-59 and 79), for the Commission to maintain a priority approach to tax evasion or illegal corporate tax practices (paragraphs 62, 68-89) and, finally, for Parliament to be able to co-decide in the latter field (paragraph 110).  Useful references have also been made in the report to the need to incorporate flexibility in compliance with competition rules for the outermost and island regions. Also included in the report, on the proposal of Jonás Fernández and Ramón Jáuregui, a reference to the need to regulate ATM commissions because it is the price of a service whose market value is difficult to fix, which is very relevant for Spain at the moment.

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report submitted by the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs makes calls and requests to the Commission on the 2014 evaluation of competition policy. It stresses, inter alia, that an effective and credible competition policy should not only prioritise lowering consumer prices, but should also take into account the strategic interests of the European economy, namely: capacity to innovate, invest, competitiveness and sustainability, special competitive conditions for SMEs, start-ups and micro-enterprises. The report also contains wordings that are in line with and contrary to the values of the party I represent, which I have assessed accordingly in the item-by-item vote (acceptance or rejection). My final vote was rejection, because overall, the report is an endorsement of the EU competition policy that is in practice at the expense of the weaker Member States (the peripherals), because they cannot compete with significantly more developed, richer centre countries.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. Despite fairly accurate findings on social, fiscal and environmental dumping and some common demands, I cannot support the deepening of the 'European Single Market'.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. I approved this report, which underlines in particular Commissioner Vestager's desire to make competition policy, in close collaboration with the European Parliament, an important instrument of European integration and which calls for competition policy to strengthen social cohesion in the Union. In this regard, the Commissioner has just taken a series of encouraging sanctions on tax evasion by large companies. It cannot have a sustainable European construction without social and fiscal justice. The resolution also stresses the need, through competition policy, to combat social dumping and promote high labour and environmental standards. It cannot be a discourse based solely on competitiveness and productivity regardless of working conditions and workers' rights.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The issue of competition is one of the most important aspects of the Union's economic policy, closely linked to the European concept of a social market economy. The fight against monopolies, against excessive concentrations of economic and financial power, is undoubtedly a crucial element in maintaining an efficient democratic system capable of protecting the rights and prerogatives of all citizens. I supported the Langen report in the belief that moving towards an improvement in competition policy means combating social dumping in the labour market and tax evasion and fraud. I strongly support the position that Parliament should be given codecision powers in the field of competition, going beyond the provisions of the current Treaties. Only by strengthening democratic spaces will it be possible to successfully pursue the objectives of the coming years: innovation, sustainability, welfare, protection of working conditions and protection of SMEs.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I abstained in the vote on the annual report on the European Parliament's competition policy. It maintains a globally neoliberal vision of competition policy, focused on the single market and with little specific reference to the different economic sectors. While it devotes enough space to the issue of taxes, it does not propose any coercive measures to combat tax evasion or avoidance. Some amendments tabled by my group were, however, included, such as those relating to abuses in food distribution or down-down social competition. I think the report is not very negative, but we still do not share the overall approach.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I thank the rapporteur for his work with all groups in order to be able to approve this report on the Union's competition policy. I voted in favour of it as it underlines the importance of competition policy in the Union. I supported the section which points to the need to end social dumping and that competition decisions should take into account social impact in remote or isolated regions.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. This annual report on EU competition policy welcomes the Commission's report on the importance of competition policy while calling for competition policy not to be a hindrance to business competitiveness and that the aim should not only be price reduction but also the defence of the EU's strategic interests. This report talks in particular about social dumping, unfair or illegal practices in the banking sector, cases of dominance (we are talking about incorporating fines into a legislative framework to really deter in case of cartels)... The problem of unfair tax competition between states is also highlighted. MEPs recommend an arsenal of measures such as ensuring that no profit will leave the EU without being taxed. Contradiction when we know the role of big banks and multinationals in European affairs and when we do nothing concrete to fight tax havens. Despite interesting observations and good recommendations at times, this report always wants to further trash our industry because it wants to move in the direction of the single market when our economies are too different. I abstained.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I do not agree with what is contained in Mr Langen's report on the analysis of EU competition policy. I cannot support a text which, in its fundamental passages, praises the Commission's work and portrays it almost as infallible. With regard to the state aid chapter, I believe that Europe must change direction diametrically, the policies implemented so far in this regard have prevented the Member States and our territories from facing third-country multinationals and from supporting European production and industry; the EU must change course and must do so quickly by abandoning the failed policies that have been supported up to now; For these reasons, I voted against.

name: Malin Björk (GUE/NGL)
text: Written. I've abstained. The report is based fundamentally on the eu's market-liberal doctrines. Already at committee level, several of the GUE/NGL Group's amendments were rejected, which aimed to tighten up wordings, for example, against social dumping and strong measures to combat transnational corporate tax avoidance. I am in favour of mandatory public country-by-country reporting of profits and taxes and for increased coordination and exchange of information between Member States to combat tax evasion and aggressive tax planning. However, I am opposed to proposals aimed at giving the EU power over tax policy and, in the long term, tax law.  I therefore choose to abstain.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report on competition policy as key objectives have been achieved for the Socialist and Democratic Group, such as asking the Commission for a more belligerent position against social dumping in the labour market (paragraph 5), for services of general economic interest to be excluded from competition rules (paragraph 46) , addressing the problem of fragmentation of the EU digital market (paragraphs 55-59 and 79), for the Commission to maintain a priority approach to tax evasion or illegal corporate tax practices (paragraphs 62, 68-89) and, finally, for Parliament to be able to co-decide in the latter field (paragraph 110).  Useful references have also been made in the report to the need to incorporate flexibility in compliance with competition rules for the outermost and island regions. Also included in the report, on the proposal of Jonás Fernández and Ramón Jáuregui, a reference to the need to regulate ATM commissions because it is the price of a service whose market value is difficult to fix, which is very relevant for Spain at the moment.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report, in which the European Parliament expresses its opinion on the annual report on competition policy in the European Union. In its 2014 report on competition policy, the Commission stressed that this is a new year for Europe, as Commission President.C Juncker stated in the mandate letter of the new Commission that competition policy should also "make a proper contribution to the implementation of the agenda for jobs and growth, including in the digital single market, energy policy, financial services, industrial policy and the fight against tax avoidance". The new EU guidelines on competition policy could only be introduced in November 2014, raising expectations that in the future not only the current competition policy will be developed, but also the priorities reviewed. The European Parliament's involvement so far in the consultation procedure is only involved in competition law issues. Its influence, therefore, is unfortunately limited compared to that of the Commission and the Council. For this reason, Parliament has repeatedly called for the application of the ordinary legislative procedure and competition law under the Treaty of Lisbon. This seems necessary because, in the rapporteur's view, the Commission, as a competition authority with strong implementing powers, cannot simultaneously establish the legal basis for the form of guidelines and then be responsible for the implementation of its own guidelines and impose significant pecuniary sanctions.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Competition policy is an important tool for creating equal opportunities for companies in each Member State. I continue to consider it essential to introduce measures to ensure that all products imported from third countries comply with the environmental, health and social standards applied by the Union and protected on the world market, in order to protect European industrial producers from unfair competition and the health of the European population from unintended effects. A typical example of this is the case of honey, the import and repackaging of which raises serious questions in this area.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. The Common Internal Market (A)- The Common Internal Market (2012) is one of the EU's greatest acquisitions, so the conditions for ensuring free competition in the internal market are key to its existence and functioning. One of the conditions is the prohibition on concluding agreements and agreements between undertakings which hinder trade between Member States. This may lead to an abuse of a dominant position on the market, which is why the European Commission's work in this area is very important, since it controls the acquisitions and mergers of undertakings in the EU which lead or are able to lead to a significant concentration on the market and thus a dominant position on the market.  The fundamental objective of Eu competition rules is to protect competition from distortion, since competition is not an end in itself, but a condition for the realisation of a free and dynamic internal market and thus the conditions for effective economic growth. The proposed resolution, which I have, of course, supported, therefore not only represents Parliament's response to the Commission's findings, but serves as a guide for resolving topical issues and drafting legislation in this area. It is clear from the proposal that the Commission will have to inform the Member States more frequently about the control of state aid and strengthen supervision of the digital economy. The issue of fair competition should also not be separated from the issues of tax avoidance, so-called unfair tax competition, as it also distorts competition.

name: Simona Bonafè (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Ensuring fair competition, and therefore the existence of fair competition at the base of the European single market, including the increasingly important digital market, is one of the prerequisites necessary for achieving the general objectives of the European Union's economic policy. The resolution voted on today aims to give new impetus to competition policy in Europe, but also to extend protections towards compliance with it. It is necessary to strengthen, in an increasingly coordinated perspective at European level and with increasing cooperation between national antitrust authorities, the action to combat tax practices that could generate market-distorting effects. It is necessary to oppose the establishment of cartels and to prevent the formation of dominant positions on the market, in particular the digital market, which requires a rethink and deepening of current legislation in this area. States must also refrain from implementing tax policies that are potentially detrimental to competitiveness and must ensure fair opportunities for competition. Only if the relevant rules are effectively applied can fair and non-discriminatory access to the market be guaranteed, which can be of particular benefit to small and medium-sized enterprises and, ultimately, to all European consumers.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ I welcome colleague Cofferati's report. It is very important to ensure a fair single market. I hope that we will almost include on the European agenda the topic of equal quality of products in newer and older Member States. Citizens complain to me about differences on a daily basis and I think it is necessary to talk about this at EU level.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. Although this report highlights a number of dysfunctions (social dumping, public procurement, unfair bank practices) that should be corrected, or interesting suggestions (really deterrent fines, mandatory and automatic exchange of information on advance tax decisions, common IS base, taxation of profits transferred outside the EU), it aims instead to accelerate the creation of the Single Market whose result is the ransacking of our industry by competing with economies higher productivity. I therefore vote against the conclusions of this report.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution on the Annual Report on EU Competition Policy because I believe that the EU's single market and competition policy are the union's flagship. I particularly agree with the call for the Commission to put an end to social dumping, which is a real and pressing problem which must be resolved as soon as possible.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. This report reminds us above all of the importance of competition policy in the European Union but calls for this policy not to be a hindrance to the competitiveness of companies. A large part of this report addresses the problem of abuses of dominant position, which are detrimental to free competition between companies within the single market. The rapporteur stresses that the introduction of more substantial financial sanctions would limit cartels and anti-competitive practices. Finally, to combat tax dumping within the Union, there is a demand to introduce automatic and compulsory data exchanges between Member States and the creation of a consolidated common corporate tax base. Although this report attempts to combat tax dumping and abuses of dominant position, we believe that the solutions put forward contribute to strengthening the single market, particularly through the creation of the Banking Union. However, we believe that the loss of competitiveness that our industry and our companies are experiencing is largely the result of European policies that compete with too different economies. I therefore abstained on this text.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the annual report on EU competition policy because I believe that it is a basic pillar of the social market economy in Europe and an essential tool for the proper functioning of the Union's internal market.  In the field of competition, the European Union has gained a visible and respected position on the international stage. This independent and unified external representation based on clearly defined competences enables the Union to display its true political, demographic and economic power.  In view of the challenges of the digital age, the instruments provided for by current competition law need to be thoroughly reviewed. At the same time, I believe that it is essential to ensure a level playing field in the digital market and to combat abuses of dominance and tax optimisation, which will ultimately benefit consumers.  I welcome the fact that competition rules have proved their usefulness over many years of administrative experience on the part of the Commission, being further developed and strengthened in the case-law of the European courts, so that we can now say that they are widely recognised and stable.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against. In the field of State aid, the text signed by Mr Beazley, on be it, states that the commission's proposals should be based on the following: Langen does not deviate in the slightest from the previous ones. Yet state aid, according to many, is one of the policies that has most of all prevented Member States from facing multinationals from third countries, or supporting European production and industry. On the other hand, the persistence of classic liberal visions, which are not suited to our times and to the current crisis, is certainly having an impact on creating a situation of growth much lower than that of any other world economic area.

name: Cristian-Silviu Buşoi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union contains in Articles 101–109 binding rules on competition in the internal market based on a market economy open to free competition. European Union competition policy is a basic pillar of the social market economy in Europe, being a means of protecting European democracy, controlling and limiting unfair trade practices associated with monopolies and market dominance, while bringing benefits to consumers, entrepreneurs and workers, encouraging economic growth and innovation, thereby creating the framework within which each person has a fair chance of success. I support the EP's motion for a resolution on the annual report on EU competition policy. I also consider it particularly important to confer codecision powers in competition policy, especially when it comes to fundamental principles and binding legislative guidelines.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report on competition policy as key objectives have been achieved for the Socialist and Democratic Group, such as asking the Commission for a more belligerent position against social dumping in the labour market (paragraph 5), for services of general economic interest to be excluded from competition rules (paragraph 46) , addressing the problem of fragmentation of the EU digital market (paragraphs 55-59 and 79), for the Commission to maintain a priority approach to tax evasion or illegal corporate tax practices (paragraphs 62, 68-89) and, finally, for Parliament to be able to co-decide in the latter field (paragraph 110).  Useful references have also been made in the report to the need to incorporate flexibility in compliance with competition rules for the outermost and island regions. Also included in the report, on the proposal of Jonás Fernández and Ramón Jáuregui, a reference to the need to regulate ATM commissions because it is the price of a service whose market value is difficult to fix, which is very relevant for Spain at the moment.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. Every year, the European Parliament produces a report on the EU's competition policy. In a Borderless Europe, it is important that everyone respects the same rules. Competition within the EU and with its external partners must be fair. Distortions of competition such as cartels, monopolistic situations and state aid must be avoided at all costs.  The European Commission has a duty to enforce competition rules on all Member States and all companies operating within the Union and to punish them for abuses. Through this report I have been able to reiterate my positions in favour of tax harmonisation and the fight against social dumping.  I also reminded the Commission of the importance of examining the behaviour of distributors and their interactions at national and European level. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the Annual Report on Eu ropean Union Competition Policy. The European Union's competition policy is one of the fundamental pillars of the social market economy in Europe and is an essential instrument for the functioning of the Union's internal market. The report stressed the importance, for an effective and credible European competition policy, of the ability to innovate, the creation of favourable conditions for SMEs, startups and micro-enterprises, sustainability and the promotion of high environmental standards. With this report, Parliament has expressed to the European Commission the need to continue working to put an end to social dumping, with a particular focus on remote or isolated regions. In view of all these factors, I have chosen to vote in favour of this report.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ By way of background information, this is  an own-initiative report oriented to set the vision of the European Parliament on the implementation of competition policy by the General Directorate of Competition of European Commission. The Competition Working Group of the Economic and Monetary Affairs Committee drafts every year this report with its analysis of the actions taken during the past exercise and setting its main priorities for the next year. There were some positive provisions contained within this report such as a focus on abuses of dominant positions and cartels. Moreover, there were progressive  provisions in relation to addressing the issue of  state aid particularly in the financial sector  However, there were many other provisions which overstepped the competitiveness of the EU, for example a call for a European legislative framework and also the focus on the introduction of the CCCTB. It was for these reasons, that I abstained on the report.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ The European Parliament’s Report on the EU’s Competition Policy encourages the harmonisation of taxation across the EU – for this reason, and to defend tax sovereignty, UKIP voted against the Report.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report deals with the development of competition policy in the European Union. The report contains interesting points, including the reference to the introduction of a common corporate tax base, the call for a strengthening of policies to encourage infringement complaints and the call to go beyond the proposals put forward in the OECD draft in order to avoid any form of harmful tax competition in the internal market. I also fully support the call for the Commission to examine carefully the dominant position on the market of Google and other internet platforms. However, the report is also very critical. In addition to over-supporting the work done so far by the Commission, the report does not sufficiently call on the Commission to strengthen its powers of sanction and investigation. The issue of transparency is also not fully addressed and there is no proposal for a revision of the State aid framework, both of which I believe to be fundamental. For these reasons, I have chosen to abstain.

name: Dita Charanzová (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it gives a realistic assessment of state of play of the EU Competition policy. However, I could not agree with several paragraphs calling for investigation of Google related to the use of Android systems in mobile devices or accommodation booking engines. I believe we should respect the independence of the competition authorities. They must be free to act independently  and should not take actions based on political pressure.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (EUA) contains in Articles 101 to 109 binding rules on competition in the common internal market, based on an open economy with free competition. We support the report and stress that competition policy can contribute to achieving the objectives of the Agenda for Jobs and Growth, including in areas such as the digital internal market, energy policy, financial services, industrial policy and the fight against tax evasion. However, we disagree with the proposal for a common corporate tax rate for the Member States. This violates the basic principle of free economic policy.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 Today's resolution on the outcome of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs is part of a very important process because it refers to competitiveness which greatly affects economic activities within European territory. Although the rapporteur's proposals are a positive basis, I nevertheless believe that they are not complete and that they do not address all the important issues for the benefit of European citizens. In this light, I cannot accept that the effort made is sufficient and that is why I have decided to abstain.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the measure. The report commends Commissioner Vestager's work on cooperation with the European Parliament and calls for greater involvement of Parliament in competition policy. The report highlights the need for competition decisions to take account of social impact in peripheral and more isolated areas of European territory. Finally, the Commission is called for greater transparency in infringement proceedings against private companies.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The text dismissed by the ECON Commission does not seem to me to be perfect, and in fact there was a need to rework it a little with the amendments and the voting list, but basically I voted in favour of this report because I saw first-hand how Commissioner Vestager is very attentive to the political dimension of her decisions and if, on the one hand, she does not leave the sector bounded by the rules , on the other hand, it has the reasonableness that you do not expect from a Commissioner, especially if she comes from a northern European country. Good Commissioner, and congratulations on the way you conduct this key area of European policy.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The report commends Competition Commissioner Vestager for good cooperation with the European Parliament, and meantime explicitly demands greater involvement of Parliament in competition matters through the ordinary legislative procedure. The report states for the fifth consecutive time that the temporary state aid in the financial sector was necessary for the stabilisation of the global financial system but must be quickly reduced or totally removed and scrutinised as a result of the completion of the Banking Union. It calls on the Commission to put a stop to social dumping, and emphasises that competition policy decisions must take particular account of the social impact in remote or isolated regions. According to the report, the existing rules, related to competition policy infringements, on fines to be imposed on legal persons for infringements must be supplemented by ongoing penalties against the natural persons responsible. It calls on the Commission to incorporate the rules on fines, for example those imposed in cartel proceedings, into a legislative instrument. Concerning the digital economy, the report notes that the original market models of the competition policy may be inappropriate for the digital economy, and the use of price-based indicators in this dynamic economic sector often fails to achieve the desired outcome.  That is why I have voted for this report.

name: David Coburn (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ The European Parliament's Report on the EU's Competition Policy encourages the harmonisation of taxation across the EU – for this reason, and to defend tax sovereignty, UKIP voted against the Report.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. Competition policy has always been an instrument for a healthy economy with benefits for consumers, not an instrument in itself. However, as the report points out, competition policy should be seen as a cross-cutting instrument with social impacts, in consolidating the internal market, in creating a digital single market or in the soundness of the banking system. The 2014 Annual Report also assesses competition policy in the light of commitments made by President Juncker and Commissioner Vestager. The report points out that, as early as the first year, the Commission acted in all the promised areas. In particular, in the digital field, such as the abusive practices of large multinationals, or in terms of State aid with harm to taxpayers. However, the Commission's action has not been without failure and there is a wide margin for improvement. I would like to point out the transparency of the procedures and the need to genuinely involve Parliament in the development of regulatory instruments which, in some cases, are genuine legislative measures and therefore go away from the implementing competence of the European Commission.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this own-initiative report by Parliament. Competition from the European Union remains a fundamental policy, especially at this stage when it needs to be strengthened in order to achieve greater values of growth and employment. Specifically, I would like to point out the need to involve the European Parliament more in competition issues, as well as the need for the Commission to take into account the social impact of its decisions, even more so in remote and isolated regions, by supplementing sanctions against legal persons, including the natural persons responsible, in order to make the sanctioning function more effective. In addition, it is important to take a tougher look at member states' unfair tax practices.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The report demands greater involvement of the EP in competition matters through the ordinary legislative procedure.  I am in favour of competition and support most of the report, but i disagree that competition needs the introduction of CCCTB especially when the economy of states is naturally not on a level playing field.  Moreover, state aid for islands needs to be reviewed especially due to the obstacles that their economy faces.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report analyses competition aspects in the EU. There are many ideas in the text that we broadly support to prevent excessive market concentration, abuse of a dominant position and cartels. Of particular importance is the reference to the Google case and other internet platforms. Several references are also made to the necessary competition policies in the financial markets, in this case there are no points of contention. Interesting and worthy of support also the parts related to whistleblower policy, CCCTB, BEPS and the work of the TAXE commission and the reference to the Luxleaks case and the need to start country by country reporting as soon as possible. Good text, not unbalanced, which reflects priorities that are also ours. However, progress could be made in terms of transparency through increased reporting to the European Parliament. The report could have been more ambitious with regard to the amendment of the State aid law which, in my opinion, should be reviewed. That is why I have chosen to abstain.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I have not been able to vote in favour of this report because, despite containing very positive aspects, it continues to develop the neoliberal conception of the economy that perceives the market as the main agent of the European economy. This report has included numerous amendments tabled by my group and more aspects of central importance to the European economy: from supporting decisions to sanction tax-evading multinationals, to the crisis that has arisen in order to milk quotas or the investigation of the connections between certain former governors and large power companies. However, it is not recognized that services of general economic interest must be provided by the State, the internationalisation of public procurement and the European economy as a whole is called in clear reference to TTE. That is why, despite the important positive aspects, I have not been able to vote in favour of this report.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 EU competition policy is one of the fundamental pillars of the social market economy in Europe and, through the strict application of the principles of law, contributes to the functioning of the Union's internal market, benefits consumers, workers and entrepreneurs and promotes innovation and growth. I also voted in favour of this resolution because it addresses the issue of inequalities between European regions. In particular, the resolution notes that competition policy must take account of the objectives of sustainable development and social cohesion, support businesses located in regions suffering from temporary or permanent disadvantages and give greater flexibility to regions suffering from serious economic problems, such as regions included in the convergence and competitiveness objectives, and island regions.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Although the European Parliament has very limited competences with regard to EU competition policy, as this is mainly in the hands of the Commission, the EP drafts a plenary report on all the issues related to competition on an annual basis. In this year’s resolution there is a strong emphasis on fighting social dumping in the labour market, on tackling fragmentation and anti-trust behaviour in the EU digital market, and on state aid and tax issues. I could support the report because of the stance it took on these issues, although I have reservations on tax-related content. It must be noted that the Treaty affords flexibility to Member States in areas of taxation, namely setting rates and tax bases. I mention this as this is of crucial importance for the survival of certain (sometimes smaller) Member States which are isolated from the internal market. Therefore, I voted against those amendments that call for a Consolidated Common Corporate Tax, otherwise, I voted in favour of this EP report.

name: Daniel Dalton (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I am afraid I cannot support this report, which is supposed to be about competition policy, but instead chooses to address many issues of taxation, growing the EU’s own resources and enhancing the European Parliament’s powers at the expense of national governments. I cannot support calls for a Common Consolidated Corporate Tax Base, nor the attempt to grab even more own resources for the EU by allocating recovered illegal state aid to the EU budget. Similarly I do not feel the European Parliament should be given co-decision powers in the field of competition policy. For all of these reasons I voted against this year’s report on competition policy.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This report presents Parliament's position on the Commission's annual report on EU competition policy. However, with an overall positive view of the work of Commissioner Vestager in charge of this issue, Parliament calls for greater involvement in competition policy through the ordinary legislative procedure, particularly with regard to infringement procedure and fines.  For the fifth year in a row, it calls for the reduction or abolition of state aid in the financial sector following the completion of the banking union, and the cessation of social dumping measures, which France also defends.  For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. The EU's competition policy sets the rules for the proper functioning of the internal market. In its report, the European Parliament calls on the European Commission to step up its efforts in several areas, including merger control and the fight against abuse of dominance, tax optimisation and social dumping. These measures are important to protect European consumers, which is why I supported this report.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Competition is undoubtedly one of the key principles around which the Commission's economic policy was built. On many occasions, however, the European debate has called into question the strict and overly stringent application of these policies. It is necessary to better understand the limits of this economic policy, especially at a time of great change for European industry. The production of steel and other commodities has often been the subject of attention by European policies, but the decisions taken in Brussels have found numerous oppositions from national governments, local authorities and especially from producers. Is it possible to rethink policies that bring together incentives for innovation, restrictions on unfair practices arising from dominant market positions and at the same time ensure a social economy? In particular, these policies, rather than uniting Europe, seem to create friction between the various local economic realities. Moreover, the credit crunch and unemployment seem to make some of these policies, such as quota policies, no longer adapted to the global challenges that lie ahead. I therefore believe that these policies must be the result of a more in-depth dialogue with local realities and with the social groups concerned in order to make them more efficient and more integrated with the heterogeneous European economic fabric.

name: Angélique Delahaye (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the Langen Report on the European Union's Annual Competition Policy Report. This 2014 competition report shows that the Commission and the competition authority, with more than 1,000 employees, are the most powerful authorities in Europe to ensure compliance with competition rules within the internal market.  Through this vote, I support the idea that multi-billion euro fines for illegal price cartels should in future be supplemented by penalties for business leaders and managers responsible for these practices. I also believe that decisions made in the context of competition policy must take into account social implications in particular.  On the other hand, I objected to the paragraphs dealing with competition in perishable commodity markets. As it stands, the European Union's competition policy is not in line with agricultural issues, which is why I think we need to call for a common reflection that aligns the policy of competition with agricultural policy.

name: Jean-Paul Denanot (S&D)
text: In writing. The text put to the vote proposes some inflections in the concept of free and undistorted competition defended without nuance by the Commission. First, by introducing the concept of innovation, it allows us to welcome the principle of risk-taking and the climate of confidence necessary for investment. Second, because it acts an approach that is not based solely on lower consumer prices. Finally, because it takes up a number of proposals from the Tax Committee to investigate tax rulings.  The report thus calls for a consolidated common corporate tax base and the establishment of country-by-country reporting.  It also wants to reduce state aid to the banking sector or condition it on lending to SMEs. I also supported three amendments dealing with the TISA and TTIP trade agreements (including their anti-competitive scope and their impact in terms of social dumping) and the preferential use of generic drugs.  Finally, I have contributed my voice to the amendment of my colleague Edouard Martin calling for consideration of the major energy-intensive industries that must be accompanied in the transition of their ecosystem.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. This annual report on EU competition policy covers many areas where extreme vigilance is needed, such as the differences in competitiveness within the Union, the digital economy, public procurement, telecommunications networks and unfair practices that can be observed in the banking system.  Similarly, the report proposed to us is positive in that it seeks to strengthen antitrust procedures and the fight against abuses of dominant position. In addition, it is suggested that the fight against tax evasion should be accompanied by a European mechanism. In addition to these good intentions, the report supports strengthening the European Parliament's involvement through the codecision procedure.  However, all of these proposals are only elements of a strategy to strengthen the European single market which is the basis of the European deregulation as we know it. That is why I have decided to abstain.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I did not support this report for several reasons. One of them is the fact that the report goes beyond its limitations, greatly affecting taxation issues. By repeating a number of points of the TAXE parliamentary committee's report, it hints not only at the completion of the Banking Union, but also the allocation of resources to the EU from illegal State aid. It makes an impression to name specific cases, such as Google. In my opinion, this infringes DG Competition's independence when it comes to resolving individual cases and the fact that this is outside the remit of that report. The annual report can hardly be the place for such a strong wording and broad interpretation of competences.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 Although the report highlights the distortions of existing practices that hinder growth, destroy SMEs and promote tax evasion and unfair competition, it nevertheless avoids stressing the need to apply competition rules and proposing those rules and controls that will not destroy national - local markets (imposing the single market) but will instead force profitable multinational companies to contribute to the financing of Member States and promote entrepreneurship and transparency , in particular in enterprises for medicines, food, fuel, telecommunications services, etc.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU) provides for binding rules for competition in the internal market, based on an open economy with free competition, and agreements and concerted practices between undertakings affecting trade between Member States and giving rise to an abusive exploitation of the dominant market position are prohibited. As a general rule, and with rare exceptions, State aid for the benefit of certain undertakings or products distorting competition in the internal market is prohibited, but may be authorised by the Commission under certain conditions. In suma, the 2014 Competition Policy Report shows that the Commission, alongside the competition authority, is the decisive authority to make competition prevail in the internal market. Financial penalties of billions of euros imposed as a result of price-fixing agreements should in future be effectively supplemented by sanctions on business managers and managers in order to more effectively avoid such behaviour.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I abstained on this report because it is in the direction of a single market.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. THE EU's competition policy does not prevent the concentration of economic and financial power in the hands of the few. On the contrary, this is the dynamics of the whole process of integration, given its capitalist nature. Subjecting most public services and strategic sectors of the economy to EU competition policy and its single market has served the objectives of large private economic groups wishing to take ownership of these services and sectors, making them subject to the logic of the incessant demand for maximum profit and minimum cost. Under the false pretext of unfair competition or distortions of competition, this policy has resulted in legislation aimed at preventing public and democratic control of the strategic sectors of the economy and promoting universal, free and quality public services. We support the call to put an end to social dumping, but it is all EU policy that runs counter. The deepening of the single market and the elimination of so-called market restrictions serve the objectives of monopolistic concentration and deepen divergences within the EU. We call for all cooperation efforts between Member States and for a real commitment to combat tax havens and tax avoidance and tax evasion.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing \ u2012 This annual report in question allows the European Parliament to make political declarations on the state of competition in the European Union.  Although the European Commission closely monitors the econ committee's position, the European Parliament has very limited competences in this area. It is therefore right to ask the European Commission to combat social dumping more actively in the labour market, to try to exclude services with a general economic interest from the competition rules, to penalised fragmentation and antitrust behaviour in the digital market, but also many other unsolved problems. Competition policy should promote fair conditions for all companies and encourage their participation in competition in the internal market.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 Although the report highlights the distortions of existing practices that hinder growth, destroy SMEs and promote tax evasion and unfair competition, it does not highlight the need to apply competition rules and does not propose those rules and controls which will not destroy national - local markets (imposing the single market) but will instead force profitable multinational companies to contribute to the financing of Member States and promote entrepreneurship and transparency , in particular in enterprises for medicines, food, fuel, telecommunications services, etc.  For these reasons I am voting against the report on the annual report on EU competition policy.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I would like to welcome the report on Annual Report on EU Competition Policy, recognising the importance of the competition policy in the EU encouraging fair conditions for all companies to compete in the internal market, by also maintaining a high level of social welfare and protection of working conditions. For that reason, we need to put a stop to social dumping, and ensure that competition policy decisions take particular account of the social impact in remote or isolated regions. We also need to complete the internal market, as there are still areas that are fragmented and incomplete, by ending as soon as possible unjustified market restrictions and distortions of competition.  Competition policy should aim, therefore, at strengthening social cohesion in the Union, also by a better convergence and cooperation among national competition authorities in the EU. And, nevertheless, coherence needs to be achieved between the Union’s trade and competition policies and the objectives of its industrial policy. I strongly support the focus to end tax evasion and illegal corporate tax practices that is to be ensured through the EU legislative framework. A democratic strengthening of the competition policy can also be reached through the co-decision power of the Parliament in competition policy.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Overall, the 2014 Competition Report shows that the Commission and the competition authority with around 1 000 employees are the strongest authorities in Europe capable of achieving competition in the internal market. Billions in fines for illicit price fixing should in future be effectively supplemented by penalties for responsible managers and managers in order to prevent these behaviours more effectively. Parliament hopes that Competition Commissioner Vestager hopes that EU competition policy will ensure its prominent role in the implementation of the market economy and European competition, that it will progress internationally and will not lead to too many sectoral and national exceptions and uncontrollable exemption thresholds.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report because it was based on the need to guarantee the internal market and based on an open market economy and free competition. It is necessary to give Parliament powers in reference to competition law, since the Commission cannot at the same time be responsible for establishing the legal framework in the form of guidelines and then being responsible for compliance with its own guidelines. Similarly, the Commission must incorporate new criteria for the digital economy. Unfair tax competition between Member States is another focus of concern, as it greatly distorts the internal market in the Union and we must therefore work on its elimination. Similarly, we must investigate the presence of expolithics on the board of directors of large energy companies, which causes great rejection in our society.

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report on competition policy because we have succeeded in including key objectives for the Group of Socialists and Democrats, such as asking the Commission for a more belligerent position against social dumping in the labour market, that services of general economic interest be excluded from competition rules, that the problem of fragmentation of the EU digital market be addressed , for the Commission to maintain a priority approach to tax evasion and illegal corporate tax practices and, finally, for Parliament to be able to co-decide in the latter area.  Useful references have also been made to the need to incorporate flexibility in compliance with competition rules for the outermost and island regions. Also included in the report, on a proposal from the Spanish Socialists, is a reference to the need to regulate ATM commissions because it is the price of a service whose market value is difficult to fix, which is very relevant for Spain at the moment.

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report on competition policy as key objectives have been achieved for the Socialist and Democratic Group, such as asking the Commission for a more belligerent position against social dumping in the labour market (paragraph 5), for services of general economic interest to be excluded from competition rules (paragraph 46) , addressing the problem of fragmentation of the EU digital market (paragraphs 55-59 and 79), for the Commission to maintain a priority approach to tax evasion or illegal corporate tax practices (paragraphs 62, 68-89) and, finally, for Parliament to be able to co-decide in the latter field (paragraph 110).  Useful references have also been made in the report to the need to incorporate flexibility in compliance with competition rules for the outermost and island regions. Also included in the report, on the proposal of Jonás Fernández and Ramón Jáuregui, a reference to the need to regulate ATM commissions because it is the price of a service whose market value is difficult to fix, which is very relevant for Spain at the moment.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. I am pleased to have supported the report by the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs and Industrial Policy, which forms part of the structured dialogue with the European Commission on competition policy. I agree that the priorities of the S&D Group are reiterated in particular in a number of paragraphs stressing the need to prevent the negative employment effects of EU competition rules, with particular reference to sectors of general economic interest. I can therefore only welcome this report, which also calls for wider and more coherent action to resolve conflicts of interest in competition policy, starting with stronger action against tax evasion and illegal circumvention practices by large companies.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the ANNUAL REPORT ON EU Competition Policy. This report marks a new beginning, because as was also pointed out during the investiture procedure of the new EC, competition policy "will contribute, where necessary, to the programme for employment, growth, including in innovative sectors such as the digital market, energy policy, financial services, industrial policy and the fight against evasion. This is no longer just a ritual and periodic exercise. The EP is aware of the powers conferred on the EC in the field of competition in the internal market, based on an open economy and free competition, and it is understood that the basic objective of competition policy is to avoid distortions of free competition and therefore of the proper functioning of the internal market. However, it is time to give the EP more powers because it is paradoxical that the EC should lay down its annual competition policy guidelines and be itself responsible for implementation and have the power to impose sanctions in vital areas such as State aid. I strongly support the EP's call for more information on the strict control and monitoring of illegal state aid, tax rulings.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted against Mr Langen's report on the annual report on EU competition policy today, acknowledging that the report identifies a number of important points, such as the need for greater tax justice and tax transparency. At the same time, however, in a futile effort to create what appears to be a "grand coalition" in the European Parliament, he makes too many concessions that dilute the result. For example, I cannot agree with the plea for a European deposit guarantee. Our citizens' savings are not a European commodity!

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. A fair competition policy is essential to ensure Europe's economic growth and stability. To this end, it is necessary for Parliament to be more fully involved in the protection of competition law.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Report on the Annual Report on Competition Policy.
