A strong European competition policy not only ensures that consumers get the best possible deal, but also that small and local business in the West Midlands can compete on a level playing field.  In light of the ongoing crisis in the UK steel industry, I particularly welcome paragraph 54, which ‘requests a study into whether current EU provisions on state aid inhibit the consolidation and strengthening of competitiveness among European firms vis-à-vis their global competitors.’

name: Bruno Gollnisch (NI)
text: In writing. I abstained on Mr Langen's report. It contains very relevant and common-sense remarks and considerations, particularly on social and fiscal dumping, or on the consideration of the digital economy. He even timidly calls for some intellectual revolutions, such as the redefinition of the notion of competition, by integrating the structure-behavior-result parameter. It advocates the support of European companies competing at the international level with companies that are not subject to the same regulatory constraints as they do on their territory. I doubt that these revolutions will take place in the Commission. However, the report does not call into question the essential: this competition takes place in a European market that is neither unique nor homogeneous, since it does not correspond to a single and homogeneous political entity. European policies as a whole, far from ensuring the convergence of twenty-eight disparate economies, aggravate their heterogeneity and even promote unfair behaviour, as with the 'detachment' directive. And that causes many, too many victims, especially in my country.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I abstained in the vote on the annual report on the European Parliament's competition policy. It maintains a globally neoliberal vision of competition policy, focused on the single market and with little specific reference to the different economic sectors. While it devotes enough space to the issue of taxes, it does not propose any coercive measures to combat tax evasion or avoidance. Some amendments tabled by my group were, however, included, such as those relating to abuses in food distribution or down-down social competition. I think the report is not very negative, but we still do not share the overall approach.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for the report on EU competition policy because there is a need for an increase in market verification and supervision of competition. The EU was founded as an open-ended social market economy based on free but also fair competition, with the aim of increasing consumer prosperity and citizens' standard of living. The pressure of unfair competition on SMEs, which account for 98% of EU businesses and 67% of all jobs, needs to be reduced. The data show that there is still tax evasion, tax fraud and tax havens that cost taxpayers EUR 1 trillion annually. Trade defence against unfair competition and non-European imports is vital and the European Parliament has drawn the Commission's attention to this. Competition policy must pay particular attention to the objectives of sustainable development and social cohesion.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Alongside fellow Labour MEPs, I voted in favour of the Annual Report on EU Competition Policy. I believe that it is with a strong European competition policy that we can best ensure that our consumers are getting the best possible deal, and that our small and local businesses are competing on a level playing field. Being a part of a 500 million strong consumer market is surely one of the biggest benefits we receive from being a part of the EU, and by developing as well as enforcing strong rules for fair competition, we can ensure more innovation, more opportunity and a better deal for British consumers.

name: Enrique Guerrero Salom (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report on competition policy as key objectives have been achieved for the Socialist and Democratic Group, such as asking the Commission for a more belligerent position against social dumping in the labour market (paragraph 5), for services of general economic interest to be excluded from competition rules (paragraph 46) , addressing the problem of fragmentation of the EU digital market (paragraphs 55-59 and 79), for the Commission to maintain a priority approach to tax evasion or illegal corporate tax practices (paragraphs 62, 68-89) and, finally, for Parliament to be able to co-decide in the latter field (paragraph 110).  Useful references have also been made in the report to the need to incorporate flexibility in compliance with competition rules for the outermost and island regions. Also included in the report, on the proposal of Jonás Fernández and Ramón Jáuregui, a reference to the need to regulate ATM commissions because it is the price of a service whose market value is difficult to fix, which is very relevant for Spain at the moment.

name: Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report on competition policy as key objectives have been achieved for the Socialist and Democratic Group, such as asking the Commission for a more belligerent position against social dumping in the labour market (paragraph 5), for services of general economic interest to be excluded from competition rules (paragraph 46) , addressing the problem of fragmentation of the EU digital market (paragraphs 55-59 and 79), for the Commission to maintain a priority approach to tax evasion or illegal corporate tax practices (paragraphs 62, 68-89) and, finally, for Parliament to be able to co-decide in the latter field (paragraph 110).  Useful references have also been made in the report to the need to incorporate flexibility in compliance with competition rules for the outermost and island regions. Also included in the report, on the proposal of Jonás Fernández and Ramón Jáuregui, a reference to the need to regulate ATM commissions because it is the price of a service whose market value is difficult to fix, which is very relevant for Spain at the moment.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report promotes the common tax base and continues to seek to deregulate the labour market within the framework of EU competition policies. Some positive amendments have been incorporated into the report on social dumping and pharmaceutical companies but, despite their inclusion, we consider that the most appropriate attitude is that of voting against it.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I chose to vote against this report due to a number of sensitive issues concerning Ireland, namely CCCTB, EU tax policy and Google’s market position.

name: Anja Hazekamp (GUE/NGL)
text: Written. 'Everyone just has to pay taxes properly, including large corporations. Tax evasion and avoidance must therefore be tackled firmly. Although I believe that the design of tax legislation is primarily a matter for the Member States themselves, arrangements should be made at European level to combat tax avoidance and evasion of such companies. Disclosure of taxes paid is an important step in this. More transparency in tax arrangements between Member States and companies is also needed to prevent abuses , such as those made by Starbucks and the Netherlands, by Apple and Ireland and by Amazon and Luxembourg.  However, a consolidated common tax rate for companies imposed on the Member States from Brussels goes far too far. Member States must have control over this themselves.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: Writing. The European Parliament's annual competition report identifies and assesses European competition policy issues and the work of the Commission last year. The 2015 Annual Report identified a number of key challenges. For example, the calls for greater transparency in tax competition through the introduction of a common corporate tax base seems reasonable and deserves support. However, there are also a number of problematic demands in the report. ALFA does not support the call for a European deposit guarantee as the third pillar of the Banking Union. I also think it is fundamentally wrong to give the European Parliament a greater say in competition policy. It is essential for an effective competition policy that it can act independently of politics. The independence of competition authorities must be strengthened and freed from political influence. I was therefore unable to vote in favour of the report in this form. Incidentally, I believe that the single euro must be abolished. It leads to strife and discord in Europe.

name: Gunnar Hökmark (PPE)
text: Written. We regret that the annual competition report attaches so much focus to successful entrepreneurship in the digital economy and wants to regulate rather than open up the conditions for new entrepreneurship and increased competition. We would also like to draw attention to a major competition problem relating to the Energy Union, which must be followed up in next year's competition report, namely Gazprom's attempts at monopolisation and to increasing dependence on Russian gas. It is contrary both to internal energy market legislation and to European security interests. Gazprom's conscious attempts at market dominance have a scale and importance that is far greater for the European market than successful digital companies that are constantly exposed to new competition but which are developed through their ability to innovate.

name: Mary Honeyball (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because it is through a strong European competition policy that we are able to ensure that our consumers are getting the best possible deal. It also means that our small and local businesses are competing on a level playing field.  Being part of a market with half a billion consumers is one of the biggest benefits we get from being in the EU. By developing and enforcing strong rules for fair competition we ensure more innovation, more opportunity, and ultimately a better deal for British citizens and consumers.

name: Brice Hortefeux (PPE)
text: In writing. Competition policy is one of the most harmonised policies in that the European Commission has a strong control over state aid, mergers and antitrust procedures. It is an essential instrument for the proper functioning of the internal market. This annual diagnosis is a healthy exercise that allows both legislators and citizens to know the state of the common market. Indeed, it should be noted that the existence of cartels causes losses ranging from 181 to 320 billion euros, or about 3% of the EU's GDP, that in terms of energy costs, the European single market is less efficient than the internal market of the United States, with price differences of 31% compared to 22% in the United States, than in many Member States , a drastic credit crunch continues to affect SMEs, which account for 98% of EU businesses and 67% of employees. If we can welcome this regulation, which is the most successful of all European policies, we must continue to be vigilant with regard to the anti-competitive or at least offensive practices of foreign companies which may pose a threat to jobs in Europe.

name: Ian Hudghton (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ On balance I was able to support this report whilst retaining reservations on some of its content.  EU competition policy is extremely important although it must always be framed within the context of a healthy social Europe.  Furthermore, whilst I support EU efforts to coordinate efforts against tax evasion, I consider that taxation law itself must remain a Member State competence.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome this report. It is important that the Commission conclude quickly and as comprehensively as possible the proceedings instituted in 2014 against the number of large international companies in relation to the massive tax reductions benefiting them in. Moreover, Parliament has repeatedly called for the ordinary legislative procedure under the Lisbon Treaty to be introduced for competition law.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a proposal for a European Parliament resolution on the EU's annual competition policy report, as I believe that European competition policy plays a key role in strengthening the market economy and competition within the European Union. In this context, it is important to note that one of the main objectives of European competition legislation is to prevent its distortion and ensure employment and grow in order to achieve a fully open economy based on free competition. However, efforts should be increased to prevent unfair tax competition between Member States and speed up the timing of investigations by the Commission, as shortcomings in these segments contribute greatly to the functioning of the Union internal market. Therefore, I support the role of the European Commission and other competent authorities in the field of competition, but I also consider that some improvements and changes are necessary.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. This text raises a number of important problems such as social dumping, the digital economy, social cohesion, public procurement, telecommunications, unfair and illicit practices used by the banking sector. In addition, there is a demand that fines rules that would have a real deterrent impact in anti-competitive cartels and practices be incorporated into a legislative instrument.  With regard to state aid to the banking system, it should no longer exist after the establishment of the banking union and should be linked to conditions for granting credit to SMEs. MEPs call for the creation of a legislative framework for the European Union to prevent distortions of competition through aggressive tax planning and tax evasion.  While some observations are correct, this report is in line with the creation of the single market, which is at the root of the rampage of our industry. So I abstained.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. – The European Parliament's Report on the EU's Competition Policy encourages the harmonisation of taxation across the EU – for this reason, and to defend tax sovereignty, my fellow colleagues and I voted against the Report.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ This report outlines the European Parliament main recommendations on how to improve EU competition policy and Member States’ corporate taxation practices. The increasing digitalisation of our economy requires new European rules on fair taxation and market dominance; this is one of our biggest challenges. The turnover criterion is not enough to determine whether a digital company has a dominant market position. The customer base must also be taken into consideration. We should also review the sanctions procedure. I find it counter-productive that a company which benefited from illegal state aid from a Member State has to return the money to the same Member State.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report because strong competition and proactive policy on these issues are needed to protect consumers, strengthen the single market and thus return to growth and jobs. The report calls on the Commission to step up its efforts to combat abuses of dominant positions and social dumping.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. I believe it is important to ensure strong control in antitrust proceedings and mergers of large companies, including increasingly in the digital sector. Important decisions have been taken, particularly in the digital economy and in the area of tax aid law, which will bring back millions of unpaid taxes to the nation states and open up a level playing field for European companies, especially SMEs. I agree with this report.

name: Krišjānis Kariņš (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 European Union competition law is one of the cornerstones of the internal market. Its aim is to ensure a fair environment for businesses, which results in consumers receiving goods and services at market-conform prices and quality, while entrepreneurs obtain understandable rules of the game. Unfortunately, in practice, everything does not work as it should. We still have monopolies and cartels in the European Union, which have caused losses to the economy of between EUR 181 billion and EUR 320 billion.  Therefore, the work of the European Commission is important, which monitors compliance with competition law and restricts the offenders by indicting them and imposing penalties. For example, microsoft has received a fine of €1.68 billion from the European Commission. The European Commission has also accused the Russian state-owned Gazprom of abusing its dominant market position in eight countries of the European Union. I therefore believe that the European Commission's ability to investigate and ensure that such serious infringements are respected must be further strengthened and that unfair competition is avoided, which is detrimental not only to consumers but also to the many honest businesses.  In view of the above arguments, I voted in favour of the resolution.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Report on the Annual Report on Competition Policy because it is through a strong European competition policy that we are able to ensure that our consumers are getting the best possible deal, and that our small and local businesses are competing on a level playing field.  Being part of a market with 500 million consumers is one of the biggest benefits we get from being in the EU, and by developing and enforcing strong rules for fair competition we ensure more innovation, more opportunity, and ultimately a better deal for British citizens and consumers.

name: Jude Kirton-Darling (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Yesterday, Tata Steel UK announced the loss of over 1 000 jobs in its UK steel manufacturing facilities, including in Hartlepool. My thoughts have been with those affected by this decision. They find themselves in the same situation as the thousands of jobs lost in this sector during the last quarter of 2015, including in Redcar at SSI. On 24 November 2016, the Commission responded to my written question on state aid rules, clearly stating that ‘under EU State aid rules, the steel sector can benefit from several categories of aid: R&D and innovation, training, employment and environmental aid can thus contribute to long-term competitiveness of the sector. Moreover Member States can also mitigate the effect of higher electricity prices to the sector induced by the EU emissions trading scheme.’ The UK steel industry is in free-fall, the UK Government is refusing to pull the parachute open, and soon our entire industry will be irreparably damaged. That is why I submitted an amendment to today’s annual report on EU Competition Policy calling for Europe-wide action to tackle the crisis in the steel sector. I am delighted that this amendment and the report gained broad support. No more talk: we need concrete action to Save Our Steel.

name: Bernd Kölmel (ECR)
text: Writing. The European Parliament's annual competition report identifies and assesses European competition policy issues and the work of the Commission last year. The 2015 Annual Report identified a number of key challenges. This includes, for example, the call for greater transparency in tax competition, specifically through the introduction of a common corporate tax base. I think this makes sense and it deserves support. However, there are also a number of problematic demands in the report. ALFA categorically rejects the call for a European deposit guarantee as the third pillar of the Banking Union. I also think it is fundamentally wrong to give the European Parliament a greater say in competition policy. It is essential for an effective competition policy that it can act independently of politics. The independence of competition authorities must be strengthened and freed from political influence. I was therefore unable to vote in favour of the report in this form.

name: Elisabeth Köstinger (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of this report because it also addresses the urgent challenges in agriculture. In particular, I fully support the call for binding measures in the food supply chain, against retailers that harm farmers and consumers, and the establishment of a European food price observatory to monitor abusive behaviour towards farmers and consumers!

name: Stelios Kouloglou (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ Every year the ECON committee draft its evaluation and new priorities. This report is a key tool for the European Union, since the Commission has more power regarding this topic.  Furthermore, the European Parliament has to analyse the implementation of competition policies. It is essential for the GUE/NGL to evaluate ECON’s activities and reorder to include some socials concerns. Even if the final report includes some important points for our political group, I voted abstention since the general content of the report is still very neoliberal.

name: Béla Kovács (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 Part of the purpose of the report is that the Commission should not be allowed to simultaneously impose the legal framework in the form of guidelines and then to comply with its own guidelines and to impose heavy fines at its discretion or on the basis of political motivations. It refers to the latter in the campaign against my country and now against Poland.  It is appropriate to extend the ordinary legislative procedure under the Treaty of Lisbon to competition law, i.e. to involve the European Parliament in investigations. The report submitted by the EP's Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs already makes more than 100 calls and requests to the Commission on the 2014 evaluation of competition policy. However, it cannot be supported as a whole, because it serves to preserve the disadvantage of peripheral States and the Member States that later joined in a competition in which the old members had significant advantages, since state aid was not initially limited.

name: Constance Le Grip (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the annual report on EU competition policy. I believe that it is indeed important to strengthen the competitiveness of our European companies internationally by asking the European Commission not to limit external trade strategies.  Nevertheless, like my French parliamentary colleagues in the EPP Group, I voted in favour of paragraph 5 in order to affirm my support for the fight against social dumping and paragraph 73 supporting the public nature of the tax information published by companies under the country-by-country reporting mechanism.  I also abstained on Amendment 14 tabled by the GUE Group in order to denounce the uncooperative attitude of many multinationals towards the European Parliament on competition policy issues in the context of the work of the special committee TAXE, but by rejecting the taking of binding measures against them.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. Like the other Members of the National Front, I abstained on the european Union's competition policy report, which calls on the Commission to improve the establishment of the single market. Despite some good demands and findings on social, fiscal and environmental dumping, and the demand for an increase in Parliament's powers over the Commission, we cannot support the deepening of the European single market.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report because despite some interesting recommendations it goes in the direction of the creation of the Single Market, the result of which is the ransacking of our industry by putting very different economies in competition.

name: Sander Loones (ECR)
text: Written. 'The Langen report should be a report on European competition policy. In practice, however, it appears to be mainly about tax policy. For example, several proposals are copied from the TAXE report, proposals that we do not share. That cannot be the intention of a report on competition. That is why the N-VA voted against this report.  On top of that, this report does not seem to respect the independence of the European Commission in this matter. The European Parliament considers itself the competition authority. However, it is not politics, but an independent institution that must assess competition policy.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report on competition policy as key objectives have been achieved for the Socialist and Democratic Group, such as asking the Commission for a more belligerent position against social dumping in the labour market (paragraph 5), for services of general economic interest to be excluded from competition rules (paragraph 46) , addressing the problem of fragmentation of the EU digital market (paragraphs 55-59 and 79), for the Commission to maintain a priority approach to tax evasion or illegal corporate tax practices (paragraphs 62, 68-89) and, finally, for Parliament to be able to co-decide in the latter field (paragraph 110).  Useful references have also been made in the report to the need to incorporate flexibility in compliance with competition rules for the outermost and island regions. A reference to the need to regulate ATM fees for the price of a service whose market value is difficult to set has also been included in the report, which is very relevant for Spain at the moment.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report on competition policy as key objectives have been achieved for the Socialist and Democratic Group, such as asking the Commission for a more belligerent position against social dumping in the labour market (paragraph 5), for services of general economic interest to be excluded from competition rules (paragraph 46) , addressing the problem of fragmentation of the EU digital market (paragraphs 55-59 and 79), for the Commission to maintain a priority approach to tax evasion or illegal corporate tax practices (paragraphs 62, 68-89) and, finally, for Parliament to be able to co-decide in the latter field (paragraph 110).  Useful references have also been made in the report to the need to incorporate flexibility in compliance with competition rules for the outermost and island regions. Also included in the report, on the proposal of Jonás Fernández and Ramón Jáuregui, a reference to the need to regulate ATM commissions because it is the price of a service whose market value is difficult to fix, which is very relevant for Spain at the moment.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. As we already know, on the basis of the TFEU, our internal market is based on an open market economy and free competition.  The fundamental objective of EU competition law is to protect it from market-harming business activities. For this reason, it is essential to achieve effective competition as a condition so that we can finally enjoy a free and dynamic internal market.  To achieve this, coordinated efforts are needed from the Commission, through the Competition Commissioner, the European Parliament and the Member States. One of the demands in the report is that the Commission is obliged to give an oral and written opinion on the specific proposals which Parliament approves by a large majority, and not only through the annual report it already makes.  In my view, this report is of great importance as its adoption is essential to prohibit agreements between undertakings which go against free competition and adversely affect trade between Member States.

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR)
text: Writing. The European Parliament's annual competition report identifies and assesses European competition policy issues and the work of the Commission last year. The 2015 Annual Report identified a number of key challenges. For example, the calls for greater transparency in tax competition through the introduction of a common corporate tax base makes sense and deserves support. However, there are also a number of problematic demands in the report. ALFA does not support the call for a European Deposit Guarantee as the third pillar of the Banking Union. I also think it is fundamentally wrong to give the European Parliament a greater say in competition policy. It is essential for an effective competition policy that it can act independently of politics. The independence of competition authorities must be strengthened and freed from political influence. I was therefore unable to vote in favour of the report in this form.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report as it calls for an investigation by Google for "transgressions" such as supplying Android OS in conjunction with other products. I also disagree with the effort to regulate companies such as Uber, Airbnb and others. I am also against the introduction of a 'harmonised corporate tax base'. I am in the for a tax competition between states that prevents governments from imposing too high taxes on citizens.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒In order to ensure the construction of the single market, a full range of steps should be taken starting from building a Digital Single Market, e-administration and implementing new public procurement rules, through the Energy Union, building a single capital market and a banking union to the most important one – further developing competition policy as a basis for the development of the single market. Competition policy needs to be developed, administratively simplified and democratically strengthened. In antitrust procedures, the rules on fines should definitely be extended to those responsible natural persons. Effective and credible competition policy must be geared towards the realisation of the strategic interests of the European economy such as innovation, investment, competitiveness and sustainability. Opening a source of entrepreneurship financing to modernise business and innovation is a precondition without which we will not initiate stronger growth in Europe. I supported MEP Langen's annual competition policy report because of the importance of preventing abuse of office, which poses a serious problem in competition. I fully agree that state aid to banks should be conditional on their lending to SMEs.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing \ u2012 Properly implemented competition policy is a tool to ensure a fair and level playing field for business in order to achieve economic benefits and growth in the common internal market. In order to increase the transparency and effectiveness of competition control, it is essential that the European Parliament's position vis-à-vis the Commission is strengthened legislatively as soon as possible and that legislative power is thoroughly separated from executive and supervisory powers.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on the annual report on EU Competition Policy for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech before the plenary of the European Parliament on 18/1/2016. In my view, this report is neither complete nor substantiated.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I abstained on this vote. This report presents some interesting points and fair observations, recognising in particular that the competitiveness of businesses and the defence of the EU's strategic interests are a priority. Despite this, the report is in the direction of the creation and strengthening of the Single Market, which we oppose because it will be economically harmful for France. In these circumstances I prefer to abstain.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this proposal. I particular welcome the paragraph that ‘Reiterates that EU Structural Funds may not be used in a way that directly or indirectly encourages the relocation of services or production to another Member State, e.g. by a waiting period for undertakings receiving such funds; stresses that State aid is sometimes necessary in order to guarantee the delivery of services of general economic interest (SGEI), including energy, transport and telecommunications; emphasises that State intervention is often the most effective policy tool for guaranteeing the provision of services that are vital to safeguarding economic and social conditions in isolated, remote or outlying regions and islands in the Union’.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Competition policy is a key pillar of the single market. Fair competition must be ensured so that the market continues to grow towards its greatest potential. As the rapporteur says, digital networks are a key tool for consumers and investors to participate fairly in the market. In view of the rapid development of the new networks, appropriate regulation must be ensured so that the objectives of the single market are also achieved in the digital area. I voted in favour, calling on the European Commission to better regulate competition in the EU.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. "U2012 My support for the EU Competition Policy Report in 2014, in which from the European Parliament we would like to stress that, thanks to the work carried out, the EU's competition policy is capable of strengthening its important role in the realization of the market economy and competition in Europe, driving it at the international level , and does not result in endless sectoral and national exceptions and uncontrollable derogation thresholds. We also note that, in addition to the fines imposed for illicit pricing, it is important to complement this work in the future by fines to responsible business managers and managers, in order to prevent this practice more effectively.

name: Κώστας Μαυρίδης (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 In the 2014 ANNUAL REPORT on EU competition policy, the Commission states that more and closer cooperation with the European Parliament is needed in order to properly implement the Lisbon Treaty in the field of competition. This is also a requirement on our part so that there is transparency and real control of the executive. It is well known that the EU relies on an open economy and free competition. Abusive agreements between large companies should therefore be prohibited in order to avoid the accumulation of power and circumvention of legislation which creates unfair competition and adversely affects both the national and Community internal market. I also consider the paragraph referring to unfair and illegal clauses and practices used by the banking sector in consumer contracts to be an important reference to Cyprus. The Commission is invited to examine the matter in detail. However, I disagree with the references to a common consolidated corporate tax base which inevitably aim to bring down the corporate tax rate of the Member States and deconstruct the competitive advantage, especially in small island and remote Member States. That is why I voted against the relevant amendments.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. The report advocates more parliamentary participation. I believe that this democratic participation is essential. However, the report also advocates stronger control mechanisms at EU level, leading to further centralisation and disempowerment of nation states, as proposed. I therefore abstain from voting.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. In his letter of mission to head the European Commission, Jean-Claude Juncker stated that competition policy "will contribute, (...)  to the success of our growth and employment agenda, including in areas such as ... financial services and the fight against tax evasion." Also, the 2014 EU competition policy report focuses on "unfair tax practices" in relation to the Luxleaks case. But it merely enumerates the proposals already made by the Special Tax Committee, while calling for the establishment of a commission of inquiry which has already been refused to us. The report notes that "in the single market, products that do not have the same composition from batch to batch are distributed to consumers while the brand and packaging are identical" and is concerned about the possible "negative consequences for SMEs" but not for consumers! For "competition" remains an objective in itself for the rapporteur, who also states that the large Trans-Atlantic Market should "contain an important chapter in competition". I am voting against this text. In the worst case, at the worst possible time, he repeats the recitation of the liberal mantras that are the cause of widespread fraud.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. This report raises a number of important issues such as social dumping, the digital economy, social cohesion, public procurement, telecommunications, unfair and illicit practices used by the banking sector.  In addition, there is a demand that fines rules that would have a real deterrent impact in anti-competitive cartels and practices be incorporated into a legislative instrument. With regard to state aid to the banking system, it should no longer exist after the establishment of the banking union and should be linked to conditions for granting credit to SMEs. MEPs call for the creation of a legislative framework for the European Union to prevent distortions of competition through aggressive tax planning and tax evasion. While some observations are correct, this report is in line with the creation of the single market, which is at the root of the rampage of our industry. So I abstained.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Competition regulation is fundamental to the proper functioning of markets. Perfect competition carries in itself the seed of its own destruction, so it is essential that markets are regulated and that, at the invisible hand of the market, the visible hand of the State arises, regulating behaviour, avoiding coalitions and concertations, as well as abuses of a dominant position. The EU Annual Report on Competition Policy is a key tool for analysing the state and development of a central policy in defining the smooth functioning of markets and economic prosperity.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I could not support this report as despite having a number of positive points, it calls for the creation of a common consolidated corporate tax base. This would inevitably mean that it is our Union’s smaller economies that will be forced to bear the disproportionate brunt of the policies. In effect it will see smaller efficient economies like ours end up subsidising larger less efficient ones.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. An effective and credible competition policy must enable the European Union to revitalise its economy. It is not just a matter of focusing this policy on lowering consumer prices. We also need to pay particular attention to the strategic interests of our economy. The ability to innovate, investment, competitiveness and sustainability must be pillars of our competition policy.  For this to happen, the European Union must strengthen its fight against social dumping, develop the digital economy, complete the internal market and ensure a fairer and more transparent financial sector, notably by combating tax evasion.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: in writing – Small and medium-sized enterprises form the basic structure of each state's economy. Despite the fact that large enterprises provide a lot of jobs and produce more resources, it is small and medium-sized enterprises that keep the economy of the state afloat. It is common knowledge that these enterprises find it more difficult to cope with the onslaught of administration, the change in legislation and the ordinary business life, because it is often a type of family business, often without the possibility of employing extra qualified reinforcements. It is common practice for large enterprises to benefit from tax credits in the area of taxation, making it even more difficult for small entrepreneurs who do not have tax reliefs. With regard to these businesses and the economy of the Member States, it is essential that the European Parliament is also involved in resolving this situation by codecision.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the Annual Report on EU Competition Policy that allows the EP to make political statements on issues related to competition.  However, I have my strong reservations and voted against all paragraphs on CCCTB. A move towards an EU-wide basis to introduce tax convergence and harmonisation in direct tax matters, imposing a one-size-fits all approach, could put small Member States such as Malta into a disadvantaged position.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 EU competition policy is a cornerstone of the European social market economy and an essential tool not only for the functioning internal market of the Union, but also for preserving European democracy, in so far as it prevents economic and financial power from being concentrated in the hands of the few. The Report of the Economic Committee in this area states that the Commission's tasks will in future include consistent review and preventive control of prohibited State aid which distorts competition through undertakings and the lower units of certain Member States or those Member States. The Commission's report points out that the Commission has previously focused more on uncertainty in the digital economy, both on the question of where there is a dominant position and abusive behaviour and on the control of mergers, and notes that the Commission should focus more on the company's current business model when assessing competition and not on a few factors which are not representative of actual market power. A further problem is the monitoring of Member States in state aid procedures. Finally, it concludes that the Commission and the competition authority are the strongest authorities in Europe capable of achieving competition in the internal market. It proposes to supplement the billions in fines imposed for illicit price fixing in the future with penalties for responsible managers and managers in order to prevent these behaviours more effectively. I supported the adoption of this report.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. This report reminds the Commission of the importance of competition policy while calling for it not to be a hindrance to business competitiveness and that the aim should not only be price reduction but also the defence of the EU's strategic interests. The report therefore talks about social dumping, the digital economy, social cohesion, public procurement, telecommunications, and unfair and illicit practices used by the banking sector. Unfair tax competition between states is also a point raised in the report which calls for the creation of a legislative framework for the EU to prevent aggressive tax planning and tax evasion. It recommends the introduction of a mandatory and automatic exchange of tax information, a common consolidated corporate tax base (ACCIS) and a guarantee that no profit will leave the EU without being taxed. Finally, the report believes that Parliament should also have the power to co-decision on competition policy issues. But, despite fair observations and some interesting recommendations, this report is in the direction of the creation of the Single Market, the result of which is the ransacking of our industry.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU) provides, in Articles 101 to 109, binding rules for competition in the common internal market, based on an open economy with free competition. I am voting in favour of this report, arguing that there must be free competition between undertakings and that Member States should only confine themselves to the role of regulator and supervise whether there is a dominant position. The European Union also needs to support more creded all those entrepreneurs who want to start new businesses, especially those associated with the Digital Economy, because they have ample opportunities for job creation and wealth creation. Finally, it is extremely important that social aid for the transport of residents of peripheral regions has been taken into account in the General Block Exemption Regulation (GBER), which now recognises the connectivity problem. The connectivity of peripheral island regions is also essential to maintain and develop acceptable levels of economic and social initiative by maintaining essential business links.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This Langen report on EU competition policy welcomes the European Commission's report on the value of competition policy, while adding to some caveats that are not original and which are always in the direction of a deepening of the single market. The rapporteur therefore regrets that the EU's only target is lower prices (which lead to deflation, lower yields and therefore low investment) at the expense of the 'eu's strategic interests' (chimera when we see that the major European groups prefer to ally themselves with Japanese or American companies rather than European ones and so much the interests of the EU countries are divergent since they are directly competing). If it makes the fight against tax evasion a priority, the report favours the same European solutions (such as ACCIS, a real sea snake...). Because it is a fundamentally European text, and I want to complete the construction of the single market, I have decided to vote against it.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the Annual Report on Competition Policy because it is through a strong European competition policy that we are able to ensure that our consumers are getting the best possible deal, and that our small and local businesses are competing on a level playing field.  Being part of a market with 500 million consumers is one of the biggest benefits we get from being in the EU, and by developing and enforcing strong rules for fair competition we ensure more innovation, more opportunity, and ultimately a better deal for British citizens and consumers.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this annual report on the EU's competition policy. Some of the measures in this text call for a strengthening of the fight against social dumping, which I believe is essential. I also approved the provisions on competition issues in perishable commodity markets. The aim is to protect European farmers and consumers from potential abuses by certain distributors, particularly in the dairy sector.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 EU competition policy aims to encourage fair competition between all companies within the internal market, while pursuing the maintenance of a high level of social protection and well-being and the improvement of working conditions. For this reason, we welcome the adoption of this report. We are convinced of the need to prohibit any agreement or agreement which is restrictive of competition and which may affect trade between Member States or lead to the abuse of a dominant position. Effective competition is not an end in itself, but a condition for the creation of a free and dynamic internal market. We agree with Mr Juncker's statement that competition policy will contribute, where necessary, to the employment and growth programme, including in areas such as the digital market, energy policy, financial services, industrial policy and the fight against tax evasion. Unfortunately, we cannot fail to note that, until now, Parliament has been involved in competition law solely through the consultation procedure, with unfortunately limited influence, compared with that of the Commission and the Council. We therefore call for the introduction of the ordinary legislative procedure provided for in the Treaty of Lisbon for competition law as well.

name: Renaud Muselier (PPE)
text: In writing. The annual report on EU competition policy follows Parliament's support for Competition Commissioner Margrethe Vestager. I voted in favour of the report, recalling the roadmap presented to the Commission for the success of the growth and employment programme.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of Mr Langen's report to ensure that EU competition policy plays its primary role in the implementation of the market economy and competition in Europe. The 2014 Competition Policy Report indicates that the Commission and the Competition Authority are the European authority with the most powers to implement competition in the internal market. Fines of several billion euros imposed for illegal price agreements will in future have to be effectively supplemented by sanctions against responsible managers and managers, in order to prevent this behaviour more effectively.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the adoption of this report, knowing that competition in a well-functioning market economy is the main guarantee of long-term development. Since the beginning of the economic crisis, the European Commission has taken a number of measures that went against the principle of free competition, taking into account the social needs of citizens, I mean the high level of support for the banking sector in the years of the crisis. I do not want to take away the legitimacy of these steps, but I urge that, in the current growing economic environment, we give as much space as possible to competition in the market, thereby ensuring the sustainable development of the EU in all market segments.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. – I have voted for this report that reiterates EU competition law in order to create fair competition among the Member States and to ensure a cohesive and transparent internal market within the European Union.

name: Dan Nica (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for the annual report on EU competition policy because EU competition policy contributes to achieving the objectives of the jobs and growth agenda, including in areas such as the Digital Single Market, energy policy and industrial policy.  We call on the Commission to support all initiatives on the development of e-government. Promoting and introducing eGovernment systems in all Member States are essential for effective monitoring of infringements and for ensuring transparency in the public and private sectors. Competition in the telecommunications sector is essential not only for stimulating innovation and investment in networks, but also for affordable prices and consumer service options. The Commission must therefore ensure competition in this sector, including by allocating frequency bands. At the same time, strong interaction between the application of competition rules and the internal energy market is needed in order to remove barriers to the free movement of energy across borders and build the energy union.

name: Андрей Новаков (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the draft resolution believing that competition policy could thus contribute to the achievement of the objectives of the Jobs and Growth Agenda. The report stresses that an effective and credible competition policy must not only focus on reducing prices for consumers, but must also take into account the strategic interests of the European economy: the ability to innovate; investments; competitiveness and sustainability; conditions of competition for SMEs and start-ups and micro-enterprises.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of this report because it addresses meaningful objectives such as growth and employment. It also addresses the fight against tax evasion and a consistent review and monitoring of illicit state aid, which distorts competition among Member States. In 2014, it is shown that the Commission and the Competition Authority were very successful and fined billions of euros for illegal price fixing.

name: Younous Omarjee (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. I voted against this report which, in commenting on the Commission's annual report on competition law, makes opening up to competition a real engine of the social market economy, enabling social and economic cohesion to be achieved.  While I recognise the importance of competition rules in preventing the biggest economic operators from abusing their dominant position and agreeing on prices, I am opposed to this vision of opening up all sectors to competition the pillar of European integration.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. Among other things, I consider it important that the report deals with the creation of a digital single market and the need for certain rules to be agreed and strongly supports the development of e-government. As regards State aid, it has been pointed out that more room for manoeuvre should be given to remote and outermost regions in the application of State aid rules than is currently the case. It could have been applied in the case of Estonia and Estonian Air in its own time.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ The European Parliament's Report on the EU's Competition Policy encourages the harmonisation of taxation across the EU – for this reason, and to defend tax sovereignty, UKIP voted against the Report.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The most recent events have shown that companies are trying to limit competition. In this regard, I would like to point out that the EU's competition rules are designed to ensure fair and fair conditions, while leaving room for innovation and promoting uniform standards and development, particularly for small businesses. I am voting in favour of a fair policy on the part of all companies.

name: Eva Paunova (PPE)
text: in writing. – The heart of the European economy has long been faith in the value of competition. It fosters a healthy environment for business in Europe where companies can generate economic growth, create jobs, and invest in the future. Competition is also good for consumers for the simple reason that it compels producers to offer better deals. Moreover, putting the focus of the report on the digital economy shows how important it is for the future of the EU. The digital industries are among the most promising growth sectors for the EU. This is why it is so crucial that the implementation of EU competition rules in these markets is robust and effective, and I voted in favour of the report.

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I support the report and I consider of key importance that the European Parliament participates from a legislative position in the policy-making process for enhanced EU competition, in view of the needed scrutiny over important topics such as excessive state aid in the banking system or oversight of excessively big or over-dominant market players, in the best possible interest of the citizens and the taxpayers.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I support this report because it speaks openly about the EU competition policy implemented in 2014. This year was very challenging, elections were held for the new European Parliament and a new Commission was appointed. Commission President Juncker presented the work plan and guidelines of the new Commission. The Competition Commissioner pledged that competition policy would contribute to increasing jobs especially in areas such as access to the digital labour market, energy policy, financial services, industrial policy and the fight against tax non-payment.  Indeed, competition policy successfully covered all these areas in 2014. The stimulation of innovation is supported and equal rights are ensured for all companies, be they small, medium or large. Also, the revised state aid rules provide targeted support for specific areas, such as infrastructure investments to reduce the burden on transmission systems and renewables. At the end of 2014, in November the Commission announced the creation of a European Fund for Strategic Investment (EFSI), with a view to increasing investment in the European Union, worth €315 billion.   I hope that the 2015 report will also show positive and successful results, and it is up to us all to make this year even better.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. Despite fair observations and some interesting recommendations, this report is in line with the creation of the Single Market, the result of which is the rampage of our industry by competing with very different economies. So I decided to vote against it.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ Competition policy is an important instrument of eu internal market action that should prevent excessive concentration of economic and financial power for the benefit of a small number of individuals, and aim to increase the living standards of all EU citizens. The fact that annual losses due to the existence of cartels are between €181 billion and €320 billion, representing around 3% of the EU's GDP, is the best call for an immediate upgrade of the existing legal framework for the implementation of competition policy in the EU. In doing so, a particularly sensitive part is the issue of State aid. They must not be used illegally, anti-competitive and protectionist. However, as regards State aid to peripheral regions and islands, flexibility should be increased, which is properly emphasised in amendments 44-48. I welcome the decision to include social assistance for the transport of residents living in remote regions in the General Block Exemption Regulation, which recognises the problem of connectivity. I hope that the same principle will apply in Croatia where the pilot project of the emergency helicopter medical service has recently ceased operations. State aid verification should be based on the understanding that in strategic and vital sectors such as energy, transport and health, states must be able to guarantee full security, continuous supply and provision of these services to all their citizens.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I support the proposal for a Resolution on the ANNUAL REPORT on EU competition policy by my colleague Werner Langen. Competition policy is one of the European Union's main instruments for achieving a common internal market. While it is clear that abuse of a dominant position is prohibited and poses a serious problem in competition, problems still exist. Annual losses due to the existence of cartels (monopoly mergers) are between €181 billion and €320 billion, representing around 3% of the Union's GDP. Therefore, we must limit unfair market practices as a result of monopolies and dominant market position so that each individual has a fair chance of achieving success.  Furthermore, in terms of energy costs, the Single European Market is less successful than the US internal market, with a price dispersion of 31% versus 22% in the US. Also, in many Member States, the serious credit crisis continues to affect SMEs, which represent 98% of EU businesses and 67% of all employees. Redefining competition policy will result in a more transparent and competitive single market that is crucial for growth and real recovery. In my view, competition policy, guaranteeing a level playing field for all market stakeholders, is an important tool for protecting the rights and benefits of consumers, citizens, businesses, in particular SMEs, and workers within the social market economy.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEI) lays down, in Articles 101 to 109, binding rules on competition in the internal market. The basic objective of the competition rules is to ensure that there is no distortion for the creation of a free and dynamic internal market. To date, the European Parliament has been involved in the formulation of competition legislation exclusively through the consultation procedure. Unfortunately, therefore, its influence is limited compared with that exercised by the Commission and the Council. I voted in favour of this report and believe that, in future, more attention should be paid to illegal state aid and unfair tax competition between Member States, practices that cause considerable distortions of the EU's internal market. In particular, I would like to point out that it says in the text that fines of several billion euros imposed for illegal price agreements must be effectively supplemented by sanctions against responsible managers and managers of companies, in order to prevent this behaviour more effectively.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I welcome the fact that the majority of my colleagues voted in favour of this annual report. European Union competition policy is one of the key areas in which the Institutions of the European Union can play a positive role in promoting economic growth. I consider it important for the European Union to create a fair and effective legal framework that oversees consumer protection, a transparent and clear system of financial assistance and taxes. Although I express some doubts about the wording of paragraph 89 on distortions of competition, tax evasion and the automatic exchange of information on tax evasion, I believe that, overall, this report will help create a healthy and fair competitive environment and reduce unemployment.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The report was intended to address competition policy, but it largely deals with taxation. That is why I could not support the report. It repeats many of the recommendations contained in the TAXE report. For example, it calls for a common consolidated corporate tax base, public country-by-country reporting for MNMs, access by the Commission to data exchanged by Member States' tax authorities, the Commission's submission of legislative proposals going beyond the OECD/G20 proposals on BEPS and the establishment by the European Parliament of a committee of inquiry to further investigate harmful tax practices (as opposed to TAXE 2, which remains a special committee rather than a committee of inquiry).  The report mentions the completion of the Banking Union (i.e. the third pillar, the European Deposit Insurance Scheme) and even the increase in the EU's own resources by transferring recovered illegal State aid to the EU budget.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report because I am convinced that competition policy is a key issue for the European Union. But it must be a means to our growth, not a brake. That is why I support the tools to combat social dumping in particular and all the solutions that enable our companies to take full advantage of the opportunities offered by external markets, on an equal footing.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ The European Parliament’s report on the EU’s Competition Policy encourages the harmonisation of taxation across the EU – for this reason, and to defend tax sovereignty, UKIP voted against the report.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. I welcome the Commission's report, which underlines the importance of putting an end to social dumping. EU competition policy, with different impacts on the different Member States, is a cornerstone of europe's social market economy and is a crucial tool for ensuring the smooth functioning of the Union's internal market.  This vote in favour is nothing more than a way to benefit workers and entrepreneurs by promoting innovation, and to increase the prosperity of consumers and, consequently, the living standards of all EU citizens. Furthermore, with this vote, I also want to promote social cohesion and sustainable development on the basis of price stability and balanced economic growth.

name: Robert Rochefort (ALDE)
text: In writing. Free, fair competition that allows the emergence of European economic champions is one of the prerequisites for the proper functioning of the internal market and consumer protection. That is why I have supported this text, in which we are reacting to the Commission's annual report on competition policy in 2014. Our resolution makes proposals in various areas such as antitrust procedures, state aid, merger control, particularly in the digital economy, financial aid and taxes, competition at the global level and the democratic strengthening of European competition policy.  In particular, I would like to stress our request that the amounts recovered as a result of a breach of EU rules on state aid of a tax nature be returned to the Member States which have been subjected to the illegal practice, and not to the Member State which has granted irregular tax aid. This seems to me to be absolutely necessary and justified. I would also like to welcome Commissioner Vestager's courageous policy and the various actions under her authority, the results of which we expect.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament participates in competition legislation only through the consultation procedure. Its influence is reduced compared to that of the Commission and the Council. This report argues that financial penalties of billions of euros imposed as a result of price-fixing agreements should be effectively supplemented by sanctions on business managers and managers in order to avoid such behaviour. We hope that EU competition policy will cement and develop the market economy in Europe and not evolve towards a policy of sectoral and national exceptions and uncontrollable exemptions. An effective and credible competition policy must take into account strategic interests of the European economy, such as: the ability to innovate; investment; competitiveness and sustainability; the special conditions of competition for SMEs, emerging enterprises and micro-enterprises and the promotion of high social and environmental standards. It is also important that the Commission put an end to social dumping and take into account the social impact of competition policies in the most remote or isolated regions.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report on competition policy as key objectives have been achieved for the Socialist and Democratic Group, such as asking the Commission for a more belligerent position against social dumping in the labour market (paragraph 5), for services of general economic interest to be excluded from competition rules (paragraph 46) , addressing the problem of fragmentation of the EU digital market (paragraphs 55-59 and 79), for the Commission to maintain a priority approach to tax evasion or illegal corporate tax practices (paragraphs 62, 68-89) and, finally, for Parliament to be able to co-decide in the latter field (paragraph 110).  Useful references have also been made in the report to the need to incorporate flexibility in compliance with competition rules for the outermost and island regions. Also included in the report, on the proposal of my colleagues Jonás Fernández and Ramón Jáuregui, a reference to the need to regulate ATM commissions because it is the price of a service whose market value is difficult to fix, which is very relevant for Spain at the moment.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. The European Parliament would like states that grant illegal state aid through tax benefits to companies not to recover such aid when the Commission decides that there should be recovery. And that these sums that companies must make should go directly to the EU budget. This is one of the recommendations included in a report on competition policy, adopted yesterday 19 January in plenary session. The text of the report also addresses the 'Google' case and calls on the Commission to investigate why the US giant offers the 'Android' mobile operating system only in conjunction with other Google services and why manufacturers would not be allowed to pre-install competing products. The report also asks the Commission to examine Google's dominant market position in the hotel booking sectors.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I congratulate the Commission on its excellent work on this review of the supervision of competition policy. At the same time, I would like to draw attention to one important topic that is not there, but I very much hope that it will emerge next year. This is an assessment of the situation in the primary food sector in the European Union. I think it is no secret to anyone that there is a critical situation in the milk, pigmeat and some other food sectors in the European Union. Farmers and other primary producers suffer greatly from external declines in demand. Nevertheless, there are, of course, many cases where processors and traders are exploiting this situation and abusing their dominant market position by lowering buying-in prices.  This is a ruin in the village of the European Union. I very much hope that from 2016 In the competition policy report, we will be able to find out how the Commission has dealt with numerous infringements of competition, how it defended fair competition in the agricultural sector and how it penalised those who abused their dominant position.

name: Virginie Rozière (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted for Werner Langen's report. While competition policy is marked by renewed dynamism, thanks to Commissioner Vestager's voluntarism, the European Parliament supports this movement in this report. In particular, it focuses on new issues related to the digital economy and considers it essential, and in the interests of consumers, that a level playing field is guaranteed in this new context.  The objective of this report is clearly the fight against tax optimisation. It welcomes the commission's 2014 investigations into illegal state aid, which is part of unfair tax competition, for the benefit of certain companies. It expresses concern about the difference between the strict European competition rules and those of some other, less protective countries. Finally, it reminds us that large international companies must make a fair and equitable contribution to the public finances of member states.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report shows that the Commission, along with the competition authority, is currently decisive in making competition prevail in the internal market. For this reason, I support the proposal in the report on extending the applicability of financial penalties to business managers and managers when we are dealing with price-fixing agreements in order to more effectively avoid such behaviour.  Thus, with a view to cementing and developing, at international level, the fundamental role played by EU competition policy, it is intended to be possible from now on to make the market economy and competition prevail in Europe, so as to avoid moving towards a policy of sectoral and national exceptions or uncontrollable exemptions.  In agreement with the proposals in this report, I have given my vote in favour.

name: Pirkko Ruohonen-Lerner (ECR)
text: Written. \u2012 Fair competition is the basis of the EU's common market. Ladies and gentlemen, this foundation is wobbly. When a local small business owner fights to meet taxes and remain profitable, what does an international big business do? Transfer his winnings to Luxembourg. Tax planning is a euphemission used by accountants for this theft, which distorts competition and puts companies in an unequal position. The facts must be acknowledged. Market integration in the EU has made it too easy for large international companies to transfer profits. $1,000 billion. Such an amount of corporation tax is not collected annually within the EU. This much of our common money disappears completely legally and completely immorally. This has to stop. Companies headquartered in tax havens should be excluded from public tendering. I see no reason to give major works, telecommunications projects or, for example, care services for the elderly to companies that record their profits in tax havens and losses in high-tax Member States. That is why I am in favour of an EU comprehensive business register, which tells the Member State where the company pays its taxes. It is worth remembering that without common rules of the game and transparency that guarantee fair competition, our tax base will erode. The money for the services provided by society will then have to be taken from the earnings of low- and middle-income wage earners. It is short-sighted and wrong policy. For these reasons, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which provides an annual assessment of the implementation of the Union's competition policy within the Member States. The primary objective of an effective competition policy is to enable economic growth. Indeed, the only objective of European competition policy is the benefits that consumers derive from lower prices; it must be based on innovation, competitiveness and investment.  I supported this text which calls on the Commission to put an end to social dumping practices within the Union and calls for competition policy to take into account its social consequences, particularly in the most isolated and disadvantaged regions.  In addition to the fight against social dumping, the European Union must embark on the path of a digital single market, complete the harmonisation of its internal market and continue integration within the Member States, particularly in the financial sector.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour because the report emphasises cooperation between Parliament and the Commission, but at the same time proposes points to improve the single market in Europe. For example, it is urgently necessary to respond to the challenges of digitization by adapting the competition rules to new business models.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I abstained in the vote on the annual report on the European Parliament's competition policy. It maintains a globally neoliberal vision of competition policy, focused on the single market and with little specific reference to the different economic sectors. While it devotes enough space to the issue of taxes, it does not propose any coercive measures to combat tax evasion or avoidance. Some amendments tabled by my group were, however, included, such as those relating to abuses in food distribution or down-down social competition. I think the report is not very negative, but we still do not share the overall approach.

name: Alfred Sant (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have abstained on the roll-call votes ‘Subject of the Amendment’ 76 third part, ‘Subject of the Amendment’ 81 second part, and ‘Subject of the Amendment’ 89. I did so because I was a shadow rapporteur for the Annual Report on EU Competition Policy. Otherwise I would have voted against.

name: Sven Schulze (PPE)
text: Writing. The role of the European Parliament in EU competition policy must finally be improved! We also want to become co-legislators in this policy area – even if we have to change the Treaties for this! It is not acceptable for us to consult in all relevant policy areas, but still not in competition policy – a core area of the EU. Make sure that the EU becomes more democratic here. I will do the same. For me, the key issue in this report is tax avoidance: member states are called upon to work more closely with the Commission and Parliament and to provide the necessary information. Speaking of tax avoidance, this includes a single corporate tax base and a review of the VAT Directive. This will enable us to effectively avoid abuse and tax dumping. And one more thing: in the digital world, we are dealing with a massive concentration of market power. How can it be that the Commission approved Facebook's acquisition of WhatsApp without conditions? We can only properly assess such mergers if we develop models to assess the real market power of companies. Commissioner Verstager is called upon to develop a viable solution as soon as possible.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I have not been able to vote in favour of this report because, despite containing very positive aspects, it continues to develop the neoliberal conception of the economy that perceives the market as the main agent of the European economy. This report has included numerous amendments tabled by my group and more aspects of central importance to the European economy: from supporting decisions to sanction tax-evading multinationals, to the crisis that has arisen in order to milk quotas or the investigation of the connections between certain former governors and large power companies. However, it is not recognized that services of general economic interest must be provided by the State, the internationalisation of public procurement and the European economy as a whole is called in clear reference to TTE. That is why, despite the important positive aspects, I have not been able to vote in favour of this report.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this policy as it expands the Commission’s protectionist policies into our market.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report on the Commission’s Annual Report on Competition Policy in the EU because in order to get the best possible deal for our consumers we need a robust and dynamic competition policy which will ensure that our small and local businesses are competing on a level playing-field with the larger businesses. Being part of the world’s largest single market, at over half a billion consumers, is one of the largest benefits that we get from being in the European Union. This is great for businesses and consumers in the West Midlands, and I am glad to come to the European Parliament to ensure citizens’ voices are being heard when it comes to the evaluation and formation of EU legislation.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ Competition marks the economic structure of the European Union, presenting itself as a powerful actor on the international stage. It is distinguished by ensuring fair competition for many companies by providing consumers with more choice and better quality of products at lower prices.  Unfortunately, there are also actors who do not follow these rules. It is therefore important to take effective measures against such forms of action that seriously distort fair competition such as abuse of a dominant position, cartel action, granting unjustified State aid to one or a small number of undertakings by bringing them to the advantage, etc. Greater scrutiny is needed in all segments, in particular in the implementation of trade agreements, mergers of companies, ways of taxation and tax rulings of the Member States, and precisely enhanced control of areas of vital and strategic sectors such as energy, health and transport would prevent any possibility of ceasing supply and provision of services to citizens across the European Union. I would like to highlight the creation of a new Tax Decision Board (TAXE) that will provide insight into transparency in member states' taxation methods, just one year after the LuxLeaks affair, indicating developments.
