I expressly support the overall efforts to combat unfair and opaque behaviour to the detriment of others, and for these reasons I supported Parliament's resolution, stressing the importance of available and sustainable energy and security of supply under transparent trade agreements.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ I supported the resolution because I consider EU competition policy to be a key instrument of the Union and one of the fundamental pillars of the social market economy in Europe. Although the fundamental objective of the competition rules in the Union is to protect competition from distortions, we are still seeing serious distortions of competition in many Member States. It is important for the Commission to examine in depth the existing instruments for competition and, in the light of the new challenges, to create conditions that will continue to be able to provide an environment that supports business and the development of SMEs that drive growth and employment in the coming periods. I also believe that competition policy must play an even greater role in ensuring that financial markets are safer and more transparent for consumers. I also consider it extremely important to apply EU competition rules more quickly and effectively, which can prevent the current fragmentation and help remove many barriers to market access.

name: Renato Soru (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the annual report on EU competition policy in which Parliament examines what the Commission is doing or intends to do in order to promote healthy and free competition between businesses, in accordance with the rules and for the benefit of consumers. The critical issues highlighted in the European Parliament's report are manifold and concern several sectors, among which the digital economy and the financial sector seem to me to be crucial. The giants operating in the digital economy have traditionally been under the lens of the Commission, because of the danger that their size pose to free competition and by virtue of commercial practices that are not always transparent. In this respect, Parliament has expressed its agreement with the Commission and has called on it to speed up the investigation of possible liability. With regard to competition in the financial sector, I wanted to highlight with my colleagues the need to apply uniformly in the Member States the European legislation supporting banking systems through public resources, which various countries used during the years of the financial crisis, and the elimination of disparities for those who now wish to use them.

name: Joachim Starbatty (ECR)
text: Writing. The European Parliament's annual competition report identifies and assesses European competition policy issues and the work of the Commission last year. The 2015 Annual Report identified a number of key challenges. For example, the calls for greater transparency in tax competition through the introduction of a common corporate tax base makes sense and deserves support. However, there are also a number of problematic demands in the report. ALFA does not support the call for a European Deposit Guarantee as the third pillar of the Banking Union. I also think it is fundamentally wrong to give the European Parliament a greater say in competition policy. It is essential for an effective competition policy that it can act independently of politics. The independence of competition authorities must be strengthened and freed from political influence. I was therefore unable to vote in favour of the report in this form.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: in writing \ u2012 Competition policy is one of the most important instruments of the Common Market of the European Union. Based on the evaluation of the annual report, EU competition policy also needs to adapt to the new conditions and challenges in the internal market. It is essential that EU competition policy take into account the specificities of certain sectors and focus on creating the conditions in the Digital Single Market. The current competition policy should also aim at developing eGovernment and adopting new public procurement rules for the development of e-Government. It is also necessary to review the rules on state aid assessment, merger control and streamlining the antitrust proceedings under way.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ EU competition policy is the cornerstone of europe's social market economy and an important instrument of the Union's effective internal market. The European Union was founded as an open social market economy with free competition aimed at increasing consumer welfare and living standards for all EU citizens, and as the European Union establishes an internal market organised to lead to the sustainable development of Europe based on balanced economic growth and price stability.  Effective and credible competition policy must not only focus on lowering consumer prices, but must also benefit the strategic interests of the European economy such as: innovation, investment, competition and sustainability, specific competition conditions in which SMEs and start-ups operate, and microenterests, and the promotion of labour and environmental standards. I believe it is essential that the Commission continues to promote stronger convergence and cooperation between national competition authorities in the EU, and I support the report.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the Annual Report on Competition Policy because it is through a strong European competition policy that we are able to ensure that our consumers are getting the best possible deal, and that our small and local businesses are competing on a level playing field.  Being part of a market with 500 million consumers is one of the biggest benefits we get from being in the EU, and by developing and enforcing strong rules for fair competition we ensure more innovation, more opportunity, and ultimately a better deal for British citizens and consumers.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The European Union's Annual Competitiveness Policy Report contains all the essential elements. Progress is visible from previous periods, the situation has been analysed and progress in the process of creating the Banking Union is visible.  The report underlines the need to step up efforts to achieve adequate competition in isolated and peripheral parts of the Union. It also suggests a review of the current legal framework during the development of the digital economy, as existing legislation has some limitations on why it needs to be modernisation. It is important to ensure absolute non-discrimination of businesses in the digital economy, which has so far often been in favour of global co-ordas.  I support the EU's annual competitiveness policy report.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the annual report on EU competition policy.  A well-functioning EU competition policy is very important for a properly functioning Internal Market of the European Union. The greater the competitiveness, the greater the benefits of consumers: lower prices and better services.  There is open market competition in the European Union, so we should all strive for as competitive a market as possible, for as many competition between companies as possible, for as much competition as possible. All this has a profound impact on the well-being of citizens and on the rise of living standards.  Member States must also have adequate mechanisms and also provide sufficient financial support to these mechanisms to ensure that there is competition between companies on the free market to compete fairly with each other, without unfair advantages.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 The annual competition report records the economic situation in the EU every year and focuses on how it can become more competitive. Over time, the perception of the dominant circles and the majority of the European Parliament differs from our point of view. The forces of neoliberalism perceive competitiveness as lowering prices through downward wage pressure and lower social security taxes, and by extension social security and social benefits.  Although some of the GUE/NGL amendments on social dumping and pharmaceutical companies were introduced in the text of the report, we chose to vote against the text because, on the one hand, it promotes the common tax base (something we disagree with as Cypriots) and because it continues to promote the deregulation of the labour market because of EU competition policies.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 Although the report highlights the distortions of existing practices that hinder growth, destroy SMEs and promote tax evasion and unfair competition, it nevertheless avoids stressing the need to apply competition rules and proposing those rules and controls that will not destroy national - local markets (imposing the single market) but will instead force profitable multinational companies to contribute to the financing of Member States and promote entrepreneurship and transparency , in particular in enterprises for medicines, food, fuel, telecommunications services, etc.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the adoption of the annual report on EU competition policy. I think it is right that the report has sought the Commission's particular attention in relation to abuses of a dominant position at the expense of EU consumers. Furthermore, there is a legitimate expectation that unfair and unlawful clauses and practices used by the banking sector in consumer contracts will be subject to stricter controls. As, despite the work of the EP TAXE Committee and the European Commission so far, the tax avoidance and fraud practices of multinationals are still causing significant damage to EU taxpayers and small and medium-sized enterprises, it is of the utmost importance that, as requested by the report, the Commission continues to use all the instruments at its disposal, such as its powers under EU competition rules, in the fight against tax fraud. In this context, I also consider it important to request that Member States make public information on their tax provisions. Rightly, the report also emphasises, in the context of State aid, that in such cases the Commission must examine more intensively the evidence provided by the Member States, as there are regular attempts to circumvent legal barriers.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. –u2012 As the author of the opinion, under the authority of the Committee on International Trade, to the 2014 report on EU competition policy, I am very pleased that the document adopted by Parliament contains the provisions I have proposed calling for a significant deepening of international cooperation in order to effectively implement the principles of competition law. The ideal solution, of which I am an ardent supporter, would be to reach a multilateral agreement on competition within the World Trade Organisation. I hope this will be possible in the coming years.  As far as the European Union itself is concerned, I believe it is extremely important to monitor more closely the state of play of the implementation of increasingly ambitious international agreements concluded by the Community with third countries. We need to know whether the competition rules are being respected and whether the obligations made by the trading partners are actually fully fulfilled and enforced. What is also worth noting in the report adopted by Parliament is the provisions I have proposed on the need to equalise access to all resources, but with a clear emphasis on access to, transmission and transport of energy sources. In this day and age, access to energy is one of the important drivers of equality in the market.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Free and fair competition is one of the fundamental values of European construction, which was the basis for the realization of the huge economic potential of the Member States and the common market. Protecting it by the European institutions must therefore be one of our main objectives.  Unfortunately, the European Parliament does not yet have the necessary powers to decisively determine the existing situation. However, as direct representatives of European citizens, we can ask the Commission to respect certain principles. One of these is to avoid abuses of a dominant position, in order to allow all actors, large and small, to be present on the market through anti-trust policies. State aid can also adversely affect free competition, but in some cases it is necessary to avoid the collapse of certain areas of Member States using a workforce of considerable size. At the same time, the level of taxes can be an element of imbalance between Member States, so harmonising them at an optimal level is necessary.  All these provisions must focus on the interests of European citizens and ensuring their highest standard of living. Otherwise, competition for the sake of competition alone cannot generate a prosperous and balanced society.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the text and support the Commission's call for the Commission to step up its efforts to investigate cases of abuse of dominance to the detriment of consumers in the European Union.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which outlines the European Parliament’s main recommendations on how to improve EU competition policy and Member States’ corporate taxation practices. The increasing digitalisation of our economy requires new European rules on fair taxation and market dominance; this is one of our biggest challenges. I opposed all the provisions which involves the Google case and Google’s dominant position on the hotel reservation sector market.

name: Isabelle Thomas (S&D)
text: In writing. For too long, the European Union has been the idiot of the world village. We apply strict competition rules that none of our trading partners respect internationally, thereby weakening our businesses and jobs. I therefore welcome the adoption of this report, which for the first time marks an inflection of the dogmatism of 'all-competitive'. It acknowledges the necessary moderation of the competition rule for innovation and job protection. After investigations into Google's practices, he proposes measures to ensure that institutions in the digital economy can no longer fall through the cracks. It also echoes the European Parliament's proposals to combat tax dumping, which is a form of unfair competition. It calls for the creation of a common corporate tax base and mandatory reporting of tax agreements between states and multinationals.  Nevertheless, I regret that the right, by its vote against, has failed two amendments. One would have highlighted the anti-competitive risks of TAFTA, the other would have made it possible to punish multinationals for refusing to respond to the convening of Parliament's special committee on tax dumping.

name: Patrizia Toia (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 EU competition policy is one of the fundamental pillars of the social market economy in Europe and is an essential tool for the functioning of the Union's internal market. Mr Langen's report deals with some interesting aspects which need to be given the greatest attention. First of all, the issue of State aid, we must first of all reiterate the need for certain legislation that promotes growth and development, creating healthy competition between European companies and enabling them to play a leading role in international and globalised trade. I would also like to point out that in the digital age it is very essential to adopt common rules in order to quickly bridge the gap between countries. Finally, it is essential for the Commission to step up its efforts in investigating cases of abuse of dominant market positions to the detriment of EU consumers.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the report on the annual report on EU competition policy, as this sums up well the developments in this area in recent years and presents the fundamental challenges for the future.  In 2014, the Commission and the body (which, with around 1000 employees, is the most powerful office in Europe to enforce competition in the internal market) collected fines of several billion euros for price collusion, pointing to the still numerous illegal practices of ENTREPRENEURS in the EU.  Effective competition is not an end in itself, but a precondition for the realisation of the free and dynamic internal market we are ing for. In particular, in the age of digitisation, control of this area poses an additional challenge and requires the attention of the competent European institutions.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I abstained in the vote on the annual report on the European Parliament's competition policy. It maintains a globally neoliberal vision of competition policy, focused on the single market and with little specific reference to the different economic sectors. While it devotes enough space to the issue of taxes, it does not propose any coercive measures to combat tax evasion or avoidance. Some amendments tabled by my group were, however, included, such as those relating to abuses in food distribution or down-down social competition. I think the report is not very negative, but we still do not share the overall approach.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I very much welcome the Competition Report of this year and I hope that the Commission will listen to our views and take it into account. I am particularly pleased to see that Parliament is calling on the Commission to pay attention to those Member States where the board of big energy companies is filled by many ex-ministers and where there is suspicion of oligopolistic practices. On the other hand, regarding the Google case I welcome paragraphs 34, 35 and 36 of the Competition Report: the Google antitrust case has to move ahead more quickly, and the Commission should step up the pace to solve this case as soon as possible to reach a satisfactory solution.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. This report follows the 2014 annual report on EU competition policy. The report talks about social dumping, the digital economy, social cohesion, public procurement, telecommunications, and unfair and illicit practices used by the banking sector. Much of the report also deals with antitrust proceedings and cases of abuse of dominance. It is requested to incorporate into a legislative instrument rules on fines that would have a real deterrent impact in the event of anti-competitive cartels and practices. Unfair tax competition between states is also a point raised in the report, which welcomes the Commission's investigations. Despite fair observations and some interesting recommendations, this report is in line with the creation of the Single Market, the result of which is the ransacking of our industry by putting very different economies into competition. I choose abstention.

name: Mihai Ţurcanu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union's competition policy is a basic pillar for the proper functioning of the single market and the European economy. The need for free and fair competition in order to increase consumer prosperity and the standard of living of European citizens has emerged since the creation of the first European communities. Over time, this policy has become a means of protecting European democracy, as it prevents the excessive concentration of economic and financial power in the hands of a few actors.  The annual report on the European Union's competition policy underlines the need for stronger action by the Commission in certain areas. It is therefore necessary to ensure a level playing field in the digital market and to combat abuses of dominance and tax optimisation, which ultimately benefits consumers. Furthermore, the Commission should ensure better convergence and cooperation between EU national authorities in this area. A strengthened competition policy can also play an important role in the effort to make financial markets safer and more transparent for consumers. I therefore voted in favour of the annual report on EU competition policy.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TMS) contains mandatory rules on competition in the common internal market, based on an open economy based on free competition, in Articles 101 to 109. Overall, the 2014 Competition Report shows that the Commission and the competition authority with around 1 000 employees are the strongest authorities capable of achieving competition in the internal market in Europe. Billions in fines for illicit price fixing should in future be effectively supplemented by penalties for responsible managers and managers in order to prevent these behaviours more effectively. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ All in all, the report is of good quality. Although it contains few problematic elements, many green amendments were integrated. On that basis, I voted in favour.

name: Inese Vaidere (PPE)
text: Writing. – Each year, the existence of cartels leads to losses amounting to EUR 181-320 billion, i.e. around 3% of the European Union's GDP. Tax evasion, tax fraud and tax havens, in the form of uncoated revenues cost EU taxpayers around EUR 1 trillion a year in the form of uncoated revenue.  I believe that every effort must be made to put an end to the distortion of competition between tax-paying and non-taxing companies. Similarly, anti-competitive national tax models, which create unequal competition, both between large multinationals and SMEs, and between Member States where such tax models are not applied, are not permitted.  The implementation of a fair EU competition policy will not only help to tackle these problems, but will also increase consumer welfare and increase the standard of living of every citizen of the European Union.  I therefore hope that the resolution adopted today will help to establish a competition policy that will ensure the successful completion of a single European market in which the consumer, regardless of their place of residence, will be able to receive an equally high quality product or service without being overpaid because of unfair competition and unjustified market restrictions.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. This is a report addressing key points in EU competition policy, such as the need to withdraw aid to the financial sector during the crisis period, the need for competition policy decisions to take into account the social impact they cause in remote or isolated regions, the need to update rules on infringements , as well as the importance of competition policy acting on the digital economy, an expanding area in which abuses against European consumers must be prevented. That is why I think it is necessary to vote in favour of this report.

name: Marco Valli (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament presents its annual report analysing the state of competition policy in the EU. The report is generally to be welcomed. The text calls for progress, such as deepening the investigation into the Google case, supporting whistleblowers and introducing the CCCTB. However, the text misses the opportunity to go boldly further, calling for greater transparency and greater involvement of the European Parliament. The report lacks any ambition to amend the State aid law. It is not enough for the Commission to sanction multinationals, they must pay taxes in the countries where they carry out their activities. For these reasons, I abstained from voting.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I have not been able to vote in favour of this report because, despite containing very positive aspects, it continues to develop the neoliberal conception of the economy that perceives the market as the main agent of the European economy. This report has included numerous amendments tabled by my group and more aspects of central importance to the European economy: from supporting decisions to sanction tax-evading multinationals, to the crisis that has arisen in order to milk quotas or the investigation of the connections between certain former governors and large power companies. However, it is not recognized that services of general economic interest must be provided by the State, the internationalisation of public procurement and the European economy as a whole is called in clear reference to TTE. That is why, despite the important positive aspects, I have not been able to vote in favour of this report.

name: Derek Vaughan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I was happy to vote in favour of the Report on the Annual Report on Competition Policy because it is through a strong European competition policy that we are able to ensure that our consumers are getting the best possible deal, and that our small and local businesses are competing on a level playing field. This report is also sympathetic to national needs. To promote the development and competitiveness of European industry, it is vital that our industry is invested in and properly protected, as the recent news from TATA highlighted. The Single Market of over 500 million people is one of the greatest strengths of our Union, and by developing and enforcing strong rules for fair competition we ensure more innovation, more opportunities, and ultimately a better deal for British citizens and consumers.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. 'I voted in favour of this annual report on the European Union's competition policy, because through a strongly developed European competition policy we are able to ensure that European consumers always get the best price and quality. In addition, a strong European competition policy also ensures that our SMEs can compete in an equal market. By maintaining fair competition, we keep companies on their toes and create more innovation. This will ultimately only benefit europe's 500 million consumers.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. This annual report on competition policy is in line with European policies. Competition is valued as the "common ground of the European Union" and the main "engine of the social market economy".  The report calls for more openness to competition and more independence from regulatory authorities in this area.  The report was supposed to look at the consequences of competition in Member States' tax and agricultural policies. While there is recognition of the impact of the aggressive tax policies of some Member States or the consequences of free competition in the agricultural sector, particularly in the dairy sector, no lessons are learned.  While I welcome the adoption of two amendments tabled by my group to protect generic medicines and support dairy farmers, I have not been able to vote for this ode to free and undistorted competition.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. THE EU's competition policy is far from being an instrument for safeguarding European democracy. It does not prevent the excessive concentration of economic and financial power that remains in the hands of the few. The subjecting of public services and strategic sectors of the economy to EU competition policy and its single market has made life easier for large private economic groups wishing to take ownership of these services and sectors, making them subject to the logic of the incessant demand for maximum profit and minimum cost, which obviously has a negative impact on their users and consumers. , but also on the workers of these organizations. Under the false pretext of unfair competition or distortions of competition from this policy, directives and regulations whose sole purpose is to prevent public control of the strategic sectors of the economy and the promotion of universal, free and quality public services. We therefore reject any call on the European Commission to complete the single market in areas where it is supposedly fragmented and incomplete because we believe that the deepening of the single market accentuates the dismantling of sovereign regulation instruments for economies by feeding the dominance of large economic and financial groups.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. The report advocates more parliamentary participation. I believe that this democratic participation is essential. However, the report also advocates stronger control mechanisms at EU level, leading to further centralisation and disempowerment of nation states, as proposed. I therefore abstain from voting.

name: Daniele Viotti (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the annual report on competition policy in the European Union. I firmly believe that all companies operating in our market must be treated fairly. This must not, however, result in a simple reduction in prices, but must go hand in hand with high standards of social protection and working conditions.

name: Udo Voigt (NI)
text: Writing. It was appropriate to abstain because, while free competition on the basis of equal opportunities and red tape reduction is worthy of support, the dogmatic reduction of subsidies, as advocated in the report, penalises small and medium-sized enterprises and remote regions with weak infrastructure; their protection is not sufficiently taken into account in the report.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. I rejected the European Parliament's resolution on EU competition policy. The report calls for a Common Consolidated Corporate Tax Base, country-by-country reporting for multinationals and access for the Commission to data exchanged between Member States and Member States' tax authorities. The report also calls on the Commission to propose legislation that goes further than the OECD and G20 proposals on BEPS. I reject any EU tax competence. The report also aims to increase the involvement of the European Parliament in the field of competition policy by giving it codecision powers. This is a clear violation of the principle of subsidiarity and another reason why I voted against this report.

name: Iuliu Winkler (PPE)
text: in writing. – I voted for the own-initiative report on the annual report on EU competition policy. I welcome the concern that the rapporteur has shown towards the SME sector, criticising the tax models which have the effect of distorting competition, creating, in particular, considerable problems for medium-sized enterprises. In the report, the Commission is invited to ensure that Member States implement new public procurement legislation, as well as new provisions on taking social and environmental criteria into account and the division of contracts into lots, in order to stimulate innovation and fair competition and to support SMEs in public procurement markets, ensuring the best value for money in the use of public funds.

name: Θεόδωρος Ζαγοράκης (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of Mr Langen's report of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs on competition policy in the EU. The annual report examines, by sector, the main axes of interest in anti-monopoly procedures, State aid, financial taxation and financial aid, as well as merger control.

name: Marco Zanni (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 As every year, the European Parliament presents an own-initiative report analysing competition aspects in the EU. There are many ideas in the text that we broadly support to prevent excessive market concentration, abuse of a dominant position and cartels. Of particular importance is the reference to the Google case and other internet platforms. A number of references are also made to the necessary competition policies in the financial markets; the parties related to whistleblower policy, CCCTB, BEPS and the work of the TAXE committee and the reference to the Luxleaks case and the need to start country by country reporting as soon as possible are also interesting and worthy of support. However, there is too much complacency in the text about the work done so far by the Commission, while we should be bolder by asking dgcomp for more, for example through greater powers of inquiry and more powers to impose sanctions. Progress could also be made in terms of transparency through greater reporting to the European Parliament. Furthermore, the report could have been more ambitious with regard to the State aid law which, in my opinion, needs to be reviewed. For these reasons, I have chosen to abstain.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I have decided to support this report, which contains many recommendations for improving competition policy, which is one of the fundamental pillars of the social market economy in Europe and an important instrument for the proper functioning of the EU internal market. I consider it important for the European Commission to thoroughly investigate attempts to abuse market dominance in order to protect us consumers. I am also in favour of updating the general competition rules in the digital economy, which must correspond to the current market reality. I consider it necessary to continue to have a very intensive dialogue with the Commission in this area, and I would very much like to see the consultation procedure replaced by a regular legislative process in the future.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: in writing ‒ I did not support the report, which is the European Parliament's reply to the European Commission's 2014 report on competition policy. Although in most cases there is no problem with this type of report, I am not convinced by mr Langen's report with its content and, in particular, by a few elements with which I disagree. One of the most striking problems for me was the common consolidated tax base. I am of the opinion that tax issues should remain within the competence of the Member States and I therefore do not share the harmonisation of the tax area. Likewise, because of my opposition to over-harmonisation, references to and completion of the Banking Union were also problematic in this report. On the issue of individual cases of harmful tax practices and their investigations, I do not agree with the report's proposal that a parliamentary committee should be set up for this purpose. I believe that the powers to investigate individual cases are already given to taxe 2 and should be retained. For all these reasons, I voted against.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the annual report on EU Competition Policy, because I believe that it is a cornerstone of Europe's social market economy and is an essential tool for ensuring the smooth functioning of the Union's internal market.  Furthermore, in the absence of powers of codecision, the European Parliament resolution on the European Commission's Annual Report on Competition Policy is one of the most important tests of its supervision in the field of European policy.  I therefore believe that the European Parliament must continue to fight to make its vision prevail with regard to certain aspects of EU competition policy, especially with regard to its integration into the codecision procedure on these matters. EU competition policy should therefore encourage the existence of conditions for fair competition for all businesses in order to complete the internal market, especially with regard to the fight against tax evasion and illegal corporate tax practices, while maintaining a high level of social welfare and protection of working conditions.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 Always under the false pretext of unfair competition or distortions of competition from this policy, directives and regulations whose sole purpose is to prevent public control of the strategic sectors of the economy and the promotion of universal, free and quality public services. We support the call to put an end to social dumping, but we argue that being more competitive cannot in any way have a negative social impact, regardless of the degree of isolation of the regions. We reject any call on the European Commission to complete the single market in areas where it is still fragmented and incomplete and that so-called market restrictions be removed, because we believe that the deepening of the single market has increased the dismantling of sovereign regulation instruments for economies and that it contributes to the escalation of tax avoidance and profit-making at Member State level. We call for all cooperation efforts between Member States and for a real commitment to combattax havens, tax avoidance and tax evasion. We voted against it.

name: Marco Zullo (EFDD)
text: in writing. This own-initiative report is presented annually by Parliament with the aim of providing a complete picture of the competition policy aspects within the 28 Member States of the European Union. The text contains a number of points which I welcome, such as combating excessive market concentration or putting in place actions to prevent situations of abuse of a dominant position and cartels. Particular reference is made, according to this perspective, to the Google case and other internet platforms. However, I have chosen to abstain during the vote in plenary because the text of the report shows too much satisfaction with the work done so far by the European Commission, identified in the people of the old Commissioner Joaquín Almunia and the current Commissioner, Mr Vestager. In my opinion, their work should have been much more ambitious. I would have expected a bolder text to provide for the establishment of greater powers of investigation and investigation, as well as a more stringent system of sanctions. Much progress could also be made in terms of transparency by imposing more detailed reporting on the European Parliament. In addition, the report should have dealt more with state aid rules, which need to be considered in depth in order to assess their effectiveness and application.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. Effective implementation of competition policy is essential to ensure a free and dynamic internal market. I supported the annual report on EU competition policy (2015/2140(INI)) because I believe that it rightly identifies the current challenges of restrictive practices and draws attention to the European Parliament's lack of role in the adoption of competition law legislation.

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI).
text: – I could not support the report on intercultural dialogue, especially given that there was very little talk about issues and values in which there is no place for any dialogue. There is no room for intercultural dialogue, for example, on whether European women can go out on New Year's Eve to celebrate en masse in a public place. There is no room for intercultural dialogue about whether we European women can travel by train or without a male escort. There is no room for dialogue about whether we can play sports or go to the swimming pool. We do not need dialogue here, but that those who want to take away from us the rights for which our mothers and grandmothers fought, the right of women to equality and dignity and freedom, have their place in prison, or should be removed from Europe with immediate effect, back to the sender.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D).
text: – Grazzi Sur President, meta Jean Monnet kien qed ifassal il-bażi tal-Unjoni Ewropea, qal li, kieku dan il-proèess kellu jibdieh mill-bidu, kien jibda mill-kultura u mill-edukazzjoni. Huwa important li l-żenerazzjoni futura tkun magťmula minn members tas-soèjetà u b'moťť miftuť li jirrispetta d-diversità; Żenerazzjoni li tiżżieled phenomena sożjali bťad-diskriminazzjoni, il-vjolenza, ir-radikaliżmu, ir-razziżmu u l-ksenofobija. Gťaldaqstant, nixtieq nifrať lir-rapporteur — u vvutajt favur dan ir-rapport — gťar-riżultati finali. Sodisfatta ťafna talli ttieťdet inkonsiderazzjoni l-idea tiegťi li gťandna nesponu lit-tfal tagťna gťal kulturi oťra minn età żgťira, biex tgťinhom jiksbu żiliet bażiżi tal-ťajja u l-kompetenzi meťtieża gťall-iżvilupp personal tagťhom, impjieg fil-futur u żittadinenza attiva fl-Unjoni Ewropea. name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – Mr President, i would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur Cultural diversity is an integral part of our world. Consequently, intercultural dialogue aimed at the exchange of knowledge, understanding traditions, traditions and the whole of these things in education are quite important things. Their role, both in our society and elsewhere in the world, cannot be ignored, especially in view of the often very widespread stereotypes, which are often quite negative in their very nature. Support from non-governmental organisations, the positive modernisation of the education system, the reform of integration policies, largely due to the current ineffective results in a number of Member States of the European Union, as well as diplomacy, the preservation of cultural identity and so on – the implementation of these and a number of other policies at supranational level is not only simply important, but also vital. It must be said that an effective adaptation of existing principles in the cultural sphere and a rational reform of the present and future challenges is a guarantee that our society will continue to function effectively and our core values will not disappear. Thank you!

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE).
text: – The need for cultural diversity and intercultural dialogue has always been present in Europe, not brought about by the wave of immigration in recent years. Europe's society is diverse, with mostly non-ethnically homogeneous nations within the Member States, but communities that have evolved throughout history coexisting and interacting. The need for intercultural dialogue needs to be discussed not only with regard to new immigrant minorities and EU citizens, but also between indigenous national minorities living in Europe and the majority nations of the Member States. The report emphasises that intercultural dialogue is a two-way process and will benefit both sides. Unfortunately, in many cases, we find that Member States do not want to take into account the readiness, needs and complaints of national minorities in their territory to have dialogue. We must say that this type of intercultural communication is not working properly, which is why minorities are turning to the European Union to moderate this process and help the parties to understand each other. We hope to see more openness from the European institutions in this area in the future.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE).
text: – Mr. President, I supported this report because I consider intercultural and interreligical dialogue the key to understanding and respecting diversity and achieving and preserving peace. Unfortunately, this dialogue has been largely absent in today's world, and we in Europe often forget on what foundations and values our culture and our entire society was built. I am therefore particularly pleased that the report highlights the important role of families in preserving cultural identity, tradition and values, and that it particularly emphasises that learning about one's own culture starts in the family.  Family is a pillar of our society and we must do everything in our power to protect it, as well as the values with which we teach our children in it. If we succeed in preserving families, we do not have to fear that our culture will be threatened because we will raise children who will love their own and respect other people's, and this is the first and most important step in building peace.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I supported this report because I am aware that education, better learning, as well as the fundamental values of the Union, which are embodied in Article 5, be it the rule of law, the defence of human rights, are undoubtedly values worth protecting and, at the same time, telling to those cultures and societies that have not yet reached this stage of knowledge. However, I would like to say that intercultural dialogue is different from multiculturalism. I find it quite dangerous to replace the awareness of our identity, our roots and traditions with this very alleged value of multiculturalism. I think that it is very late to blame the states that are members of the European Union, but they may not have reached this stage of the development of society, this alleged deficiency.

name: Diane Dodds (NI).
text: – Mr President, as a Member of this House from Northern Ireland, I recognise fully the transformation that can occur in lives, particularly for young people, as a result of engaging positively with those that are assumed to come from a different background or hold diverse beliefs. In light of the spate of terror attacks and the trend of radicalisation witnessed in Europe in recent months, I am in full support of appropriate measures aimed at stopping the recruitment of young people and combating the wave of division and intolerance that besets us.  However, while sending a joint message right across Europe, it is important in this battle that national governments have the primary role to play. This report attempts to influence the nature of national education. It wants to harmonise legislation around cultural heritage and cultural expression. These are matters for sovereign governments to decide, not the European Parliament. Grassroots divisions require grassroots solutions and this is something that the unrelenting federalists in this House today should remind themselves of.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU promotes the sharing and respect of fundamental values such as freedom, democracy, human rights and solidarity. That is why intercultural dialogue, based on the mutual exchange of views and opinions by different cultures, fits perfectly into European objectives, stimulating mutual understanding and integration between citizens. Calling on The Member States to implement programmes that enhance cultural differences in today's societies, condemning all forms of discrimination or racism, is a priority of intercultural dialogue. I voted in favour because I believe it is essential to involve institutions, states and local authorities in promoting the sharing of good practices aimed at respecting the dignity of the individual and his rights.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. In 2012 Following the terrorist attacks in France and Denmark in 2015, education ministers from EU Member States adopted a declaration with the aim of promoting the values of freedom and tolerance through education. This report is on that same line. Although the report has been improved thanks to the amendments tabled by my political group reiterating the value of social justice, they point to the need to promote cultural diversity especially among young people through culture and the media and promote training in multiculturalism among teachers, I have had to abstain as the text gives religious confessions a role of representativeness that I do not think is compatible with the values of secularism essential for the development of individual beliefs in freedom.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. I spoke out against this report on the role of intercultural dialogue, cultural diversity and education in promoting the Union's core values.  This text places the problem of integration at European level, whereas it falls within the exclusive competences of states according to the EU treaties themselves. Moreover, this text is very ideological in emphasizing that multiculturalism would be the great solution to combat radicalization and religious fundamentalism.  Finally, this text tends to promote the fact that migrants can enrich the culture of the Member States. On the contrary, I believe that integration must involve knowledge and learning of the culture of welcome and the re-establishment of national identities and cultures, which is the role of the state. Deeply opposed to European harmonisation of culture, I therefore oppose this text.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 With this report, Parliament wishes to stress the importance of intercultural and interreligious dialogue, cultural diversity and education as prerequisites for the prevalence of peace and conflict management, the defence of fundamental human rights and the promotion of mutual respect and social inclusion and cohesion. Through intercultural dialogue there can be real communication between peoples and the foundations can be laid for the preparation of future generations, so as to form a society of responsible citizens who respect diversity and act to combat social phenomena such as discrimination, racism, xenophobia and others. I believe that education and intercultural dialogue are the only way to tackle as European citizens the main challenges of today's society and, for this reason, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. The news shows us more and more every day the failure of multiculturalism. Yet this report proposes to continue on this path at high speed.  Integration problems, linked to successive waves of immigration, are a reality that Eurocrats do not want to see. But once again the European Union is meddling in national policies by wanting to impose its ideology and by wishing to create a sense of common belonging in such a vast territory, within which cultural barriers are far from being crossed, if only languages. In particular, the report proposes educational programmes "accessible to refugee children" whereas it is an integration by assimilation into our national values that should be proposed. Totally contradictory, this report affirms a desire to integrate cultural diversity, but proposes a few lines later to "take into consideration" different types of communitarianism. On the other hand, we believe that it is important to defend our identity, our values and our roots and to give priority to the cultural diversity of the Member States and not to create, ex-nihilo, a global culture. I therefore voted against this report.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Whilst much of this report refers to matters which everyone can agree on – for example, suggesting that we need greater understanding between different cultures – the remedies proposed for this situation will be a hindrance rather than a help. In the United Kingdom, education should always be politically neutral. This is enshrined in law under the Education Act of 1996. Therefore I am most concerned by calls for further EU involvement in our education system. Furthermore, the report frequently calls for taxpayers’ money to be spent on various initiatives. Yet far from strengthening the genuine national and local cultures which are so vibrant across Europe, it would rather foster a non-existent ‘European culture’, forgetting rather conveniently that almost half of all European countries are not even members of the European Union!

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution because it is important that Member States commit to supporting the role of intercultural dialogue in education. I pay particular attention to strengthening learning, particularly through the development of EU-funded programmes, such as Erasmus.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to strengthen the roles of cultural diversity and education in upholding the EU's core values. This report is based on a joint agreement between education ministers, which provides an effort to prevent and combat marginalisation, intolerance, racism and radicalisation, as well as to preserve the basis for equal opportunities for all. I agree with the specific recommendations on the need for action at all levels of government , including at EU level, including a stronger focus on culture in external relations and the EU Development Agenda.

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The aim of the report is to learn lessons from the Year of Intercultural Dialogue 2008 and the member states' consultations and to further its values. It is important to point out that the development of culture and cultural policy is a competence of the Member States, which the EU is now trying to raise to EU level, ignoring the principle of subsidiarity, with this report. Another important problem is that it contains a veiled numerus clausus, under which, along the lines of quasi-quotas in education and culture, groups of people of different denominations and sexual origins could be regulated and multicultural propaganda would be created at EU level, regulated over the heads of member states' governments. They aim to achieve an understanding and acceptance of cultural diversity among young people by establishing joint study programmes and extending existing ones. It should be acknowledged, however, that certain religious and cultural groups are unable and unwilling to tolerate the other in any form, with any tolerant behaviour, in relation to their own culture and religious standards. The document does not show the perception that people who know their own culture, respect it and see it as a defining part of their identity, are capable of understanding people living in different cultures. On this basis, I did not vote on the report.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this multiculturalist report which aims to promote imported diversity at the expense of the various cultural specificities that have made the richness of our Old Continent.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. I have, of course, supported this report by my colleague Julie Ward, which calls for the intensification of a structured intercultural and interfaith dialogue between all stakeholders in order to promote the fundamental values of the Union. It recalls the crucial role of education in any intercultural strategy and stresses that the Union should also strengthen the weight of culture and education in its international exchanges and its development cooperation policy.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Europe of the second decade of the 21st century is, without a doubt, a melting place of heterogeneous identities and traditions. Cultural, religious and linguistic diversity is an intangible wealth that reveals a common feeling of the continent around those values that we believe to be the basis of European society. The rule of law, social justice, democracy and human rights are both an achievement and a constant objective to strive for. A goal that today seems threatened by the growth of xenophobic pressures and religious radicalism. I supported julie ward's report with conviction, aware that the challenge of intercultural dialogue will be crucial for the coming years. The EU must promote formal, non-formal and informal education, involving associations, political actors and religious realities as much as possible in a vast citizenship education project to respond effectively to the challenges posed by globalisation and migration. The issue of work, which is safe and of quality, cannot be ruled out, representing a real opportunity for integration for all citizens. The challenge for a more open and safer European society is to make the most of artistic, sporting and voluntary activities, which make it possible to overcome the mechanisms of segregation.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report is an attempt to take advantage of the joint agreement of the Ministers of Education, signed in Paris on 17 March 2015, on the need for combined efforts to prevent and combat marginalization, intolerance, racism and radicalisation, as well as to preserve a framework of equal opportunities for all. The report identifies both opportunities and challenges and proposes concrete recommendations for action at all levels of government, as well as at EU level, especially through education. It includes a broad approach that encourages new reflections on the nature and processes of political violence, based on the premise that radicalization is a dynamic relational process and an unforeseen and unpredictable consequence of a number of disturbing events. The GUE/NGL Group had a good impression of the original report. In addition, our group's amendments were contained in the commitments and approved with them. I therefore voted in favour of the report.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report on the role of intercultural dialogue, cultural diversity and education in promoting the fundamental values of the Union. I am grateful for the rapporteur's work in reaching the agreement. I would like to stress the importance of integrating and educating segregated communities in a timely manner. I also voted against the reference that these communities have behaviours contrary to fundamental European values.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. I strongly opposed this report, which irresponsibly and in total denial of reality promotes multiculturalism. To the detriment of the events of recent weeks such as the vote of many European women by migrants, the text of the socialist Julie Ward posits that intercultural dialogue must be a weapon to fight racism and discrimination, real sources of radicalisation and extremism. It also takes the opportunity to try to counter the Treaties which provide that culture and education are exclusive competences of the Member States and seeks to strengthen the European Union in these areas, although the inability of Brussels politicians to solve the problems of the European peoples has never been more glaring. In the face of so much ideology, I have therefore tabled on behalf of the ENL Group an alternative proposal to combat multiculturalism and preserve the capacity of Member States to establish their own integration policies, including by upgrading national traditions and cultures and by reminding newcomers that it is up to newcomers to adapt to the national identity of the country that welcomes them. , not the other way around.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that the model of integration at all costs to promote intercultural dialogue, which in all cases remains an end in itself, not a reality and propaganda, is a failed model and one of the causes of the social crisis that Europe is currently going through, which is why I voted against the Ward report.

name: Malin Björk (GUE/NGL)
text: Written. I have voted in favour of the report.  The report addresses important issues of cultural and social marginalisation and how vulnerability can lead to radicalisation. The report also notes the increase in racism and xenophobia, and wants financial means to combat it. Despite these positive elements, the report maintains an uncritical approach to intercultural dialogue. Above all, the report believes that Europe is the owner of the values that other groups need to embrace, it uses words such as 'exposing children to other cultures', and 'segregated communities, behaving in a way that is contrary to European fundamental values'. This consistent attitude shows that the European Parliament still has a lot to work on in terms of critically examining its own cultural heritage, and not just assuming that the problems lie with the 'others'. Despite these negative elements, I have chosen to vote in favour, because it is a report that wants to highlight dialogue instead of polarisation and discrimination and wants to allocate more resources to culture and education.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I supported this motion for a Resolution which advocates strengthening the role of intercultural dialogue, cultural diversity and education as a vehicle for peace and as a tool in conflict resolution promoting human rights, freedom of thought, mutual respect, integrity, cultural diversity, inclusion and social cohesion. The text emphasizes that genuine intercultural and inter-confessional dialogue fosters positive and cooperative interactions, promotes understanding and respect between cultures, promotes diversity and increases respect for democracy, freedom and human rights, as well as tolerance with universal values. It also considers it key that intercultural dialogue is an EU objective and to invest in inclusive, accessible and quality education at all levels to develop ethical and civic values. It also calls for renewed attention to the promotion of an intercultural society based on solidarity, especially among young people. And it calls on the Member States and the Commission to prevent extremism, such as xenophobia, racism and all forms of discrimination and marginalising, with measures to strengthen Community cohesion capable of successfully countering socio-economic inequalities.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because the European Union is experiencing a special gap in history when the concepts of identity and commonality are challenged, reshaped and defended. This process is accompanied by strong emotions arising from differences in opinion diversity and political attitudes. March 17, 2015 The Paris Declaration is a significant statement; welcomes its call for Member States to take action to strengthen the role of intercultural dialogue in education and training. At the same time, the education ministers of the EU countries have made it clear that a pluralistic, non-discriminatory, tolerant and just society, which wholeheartedly supports solidarity and equality between women and men, in order to ensure respect for the EU's fundamental values of human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law and respect for human rights, is a value. This report is an attempt to follow the joint agreement between education ministers, which has focused the efforts necessary to prevent and combat marginalisation, intolerance, racism and radicalisation, as well as to preserve the basis for equal opportunities for all. The report identifies opportunities and makes concrete recommendations for action at all levels of government , including at EU level, including a stronger focus on culture in external relations and the EU Development Agenda. It also recognises the unique role that culture can play in building peace, resolving conflicts and preventing crises.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The challenges discussed in the report require cultural dialogue and diversity to be transversally integrated into all policies such as children's and youth, mobility, employment and social affairs, security and home affairs, women's rights and equal opportunities, and regional development policies. We need better and more coherent cooperation between the various political structures and topics, not only at EU level, but also at national and local level. Education and intercultural dialogue play an important role in the active and conscious participation of citizens in social, political and local life. Learning is a dynamic process that lasts until the end of a person's life, in which it is important to acquire different skills and intercultural competences.  The report underlines the role of the family in preserving the values of cultural identity, traditions, morality and society, and stresses that the family begins to learn about the culture, values and norms of society, the nation and Europe. In line with the position of the Fidesz-KDNP Group, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. At a time of the greatest crisis since The 2nd World War, which Europe is currently facing, and the simultaneous crisis of values, the promotion of intercultural dialogue can be one way of resolving crisis situations. All too often it happens to be heard from each other, but we don't hear each other. We either don't want to do that or we don't want it. Unfortunately, all too often because of the latter.  Ethnically closed neighbourhoods, which do not offer young people the opportunity to flourish in personality, social and existential, give birth to different types of crime, including terrorism. This can only be prevented through appropriate intercultural dialogue, education and integration. And sincere devotion to these goals.  Cultural dialogue should be integrated into all policy areas, such as policies relating to children and young people, education, mobility, employment and social affairs, security and internal matters, and women's rights and gender equality and regional development.  Diversity and diversity must be respected, but it should be noted that any cultural habits from other backgrounds must not and cannot be above the values on which modern Europe is built: individual freedom, equality, respect for human rights and the rule of law. This can only be achieved by the desire to listen and cooperate and not by imposing it.  I, of course, supported the report.

name: Simona Bonafè (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I strongly support this report which, in line with the Paris Declaration of March 2015 and the challenges facing us today, underlines the importance of intercultural dialogue as a main means of achieving an increasingly cohesive and inclusive society. In addressing today's problems, such as the refugee crisis, the radicalisation of many young people and the phenomenon of terrorism, we cannot forget that the comparison between different cultures and dialogue in diversity are among the founding principles of the European Union, which was also born and above all to promote these values. In order to strengthen the European area of dialogue and to address the critical issues of the present, we can only focus on young people and their education, at all levels and by all possible means, in the knowledge that culture and mutual knowledge are the basis of every truly harmonious society based on integration.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. I support this Report, which focuses on the role of intercultural and interfaith dialogue with all interested parties and the role of education at all levels in light of all recent developments, all with the aim of promoting human rights, freedom of thought, mutual respect, integrity, ethical principles, cultural diversity, social inclusion and cohesion. I believe that only in this way do we create a precondition for future peace and successful conflict management.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe that the European Union, with its immense cultural, linguistic and religious diversity, must take all necessary measures to protect and advance intercultural dialogue. It is a fundamental resource for our future and it is our job to preserve it.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. Culture is a soft power which the Union must place at the heart of its action. The EU represents a beacon of civilisation in the world, where the highest ideals of human thought tend to become a reality, through legislative reforms and the progressive and constant action of the institutions that the European people have democratically chosen. This level of civil conquest, although still improveable and not free from defects and errors, is a positive example. We Europeans have a moral duty and a political opportunity to grasp what we represent in the world and, through that important two-way instrument, intercultural dialogue, to implement it both with people and from other countries arriving in the Union and towards those who remain in areas subject to environmental problems or conflicts. Eliminating social, cultural and economic discrimination against people in their communities de-empowers fundamentalism and violent extremism at its root. By including cultural dialogue in the Union's external policy, we will play the key role in promoting democratisation, peace-building and respect for the human rights that our founding values demand of us.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The role of intercultural dialogue, cultural diversity and education in promoting the EU's fundamental values is indisputable. The only way we can make these three instruments work is to involve society as a whole, from several actors, such as the media, educators, businesses, communities and religious leaders. In this way, it is not only political actors that will make a significant contribution to intercultural dialogue.  Without a deep knowledge of one's own culture, but also of other cultures, a genuine intercultural dialogue cannot be achieved. In this context, the development of educational mobility for students and teachers is an appropriate measure for a better knowledge of dialogue and cultural diversity. This can help to encourage interactions, increase diversity and respect for democracy, freedom and human rights, and increase tolerance for universal values and those specific to each culture.  I was in favour of this report because there is a need to significantly promote the fundamental values of the EU when there are a number of challenges at European level related to globalisation, migration, religious and intercultural conflicts, as well as the rise of radicalism.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report by the British Socialist MEP emphasises the desire to continue on the educational model that has prevailed in the last decades of reception education for a multicultural society. This report calls in the field of training for the Member States to be given the imperative of reception in order to strengthen the role of intercultural dialogue in education and learning environments. Because this model, which for us is a major failure, is one of the causes of the social crisis that Europe is going through. I am voting against.

name: Cristian-Silviu Buşoi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Cultural diversity plays a key role in the European Union, not only as a fundamental feature of European construction, but also as a cultural resource. Through the Union Treaties, the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights and the European Convention on Human Rights, the EU is committed to respecting the rights of minorities and all identities that constitute a wealth of European heritage.  The method by which we gain from this diversity requires a framework of intercultural dialogue. After the end of the European Year of Intercultural Dialogue (2008), all beneficial activities involving open exchange and interaction between people, groups and organisations from different cultural backgrounds or with different visions had no continuity. Today's society, especially in the context of the events of the past year, shows us the need for inclusive democratic participation and for the empowerment of citizens.  Intercultural dialogue is the essential tool in achieving this goal, leading to the cultivation of a deeper sense of inclusion and belonging, and thus to the strengthening of democracy. In this respect, the role of education should not be neglected either, as the people on whom such a policy can have a deeper and long-lasting impact are children.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. Now more than ever, intercultural dialogue is becoming an absolute necessity. It is a rather vague notion that comes in various trends. It would therefore be necessary to define it politically in order to better understand it and to better apply it. The diversity of our societies requires greater openness and openness to other cultures.  It is partly through education and learning programs that we will be able to reduce the distrust that some people have towards another culture. One of the foundations of the European Union is unity in diversity. This concept must become a reality in Europe and outside our borders.  By in dialogue with other cultures, other religions, we will learn to live better together and to promote the fundamental values of the European Union. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 After careful consideration and discussion in the Chamber, I voted in favour of the report. I am convinced that the constantly developing intercultural dialogue in Europe is an essential tool for the identity and cohesion of the whole Community. There is no one who does not see that through it the common values of freedom, social justice and democracy are being strengthened, which, directly emerging from human rights, are being put to the test by xenophobic and radical tendencies within and outside Europe precisely by means of the compression of cultural dialogue. That is why, as I pointed out in my questions last March, the whole area of intercultural exchange needs continuous stimulus from the Commission's political agenda, in order to spread the unique role that European culture retains in the world and, from an economic point of view, to strengthen its natural resilience to times of recession such as the current ones. I therefore agree with the report and with the recommendations proposed, in particular those that call for the capacity to make choices of intercultural dialogue, the promotion of equality and the acceptance of diversity as a resource.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report, which was concerned with promoting values of freedom, tolerance, non-discrimination and fighting racism, radicalisation and marginalisation through intercultural dialogue.  I agreed with many aspects of the report for the stance it took in seeing intercultural dialogue as a two-way process, benefiting both parties and voted against amendments that sought to reduce that dialogue in any way to a teaching exercise by Europeans alone.  As such amendments were not included in the final text; I was able to support the report as a whole.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative report.  This report provided another dimension in which the EU’s scope could be widened in the field of education, external relations, mobility and integration, while promoting ‘EU fundamental values’. This report calls for the addition of intercultural dialogue into national curricula, EU representation within the UN, and the harmonising of visa procedures, and calls for additional funding, all for the purpose of preventing radicalisation and helping integration. Whilst we agree that radicalisation, extremism and integration are issues to be tackled, such issues are to be resolved at nation state level.  We oppose any calls for the EU to influence or interfere with the education and national curricula of Member States. We feel particularly strongly with regard to the exploiting of EU financial instruments and mobility programmes to justify the free movement of people, all at the taxpayers’ expense.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report because I support the EU Education Ministers’ agreement that the Member States need to cooperate and promote our fundamental values and combat radicalisation, marginalisation and intolerance. We must focus on intercultural dialogue and strive for mutual understanding in order to achieve a more tolerant and pluralistic society.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report is generally very positive. The great importance of intercultural dialogue as an instrument of inclusive democratic participation and citizen empowerment is recognised, with a specific reference to the management of commons and public spaces. The text also emphasizes the centrality, for the objective of social inclusion and active citizenship, of building solid links between culture and education. Again, the reference to the need for civic education to begin in early childhood is certainly positive. I voted strongly in favour.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 We are in favour of the report based on the joint agreement of the Ministers of Education, which requires combined efforts to prevent and tackle marginalisation, intolerance, racism and radicalisation, as well as to maintain a framework of equal opportunities for all. The report identifies opportunities and challenges and makes concrete recommendations for action at all levels of government, as well as at EU level, including by increasing the use of culture in external actions and in the EU development programme, as it recognises the unique role that culture can play in peace processes, conflict resolution and crisis prevention.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 Given that we are going through a particularly tense period and are faced every day with the results of wrong political choices that in turn give rise to cultural conflicts, we can see the obvious need to review our choices and adopt new perceptions. This finding contains a number of particularly positive elements and proposals that can form a basis for improving the conditions for cooperation and understanding of citizens. That is why I voted in favour of the need to promote the fundamental values of the EU.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the measure as I am convinced that intercultural dialogue must be considered a key component of EU external action. The Paris Declaration of 17 March 2015 requires Member States to welcome them in order to strengthen the role of intercultural dialogue in education and learning environments. To this end, structural and sustainable support must be given to NGOs, institutions dealing with young people and young people, training institutions, all the organisations concerned and initiatives taken at local level.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU has always stood out for the predominance of soft power over hard power, dialogue against war, and academics say that Europe comes from Venus (as opposed to the US coming from Mars). I am not sure that this approach is always the best, but the fact is that intercultural dialogue, cultural diversity and education can do much more than repression in creating better citizens. History teaches us that violence only works in the short term, because sooner or later the oppressed organize themselves and free themselves. Culture, on the other hand, although it bears fruit more slowly, is more lasting and spreads more deeply. With these principles in mind, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The European Union faces diverging opinions on notions of identity and belonging. Intercultural dialogue should have a larger role in education, as was suggested by the Paris Declaration of 17 March 2015. Intercultural dialogue and education can provide for a more pluralistic, tolerant society with an emphasis on equality between citizens and a respect for human rights. Culture should be recognised as a tool in peace-building and conflict resolution. Civic education, provided from an early age, would help young people take part in a more democratic society. The promotion of intercultural dialogue would engage individuals suffering from marginalisation, geographic or social isolation. NGOs, youth organisations and training institutions should be provided with structural assistance to help in this cultural exchange.
