name: David Coburn (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative report.  This report provided another dimension in which the EU’s scope could be widened in the field of education, external relations, mobility and integration, while promoting ‘EU fundamental values’. This report calls for the addition of intercultural dialogue into national curricula, EU representation within the UN, and the harmonising of visa procedures, and calls for additional funding, all for the purpose of preventing radicalisation and helping integration. Whilst we agree that radicalisation, extremism and integration are issues to be tackled, such issues are to be resolved at nation state level.  We oppose any calls for the EU to influence or interfere with the education and national curricula of Member States. We feel particularly strongly with regard to the exploiting of EU financial instruments and mobility programmes to justify the free movement of people, all at the taxpayers’ expense.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union is founded on a set of values, shared by all Member States, and which derive precisely from the constituent values of each of these countries. These include human dignity, freedom of religion, gender equality or non-discrimination on the basis of color. At a time when the world is confronted with an unprecedented number of displaced people and the Union, in particular, with the greatest migratory pressure since World War II, intercultural dialogue is of particular importance. Cultural diversity and education are essential for promoting the values that define the community in which we are part. This report rightly points to this importance and points out some paths, such as close collaboration with the United Nations and humanitarian aid that guarantees access to youth school in refugee camps. I therefore support this report.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I think it is important to support intercultural dialogue because, in the specificity of this historical moment, we are already experiencing the challenges related to coexistence between different cultures. It is more necessary than ever to reaffirm the principles on which the European Union is founded and to make these values felt by all those who are on the territory of the Union, even if they are not directly originating from them. I also agree with the need to focus primarily on education and training, which is accessible to all and of quality. For these reasons, I support the motion for a resolution.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ With Europe increasingly becoming multicultural and with events clearly showing how some European societies have failed to integrate this reality, the role that education plays in addressing these failures becomes even more pertinent. Cultural diversity does not exclude unity in society, but requires a society that values the meaning of community. Education processes provide key tools in rebuilding communities. I have thus voted in favour.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report presents a very positive overall profile on the declination of the role of intercultural dialogue, cultural diversity and education in relation to the promotion of the fundamental values of the European Union. Intercultural dialogue, as understood in the report, should be based on the work developed during the European Year of Intercultural Dialogue in 2008. It also calls for interreligious dialogue, which is seen as a component of intercultural dialogue and is seen as an essential prerequisite for peace and a key instrument for conflict management. To preserve respect for the dignity of the individual and human rights, with particular reference to freedom of thought, conscience and religion and the right to protection of religious minorities, contributing significantly to the strengthening of democracy and the development of a stronger and deeper sense of inclusion and belonging. Educational resources should be reviewed to promote multi-perspective and multilingual learning, and teachers' multilingual and intercultural experiences and skills must be systematically exploited and promoted. Member States and the Commission are urged to prevent extremism, xenophobia, racism and all forms of discrimination and marginalisation, through cohesion measures within the community. I am therefore voting in favour.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. In 2012 Following the terrorist attacks in France and Denmark in 2015, the education ministers of eu Member States adopted a declaration with the aim of promoting the values of freedom and tolerance through education. This report is on that same line. I voted in favour, because the report has also been improved by the amendments tabled by my political group which reiterate the value of social justice, point to the need to promote cultural diversity especially among young people through culture and the media and promote training in multiculturalism among teachers.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Because Europe is characterised by cultural, social, linguistic and religious diversity, the common values that hold our societies together such as freedom, social justice, fairness and non-discrimination, democracy, human rights, the rule of law, play a fundamental role. I voted in favour of this resolution because it encourages the European Commission and the Member States to take appropriate measures to promote intercultural dialogue, such as: developing training programmes that promote diversity, promoting the use of new information and communication technologies, encouraging the performance of artistic, sporting, educational and training activities for all ages, as well as voluntary activities , in order to strengthen socialisation processes and minority participation, develop strategies that recognise intercultural dialogue as a process of interactive communication between and within cultures in order to ensure mutual respect and equal opportunities, to exploit European financial instruments, eu neighbourhood policy and external relations instruments, and bodies such as the European Union Agency for Fundamental Rights.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Intercultural dialogue, cultural diversity and education can play an important role in promoting EU core values, according to the report of the Committee on Culture, which I voted in favour of. The EU's core values laid down in the Treaties are human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law and respect for human rights, including the rights of persons belonging to minorities. These values can also be strengthened through education, dialogue and sport. The report also places particular emphasis on the role of volunteering, sport and the arts in strengthening the socialisation process. It does not specifically focus on national minorities, but rather focuses on the process of socialising marginalised communities, migrants and refugees. Nevertheless, I consider it important to send a message in order to eliminate the coexistence problems of the various ethnic groups in the European regions.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ While ECR strongly supports intercultural dialogue and although this report contains positive elements in reinvigorating dialogue between communities, it has a number of serious faults which prevent us from approving it. Primarily, the report fails to address the specificity and characteristics of cultural dialogue. While referring to EU fundamental values as they are set out in the Treaties, it does not take into consideration existing pluralism in their interpretation, which should be acknowledged and respected. The report seems to neglect that genuine intercultural dialogue requires strong identities of interacting individuals or communities based on deep knowledge of their cultural canons, therefore a good knowledge of history, literature, music, etc. is indispensable. The spirit of the document suggests that a successful intercultural dialogue relies solely on opening up to other cultures by resigning from one’s own heritage – the rapporteur strongly objected to incorporating any references to the Christian roots of the Europe despite tabled amendments on behalf of several political groups. Concerns were also raised regarding the form of the report – the text is incomprehensible and consists of lengthy, vague paragraphs made up of fragments that do not match.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The report looks at new ways to approach cultural diversity in a Europe based on diverse opinions and political perspectives in order to promote and foster pluralistic, non-discriminatory, tolerant and just societies. By focusing on values underlined in international human rights frameworks, the report stressed the promotion of the implementation of the UNESCO Convention on the Protection and Promotion of Diversity of Cultural Expression. The report highlights the need to recognise the importance of the promotion of common core values which hold our societies together, such as tolerance, freedom, the rule of law, equality, democratic participation and citizen empowerment within the context of cultural, social and religious diversity. The report notes the importance of learning mobility, the promotion of volunteer programmes and rights-based, gender-sensitive learning environments as an essential aspect of promoting EU fundamental values in order to promote the fostering of confidence in one’s own identity on an EU, local and global level. For this reason I voted in favour of this report.

name: Daniel Dalton (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ Whilst I welcome some elements of this report, particularly its emphasis on the importance of education in integration, which is pertinent given recent tragic events in Paris, I cannot support the report as a whole. It goes too far in promoting EU citizenship and EU representation at international level at the expense of national governments and identity. Some of its proposals on Member State education policies clearly infringe national sovereignty and are outside EU competences. The proposal for an EU cultural attaché to third partner countries and stronger EU representation within UN agencies directly undermines national interests and risks undermining the strength of cultural diversity within Europe. For all these reasons I voted against the report in the final vote.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the rapporteur's position on encouraging European citizens to carry out educational and training activities in the artistic and sports field for people of all ages, as well as voluntary activities.  I believe that this activity is the best way of socialising and participating minorities, disadvantaged groups, marginalised communities, migrants and refugees in cultural and social life in the community in which they live and enables language learning and better knowledge of cultural heritage.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This initiative report looks at the role of culture and education in promoting the Union's core values. Increasing the mobility of young people and teachers, as well as the use of culture in external development programmes in the European Union, must promote mutual understanding and help in the fight against prejudice or extremism. Considering that it is essential to promote the values of citizenship in all forms and pathways of education and to use European programmes to strengthen the training of teachers, educators and facilitators, I have spoken in favour.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. The objectives set out in this report reflect a collective will to prevent marginalization, intolerance, racism and radicalisation and to preserve a framework of equal opportunities for all. In addition, the report calls for concrete actions to be taken at the cultural and educational policy level. That is why I voted in favour.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 EU education ministers were clear in jointly affirming the value of a pluralistic, non-discriminatory, tolerant and fair society, respectful of key EU values such as human dignity, freedom, democracy and equality. This report is an attempt to follow up this conviction by promoting a healthy intercultural dialogue between all types of communities leading to a better understanding and acceptance of fundamental common values. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that intercultural dialogue makes it possible to deal constructively with stereotypes, prejudices and forms of discrimination, offering new opportunities to marginalised communities and laying the foundations necessary for the peoples of the future to be strong, confident and cohesive.

name: Jean-Paul Denanot (S&D)
text: In writing. In Europe's turbulent political period (refugee crisis, rejection of institutions, withdrawal, rise of fundamentalism, etc.), this report is essential. It is the indispensable counterpart to safer considerations to combat the radicalization of one part of the youth and the dropping out of another. Intercultural dialogue, which includes openness to others, understanding and accepting different points of view, language proficiency, knowledge of other countries and other customs, must become a genuine structural policy of the European Union. It requires increased mobility of the youngest, in the service of the construction of European citizenship. It also involves media education. Intercultural dialogue is generous in its expectations and brings new hope and solidarity in its potential. Cultural dialogue is an active agent of further integration for greater unity among European peoples.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. This report first suggests that the Union should go far beyond the Union's competences by dealing with culture, an area which falls within the purview of the Member States and does not refer to any functional deficit on the part of the Member States, which could justify a transfer of powers. Moreover, by choosing to approach the issue of integration from the perspective of multiculturalism, this report is detached from the reality and the serious cultural crises suffered by the peoples of Europe, particularly as a result of mass immigration. I therefore voted against this report, which undermines national identities and cultures, gradually weakening the European nations.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Member States of the European Union represent a huge cultural and linguistic diversity, which is our wealth and must be respected but not forcibly unified. Our peoples must preserve their identity and, through the European Union, have the opportunity to exchange good practices that will only help their development. Signed on the Paris Declaration of March 2015 is an important step in the fight against radicalization. In this regard, our report could propose actions that would bring Member States together in their efforts to strengthen the role of intercultural dialogue in preventing radicalisation, but unfortunately I do not believe that the objective has been achieved. There is an ideology that has no practical realization, as well as those that do not affect the subject, let alone subsidiarity, which is completely overrun. Action is needed, but the proposed resolution certainly does not represent the message I want to send to my constituents. Due to the facts listed above, I voted against it.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 Europe has reached an impasse and yet continues to support intercultural dialogue and diversity in education and culture, putting European citizens in the crosshairs of those who are in fact incapable of dialogue and sharing the same values. Strengthening intercultural dialogue, particularly in educational institutions, can only have negative consequences for society at the risk of repeating the dramatic events that Europe has experienced in recent months and rekindling extremism. For these reasons we are voting against this report.

name: Eleonora Evi (EFDD)
text: in writing. – The Paris Declaration on the promotion of citizenship and common values of freedom, tolerance and non-discrimination through education, adopted by eu ropean Union education ministers in Paris on 17 March 2015, is an incisive declaration, which imposes on Member States the imperative of reception in order to strengthen the role of intercultural dialogue in education, an imperative necessary in order to lay the foundations for the construction of strong communities of the future , confident, resilient and cohesive.  The resolution, along the lines of the Paris Declaration, reaffirms the value of a pluralistic, non-discriminatory, tolerant and fair society, in which solidarity and equality between women and men are firmly embraced in pursuing fundamental EU values such as human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law and respect for human rights (as enshrined in Article 2 of the Treaty on European Union and the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union). Europe represents an immense wealth in terms of cultural, social, linguistic and religious diversity; In this context, the common values that hold our societies together, such as freedom, social justice, fairness and non-discrimination, human rights, tolerance and solidarity, are fundamental to the future of Europe. For this reason, I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union is at a particular historical moment when the senses of identity and belonging are challenged, reconfigured and defended, in a very emotional way, by a multiplicity of voices and divergent political perspectives. This report is an attempt at progress on the basis of the common agreement between the Ministers of Education, that combined efforts are needed to prevent and address marginalisation, intolerance, racism and radicalisation, as well as to preserve a framework of equal opportunities for all. Addressing the challenges addressed in this report requires that dialogue and cultural diversity be integrated across all policy areas, such as policies for children and young people, education, mobility, employment and social affairs, security and home affairs, in addition to women's rights, gender equality and regional development.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report because it gives migrants an inappropriate role.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report contains some positive aspects but generally adopts a perspective that is incapable of addressing the problems that lead to extremism, xenophobia and racism, laundering the role of the EU, governments and their policies in promoting inequalities, lack of access to public services and attacking fundamental rights, producing stigmas in short, in promoting values contrary to those proclaimed, in promoting interference and war instead of peace. It mixes concepts and skills to be acquired through education and training that will allegedly contribute to the promotion of the eu's fundamental values. Some of the wording of the report reveals the content and meaning of these so-called values (education for "leadership", "entrepreneurship"). The report aims to combat intolerance, racism, so-called radicalisation and marginalisation by promoting intercultural dialogue. A perspective on education for values that understand intercultural dialogue as a "two-way process where both parties benefit through being able to take each other's place" is advocated, rather than adopting a fear approach. These are positive aspects that coexist in the report with the aforementioned negative aspects.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ Promoting EU fundamental values. Could not support such values. Bullying and domination are not my idea of values that one could support.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing \ u2012 The focus of the report is the role of intercultural and interreligious dialogue with all stakeholders and the role of education at all levels in the light of all recent events as a prerequisite for peace and a tool for conflict management. It is very important to adopt intercultural dialogue as a strong and clearly stated objective of the European Union in the area of interactive communication within and between cultures, and to train and prepare future generations to be courageous in addressing the challenges and challenges that they will face as future European citizens by investing more in efficient and innovative and easily accessible and quality education at all levels. We must strive to offer the younger generations access to education and citizenship and the opportunity to acquire civic, social and intercultural skills and competences to help it develop ethical and civic values and to be active, responsible and open-minded members of society, and to respect diversity and the fight against social phenomena such as discrimination, violence, radicalism, racism and xenophobia.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 Europe has reached an impasse and yet continues to support intercultural dialogue and diversity in education and culture, putting European citizens in the crosshairs of those who are in fact incapable of dialogue and sharing the same values. Strengthening intercultural dialogue, particularly in educational institutions, can only have negative consequences for society at the risk of repeating the dramatic events that Europe has experienced in recent months and rekindling extremism. For the above reasons I am voting against this report.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I believe it is now crucial for the future of the EU to adopt intercultural dialogue as a strong and committed objective in an interactive communication within and between cultures. The aim is to train and prepare future generations to be audacious problem solvers. We must address the challenges that European citizens have to face in an effective and innovative way by investing in inclusive, accessible and quality education at all levels and by giving them access to citizenship education, a precondition of peace and a tool of conflict management.  Moreover, we must support the possibility to acquire civic, social and intercultural skills and competences that should help the citizens of the future to develop ethical and civic values and to become active, responsible and open-minded members of society, respecting diversity and combating social phenomena such as discrimination, violence, radicalism, racism and xenophobia.

name: Мария Габриел (PPE)
text: in writing. – I voted for the adoption of this report as it makes concrete recommendations for action at both European and national level to promote intercultural dialogue and the use of culture as an instrument for peace-building, conflict resolution and crisis prevention. I believe that it is essential that cultural dialogue and diversity are integrated horizontally in all policy areas, such as children's and youth policy, education, mobility, employment and social affairs, home affairs and security, as well as women's rights and gender equality, and regional development. I therefore welcome the commitment set out in the report on the inclusion of intercultural dialogue in the EU's external relations, including in the Union's development agenda. Promoting and protecting cultural diversity on the international stage can benefit the EU and its Member States in their relations with the rest of the world. Finally, I support increased exchange of good practices and enhanced intercultural dialogue, as they will undoubtedly foster solutions to the common challenges currently facing the EU.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I was particularly pleased to vote today on the report on intercultural dialogue, which states the protection of traditional values such as family, good education and cultural diversity.  The report emphasises the role of the family in preserving the values of cultural identity, traditions, morality and society, as children begin to learn about the culture, values and norms of society in the family. The report highlights the benefits of consistent intergenerational work through peer or family learning. I believe that, in the current situation, the most fundamental unity of society, the role of the family, must be strengthened in order to strengthen European society as a whole.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The challenges discussed in this report require cultural dialogue and diversity to be transversely integrated into all policies such as children's and youth, mobility, employment and social affairs, security and home affairs, as well as women's rights and equal opportunities and regional development policy. We need better and more coherent cooperation between the various political structures and topics, not only at EU level, but also at national and local level. The role of mobility and exchanges in promoting intercultural dialogue should be emphasised. In this area, the challenge is to make full use of existing instruments, and it is also an opportunity to reach out to a wider range of participants in order to involve individuals affected by marginalised, geographical and social isolation and other forms of discrimination.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the importance of working for a plural, non-discriminatory, tolerant and just society in line with the EU's core values of human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law and respect for human rights. To achieve such high objectives, a positive approach is needed and it is important to work for intercultural dialogue and the celebration of cultural diversity. There is no doubt that intercultural education and learning in its various scenarios are essential to ensure sustainable progress in the field of active citizenship.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. The message that the European Parliament sends with the adoption of julie ward's report, which I think is important to support, is the firm reference to the natural and first value on which the Union's cultural identity is built: the guarantee of respect for human rights and dignity. Marginalisation, intolerance, the re-emerge of xenophobic phenomena: against the great evils that threaten our society today, the most powerful instruments that we have remain inclusion, fairness and respect for the person that we find in our DNA as Europeans, already enshrined in the Charter of Fundamental Rights. I share the view that dialogue, cooperation and education are the key factors in supporting the dissemination and sharing of our values, for concrete support for the development of a pluralistic and democratic society, and I also hope that Europe will soon be able to take the lead not only in expressing but also leading the way in a common feeling with a strong solidarity and democratic character. , where equal opportunities are finally considered investment and resource and not a danger to be hindered.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. Unfortunately, I had to vote against today the report on the role of intercultural dialogue, cultural diversity and education in promoting the EU's fundamental values. Unfortunately, because I am convinced that a genuine and sincere dialogue between cultures and religions is of enormous importance today. However, it must not be misunderstood or deliberately misinterpreted. Intercultural dialogue needs tolerance, real tolerance. Furthermore, reports such as this must not be misused to demand, for example, unjustified EU influence over national or regional education policy.

name: Lidia Joanna Geringer de Oedenberg (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Cultural, linguistic or religious diversity is europe's vast wealth, which must be nurtured on the basis of the common values that connect our societies, such as freedom, equality, social justice and non-discrimination.  Intercultural dialogue involves open and respectful exchanges or interactions between individuals, groups and organisations from different cultural backgrounds or worldviews. It is a tool for strengthening the role of citizens and contributes significantly to improving democracy and the development of a sense of belonging.  Culture should also become a central element of political dialogue. The contribution of artistic creation to cultural diversity is enormous and its role in spreading EU values and encouraging European citizens to develop critical thinking is invaluable. That is why I am particularly pleased that my hometown , Wroclaw, plays an honourable role as European Capital of Culture in 2016, which is a challenge for the city, the region and my whole country to prove that integration through culture in the broader world is possible. In this spirit, a year-round program of celebrations was also built. Given the importance of respecting universal human rights as individuals and cultural rights, I call for initiatives aimed at promoting cultural diversity and intercultural dialogue to be given a higher priority. More cooperation in this area is essential, not only at EU level, but also at regional level.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. It is currently particularly important that European fundamental values are conveyed in a clear and comprehensible way for all. It is therefore important to promote intercultural exchange within the EU. High-quality training programs are also an important part of this.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒  I voted in favour of the report on ‘the role of intercultural dialogue, cultural diversity and education in promoting EU fundamental values’ because I am convinced by the need for intercultural dialogue, especially in light of dramatic events such as the refugee crisis and the terrorist attacks in Paris. This serves to further reinforce the fact that Europe must tackle these common challenges and promote its fundamental values. I welcome  concrete recommendations for action at a national as well as at an EU level including the increased use of culture in external actions and in the EU development agenda. Through these recommendations, the report recognises the unique role that culture, inclusive learning and active citizenship can play in building strong and cohesive communities.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (ENF)
text: In writing. This motion for a resolution "on the role of intercultural dialogue, cultural diversity and education in promoting the fundamental values of the European Union" is characteristic of the totalitarian excesses of the European Union. It is a very clear call to politicise the sports, associations and education communities, while inviting Member States to legislate to sanction behaviours that would appear to be contrary to the spirit of the resolution. By targeting, without saying so and using allusions, patriots and sovereignists concerned with the identity and sovereignty of their nations, the resolution wishes to close any political debate on immigration, integration and multiculturalism. For these reasons, and to denounce the pernicious nature of this draft resolution, I have spoken out against this report.

name: Bruno Gollnisch (NI)
text: In writing. I cannot resist the urge to quote a piece of the anthology of Mrs Ward's report, paragraph 7: '[The European Parliament] stresses the importance, in due course, of the integration and education of segregated communities, whose behaviours run counter to fundamental European values'. But while we are waiting for this 'time to come', we are condemned to organise cohabitation with these 'segregated communities', which, as I understand it, include all communities except national communities, and whose behaviour would allegedly be a consequence of segregation, when the exact opposite is true. In my country, forty years of the policy advocated by Mrs Ward has only led to the weakening of our national values in the name of absolute respect, even promotion, of the right to difference. This policy has fostered the aggressive demands of groups that, having the inappropriate behaviour mentioned above, not only do not intend to change it, but dream of imposing them on the whole of society. And, in the end, it led to the terrible attacks of 2015, the rise of which was the hatred of host societies that are constantly denigrated, lowered, blamed. It is distressing that some still do not understand that a multicultural society necessarily becomes a multi-conflict society.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report is an attempt to take advantage of the joint agreement of the Ministers of Education, signed in Paris on 17 March 2015, on the need for combined efforts to prevent and combat marginalization, intolerance, racism and radicalisation, as well as to preserve a framework of equal opportunities for all. The report identifies both opportunities and challenges and proposes concrete recommendations for action at all levels of government, as well as at EU level, especially through education. It includes a broad approach that encourages new reflections on the nature and processes of political violence, based on the premise that radicalization is a dynamic relational process and an unforeseen and unpredictable consequence of a number of disturbing events. The GUE/NGL Group had a good impression of the original report. In addition, our group's amendments were contained in the commitments and approved with them. I therefore voted in favour of the report.

name: Beata Gosiewska (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I voted against the report because it shows a very cross-cutting and comprehensive approach to radicalisation and extremism. The solutions proposed in the report violate the principle of subsidiarity in the field of education and go beyond the competence of the European Union. The compromises proposed have not been recognised by me because they are based on overly broad concepts that do not improve the situation in intercultural dialogue, cultural diversity and education.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I, alongside other S&D MEPs, voted in favour of this report on the role of the intercultural dialogue, cultural diversity and education in promoting EU fundamental values. This report highlights the ever growing importance of the need for intercultural dialogue, especially in the light of recent event such as the refugee crisis and terrorist attacks in Paris and reminds us more than ever that Europe must tackle these common challenges and promote its fundamental values.

name: Sylvie Guillaume (S&D)
text: In writing. What are the answers to the terrorism that is dramatically hitting our countries? There are many answers to these answers, but if we want to tackle this issue deeply, we need to develop more dialogue and encourage diversity in our societies. That is why I supported my colleague Julie WARD's report.  Education is a fundamental element in promoting social inclusion. In the face of hate speech and fear from abroad, we oppose real solutions that involve significant investments against intolerance and marginalization. Citizenship education, youth mobility, alternative teacher training and media education are all useful tools to break the deadlock we are in today, and this will have to be accompanied by adequate funding and up to the challenge.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 Given the terrorist attacks that took place in France and Denmark at the beginning of 2015, the report aims to tackle intolerance, racism, radicalisation and marginalisation by promoting an intercultural dialogue in the field of education in EU values. We supported the report because it takes into account the great importance of social justice and equality in building a common approach to EU intercultural dialogue, because it seeks to enhance cultural diversity in all youth programmes but also in the fields of culture and media, because it promotes access to multicultural and multilingual wealth of skills for teachers and , finally, because it urges the EU institutions to broaden their analysis of all forms of radicalisation and political violence in order to tackle all forms of extremism and discrimination.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as I believe that the European Union should try and foster intercultural dialogue, cultural diversity and education especially when we consider the recent Paris attacks and the massive migration challenges we are currently facing. I support the call for the EU to continue the work initiated during the 2008 European Year of Intercultural Dialogue. The Year, which helped raise awareness of cultural diversity based on common values, is important  to help educate people about the values of freedom, tolerance and non-discrimination. Likewise, I was happy that within the report, the rapporteur made specific reference to the cultural benefits which have been given to many young people in Ireland and across Europe who have participated in the Erasmus+ programme. I was also happy to support the call to systematically integrate culture into the EU3s development projects and programmes and, therefore, highlight the need to remove obstacles to mobility for artists, educators, academics and culture professionals. To this end, visa procedures should be harmonised and simplified to encourage cultural cooperation with other parts of the world.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I decided to vote in favour of this report because Europe represents an immense richness of cultural, social, linguistic and religious diversity, In this context, the shared values that hold together our societies, such as freedom, social justice, equality and non-discrimination, democracy, human rights, the rule of law, tolerance and solidarity, are all crucial for Europe’s future. It is of great importance that the necessary means are provided, especially financially, to prioritise the funding of programmes designed to foster intercultural dialogue and dialogue between citizens in order to strengthen mutual respect in a context of strong cultural diversity and to address the complex realities of our societies and the coexistence of different cultural identities and beliefs, as well as to highlight the contribution of different cultures to European societies and heritage , and to effectively manage conflicts.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ This report wants to give Member States an outline to reinforce the importance of intercultural dialogue in education. Though the report aims at reinforcing positive intercultural dialogue, it fails to recognise cultural differences and challenges. Furthermore, by trying to restrict solutions rooted in international law about children’s education, it infringes upon subsidiarity. While the intentions are good, it is undeniable that the report also seems to rely excessively on broad notions. My group and I firmly believe in the principle of subsidiarity and that is why I have voted against this report.

name: Richard Howitt (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This is a debate between those who seem to think cultural diversity is a threat, and the rest of us who celebrate it. To win the argument for mutual understanding, respect, indeed celebration, we need dialogue. That is why we endorse the Paris Declaration commitments to prevent and tackle marginalisation, racism and radicalisation, and recognise the need for inclusive learning to promote integration. An example of this is shown by my recent visit to ‘Fresh Beginnings’, a refugee support centre within my own constituency in Colchester. The support being given to help refugees integrate into the North Essex community ranged from free English lessons to volunteers coming in to break down barriers. What I saw in Colchester provides a much better lesson than what we witnessed in Cologne. I have sought to support similar initiatives throughout my constituency including ‘Luton in Harmony’ and the Stevenage World Forum. So let us see more such initiatives, by supporting the concrete recommendations for action at all governmental levels, contained in today’s report. I am proud the report was written by my British Labour MEP colleague. She is right to conclude that this is the means to create strong and cohesive communities.

name: Ian Hudghton (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ Cultural diversity and intercultural dialogue are at the very heart of what the EU stands for. It is therefore not surprising that the UK Tories joined with UKIP and the fascists in voting against this report. The Tory government at Westminster, abetted by the London media, are leading the UK into an increasingly inward-looking and xenophobic mind-set.  During Scotland’s recent referendum we were told that independence would lead to Scotland’s isolation in Europe; in reality it is our continued membership of the UK which is leading to our isolation.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This report is an attempt to build on the Education Ministers’ common agreement and combines efforts that are needed in order to prevent and tackle marginalisation, intolerance, racism and radicalisation, and also to preserve a framework of equal opportunities for all. I agree with this initiative, because it identifies opportunities along with challenges and makes concrete recommendations for action at all governmental levels as well as at EU level, including the increased use of culture in external actions and EU development agenda. The report puts a particular emphasis on the role of volunteering, sport and arts in strengthening socialisation processes. Therefore, the report tackles the issue of education ensuring the involvement of all generations, in particular through lifelong learning opportunities.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the Intercultural Dialogue, Cultural Diversity and Education Report to promote the EU's core values, which speaks of intercultural dialogue as a process consisting of open or respectful interaction between individuals, groups and organisations with different cultural backgrounds or worldviews. It is important to provide the necessary resources, which would prioritise the financing of programmes to foster intercultural dialogue and dialogue between citizens in order to strengthen mutual respect.  The report is important as Europe and the world face a number of challenges related to globalisation, migration, religious and intercultural conflicts and the strengthening of radicalism. It encourages stakeholders to adopt and update a clear politically oriented definition of intercultural dialogue and advocates fostering an intercultural and interfaith values-based approach in the field of education, promoting mutual respect, integrity, ethical principles of cultural diversity, social inclusion and cohesion. It calls for interfaith dialogue to be taken into account as part of intercultural dialogue, a precondition for peace and a key tool for resolving conflicts, and reducing radicalisation. The Report underlines the importance of integrating and educating isolated communities in a timely manner whose behaviour is contrary to fundamental European values.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report because it seems to me that the news shows the failure of multiculturalism. However, this report proposes to continue on this path. Together with my colleagues from the National Front, we believe that it is important to defend our identity, our values and our roots and to give priority to the cultural diversity of the Member States and not to create, ex-nihilo, a global culture.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. – I voted against this non-legislative report.  This report provided another dimension in which the EU’s scope could be widened in the field of education, external relations, mobility and integration, while promoting ‘EU fundamental values’. This report calls for the addition of intercultural dialogue into national curricula, EU representation within the UN, and the harmonising of visa procedures, and calls for additional funding, all for the purpose of preventing radicalisation and helping integration. Whilst we agree that radicalisation, extremism and integration are issues to be tackled, such issues are to be resolved at nation state level.  We oppose any calls for the EU to influence or interfere with the education and national curricula of Member States. We feel particularly strongly with regard to the exploiting of EU financial instruments and mobility programmes to justify the free movement of people, all at the taxpayers’ expense.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the Ward report, which aims to promote intercultural dialogue in society to promote a better anchoring of the values of the European Union. It is about making Europeans active citizens who are aware of the values of the Union and who are committed to their defence. Education and training are thus highlighted in achieving this goal.  I also welcome the fact that art, sport and volunteerism are also seen as ways to participate in civic life and foster dialogue. Finally, the report calls for the integration of culture into the Union's external policies when they relate to fundamental European values and development policy, which I welcome.

name: Marek Jurek (ECR)
text: in writing. – While ECR strongly supports intercultural dialogue and although this report contains positive elements in reinvigorating dialogue between communities, it has a number of serious faults which prevent us from approving it. Primarily, the report fails to address the specificity and characteristics of cultural dialogue. While referring to EU fundamental values as they are set out in the Treaties, it does not take into consideration existing pluralism in their interpretation, which should be acknowledged and respected. The report seems to neglect that genuine intercultural dialogue requires strong identities of interacting individuals or communities based on deep knowledge of their cultural canons, therefore a good knowledge of history, literature, music, etc. is indispensable. The spirit of the document suggests that a successful intercultural dialogue relies solely on opening up to other cultures by resigning from one’s own heritage – the rapporteur strongly objected to incorporating any references to the Christian roots of the Europe despite tabled amendments on behalf of several political groups. Concerns were also raised regarding the form of the report – the text is incomprehensible and consists of lengthy, vague paragraphs made up of fragments that do not match.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which aims to promote intercultural dialogue in order to anchor the values of the European Union in society as best as possible. In particular, the report calls for support for human rights organizations to prevent and confront extremism.

name: Jarosław Kalinowski (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. "Mutual understanding, tolerance and trust are at the heart of peaceful coexistence, and we are aware of this in our Community, which brings together 28 ethnically, religiously and culturally diverse countries. We are able to work together, take care of our citizens, build a stable and competitive economy, and strive for good relations with the rest of Europe and other continents. We must also promote the ideas of freedom, democracy and respect for human peacocks around the world.  The "Statement on promoting citizenship and the common values of freedom, tolerance and non-discrimination through education" adopted at the informal meeting of the Education Ministers of the Member States of the European Union on 17 March 2015 in Paris expresses this message. The message is that we are committed to mutual respect, to respecting the inviolable rights of the individual: the rights to life, freedom of thought, conscience and religion, access to education, healthcare, work and entertainment. The report on which we voted develops these demands and calls for joint efforts to spread these valuable ideas.  Let us also remember that promoting intercultural dialogue has the opportunity to prevent radical attitudes, political or religious extremism, which is extremely important today. As we draw on our own experiences, let us pass on our knowledge to others who can benefit from it.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. Europe must preserve its culture and identity, which is why immigrants must commit themselves to integration and adapt to the way of life and the social foundations of our coexistence. These foundations are non-negotiable and should not be changed in their openness. That is why I am voting against this report.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report because I am convinced by the growing importance of the need for intercultural dialogue, especially in the light of dramatic events such as the refugee crisis and the terrorist attacks in Paris. I welcome that the report makes concrete recommendations for action at all governmental levels as well as at EU level including the increased use of culture in external actions and in the EU development agenda, recognising the unique role that culture, inclusive learning and active citizenship can play in building strong, confident, resilient and cohesive communities of the future.

name: Sławomir Kłosowski (ECR)
text: in writing. – While the ECR strongly supports intercultural dialogue and although this report contains positive elements in reinvigorating dialogue between communities, it has a number of serious faults which prevent us from approving it. Primarily, the report fails to address the specificity and characteristics of cultural dialogue. While referring to EU fundamental values, as they are in the Treaties, it does not take into consideration existing pluralism in their interpretation which should be acknowledged and respected. The report seems to neglect that genuine intercultural dialogue requires strong identities of interacting individuals or communities based on deep knowledge of their cultural canons, therefore a good knowledge of history, literature, music, etc. is indispensable. The spirit of the document suggests that a successful intercultural dialogue relies solely on opening up to other culture by resigning from one’s own heritage – the rapporteur strongly objected incorporating any references to the Christian roots of Europe despite amendments tabled on behalf of several political groups. Concerns were also raised regarding the form of the report – the text is incomprehensible and consists of lengthy, vague paragraphs made up of fragments that do not match.

name: Stelios Kouloglou (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ In light of the dramatic events that Europe has faced in the past months and years, this report aims at building on the common agreement of Education Ministers to tackle intolerance and radicalisation through the promotion of intercultural dialogue. I strongly believe that education and intercultural learning are crucial to prevent violent extremism. Hence, the report recognises intercultural dialogue as a tool for inclusive democratic participation. It also stresses the need to integrate this dialogue in a transversal way in all EU policy areas, calls on the EU and the Member States to implement interactive methods of rights-based learning and proposes to increase public investment in these methods. Therefore, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Agnieszka Kozłowska-Rajewicz (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Julie Ward's report on the role of intercultural dialogue, cultural diversity and education in promoting the EU's fundamental values rightly cites the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights as the core of European values and draws attention to the links between radicalism, the process of radicalisation and social exclusion, culture and marginalisation.  Intercultural dialogue reduces tensions, facilitates integration and finds the best answers to the challenges of today and the future. I agree that effective intercultural dialogue requires knowledge of one's own culture and other cultures, and that its importance is growing in the context of intensified processes of globalisation, migration, religious and cultural conflicts, increased hate speech. The development of intercultural dialogue should be seen not only as a strengthening of the EU's intellectual potential and capital, but also in terms of security, protection against extremism and terrorism. I therefore support the report's calls for increased mobility of pupils, students and teachers, including academic staff, international cooperation between schools and universities, as well as investment in inclusive formal and informal education. I support the recommendations on preserving cultural diversity in classrooms and staff, as well as on the education of refugees and economic migrants.

name: Zdzisław Krasnodębski (ECR)
text: in writing. – While we as the ECR Group strongly support intercultural dialogue and although this report contains positive elements in reinvigorating dialogue between communities, it has a number of serious faults which prevent us from approving it. Primarily, the report fails to address the specificity and characteristics of cultural dialogue. While referring to the EU fundamental values, as they are in the Treaties, it does not take into consideration existing pluralism in their interpretation which should be acknowledged and respected. The report seems to neglect that genuine intercultural dialogue requires strong identities of interacting individuals or communities based on deep knowledge of their cultural canons, therefore a good knowledge of history, literature, music, etc. is indispensable. The spirit of the document suggests that a successful intercultural dialogue relies solely on opening up to other culture by resigning from one’s own heritage – the rapporteur strongly objected incorporating any references to the Christian roots of the Europe despite tabled amendments on behalf of several political groups. Concerns were also raised regarding the form of the report – the text is incomprehensible and consists of lengthy, vague paragraphs made up of fragments that do not match.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the report on the role of 'intercultural dialogue, cultural diversity and education in promoting the union's core values'.  Socialist MP Julie Ward's original text is an apology for multiculturalism and disregards the European treaties, which stipulate that education and culture remain the exclusive competence of the Member States. That is why the ENF Group has proposed an alternative motion to highlight the sovereignty of Member States in terms of culture and education, to highlight different national cultures and identities, in particular to combat the idea of standardising national cultures in favour of a 'global culture', and to promote civic education and the need for every citizen to integrate the culture of the country in which he lives.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report because it tries to take culture and education out of the competence of the Member States and turn it into instruments for promoting multiculturalism. It also pours into angelism by claiming that migrants can contribute a lot to European culture. Neither the Paris attacks, nor the lawlessness in Calais, nor the sexual assaults in Cologne seem to shake this irrational certainty.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. We were faced with a very ideological text, in line with the Union's crazy immigration policy. This report - carried by a Socialist MP - called for the promotion of multiculturalism as a solution to integration problems.  In addition, it proposed further deconstructing the competence of Member States in cultural matters, by only reassigning this competence exclusively to the European Union.  Denial of reality, blind angelism on migrants, fight against discrimination as the main cause of radicalisation and extremism... All the intellectual excesses of the moment related to the migrant crisis are included in this report, on which I voted against it.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. This report is born as a result of the current situation in which we find ourselves since, unfortunately, notions of identity and membership of the EU are being questioned or redefined. That is why Member States must commit therefore to action to strengthen the role of intercultural dialogue in education. Among other things, this report aims to prevent and combat marginalization, intolerance, racism and radicalisation, as well as to preserve a framework of equal opportunities for all Intercultural dialogue should be seen as a positive two-way process that benefits both sides by allowing them to put themselves in the place of the other. Today we can find several examples of these EU-funded cultural exchange practices, one of which is the Erasmus+ programme, for example. Similarly, we need integrative learning to develop in which differentiated approaches are implemented to respond to specific community needs.  Finally, I consider the adoption of this report of great importance because it presents measures which will help to build a strong and coherent Europe. For this to be possible we need cooperation in policies carried out at European, national and local level.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against the report, which highlights the artificial ideology of multiculturalism and calls for propaganda funding in schools and meddles in national education policy.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Intercultural dialogue has several objectives, and above all promotes respect for human rights, democracy and the rule of law. Education, formal and non-formal, as well as providing funding, support programmes to foster intercultural dialogue and dialogue between citizens with a view to strengthening mutual respect and coexistence between different cultural identities and beliefs, highlighting the contribution of different cultures to European societies and heritage and effectively resolving conflicts. Inclusive arts, sports, education and training activities for all ages, as well as volunteering, are supported to strengthen the socialisation process and participation of minorities, disadvantaged groups, marginalised groups, migrants and refugees in cultural and social life. Europe and the world face a number of challenges related to migration, religious and intercultural conflicts and the strengthening of radicalism, and Member States are responsible for creating and implementing measures aimed at preventing negative conflicts. I supported MP Julie Ward's report because intercultural dialogue as such can make a significant contribution to improving democracy. It should prevent ethnic, religious, linguistic and cultural divisions. Intercultural dialogue is a tool for inclusive democratic participation and empowerment of citizens, especially when it comes to common good and public spaces.

name: Светослав Христов Малинов (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 By an overwhelming majority in plenary, my colleagues and I approved the resolution on the role of intercultural dialogue, cultural diversity and education in promoting the fundamental values of the European Union. Europe and the world face serious problems related to the immigration flow. The big task ahead is to integrate immigrants and their children into our society, making fundamental European values understandable to them. The new situation requires particular attention and effort towards upholding European values and culture, preserving peace and preventing conflict. I am convinced that education and the linguistic diversity at stake are the basis for this. An integrated approach is needed, including cooperation not only between European countries, but also with EU partners, including UN agencies – UNESCO and UNICEF. That is why I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing \ u2012 The report covers the events of recent months in the Union, where groups of persons who do not accept European fundamental values, intercultural and interreligious dialogue have increased tensions between the population. In an illegal, violent, reprehensible and inhumane way, they have affected life not only in Europe. It is the responsibility of all politicians to ensure in advance that measures are taken to exclude such action in Europe and to ensure sufficient and preventive protection against such action. Otherwise, distrust, resentment and violence will naturally increase in Europe, including among the European people themselves, which will ultimately cause the rise of extremism, intolerance and tension.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on the role of intercultural dialogue, cultural diversity and education in promoting the fundamental values of the EU because I do not consider it complete and documented. However, I would like to point out that intercultural dialogue, cultural diversity and education can indeed play a serious role in promoting the fundamental values of the EU, especially now that, due to strong refugee and migration flows, interculturalism itself is inevitably intensifying and increasing. The European Union must therefore promote intercultural dialogue between countries and people. At the same time, however, both refugees and migrants must respect the core core of the values of the EU Member States in which they are hosted. This means that the EU must fund forms of education in order for all those refugees who remain in the EU to understand, as long as they remain, that they are temporary guests and that they must live and behave with absolute respect for the culture and national traditions of the Host Member States. In particular, Muslim refugees must abandon Sharia practices and respect the national identity, way of life, institutions and religion of the host countries.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. Dominique Martin voted against the report. This particularly damaging text wants to integrate the cultural component as a tool of the Union's external policy, which, de facto, would make it a competence of Brussels, whereas the treaties themselves make it a competence of the Member States. Worse, the text goes further by advocating that migrants are a chance for Europe, because they bring another culture. No doubt the inhabitants of Cologne do not agree...

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report and note the essential role of teachers in strengthening – in cooperation with families – social ties, generating a sense of belonging and helping young people to develop ethical and civic values.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the role of intercultural dialogue, cultural diversity and education in promoting the EU's core values. Intercultural dialogue aims to create common links and bases between different cultures, communities and peoples in order to promote mutual understanding and interaction and is indispensable to avoid conflicts and the marginalisation of citizens on the basis of their cultural affiliation. Freedom, social justice, fairness, non-discrimination, tolerance, represent great wealth and are fundamental for the future of Europe. It is therefore necessary to ensure an open and respectful exchange between people, to encourage an intercultural and inter-faith approach in order to ensure that principles such as integrity, cultural diversity, social inclusion are respected. The European Union must act and condemn any inhuman and degrading attitudes and violations of human rights and so on by the Member States, as well as ensure the full implementation of European and international anti-discrimination rules in its national legal systems.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Europe is at a time when it needs to strengthen its commitment to intercultural dialogue and diversity. By increasing our openness to tolerance and dialogue, we become safer and stronger when dealing with current problems. The understanding of our neighbours, in Europe and in neighbouring countries, will enable us, as protagonists for global peace, to devote ourselves to the problems of human rights, especially those of gender and religion. That is why I voted for this report.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. The report on the role of intercultural dialogue, cultural diversity and education in promoting the fundamental values of the EU approved by this Parliament, and which I have supported, shows that we have been at a particularly relevant historical moment in this area. We must therefore meet this challenge, with a coherent and integrated approach, in which there is greater cooperation between the different policy structures and thematic areas, not only at EU level, but also at national and local level. From the European Parliament we also call for intercultural dialogue to be included in eu external relations as well as on the EU development agenda. Culture plays a key role in promoting democratization, peacebuilding and respect for human rights.

name: Κώστας Μαυρίδης (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Today we live in a multicultural society, in a period of coexistence under the same roof of different cultures and mentality. The EU itself is a striking example. Despite their different origins, EU citizens are classified as European citizens. This approach is an important weapon in the fight against discrimination, racism and intolerance and reinforces, on the other hand, teamwork and tolerance of the "different". The fundamental values of the EU a source of the founding Treaties, values such as democracy, equality and respect for human rights, values also laid down in the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights, highlight the need for intercultural dialogue and acceptance of cultural diversity and pluralism.  This objective can be achieved through the education and education of young people. Education systems should promote healthy and democratic dialogue and citizenship with a view to developing culture as an important peace instrument for humanitarian crises. They must also promote the strengthening of European identity while preserving national and other specific characteristics. Therefore, in this context, I am in favour of this resolution and I would also like to stress that the EU itself must contribute to this effort through specific development and other programmes.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. For me, it is the highest priority that Europe preserves its culture, its identity and its values. These points are non-negotiable to me. There must be no dilution of the European community of values. The rapporteur seems to believe that a change in culture, through the mass immigration currently taking place, is a natural process and would even be enriching for our continent. These views are diametrically opposed to my political positions, so I reject this report.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. Following the attacks in France last year, EU education ministers proposed a text against "marginalization, intolerance, racism and radicalisation". The European Parliament is at least a reminder that these good words require means. It calls for increased public investment in education to truly enable "civic education, integration and social justice" in our schools. The root causes of the attacks will, however, remain unselected. "Radicalisation would be" an "unforeseen and unpredictable consequence of a series of transformations".  Prisoner of a purely communitarian and essentialist vision, this text absurdly opposes "host communities", "religious communities" or "secular communities". Under the veneer of good intentions, there is a support for the theory of the clash of civilizations from which the S and D derives the idea of a "dialogue of cultures" as ridiculous as it is harmful.  I welcome the commitment to more public spending on education, but I cannot bring myself to support a text that completely misses the real international and geopolitical causes of the January and November 2015 attacks. I'm voting against it.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. As current events demonstrate the failure of a multicultural world, this report proposes to continue on this path at high speed. Since it doesn't work, let's speed up the process! Indeed, it is worth recalling the problems of integration, linked to successive waves of immigration. It is a multi-conflict world that triumphs. Is it necessary to remember that cultural policy remains, according to the treaties, a prerogative of states? Once again, the European Union is meddling in national policies by wanting to impose an ideology and by wishing to create a sense of common belonging in such a vast territory, within which cultural barriers are far from being crossed, if only languages. There is also talk of guiding educational programs. Among other things, make them "accessible to refugee children". On the contrary, we propose integration through assimilation into our national values. Totally contradictory, this report affirms a desire to integrate cultural diversity, but proposes a few lines later to "take into consideration" different types of communitarianism. On the other hand, we believe it is important to defend our identity, values and roots, and to prioritize the cultural diversity of states and not to create, ex-nihilo, a global culture. For these reasons, I voted against it.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 It is essential to focus on the development of a generation of young people with ambition, motivation, commitment, through the development of social and civic skills, critical thinking capacity, fundamental to promoting economic development and the basic values of the EU. I voted in favour.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution because dialogue between different nations and cultural backgrounds within the Union is essential.  The resolution will promote intercultural dialogue – so as to prevent xenophobia and racism – while protecting the individuality and different character of each nation.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: Written. – Europe has been gripped by a number of dramatic and violent events in recent months. An unprecedented number of refugees and asylum seekers are knocking on the door for protection in Europe.  In fact, terrorist attacks, such as those in Paris, explicitly aim to disrupt our European society. The European Union is at a pivotal moment because of these events. Concepts and values such as identity, pluralism, justice and equality are under pressure and in danger of being re-enernized.  That is why I support this report, which advocates for our European values and principles and proposes a number of measures to promote active citizenship in Europe. Education plays a crucial role in this. Learning about human rights, promoting a democratic, pluralistic and just society is essential to teach young people engagement, entrepreneurship and leadership in order to build a lasting barrier against intolerance, racism, radicalisation and violent extremism on the basis of the universality of our values.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: in writing – the European Union has recently faced truly historic events. The arrival of a large number of foreigners and their inclusion in life in Europe still reopens the problem of integration not only of adults, but also of children. It is children and young people who are the easiest to enter into the new society, as they learn quickly and naturally and embrace the values instilled in them by upbringing. It is extremely important that the Member States of the European Union generally approach children sensitively, including when learning about other cultures, in an attractive and non-violent way, which can contribute to mutual understanding between members of different nationalities and eliminate growing extremism and disagreements with other cultures or religions in Europe.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report of the Committee on Culture and Education assumes that the European Union is at a stage in history in which the concept of identity and affiliation is challenged, re-defined and defended, with serious overtones due to the diversity of voices and different political perspectives. It considers the Paris Declaration of 17 March 2015 to be a strong resolution that welcomes member states to take action to strengthen the role of intercultural dialogue in an educational and learning environment. The report tries to build on the common agreement of EU education ministers on the need for a joint effort to prevent and tackle marginalisation, intolerance, racism and radicalisation and to preserve a framework that ensures equal opportunities for all. The report also recalls the need to attach more importance to the power inherent in civil society to continue intercultural exchange, so that the role of communities is central to strengthening the social cohesion process. Structural and sustainable support should therefore be provided to NGOs, children's and youth organisations and training institutions, as well as to all relevant organisations and smaller-scale initiatives at Community level. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. This report by Socialist MP Julie Ward invites a European-level reading of integration issues by choosing the promotion of multiculturalism as a solution to this problem. The text proposes to integrate the cultural component as a tool of the EU's foreign policy, thereby seeking to make it an exclusive competence of the European Union even though the treaties make it a competence of the Member States. They are also invited to pursue a proactive policy of promoting intercultural dialogue to combat all forms of discrimination and racism, which Ward says are a source of radicalisation and extremism. Finally, the text is driven by the certainty that migrants can contribute a great deal to the cultures of the Member States, as migration is an integral part of their cultural heritage. This ideological text calls for a negative vote.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Europe faces a historic moment of reconfiguring the concepts of identity and belonging. Radicalisation and extremism are movements that require reflection and action from a holistic perspective. Dialogue and cultural diversity must therefore be integrated across all public policies. Pluralistic, non-discriminatory, tolerant and just societies based on solidarity and equality between men and women are the basic principles of the European project and modern societies.  I believe that intercultural dialogue should be included in the Union's external relations, such as soft power, in order to promote the protection of cultural diversity. I also believe in the importance of mobility and exchanges to promote contact between cultures. Education, volunteering, sport and the involvement of civil society are also powerful tools for social cohesion.  I vote in favour of this report because I believe that citizenship is an instrument against intolerance, marginalisation, racism and radicalisation.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This Ward report aims to promote multiculturalism as a solution to integration problems. This text is an example of a denial of reality, as it proposes to integrate the cultural component into the EU's foreign policy to make it an exclusive competence of the European Union, which is contrary to EU primary law.  States are encouraged to promote intercultural dialogue to combat discrimination and racism... The icing on the cake is that the rapporteur firmly believes that migrants are sources of cultural enrichment. This text falls very badly in view of the recent events in Cologne and other German cities...  Considering that culture and education must remain the exclusive competence of sovereign states, as well as integration policy, but also that this report is completely shameful since a multicultural society can only be a multi-conflict society, I have obviously voted against this text.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Together with my Labour colleagues, I voted in favour of the report on ‘the role of intercultural dialogue, cultural diversity and education in promoting EU fundamental values’ because I am convinced by the growing importance of the need for intercultural dialogue, especially in the light of dramatic events such as the refugee crisis and the terrorist attacks in Paris which remind us more than ever that Europe must tackle these common challenges and promote its fundamental values. I welcome the fact that the report identifies opportunities along with challenges and makes concrete recommendations for action at all governmental levels as well as at EU level including the increased use of culture in external actions and in the EU development agenda, recognising the unique role that culture, inclusive learning and active citizenship can play in building strong, confident, resilient and cohesive communities of the future.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which aims to promote intercultural dialogue in society in order to promote a better anchoring of the values of the European Union. It is about making Europeans active citizens who are aware of the values of the Union and who are committed to their defence. Education and training are thus highlighted in achieving this goal. Art, sport and volunteerism are also seen as ways to participate in civic life and foster dialogue. In particular, I have endorsed the provisions which call for the integration of culture into the Union's external policies when they relate to the fundamental values of Europe.

name: Luigi Morgano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Europe, the world, is facing many difficult challenges related to globalisation, migration, the growth of a dangerous, violent radicalism that has dramatically bloodied European cities, especially Paris. In order to combat extremism in all its forms, intercultural dialogue is one of the main instruments for improving mutual understanding and promoting common European values: peace, freedom, equality, respect for rights, democracy. Values that undersea our societies originate from the extraordinary richness of cultural and linguistic diversity that characterizes our continent. It is therefore essential to 'structure' intercultural dialogue according to an intercultural, more than multicultural approach, actively involving the whole of society: not only educators – particularly in the fields of education, culture and sport – and public authorities, but also families, the primary place of transmission of values, the media, churches, associations, religious and voluntary communities.
