Starting, therefore, from a culture that is truly inclusive and at the same time aware of its history. A truly fruitful intercultural dialogue, which creates mutual respect and understanding, requires a deep knowledge of one's own history, its cultural roots and traditions, the fundamental values underlying our common European culture and which, objectively, derive to a large extent from Europe's Christian roots.

name: Renaud Muselier (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on intercultural dialogue, which highlighted the importance of promoting a better dissemination of the values of the European Union and supporting the role of education, training, art, sport and volunteerism.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Paris Declaration of 17 March 2015 required Member States to welcome in order to strengthen the role of intercultural dialogue in education and learning environments, at this historic moment when the concepts of identity and belonging are challenged, reworked and defended. I support Mr Ward's report because it represents an attempt to follow up the common conviction expressed by EU education ministers that efforts must be combined to prevent and tackle marginalisation, intolerance, racism and radicalisation, as well as preserving a framework of equal opportunities for all. The report identifies opportunities and challenges and proposes concrete recommendations for action at all levels of government and at EU level, first and for all taking greater account of culture in external actions and on the EU's development agenda.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In recent years, the European Union has not only expanded with Member States, but has also enriched many new nationalityes, cultures, religions, customs and customs. Values such as democracy, human rights, equality or non-discrimination are of particular importance. The report I support aims to strengthen the role of intercultural dialogue, cultural diversity and education. To achieve this, it draws attention to the use of tools such as the mobility of young teachers and students, inter-school cooperation and intercultural dialogue on social media. I believe that the report has a major role to play in the development of a strong, cohesive and flexible European community.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. – I have voted for this report that supports education policies as the main vehicle for building reliable and cohesive communities of the future, as well as for preparing them for active citizenship.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported this report by vote, as I am convinced that the cultural component must be at the heart of the EU and its fundamental values must be promoted through the role of intercultural dialogue, cultural diversity and education. The common values that structure all Member States, such as freedom, social justice, equality, etc., are and will continue to be the future of Europe.  In this respect, today's report shows how important it is for Member States to protect and promote cultural heritage by adopting harmonised legislation and international agreements, in close cooperation with UNESCO. I also welcome the report's proposal that the European Commission, together with the Member States, should continue and prioritise initiatives to support cultural diversity, intercultural dialogue and education through the Erasmus, Europe for Citizens, Creative Europe and Horizon 2020 programmes, the European Neighbourhood Policy, etc., these initiatives being absolutely beneficial for the integration and preservation of European cultural heritage.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I voted against this report because the report forces European citizens to adapt to migrants and refugees. Migrants and refugees, on the other hand, are not asked by the report to adapt to our culture. On the contrary, it calls for European children to get to know different cultures from an early age and to celebrate the holidays of Muslim society. The rapporteur therefore sees mass migration as positive and does not recognise the dangers it entails for our values and our culture.

name: Younous Omarjee (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which promotes cultural and intercultural dialogue as a tool for democratic participation, the development of civic education and social integration to encourage a sense of common belonging and to avoid the excesses of radicalisation and racism.  The report calls for increased public investment in education and reminds us of the essential role of teachers in boosting a European consciousness among young people. The report also calls on EU Member States to cooperate more to make learning and schooling accessible to refugee children, as well as to ensure the integration of migrant students in Europe.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The report points out that the increasing number of violent attacks and ever-increasing extremism in recent times stem from cultural, social and economic exclusion in society. Intercultural dialogue and diversity must be integrated into all policy areas, including the EU's external relations, and there is also a need to focus on young people, make learning available and provide better conditions for teachers and young people. To achieve all this, greater cooperation is needed at all levels – between governments, municipalities, communities, religious associations, researchers and others.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative report.  This report provided another dimension in which the EU’s scope could be widened in the field of education, external relations, mobility and integration, while promoting ‘EU fundamental values’. This report calls for the addition of intercultural dialogue into national curricula, EU representation within the UN, and the harmonising of visa procedures, and calls for additional funding, all for the purpose of preventing radicalisation and helping integration. Whilst we agree that radicalisation, extremism and integration are issues to be tackled, such issues are to be resolved at nation state level.  We oppose any calls for the EU to influence or interfere with the education and national curricula of Member States. We feel particularly strongly with regard to the exploiting of EU financial instruments and mobility programmes to justify the free movement of people, all at the taxpayers’ expense. .

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The commitment of the European institutions to protecting the role of intercultural dialogue and cultural diversity is crucial, and I am happy to be able to contribute with my positive vote. In recent years, therefore, the European Union has gone through a particular moment in history when the concepts of identity and belonging have been challenged, and it is therefore in our interests to be able to emerge from this condition.

name: Eva Paunova (PPE)
text: in writing. – As elaborated in the report, the EU fundamental values of human dignity, liberty, democracy, equality, the rule of law and respect for human rights are represented through intercultural dialogue, cultural diversity and education. Aiming towards pluralistic, non-discriminatory, tolerant societies, the education policies of the Member States have to be shaped in this way. As a founder of the Education Bulgaria 2030 project, I am a keen supporter and advocate for education policies that are adjusted to today’s reality, challenges and environment. That is why I voted in favour of the report

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. In a total denial of reality, the text proposes to integrate the cultural component as a tool of the Union's foreign policy - thereby seeking to make it an exclusive competence of the European Union, even though the treaties make it a competence of the Member States. They are also invited to pursue a proactive policy of promoting intercultural dialogue to combat all forms of discrimination and racism, which are genuine sources of radicalisation and extremism. Finally, the text is driven by the certainty that migrants can contribute a great deal to the cultures of the Member States, as migration is an integral part of their cultural heritage. This report is yet another propaganda logorrhea unrelated to reality. Of course, I decided to vote against it.

name: Pina Picierno (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union represents an immense wealth for its cultural, social and linguistic diversity. In this context, preserving the common values that unite our societies such as freedom, democracy, human rights, tolerance and solidarity becomes crucial to its advancement. The many current challenges, including immigration, the dangers of radicalisation, rising inequalities and the violence of populist policies, require a common effort to avoid a closed society in which a sense of citizen belonging and the capacity for collective reaction are eroded. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that strengthening intercultural dialogue can make a significant contribution to building a plural and inclusive society. Promoting cultural pluralism is important for improving democracy and laying the foundations for a new culture of citizenship, which will shape a European collective consciousness. Intercultural dialogue can therefore be the privileged place for understanding and developing innovative democratic practices, as well as a vector of a new level of unity within the Union.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ The European Union approach should take into account and continue the excellent work launched in 2008, which marked the European Year of Intercultural Dialogue, strengthening the exchange of good practices and promoting a new structured dialogue with all stakeholders in intercultural and interfaith issues. In the field of education, we need to foster an intercultural and interfaith, values-based approach to promote mutual respect. Interfaith dialogue should be taken into account as part of intercultural dialogue, which is a precondition for peace and a key tool for resolving conflicts. It is necessary to train and prepare future generations for audacious problem solving and to effectively and innovatively address the challenges that European citizens will face in the future. Of particular importance and value can be the ERASMUS programme, which encourages the mobility of young people and teachers and all forms of cooperation between schools and universities. This report covers all of these priorities and is why I support it.

name: Bolesław G. Piecha (ECR)
text: in writing. – While ECR strongly supports intercultural dialogue and although this report contains positive elements in reinvigorating dialogue between communities, it has a number of serious faults which prevent us from approving it. Primarily, the report fails to address the specificity and characteristics of cultural dialogue. While referring to EU fundamental values as they are set out in the Treaties, it does not take into consideration existing pluralism in their interpretation, which should be acknowledged and respected. The report seems to neglect that genuine intercultural dialogue requires strong identities of interacting individuals or communities based on deep knowledge of their cultural canons, therefore a good knowledge of history, literature, music, etc. is indispensable. The spirit of the document suggests that a successful intercultural dialogue relies solely on opening up to other cultures by resigning from one’s own heritage – the rapporteur strongly objected to incorporating any references to the Christian roots of the Europe despite tabled amendments on behalf of several political groups. Concerns were also raised regarding the form of the report – the text is incomprehensible and consists of lengthy, vague paragraphs made up of fragments that do not match.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒I support the motion for a Resolution on the role of intercultural dialogue, cultural diversity and education in promoting the core values of the EU of my colleague Julie Ward. The Union, with its 28 members, 24 official languages and over 500 million inhabitants, must pay extreme attention to intercultural dialogue as a process consisting of an open and respectful exchange and interaction between individuals, groups and organisations with different cultural backgrounds or worldviews. Intercultural dialogue is not regulated by national, European or international law because it is not a legal concept, but it is based on international frameworks aimed at protecting human rights and cultural diversity.  Quality intercultural dialogue requires good knowledge of both one's own and other people's cultures. The Union should take into account and continue the excellent work launched in 2008, which marked the European Year of Intercultural Dialogue, enhance the exchange of good practices and promote a new structured dialogue with all stakeholders in intercultural and interfaith issues in the context of all recent dramatic events: European and national politicians, local and regional authorities, churches, religious associations and communities, and worldview and non-confessional organisations , civil society organisations and platforms, employees in the fields of sport, culture and education, national and European youth boards, academics and media.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I believe that intercultural dialogue, cultural diversity and education play one of the most important roles in promoting the fundamental values of the European Union, all the more so now that we are witnessing the violent and dramatic events that we have had to face in recent months. Intercultural dialogue is a two-way process in which both sides try each other's situation, leading to greater empathy, volunteering, developing the capacity for critical and creative thinking and, above all, the ability to deal with different views. Erasmus plus and various initiatives implemented by NGOs funded by EU funds can be cited as working examples of this process. I consider it important to continue to support these efforts in order to build social cohesion between people.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Common efforts must be combined in protecting the EU's fundamental values. Preventing and tackling marginalisation, intolerance, racism and radicalisation, as well as preserving a framework of equal opportunities for all, is the key to solving the current challenges. This report is concerned with promoting inclusion, participation and active citizenship through the development of new education policies, such as high-quality training programmes for educators in both the legal and voluntary sectors. In particular, the report highlights the positive role played by volunteering, sport and the arts in strengthening socialisation processes. It is also important to ensure that cultural heritage and history are not used as an instrument of division but as an opportunity for inclusion. Promoting the EU's core values also requires greater cooperation between international institutions, in particular between the Union, its Member States and international organisations such as the United Nations and related agencies, and greater structural and sustainable support for NGOs, youth and youth organisations, training institutions and all relevant organisations. That is why I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The report promotes solutions marked by ideology and goes beyond the european Union's remit, violating the principle of subsidiarity in the field of education. This applies in particular to amendments restricting the solutions based on international law, which grant parents the right to choose how their children are educated. In addition, the report referred to the gender perspective and recognises the LGBTI community as a marginalised community. That is why I could not support the report.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report to promote intercultural dialogue, as it tends to promote a better anchoring of the values of the European Union in society. I am sincerely convinced that the defence of Europe's values requires an awareness on the part of its citizens. This report encourages every European to become an active citizen through education and training.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Paris Declaration of 17 March 2015 calls on the Member States to act to strengthen the role of intercultural dialogue in the fields of education and learning. EU Education Ministers were clear in the joint affirmation of the value of pluralistic, non-discriminatory, tolerant and fair societies, in which solidarity and equality between men and women are integrated without reservation, with a view to realising the EU's fundamental values of human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law and respect for human rights. In fact, combined efforts are needed to prevent and resolve marginalisation, intolerance, racism and radicalisation, as well as to preserve a framework of equal opportunities for all.  Building on the agreement between Education Ministers, this report identifies the opportunities and challenges in this area and presents concrete recommendations for action at all levels of governance, including increasing the use of culture in external actions and the EU development agenda and recognizing its role in peacebuilding , conflict resolution and crisis prevention.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative report.  This report provided another dimension in which the EU’s scope could be widened in the field of education, external relations, mobility and integration, while promoting ‘EU fundamental values’. This report calls for the addition of intercultural dialogue into national curricula, EU representation within the UN, and the harmonising of visa procedures, and calls for additional funding, all for the purpose of preventing radicalisation and helping integration. Whilst we agree that radicalisation, extremism and integration are issues to be tackled, such issues are to be resolved at nation state level.  We oppose any calls for the EU to influence or interfere with the education and national curricula of Member States. We feel particularly strongly with regard to the exploiting of EU financial instruments and mobility programmes to justify the free movement of people, all at the taxpayers’ expense.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. This report refers to the Paris Declaration of 17 March 2015, where Member States are asked to act to strengthen the role of intercultural dialogue in the fields of education and learning. I agree that this is fundamental in addressing the current concerns properly, and has also contributed to the laying the foundations for the promotion of strong, confident, resilient and cohesive communities of the future. I support the need to formulate education policies that address the value of pluralistic, non-discriminatory, tolerant and fair societies, in which solidarity and equality between women and men are guaranteed. I voted in favour of this report because it is based on a common agreement between the Ministers of Education, which defined the need to make combined efforts to prevent and resolve marginalisation, tolerance, racism, radicalisation, as well as the preservation of an equal opportunities framework for all. To this end, I welcome this report, as it states that intercultural learning plays a key role in sustainable progress in the field of active citizenship.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. This afternoon, the European Parliament supported the Ward report on the role of intercultural dialogue and education.   Today Western society and its values are under attack. The tragic events in Europe in recent months attest to this. They take multiple forms, sometimes fatal, but always traumatic. In January, the attack on a Jewish teacher in Marseille, simply because he was wearing a kippah, recalls the dark hours of our history. This act only confirms a resurgence of religious and cultural intolerance in the Union.  The numbers speak for themselves. According to a 2014 report by the Coordination Forum for Combating Anti-Semitism, no less than 109 anti-Semitic incidents were recorded in Belgium, and 1,168 in Britain. More broadly, in 2015, 50% of Europeans thought religious discrimination was a common phenomenon. In this regard, the Paris Declaration (17 March 2015) of the European Ministers of Education already revealed a collective will to combat these scourges by promoting the union's values through education.  Educating today's youth to tolerance is a major challenge, but the European Union has no choice but to take up it.

name: Robert Rochefort (ALDE)
text: In writing. This resolution aims to increase the role of intercultural dialogue, cultural diversity and education in promoting the Union's core values. These levers that develop openness and reflection are a useful tool in the face of the challenges that run through our European and global societies, such as globalisation, migration, religious or intercultural conflicts, the rise of radicalism and extremism.  For example, our Assembly calls for further work undertaken in 2008 during the European Year of Intercultural Dialogue, in order to work with stakeholders to develop a clear and up-to-date political definition of intercultural dialogue. All work must be based on a solid foundation, which will be what such a definition will provide.  Secondly, the european financial instruments, programmes and initiatives existing in the Union must be used optimally. I am thinking, of course, of course of the Erasmus programme, but also of the 'Europe for Citizens' or 'Creative Europe' programmes. These programs exist, and we must take full advantage of them.  Finally, we call for culture to be systematically integrated into development projects and programmes. These proposals seem sensible to me and that is why I voted in favour of this text.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Cultural dialogue and diversity should be integrated across all policy areas, such as policies for children and young people, education, mobility, employment and social affairs, security and home affairs, in addition to women's rights, gender equality and regional development. Strengthened and more coherent cooperation between different political structures is needed, not only at EU level, but also at national and local level. In this report, a particular request is made to include intercultural dialogue in the EU's external relations, in particular in its development agenda. I believe that culture plays a key role in fostering democratisation, peacebuilding and respect for human rights. The development of a dynamic role for culture on the international stage as a 'power of influence', including the promotion and protection of cultural diversity, can benefit the EU and its Member States in their relations with the rest of the world.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I supported this motion for a Resolution which advocates strengthening the role of intercultural dialogue, cultural diversity and education as a vehicle for peace and as a tool in conflict resolution promoting human rights, freedom of thought, mutual respect, integrity, cultural diversity, inclusion and social cohesion. The text emphasizes that genuine intercultural and inter-confessional dialogue fosters positive and cooperative interactions, promotes understanding and respect between cultures, promotes diversity and increases respect for democracy, freedom and human rights, as well as tolerance with universal values. It also considers it key that intercultural dialogue is an EU objective and to invest in inclusive, accessible and quality education at all levels to develop ethical and civic values. It also calls for renewed attention to the promotion of an intercultural society based on solidarity, especially among young people. And it calls on the Member States and the Commission to prevent extremism, such as xenophobia, racism and all forms of discrimination and marginalising, with measures to strengthen Community cohesion capable of successfully countering socio-economic inequalities.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. Intercultural dialogue, cultural diversity and education play an important role in combating religious radicalism. This is the message adopted yesterday by the European Parliament, in response to the increase in attacks in recent months, in a report that follows on from the Paris Declaration, adopted in March 2015 by education ministers.  The voted text underlines the need to combine efforts to prevent and combat marginalization, intolerance, racism and radicalisation, as well as to preserve a framework for equal opportunities for all. This means "increasing public investment in formal, non-formal or informal, open, accessible and quality education." The text suggests integrating dialogue and cultural diversity into all areas of THE Union's action affecting the union's core values. It refers in particular to youth, education, mobility, employment, social and foreign affairs policies, women's rights and gender equality, and trade and regional development. Finally, the text suggests integrating these issues into the Union's foreign and development policy.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 This post is very important. Right now, we are witnessing a cultural conflict, and perhaps even participants. Unfortunately, I am afraid that the report was too late: it was necessary to publish political recommendations and implement practical steps more than a decade ago, when it became clear that not all cultures living in Europe had acceptable European values. I support this report, while regretting that its authors believe too much in dialogue, even with the representatives of subcultures that openly despise European values.

name: Virginie Rozière (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted for Julie Ward's report. At a time when Europe has been confronted with dramatic events and extreme violence in the past months, this report strongly affirms the european Union's values of tolerance, pluralism and inclusive democratic participation. It follows the commitment made by Member States on 17 March 2015 to strengthen the role of intercultural dialogue in education. Indeed, it is the education of young people that prepares the future of the continent and the construction of a plural and peaceful society.  This report calls for a clear definition of intercultural dialogue and a greater integration into our education programmes. It advocates for quality education, guaranteeing social equality and respect for cultural diversity. It also relays Europe's necessary support, through its programmes such as Europe for Citizens, or Erasmus, to civic and social inclusion and to the mobility of citizens. Finally, it recognises the essential role of NGOs, civil, civic, sports and cultural associations, as well as ICT, in dialogue between cultures and within societies.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. I would like to stress the relevance of this own-initiative report and my strong support for it, as I consider the role of education in promoting the fundamental values of the EU to be absolutely central. We are increasingly witnessing growing scepticism about europe's sense of identity and belonging, as well as a growing escalation of extremism and radicalisation, especially on certain economic and social fringes of our communities. To this extent, intercultural dialogue, mutual understanding and education for plurality and diversity are instruments at the service of a culture of peace, conflict resolution and crisis prevention.  Because I believe that this report makes a very correct diagnosis of the current reality and proposes viable and credible measures to reverse this trend, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported this report as a reminder that genuine intercultural and interfaith dialogue promotes understanding and respect between cultures and increases diversity and respect for democracy, freedom and human rights. The text also encourages the development of the use of intercultural dialogue in external relations and recalls the importance of culture and education in promoting the fundamental values of the European Union.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report is an attempt to take advantage of the joint agreement of the Ministers of Education, signed in Paris on 17 March 2015, on the need for combined efforts to prevent and combat marginalization, intolerance, racism and radicalisation, as well as to preserve a framework of equal opportunities for all. The report identifies both opportunities and challenges and proposes concrete recommendations for action at all levels of government, as well as at EU level, especially through education. It includes a broad approach that encourages new reflections on the nature and processes of political violence, based on the premise that radicalization is a dynamic relational process and an unforeseen and unpredictable consequence of a number of disturbing events. The GUE/NGL Group had a good impression of the original report. In addition, our group's amendments were contained in the commitments and approved with them. I therefore voted in favour of the report.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. In 2012 Following the terrorist attacks in France and Denmark in 2015, the education ministers of eu Member States adopted a declaration with the aim of promoting the values of freedom and tolerance through education. This report is on that same line. I voted in favour, because the report has also been improved by the amendments tabled by my political group which reiterate the value of social justice, point to the need to promote cultural diversity especially among young people through culture and the media and promote training in multiculturalism among teachers.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D)
text: in writing. The measures proposed in this report are supported by this report. They set out an integrated and long-term European intervention strategy. They result from the desire to act, from the need to do it now so that later there are no more episodes like the ones we have been watching again.   It is therefore that the commitment to a valued approach to diversity and intercultural dialogue is a path that makes, at all times and even more so at a time like this, a point of tread. The intensification of formal and informal education, as a cornerstone for the sociocultural development of a Europe that wants an extended space of tolerance and respect for difference, is a necessary and consistent response. The report presented points to a path, although it does not appear to be free from obstacles and difficulties, it is capable of contributing to the future of Europe, as it advocates the defence of the common values that hold our societies together, such as freedom, justice, solidarity, democracy, human rights, the rule of law, tolerance and solidarity.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We do not believe in the EU interfering with the education systems of Member States, particularly with regards to integration and tackling radicalisation. We oppose calls for the EU to spend taxpayers’ money.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ President, it was great to see one of my fellow Labour MEPs have her report pass after having worked on it so hard. Naturally, I voted in favour of this report, not only to support my colleague, but also because I believe that it is crucial to adopt intercultural dialogue as a strong and committed objective of the EU through interactive communication within – and between – cultures. There is a growing need for this dialogue, particularly in the light of such dramatic events as the refugee crisis and the terrorist attacks in Paris. Europe must tackle these common challenges and promote its fundamental values. This report identifies the potential opportunities that could be taken along with the challenges, making concrete recommendations for action at all governmental levels as well as at EU level.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ This report on fundamental rights and European values contained some encouraging points; emphasising the importance of defending freedom of religion and conscience and recognising the family as the first place children are introduced to the ‘culture, values and norms of their society’.  However I voted against this report because it ignored the principle of subsidiarity, seeking to dictate what those values were to sovereign Member States.  It also focused on gender ideology and LGBTI rights, rather than rights and responsibilities for all European citizens.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ The European Union is remarkably consistent in respecting fundamental principles that advocate freedom, democracy, the protection of human rights, tolerance and equality. Today, unfortunately, we are witnessing the extent to which intercultural conflicts caused by religious animosity and disrespect for other cultures and customs can reach, and for these reasons it is necessary to take as urgent measures as possible. It is necessary to start from education, i.e. creating a favourable educational environment that includes learning about democracy, the rule of law, respecting their identity and someone else's identity in which young people, especially through mobility programmes, have the opportunity to get to know other cultures that they may not have the opportunity to encounter on a daily basis and thus contribute to the realization of intercultural dialogue. Also, every upbringing begins in the family, and as a carrier of society greatly contributes to the preservation of cultural identity, value system and intercultural dialogue. Let us also not forget the role of teachers, social workers, religious associations that can have a positive impact on the actions of young individuals by teaching them about the true values of life. For these reasons, I supported the European Parliament's resolution, as I believe that in today's times the topic of interfaith and intercultural relations has become extremely sensitive and the value of dialogue and mutual agreements is all the greater.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ I supported the current resolution because I believe that, with the proposed measures and meaningful intercultural dialogue with all stakeholders, we can achieve a deepening of mutual respect and thus preventing radicalisation and extremism within the framework of significant cultural diversity. We certainly agree that traditional cultural diversity is now increasing and Europe is thus becoming a space with an increasingly diverse culture. I am glad that the enlargement of the European Union, deregulation of employment and the free movement of labour, as well as globalisation, have brought many positives for Europe. Unfortunately, I am increasingly concerned that we have seen some negatives in recent periods. The specificity of the last two decades is mainly the migration of members of more distant and hitherto only mediated cultures and subcultures. It regrets that the violent and dramatic events that Europe has faced in recent months and years are creating some concern for European citizens for their lives and their existence. I trust that, on the basis of the concrete recommendations and measures of this report, we will build on the results carried out during the European Year of Intercultural Dialogue (2008) and thus create good conditions for a stronger and more functional European Union.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report under consideration presents opportunities and challenges, as well as concrete recommendations for action at all administrative and EU levels. These recommendations include a more culture in external actions and the EU's development agenda, thus acknowledging the unique role that culture can play in maintaining peace, resolving conflicts and preventing crises.  The report also reflects concerns about the violent and dramatic events facing Europe in recent months. It also highlights the fact that sometimes the cultural, social and economic exclusion of individuals from society may be to blame for violent extremism. I agree on the need to promote inclusion, participation and active citizenship.  Greater cultural pluralism requires active participation in the democratic process at all levels, not only through citizens' participation in institutional structures, but also through the development of dialogue and the achievement of consensus between groups with different interests, different origins and from different backgrounds.  I believe that it is extremely important to provide funds, especially financial resources, to prioritise the financing of programmes aimed at promoting intercultural dialogue and dialogue between citizens.  As a result of the above, I broke the report and voted in favour of its adoption.

name: Renato Soru (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the resolution on the role of intercultural dialogue, cultural diversity and education, because I believe that this text is an effective response to europe's increasingly evident multidimensional and multicultural structure, and because I believe it is essential, in the light of recent events, to promote intercultural and interreligious exchange in an interactive and inclusive dimension. An inclusive society is a society that invests in education that is accessible at all levels, that streamlines bureaucratic procedures for obtaining citizenship, that offers the opportunity to acquire intercultural and social civic skills. Creating such a society means providing future generations with the tools to manage and overcome bold challenges in an innovative way and to combat concretely the social phenomena of discrimination, violence, racism, xenophobia and radicalism. With this resolution, we therefore call on all levels of government to promote more and more initiatives to support cultural diversity, intercultural dialogue and education, making full use of the financial resources and initiatives that exist at European level.

name: Helga Stevens (ECR)
text: Written. – The N-VA MEPs voted against this report. It is a good thing that differences between religions are taught. Education contributes to a better understanding of different cultures and to better social cohesion. However, the N-VA delegation believes that promoting diversity, achieving inclusion and eliminating socio-economic differences requires an appropriate migration, integration and activation policy tailored to each individual involved. Unfortunately, the report before us does not address this.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒Given that Europe is adorned with an endless wealth of cultural, social and linguistic diversity and that in this context the common values that bind our societies together, such as freedom, social justice, equality and non-discrimination, democracy, human rights, the rule of law, tolerance and solidarity, are essential for the future of Europe.  Cultural heritage represents the diversity of cultural expression and must therefore be protected and promoted by adopting harmonised legislation and international agreements in close cooperation with UNESCO. Intercultural dialogue is not regulated by national, European or international law because it is not a legal concept, but it is based on international frameworks aimed at protecting human rights and cultural diversity. Intercultural dialogue can make a significant contribution to improving the state of democracy and developing greater and deeper inclusiveness and a sense of belonging, and I therefore supported the report.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Together with my Labour colleagues, I voted in favour of the report because I am convinced by the growing importance of the need for intercultural dialogue, especially in the light of dramatic events such as the refugee crisis and the terrorist attacks in Paris which remind us more than ever that Europe must tackle these common challenges and promote its fundamental values. I welcome the fact that the report identifies opportunities along with challenges and makes concrete recommendations for action at all governmental levels as well as at EU level.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. Europe is adorned with an endless wealth of cultural, social, linguistic and religious diversity. As intercultural dialogue is not regulated by national, European or international law because it is not a legal concept, it is based on international frameworks aimed at protecting human rights and cultural diversity. Work needs to be done to develop a better understanding of different perspectives and practices, increase participation and freedom and capacity to make decisions, foster equality and strengthen creative processes. The European Union should take into account and continue the excellent work launched in 2008. Sincere intercultural and interfaith dialogue fosters positive interactions based on cooperation, promotes understanding and respect between cultures, increases diversity and respect for democracy, freedom and human rights, and creates a tolerance for universal and culture-specific values. I support Mrs Ward's report because the existence of European values is the foundation of coexistence and development, but I also emphasise the importance of respecting gender equality.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the role of intercultural dialogue, cultural diversity and education in promoting the EU's core values.  There are many cultures in the European Union that are intertwined and complementary. In today's time, when we are facing many conflicts both between religions and cultures, intercultural dialogue is all the more important. Dialogue based on respect, acceptance and freedom of the individual.  However, in doing so, we must respect the legacy of our predecessors and remain true to our beliefs: a united Europe based on values such as solidarity, peace, democracy, prosperity, freedom and justice.

name: Pavel Svoboda (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report on the role of intercultural dialogue, cultural diversity and education in promoting the fundamental values of the Union, as I believe that its text describes the current difficult situation well, while pointing out how to improve it. The text does not give up on the fundamental values of the Union, which in this context include, above all, democracy, respect for each individual or non-discrimination. Under these conditions, intercultural dialogue should be developed as a tool for the peaceful coexistence of members of different ethnicities or members of different religions. Education plays a major role here. One can only agree that "meaningful intercultural dialogue requires a good knowledge of one's own culture and other cultures."

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 We voted in favour of this report because it encourages the exchange of good practices with a view to promoting intercultural dialogue and cooperation between schools and universities in different Member States. At the same time, interreligious dialogue promoting understanding, mutual respect and peace is being promoted, especially at a time of global challenges such as the refugee issue or the rise of nationalism in European societies, challenges that are certainly the afterthing of the capitalist crisis and economic and social inequalities.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 Europe has reached an impasse and yet continues to support intercultural dialogue and diversity in education and culture, putting European citizens in the crosshairs of those who are in fact incapable of dialogue and sharing the same values. Strengthening intercultural dialogue, particularly in educational institutions, can only have negative consequences for society at the risk of repeating the dramatic events that Europe has experienced in recent months and rekindling extremism.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, which lists the challenges facing Europe and the world in relation to globalisation, migration, interfaith and intercultural conflicts and the rise of radicalism. At the same time, it makes important recommendations in order to ensure an open and respectful exchange of views between people and groups with different cultural backgrounds or worldviews in the European Union. I agree with the finding that the European Union must facilitate full respect for the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, both internationally and in its Member States. Furthermore, I support the idea of transversal cultural dialogue and diversity in policies such as children's and youth policy and home affairs. We need better and more coherent cooperation between the various political structures and topics, not only at EU level, but also at national and local level. Finally, I also share the report-makers' view that intercultural respect and acceptance is not only the responsibility of the authorities and decision-makers, but also of society as a whole. Nevertheless, I would like to draw attention to the minework carried out by individual Member States in this area, in which they not only helped the intercult cultural dialogue, but, on the contrary, ran a campaign of inciteration. The European Union must be clear against such overtly hateful activities.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Children were not born with a sense of hatred towards others, these are the emotions and behaviors that shape up as we grow up. It is therefore important to work from an early age to promote tolerance, equality and openness. People representing different cultures, nations or views should come together as often as possible and learn that we are all human beings, in fact with similar aspirations or fears, and only through dialogue and cooperation can we find out. The EP resolution aims to continue the dialogue after the agreed agreement of education ministers after the November attacks in Paris. This agreement points to the need for joint efforts to prevent and combat marginalisation, intolerance, racism and radicalisation, and to strive for a level playing field for all. The EP resolution proposes concrete recommendations for action at all levels, including increasing the use of culture in external action and eu development programmes, highlighting the specific role of science, culture and active civil society in building a strong, resilient and open European society in the future. I have therefore decided to vote in favour of the report on the role of intercultural dialogue, cultural diversity and education in promoting the EU's fundamental values.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union has underpinned dialogue between all relevant social actors and cultural diversity since its founding. Intercultural dialogue is one of the essential tools for ensuring coexistence between the various groups existing at Member State level. Inclusive education is another tool that ensures the participation of all social groups in the process of continuous learning.  In the context of the migrant crisis, which has been affecting member States in recent times, it is essential to strengthen and develop these instruments, which can be viable solutions for de-stressing the situation, through the direct interaction of representatives of the various cultural communities.  The European Union must adopt the strategy of encouraging intercultural dialogue for better communication between different social groups and for the development of innovative ways of investing in inclusive, accessible and quality education. In this way, new social groups will be able to better integrate into host societies and become active members of society, contributing positively to the development of those countries. At the same time, the negative phenomena of discrimination, violence, radicalism and xenophobia, which are rooted in the lack of accurate information on the various cultural communities, will be more effectively combated.  For these reasons, I believe that the current document is an important element for changing the current situation for the better.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted for Julie Ward's proposal. Europe has an immense wealth in terms of cultural, social, linguistic and religious diversity; in this context, the shared values that are the glue of our societies, such as freedom, social justice, equality and non-discrimination, democracy, human rights, the rule of law, tolerance and solidarity, are essential for the future of Europe.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report on intercultural dialogue, cultural diversity and education. Indeed, in a period of troubles for Europe, I believe that intercultural dialogue can play an important role in the fight against all kind of radicalism. In the report adopted we underline the need to combine efforts in an effort to prevent and fight against marginalisation, intolerance, racism and radicalisation, in the context of equal opportunities for all.

name: Patrizia Toia (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 At a time like this, marked by violent and tragic events in Europe, I believe it is more necessary than ever to reaffirm the need to foster intercultural dialogue, through concrete interventions in the daily lives of all citizens. Education, education, training and culture must be seen as keywords in our daily lives. The aim of all our actions is integration and solidarity, especially towards the many children who are forced by war and hunger to leave their country of origin. We also need to give impetus to the common foreign and security policy, not only through cultural diplomacy, but we also need strong signals of social and economic integration, which are possible by extending access to culture and the training of immigrants, with educational corridors for students in refugee camps; promoting inclusion through active citizenship programmes and support for new forms of entrepreneurship.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. The report on the role of intercultural dialogue, cultural diversity and education in promoting the EU's fundamental values was supported, as I believe that, especially in recent months, when there is concern about violent and dramatic events in the EU, cultural dialogue should be integrated into all policy areas.  At national level, however, structural support must be made for organisations in this educational process. Only in this way will we be able to promote respect for human rights and lay the foundations for a more robust, inclusive and pluralistic society that can more easily resolve potential conflicts.

name: Yana Toom (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ The cultural landscape of the European Union has recently undergone major changes. Its society is becoming more multicultural by the day. An increasingly multicultural society requires a platform where everyone can benefit from cultural diversity. This is exactly the goal of intercultural dialogue and it results in mutual understanding without exclusion. Fostering a multicultural society should not only be limited to cultural practices: the importance of language in this context has to be highlighted. Multi-language learning and multilingual experience has to be promoted in the educational system not only when it comes to the official languages of the EU, but also minority languages.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report is an attempt to take advantage of the joint agreement of the Ministers of Education, signed in Paris on 17 March 2015, on the need for combined efforts to prevent and combat marginalization, intolerance, racism and radicalisation, as well as to preserve a framework of equal opportunities for all. The report identifies both opportunities and challenges and proposes concrete recommendations for action at all levels of government, as well as at EU level, especially through education. It includes a broad approach that encourages new reflections on the nature and processes of political violence, based on the premise that radicalization is a dynamic relational process and an unforeseen and unpredictable consequence of a number of disturbing events. The GUE/NGL Group had a good impression of the original report. In addition, our group's amendments were contained in the commitments and approved with them. I therefore voted in favour of the report.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. It is a very ideological report by Socialist MP Julie Ward, who invites integration issues to be used at European level by promoting multiculturalism. In a total denial of reality, the text proposes to integrate the cultural component as a tool of the Union's foreign policy, thereby seeking to make it an exclusive competence of the European Union, even though the treaties make it a competence of the Member States. They are also invited to pursue a proactive policy of promoting intercultural dialogue to combat all forms of discrimination and racism, which are genuine sources of radicalisation and extremism. Finally, the text is driven by the certainty that migrants can contribute a great deal to the cultures of the Member States, as migration is an integral part of their cultural heritage. A very ideological text that can only motivate my opposition. So I'm voting AGAINST.

name: Mihai Ţurcanu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In 2008, in the context of the European Year of Intercultural Dialogue, intercultural dialogue was defined as an open and respectful interaction between people, groups and organisations from different cultural backgrounds or with different worldviews. Intercultural dialogue is extremely important, especially in a framework such as that represented by the EU, the immense heritage of cultural, social, linguistic and religious diversity.  Developing a strengthened interaction between different EU societies is crucial in order to strengthen mutual respect in a context of strong cultural diversity, the approach to complex realities in our societies and the coexistence of different cultural identities and beliefs.  It is therefore necessary to mobilise all means, in particular financial ones, to support programmes aimed at developing and strengthening intercultural dialogue. Dialogue between different cultures is extremely important, especially in the current context of globalisation, migration, religious and intercultural conflicts, as well as the rise of radicalism, with a view to creating solidarity and cooperation in the face of these diverse challenges.  In this regard, I voted in favour of the Report on the role of intercultural dialogue, cultural diversity and education in promoting the EU's fundamental values, which provides for its establishment and strengthening by taking multiple measures at European level.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union is at a stage in history in which the concepts of identity and belonging are challenged, rede determined and defended, with serious overtones due to the diversity of voices and different political perspectives. The Paris Declaration of 17 March 2015 is a strong resolution, which welcomes the call on the Member States to take action to strengthen the role of intercultural dialogue in an educational and learning environment. This report tries to build on the common agreement of education ministers on the need for a joint effort to prevent and tackle marginalisation, intolerance, racism and radicalisation and to preserve a framework that ensures equal opportunities for all. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour as agreed on the general line of the draft report to express support for a coherent and integrated approach to intercultural dialogue, cultural diversity and education, and because most of our amendments of improvement taken on board.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. This is a non-legislative report aimed at promoting measures by national and European authorities, both within the Union and in third countries, aimed at the development of plural and tolerant societies, where solidarity and equality are achieved through the search for European values of human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, respect for the law and respect for human rights. That is why I think it is appropriate to vote in favour of this report.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. In 2012 Following the terrorist attacks in France and Denmark in 2015, the education ministers of eu Member States adopted a declaration with the aim of promoting the values of freedom and tolerance through education. This report is on that same line. I voted in favour, because the report has also been improved by the amendments tabled by my political group which reiterate the value of social justice, point to the need to promote cultural diversity especially among young people through culture and the media and promote training in multiculturalism among teachers.

name: Derek Vaughan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Together with my Labour colleagues, I was proud to vote in favour of this the report ‘the role of intercultural dialogue, cultural diversity and education in promoting EU fundamental values’. The rising tide of hate from both within and without Europe, which has led to acts of violence in Europe and increasing tensions needs to be dealt with. Along with my colleagues I believe that one of the best ways to achieve this is through intercultural dialogue and increased understanding, to promote our values. It is very positive that this report not only looks at the challenges we face, but also sees opportunities in the current troubled landscape. This report also makes concrete recommendations for action at all governmental levels. The report also recognises the fact the EU needs to be robust in its use of culture as part of its external development policies.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. Of course, I voted in favour of this report on intercultural dialogue, cultural diversity and education. More than ever before, in view of the migration crisis and the recent attacks in Paris, intercultural dialogue can play an important role in the fight against extremism in all its forms.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. In the wake of the 2015 attacks, the European Parliament's Committee on Culture and Education wanted to implement a report on the role of intercultural dialogue, cultural diversity and education. Strengthening intercultural dialogue and recalling the fundamental values of justice, freedom, equality, tolerance, democracy and non-discrimination is indeed a necessity in the light of the policies first and foremost safe, even discriminatory, implemented, especially in France.  This report seeks to define concepts from different studies and studies and stresses the need for multidimensional policies and to include all actors. It is based in particular on respect for the Charter of Fundamental Rights.  This report is paved with good intentions, but beyond a few measures that I could criticize, it goes in the right direction. So I voted for it.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report recognises that intercultural dialogue is a tool for inclusive democratic participation and empowerment of citizens, in particular in relation to common goods and public spaces. It considers that, in accordance with Article 167(4) TFEU, cultural diversity and dialogue should be integrated across the board in all policy areas of the European Union. However, it is not whitening the role of the EU and the governments of some Member States and their policies in promoting inequalities, lack of access to public services and fundamental rights, in the production of stigmas, which promotes multiculturalism and tolerance. How can the EU be advocated as a global peace promotion agent, and the EU is one of the ones responsible for the various wars taking place at the moment? Intercultural dialogue makes perfect sense, but if it is consistent ly and properly integrated into inclusive social policies that promote social justice, peace and solidarity between peoples and cultures, that is, the opposite of what Europe does, whether with refugees or with national states seeking their own paths of development.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. For me, it is the highest priority that Europe preserves its culture, its identity and its values. These points are non-negotiable to me. There must be no dilution of the European community of values. The rapporteur seems to believe that a change in culture, through the mass immigration currently taking place, is a natural process and would even be enriching for our continent. These views are diametrically opposed to my political positions, so I reject this report.

name: Daniele Viotti (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I believe in the role of intercultural and interreligious dialogue and in education, as fundamental tools to promote peace, facilitate conflict management and promote and human rights. All this is particularly important in the light of recent events in Europe. We must work above all on young people in order to become members of an open society, which adheres to EU values and which combats phenomena such as racism, radicalism and discrimination.

name: Udo Voigt (NI)
text: Writing. Rejection because "intercultural" re-education and indoctrination programmes for ethnic and other minorities deserve rejection, not support, from the point of view of national politics.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. I rejected the European Parliament's resolution on 'The role of intercultural dialogue, cultural diversity and education in promoting the EU's fundamental values'.  The good intentions of the report do not fit with the ideological solutions that go beyond the competences of the European Union, thereby violating the principle of subsidiarity in the field of education. This applies in particular to the right of parents to decide how their children are brought up, which should be restricted. I also reject the gender perspective and the ideological references to the LGBT community. The report also seeks to harmonise the visa procedure and refers to terms such as 'common fundamental values' and 'fundamentals of the European Union', which I cannot see as such at the moment. As this is a clear violation of the principles of EU subsidiarity, I voted against this report following the ECR line.

name: Julie Ward (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the adoption of my report on ‘the role of intercultural dialogue, cultural diversity and education in promoting EU fundamental values’ because I am convinced by the growing importance of the need for intercultural dialogue, especially in the light of dramatic events such as the refugee crisis and the terrorist attacks in Paris which remind us more than ever that Europe must tackle these common challenges and promote its fundamental values. My report identifies opportunities along with challenges and makes concrete recommendations for action at all governmental levels as well as at EU level, including the increased use of culture in external actions and in the EU development agenda, recognising the unique role that culture, inclusive learning and active citizenship can play in building strong, confident, resilient and cohesive communities of the future. The report was informed through extensive consultation with colleagues in Parliament, academics, educators, NGOs, civil society, faith groups and young people, and I would like to thank them for their invaluable input, and to encourage their use of the final document as adopted without amendment.

name: Iuliu Winkler (PPE)
text: in writing. – I voted for the Own Initiative Report on the role of intercultural dialogue, cultural diversity and education in promoting the EU's fundamental values. I agree that the EU, as a global player, should include culture and cultural exchanges and increase the share of education in its external relations and development policy as tools for strengthening common fundamental values. The report advocates the inclusion of intercultural dialogue in the EU's external relations, including the EU Development Agenda. It is to be welcomed that the rapporteur, taking into account all the concerns inside and outside the EU, aims to boost the exchange of best practices and promote a new structured dialogue with all actors on intercultural and interfaith issues.

name: Θεόδωρος Ζαγοράκης (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this vote which brings EU citizens closer together. The final text has adopted the amendments I tabled as a member of the Committee on Culture and Education, which concern, inter alia, the importance of sport in social inclusion and the fight against social phenomena, the role of the internet and communication technologies and the encouragement of an expanded dialogue at international level.

name: Flavio Zanonato (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I welcome the adoption of the report on intercultural dialogue, cultural diversity and education in the fundamental values of the European Union. I almost entirely agree with the content of the report: it is important to note that intercultural and interreligious dialogue and education are fundamental elements in the creation of a climate of peace and important instruments for conflict management. This is particularly true today, in the light of the tragic terrorist attacks that have just taken place. I agree with the report in particular where it recognises that joint efforts are needed to prevent and combat marginalisation, intolerance, racism and radicalisation. I would also like to point out that it is our duty to work to preserve a framework of equal opportunities for all.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I support this report because, especially in view of the current situation related to the migration wave, I consider it a crucial effort to deepen intercultural dialogue. This can help prevent manifestations of anti-Semitism, xenophobia, racism and religious intolerance. I consider it crucial that education and activities promoting awareness of different cultures take place at all levels of civil society in all Member States of the Union.

name: Bogdan Andrzej Zdrojewski (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Julie Ward's report came at a very right time when, in the face of a wave of refugees, Europe was confronted with the question of how to deal with problems arising at the cultural level, very often simply due to ignorance. The role of intercultural dialogue in promoting the EU's fundamental values should be strongly emphasised in this context. As well as the role that culture itself can play in the EU's external relations. A good knowledge of cultural realities, with a full understanding of their diversity, is an element enabling crisis prevention and an extremely effective tool in resolving conflicts and bringing about peace. An important element to achieve this will be the education of skills by including relevant content in educational programmes, providing training and workshops. However, effective intercultural dialogue also requires financial support. I would therefore like to recall once again the importance of equipping existing, excellent examples of promoting cultural exchanges and intercultural dialogue with appropriate funds, within the framework of EU programmes such as Erasmus+ and the Urban Partnership funded by the Europe for Citizens programme. It is important that, in the fight for cultural diversity and education on fundamental European freedoms, attention should be paid to improving the awareness and knowledge of not only hosts and visitors.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: in writing ‒ I abstained in the final vote on the report on intercultural dialogue. In the light of last year's attacks in Paris, the report seeks to prevent radicalisation and extremism through enhanced dialogues between different cultures and religions. At the same time, it seeks to introduce tolerance and diversity into schools and to strengthen the role of intercultural exchange, for example through the Erasmus programme, already for school-age children, and to make study exchanges available, for example, to disadvantaged populations, marginalised children or disabled children. The report also supports better and more targeted pedagogical training of teachers for situations that will legitimately occur in today's society, also with regard to high mobility within the EU, but also migration from third countries. Educators should thus be able to travel, for example through exchanges, or gain new knowledge of different cultures in lifelong learning programmes. On the other hand, it must be taken into account that the report could, in view of its subject matter, namely the inclusion of intercultural dialogue in teaching, interfere with the sovereignty of the Member States, thereby infringing the principle of subsidiarity, for which I decided to abstain in the final vote.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the role of intercultural dialogue, cultural diversity and education in promoting the eu's core values, as I believe that the report is an attempt at progress on the basis of combined efforts at European level to prevent and address marginalisation, intolerance, racism and radicalisation, as well as to preserve a framework of equality and opportunity for all European citizens.  In this context, I believe that the report clearly identifies both the opportunities and challenges of cultural diversity in Europe and makes concrete recommendations for action at all levels of governance, recognising the unique role that culture and education can play in peace-building, conflict resolution and crisis prevention.  Consequently, I think it is essential that intercultural dialogue, cultural diversity and education become a strong commitment of the EU, so that European citizens can be given access to citizenship education and the possibility of acquiring civic, social and intercultural skills that help them develop ethical and civic values, respecting existing European diversity and combating the social problems of exclusion within their societies.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report adds to some positive aspects a perspective which does not go to the real origin of the problems that lead to extremism, xenophobia and racism. Laundering the role of the EU and the governments of some Member States and their policies in promoting inequalities, lack of access to public services and social and economic rights, in the production of stigmas, the report "advocates that the EU, as an agent for promoting peace at global level, should promote intercultural dialogue".  There is no talk of concrete social inclusion measures but always on integration through intercultural dialogue, and the report is asked to have an updated definition of this concept, which is not understood very well how it will be measured.  Recognizing that intercultural dialogue is a tool of inclusive democratic participation, we must stress that it is not in the context of concrete but abstract inclusion measures. On the other hand, the EU itself, by recalling the eu's supposed fundamental values in opposition to others, particularly when it ingests in countries or rejects the entry of those who do not have eu country citizenship, in practice denies such dialogue. We abstained.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. Intercultural and interfaith dialogue is important at a time when Europe is facing a number of challenges related to migration, religious and intercultural conflicts and the rise of radicalism. Education plays an extremely important role in regulating this challenge.  However, the adoption of different cultures and practices must not be at the expense of the EU's fundamental values, such as respect for human rights, human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality between women and men and the rule of law enshied in Article 2 of the EU Treaty and in the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the EU.  Although the report does not stress the importance of respecting Europe's universal fundamental values, I supported it, inter alia, because it emphasises the importance of family and education for disadvantaged children.

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI).
text: – One of the reasons I did not vote in favour of the report on EU financial services regulation is that it requires things with effect for the future that were already in place in the past and would have been of particular importance in preventing foreign currency credit tragedies. What am I thinking here? For example, the report contains the obligation to inform customers thoroughly when borrowing, as it has already done. It includes the responsibilities of bank managers – they should have done so before – many of them would already be in prison, as well as strong banking supervision. I don't understand why that didn't work either. I asked the Eu Commissioner what the Union would like to do during the debate to help foreign currency creditors in very big trouble and in a tragic situation. Of course, brazenly, as usual, he did not answer.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: Mr President, i would like to begin by congratulating The repercussses of the global financial crisis that took place almost a decade ago are still being felt in the European Union's economy as a whole and in the financial sector in particular, which suffered a major blow, as we know. While the reforms of the financial system, which primarily affect capital markets and different levels of financial services, have been in place for a long time, this path is not yet fully affected. It must be said that the European Commission and all other regulatory bodies at the european union's supranational level and other, at national levels, must work closely with each other to facilitate both the ongoing reforms and the repetition of crises. One of the primary factors that led, by the way, the seventh- to ninth year of the crisis was the inefficiency of the banking system and a weak verification system. It is therefore extremely important to note this decision, which we voted on today. Thank you!

name: Monica Macovei (ECR).
text: – Mr President, the financial crisis has made it necessary to adopt legislative measures at European level. In the process of implementing these measures, there were stumbles, there were differences in application in the various Member States. There were also legal provisions that partially contradicted each other. This report addresses these shortcomings and proposes an impact of the legislative framework outlined and adopted during the financial crisis, as well as the way in which it has been applied in various Member States, precisely so that, after this assessment, both legislation and practices in Member States that have not followed the legislation can be corrected.  This assessment, planning and transparency are therefore needed in the legislative process and for the exact implementation of the measures taken in the context of the economic crisis or for other legislative measures to be taken, after so many years of seeing the economic crisis, that is to say, to adopt measures that are current today.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I have spoken several times about the quality of financial standardisation and governance in the sector. With the report that we have adopted, we are taking a step towards greater transparency in the legislative process in the field of financial services, in order to avoid re-hanging into an acute recession such as that of 2008, with subprime mortgages. This risk is less abstract than is believed, if distinguished economists now advocate an "epidemic" of the energy sector for the possible failure of shale oil companies and if the monetary authorities of the main countries do not take proactive initiatives. I agree with the report and join the rapporteur in his concern about inconsistencies and the lack of uniformity in legislation, in particular the objectives that I hope all the regulators involved will take on, namely financial stability, consumer protection and the financing of small and medium-sized enterprises. As a result, the global competitiveness of Europe's financial sectors, which is also threatened by China, Brexit and persistent tensions in the euro area, must be stimulated by a cultural change in the financial sector that puts consumer interests first with a coherent and risk-based approach.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Mr President, having being here in the last mandate, right throughout the recession, and seen the continuous efforts being made by yourself, Commissioner, and particularly Commissioner Barnier at the time, to get to grips with the problems and to try and put regulation in place that would ensure that these problems did not occur again, it is good that we should now take stock and look at what is happening and indeed insulate ourselves from any occurrences in the future. The last speaker pointed out, for instance, the possible consequences of shale gas for companies and consequently for the European economy. We can take nothing for granted, and for that reason we have to be vigilant all the time. I particularly welcome the creation of a banking union and the discipline that this will bring into the whole banking system, but as pointed out we have to be on our guard continuously for the future of European citizens.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I supported this own-initiative report because I think it illustrates well the fundamental problems that we see in accessing finance in the European market – the Capital Markets Union is, after all, part of this – and compared to access to finance precisely for business development, but also for small start-ups at the level of, say, the United States of America. We must realise that this is a fundamental problem in the development of businesses and the service sector at European Union level. This also undermines investment, investment and the possibility of creating innovation at European level. That is why I supported this report, and I would very much like it to be respected by the European Commission in drafting further legislation in this field of capital market union creation.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
