text: in writing. \u2012 The Capital Markets Union aims to tackle the lack of investment with determination by broadening and diversifying the sources of funding for companies and long-term projects in Europe. To this end, the Commission has proposed an action plan, to be completed by 2019, aimed at facilitating cross-border investments with the ambition of making the European financial system more stable and competitive. The Capital Markets Union, as proposed, does not respond to the particular financing needs of SMEs, which are in need of local banks rooted in the reality of the territory. That is why I voted against, considering the proposed system to be unsuitable for protecting SMEs, while on the contrary creating an even more complex and expensive funding channel.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this own-initiative report as it calls on the Commission to examine the impact of legislation on financial markets adopted in recent years, as well as to encourage the creation of a Capital Markets Union which should contribute to improving the liquidity channeling to the economy.  Thanks to the work of our group, there is no point in this report questioning the consideration of sovereign debt as a risk-free asset. However, we still do not have a risk-free pan-European financial asset, which would be kept with the issuance of the Union's public debt. The hypothetical issuance of Union bonds does not contraviate Article 310 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. I therefore call on the European Commission to take advantage of ultra-low interest rates to create a European Treasury. I also welcome the inclusion in this report of the delegation's amendments on the need to incorporate the consumer and small investor perspective into the Capital Markets Union, as well as non-discrimination on the issuer of the receipt.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against it because it implies the implicit ratification by the European Parliament of the European Commission's proposal on the Capital Markets Union. This proposal, presented by Mr Juncker as the solution to solve the problems of access to credit and financing of the European economy, is a mere strategy for introducing speculative capital into the direct financing of small and medium-sized enterprises. This proposal is absolutely contrary to the interests of SMEs in Europe who need credit to be guaranteed through the traditional banking system and not through increasingly complex mechanisms that leave all the risk to small entrepreneurs, who will now have to become participating shareholders of their own companies. This crazy proposal will cause more problems for small businesses than it seeks to solve, being designed for the interests of large capitals. That is why I voted against this report.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. I abstained on this report, which presents the balance sheet and the issues of European financial services regulation.  The text mentions the need to harmonize this increasingly complex regulation and supports the project of a European public rating agency for sovereign debt. Although I support these measures, I am strongly opposed to the banking union that would result from the proposal to sever the link between sovereign states and banks at the national level. Moreover, this text takes a simple look at this regulation and does not present any concrete and new proposals.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 This European Parliament report, which I voted for, calls on the European Commission to take into account the impact of the legislation adopted in recent years on financial markets and calls for the EU to be protected from future crises. In addition, this report looks forward to the efficiency and effectiveness that legislation must demonstrate in the environment of the real economy. The creation of the Capital Markets Union is expected to contribute to this. In conclusion, the Group of the Party of Socialists and Democrats supports the creation of the Capital Markets Union, with the aim of harmonising financial legislation with the real economy and reducing red tape.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. This text provides few legal elements and concrete proposals. Overall, it takes up the Commission's communications. Two key aspects can be supported: concern about the complexity and abundance of European regulation, as well as the proposed European and public rating agency on sovereign debt. On the other hand, we do not support the idea of severing the link between Member States and their national banks, that is, the finalisation of the Banking Union.  Moreover, the reforms initiated by Commissioner Hill, on the construction site of the CMU, raise a question as to their purpose, the influence of American market players on Europe. That is why I have chosen to abstain.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ The EU Financial Services Regulation will prove to be hugely damaging for the City of London. It blames the financial crisis on lack of regulation, showing a complete misunderstanding of how the financial sector operates. Naturally, I voted against this report.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. Many legislative initiatives in the EU's financial services sector have been launched in recent years with a view to restoring financial stability and implementing the lessons learned from the crisis. I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe that a thorough assessment of the effects of the financial services framework is necessary. By assessing the cumulative effects and regularly monitoring these legislative initiatives, the application of financial services texts should be less complex, understandable and better suited to the needs of small and medium-sized enterprises.

name: Inés Ayala Sender (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this own-initiative report as it calls on the Commission to examine the impact of legislation on financial markets adopted in recent years, as well as to encourage the creation of a Capital Markets Union which should contribute to improving the liquidity channeling to the economy.  Thanks to the work of our group, there is no point in this report questioning the consideration of sovereign debt as a risk-free asset. However, we still do not have a risk-free pan-European financial asset, which would be kept with the issuance of the Union's public debt. The hypothetical issuance of Union bonds does not contraviate Article 310 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. I therefore call on the European Commission to take advantage of ultra-low interest rates to create a European Treasury. I also welcome the inclusion in this report of the delegation's amendments on the need to incorporate the consumer and small investor perspective into the Capital Markets Union, as well as non-discrimination on the issuer of the receipt.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to review the EU Financial Services Regulation. Since the financial and debt crisis began in 2007 and 2008, it was necessary for European legislators and international standards bodies to take comprehensive action. Since the financial and debt crisis of 2007 and 2008, a number of legislative initiatives have been launched in the area of EU financial services in order to restore financial stability, strengthen customer protection and exploit the experience gained from the crisis. This report assesses this legislative work, addresses the shortcomings in the financial services legislation and raises concerns. I agree that financial services legislation must take into account proportionality, which requires greater attention. Full implementation of existing legislation and strong enforcement in the Member States are also needed. It is important that financial stability and customer protection remain priorities of the legislators, giving greater importance to a coherent and risk-based approach.

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report actually raises questions to be examined in order to facilitate the path towards a Capital Markets Union. It is precurdished by the Commission's Green Paper 'Building a Capital Markets Union' and Parliament's resolution of 9 July 2015 on the Green Paper. These materials, as their title shows, are about the realisation of the Capital Markets Union. The report assumes that, as the Union's capital market remains fragmented, the Commission should take measures to facilitate the development of a single capital market. Some measures are acceptable in order to mitigate the possibility of financial crises, although we must stress that crises are the consequences of financial liberalisation and deregulation in the 1990s and are not about reversing it, but only limiting it to a certain extent. However, the fundamental objective is to create full integration of the Union in the financial field, which means centralisation of measures in the financial field, and thus one of the means of achieving the objective pursued by the Union leadership is 'ever closer union', i.e. the creation of a centralised European empire. I do not agree with this objective, so I rejected the report as a whole.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. This text is only an agreed presentation on ongoing financial regulatory reforms. The rapporteur is careful not to mention the subjects that are upsetting, such as bank separation or the question of securitisation. That's why I abstained.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. In the wake of the 2008 crisis, many reforms have taken place in the area of financial services. The report takes stock and brings new ideas for the future. The report highlights the potential inconsistencies and lack of harmonization of current legislation. He said that initiatives would be taken to address this. It calls for the full and enforced implementation of current legislation strictly in the Member States. Financial stability and consumer protection remain the priorities. I voted in favour of this report because it is essential to learn from the past in order to rebuild viable financial services.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The economic crisis that has developed since 2008 has highlighted all the risks related to a regulatory deficiency in the financial sector. The difficulties of the real economy have been created as a result of the strong shocks suffered by the stock markets, the banking system and all the financial institutions. However, the EU's commitment in recent years to promoting a financial system that responds better to shocks and more transparent has been linked to a non-exhaustive assessment by the Commission of the results of the reforms promoted. I supported the Balz report because I am convinced that we must promote as much as possible the path towards a capital markets union that favours the real economy. The new financial system must be based on a renewed culture and ensure that savers and investors have access to relevant, accurate, simple and reliable information. Initiatives to improve the financing of SMEs should also be extended to start-ups, micro-enterprises and mid-caps in order to promote stable and sustainable growth and the creation of new jobs.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this own-initiative report, which reviews the various European legislative acts on financial services that have taken place in the previous mandate, seeking to assess achievements and problems. In this way, it intends to give some indications in the light of the Capital Markets Union envisaged for this legislature by the Commission. The report welcomes projects such as the Juncker Plan and the Capital Markets Union, as well as being overly positive about the legislative achievements of the previous legislature.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report on the assessment and challenges of the Union's financial services legislation: impact and path to a more efficient and effective Union framework for finance regulation and a union of capital markets. I welcome the Commission's investment package and stress the need for additional financing of companies not based on banks, while noting that one of the fundamental principles of the creation of a CMU should focus more on end-users of capital markets, i.e. , companies and investors.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. This report on the EU regulation on financial services, which takes stock of it and defines its stakes, is in fact a rather hollow text. It takes stock of the situation without any real new proposals.  One can support the increasing complexity of regulation or the creation of a European public rating agency for sovereign debt (so as not to suffer the US agencies). On the other hand, I cannot agree on the need to sever the link between sovereign states and banks at the national level, i.e. to finalise the banking union.  On the Capital Markets Union, I remain reserved, particularly on securitisation or on the real access of SMEs to markets.  With regard to the CMU, I fear that the proposed reforms will ultimately only benefit the American actors who dominate the Union from London. So I abstained.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I do not agree with the Balz report, which analyses the budget and the challenges of EU regulation of financial services. I believe that we need to completely rethink EU legislation on financial services, that some legislative initiative is not enough to finally bring stability to the EU's financial markets. There is a need for radical change, which restores confidence in businesses and consumers. For these reasons, I voted against this text.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this own-initiative report as it calls on the Commission to examine the impact of legislation on financial markets adopted in recent years, as well as to encourage the creation of a Capital Markets Union which should contribute to improving the liquidity channeling to the economy.  Thanks to the work of our group, there is no point in this report questioning the consideration of sovereign debt as a risk-free asset. However, we still do not have a risk-free pan-European financial asset, which would be kept with the issuance of the Union's public debt. The hypothetical issuance of Union bonds does not contraviate Article 310 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. I therefore call on the European Commission to take advantage of ultra-low interest rates to create a European Treasury. I also welcome the inclusion in this report of the delegation's amendments on the need to incorporate the consumer and small investor perspective into the Capital Markets Union, as well as non-discrimination on the issuer of the receipt.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because, in the wake of the financial and debt crisis in 2007 and 2008, it was necessary for European legislators and international standards bodies to take comprehensive action. Since then, many legislative initiatives have been launched in the area of FINANCIAL SERVICES in the EU to restore financial stability, strengthen customer protection and exploit the experience gained from the crisis. Many pieces of legislation have already been successfully implemented, in accordance with the deadlines for their implementation and application, which have already passed or will soon pass. This own-initiative report is a first step towards assessing this legislative work, addressing the observed shortcomings in the financial services legislation and reporting on the highlighted concerns, in particular because the impact of individual legislative instruments and their interaction has not been sufficiently analysed, and the overall impact of all legislation has not been fully assessed so far. The European Parliament believes that important new Commission initiatives, such as the Investment Package and the Capital Markets Union, will lead to better results if they are based on existing financial services regulation, which is effective and effective.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the proposed report on the assessment of the state of the financial services market in the EU.  Despite the many measures taken by the EU since the start of the financial and economic crisis in 2008, which have stabilised financial markets in Europe, there are still many outstanding issues and initiatives in this area. Such are, for example, the Commission's capital markets union initiative and the investment package, which will have to be based on the financial markets regime to be established to this day.  The upgraded regulation should also be friendly to SMEs, key generators of economic growth in the EU, and resources to finance real sector projects should be greatly strengthened. This is the only one that will allow growth to continue and unemployment will be reduced.  Lastly, regulation of financial markets must also be strengthened, which must not in turn lead to additional costs for the real economy.

name: Simona Bonafè (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The revision of the financial services regulation gives us the opportunity to take stock of the situation and to propose improvements in an area which, as the financial crisis has shown, has an increasing impact on the real economy. This report, which I support, has the merit of strike a good balance between the desire to facilitate access to finance and the need to review a regulation that has often proved unsuitable for dealing with current problems and challenges. Revision of the legislation on financial services does not mean that we are moving towards progressive deregulation, but towards better regulation. With a view to creating a Capital Markets Union, too, we need clearer and more effective legislation, but also more transparent and coherent legislation, capable of creating a more investment-friendly environment, and also providing for the creation of new channels of access to credit, from which small and medium-sized enterprises and start-ups in particular can benefit. We need a clear and coherent regulatory framework to ensure financial stability and competitiveness.

name: Mario Borghezio (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report is a compendium of good intentions, some of which we can support but with "distinction" such as point 14, which appears to be intrinsically contradictory. The problem, however, is the absolute silence on the only fundamental prerequisite of good intentions, namely the restoration of the clear separation between those involved in finance and those who have to exercise credit (glass steagall law). Without this, there can be neither savings protection nor adequate credit for the real economy. Furthermore, the report does not sufficiently assess the systems for the non-conflicting settlement of debt disputes and in fact demonises shadow banking (point 26) which was created to remedy the credit shortages found even in the context of large fortunes. Above all, it does not offer concretely applicable measures for risk analysis on derivatives to protect the widespread interest of investors and, in particular, of small European savers.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ I support this Report which calls on the Commission to check the impact of legislation on financial markets in recent years and to ensure further protection of the EU from future crises, with efficiency in financing the real economy and SMEs

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. This report presents few new proposals.  While he highlights the increasing complexity of regulation and suggests the creation of a European rating agency, which I would eventually agree on, he also advocates the establishment of the banking union, the severing of the link between states and banks at national level, and the extremely dangerous principle of securitisation. Therefore, I abstained.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe that the actions taken by the EU in the field of financial services represent an important step on the road to the completion of the single market and European integration. In particular, I think it is important that the regulation in this area should focus more on the end users of capital markets, namely companies and investors.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. The 2008 financial crisis highlighted numerous shortcomings in regulating market activities. It is in this context that this report takes stock and the issues of regulation on financial services. The rapporteur rightly raises serious concerns about the complexity of national regulations and promotes harmonisation of the various laws that govern this sector of activity. We also agree with him on the idea of creating a public sovereign debt rating agency. On the other hand, we consider that the banking union will be harmful to the Member States, insofar as it will prevent them from coming to the rescue of their banking sector if it were to run into serious financial difficulties, particularly in terms of capitalisation. This new legislative framework seems to us to be dangerous for savers. Moreover, the report does not address the issue of the separation of deposit and investment banks, which is the only effective solution to protect savers from speculative activities by certain financial institutions.  I therefore abstained on this text.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Following the financial crisis that occurred in 2007-2008, a number of legislative initiatives were launched targeting the EU financial services sector, with the aim of restoring financial stability, strengthening consumer protection and implementing lessons learned from the crisis. To date, many pieces of legislation have been successfully completed and their implementation has already been carried out within the deadlines laid down or is due to take place soon. I was in favour of this report because it assesses the shortcomings observed in the legislative process in the field of financial services and highlights certain concerns fuelled in particular by the fact that the impact of individual legislative measures and their interactions has not been sufficiently analysed.  I believe that there is a need for an in-depth assessment of the impact of the regulatory framework for financial services and that such an assessment should be repeated periodically.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Following the financial and debt crisis (private, but omits to specify it) that erupted in 2007/2008, numerous legislative initiatives were launched in the field of EU financial services with the aim of restoring financial stability, strengthening consumer protection and putting into practice the lessons learned from the crisis. This own-initiative report is a first step in taking stock of this legislative work, within the framework of important new Commission initiatives such as the investment package and the Capital Markets Union. There is no point in a simple cosmetic operation to a system of economic and financial rules that have made the EU, and in particular the eurozone, helpless in the face of external shocks and the global demand black hole. Moreover, entrusting the Commission with the governance of financial markets (such as the Capital Markets Union) is like putting a fox in a chicken coop. The first and only effective action to be taken is the (coordinated, hopefully) dismantling of economic and monetary union, followed by the dissolution of the Banking Union. I am voting against.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this own-initiative report as it calls on the Commission to examine the impact of legislation on financial markets adopted in recent years, as well as to encourage the creation of a Capital Markets Union which should contribute to improving the liquidity channeling to the economy.  Thanks to the work of our group, there is no point in this report questioning the consideration of sovereign debt as a risk-free asset. However, we still do not have a risk-free pan-European financial asset, which would be kept with the issuance of the Union's public debt. The hypothetical issuance of Union bonds does not contraviate Article 310 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. I therefore call on the European Commission to take advantage of ultra-low interest rates to create a European Treasury. I also welcome the inclusion in this report of the delegation's amendments on the need to incorporate the consumer and small investor perspective into the Capital Markets Union, as well as non-discrimination on the issuer of the receipt.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on the balance sheet and the issues of the EU Regulation on Financial Services. The economic and financial crisis that emerged in 2008 led to the necessary regulation of the European financial sector. Most EU legislation in this area is fully or partially implemented by the Member States. It is therefore appropriate now to consider their effectiveness and relevance. This report calls on the Commission to carry out this first assessment by the end of 2016 and to undertake this exercise on a regular basis.  It is in the interests of consumers, investors and businesses to put in place a regulatory framework that protects them from the excesses we experienced before and during the crisis. However, this regulation must be proportionate and should not stifle the financial sector, which is essential to the Economic Recovery of the Union.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ The Report calls for EU agencies to become more involved in international standard setting (inevitably at the expense of national regulators), accordingly UKIP voted against this dilution of national sovereignty.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report as it is a thorough analysis of the EU Financial Services Regulation. It is true that we need to evaluate and update our regulations in line with the constant changes in the financial sector and these must be coherent, consistent and transparent in order to ensure effective implementation. The report also proposes an interesting notion of a common register which would include references to national implementation of the financial services regulations.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report deals with the achievement of the Capital Markets Union, with the aim of overcoming the fragmentation of financial markets by reducing companies' dependence on the banking system. The text focuses on alternative financing channels to bank loans through greater financialization of the economy (to be carried out through new instruments, such as peer to peer lending and crowdfunding, which away others already known as securitisation). The solution to promoting more growth and employment has therefore been found in the further expansion of finance, forgetting that it is precisely in its predominated over the real economy that the crisis itself has its roots. The proposal, which also calls for greater coherence both within EU legislation and within the framework of the international framework, does not take into account the specificities of European SMEs and the damage that the standardisation of financial products would do them. I have therefore voted against.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 We are in favour of the own-initiative report because it is a first step in taking stock of the legislative work in the financial services sector in the EU and because it helps to address the shortcomings that have been observed in financial services legislation. The report also takes into account the concerns expressed because the impact of individual legislative measures and their interaction has not been sufficiently analysed and because the cumulative impact of the legislation as a whole has so far not been fully assessed. A thorough impact assessment of the financial services framework is necessary and should be repeated regularly.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 The vote on the regulation of financial services in the Union could not have a positive effect. The obvious absence of key references from the report, combined with the lack of innovative proposals, make such efforts meaningless. That is why I have decided to vote against it.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I have chosen to vote in favour of the own-initiative report because I believe that financial stability and consumer protection are a priority for the legislative body's action. The aim of the measure is to address the shortcomings found in financial services regulation. The rapporteur also believes that the current legislation must be fully implemented and rigorously applied in the Member States.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I believe that not only should we not forget the lessons learned from this crisis, but we should not stop observing yet because there is still so much to learn. The legislation that followed in particular the 2007-2008 crisis must be implemented and we cannot afford to relax, because distraction in this sector can lead to enormous damage, which is spreading especially to those who have no fault, and this is not politically acceptable.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The report calls on the Commission services to complete the first assessment by the end of 2016 and to report on the overall impact and, among other things, on the following: the effects on the different financial sectors, including an appropriate differentiated breakdown of the market participants by size, complexity and business model, and on non-financial entities, possible gaps and loopholes , while considering the possible development of new threats and risks; the actual and expected economic effects, as well as the competitiveness of the European financial sector in the world; the possibilities of benefiting the real economy, including SMEs, consumers and employment; the need to further improve existing, and extend complementary, funding channels, including the effect on access to finance for SMEs and mid-cap companies; the effects on supply and demand of long-term financing; the capacity of ESAs to fulfil the tasks given to them under the current legislative framework and on the steps that may be needed to improve the framework, especially the financing of ESAs in the near future.  The first accumulated impact assessment should be used for a targeted examination of the overall financial services framework, whilst avoiding a broad reopening of recent legislation.

name: David Coburn (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ The Report calls for EU agencies to become more involved in international standard setting (inevitably at the expense of national regulators), accordingly UKIP voted against this dilution of national sovereignty.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I support Mr Burkhard Balz's report on EU regulation on financial services and the focus on restoring financial stability, strengthening consumer protection and putting into practice the lessons learned from the crisis.  I agree with the rapporteur's criticism that the impact of individual legislative measures and their interactions has not been sufficiently analysed or fully assessed the cumulative impact of legislation in general.  I hope that the Commission's new initiatives, such as the Investment Package and the Capital Markets Union, will be built on the basis of existing financial services regulations, which work effectively and efficiently.  I underline the rapporteur's concern that financial services legislation meets the principle of proportionality, and that more attention should be paid to SMEs and sme funding. The implementation of financial services legislation should be less complex, more comprehensible and better adapted to the needs of small and medium-sized enterprises.  It is essential that financial stability and consumer protection remain the priorities of legislators and greater relevance should be given to the implementation of a risk-based approach.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The real competitiveness of Eu ropean legislation and the Financial Sectors of the European Union is a crucial challenge for financial services regulation. This regulation should be consistent and proportionate, especially in relation to current initiatives on SMEs and the financing of SMEs. There is still a lack of information about their financial situation in the latter, and this is one of the main obstacles to investment. Having said that, I felt I had to vote in favour of this own-initiative report and I hope that healthy financial stability can soon be restored, especially by strengthening consumer protection, encouraging investment and putting into practice the lessons learned from the crisis.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Since the financial crisis in 2008 several legislative initiatives in the field of EU financial services have been launched to restore financial stability, to strengthen customer protection and to implement the lessons learnt from the crisis. This report is a stocktake of these legislative instruments and their overall impact. It calls on the Commission to complete the first assessment by the end of 2016 and to report back on the actual and expected economic effects, as well as on the competitiveness of the European financial sector in the world, on the effect on access to finance for SMEs and their long-term financing perspectives. Financial stability and customer protection need to remain the priority of the legislators. I voted in favour.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The own-initiative report welcomes the Commission's proposal to achieve a Capital Markets Union (CMU) with the aim of overcoming the fragmentation of financial markets by reducing companies' dependence on the banking system.  The focus is on alternative financing channels to bank loans through greater financialization of the economy both with new tools, such as peer to peer lending and crowdfunding, and with tools already used such as securitisation. The latter remains too complex and expensive a channel of financing to meet the financing needs of SMEs, which need local banks that can know directly the territorial context in which the company operates.  The CMU will make the economic system more fragile, interconnected and exposed to systemic risks and new crises at the expense of growth and the real economy. It will not solve the problem of financing SMEs that need stable, sustainable and long-term sources of credit. It is also dangerous and irresponsible to promote market integration in the absence of structural banking reform based on the separation of credit activities from investment activities and real regulation of the shadow banking system. My vote is therefore unfavourable.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against it because it implies the implicit ratification by the European Parliament of the European Commission's proposal on the Capital Markets Union. This proposal, presented by Mr Juncker as the solution to solve the problems of access to credit and financing of the European economy, is a mere strategy for introducing speculative capital into the direct financing of small and medium-sized enterprises. This proposal is absolutely contrary to the interests of SMEs in Europe who need credit to be guaranteed through the traditional banking system and not through increasingly complex mechanisms that leave all the risk to small entrepreneurs, who will now have to become participating shareholders of their own companies. This crazy proposal will cause more problems for small businesses than it seeks to solve, being designed for the interests of large capitals. That is why I voted against this report.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The report on the role of intercultural dialogue, cultural diversity and education in promoting the EU's fundamental values is an attempt to take stock of legislative work on financial services, to try to remedy the shortcomings identified in the financial services law-making process and to try to draw attention to the problems that have arised. The report also draws attention to the impact of individual legislative measures and the lack of an adequate analysis of their interconnectedness, as well as the lack of a full assessment of the cumulative effects of the legislation as a whole.  I fully agree with the rapporteur's position that one of the main challenges for financial services regulation is the global competitiveness of EU legislation and the EU financial sectors. The quality of financial services regulation is also important, which also depends on the coordination, timeliness and transparency of the legislative process. Considering this initiative to be justified, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ An efficient and effective financial services legal framework should ensure financial stability. That is the prerequisite for increasing long-term investment and fostering growth in a competitive EU economy. In this sense, capital markets play an important role in addressing the financing needs of our Member States’ economies. This parliamentary report on the stocktaking and challenges of the EU financial services regulation explores the impacts of legislation on financial markets that were adopted in recent years. It emphasises the need to defend the EU from future financial crises, while being effective in financing the needs of the real economy and SMEs. In fact, a successful capital markets union should enable EU companies of all sizes and at different stages of growth to access EU capital markets in a user-friendly, efficient and low-cost manner. This is why I could support this parliamentary report.

name: Daniel Dalton (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome this report as a useful overview of legislation covering financial services: the assessment of individual legislative measures and the lack of analysis on their impact is particularly helpful. The rapporteur is quite right to identify the global competitiveness of EU legislation and the EU financial sectors as an essential challenge in financial services regulation. As a useful contribution to the debate on financial services regulation I welcome this report and am happy to support it.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 A financial sector as efficient as possible at European level cannot exist without further digitisation of information and increased transparency in the practical use of data and information. However, they must be relevant, accurate, comparable, easy to use, reliable and presented in a timely manner in order to ensure a balance in terms of providing consumers with the information they need to choose the products most appropriate to their needs and to understand the risks involved.  On the other hand, the financial system needs financial advisers with adequate training in order to be able to provide advice to clients in financial institutions and appropriate services.  In addition, small and medium-sized enterprises should also benefit from specific financial education programmes in order to enable them to take part in the use of capital markets and to help them understand the costs and benefits of the capital market for the various services provided by capital market participants.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This initiative report provides an initial assessment of the series of legislation produced by the European institutions in the field of financial services following the financial and economic crisis of 2007/2008.  As a preamble, the European Parliament reminds us that financial stability, consumer protection and the EU's competitiveness in the global financial sector must remain the political priorities in this area. He suggests that more attention should be paid to risk studies. I also share the analysis that Member States have an important responsibility in the implementation of European decisions.  The report calls on the European Commission to finalise its assessment of the measures by the end of 2016 and proposes to look at the economic impacts of the measures taken since 2007/2008, as well as the opportunities that exist to support the real economy, such as access to loans for SMEs and citizens.  Considering that such a quality review is necessary in order to adjust the rules without reopening the basic texts and to plunge the economic actors into an uncertainty that would only weaken them, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported this report, which sets out the European Parliament's recommendations to improve European regulation in the field of financial services. These recommendations will enable the main components of a European capital markets union to be put in place, thereby strengthening consumer protection.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Dangerous fluctuations from falling oil, financial market instability in China and unresolved issues in the economic and financial structure can once again prove explosive for fragile economic growth in Europe and Italy.  That is why, when we think about financial reforms in Europe, we should act with the possible dangers in mind if we were to lighten part of the regulatory framework that the European institutions have painstakingly pursued in recent years.  Today it is time to reread the history of recent years and strengthen those reforms implemented as EMIR and still to be implemented as MiFID II and MMF in a key of economic recovery, which does not mean reducing its scope, but making them consistent with an economy not yet ready for new global challenges. It is up to us legislators to initiate work that makes the Capital Markets Union a winning challenge for all European economies, not just those that have already developed platforms in this regard, overcoming credit problems, especially for small and medium-sized enterprises. For these reasons, I felt it necessary to vote in favour of this proposal.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. Despite good intentions, such as the improvement and harmonization of complex and unreadable banking regulations, this report provides a simple, rather poor balance sheet. It does not devote itself enough to the substantive issues that deserve to be addressed, in order to correct the mistakes that led to the last financial crisis or to enable more effective financing of the economy, in particular through access to financial markets by small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs). On the contrary, the banking union is ultimately supported; however, it is a project that we cannot accept. Not wishing to endorse this lack of ambition and pragmatism, I abstained.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that the text of this report is quite neutral and although it concerns sensitive topics such as that of the Banking Union and whether only euro area countries should participate, balanced content has been achieved. That's why I supported the report. It raises issues that need to be further addressed, such as highlighting the competitiveness of EU legislation globally and the fact that the EU financial sector is a major challenge in regulating financial services.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The inability of the financial system to cope with the economic crisis and its impact have demonstrated the lack of adequate and high quality financial services arrangements for increasingly complex markets and products. The regulatory framework should include all financial sectors, banking, insurance, real estate and securities markets, investment funds, etc. The framework we need will require market transparency, effectiveness in macro-prudential supervision, international competitiveness of European enterprises, promotion of entrepreneurship, effectiveness in removing market barriers, and at the same time allow for a full assessment and/or quantitative analysis of the overall impact and interaction of individual measures.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. The financial and sovereign debt crisis that emerged in 2007/2008 required global action by European legislators and international standardisation bodies. This own-initiative report is a first step towards taking stock of legislative work, addressing gaps in financial services legislation and expressing concerns that have arisen, in particular, that the impact of individual legislative measures and their interactions has not been sufficiently analysed, nor has the cumulative impact of legislation in general fully assessed. This legislation requires full transposition and strong implementation in the Member States. I believe it is important that financial stability and consumer protection continue to be the priorities of legislators. I would like to note that the quality of financial services regulation also depends on coordination, timing and transparency in the legislative process.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I abstained on this report because it does not oppose the banking union.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The dominant economic theory points as the main explanation, and practically unique, for the financial crisis of 2007/2008 the scarcity (or reduced application) of financial regulation and supervision, the lack of transparency and notification. For this reason, we have seen a high production of regulatory and supervisory legislation in the EU, which, its advocates say, will prevent new financial crises from emerging. Pure hoax. Despite the importance of the changes made in this area, the most important steps are to be taken: the separation of commercial banking from investment banking and public control of banking. Only these measures can protect workers and the peoples of the Member States from paying for new "adventures" of high finance. The Capital Markets Union says they want to facilitate smes' access to capital markets as a way of resolving the constraints they face with commercial banking. Its main objective, however, is to increase the profits of the financial sector. Its promoters say that improvements in legislation will prevent a crisis such as the one in 2007/2008. Another scam. We voted against it.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on EU regulation on financial services. The lack of uniformity in the regulation of these services has often led to the discretionary adoption of less stringent rules to attract businesses, with negative results for the functioning of the internal market.  I believe it is essential in this particular area to implement the legislative process in terms of coordination and transparency, in order to ensure the global competitiveness of the EU's financial sectors.  To do this, the ESAs and the SSM need to have a decisive role to play in achieving the objectives of better regulation and supervision.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ the economic and financial crisis of 2007 and 2008 required many measures from European legislators, who had to take a number of measures in the area of the European Union's financial services. This report, which is submitted to the European Parliament, seeks an evaluation of the legislative work in question. Current legislation deserves full implementation and strong enforcement in the Member States. Financial stability and customer protection must become important priorities for legislators, with greater emphasis to be placed on applying a consistent risk-based approach.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The inability of the financial system to cope with the economic crisis and its impact have highlighted the lack of adequate and high-quality financial services arrangements for increasingly complex markets and their products. The regulatory framework should include all financial sectors, banking, insurance, real estate and securities markets, investment funds, etc. and should impose market transparency, effectiveness in macro-prudential supervision, international competitiveness of European enterprises, promotion of entrepreneurship, effectiveness in removing market barriers, while providing the means for a full assessment and/or quantitative analysis of the overall impact and interaction of individual measures. For these reasons, I am voting in favour of the report on the assessment and challenges of EU regulation on financial services.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Although we have an ambitious reform agenda for the EU financial sector that has been launched to strengthen financial regulation and supervision against the background of the 2007-2008 financial crisis, the transposition and implementation of the financial regulatory reform is still ongoing and not yet completed.  Therefore, I welcome the purpose of the report to ensure that the legislation on financial markets continues to defend the EU from future crises while being effective and efficient in financing the real economy and SMEs.   I believe that the creation of the Capital Markets Union should further strengthen this process, as it is an improvement in channelling funding to the real economy. An efficient and effective financial services framework ensuring financial stability is a prerequisite for increasing (long-term) investment and fostering growth in a competitive European economy. But I have to underline, taking into account the importance of the international framework for the EU framework, that we need to increase the EU’s influence and promote the legislation we have adopted through a democratic process. I welcome the creation of a European Public Rating Agency and I stress the objective of maintaining the highest investor protection standards across markets.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The financial and debt crisis that erupted during 2007/2008 required comprehensive action by European legislators and international standard-legislators. Since then, a number of legislative initiatives have been launched in the field of financial services in the EU aimed at restoring financial stability, strengthening consumer protection and implementing the lessons of the crisis. Many pieces of legislation have already been successfully passed and implementation and application deadlines have already been or will soon be met.  This own-initiative report is the first step towards an overview of this legislative work, address the shortcomings identified in the legislation on financial services and respond to concerns expressed in particular because the effects of individual legislative measures and their interactions have not been sufficiently analysed and the cumulative impact of general legislation has not yet been fully assessed.  In my opinion, important new Commission initiatives, such as the Investment Package and the Capital Markets Union, can achieve better results if they are based on existing financial services legislation, which works effectively and effectively.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report which aims to assess the EU's legislative work on financial services in order to address the deficiencies identified. Financial stability and consumer protection should remain the EU's priorities in this area, always taking into account interdependencies with international standards.

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it is asking the Commission to examine the impact of the financial market legislation adopted in recent years, as well as to encourage the creation of a Capital Markets Union which should contribute to improving the liquidity channeling to the economy.  Thanks to the work of the Socialist Group, this report does not call into question the consideration of sovereign debt as a risk-free asset. However, we still do not have a risk-free pan-European financial asset, which would be kept with the issuance of the Union's public debt. The hypothetical issuance of Union bonds does not contraviate Article 310 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. We therefore call on the European Commission to take advantage of ultra-low interest rates to create a European Treasury. Finally, the Spanish Socialists have succeeded in including amendments concerning the need to incorporate the consumer and small investor perspective into the Capital Markets Union, as well as non-discrimination because they have an IBAN code other than the issuer of the receipt.

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this own-initiative report as it calls on the Commission to examine the impact of legislation on financial markets adopted in recent years, as well as to encourage the creation of a Capital Markets Union which should contribute to improving the liquidity channeling to the economy.  Thanks to the work of our group, there is no point in this report questioning the consideration of sovereign debt as a risk-free asset. However, we still do not have a risk-free pan-European financial asset, which would be kept with the issuance of the Union's public debt. The hypothetical issuance of Union bonds does not contraviate Article 310 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. I therefore call on the European Commission to take advantage of ultra-low interest rates to create a European Treasury. I also welcome the inclusion in this report of the delegation's amendments on the need to incorporate the consumer and small investor perspective into the Capital Markets Union, as well as non-discrimination on the issuer of the receipt.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the EP resolution on the budget and the challenges of recent financial services legislation: impact and way forward for a more efficient and effective framework, because I believe that the usefulness of a rule is its ability to be effective in solving the problems for which it has been designed. The last parliamentary term ended with unprecedented legislative production in financial matters, as a result of the financial crisis imported from the United States. A large part of it has entered into force, another part is still being implemented. Consequently, the European legislator has a great challenge to take up, on the one hand, to properly verify the functioning of the legislation in force, and on the other hand to complete the Banking Union, with the third pillar represented by the European deposit insurance system, which is more necessary than ever to guarantee European depositors wherever they have deposits, so that the rules are applied uniformly, and that there is certainty in the application and a reduction in discretion.  Equally committed is the objective of creating a Capital Markets Union that expands credit opportunities for European companies, diversifying the source and increasing the competitiveness of the system.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on 'EU rules on the financial services sector – balance sheet and challenges: impact of legislation and ways to a more efficient and effective EU framework for financial regulation and a capital markets union', because I share the basic aim of this paper: we need to learn the lessons of the financial market crisis, and above all to better protect citizens and consumers. Pictured: The sad story of the "Lehman grandma" must never be repeated. Better, applicable rules for the financial services sector are an important step in this direction.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. It is important to learn the right lessons from the financial and debt crisis. With today's report, we analyse the shortcomings identified and account for the success of adopted legislative initiatives. This is an important step towards improved financial stability.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, and support the wider CMU project, especially with a view to harmonise further financial services legislation, to fill in regulatory gaps where needed, to reduce red tape and to ensure it is effective and efficient in financing the real economy and SMEs. We need better regulation, not deregulation, of financial services.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (ENF)
text: In writing. The Balz report addresses the issues of financial regulation since the 2008 crisis. It repeatedly raises concerns about the increasing complexity of regulation and proposes some interesting avenues, such as the creation of a European public rating agency for sovereign debt.  Other proposals, positive at first glance, are for the moment the profession of faith: this is the case for example the access of SMEs to financial markets, which would nevertheless have the advantage of supplementing and competing with financing by banks. However, other recommendations in the report do not win our support: this is the case in particular of the rupture between states and banks at the national level, in particular with the aim of limiting the risks associated with sovereign debt.  We are also reserved about reviving securitisation, since it is partly because of poorly controlled securitisation that the 2008 crisis was triggered. Finally, this report omits the need to separate deposit and investment banks, a measure that would increase the security of the banking system.

name: Bruno Gollnisch (NI)
text: In writing. I find Mr Balz's report rather dull and agreed. Certainly, at the level of the European Union, efforts have been made to restore some order to a financial system whose follies and missteps have been responsible for a serious, deep crisis, and from which we have not yet come out, whatever is said. But this regulation has sometimes stopped in the middle of the ford, as for example with hedge funds or the shadow banking system. At the same time, it became more complex in the extreme, with the proliferation of delegated acts and executions.  But the report is also a failure. Despite massive aid or the European Central Bank's quantitative easing policy, banks are still not playing the game of financing the real economy. The solution that this Parliament is calling for is the creation of a capital markets union, which is in fact for this financing to do without the banks and to bet on the markets, which have nevertheless learned nothing from the crisis. I doubt that SMEs, which provide the bulk of employment in Europe, will benefit.  That's why I abstained.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this own-initiative report, which reviews the various European legislative acts on financial services that have taken place in the previous mandate, seeking to assess achievements and problems. In this way, it intends to give some indications in the light of the Capital Markets Union envisaged for this legislature by the Commission. The report welcomes projects such as the Juncker Plan and the Capital Markets Union, as well as being overly positive about the legislative achievements of the previous legislature.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I, along with other S&D MEPs, voted in favour of this report. This report on stocktaking and the challenges of the EU Financial Services Regulation, supports the Capital Markets Union (CMU) project with a view to harmonising further financial services legislation, filling the regulatory gaps where needed, reducing red tape and ensuring alternative credit channels for the real economy.

name: Enrique Guerrero Salom (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this own-initiative report as it calls on the Commission to examine the impact of legislation on financial markets adopted in recent years, as well as to encourage the creation of a Capital Markets Union which should contribute to improving the liquidity channeling to the economy.  Thanks to the work of our group, there is no point in this report questioning the consideration of sovereign debt as a risk-free asset. However, we still do not have a risk-free pan-European financial asset, which would be kept with the issuance of the Union's public debt. The hypothetical issuance of Union bonds does not contraviate Article 310 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. I therefore call on the European Commission to take advantage of ultra-low interest rates to create a European Treasury. I also welcome the inclusion in this report of the delegation's amendments on the need to incorporate the consumer and small investor perspective into the Capital Markets Union, as well as non-discrimination on the issuer of the receipt.

name: Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this own-initiative report as it calls on the Commission to examine the impact of legislation on financial markets adopted in recent years, as well as to encourage the creation of a Capital Markets Union which should contribute to improving the liquidity channeling to the economy.  Thanks to the work of our group, there is no point in this report questioning the consideration of sovereign debt as a risk-free asset. However, we still do not have a risk-free pan-European financial asset, which would be kept with the issuance of the Union's public debt. The hypothetical issuance of Union bonds does not contraviate Article 310 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. I therefore call on the European Commission to take advantage of ultra-low interest rates to create a European Treasury. I also welcome the inclusion in this report of the delegation's amendments on the need to incorporate the consumer and small investor perspective into the Capital Markets Union, as well as non-discrimination on the issuer of the receipt.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report is clearly in favour of the capital markets union, considering that the EU has an obligation to help businesses (mainly small and medium-sized enterprises) have easy access to stock exchanges throughout the Union. As far as the future is concerned, it promotes direct controls from Brussels to the authorities of the Member States, which we disagree with over time because it in fact completely catalyzes the sovereignty of the Member States and concentrates all the powers in Brussels. In view of our vertical disagreement with both the Capital Markets Union and the accumulation of privileges for political decision-making and for carrying out the checks in Brussels, we consider the voting stance to be appropriate.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of a motion for a European Parliament resolution on stocktaking and challenges of the EU Financial Services Regulation. It also charts the way forward towards a more efficient and effective EU framework for financial regulation and a Capital Markets Union. This own-initiative report is a step forward to address the weaknesses in financial services law-making and to voice concerns on the impact of legislative measures that have not been sufficiently evaluated before being implemented. In particular it rightly highlights the need for a thorough impact assessment of the financial services framework and the need for more proportionality in the financial services legislation with regard to policy initiatives on SMEs and SME funding. I fully support the introduction of an impact assessment by the Commission services as well as ongoing obligatory checks to ensure that the application of financial legislation is understandable and better aligned to the needs of SMEs.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report due to the fact the financial crisis of 2007-2008 and its widespread negative impact were caused, inter alia, by a lack of application of appropriate, high-quality financial services regulation for increasingly complex markets and products. In recent years an ambitious reform agenda for the EU financial sector has been launched to strengthen financial regulation and supervision, restore financial stability and make the financial system more resilient to shocks, limit risks to taxpayers and better serve the needs of investors and the funding needs of the real economy. While the outlook for growth in Europe has improved, full recovery has not yet been achieved. The capital market in the Union remains fragmented, whereas the Capital Markets Union (CMU) potentially offers a valuable framework to safeguard equal access to finance for SMEs throughout the EU and to promote innovative venues for market-based funding. There are nevertheless still specific shortages of credit to SMEs and micro-enterprises deriving also from economic instability and a lack of targeted solutions for the real economy. The capital-market-based context in the United States is often cited, but fundamentally differs from the banking-based EU context, and should not be copied or used as a template.

name: Ian Hudghton (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ Whilst many in the financial services sector have spoken out against various aspects of EU regulation, in reality the events of recent years have shown the potential for catastrophe in the absence of adequate regulation.  This is a well balanced report and I accordingly voted in favour.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome this report, because it is an important first step to address shortcomings in financial services law-making. It is very important that financial stability and customer protection remain the priorities of the legislators. I support the Capital Markets Union  project which will harmonise further financial services legislation, will fill the regulatory gaps and will ensure alternative credit channels for the real economy.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a proposal for a European Parliament resolution on the review of the situation and challenges in the regulation of financial services in the EU: a path towards a more efficient and effective EU framework for financial regulation and towards the Capital Markets Union and their impact, as this further encourages the improvement of the overall financial services regulation process.  I believe that effective financial stability and strengthen consumer protection need to be established and that the legislation in place should be fully implemented and ensured that it is applied by the Member States. This strengthens the competitiveness of European legislation and the European financial sector, while on the other hand it is necessary to assess the impact of financial services whose quality, in the process of legislising, depends significantly on timing, coordination and transparency. I therefore support this motion for a resolution.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. This report provides few legal elements and concrete proposals. Overall, the report echoes the Commission's communications.  We can join him on two key points: concern about the complexity and abundance of European regulation, as well as the proposed European and public rating agency on sovereign debt. On the other hand, we oppose the idea of severing the link between Member States and their national banks, that is, the finalisation of the banking union. Moreover, the reforms initiated by Commissioner Hill, on the construction site of the CMU, raise a question as to their purpose, the influence of American market players on Europe. I abstained.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. – The Report calls for EU agencies to become more involved in international standard setting (inevitably at the expense of national regulators), accordingly UKIP voted against this dilution of national sovereignty.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ This Stocktaking Report is well balanced. I believe it is particularly important, at this time, that the Commission undertakes a cumulative impact assessment of all measures implemented in the wake of the financial crisis. We need to be sure, as we try to build a Capital Markets Union, that rules we have put in place since 2008 address systemic risk concerns while also leaving room for growth and innovation in European financial markets.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Burkhard Balz's report on the balance sheet and the issues of European financial services regulation. Following the financial crisis, many legislations in this area emerged, sometimes in scattered order. The objective of this report is therefore to assess its status in order to achieve a more effective regulatory framework.  I welcome the report's focus on financial stability and customer protection. The competitiveness of the European financial sector and the quality of European legislation are essential issues in the international regulation of financial services. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. This report, for which I voted, was intended to take stock of European financial regulation following the 2007/2008 crisis. It stresses the need to adopt a comprehensive view of these regulations to encourage the financial sector to be at the service of the financing needs of the real economy, and also supports the creation of a European public rating agency so as not to be subject only to the ratings of three major US agencies.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. This report is an inventory of current financial market regulations adopted with increasing speed during the crisis, without taking into account interactions. I can only agree with the desire for more impact assessments and for a review of interactions.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report, as it contributes to the building of a better functioning financial market servicing the financial needs of the real economy by addressing loopholes, gaps, inconsistencies, incoherence and disproportionality.

name: Stelios Kouloglou (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This report is on the legislative work of the ECON committee, in particular regarding the Capital Market Union. However, all the shortcomings in financial services have still not been addressed in this report. Furthermore, I think that this outcome is modest on the future challenges that we will have to overcome. Even if I welcome the capital market union and the EFSI, I voted against this report since I was expecting more legislative work towards a more efficient and effective EU framework for financial regulation.

name: Béla Kovács (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report supports the achievement of a goal whose reality is becoming less and less, so it can only be supported in detail. Some measures are acceptable in order to reduce the possibility of financial crises. It is true that these crises are the result of financial liberalisation and deregulation in the 1990s, and there is no point in reversing them, but limiting them to a certain extent. The main objective is to create full integration of the Union in the financial field, which is one of the means of creating an 'ever closer union', that is, a European Union of the Type of United States, set by the Union leadership. Omitting the catch-up of weaker countries. That would be hard to agree with.

name: Patrick Le Hyaric (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The Capital Markets Resolution supports the current guidelines for monitoring financial flows, boosting them by securitisation and the creation of a large European capital market, without raising the question of access to productive credit.  The resolution proposed to us starts with the supposed advantages of the "capital markets union" (market fluidity, harmonization of rates in favour of the countries of the South). However, this capital union is currently being done without an adequate European resolution fund due to the German opposition. The banking supervision section supports the ECB's takeover of European supervision, without asking the question of the lack of democratic control over this key institution. Finally, the European Central Bank may inject hundreds of billions of euros into European financial channels with its debt buyback programme, but these funds remain blocked by banks and financial players, who prefer to keep them on the stock exchange. It is good that there is a real problem of productive credit in the European Union and access to it, but this text does not address this fundamental problem in any way. So I voted against it.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. Like the other Members of the National Front, I abstained on the report on the balance sheet and the issues of the EU's regulation on financial services. He can be joined by concerns about the increasing complexity of regulation and the need for harmonized, consistent and non-redundant regulation. On the other hand, it cannot be followed on the need to sever the link between sovereign states and banks at the national level, i.e. to finalise the banking union. He makes no mention of the need for a real bank separation, which is now stalled.  On the union of capital markets, we are both in favour of diversifying financing methods and reserved on securitisation or on real access to the markets of most SMEs, which cannot access the markets anyway. In the end, on this CMU project, we fear that commissioner Hill's reforms will ultimately only benefit Us market players, who can shine in Europe from London.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I abstained on this report. It certainly has the merit of worrying about the increasing complexity of financial regulation, but it persists in achieving the banking union, to which I am hostile.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. This report presents the balance sheet and issues of European financial services regulation. In particular, it defends the need to harmonize this regulation, which has become more complex over the years, and supports the project of creating a European public rating agency for sovereign debt. Although I am in favour of these measures, I cannot accept the banking union that would result from the proposal to sever the link between sovereign states and national banks.  I abstained on this text, which also takes stock without any new solution for this regulation.

name: Sander Loones (ECR)
text: Written. \u2012 The N-VA delegation in the European Parliament supports this evaluation report on EU financial services legislation. However, we are less enthusiastic about the fact that the report mentions the 'great steps' that have been taken by the coming into force of the Solvency II Directive.  The N-VA MEPs abstained on the text section in which Solvency II is mentioned. Investments by insurers with a guarantee from the federal government get a more favourable risk assessment than investments that support a Flemish regional guarantee. This distinction, which burdens Flemish insurers with additional capital costs, is inefensible. In doing so, the European Union is making an unjustified abstraction of the Belgian institutional system. A Flemish guarantee should be weighed in the same way as a guarantee from the federal government. Moreover, for direct exposures, this distinction is not made. This provision should therefore be adjusted. As soon as possible. We therefore continue to raise this issue in the European Parliament and in the European Commission.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this own-initiative report as it calls on the Commission to examine the impact of legislation on financial markets adopted in recent years, as well as to encourage the creation of a Capital Markets Union which should contribute to improving the liquidity channeling to the economy.  Thanks to the work of our group, there is no point in this report questioning the consideration of sovereign debt as a risk-free asset. However, we still do not have a risk-free pan-European financial asset, which would be kept with the issuance of the Union's public debt. The hypothetical issuance of Union bonds does not contraviate Article 310 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. I therefore call on the European Commission to take advantage of ultra-low interest rates to create a European Treasury. I also welcome the inclusion in this report of the delegation's amendments on the need to incorporate the consumer and small investor perspective into the Capital Markets Union, as well as non-discrimination on the issuer of the receipt.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this own-initiative report as it calls on the Commission to examine the impact of legislation on financial markets adopted in recent years, as well as to encourage the creation of a Capital Markets Union which should contribute to improving the liquidity channeling to the economy.  Thanks to the work of our group, there is no point in this report questioning the consideration of sovereign debt as a risk-free asset. However, we still do not have a risk-free pan-European financial asset, which would be kept with the issuance of the Union's public debt. The hypothetical issuance of Union bonds does not contraviate Article 310 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. I therefore call on the European Commission to take advantage of ultra-low interest rates to create a European Treasury. I also welcome the inclusion in this report of the delegation's amendments on the need to incorporate the consumer and small investor perspective into the Capital Markets Union, as well as non-discrimination on the issuer of the receipt.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. In the wake of the financial crisis and debt that erupted in 2007, the EU has undertaken numerous initiatives in the field of financial services to restore financial stability and strengthen consumer protection, among other purposes. This report aims to carry out an assessment of this legislative work to implement lessons learned during the crisis and to establish less complex financial services legislation. It also stresses the importance of coordination, temporary planning and transparency in the legislative process in order to achieve coherent and quality financial services regulation. Among other challenges, it establishes the obligation of European legislators to take into account interdependencies with international standards in order to avoid contradictions. In my view, this report will be of great help in amending possible mistakes made in the past or not addressed correctly and using them as a reference for the future.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
