text: Writing. \u2012 I am opposed to this report, which mistakenly sees the causes of the financial crisis as insufficient regulation. It calls for interference in the market for credit rating agencies and other regulations. This would only further harm the financial market.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The financial crisis called for necessary reforms aimed at better regulating the banking system and establishing the basis of stability and restoring trust in institutions. Work now needs to be done on the convergence of financial markets at EU level, in particular to establish a Capital Markets Union that will open up new financing opportunities for the economy, in particular SMEs. It is therefore necessary to complete as soon as possible the development of market securitisation and the revision of the Prospectus Directive in order to facilitate access to small and medium-sized entrepreneurship in capital markets.  This report does not call for market deregulation, but calls for exploring additional opportunities, in order to further improve the financial system with a view to stronger lending to those who contribute to economic growth, so I supported it.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ Financial Services Regulation should now be more focused on rigorously reviewing and inferncing financial services conventions, with the simultaneous publication of penalties and impacts to fulfil prevention tasks. At the same time, the uniform and effective implementation of existing legislation will increase confidence in the union's and Member States' authorities, but also in the legislation itself, which will have a global positive impact. The results of the checks and findings should also be reflected in any necessary adaptation of the legislation. Extending regulation and adopting other new standards may not be effective. On the contrary, it will lead to a worsening of transparency and thus to a more complicated interpretation of standards.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report entitled "Report and challenges of financial services regulation at EU level: impact and next steps towards a more efficient and effective EU framework for financial regulation and the Capital Markets Union" for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament on 18.1.2016, given that this report, in my view , is neither complete nor documented.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I abstained on this text.  We acknowledge some good points, including his concerns about the increasing complexity of regulation, but we cannot accept his idea of severing the link between Member States and banks at national level. So we prefer abstention.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report, which ‘welcomes the objectives of the better regulation agenda; acknowledges the general need to examine the fitness of regulation now and in the future; however, this fitness cannot be decoupled from the functioning of the financial sector as a whole; underlines the role of REFIT in achieving efficient and effective financial services regulation that takes due account of the proportionality principle and in supporting the stocktaking exercise; calls for Parliament to have a bigger role in the decisions and assessments intrinsic to REFIT; recalls that the focus must be on improving regulation, not deregulating; stresses that ensuring transparency, simplicity, accessibility and fairness across the internal market should be part of the better regulation agenda for consumers; stresses also that the EU must not create an unintended compliance burden in the drive to bring about greater harmonisation under the CMU’.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the budget and the challenges of EU regulation on financial services. The aim of the report is to stress the importance of an in-depth analysis of the impacts that legislation has and that have not been properly assessed.  Both financial stability and consumer protection remain priorities, and the report identifies the global competitiveness of EU legislation and EU financial sectors as an essential challenge in regulating financial services.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report confirms that much progress has already been made in overcoming the 2007-2008 financial crisis; Nevertheless, work must continue to prevent future financial crises.  I agree with the rapporteur on the importance of supporting the 'real economy', but we must not forget that the financial sector is the real nerve of this economy. The 'real economy' depends on the financial sector, so we must give strength to both of us to continue on the path to progress. That is why I voted in favour of this report calling for more rules for financial services.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. The legislative changes that had to be made, often urgently, in the wake of the financial crisis and debt since 2007, were in many cases decisive in dealing with very complicated situations. The time has come, however, to review these acts in order to articulate legislation for financial regulation and a more efficient Union of Capital Markets in the EU. I support Mr Balz's report, which points to the need for a detailed assessment of the impact of the financial services framework and that such an assessment is regularly respected. Work must be done to ensure that financial stability and consumer protection remain the priorities of legislators, with greater emphasis on the implementation of a coherent risk-based approach.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. The report is merely an inventory to identify possible interactions and inconsistencies in financial regulation. The report does not contain any firm legislative proposals to remedy identified shortcomings. That is why I am abstaining from voting.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it highlights the importance of financial stability and consumer protection.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. Since the 2008 financial crisis, numerous legislative initiatives in the EU's financial services sector have been launched to restore financial stability. The report welcomes these measures and the future creation of a 'capital markets union', pretending to believe that such a union will solve investment problems, when the sluggishness of investment is actually linked to weak demand for business, which comes from the policies of wage and budgetary rigour imposed on European Union countries.  The proposed Capital Markets Union is effectively aimed at changing the European financial system from the current financing model mainly based on bank credit to one based on market finance. Under this model, banks can resell these debt securities in the form of financial securities on the capital markets (securitization), allowing them to lend by freeing themselves from their risks, while pocketing bank fees. However, it was this securitization that contributed greatly to the 2008 financial crisis.   I am against this text, which is clearly written by the banking lobby.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. The Balz report provides few legal elements and concrete proposals. Overall, the report echoes the Commission's communications. We can join him on two key points: concern about the complexity and abundance of European regulation, as well as the proposed European and public rating agency on sovereign debt. On the other hand, we oppose the idea of severing the link between Member States and their national banks, that is, the finalisation of the Banking Union.  Moreover, the reforms initiated by Commissioner Hill, on the construction site of the CMU, raise a question as to their purpose, the influence of American market players on Europe. With these points in mind, I have decided to abstain.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The own-initiative report is an important step towards the analysis and balance of legislative work for the consolidation of economic and monetary union.  Knowing that the complexity of regulation is also a reflection of the complexity of financial markets, I do not fail to stress the need for further clarification and simplification of the legal acquis in this area. I have expressed my vote in agreement with the priorities set out.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution because it is important to assess the legislative work that was completed in order to stabilise the economy after the financial crisis. This resolution will address the observed limitations of the legislative work and fully evaluate the impact of the legislative measures.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. The financial crisis of 2007-08 led to an ambitious programme of reform of the EU's financial sector. It is now time to take stock to assess the compliance of the new framework with current challenges. We need to ensure financial stability that ensures investment growth, mainly in the long term. Financial markets need to better meet the financing needs of the real economy. However, in this report we highlighted the increasing complexity of the legislation. It is therefore essential that we have a global vision in order to maintain consistency in the current European regulations.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report on stocktaking and challenges of the EU Financial Services Regulation, which calls on the Commission to look at the impact of legislation on financial markets adopted in the recent years and ensure that it continues to defend the EU from crises while being effective and efficient in financing the real economy and SMEs. On a more general note regarding the Capital Markets Union it is vital to seek new avenues and opportunities to renew the European economy. However, I am not in agreement with introduction of the Financial Transaction Tax in all EU Member States

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Since the financial and debt crisis that erupted in 2007/2008, a number of legislative initiatives have been launched in the field of FINANCIAL SERVICES in the EU aimed at restoring financial stability, strengthening consumer protection, learning lessons from and enforcing the lessons of the crisis. The purpose of the Report of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs is to gain an overview of this legislative work, to address the shortcomings identified in the legislation on financial services and to respond to concerns expressed in particular because the effects of each legislative action and their interactions have not been sufficiently analysed. The report is concerned about possible contradictions and inconsistencies in the current legislation and recommends monitoring the informal initiative launched by the Commission in early 2014. An aggregate impact assessment and mandatory regular monitoring of consistency and proportionality will ensure that the application of financial services legislation is less complex, accessible to small and medium-sized organisations and better adapted to their needs. According to the report, the full implementation and strict application of current legislation in the Member States is necessary. It considers it important that financial stability and consumer protection should continue to be a priority for legislators and that greater emphasis should be placed on the consistent application of a risk-based approach. I supported the adoption of this report.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: in writing – The financial crisis, which dates back to 2007, has shaken the world economy, including Europe. To this day, the Member States of the European Union are still repercussions, although the situation has deteriorated almost a decade ago. Today, we are witnessing a so-called legislative whirlwind, which, while trying to reverse the negative impact of the financial crisis, may at the same time be a risk factor because of the inconsistency in the legislation, which is signed under the weakening of legal certainty, which forms one of the fundamental pillars of the rule of law. With regard, in particular, to small and medium-sized enterprises, it is crucial that checks are carried out on the coherence and proportionality of legislation and that they are respected in all Member States.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. The Balz report is a rather hollow text on the issues of financial regulation since the 2008 crisis as well as the capital markets union's plans. It merely gives an agreed overview of the situation and proposals following the trend of the texts proposed by the Commission, with few legal elements or new proposals. He can be joined by concerns about the increasing complexity of regulation and the need for harmonized, consistent and non-redundant regulation. On the other hand, it cannot be followed on the need to sever the link between sovereign states and banks at the national level, i.e. to finalise the banking union. He makes no mention of the need for a real bank separation, which is now stalled. On the union of capital markets, we are both in favour of diversifying financing methods and reserved on securitisation or on real access to the markets of most SMEs, which cannot access the markets anyway. For these reasons, it is preferable to abstain on this text.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In the face of the financial crisis that has plagued the European Union since 2007, numerous legislative initiatives have been put in place in relation to EU financial services to restore financial stability, strengthen consumer protection and put into practice the lessons learned from the crisis.  I endorse the rapporteur's position in considering that this legislation needs full transposition and strong implementation in the Member States. I also believe that financial stability and consumer protection remain the priorities of legislators and that greater importance should be given to the implementation of a risk-based approach. I believe that in order to increase market stability, enable non-bank financing, invest in the real economy and deliver long-term sustainable growth, the European Union must absorb the lessons learned during the crisis.  I believe that financial stability, consumer protection, consistent and proportionate regulation, information and easy access should remain the priority of legislators. It is essential to aim for sustainable economic growth to create an environment conducive to investment, extending access to finance and unlocking investment.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This Balz report is an alignment of poncifs and brings nothing new to the substance. It lists the Commission's proposals on financial regulation and capital markets union.  Some positive points are to be remembered such as his concern about the increasing complexity of financial regulation that weighs on the activity, or the creation of a public rating agency.  However, it follows the Commission on the need to sever the link between states and troubled banks, by promoting the banking union whose limits were seen in Italy during the rescue of four local banks.  Nothing is proposed on the necessary bank separation. On the contrary, we are putting back on the table the capital markets union that would relaunch securitization to supposedly finance SMEs on the American model.  However, by the admission of SMEs, they would prefer to focus on bank financing rather than securitization, which in the United States is mainly the responsibility of large public funds.  I have therefore abstained on this text, which seems very hollow and does not bring much.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it is a balanced report which promotes better regulation in the financial sector; however this is not a synonym for less regulation. In addition, it is important that every five years a report on the cumulative impact of the financial legislation will be produced.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which presents the balance sheet and issues of European regulation in the financial services sector. This text recalls the need for harmonization that goes towards simplification and not redundancies and additional complexities. In particular, I supported provisions to prevent legal uncertainty, in order to avoid regulatory arbitrage, which can result in high transaction costs.

name: Renaud Muselier (PPE)
text: In writing. The report on the balance sheet and the issues of the EU Financial Services Regulation calls on the Commission to present an assessment of the legislative measures taken to deal with the financial crisis and public debt. I voted in favour of the report to support the request for evaluation.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of Mr Balz's report because I believe it is important that financial stability and consumer protection remain the priorities of legislators and that more weight is given to the application of a coherent risk-based approach.  I also believe that the global competitiveness of EU legislation and financial sectors is a challenge for financial services regulation, the quality of which also depends on the transparency and timing of the legislative process.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Positive changes in the wide-scale issue of financial regulation are much needed at EU level. In the midst of the difficulties caused by the economic crisis, the development of a Pan-European financial regulatory system has accelerated and the progress made on certain issues is to be welcomed. At the moment, however, the biggest problem is that the existing legislation is not uniform and, as a result of the resulting loopholes, competition is distorted and the budget is reduced on the revenue side. Small Member States, such as Slovakia, have an obvious interest in introducing uniform legislation as soon as possible, which is why I support the adoption of this report.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. – I have voted for this report that adjusts existing EU financial services regulation through consistent and coherent policies that work effectively and efficiently, particularly aligned with the needs of small and medium-sized entities.

name: Dan Nica (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for the own-initiative report on the balance sheet and the challenges associated with the EU financial services regulatory framework as the 2007-2008 financial crisis and its large-scale negative impact were caused, inter alia, by the fact that appropriate, high-quality financial services regulations were not implemented to meet the needs associated with increasingly complex markets and products.  The establishment of an effective and effective framework for regulating financial services, ensuring financial stability, is a prerequisite for increasing (long-term) investment volume and stimulating economic growth in a competitive European economy.  We call on the Commission, as far as the Capital Markets Union is concerned, to implement an integrated approach and also to pay attention to other policy agendas, such as the development of a digital single market. The Commission should also take into account the latest technological developments. The Commission must also take into account cybersecurity threats and ensure that this is an integrated dimension of the EU strategy.

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported mr Balz's report and believe that, as part of the way forward, we need to start by analysing the numerous barriers to cross-border access, marketing and investment. At the same time, I believe that there is no need to overwhelm consumers with large volumes of information, but rather attention should be focused on the quality and clarity of information enabling an informed choice. Let us look for ways to strike a balance so that consumers are provided with the information they need to make informed decisions and understand the risks involved without unnecessarily burdening businesses, especially small and medium-sized enterprises.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. The report says that the main focus of legislators must continue to be on financial stability and consumer protection. Current legislation must be fully implemented and strictly enforced in the Member States. European legislators must also pay greater attention to the interactions with international standards in order to ensure global competitiveness. The report also calls for further improvement of procedures and for better accountability of the European Supervisory Authorities and the European Supervisory Mechanism in this regard. However, as there are still some inconsistencies in implementation, I abstained from voting on this report.

name: Younous Omarjee (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. This report takes stock of the legislative work of the previous Parliament on financial services regulation and makes suggestions to the European Commission for its new capital markets initiative. I voted against this report which, while welcoming the Capital Markets Union, is too uns critique of past legislation and mistakes and promotes the alleged effectiveness of structural reforms and fiscal policies so far.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. Legislation has been launched in the eu's financial services to restore financial stability, strengthen consumer protection and apply lessons learned from the crisis. The impact and the inter-euability of individual legislative measures have not been adequately analysed, so this own-initiative report is essential to ensure transparency and address the legislative shortcomings in financial services.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ The Report calls for EU agencies to become more involved in international standard setting (inevitably at the expense of national regulators), accordingly UKIP voted against this dilution of national sovereignty.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Taking note of all the actions taken to deal with the crisis that broke out in 2007/2008, I believe it is appropriate to aim for long-term growth through, for example, the diversification of funding channels. I also fear that the shortcomings and inconsistencies in the European financial services system may harm the work of SMEs involved in the regulatory labyrinth. I therefore welcome the tabling of the resolution supplementing and harmonizing the discipline, also on the basis of the comments of the ITRE Committee, and I would like to express my strong vote in favour.

name: Eva Paunova (PPE)
text: in writing. – Since the financial crisis that hit Europe in 2007/2008, numerous legislative initiatives in the field of EU financial services have been initiated in order to restore financial stability, to strengthen customer protection and to implement the lessons learnt from the crisis. I fully support the report that looks at the impact of these challenges and the way forward towards a more efficient and effective EU framework for financial regulation and a capital markets union. I believe that the present legislation needs full implementation and strong enforcement in all Member States.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Better regulation of financial services in the EU is one of the priorities in the creation of a Capital Markets Union, which is particularly evident by the onsee of the financial crisis in 2007. Supervision of the financial sector certainly needs to be stepped up, as this protects financial service users, and that is all of us. The transposition of financial regulation and reforms into national legislation needs to be accelerated, as it is an effective and effective framework for financial services, both at national and EU level, a guarantee of financial stability and a precondition for increasing investment and boosting growth in a competitive European economy. In doing so, it is important to take into account that the number and complexity of the rules is not exaggerated, which could cause problems in the form of their different interpretations by individual Member States or the unevenness with EU regulation. The solution imposed in this regard is a comprehensive approach to the regulation of financial services in the Union.  Building more functional financial markets that respond to the financial needs of the real economy is particularly necessary because of the stability of financial services provision, thus contributing to their better availability to SMEs and start-ups which, in my opinion, must remain the focus of the Union as the main generators of economic growth and the reduction of unemployment. The report before us represents a significant step towards more effective financial regulation and I will support it.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. The Balz report is a rather hollow text on the issues of financial regulation since the 2008 crisis, as well as the capital markets union's plans. It merely gives an agreed overview of the situation and proposals following the trend of the texts proposed by the Commission, with few legal elements or new proposals. I could join him on the concerns about the increasing complexity of regulation. On the other hand, it is impossible for me to follow him on the need to break the link between sovereign states and banks at the national level, that is to say to finalise the banking union. So I abstained.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ I support the report on the review of financial services regulations in the Union and the pursuit of a more precise and systematic form of consideration of their impacts on financial markets, but also on the real economy. Also, the Capital Markets Union project should be supported and in this context insist on harmonisation of financial services rules. This solution struck a good balance between the three fundamental objectives in overseeing financial regulation: protecting consumers and investors, creating new credit channels for the real economy (especially SMEs), and identifying barriers that persist in trade in financial services.  In particular, I welcome the requirement for regular checks on proportionality, consistency and coherence with a view to simplifying existing regulation of financial services in order to make them simpler and more in line with the needs of SMEs. In Croatia, for example, there are major problems with the illiquidity of small and medium-sized enterprises, capital constraints and often with poor level of information of those embarking on an entrepreneurial venture. From this perspective, an important part of the text also relates to identifying a key role in the search for alternative sources of financing for SMEs, in particular in the form of venture capital use. Finally, it is a commendable emphasis by which the report reaffirms Parliament's commitment to the effective regulation and empowerment of the Union's public supervisory institutions, and by no means deregulation, bearing in mind all safeguards and supervisory measures and regulations introduced as a result of the financial crisis.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒I support colleague Burkhard Balz's proposal for a Resolution on the Review of the Situation and Challenges in The Regulation of Financial Services in the EU: a path towards a more efficient and effective EU framework for financial regulation and towards and impact of the CAPITAL Markets Union. The financial crisis that emerged in 2007 and its far-reaching negative consequences were also due, inter alia, to the lack of application of appropriate financial services rules for increasingly complex markets and products. The still ongoing crisis has led to unprecedented negative consequences, especially for the real economy and taxpayers' money.  It is therefore of utmost impact to develop an effective and effective financial services framework that guarantees financial stability, as this is a precondition for increasing long-term investment and boosting growth in a competitive European economy. Care should be taken to ensure that effective and effective financial services rules in the EU are harmonised, consistent (including on a cross-sectoral basis), proportionate, should not be duplicated, deprived of unnecessary complexity and such as not leading to legal uncertainty, regulatory arbitrage and high transaction costs. An example of the need for more efficient financial regulation are everyday problems with IBAN numbers, as they are still not considered valid for direct debit of a bank account in one Member State for the benefit of an entity in another Member State.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Following the financial and debt crisis that erupted between 2007 and 2008, a number of legislative initiatives were launched in the field of EU financial services, with the aim of restoring financial stability, strengthening consumer protection and putting into practice the lessons learned from the crisis.  Many of these pieces of legislation have already been implemented and implemented or will be implemented in the near future. But there is no shortage of future challenges. An in-depth impact assessment of the financial services framework, which should be repeated at regular intervals, with efficient regulation on the basis will undoubtedly produce better results.  In addition, mandatory checks on coherence and proportionality should ensure that the application of financial services legislation is less complex and that it is comprehensible and better adapted to the needs of small and medium-sized entities. The Member States, for their part, will have to apply the current legislation rigorously. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 This own-initiative report attempts to take stock of legislative work on financial services, to remedy the shortcomings identified in the financial services law-making process and to draw attention to the problems that have arised. In particular, it draws attention to the impact of the various legislative measures and the lack of an adequate analysis of their interconnectedness, as well as the lack of a full assessment of the cumulative effects of the legislation as a whole. It also responds to important new Initiatives of the European Commission, such as the Investment Package and the Capital Markets Union, and identifies ways to achieve better results by building on existing financial services regulations that operate effectively and efficiently. The rapporteur also believes that one of the main challenges for financial services regulation is the global competitiveness of EU legislation and the EU financial sectors. The rapporteur points out that the quality of financial services regulation also depends on the coordination, timeliness and transparency of the legislative process.  Although the report addresses difficult topics such as the completion of the Banking Union and the participation of euro area member states and non-euro area member states, the rapporteurs managed to find neutral language, which is why I drafted the report.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report because the financial crisis of 2007-08 showed the urgency of reforming the Union's financial sector. This report is all the more relevant because it takes stock of current legislation and sends very concrete messages on areas for improvement.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In the context of the financial and sovereign debt crisis, numerous legislative initiatives on EU financial services have been launched with a view to restoring financial stability, strengthening consumer protection and implementing lessons learned from the crisis. The truth, however, is that, to date, a full assessment of the effects of these individual legislative measures, their interactions and their cumulative impact has never been carried out.  This own-initiative report is a first step towards a balance of this intensive legislative work. To this extent, it calls on the Commission services, by the end of 2016, to carry out a first assessment and report on the cumulative impact of EU regulation on financial services, in order to analyse its effects, effectiveness, efficiency and adequacy, to identify possible failures and shortcomings and to address the essential role and responsibilities of the ESAs and the SSM in this context. Such an assessment shall be of a regular nature, and the Commission services, in cooperation with the ESAs, the SSM and the ESS, shall carry out this analysis and submit the corresponding report to Parliament every five years. I voted in favour.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ The Report calls for EU agencies to become more involved in international standard setting (inevitably at the expense of national regulators), accordingly UKIP voted against this dilution of national sovereignty.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This own-initiative report, as an instrument for the balance of legislative work, aims to address gaps in financial services legislation and to raise concerns, such as that individual legislative measures have not been sufficiently analysed, along side the insufficient assessment of the accumulated impact of legislation in general. Firstly, I approved this report because I considered the relevance of the recommendations addressed to the Commission, in particular as regards the construction of initiatives on the basis of existing financial services regulations, as well as the importance of regular evaluation of financial services frameworks. Secondly, because I agree that the relevance of the quality of regulation in the context of financial services depends on coordination, timing and transparency in the legislative process. I therefore believe that this report could contribute to the improvement of this process.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. In 2008, the so-called "subprime" financial crisis in the United States swept europe, weakening the European economy for a long time. Let us remember the high price and considerable efforts required of taxpayers to help the banking sector: 26% of European GDP has been absorbed in this task. Certainly since then, the European Union has spared no effort to stabilise the financial system, and in particular banking, and many legislations have been adopted in the last 3 years: a single resolution mechanism in the event of bank failure, a framework for managing bank failures and a deposit guarantee system.  So it's time to take stock at the halfway point. In any case, this is what the European Parliament wanted, which on Tuesday called on the Commission to carry out an impact study of the forty European legislations that have been implemented since the financial market crisis. The aim is to be able to judge the consistency and proportionality of the rules while pointing out any undesirable side effects that would weaken SMEs and investors.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. The financial crisis that emerged in 2007/8 required global action by European legislators and international standardisation bodies. Since then, numerous EU financial services legislative initiatives have been launched to restore financial stability, strengthen consumer protection and put into practice the lessons learned from the crisis. This report is a first step towards taking stock of this legislative work, addressing gaps in financial services legislation and expressing concerns that have arisen.  I believe that a comprehensive impact assessment of the financial services framework is necessary and that such an assessment should be carried out on a regular basis. This task should be left to the Commission services and take advantage of their liaison with supervisory agencies.  I believe it is important that financial stability and consumer protection remain the priorities of legislators and that greater importance should be given to the application of a risk-based approach.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this own-initiative report as it calls on the Commission to examine the impact of legislation on financial markets adopted in recent years, as well as to encourage the creation of a Capital Markets Union which should contribute to improving the liquidity channeling to the economy.  Thanks to the work of our group, there is no point in this report questioning the consideration of sovereign debt as a risk-free asset. However, we still do not have a risk-free pan-European financial asset, which would be kept with the issuance of the Union's public debt. The hypothetical issuance of Union bonds does not contraviate Article 310 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. I therefore call on the European Commission to take advantage of ultra-low interest rates to create a European Treasury. I also welcome the inclusion in this report of the delegation's amendments on the need to incorporate the consumer and small investor perspective into the Capital Markets Union, as well as non-discrimination on the issuer of the receipt.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. The financial and debt crisis of 2007/2008 required comprehensive action by European lawmakers. Since then, numerous legislative initiatives in the area of financial services have been launched to restore financial stability, strengthen consumer protection and implement lessons learned from the crisis.  This initiative report voted yesterday aims to take stock of this legislative work, to remedy the shortcomings found in the legislation on financial services and to set out concerns which stem in particular from the fact that the effects of the various pieces of legislation have not been sufficiently analysed so far. However, a thorough assessment of the effects of the financial services framework is needed and this exercise should be repeated on a regular basis.  Moreover, the application of financial services legislation should be more understandable and better adapted to the needs of SMEs. As for financial stability and consumer protection, they must remain the priorities of legislators, with more weight to be given to the implementation of a coherent risk-based strategy.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The regulation of financial services is a particularly sensitive area where action requires extreme care and careful consideration. At the same time, we must bear in mind that one of the fundamental objectives of the European Union is to create a free area of capital movement that is still not fully realised. At least as long as there are different restrictions on the movement of capital within the EU. This document is an important step towards a single European area of capital movement.  The only point I would like to make to him is that the document resuses the idea that consumer protection does not require much information. Supposedly enough just quality. But who will set quality standards for that information? The Regulation does not provide for this. Will this be done by the financial institutions themselves? If so, do we believe that they will ensure quality information for consumers? Of course, this provision of the regulation is more informative and has no legal effect. I therefore vote in favour and want to believe that consumer protection standards will in no way be lowered. Especially in such a sensitive and loss-making area as financial services.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. It is relatively agreed that the financial crisis of 2007-2008 and its negative effects were caused, inter alia, by the lack of proper and comprehensive financial services regulation. The EU has therefore launched a comprehensive reform programme for the union's financial sector, with the firm purpose of strengthening financial regulation and supervision, ensuring less permeability in the face of crisis scenarios and safeguarding investors and taxpayers as much as possible. I therefore share the ideas listed by the rapporteur on the need for coherent and effective EU financial services regulation, serving both the interests of businesses and customers and investors, as well as the need to move towards a capital markets union that puts an end to the fragmentation currently existing and allows capital markets in the EU to be strengthened as a complement to banking financing. In view of these assumptions, I voted in favour of this Own Initiative Report.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which aims to take stock of the many legislative initiatives in the field of financial services taken by the European Union since 2008, when the financial and debt crisis erupted. It is appropriate to assess whether these new financial provisions are appropriate to current challenges. An assessment of the effects of the financial services framework is essential. I have supported this text, which reminds us that the current legislation must be applied in all Member States, in order to maintain coherence within the Union itself. Moving towards a Capital Markets Union must benefit the real economy above all, and be accompanied by appropriate financial services regulations.  The EU's priorities for financial services must be financial stability and consumer protection.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union has made an enormous effort in recent years to regulate a system, banking and finance, which has suddenly plunged into a serious crisis. Much has been done, but at times, pressed by contingencies, in a somewhat hasty manner. The time has therefore come to examine what has been done, its usefulness, any errors and propose the necessary changes to further improve the system.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this own-initiative report, which reviews the various European legislative acts on financial services that have taken place in the previous mandate, seeking to assess achievements and problems. In this way, it intends to give some indications in the light of the Capital Markets Union envisaged for this legislature by the Commission. The report welcomes projects such as the Juncker Plan and the Capital Markets Union, as well as being overly positive about the legislative achievements of the previous legislature.

name: Alfred Sant (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The proposal for a financial transaction tax (FTT) is under the enhanced cooperation procedure among 11 Member States only. So it is up to those participating countries to reach an agreement amongst them. I cannot agree with an FTT that is only applied by a few countries – it is not in their national interest, though if they believe otherwise and would want to choose that option, they should be left to design the tax as they deem fit. Nor can I agree with an FTT applied only by the European Union when other blocs and countries do not. In a globalised economy, that is a recipe for undermining competitivity in those areas which apply it. For these reasons, I have voted against paragraph 35.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against it because it implies the implicit ratification by the European Parliament of the European Commission's proposal on the Capital Markets Union. This proposal, presented by Mr Juncker as the solution to solve the problems of access to credit and financing of the European economy, is a mere strategy for introducing speculative capital into the direct financing of small and medium-sized enterprises. This proposal is absolutely contrary to the interests of SMEs in Europe who need credit to be guaranteed through the traditional banking system and not through increasingly complex mechanisms that leave all the risk to small entrepreneurs, who will now have to become participating shareholders of their own companies. This crazy proposal will cause more problems for small businesses than it seeks to solve, being designed for the interests of large capitals. That is why I voted against this report.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report as it balances the balance sheet of the legislative work carried out by financial institutions following the debt crisis that erupted in 2008.  I also believe that the report provides the right opportunity to ask ourselves not only about the shortcomings found in the current regulation, but also about the overall impact of legislative measures in the field of financial services, especially with regard to small and medium-sized entities. The time has come to put into practice the lessons learned from the crisis and to analyse carefully the initiatives taken so far, with a view to responding effectively and reasonably to future challenges.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this because it calls for the EU agencies to become more involved in international standard setting (at the expense of national regulators).

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report from the ECON Committee on the challenges of the EU Financial Services Regulation. I found that this report was fairly well balanced and I’m grateful for the work that the S&D shadow rapporteur, Paul Tang, has done on it. While I support the Better Regulation package from the Commission and its application in the Capital Markets Union project, it must be said that ‘Better Regulation’ is not the same as ‘less regulation’. That said, this report does fill the regulatory gaps where needed and reduce red-tape, which I believe are necessary in the maintenance of a working Capital Markets Union.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted positively for this report, but this explanation of the vote is a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ the financial crisis to which Europe was exposed in 2008 provided a fundamental impetus for the Union to start seriously addressing the impact of financial services on the real economy. Since the outbreak of the crisis, the Commission has come up with a number of measures to restore financial stability or strengthen customer protection. I supported this report, as it seeks to evaluate the legislative amendments adopted and to highlight shortcomings or gaps that still need to be addressed.  As financial regulation legislation has been adopted in response to crisis events, many legislation may be potentially incoherent. We therefore propose in the report that the Commission examine the impact of these rules on the financial markets. We are also asking it to advocate the protection of effective and efficient financing of the real economy and small and medium-sized enterprises. Harmonisation of financial services legislation should go hand in hand with the creation of a Capital Markets Union. It would be beneficial for the real economy if businesses also had access to alternative financing methods as classic banking products. However, it is not possible for the financial market to deregulate, to which the Commission expressly points out. In addition, it is crucial that Member States apply the current rules and do not create overregulation. In this way, the functioning of the internal market and competition would be promoted.

name: Renato Soru (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on EU financial services regulation, which provides a comprehensive overview of the impact of recent legislation on financial services and its effectiveness in financing the real economy and small and medium-sized enterprises. Indeed, I believe that all financial sectors are affected by profound changes, including in the banking and insurance sectors, and therefore need the creation of a Capital Markets Union as an opportunity to strengthen the EU economy.  Indeed, given that the 2007-2008 financial crisis and its extensive negative repercussions were caused, among other things, by the failure to apply adequate and quality financial services regulation for increasingly complex markets and products, I believe it is necessary to play an active part in the construction of a regulatory framework that guarantees financial stability, making the system more resilient to shocks , limiting risks and responding better to investors' needs. All this for the benefit of the union's real economy.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: in writing \ u2012 An effective and efficient financial services framework ensuring financial stability is a prerequisite for increasing (long-term) investment and promoting growth in a competitive European economy. However, in addition to the proposed Capital Markets Union measures, it is necessary to adopt instruments intended for the complementary non-bank financing of companies. In particular, the principle of building a Capital Markets Union should be the emphasis on capital market end-users, i.e. companies and investors as well as consumers. The regulation of financial services in the EU should be coherent, consistent, proportionate, non-sensitive and free from excessive complexity, and should avoid legal uncertainty and high costs for potential financial market participants. The potential of innovative market financing, in particular financial technology options, including crowdfunding and peer-to-peer lending, in particular the harmonisation of relevant regulatory requirements and administrative simplification, should be highlighted.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The financial and debt crisis that erupted in 2007/2008 required extensive engagement by European legislators. Since then, a number of financial services legislative initiatives have been established in the European Union to restore financial stability, strengthen consumer protection, but also implement lessons learned in the crisis. Important new Commission initiatives such as the Investment Package and the Capital Markets Union will achieve a better result if they are based on efficient and effective regulation of financial services.  More attention should be paid to SMEs, as well as to their financing. The application of legislation relating to financial services should be less complex, more understandable and better suit the needs of SMEs. It is important that consumer protection, as well as financial stability, remain a priority for legislators. The global competitiveness of EU legislation and the European financial sector stands out as an important challenge in the regulation of financial services and should take into account interdependence with international standards. This process needs to be further improved and the particular role of the ESA and the SSM in this area should be highlighted. The quality of regulation of financial services depends on time, coordination and transparency in the law-making process, and I therefore supported the report.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report, which is primarily a stocktaking exercise of the financial legislation adopted during the last 5 years and a precursor to the CMU.  I am particularly supportive of the call for a culture of compliance within  financial organisations that puts the interest of the customers first.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒I support this scoreboard, as financial stability and consumer protection are imperatives that do not allow compromise. Following the experience that the EU and the whole world rocked in 2008, the EU has adopted a whole set of legislation regulating the financial market with the aim of never repeating a crisis of this magnitude. The report states, and the ECON Committee supports this view, that the current legislation is good, but needs to work on applying it in some Member States. Most legal provisions are already successfully applied and their positive impact is seen. The report calls on the Commission to carry out an impact assessment of the legislation by the end of the current year and propose any changes if it deems them necessary. The Commission should primarily explore the impact on the economy, employment and the financial sector as a whole.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the assessment of the situation and challenges in the EU's financial services arrangements: the impact and further steps towards a more effective and effective EU framework for financial sector regulation and capital markets union.  The financial crisis has left behind a number of negative consequences, which are still visible in some Member States today. However, with the financial crisis, we were able to assess and highlight the main shortcomings that have plagued our market: from the lack of adequate regulation of financial services to ever more complex markets, to ensuring that the needs of investors and the financial needs of the real economy are better met. As the consequences of the crisis are still highly visible and expressed, reforms must be continued.  I welcome the report, which emphasises the need for additional non-bank financing for companies and also that the key principle in establishing the Capital Markets Union must be to focus more on end-users of capital markets.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report is clearly in favour of the capital markets union because it considers that the EU has an obligation to help businesses (mainly small and medium-sized enterprises) have easy access to stock exchanges throughout the Union. This will, of course, lead mathematically to an even greater accumulation of capital by large European groups, but also to the strengthening of monopoly capital at European level with a view to its 'competitiveness' at global level. The report merely exposes the steps taken to date to complete the Capital Markets Union and calls for the framework to be harmonised with global data, at the same time as promoting a similar deregulation of companies' access to the stock market so that they can enter stock exchanges in other countries. It also promotes direct controls from Brussels to the authorities of the Member States for the future, something with which we disagree over time because in fact it completely dissolves the sovereignty of the Member States and accumulates all the powers in Brussels. Since our opposition to the completion of the single market and to the effort to develop small and medium-sized enterprises through stock exchanges is our firm position, we voted against the report.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The inability of the financial system to cope with the economic crisis and its impact have highlighted the lack of adequate and high quality financial services arrangements for increasingly complex markets and products. The regulatory framework should include all financial sectors, banking, insurance, real estate and securities markets, investment funds, etc. We need a framework that requires transparency in the market, efficiency in macro-prudential supervision, the international competitiveness of European businesses, the promotion of entrepreneurship, efficiency in removing market barriers and provides opportunities for full assessment and/or quantitative analysis of the overall impact and interaction of individual measures.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the review and challenges of EU financial services regulation. Indeed, the current financial and debt crisis has had unprecedentedly damaging consequences in Europe, but now the European institutions have succeeded in creating a financial regulation that strengthened the EU's financial structure in the face of future crises. At the same time, I agree with the report that the EU's capital market remains fragmented and SMEs and microenterprises continue to be severely affected by capital shortfalls. Indeed, the CAPITAL MARKETS UNION can provide a valuable framework for ensuring equal access to finance for SMEs across the Union and promoting innovative forms of market-based financing. The Capital Markets Union would provide an opportunity for SMEs to complement bank-based financing, an area in which the United States has evolved more strongly following the financial crisis. I consider it of the utmost importance and I welcome the fact that the report proposed an integrated approach to the Capital Markets Union, mentioning the Digital Single Market. Furthermore, the reporter rightly stressed the importance of consumer protection in the field of financial services. Consumer information in quality, accurate, user-friendly, reliable, timely and, above all, understandable language can help to make informed choices. However, there is concern that the consumer often encounters ambiguous information which is not intended to serve consumer needs.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 During the financial and economic crisis, the European Union produced, under enormous time pressure, countless new rules and regulations on financial services, more than all previous regulations in this area put together. Of course, changes were necessary, given that it was from the financial sector that the financial crisis began in 2008. However, we should now look closely at what objectives have been achieved, which regulations are actually in place and which have been introduced too hastily and have proved inefficient. The European Parliament's report draws proper attention to the need to examine the coherence, accuracy, proportionality, added value and economic impact of financial services regulation. Parliament also called on the European Commission to prepare a comprehensive impact assessment of the new rules before the end of this year. It is necessary to get rid of unnecessary eu legislation as soon as possible so that the European Union better serves its citizens and does not create unnecessary barriers for consumers and businesses.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The financial crisis of 2007-2008 was a test stone for the European Union and the Member States. However, the Union has demonstrated that it is capable of providing an adequate response to this crisis by adopting regulations of the financial services sector aimed at ensuring its stability.  At this point, an assessment of these regulations is needed in order to correct the problems and create the necessary prerequisites for the achievement of the Capital Markets Union, which will further harmonise European legislation in the field of financial services. First of all, there is a need to create the regulatory instruments that are needed to cover areas not yet included. It is also envisaged to reduce red tape and provide alternative lending channels for the real economy and, in particular, for small and medium-sized enterprises. Priority should be given to financial stability and consumer protection, as well as to the application of a coherent approach to risks.  In order to ensure the quality of the regulatory framework for financial services, certain conditions relating to the coordination, planning and transparency of the legislative process must also be met. The achievement of the Banking Union can be a decisive step towards strengthening integrated European financial services and coordinating Member States' policies in this area.  For these reasons, the current report should be adopted.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the text on the balance sheet and the issues of EU regulation on financial services, although I would have liked to go further.  I see that the financial and debt crisis we are going through has had unprecedented consequences, particularly on the real economy and taxpayers' money. I therefore welcome the financial settlement approved by the European institutions over the past five years, which has strengthened Europe's financial architecture in anticipation of future crises.  We have secured the Commission's inclusion of an effective level of consumer and investor protection, which is one of the founding principles of this union.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as I believe it is particularly important that the Commission undertakes an impact assessment of all measures that have been implemented in the wake of the financial crisis. Moreover an effective financial services framework ensuring financial stability is a prerequisite for increasing (long-term) investment and fostering growth in a competitive European economy.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒I support this report because I believe that the rapporteur has established a very good balance between the main needs of the financial services sector and the commitment to a higher degree of transparency. Indeed, transparency does not necessarily have to be linked to large amounts of information, but we must focus on the quality and intelligibility of information, the way to make good decisions. Also, the need for better consumer information must not assume dubios administrative procedures and unreasonable costs, so it is our responsibility to adopt smart and less burdensome regulation that will replace a good part of this that is currently in force. I also agree with the initiative for more comprehensive and better financial education targeting SMEs with a view to teaching them how to exploit capital markets. Such companies are the backbone of the European economy, so increasing their competitiveness is essential.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the report on the assessment of the situation and challenges of eu financial services regulation, as I was threed to ensure that the legislative initiatives to date contained the first assessment of the state of the reforms. However, they do not provide a comprehensive impact assessment and analysis.  The report assesses, analyses the effects in a structured way and addresses the shortcomings that have arisen in the drafting of legislation. This is the first step towards improving the whole process and further clearly sharing the powers of control between the EU level and the Member States in this area.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this own-initiative report, which reviews the various European legislative acts on financial services that have taken place in the previous mandate, seeking to assess achievements and problems. In this way, it intends to give some indications in the light of the Capital Markets Union envisaged for this legislature by the Commission. The report welcomes projects such as the Juncker Plan and the Capital Markets Union, as well as being overly positive about the legislative achievements of the previous legislature.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Before making a big leap forward with the Capital Markets Union, it is fundamental that we are able to assert where exactly is Europe in terms of financial markets legislation. I hope that this report is useful in this regard and enables the Commission to take a broad view on the current state of play and build a CMU that further diversifies and integrates our financial markets.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. The text is rather hollow on the issues of financial regulation since the 2008 crisis, as well as the capital markets union's plans. It merely gives an agreed overview of the situation and proposals following the trend of the texts proposed by the Commission, with few legal elements or new proposals. He can be reached on concerns about the increasing complexity of regulation and the need for a harmonized, coherent and non-redundant one.   On the other hand, it cannot be followed on the need to sever the link between sovereign states and banks at the national level, i.e. to finalise the banking union. He makes no mention of the need for a real bank separation, which is now stalled. On the union of capital markets (which today takes place in two texts: the relaunch of securitisation and the simplification of the "Prospectus" directive), we are in favour of diversifying financing methods, but reserved on securitisation or on real access to the markets of most SMEs, which cannot access the markets anyway.  I therefore choose abstention on this text.

name: Mihai Ţurcanu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The free movement of capital first appeared in the Treaty of Rome more than 50 years ago. This freedom is one of the four fundamental freedoms of the EU, so it should be at the heart of the European single market. Unfortunately, despite progress in this area, capital markets are still fragmented and generally organised according to national systems. The degree of integration of financial markets has decreased due to the financial crisis, with banks and investors reorienting themselves to their home markets.  In this respect, the creation of a Capital Markets Union is a key initiative of the European Commission's work programme. This would ensure a diversification of financing modes within the European economy and reduce costs, especially for small and medium-sized enterprises. This union would have the effect of increasing financial flows between investors and multiplying the number of European investment projects, which would improve the allocation of risks and capital at EU level, allowing Europe to better withstand future shocks . I therefore voted in favour of the Report on the balance sheet and the challenges associated with the EU financial services regulatory framework: the impact and the way forward towards a more efficient and effective EU financial sector regulatory framework and a capital markets union.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The financial and debt crisis that erupted during 2007/2008 required comprehensive action by European legislators and international standard-legislators. Since then, a number of legislative initiatives have been launched in the field of financial services in the EU aimed at restoring financial stability, strengthening consumer protection and implementing the lessons of the crisis. This own-initiative report is the first step towards an overview of this legislative work, address the shortcomings identified in the legislation on financial services and respond to concerns expressed in particular because the effects of individual legislative measures and their interactions have not been sufficiently analysed and the cumulative impact of general legislation has not yet been fully assessed. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ Although the main disappointments in the ECON vote were achieving only a call to review the macroprudential framework and the fact that there was no reference at all to ‘stranded assets’, most of the rest of demands were well reflected and so, as the text as a whole was inoffensive, I voted in favour.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. Following the financial crisis, a number of legislative texts have been adopted within the framework of the Union. This report notes that financial stability and consumer protection remain the top priorities of legislators. It also identifies that the competitiveness of European legislation and the Union's financial sectors are an essential challenge in regulating financial services and European Commission services are asked to complete the first assessment of the financial services by 2016, with the aim of having a comprehensive review of the state of financial services. That is why I consider it necessary to vote in favour of this report.

name: Marco Valli (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The economic system is made even more fragile and more exposed to systemic crisis risks by the Capital Market Union proposed in this report, to the detriment of real economic growth, European businesses and savers. The text adopted accentuates the predominant role of finance in the real economy. The special financing needs of small and medium-sized enterprises, which need stable and long-term sources of credit, are best understood only by local banks and not by capital markets subject to short-term volatility and speculative logic, as is proposed. The report, on the other hand, relaunches instruments such as securitisation, insisting on a financial channel that is too complex and burdensome for SMEs.  I believe that the drive towards further market integration and regulatory standardisation is dangerous and irresponsible. The European economic system therefore remains unstable, without the implementation of a separation between credit and investment banking activities. For these reasons, I voted against this report.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against it because it implies the implicit ratification by the European Parliament of the European Commission's proposal on the Capital Markets Union. This proposal, presented by Mr Juncker as the solution to solve the problems of access to credit and financing of the European economy, is a mere strategy for introducing speculative capital into the direct financing of small and medium-sized enterprises. This proposal is absolutely contrary to the interests of SMEs in Europe who need credit to be guaranteed through the traditional banking system and not through increasingly complex mechanisms that leave all the risk to small entrepreneurs, who will now have to become participating shareholders of their own companies. This crazy proposal will cause more problems for small businesses than it seeks to solve, being designed for the interests of large capitals. That is why I voted against this report.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. 'I voted in favour of this report, which gives us a broader view of the state of the legislative measures relating to the financial markets. After all, before we create the Capital Markets Union, we must first be sure that our rules, which we adopted in the aftermath of the 2008 financial crisis, are also proportionate and coherent.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 By imputing the 2007 crisis to an alleged lack of regulation we are wrong in the diagnosis. We are at the same time creating an illusion, implying that the financial system can be disciplined. We are creating the illusion that it is possible to align the interests of banking and investment funds with the interests of people and workers.  The single supervisory mechanism, as well as the single resolution mechanism, does not work and does not solve the problems of the financial system as we have recently observed in Portugal, where information has been systematically hidden and manipulated with the consent of supervisors. The problem of large financial institutions, said to be too big to fail, does not solve itself with mere palliatives that are only intended to give the idea that something is being done by staying all the same. The problem is solved by bank separation and public control of the financial system and time will soon be in place to give us reason.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. The report is merely an inventory to identify possible interactions and inconsistencies in financial regulation. The report does not contain any firm legislative proposals to remedy identified shortcomings. That is why I am abstaining from voting.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. I abstained from the EU Parliament resolution on "EU rules for the financial services sector - stocktaking and challenges: impacts and ways to achieve a more efficient and effective EU framework for financial regulation and a capital markets union". It is an own-initiative report without any legal force. As always with this form of reporting, it is a music with all sorts of tones and intermediate tones. Only in this way is it possible to squeeze as many voices as possible into the orchestra. Accordingly, the report is a wishful concert. In addition to a great deal of light, therefore, there is also shadow, for which I cannot vote in favour of the report: it welcomes the Union's investment package and is implicitly quite positive about European financial market regulation in general and all three pillars of the Banking Union in particular. For me, this is too much for me to follow my group and agree.

name: Iuliu Winkler (PPE)
text: in writing. – I voted on the report on the balance sheet and the challenges associated with the EU financial services regulatory framework.  This own-initiative report is a first step in assessing the measures taken by European legislators, but also by international bodies, following the financial crisis. The rapporteur also includes recommendations on the achievement of an EU framework for regulating the financial sector more efficiently for achieving a capital markets union.  I welcome the attention paid in this report to the SME sector in relation to the measures that have been taken, but also in view of the improvement of the current legislative framework.

name: Θεόδωρος Ζαγοράκης (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Mr Bulz's report aims to delineate the framework of those actions and rules that will enable improved regulation of financial services in the Union, thus defining future developments. Most political groups adopted the text within the relevant Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs. In turn, I voted in favour of its final approval.

name: Marco Zanni (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 This own-initiative report welcomes the Commission's proposal to achieve a Capital Markets Union (CMU) with the aim of overcoming the fragmentation of financial markets by reducing companies' dependence on the banking system.  This Union is certainly heading in the wrong direction. The solution to promoting more growth and employment has been identified in a further expansion of finance, forgetting that the crisis was generated precisely by the predominance of finance over the economy. CMU actually promotes further financialisation of the economy, relaunches non-bank lending and securitisation. The latter remains too complex and expensive a channel of financing to meet the financing needs of SMEs, which need local banks that can know the territorial context in which businesses operate.  CMU will make the economic system more fragile, interconnected and exposed to systemic risks. It will therefore not solve the problem of financing SMEs that need stable, sustainable and long-term sources of credit. Finally, there is the irresponsible promotion of market integration in the absence of structural banking reform based on the separation of credit activities from investment activities and real regulation of the shadow banking system.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: in writing ‒ I supported Mr Balza's report on the regulation of financial services in the EU. The report itself deals with the evaluation of the regulation of financial services and identifies challenges in this area. In particular, it says that we should strive for a better and more effective application of the existing rules regulating this area than the creation of new ones, which I, as an MEP, have shared from the outset with regard to European legislation as a whole. At the same time, I welcomed the fact that the report deals with the protection of consumers and small and medium-sized enterprises, calls for less administrative burdens and a level playing field within the European Union, as well as criticises the lack of diverse and profitable products for consumers. It is these facts that have convinced me to vote in favour of adopting this report.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on balance sheet and challenges of EU financial services regulation, because I believe that the capital market in the Union remains fragmented and that the Capital Markets Union (CMU) can provide a valuable framework for safeguarding fair access to finance for SMEs in the EU and promoting innovative platforms for market finance , without this meaning market deregulation.  The financial crisis of 2007 and its negative impact were caused, inter alia, by the lack of proper financial services regulation for increasingly complex markets. Consequently, in recent years, an ambitious reform programme in the EU financial sector has been launched to strengthen financial regulation and supervision, restore financial stability and make the financial system more resilient to shocks.  In this sense, I think that the report clearly identifies that the creation of the UMC does not mean deregulation, but an improvement in the channelling of funds into the real economy, underlining the importance of the European Parliament in completing the Banking Union and highlighting the need for the creation of the European Rating Agency and a high level of market protection for investors.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 In the EU, the situation is caricata. At the same time as we are witnessing the increase in regulation, the Capital Markets Union is taken from the car case. A Union that claims to want to facilitate access to capital markets for SMEs as a way of resolving the constraints they face with commercial banking, but whose sole objective is to increase the profits of the financial sector. They say, its promoters, that improvements in legislation will prevent a crisis such as the one in 2007-2008, but we will be here to tell you that history has been in charge of giving us reason. We voted against it.

name: Marco Zullo (EFDD)
text: in writing. The own-initiative report welcomes the Commission's proposal to create a Capital Markets Union (CMU) which aims to reduce companies' dependence on the banking system in favour of financial markets.  I voted against this report because, in my opinion, the CMU is heading in the wrong direction because it does not act on the causes of the crisis. The solution to foster more growth and employment has been identified in a further expansion of finance through alternative forms of lending such as peer to peer lending, crowdfunding and securitisation, forgetting that the crisis was generated precisely by the domination of finance over the real economy. The Capital Markets Union thus designed will make the economic system more exposed to systemic risks at the expense of savers. SmEs do not find in this report a response to their need for market stability and long-term financing. Instead, the document focuses on capital markets subject to volatility and driven by short-term speculative logic. I am convinced that it is dangerous and irresponsible to promote further market integration in the absence of structural banking reform based on the separation of credit activities from investment activities.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
