text: Writing. The financial services sector is a key element of the internal market, which is essential for the proper functioning of the European economy and global competitiveness.  The scoreboard of the large-scale reforms of the financial sector and the finding of shortcomings was essential in order to establish the effectiveness of the reforms and to monitor the growing presence of financial institutions, which is why I supported the report.

name: Ángela Vallina
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, we women are not a wild card to society, nor do we expect them to tell us, let alone a society governed by the great economic powers to the detriment of citizenship, to what we have to devote ourselves to. Women, like men, have the right to decide on our future, whether we want to be entrepreneurs or employees, mothers or not, married or single.  Entrepreneurship is a job option like others, but it is by no means the magic solution that solves family reconciliation and the inequality of rights and opportunities that women suffer. The European Union must promote policies that eliminate inequality and the pay gap; that truly facilitate family reconciliation, building a utility network, helping women develop their full human and labour potential, whatever they want to devote themselves to, and not through incentives to cover economic sectors, as the economy is interested in at the time.  The austerity policies implemented in recent years by the Union and by many of its Member States have severely punished the living conditions of many citizens and women bear the brunt in the family, at work and in poverty rates.  It is time for the idea that women, through their effort, dedication and submission, are the wild card that serves to patch this unjust society economically and socially and that only brings us the growth of inequality in society, and we are seeing it every day. Therefore, female entrepreneurship, yes; and help for whoever wants it and all the necessary support, too; but exploitation of women, no. Hence the abstention of our group.

name: Anna Maria Corazza Bildt (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I fully support this report because women’s entrepreneurship is an enormous untapped potential for growth and jobs. It is a matter of equality and empowerment. We are not a vulnerable group. Women are important actors in our economy, an asset for our economies, and the time has come for Member States to recognise the full potential of female entrepreneurship and to adopt clear strategies to remove all forms of discrimination and existing obstacles, from facilitating access to capital and reducing red tape to any other form of discrimination. We must also combat stereotypes. Women are too often seen as less credible, not least in sectors such as innovation and technology.  It is crucial to increase business training and education, and to develop a culture of second chance, so that women can believe that they can do it and start a company. I welcome more networks of women, because it is important to support each other, to exchange good practices and to learn from each other. Member States must also create the conditions for women to better conciliate family and work, but this is an issue that has to be dealt with at national level.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: – I would like to congratulate the EPP rapporteur on the approved report, which says the obstacles women face in doing business. I believe that girls and women deserve encouragement and support in their work implementation. But I am more cautious about the way we are supposed to work on this soil with the prejudices that persist towards women. Unfortunately, Parliament cannot determine how families should be divided into housework, and it cannot decide that it will simply increase women's self-esteem with support programmes. However, what we can do in the Member States and what we can appeal to is to offer women opportunities, flexibility and more time for their own implementation. For example, in the form of access to childcare facilities and quality training in schools. Because quality business preparation is also needed by students, which we do not think about so consistently today in business - future nurses, nannies, beautic players or cooks. It is precisely many of these female students who can one day be successful female entrepreneurs.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I was happy to support this report as it focuses on women and on trying to encourage them to enter the marketplace and become entrepreneurs or start up their own business. We are focusing on unemployment across Europe and particularly on encouraging SMEs and start-ups. Women have a huge untapped potential there that we need to focus on, and we need to address the issues that are challenging and preventing women from entering the workplace or indeed for having, most importantly, the confidence to start their own business. We hear about many of them, but probably childcare and access to cash would be the two most important. These are broad terms, but we indeed we need to ensure that finance is available and that access to funds is not an obstacle for women. In terms of child care, the support that society can provide – that the governments can provide – in encouraging women is very important. I agree with previous speakers that the state should stay away from behind the front door and let families operate themselves, but certainly we need to ensure that the obstacles in terms of childcare and flexible time are addressed.

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI).
text: – I voted in favour of this report on the obstacles to women starting a business in Europe, although I must stress, which I always stress in the Committee on women's rights, that it is not possible to talk about Women in Europe in general. There are quite different obstacles, for example, in post-communist countries, such as my own country, Hungary, where the main obstacle is the lack of civilisation and the lack of start-up capital for women – and, by the way, not really for men – to start a business. Communist comrades privatized national wealth for themselves or distributed it to Westerners, handing over the nation's funds to Western so-called investors, who set up assembly plants instead of initiating civilization by granting capital injections to those who want to live in dignity and with their heads held high, as entrepreneurs, so are a large number of women. That's the main obstacle for us.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D).
text: – Mr. President, less than a third of the self-employed in the European Union are women, and statistics show that those who embark on entrepreneurship take fewer risks and are less inclined to expand because of poor environmental support. Twice as many women as men work part-time. The most important resources entrepreneurs need are easier access to finance and environmental support to help bring private and business commitments in line as easily as possible.  I am very proud that Croatia is one of the few countries that has a national strategy and action plan for the development of female entrepreneurship. This report calls for positive changes in the economy, but also in society. Therefore, I wholeheartedly support him.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE).
text: – Although entrepreneurship has been a political priority since the Treaty of Lisbon, the Union is still behind. In 2012, only 31% of entrepreneurs were women in the EU. The report clearly shows that there is room for progress in this area. I believe that a work-life balance is key to increasing women's participation in the labour market. This is contributed by the creation of affordable and quality childcare facilities. This is still an important task.  At the same time, we need to promote an entrepreneurial culture in education, especially in areas where girls are more likely to learn. This is important for boosting entrepreneurship and creating a new business environment. In order to ensure that the real data are in line with the Europe 2020 employment target of 75%, these instruments should be given particular attention to the promotion of female entrepreneurs.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – Mr President, i would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur As if there is no difference between men and women from a legal point of view. Legal, legally, in the field of business. And can not be, but statistics show something else. Unfortunately, at present, only about a third of all entrepreneurs or self-employed persons in the European Union are women. And that's not right. And that's discrimination. All the necessary reforms are vital in this area in order to equate, real equate gender. But, in parallel, I would like to warn that gender quotas have been irrationally implemented for the boards of directors of companies. Gender equality is undeniably a good thing, but any processes and decisions in this regard must be based on the principles of genuine meritocracy. Consequently, if a person is independent of gender, it is imperative that he or she take up this or that item. Thank you!

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – A Uachtaráin, dar ndóigh vótáil mé ar son na tuarascála seo agus le mo ghrúpa sna vótaí go léir.  Now this is a topic I have been following for a number of years. I have to say that initially, when I saw the figures in relation to male and female entrepreneurs, I was very surprised at the disparity and I was wondering why there was such a disparity. Colleagues have pointed out some of the reasons, but one of them is confidence, and I that is something that has been ingrained over the years. Therefore, we have to change the circumstances; we have to remove the hurdles, as they are called in this report, so that males and females can become entrepreneurs on equal standing. The same applies to access to finance. Again, there is a perception that maybe the female entrepreneurs are not getting the same opportunities to get finance as males do when they want to start up, and this obviously has to change. I think it is beginning to change. In my own country, Enterprise Ireland has platforms and supports women for women in business,  these are all developing and absolutely vital, and we should encourage them.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE).
text: – Mr. President, the share of women entrepreneurs in the overall economy of the Republic of Croatia is only 30%, which is significantly lower than the European average, of which 23% are women business owners and 7% are women who have developed their own trades. This is a significant increase compared to 2001, when women entrepreneurs in Croatia made up only 7% of all entrepreneurs, but women are also capable of much more.  The potential of female entrepreneurship is great, but there are also major obstacles that women face in trying to start their own business. Therefore, I support the appeals made in this report to create concrete strategies that will allow for reducing bureaucratic burdens, assisting in the process of consolidating businesses, provide access to capital and establish additional education programmes.  I believe that it is necessary to come up with concrete measures that will allow women to align their work obligations with family responsibilities, which will encourage women to embark on an entrepreneurial adventure without having to fear neglecting the role of mother or family obligation.

name: Diane Dodds (NI).
text: – Mr President, I approach today’s debate and vote on promoting female entrepreneurship with a renewed sense of what is possible. In my constituency, Northern Ireland, we have a new, female First Minister. This is not only a first for our region of the United Kingdom, but also for my party, as Arlene Foster has now been elected leader as well. This is a huge step in the right direction.  However, Arlene is not a success story for those who advocate bringing change by imposing gender quotas, mainstreaming, or simply handing women opportunities as a principle in and of itself. Instead, she is an example of a woman with rural roots who has worked hard and risen to where she is today on the back of hard work, and who has demonstrated ability and steely determination to succeed for those she represents. Therefore, to the authors of this report my message is clear: yes, I support your aim to break down all forms of barriers to women entering the workplace; yes, I, too, want to remove obstacles to women accessing education and training, and yes, I want to give women in our society a base from which to display their entrepreneurial skills. However, I do not agree with quotas or any form of monitoring that redirects the emphasis from progress.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, this is an important report on female entrepreneurship and I was very happy to support it. In fact, when we look at the figures, we see that just 31% of the entrepreneurs at EU level are women. So I suppose we have to ask the question: what can we do at a European level, to try and support female entrepreneurship?  Well, one of the facilities that we have available is the microfinance facility. But again, when you look at the figures for 2013, you see that the ratio of male to female applications for this particular fund was 60:40. Therefore, it is clear that we need to do more at European level, and in that context, I was happy to support the amendment which called on the Commission to monitor the implementation of gender mainstreaming into the allocation of EU funds in relation to entrepreneurship. I think the figures for microfinance showed that is necessary. Also, I believe that the European network to promote women’s entrepreneurship helps combat stereotyping, and I am very pleased to see that the Commission this year is setting up an online platform, which will provide training, advice and business mentoring. Also, the creation of the Business Angels Network, with female business angels, will be a help.

name: Lars Adaktusson (PPE)
text: Written. Today, Parliament voted on a report on barriers to female entrepreneurship in Europe. The report highlights pressing issues, not least on reforms for increased entrepreneurship in women's dominant sectors. Unfortunately, there were also some paragraphs with which I am very critical. This includes requirements for EU regulation of parental leave. The Member States, like a broad popular opinion throughout the Union, have rejected the idea of the so-called maternity leave directive. The fact that Parliament is under pressure in this situation to start a new process on eu-regulated parental insurance is both unfortunate and fundamentally provocative. I voted against the paragraphs that raised this. However, since they together formed a very small part of the report, I chose to vote in favour in the final vote.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 In 2014, the employment rate of men in the EU was 70.1%, while that of women was only 59.6%. Unfortunately, these percentages are falling further if we are to report back to the women's entrepreneurship sector in Europe.  The factors that lead women more to prefer an employed rather than a freelance job have been identified in the difficult access to funding and the complicated work-life balance, especially as regards maternity rules. In line with European policies for economic growth and job creation, the EU must support women's entrepreneurial activities, trying to meet the demands and needs of a category still discriminated against by ancient social realities. I therefore voted in favour, relying on the implementation of new measures to ensure equal opportunities for men and women.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The report aims to accommodate concerns about women's barriers to self-employment, as only 34.4% of self-employed people are women. However, while the report stresses the importance of the Commission collecting data to assess the causes, or mentioning the importance of labour and personal conciliation — once again reiterating the need to improve the current Maternity Leave Directive – the report has a strong paternalistic approach in highlighting stereotypes and focusing on boasting entrepreneurship as a way to combat discrimination and inequality towards women without going into assess structural reasons such as symbolic violence, the unequal impact of austerity policies, or the destruction of employment and public services. That's why I abstained.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report on external factors that stand in the way of European women's entrepreneurship. Indeed, in addition to proposing measures without interest, the text is polluted with misappropriated demands such as the promotion of gender equality in companies, support for "women with multiple identities" or the establishment of psychological cells for women entrepreneurs. It is therefore a series of measures that help to place the woman as a victim that is proposed here. Moreover, the only stated measure that would be interesting is awareness during schooling, but this jurisdiction is the responsibility of the Member States and not of the European Union.  While I am in favour of gender equality in the world of work, this highly ideological text is of little interest and promotes counterproductive measures, such as equal paternity leave.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament's report on women's entrepreneurship because I believe that the relevant EU rates are at a low level, just 12%, and because I think it is worth giving extra emphasis to women's entrepreneurship as a separate priority of the economy. I would also like to point out that women's employment rates in the EU are 59% and are far from the 2020 target of 75%. Moreover, the proportion of self-employed women is 31%. Ultimately, the aim of the report is to overcome obstacles and address challenges, as well as to increase rates in the field of women's entrepreneurship, through access to additional funding and through support for social entrepreneurship which will in turn promote gender balance.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. This report presents a series of measures to make women more represented among business leaders based on the plurality of identities, the questioning of family models, the introduction of quotas for so-called disadvantaged groups... This report may ultimately justify harmful measures, so I objected.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This demeaning report claims that women entrepreneurs are ‘being used as fronts’ by men, confess to a lack of entrepreneurial skills, lack self-confidence, assertiveness and willingness to take risks when starting a business. It suggests women entrepreneurs therefore require motivational and psychological support programmes. I find such a stereotypical characterisation of women to be the most appalling example of everyday sexism, and wonder how the European Parliament could possibly pass such a patronising report given that we live in the 21st century. It will come as absolutely no surprise to anyone that I voted against this report.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this deliberation, as advocated by the committee on its merits.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to carry out a European review of female entrepreneurship. The EU's entrepreneurship sector is still lagging behind: in 2009, the entrepreneurship rate in the EU-27 was 12%, while China and the US accounted for 27% and 21% respectively. Women's entrepreneurship deserves special attention in this context, as equality in economic independence is not guaranteed in the EU so far, and the employment rate for women, reaching 59.6% in the EU-28 in 2014, is not in line with either the 75% employment target set in the Europe 2020 strategy or equal to the level of employment of men (70.1%). Unfortunately, the first obstacle to entrepreneurship is a difficult work-life balance. Women also have less access to external funding, such as bank loans and supplier credits, making it more likely that funding will be more expensive for them. This is partly because women have less knowledge of existing funding opportunities, more cautiously than men, or do not have as much experience in financial management as their male counterparts. Despite the enormous complexity of this problem, it is necessary to address the issue of female entrepreneurs who are discriminated against by financial service providers when they try to obtain credit.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. Among many uninteresting measures, there have been some far-fetched proposals, such as the support of "women with multiple identities" or the demand - directly derived from gender ideology - to "change the traditional distribution of roles within the family". Although this is an initiative report with no legislative impact, I voted against this text which risks justifying counterproductive measures such as non-transferable paternity leave, which would de facto reduce maternity leave.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. Considering the importance of entrepreneurship in creating jobs and the fact that women accounted for only 31% of entrepreneurs in the European Union in 2012, I approved this report which calls on Member States to adopt concrete strategies to remove barriers to female entrepreneurship. This is an integral part of gender equality, which must be one of our key political priorities. This includes a better work-life balance for all, support for women to start businesses, access to finance and the creation and support of network development.

name: Beatriz Becerra Basterrechea (ALDE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it identifies precisely and clearly the main elements which are an obstacle to achieving the entrepreneurship of European women. The work-life balance that entrepreneurship can offer women also represents the first obstacle, as it can put women in a vicious cycle in which women have fewer opportunities to gain management experience to run their businesses, build their credit history and gain investor confidence. I would also like to stress the importance of paragraph 22, which mentions the empirically rebutted approach to the proposal to the Commission to introduce gender quotas in all types of specific aid for underrepresented and disadvantaged groups, in order to ensure that progress is made towards business parity.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Female entrepreneurship is one of the european Union's greatest une exploited potentials: in 2012, only 31% of entrepreneurs were women, a negative figure especially when viewed in the light of the existence of realities in which women's names are used, as a figure, to obtain tax and legislative benefits.  I voted in favour of the report on external factors that represent obstacles to women's entrepreneurship in order to support the EU's commitment in this area. Opening up new spaces for women in the world of self-employment means, first and foremost, promoting growth and employment in all Member States, and also promoting positive mechanisms for cultural change. To commit ourselves to this means making childcare facilities available and affordable and for caring for the elderly; it means promoting a reconciliation of private and professional life and a fair distribution of family responsibilities between women and men.  The European Union must promote a holistic approach to female entrepreneurship, combating gender stereotypes, promoting the construction of an environment capable of developing women's entrepreneurial potential and simplifying access to finance.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report indicates that the rate of female entrepreneurship lags behind in many Member States and that there is actually untapped growth and prosperity potential. The report calls for concrete strategies to fully exploit the potential of women as entrepreneurs. While the focus is primarily on the private sector and entrepreneurship, positive references to the fight against gender stereotypes and a call to Member States to achieve Barcelona's objectives can be recognized. While it is true that there are many obstacles for women entrepreneurs, this report is part of the approach that believes that fostering entrepreneurship among women is key to achieving gender equality, something not shared from a progressive feminist perspective. References to the important role of the public sector and the negative effects of austerity policies in recent years are completely absent. Fearing that this report could be used to legitimize measures to increase women's business initiatives as the only solution to improve women's living conditions, giving greater weight to the financial and private sector, I abstained in the vote.

name: Joëlle Bergeron (EFDD)
text: In writing. I voted for this report because it is clear that the fight against youth unemployment must be the workhorse of any employment policy.  But let's not delude ourselves. The banalities and truths of La Palisse, the report of which this report is full, will not provide an answer to the challenge of youth unemployment, which today reaches staggering percentages in countries such as Spain.  Europe will not be able to do anything about it. And the litany of reports that have been written on the subject will not be able to do anything about it either. Unfortunately, we see that the countries that are not members of the Union - I am thinking of Switzerland or Norway - are doing better in this area than our Member States. We should ask ourselves why. It is up to the states to make the necessary efforts to boost youth employment. Through a proactive policy in favour of SMEs, which are the largest job creators. By a policy of lowering the loads and a training policy.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. This report on the factors impeding women's entrepreneurship should suggest positions to make women more represented among business leaders.  This text is clearly intrusive and victimizing towards women. It proposes, among other things, to promote gender equality in companies, to support "women with multiple identities", to distribute household chores equitably or to change the usual roles in families.... The only interesting suggestion is not within the competence of the Union (awareness during schooling) and I therefore voted against this text.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report is balanced and acceptable, and it does not fall into the usual woman-man rhetoric to which we are accustomed, for these reasons I voted in favour of this text.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. This report makes a detailed analysis of the different factors that hinder women's entrepreneurship in the European Union. Although entrepreneurship has been a political priority since the adoption of the Lisbon Treaty, the European Union is still a notable delay: in 2009 the entrepreneurship rate in the EU-27 was 12% compared to 27% and 21% in China and the United States respectively. In this sense, women's entrepreneurship deserves particular attention, as economic independence is not yet guaranteed in the EU, and the female employment rate, 59.6% in 2014 in the Union, is below the 75% employment target defined in the Europe 2020 Strategy. The two main obstacles faced by women entrepreneurs are the difficulty of reconciling family and work life, and the problems of access to funding, which in some cases involve gender discrimination. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report, which examines the entrepreneurial and career opportunities of European women. From a career in business perspective, the differences between women and men are still evident. In 2012, women in the EU-28 accounted for only 31% of all self-employed citizens. Female entrepreneurs are likely to develop their own company with less experience than men. Women are more likely to choose between people's health and social work or education, while male entrepreneurs are more likely to work in construction, transport and ICT sectors. As most of the latter sectors have a higher entrepreneurship rate and are all characterised by higher economic added value, it is not surprising that the incomes of female entrepreneurs were 6% lower in 2012 than that of men. In addition, their scope remains lower than that of men: 23% of women and 30% of men in the EU-28 are 28%. European women seem to decide to choose entrepreneurship for other reasons. Women often say they are forced to do so because entrepreneurship allows them to combine work and care-related responsibilities, such as childcare or care for the elderly, and provides more opportunities to work from home.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Like the report, I am concerned about helping women to entrepreneurship and developing, as this represents a huge opportunity for growth and development to be exploited. It applies not only at the general economic level (I am thinking of economic strengthening, job creation here), but also from the point of view of women's self-realisation (economic independence, important role in promoting gender equality, exemplary model for young generations). I am convinced that it is of the utmost importance to encourage and support women in building an entrepreneurial career and, of course, to facilitate their access to finance and business opportunities. It is equally important to reconcile professional and private life, as this balance helps to unlock opportunities and become successful entrepreneurs. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. The share of women in entrepreneurship remains very low despite all efforts and slight improvement in the trend. Their salaries are also lower, about 6% of the salaries paid by men. The reason for women's lower participation in entrepreneurship is to look at difficult work-life balance, which is more complex for women than for men.  I myself know many examples of excellent female entrepreneurs, who are also dedicated mothers and often the latter, that is, the mission of motherhood, gives them even more motivation in their professional goals.  The report also draws attention to differences in access to finance for women in entrepreneurship, which calls for more attention and research to help uncover the causes of this.  Despite the legal prohibited discrimination, there are a number of cases that do not allow women equal access to funds. It is the commission's job, and also us Members, to draw attention to this and to come up with measures that will eliminate similar cases. The solution may also be found in social entrepreneurship, which is more popular with women, if I may express myself.  With the hope of improving the situation, I supported the proposed report.

name: Simona Bonafè (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Promoting entrepreneurship is an essential driver of employment, economic growth, development and innovation, the European Union's top priorities and at the heart of the Europe 2020 strategy for sustainable and inclusive smart growth.  Despite this, European numbers are well below Chinese or US entrepreneurship rates. This issue is linked to another major challenge, that of gender equality. Inequalities between women and men are evident in the business professions: in 2012, women accounted for only 31% of the total eu-28 self-employed.  There are many reasons for this, from the difficulty of reconciling family and professional career to obstacles to access to finance. For these reasons, I believe that the only response must be to promote a holistic approach to women's entrepreneurship, aimed at building a framework that allows women to realise their potential, while also encouraging an entrepreneurial culture in education and training, which will also make them more aware of the economic and social opportunities at stake.  The solution to this problem is a priority: I have therefore supported this report, which calls on the Commission to present concrete legislative proposals on this subject by the end of 2016.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the report on external factors that stand in the way of European women's entrepreneurship. Indeed, this report contains many uninteresting measures and proposals that I cannot support: promoting gender equality in business, supporting in particular 'women with multiple identities', 'ensuring a good distribution of household tasks' and 'changing the traditional distribution of roles within the family'.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because I firmly believe that it is the task of the European Union and its institutions to remove all obstacles to the development of female entrepreneurship. In fact, the benefits brought by the development of female entrepreneurship would be innumerable and would have a positive impact on the whole of society, and not only from an economic point of view.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Female entrepreneurship and the employment rate of women in Europe are still undersized compared to the Europe 2020 targets.  The difficulties in ensuring work-life balance, access to finance and proper procedural information, together with the prejudices to which they are subject, still prevent many women from competing on an equal footing with men in the world of contemporary entrepreneurship.  The Union must endeavour to remove the remaining obstacles, both materially and culturally, by guaranteeing equal opportunities and by promoting women's entrepreneurship which, both in the social and the more traditional sector, represents a means of personal emancipation, social advancement and economic development not only for individuals but also for the entire economic community, which will only return to growth and development effectively when its average rate of entrepreneurship and employment is will come close to what is foreseen in the objectives of the Europe 2020 report.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. In this text, the rapporteur proposes ways of thinking so that women are better represented among business leaders. The report promotes gender equality in enterprises, wants to ensure the proper distribution of household chores in households, advocates the introduction of women's quotas and the creation of psychological support cells for women entrepreneurs. These proposals illustrate the growing disconnect between Brussels technocrats and the real concerns of women in the EU Member States. These proposals are completely counterproductive, like equal and non-transferable paternity leave, which will help to drastically reduce maternity leave. The only valid suggestion, namely the introduction to entrepreneurship in school curricula, is not within the competence of the Union. That is why I voted against it.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Entrepreneurship among women needs greater attention from the authorities, bearing in mind that equal economic independence is not yet a fact achieved in the European Union. Equal participation of men and women in the labour market could significantly increase the EU's economic potential, while confirming its fairness and inclusiveness. I believe that the role of women in the current entrepreneurial economy based on knowledge is very important; that is why it is essential to increase the rate of the number of businesses carried out by them. Women also represent enormous entrepreneurial potential, and entrepreneurship means economic growth, job creation and women's empowerment, which is why I have expressed myself in favour of this report.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report does not present any problems and does not fall into the usual rhetoric between women and men, to favour or discriminate against women according to sexual orientation, immigrant or otherwise, etc. The report encourages Member States to recognise the value of female entrepreneurship to their economies and calls on Member States to present concrete strategies to exploit the full potential of women as entrepreneurs. Welcomes the creation of the various European networks of female entrepreneurs and urges member states' equal opportunities bodies to raise awareness among lenders of the obligation to ensure equal treatment and to study the possibility of introducing gender equality into investment mandates. Encourages Member States to promote an entrepreneurial culture in education and training programmes and stresses the importance of providing courses on finance, entrepreneurship and the development of new businesses in secondary education, especially in courses more attended by girls, such as health care and other services; it also calls on schools and universities to encourage girls and women to study subjects that open up career opportunities in finance and high-growth sectors, such as technologies, including green technologies. I am voting in favour.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. One of the European Union's economic and social priorities is to stimulate entrepreneurship. This is part of the strategy of the three "E's": jobs, business and entrepreneurship. The European Union is lagging behind the United States and China in this area. From this perspective, women's entrepreneurship requires special attention. In Europe, it is mainly men who are engaged in entrepreneurship. This situation must be addressed by creating gender-appropriate incentives. Equality between men and women in terms of professional careers and wages must become a reality. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report on external factors that represent obstacles to European women's entrepreneurship, because I believe that women's entrepreneurship is a key political issue for the European institutions.  Unfortunately, the gap between men and women is still very high in EU countries and not just in the business field. Most women do not consider entrepreneurship to be one of their career opportunities. The current proportion of women entrepreneurs in the EU is 33% while only 34.4% of the EU's self-employed are women. There is still a great deal to be done, but unfortunately we are a long way from the full application of European legislation. Europe needs to commit itself to working with national authorities to address areas, such as access to credit and business networks, where the needs of women entrepreneurs are not yet sufficiently met. This type of policy is also of decisive importance in stimulating economic growth, prosperity and competitiveness.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this report as I do not see the focus on female entrepreneurship being well-placed since the government has inflicted huge cuts on the public sector where a large majority of women are working (healthcare, education and civil service).  The report calls for concrete strategies to promote a culture of female entrepreneurship but strategies on gender equality and the value of women in the public sector, which are huge issues, have been neglected. For these reasons I could not support the report.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non legislative and non-binding report.  It included calls to encourage men to become more involved in the housework for example through mandatory paternity leave. It is not for any government and especially EU bureaucrats to interfere with the private lives of families, marriages and partnerships regarding who should do the housework. It included sexist assumptions that women are used as ‘fronts’ by men to get favourable financial deals; that women underrated their skills and are more likely to confess a lack of self-confidence and assertiveness and thus need psychological support programmes. UKIP believes women and men are equal and the EU has no right to say women are inferior and need demeaning hand-outs. Finally the report calls for the EU to spend more taxpayer’s money and bring forward more legislation. The only people that should decide any of these things are our elected and accountable government, not unelected bureaucrats in Brussels.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report as it rightly points out that women still face indirect discrimination and in 2014 the employment rate for women in the EU was 59.6% in comparison to 70.1% for men. In addition to that, only 31% of entrepreneurs are female. The EU and the national governments need to encourage women to put their ideas into action and most importantly show them what kinds of financial help and expertise are available to them. The report suggests viable plans that can be put into action on national and EU levels and initiatives that will help encourage female entrepreneurship and bring us more towards our Europe 2020 targets.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report aimed at addressing the problems faced by women today in the field of entrepreneurship, unfortunately in Europe still characterised by considerable differences between men and women.  There are many obstacles encountered by women who want to devote themselves to the world of business: access to finance (the banking sector often does not welcome the participation of women, going so far as to provide funds in their favour with greater difficulty); the difficult work-life balance and, above all, the need to overcome ancient cultural and social heritages that require a full awareness on the part of society of the equal opportunities that must be guaranteed to men and women. The report was intended to send the European Commission a call for new measures and greater efforts to increase women's participation.

name: Dita Charanzová (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on the proposal of the report as the final text included particular paragraph explicitly calling for introduction of gender quotas which I strongly oppose. While the text mentions some real issues related to obstacles women face when running a business, quotas are not an appropriate instrument to remedy the situation.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The use of self-employment and business creation has been the solution to unemployment for many women and often also the preferred way to reconcile family and working life. Apart from the reasons for opting for entrepreneurship, only 31% of the self-employed are still women in the European Union today. Despite European regulations and Community guidelines calling on Member States to create a level playing field for men and women, it is still difficult for female entrepreneurs to obtain bank and insurance guarantees or access to credit, despite the fact that compared to men they are rarely insolvent when it comes to repaying loans. These difficulties, in addition to discouraging the start-up of new activities, have also limited their development and reduced the possibility of creating jobs. In order to get Europe back on the track of growth and to reach the 75% employment target for women by 2020, there is not only a need for European legislation to be implemented, but the credit world needs to overcome distrust of women. One of the reasons why I voted in favour is the call for the Commission to monitor the Member States in order to create an environment conducive to the development of women's businesses.

name: Ole Christensen (S&D)
text: Written. Equality is a social democratic issue. We have always worked for a society of equal opportunities for all and where no person is discriminated against on the basis of gender. Non-discrimination is the guiding principle. This principle must also apply to EU funds. Eu funds should be allocated on the basis of the value and nature of the projects, not on the basis of the gender of the project applicant. We would like to stress that we find it very problematic that women participate less than men in the labour market, both as employees and as entrepreneurs. A more equal distribution of maternity leave between mothers and fathers can be an instrument for increasing women's participation in the labour market. However, the EU should respect the existence of different national systems to ensure a more equitable distribution of maternity leave, where in some countries it is determined through legislation and in others by the social partners. It must remain up to each Member State which system they wish to use to ensure more equality in the labour market. We do not believe that the European Union should legislate on this.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Differences between men and women remain visible in careers in the business world. We support the report because women's entrepreneurship deserves special attention, since equal economic independence is not yet a given within the European Union.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 The wider issue of women's entrepreneurship is a particularly important area in which we need to turn our attention. The need for women entrepreneurs to find the necessary outlets to develop their activities is clear and urgent in a Europe that is looking for ways to return to healthy growth. That is why I have decided to vote in favour.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the measure as I recognise the value of female entrepreneurship as a key contribution to the development of local communities and social inclusion.  In 2012, women accounted for only 31% of all self-employed people in the EU-28. According to statistics, women make less use of external funding, find it difficult to access finance in the form of equity participation and tend to choose more expensive forms of capital raising. Although Directive 2004/113/EC expressly prohibits financial services from discriminaating in the disbursement of bank loans, I believe that we must insist on the problem of differentiation of treatment in access to credit for women entrepreneurs by financial service providers.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I congratulate Barbara Matera, who has been able to compile a long and exhaustive list of issues related to women's entrepreneurship in Europe. Whether we are talking about prejudices, or material obstacles, the European economy cannot and must not do without the resources that women can bring to the economic scenario. For these reasons, I voted in favour of this report.

name: David Coburn (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non legislative and non-binding report.  It included calls to encourage men to become more involved in the housework for example through mandatory paternity leave. It is not for any government and especially EU bureaucrats to interfere with the private lives of families, marriages and partnerships regarding who should do the housework. It included sexist assumptions that women are used as ‘fronts’ by men to get favourable financial deals; that women underrated their skills and are more likely to confess a lack of self-confidence and assertiveness and thus need psychological support programmes. UKIP believes women and men are equal and the EU has no right to say women are inferior and need demeaning hand-outs. Finally the report calls for the EU to spend more taxpayer’s money and bring forward more legislation. The only people that should decide any of these things are our elected and accountable government, not unelected bureaucrats in Brussels.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Among the strategies to revive the economy and create new jobs, the European Union should not overlook two fundamental factors: allowing access to more entrepreneurs and adopting a strategy for smart and sustainable growth.  Unfortunately, in the area of female entrepreneurship, there are still too many cases of discrimination on the grounds of sex, access to credit, equal economic independence is not guaranteed and the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy have not so far made much progress in this direction. Therefore, in order to prevent these problems from having a negative impact on the economy, I believe that we need to encourage more initiatives in favour of promoting employment and respecting gender equality.  I am therefore in favour of the European Parliament's motion for a resolution, in the hope that many of the obstacles that undermine European women's entrepreneurship will actually be removed.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Data clearly indicates that women’s employment rate remains in large disparity with that of men, that the economic crisis has continued to affect their employment prospects and that we are still off the Europe 2020 target. Entrepreneurship is however one medium through which women can use their skills and talents as well as obtain the opportunity to be able to fulfil their aspirations as equal partners in society. Female unemployment continues to have serious consequences on the living conditions of families. The report identifies measures to facilitate female entrepreneurship.  I have thus voted in favour.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report aims to address the problems faced by women today in the field of entrepreneurship, which is still characterised in Europe by considerable differences between men and women. There are a number of factors that hinder women's ability to engage in the business world, and with this report the FEMM Committee wanted to call on the European Commission to implement new measures and to make greater efforts to increase women's participation. One of the obstacles identified is access to finance, in view of the fact that the banking sector often does not welcome the participation of women, going so far as to provide funds for them with greater difficulty. Another obstacle is the difficult work-life balance. The report also refers to the failure to adopt the directive on maternity leave and therefore requires new measures to remedy this situation and to put women in a position to combine professional commitments with family life. It also highlights the need for specific training in entrepreneurship and the overcoming of ancient heritages which are primarily cultural and social. I think it is a good report and i therefore voted in favour of it.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The report aims to accommodate concerns about women's barriers to self-employment, as only 34.4% of self-employed people are women. However, while the report stresses the importance of the Commission collecting data to assess the causes, or mentioning the importance of labour and personal conciliation — once again reiterating the need to improve the current Maternity Leave Directive – the report has a strong paternalistic approach in highlighting stereotypes and focusing on boasting entrepreneurship as a way to combat discrimination and inequality towards women without going into assess structural reasons such as symbolic violence, the unequal impact of austerity policies, or the destruction of employment and public services. That's why I abstained.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament resolution for which I voted in favour encourages Member States to recognise the value of female entrepreneurship for their economies and the obstacles to be overcome.  In order to reduce these obstacles, the European Parliament considers that the gender dimension should be fully integrated into future entrepreneurship policy and calls on the Member States to present concrete strategies to promote the culture of female entrepreneurship through easier access to finance, the use of information and networks, greater education and training for entrepreneurship and taking into account the need to focus on the needs of women. , the motivations and conditions for the elimination of gender stereotypes, as well as different management and management methodologies and new organisational and management models of enterprises.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The differences between men and women are evident in entrepreneurship. Figures for 2012 show that only 31% of all self-employed citizens in the EU-28 were women. Women are more likely than men to prefer working as an employee. There are also differences in the way women and men finance their own companies. Women start their business with lower capital and lower loans, use family finance more often than men, and rely less on debt financing. Women may be less informed about the funding options available and are more cautious about taking economic and financial risks, or have less financial management experience than their male counterparts.  Encouraging women's entrepreneurship is one of the main aims of the European People's Party. In order to give the European economy a new impetus and create new jobs, the EU needs more businesses. Women's businesses need to be given more attention, partly because it is a major source of women's economic independence. The report that we voted for today highlights the factors that negatively affect women's entrepreneurship, thereby reinforcing indirect discrimination against women from the moment they start up and foreshadowing solutions.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as entrepreneurial spirit is invaluable and we must continue to foster it throughout Europe. With Europe lagging behind with a 12% rate of entrepreneurship compared to a 27% rate in the US and 21% in China, it is now more essential than ever that we utilise the female work force to help induce economic growth and job creation in line with the EU’s 2020 targets. The report builds upon the Parliament’s 2011 resolution on female entrepreneurship and highlights further initiatives aimed at bridging the gender-gap within enterprise. Although there is no conclusive evidence to suggest direct discrimination within the field, substantial evidence suggests that females are still more likely than men to find obstacles such as access to equity finance. The report suggests that extended measures such as more female representation within the finance sector may combat this.

name: Rosa D'Amato (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The figures speak for themselves and the gap between male and female entrepreneurship is huge in terms of both employment and perceived net income. The heavy burden of family and parental care and the traditional division of roles between men and women penalise women's entrepreneurial ambitions and potential.  Unlike those who argue that women have greater risk aversion and less self-confidence, it should be admitted that there is a tendency on the part of society to consider the success of a female business project to be less likely, resulting in greater difficulties for women to access funding.  I voted in favour of this report, as it calls on the European Commission and the Member States to establish strategic policies and implement concrete actions to enable a reconciliation of professional and personal life, facilitating access to services, guaranteeing access to credit, tax and financial support for women entrepreneurs, including through European microfinance instruments such as Progress. Through a further cultural change for the removal of stereotypes and all forms of discrimination, it will therefore be possible to remove obstacles and allow female entrepreneurship to express its full potential.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This initiative report is part of the European Union's strategy for smart, inclusive and sustainable growth (Europe 2020) and the desire to foster entrepreneurship to stimulate job creation. In this context, women's entrepreneurship deserves special attention, as this report raises the issue of indirect discrimination faced by women when they start their own businesses. Considering that this report is balanced, I voted in favour.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I have at heart the question of the place of women in the world of work. That is why I voted in favour of this report, which aims to promote women's entrepreneurship within the Union, particularly through quotas in the allocation of European funds.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I believe that the European Commission must take action with all the means at its possession to encourage girls and women to embark on entrepreneurial careers.  In the European Union, only 30% of entrepreneurs are women. This is totally unsatisfactory, and that is why we need new rebalancing policies and new measures which aim to remove obstacles to the free expression of women's entrepreneurial vocation and which offer women effective tools and concrete opportunities to do business in Europe.  It will also be important to ensure funding opportunities for women's entrepreneurship, which, in terms of access, often breaks the rock of negative cultural stereotypes about women's success in doing business.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. 60% of university graduates in Europe are women. However, they remain largely in the minority in senior positions and represent only 31% of entrepreneurs. At a time when the European Union is going through a serious economic crisis, women entrepreneurs have exceptional potential to create growth and jobs. Women should therefore be supported in setting up businesses and valuing their skills, and more generally accompanying them in their economic and professional projects.  The European Union has a concrete role to play in promoting, in particular, the range of European financing for entrepreneurial activity.

name: Angélique Delahaye (PPE)
text: In writing. Women's entrepreneurship deserves special attention: egalitarian economic independence is still not a reality in the European Union and the employment rate of women falls short of the target set out in the Europe 2020 strategy. That is why I voted in favour of the MATERA report on external factors that hinder women's entrepreneurship.  Through this vote, I would like to draw particular attention to the financing needs of women entrepreneurs and to raise the issue of indirect discrimination faced by women when they start their own businesses. However, I regret the introduction of gender quotas for all forms of targeted assistance to disadvantaged and under-represented groups. It is not the role of the European Parliament to introduce such quotas, but that of each Member State, which will more specifically take into account domestic needs.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 First of all, I would like to congratulate Mrs Matera on her excellent report. I, too, am concerned with helping women to do business and developing, because it represents a huge opportunity for growth and development to be exploited, not only at the general economic level (I am thinking of economic strengthening, job creation here), but also in terms of women's self-realisation (economic independence, an important role in promoting gender equality, an exemplary model for young generations). I am convinced that it is of the utmost importance to encourage and support women in building an entrepreneurial career and, of course, to facilitate their access to finance and business opportunities. It is equally important to reconcile professional and private life, as this balance helps to unlock opportunities and become successful entrepreneurs. I voted in favour of the report, of course.

name: Martina Dlabajová (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ As a previous (female) entrepreneur, I truly believe in promoting female entrepreneurship. It is important to strive for an EU-wide approach to encourage and support women in building their career in the private sector, including facilitating access to finance and business opportunities. Unfortunately this report goes far beyond this goal and that is the reason why I decided to abstain on the final vote. It feels to me counter-productive to call for additional rules of gender mainstreaming and for gender quotas in distributing EU funds for entrepreneurship. Making business should be simple, and access to finance should be simplified and not vice versa. Moreover, calling for a mandatory paternity leave as a way of promoting female entrepreneurship seems to be an overstated measure which I cannot support in this context.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. This report is a matter of utopia and tutelary ideology, as it promotes a distorted vision of human relations and identity, by associating the sexual genre. I remain convinced that the representation of women, in this case in the world of work, is not decreed by rules and quotas that distort the dynamics of merit and the fair selection of talent.  Worse still, this report seeks to promote changes or behaviours specific to the family structure, in which the Union has no legitimacy to act. Remaining on the side of the family and defending freedoms, I voted against this report, as ideological as it is intrusive.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 In general, the idea of some external factors that could be an obstacle for female entrepreneurs in Europe could find support in me. However, I abstained in the final vote on this report because of the existence of a paragraph calling on the Commission to introduce quotas for men and women in the course of their funding, and for me this is not a solution to the issue.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 We are voting against this report firstly because it does not correspond to the Greek reality. The EU should establish specific strategies to promote women's entrepreneurship in the light of the real needs of the Member States and not generally and vaguely as presented in the report as many start-ups cannot adapt and grow in the local market. In addition, according to the report, the EU aims to finance women's entrepreneurship actions but at the same time refers to grants and investments in lifelong training and retraining programmes (PROGRESS), to which we are opposed.  Finally, through freedom and full gender equality, a new role for women is emerging in today's rapidly changing economic environment, but the role of the institution of the family is being set aside.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I consider it important to help women's entrepreneurship and to develop, as it represents a huge opportunity for growth and development to be exploited, not only at the general economic level (I am thinking of economic strengthening, job creation here), but also in terms of women's self-realisation (economic independence, important role in promoting gender equality, an exemplary model for young generations). I am convinced that it is of the utmost importance to encourage and support women in building an entrepreneurial career and, of course, to facilitate their access to finance and business opportunities. It is equally important to reconcile professional and private life, as this balance helps to unlock opportunities and become successful entrepreneurs. I voted in favour of the report, of course.

name: Rosa Estaràs Ferragut (PPE)
text: in writing. The female employment rate is below the EU-marked employment line. That is why attention should be paid to the funding needs of women entrepreneurs, to the particularities of female social entrepreneurs, as well as to address issues such as indirect discrimination faced by women at the beginning of the creation of their enterprises, considering the obstacles that exist in women's entrepreneurship.  Bearing in mind also that Europe needs more entrepreneurs to expand and create new jobs, from the European institutions we must promote women's entrepreneurship. The European Union should offer women the opportunity for greater integration into labour markets, as well as offer them the opportunity to strengthen their role as business leaders, fostering cultural change within and outside their enterprises that will serve as an example for girls and young people.

name: José Inácio Faria (ALDE)
text: in writing. I abstained in the vote on the implementation of a gender quota scheme for entrepreneurship financing instruments, not because it is against women's participation in the labour market, but quite the contrary because I believe that the quota system is discriminatory to women. This system contributes to the maintenance of a differentiated form of treatment between genders and does not allow women to assert themselves by meritocracy. To assume a quota system is to accept that women are not at the same level as men, an assumption with which I totally and completely disagree.

name: Fredrick Federley (ALDE)
text: Written. For me, gender equality is a key issue. The fact that the proportion of women entrepreneurs is lagging behind in all Member States is a loss for society as a whole. I fully share the view of the need for a holistic approach to female entrepreneurship, and that women's access to EU funding and additional development opportunities should be facilitated in different ways. However, I do not believe that gender quotas are part of the solution. I therefore voted against paragraph 22 of this report, but nevertheless chose to end up endorsing the report as a whole because it contains other important elements of importance for female entrepreneurship.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Although entrepreneurship has been a political priority since the start of the Lisbon Treaty, the European Union is still somewhat behind in this area, with an entrepreneurship rate of 12 % at EU-27 level in 2009 compared to the 27% and 21% rates of China and the US respectively. In this context, female entrepreneurship deserves special attention, as equality in terms of economic independence is still not guaranteed in the European Union and that the employment rate of women, which was set at 59.6 % in 2014 at EU-28 level, is not consistent with either the 75 % employment target of the Europe 2020 strategy, nor with the male employment rate of 70.1 %. When women start businesses, they do so more often in sectors related to human health, social action or education, while male entrepreneurs are more present in areas of the construction, transport and ICT sectors.  We must encourage entrepreneurship from primary school and tackle the obstacles that are in this way.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report because it contains recommendations that have nothing to do with the substance of the matter.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The own-initiative report states that the rate of female entrepreneurship is very low in many Member States and advocates concrete strategies to fully exploit the potential of female entrepreneurship. This includes awareness-raising campaigns in banks and other financial institutions to ensure equal treatment between men and women in access to credit, quotas by gender for the allocation of EU funds, the promotion of a culture of entrepreneurship in education and training curricula. The report considers that female entrepreneurship plays a key role in the fight for gender rights and equality. Silly, it's clear. There are positive aspects to combating gender stereotypes or defending some public services and a better work-life balance. There is a lack of a critical reference to the withdrawal of the Maternity Directive. As it is certain that women entrepreneurs face numerous obstacles, there is a disproportionate weight attributed to some of the aspects addressed in this report with regard to their contribution to the fight for gender equality. On the other hand, the role of the public sector and the negative effects of austerity policies are completely absent from the report. We abstained.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ The important role of the public sector and the negative effects of the last year’s austerity policies are completely absent in this report. I voted against.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ although the European Union has been trying over the last 20 years to improve the position of women in terms of their entrepreneurial careers, it is still evident that the proportion of women from all self-employed citizens is only around 30%, an alarming figure. Women have considerable difficulties in obtaining funding for their business that convincing evidence that there is direct discrimination in the Member States — however, the non-allocation of funds to female entrepreneurs may also be the result of an economic logic whereing investors seek a higher return on investment, namely in larger companies from more profitable male-dominated sectors, even though Directive 2004/113/EC expressly prohibits direct or indirect discrimination in financial services, including bank loans.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 Female entrepreneurship is indeed a catalyst for reducing unemployment and lifting the economy, but only when it is growing in a country with a healthy economy and not in a country in times of economic crisis, such as Greece, where businesses are shrinking and going bankrupt.  We are voting against this report first of all because it does not correspond to the Greek reality. The EU should establish specific strategies to promote women's entrepreneurship in the light of the real needs of the Member States and not generally and vaguely as presented in the report, since many start-ups cannot adapt and grow in the local market. In addition, according to the report, the EU aims to finance women's entrepreneurship actions but at the same time refers to grants and investments in lifelong training and retraining programmes (PROGRESS), to which we are opposed.  Finally, freedom and full gender equality brings out a new role for women in today's rapidly changing economic environment, a role which inevitably set aside the institution of the family. For these reasons I am voting against the report on external factors that are an obstacle to women's entrepreneurship in Europe.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Female entrepreneurship is a powerful source of economic independence that further integrates women into labour markets; moreover, it strengthens their role as business leaders and induces cultural change both inside and outside their companies. However, the EU still lags behind with an entrepreneurial rate of 12%. Female entrepreneurship deserves particular attention as equal economic independence is not a given while women’s employment rate of 59% is not in line with the 75% target of EU 2020. Of all self-employed, only 31% are female. It is time for Member States to recognise the value of female entrepreneurship for their economies and the hurdles that need to be overcome. I strongly believe we must focus on work/life balance measures such as paternity, parental and maternity leaves for the self-employed; and grant access to funding. Otherwise, female entrepreneurs will remain an unexploited potential.

name: Mariya Gabriel (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this very good report, in which my colleague Barbara Matera took care to reflect a precise analysis of the obstacles to European women's entrepreneurship, taking into account indirect and direct factors.  The emphasis on gender stereotypes, both as internalised barriers by women and as barriers to access to finance, is particularly relevant and the report proposes interesting solutions at European, national and regional levels.  Raising awareness among investors and the financial community more generally is an important priority. I also welcome the special attention paid to entrepreneurship in the new information and communication technologies sector. To encourage and support women's entrepreneurship in this sector, efforts must be doubly important to reduce the impact of gender stereotypes.  Finally, the report also has the merit of recalling that it is possible to mobilise European structural funds to help reconcile work and private life, which is also an underlying element that determines women's participation in the labour market and even more so in entrepreneurship.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 First of all, I would like to congratulate Mrs Matera on her excellent report. I, too, am concerned with helping women to do business and developing, because it represents a huge opportunity for growth and development to be exploited, not only at the general economic level (I am thinking of economic strengthening, job creation here), but also in terms of women's self-realisation (economic independence, an important role in promoting gender equality, an exemplary model for young generations). I am convinced that it is of the utmost importance to encourage and support women in building an entrepreneurial career and, of course, to facilitate their access to finance and business opportunities. It is equally important to reconcile professional and private life, as this balance helps to unlock opportunities and become successful entrepreneurs. I voted in favour of the report, of course.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 First of all, I would like to congratulate Congresswoman Matera on her excellent report. I, too, am concerned with helping women to do business and developing, as this represents a huge opportunity for growth and development to be exploited, not only at the general economic level (I am thinking of economic strengthening, job creation here), but also in terms of women's self-realisation (economic independence, important role in promoting gender equality, an exemplary model for young generations). I am convinced that it is of the utmost importance to encourage and support women in building an entrepreneurial career and, of course, to facilitate their access to finance and business opportunities. It is equally important to reconcile professional and private life, as this balance helps to unlock opportunities and become successful entrepreneurs. I voted in favour of the report, of course.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Fact that the European Union still has a significant delay in entrepreneurship, as the entrepreneurship rate in the EU27 is significantly lower than that of other global actors. To strengthen recovery in Europe and create quality jobs, the European Union needs more entrepreneurs. In this context, women's entrepreneurship is particularly important, as the female employment rate is below the employment target of 75% as defined in the Europe 2020 Strategy and the male employment rate. The work-life balance that entrepreneurship can offer women also represents the first obstacle, as it can put women in a vicious cycle where they have fewer opportunities to gain management experience to run their businesses, build their credit history, and gain investor confidence. Therefore, from the EU institutions we must work tirelessly to promote the entrepreneurship of European women as well as to eliminate the locks that undermine their progress.

name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 All the data show that inequalities still exist between men and women in the business world. This report effectively highlights the external factors that hinder female entrepreneurship and on which action is needed as soon as possible to put an end to this unacceptable situation and enable women to realise their extraordinary potential.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. I can only wholeheartedly support this report, which reiterates the urgent need to ensure equal rights and opportunities for men and women in the European business world.  This is an opportunity for Europe to reaffirm that the removal of inequalities and the fight against all forms of discrimination are the cultural engines that form the foundations of this and drive the Union to development and social and economic growth. I therefore agree with the need to promote the instruments that make it easier for women to reconcile private and professional life, and I would stress in particular the importance of providing for new financial investments to promote the increase and opportunities available to female entrepreneurs.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament's non-legislative resolution on external factors that represent obstacles to European female entrepreneurship because I firmly believe that female entrepreneurs and women's entrepreneurship in general represent an extraordinary potential for EU growth, unfortunately still largely unexplored. I supported the structure of the own-initiative report, and in particular those drivers for women's participation in the European economy that the EU has a duty to promote. I am thinking of access to credit and adequate funding, but also of the issue of new professions and the participation of women in digital entrepreneurship. In addition, I am of the opinion that the development of women's entrepreneurship and the social economy in the EU, where women can play a leading role, is a great opportunity for growth for the whole EU. To this end, the issue of work-life reconciliation, which the EU must promote in the Member States, through appropriate legislation on parental leave and maternity rights for the self-employed must also play a key role.  The current 31% figure for women entrepreneurs in the EU needs to be rapidly increased if the EU really wants to achieve the EMPLOYMENT target of the EU 2020 strategy, and Parliament will strongly support good policies that promote women's work.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of Mrs Matera's 'Report on External Factors that Are Obstacles to Female Entrepreneurship', as I believe that we should resolutely promote female entrepreneurship, but in particular maternal entrepreneurship – mompreneurship. I also believe that women entrepreneurs can make a valuable contribution to promoting values in the economy and the ideal of "honourable merchant".

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. There are still differences between women and men, particularly in the field of self-employed entrepreneurs. Today's report is intended to continue to support women in setting up their own businesses.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report, which is aimed at boosting economic growth, creating sustainable jobs and empowering women.  At the moment, women make up only a third of entrepreneurs, which means that there is great untapped potential. By addressing issues such as childcare provision, parental leave for the self-employed and encouraging girls to work in areas with high growth potential such as IT and new technologies we can begin to bridge the entrepreneurial gender gap. This has benefits for society as a whole, with some estimates indicating that boosting female entrepreneurship could deliver as much as GBP 60 billion to the UK economy by 2030, and I was delighted to vote in favour of this report.
