name: Julie Girling (ECR)
text: in writing. – In the UK, women make up just 18% of entrepreneurs. The economic advantages to encouraging and supporting more women in becoming entrepreneurs are significant. According to research, if the number of female entrepreneurs equalled that of male entrepreneurs, UK GDP could be increased by 10% by 2030. Starting a business is a huge undertaking and many of the one million female entrepreneurs in the UK will testify that ‘it’s often not as straightforward a career path for women as it is for men’. The Entrepreneur Association suggests that the biggest barrier to women becoming entrepreneurs is confidence and mindset.  This report highlighted a number of practical elements which could help women become entrepreneurs; specific skills based training; peer-to- peer support; access to childcare for women with children; and confidence that banks will treat men and women equally in their application for a start-up loan. There were a small number of elements of this report which the UK Delegation was unable to support, mainly regarding social policy which we believe should be driven by national governments. Overall, the UK Delegation was pleased to be able to support this report.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report indicates that the rate of female entrepreneurship lags behind in many Member States and that there is actually untapped growth and prosperity potential. The report calls for concrete strategies to fully exploit the potential of women as entrepreneurs. While the focus is primarily on the private sector and entrepreneurship, positive references to the fight against gender stereotypes and a call to Member States to achieve Barcelona's objectives can be recognized. While it is true that there are many obstacles for women entrepreneurs, this report is part of the approach that believes that fostering entrepreneurship among women is key to achieving gender equality, something not shared from a progressive feminist perspective. References to the important role of the public sector and the negative effects of austerity policies in recent years are completely absent. Fearing that this report could be used to legitimize measures to increase women's business initiatives as the only solution to improve women's living conditions, giving greater weight to the financial and private sector, I abstained in the vote.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the report on external factors that represent obstacles to European female entrepreneurship. I know very well the obstacles encountered by women entrepreneurs because I have been working in the field for over 20 years.  Women have the potential and anthropological qualities to be a good entrepreneur. The low rate of female entrepreneurship in many Member States, although in many Member States the population is majority female, shows that there are still shortcomings.  The Commission has had good initiatives over the years, such as the network of female entrepreneurship ambassadors and female mentors. I am part of these networks and I can say that these initiatives have brought results. But we still need investment in education and behavioral changes to accept women's involvement in business.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ In voting in favour of this report with my fellow S&D MEPs, we are working towards boosting economic growth, creating sustainable jobs and empowering women across Europe. Given that women currently only account for a third of entrepreneurs, there remains a huge amount of untapped talent within the labour market. With some estimates suggesting that by boosting female entrepreneurship, as much as GBP 60 billion could be delivered into the UK economy by 2030, it is now more important than ever that we empower and nurture female entrepreneurs.

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 First of all, I would like to congratulate Mrs Matera on her excellent report. I, too, am very concerned with helping women to do business and to develop them. This is an area to be exploited with huge growth and development potential. Not only at the general economic level – I am thinking of economic strengthening, job creation – but also in terms of women's self-realisation (economic independence, important role in promoting gender equality, exemplary model for young generations). I am convinced that it is of the utmost importance to encourage and support women in building an entrepreneurial career and, of course, to facilitate their access to finance and business opportunities. It is equally important to reconcile professional and private life, as this balance helps to unlock opportunities and become successful entrepreneurs.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 As a group, we have taken a critical stance on the subject of the report. It is true that there are many obstacles for women entrepreneurs but our main priority, from a left-wing feminist point of view and with a view to gender equality, is another. The report does not refer at all to the important role of the public sector or to the negative effects of recent austerity policies. We fear that this report may be used to justify measures to strengthen female entrepreneurship as the only solution to the problem of optimising women's living conditions and we also fear that more space will simply be created for the private financial sector. That is why we have chosen to abstain.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report as encouraging female entrepreneurship is one of the core issues of the EPP group with the FEMM Committee. It is widely recognised that to bring Europe back to growth and to create new jobs, the European Union needs more entrepreneurs, and its strategy for smart, sustainable and inclusive growth (Europe 2020) explicitly mentions that more concrete policy initiatives are needed to develop European entrepreneurship.  Female entrepreneurship deserves particular attention in this context as equal economic independence is still not a given within the EU and women’s employment rate of 59.6% in 2014 at EU -28 level is not in line with the 75% employment target rate of Europe 2020, nor with that of men, of 70.01%. The report wishes to specifically draw attention to the financing needs of female entrepreneurs and raise the question of indirect discrimination of women when they are starting off their companies.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: Writing. The Matera report contains some good proposals, such as improving childcare and improving data collection on the role of women in self-employed occupations. However, it is going decisively too far with a targeted demand for gender-specific funding facilitation for women. This creates distortions of competition, which should be excluded, especially in the case of business start-ups. Nor can I agree with the call for compulsory paternity leave. While fathers should be encouraged to become more actively involved in parenting, mandatory regulation by the state constitutes an inappropriate interference with citizens' private lives. That is why I did not vote in favour of the report as a whole. Incidentally, I believe that the single euro must be abolished. It leads to strife and discord in Europe.

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 As a Member of the Hungarian People's Party, I would like to congratulate Mrs Matera on her excellent report. I, too, consider it important to help women's entrepreneurship and to develop them. This represents a huge opportunity for growth and development to be exploited, not only at the general economic level (economic recovery, job creation), but also in terms of women's self-realisation. Economic independence is an important role in promoting gender equality and is an exemplary model for young generations. I am convinced that it is extremely important to encourage and support women in building an entrepreneurial career. We must do everything we can to make it easier for them to access finance and business opportunities. It is equally important to reconcile professional and private life, as this balance helps to unlock opportunities and become successful entrepreneurs. I voted in favour of the report, of course.

name: Mary Honeyball (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Along with my socialist colleagues, I voted for this report which is aimed at boosting economic growth, creating sustainable jobs and empowering women. At the moment, women make up only a third of entrepreneurs. Some estimates suggest increasing levels of female entrepreneurship could deliver as much as GBP 60 billion to the UK economy by 2030. We need to invest in women’s potential to contribute to new and growing sectors like the digital economy. We also need to ensure that self-employment pays well and that rights such as maternity leave are guaranteed.

name: Richard Howitt (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Women in the USA are twice as likely to be entrepreneurs as women in Great Britain. The Alan Sugar ‘you’re fired’ male boardroom culture may make good television, but for women, it doesn’t always make good business. So I conducted an open surgery, with the Essex Businesswomen’s Network, to ask what are the barriers women have to overcome to succeed in business?  Some were traditional barriers to women in employment, including lack of childcare. The network was seen as invaluable to build necessary confidence. But over and over again lack of finance was cited. Jaime in Southend, told me she’d be denied a mortgage to open her own co-working centre. Home baker Sajida in St Albans, Hertfordshire, wanted to expand her business, but can’t afford the premises. Not only do women run just one-third of businesses, but those who start a business have just one-third of the cash too. Banks and other lenders must do more to support women entrepreneurs. So must Europe – when EU ‘Progress’ loans to small businesses are 50% more likely to go to men. Women at my surgery in Mark’s Tey, kept saying ‘empowerment’. I support these proposals to empower women in business.

name: Ian Hudghton (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ This report deals with an important issue: in my own country alone it has been estimated that the economy would be boosted by GBP 7.6 billion if there was a similar level of women-led businesses to those run by men.  The Scottish Government has been active in supporting Women’s Enterprise Scotland in addressing these issues and I accordingly voted in favour of this report.

name: Филиз Хюсменова (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Dear Mr President, honourable Members, despite our best efforts, gender inequalities in the labour market persist. It affects both wages and pension payments and the ability of women to hold leadership positions.  A means of improving this picture is promoting female entrepreneurship and even becoming employers. To this end, programmes are needed to support, advise and facilitate access to finance for women wishing to start their own business. It is also important to provide sufficient and affordable childcare and care facilities for the elderly, in view of the special role of women in the family.  Last but not least, it is also necessary to facilitate access to educational and training courses for the creation and management of companies that will give women further confidence in Europe.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union needs smart and lasting economic growth. Job growth and the expansion of entrepreneurship are solutions for a successful economy.  The differences between women and men are still evident in the entrepreneurial field. Men are much more inclined to see self-employment as a feasible alternative. It is desirable that in the future there will be no more inequalities in the entrepreneurial field between women and men.

name: Anneli Jäätteenmäki (ALDE)
text: Written. \u2012 Companies in the women's and female-dominated sectors are unfairly burdened by the cost of parenthood. I would like to take on the positive side of my neighbour, Sweden, where the problem has been solved by introducing an insurance-based levy. In this way, the costs are equalised between employees and employers. I think it is of paramount importance that all employers and employees should be involved in equalisation of contributions, because children are common! By equalisation of the costs of parenthood, women will have more equal opportunities to act as both entrepreneurs and employees. It is wrong that the mother's employers now have to pay for the parenting costs that are not covered by tax revenue. In addition, by equalisation of parenting costs, young women will have permanent jobs instead of short-term jobs. At present, women are in an unequal position as jobseekers.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the Report on External Factors That Hinder Female Entrepreneurship in Europe, as I believe that women's entrepreneurship carries untapped growth and prosperity potential. Reducing the already permanent gap between women's and men's entrepreneurial activity and increasing the representation of women in management positions would strengthen a woman's role as a business leader. Such a role model would also encourage younger girls to follow in entrepreneurial footsteps. Women have enormous entrepreneurial potential that lies in economic growth, job creation, strengthening a woman's position, but also a source of their economic independence that gives them the opportunity for further and easier integration into the labour market. That is why I believe that further strengthening of legislation in this area needs to be addressed as soon as possible.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report because it proposes ways to make women more represented among business leaders. A number of measures are proposed that we consider to be completely inappropriate, concerning the plurality of identities, the questioning of family models or the introduction of quotas for so-called disadvantaged groups.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. – I, with my fellow MEPs, voted against this non legislative and non-binding report.  It included calls to encourage men to become more involved in the housework for example through mandatory paternity leave. It is not for any government and especially EU bureaucrats to interfere with the private lives of families, marriages and partnerships regarding who should do the housework. It included sexist assumptions that women are used as ‘fronts’ by men to get favourable financial deals; that women underrated their skills and are more likely to confess a lack of self-confidence and assertiveness and thus need psychological support programmes. UKIP believes women and men are equal and the EU has no right to say women are inferior and need demeaning hand-outs. Finally the report calls for the EU to spend more taxpayer’s money and bring forward more legislation. The only people that should decide any of these things are our elected and accountable government, not unelected bureaucrats in Brussels.

name: Danuta Jazłowiecka (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 In 2014, the employment rate among them was less than 60% and was much lower than the Europe 2020 target. In addition, most of those who have a job provide it part-time or in flexible forms of employment. One solution to this problem is to promote entrepreneurship among women. It should not be assumed that women do not want to be entrepreneurs, but rather that they are discouraged from doing so by external circumstances. The report we voted on indicates the obstacles that exist. However, In my opinion, the fundamental problem here is the cultural constraints that still exist and the lack of viable mechanisms to support women's entrepreneurship. Moreover, as the report points out, it would be a good idea to promote social entrepreneurship.  Available data show that women are much more likely to choose to set up social enterprises because they are better suited to their sense of vulnerability and investment strategy. In turn, the experience gained in this sector of the economy will help some of them move to the traditional economy sector. An additional value is that social enterprises are much better suited to the problems currently faced by the EU economy and the labour market. Europe will only gain if we focus more on the social economy, both in terms of employment levels among women and in instruments for solving growing socio-economic problems.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Barbara Matera's report on women's entrepreneurship in Europe. My political group, the EPP, strongly supports entrepreneurship, and therefore women's entrepreneurship, as a means of returning to growth and employment.  While equality in employment rates and economic independence have not yet been achieved, I believe that it is all the more important to identify the barriers that women face when they want to start a business, so that they can destroy or overcome them. Finally, I welcome the fact that the report focuses on social entrepreneurship and its better understanding, which must promote gender equality.  This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which aimed to eliminate the factors that stand in the way of women's entrepreneurship, which now accounts for only 31% of entrepreneurs in Europe, as part of the European Union's strategy for smart, inclusive and sustainable growth (Europe 2020). In particular, the report encourages the establishment of a concrete strategy by Member States to promote entrepreneurial culture among women.

name: Jarosław Kalinowski (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Entrepreneurship can be defined as a character trait as a set of certain skills, thinking, planning and realisation of one's intentions. An entrepreneurial person is an ambitious, confident and effective man striving to achieve his goals. In the labour sector, entrepreneurship usually means doing your own business – company, company, company – as opposed to being employed by an employer.  Eurobarometer data show that the entrepreneurship rate in the European Union (12%) is still half as low as in China or the US (27% and 21% respectively) despite raising entrepreneurship to a political priority. Moreover, among Europeans who own a business, only a third are women. At the same time, it is women who are more likely than men to set up businesses – this can be explained by the desire to reconcile work and private life, after all, self-employment is usually more flexible in terms of working hours, holidays or opportunities to work from home. The obstacles faced by enterprising women should therefore be eliminated, as stereotypes such as less skills or less resilience to pressure among women result in a lack of confidence in certain entities, e.g. banks refusing to grant investment credit. Such superstitious thinking still discourages women from taking up their own activities and leads to discrimination.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. While it is worth supporting to ensure a better environment for women entrepreneurs, I think it is misguided to achieve the objective of more stringent transposition of gender mainstreaming and parental leave into national law and stricter monitoring by EU agencies. I am also opposed to the mandatory introduction of gender quotas.

name: Krišjānis Kariņš (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 At the European Parliament plenary session in Strasbourg, I voted in favour of the resolution highlighting the impact of external factors and the obstacles created to women's entrepreneurship in Europe. I support the promotion of equality between women and men and believe that important steps have already been taken to achieve equal rights and development opportunities for both women and men. I voted against the point of the resolution, which provides for the introduction of mandatory gender quotas in the Member States, because I believe that the demographic situation varies greatly from one Member State to another, so I do not believe that the introduction of mandatory gender quotas is a solution for promoting women's entrepreneurship in Europe.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report, as it is aimed at boosting economic growth, creating sustainable jobs and empowering women. At the moment, women make up only a third of entrepreneurs. That is a huge amount of untapped talent. In particular, we need to invest in women’s and girls’ potential to contribute to the digital economy. Some estimates suggest boosting female entrepreneurship could deliver as much as GBP 60 billion to the UK economy by 2030.

name: Bernd Kölmel (ECR)
text: Writing. The Matera report contains some good proposals, such as improving childcare and improving data collection on the role of women in self-employed occupations. However, it is going decisively too far with a targeted demand for gender-specific funding facilitation for women. This creates distortions of competition, which should be excluded, especially in the case of business start-ups. Nor can I agree with the call for compulsory paternity leave. While fathers should be encouraged to become more actively involved in parenting, mandatory regulation by the state constitutes an inappropriate interference with citizens' private lives. That is why I did not vote in favour of the report as a whole.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 First of all, I would like to congratulate Mrs Matera on her excellent report. I, too, am concerned with helping women to do business and developing, because it represents a huge opportunity for growth and development to be exploited, not only at the general economic level (I am thinking of economic strengthening, job creation here), but also in terms of women's self-realisation (economic independence, an important role in promoting gender equality, an exemplary model for young generations). I am convinced that it is of the utmost importance to encourage and support women in building an entrepreneurial career and, of course, to facilitate their access to finance and business opportunities. It is equally important to reconcile professional and private life, as this balance helps to unlock opportunities and become successful entrepreneurs. I voted in favour of the report, of course.

name: Agnieszka Kozłowska-Rajewicz (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I fully support Barbara Mater's report on external factors hindering women's entrepreneurship in Europe. Women are less likely than men to participate in the labour market and less likely to run their own businesses, and if they do, they are smaller and run in less profitable sectors. This is compounded by the large number of quasi-companies created by forced self-employment of women who de facto carry out work under the supervision of their employer.  The report rightly draws attention to the low availability of care services as a major barrier to entrepreneurship, but also to disparities in the burden on women in domestic work. The report, citing the Barcelona objectives of m.in. availability of care services at a level of at least 90% of children aged 3 years and over , calls on Member States to continue to invest in care infrastructure, which is a key tool for combining family and professional responsibilities.  The report also calls on the Commission and the Member States to review the law with a view to eliminating poorer treatment of female entrepreneurs compared to emeri workers, to invest in training, projects that create entrepreneurial networks, offer monitoring and exchange of good practices and combat gender stereotypes, as a key activity to promote female entrepreneurship. The popularisation of women's entrepreneurship, especially in the 45+ group, is important not only for the quality of life of the women involved, but also, through the use of their experience and work, has a positive impact on the health of the economy as a whole.

name: Constance Le Grip (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted, like a very large majority of my European Parliamentary colleagues, for my colleague Barbara Matera's report on external factors that stand in the way of European women's entrepreneurship. Indeed, while women's entrepreneurship is one of our priorities in our employment strategy, too few women actually benefit: only 30% of entrepreneurs are women. I therefore wished, through this vote, to denounce all the difficulties faced by women entrepreneurs in seeking external financing as well as the obstacles hindering the development of women's entrepreneurship.  We European parliamentarians have clearly called for the development of a genuine culture of entrepreneurship among girls and boys, among women and men, by intensifying exchanges of good practices to support women who want to embark on a business project.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the report on external factors that stand in the way of European women's entrepreneurship. Among many uninteresting measures have slipped purely ideological proposals: promoting gender equality in companies, supporting in particular "women with multiple identities", ensuring the proper distribution of household tasks and "changing the traditional distribution of roles within the family", setting up quotas for women for aid to disadvantaged groups , set up "psychological support" cells for women entrepreneurs...  However, this initiative report with no legislative impact may justify counterproductive measures, such as equal and non-transferable paternity leave (which, for obvious economic reasons, could only lead to a reduction in maternity leave). The few suggestions of common sense, such as the introduction to entrepreneurship in school training, are not within the competence of the Union.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this delusional report, which welcomes "women with multiple identities" (?), yet gives in to the blames on women's supposed weakness by advocating the establishment of "psychological support" cells to help women entrepreneurs "strengthen their self-confidence"!

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. This benevolent report was nevertheless full of absurd, communitarian, or even involved in the private sphere: cells of "psychological support" for women entrepreneurs, promotion of gender equality, support for "women with multiple identities", distribution of household tasks, and even "change in the traditional distribution of roles within the family"! Moreover, if this initiative report has no legislative impact, it would nevertheless justify counterproductive measures such as equal and non-transferable paternity leave (the main consequence of which would be the reduction of maternity leave). Finally, to protest, once again, against the encroachment of the Union on the competences of the Member States, or in this case on those of the family itself, I had no choice but to oppose this text.

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR)
text: Writing. The Matera report contains some good proposals, such as improving childcare and improving data collection on the role of women in self-employed occupations. However, it is going decisively too far with a targeted demand for gender-specific funding facilitation for women. This creates distortions of competition, which should be excluded, especially in the case of business start-ups. Nor can I agree with the call for compulsory paternity leave. While fathers should be encouraged to become more actively involved in parenting, mandatory regulation by the state constitutes an inappropriate interference with citizens' private lives. That is why I did not vote in favour of the report as a whole.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 Women have no legal barriers to doing business, so all politicians have to do is let entrepreneurs and businesswomen work, pay low taxes and not burden them with bureaucracy and nonsense. Nor is it the EU's role to call for a different division of family chores.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ A lot of activities have been undertaken with the aim of strengthening female entrepreneurship, reducing unemployment and self-employment, but they have not proven effective and we cannot be satisfied with what has been achieved because women's employment remains below 60%, far from the 75% target. Of the total number of self-employed in the EU, only 34.4% are women and their income remains lower than men.  With the same measures, we cannot come up with new solutions. One-off financial support and relief is not enough, but long-term social support and support is necessary so that women can build a career in entrepreneurship and balance private and business life.  Ensuring quality childcare and the education system are essential for this, and it is also important for women to have easier access to financial resources and the realisation of business ideas. I supported Barbara Matera's report, which seeks a new, holistic, approach to fostering women's entrepreneurship. It is important to swiftly adopt concrete measures and an appropriate legislative framework that will result in an increase in the share of women on the market, as well as the effective use of appropriate instruments and incentives, including EU funds, to provide quality care for children and other dependers, flexible working hours, full protection of social rights and measures to achieve real balance and equality in the harmonisation of family and work commitments.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing \ u2012 Business sectors, such as education, social services, health, hairdressing and beauty services, are the domain of women. On the other hand, women need to penetrate more in other areas, such as finance, construction, trade, etc., where women can contribute to economic growth and employment growth through their abilities. Due to the increased interest of women in entrepreneurship, it is necessary to create conditions that take into account the maternal role of women and their care for children and family, and which will motivate women more to set up businesses and companies. Municipalities and towns must ensure, under reasonable conditions, sufficient places in kindergartens, quality care for children after lessons in the form of interest activities. It is important to finance business plans and reduce the bureaucratic burden of doing business.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on external factors that are an obstacle to women's entrepreneurship in Europe, because it is complete and documented, as I mention in detail in my written speech on the subject.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report. This uninteresting and unsealed text risks being used as a justification for passing counterproductive measures in the promotion of gender equality in companies, support for women with "multiple identities", rebalancing of household tasks... It plans to set up quotas for women for aid to disadvantaged groups, "psychological support" cells for women entrepreneurs... Worse, the few interesting suggestions in this text do not even fall within the competence of the Union! So I object to that.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome this report which calls on the Commission to incorporate the issue of women’s entrepreneurship into its post-2015 strategy on equality between women and men.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on external factors that represent obstacles to European female entrepreneurship. This is a key political issue for the European institutions, synonymous with economic growth and job creation. Although women's entrepreneurship has been one of the political priorities since the adoption of the Treaty of Lisbon, the European Union is still lagging far behind in this area. Europe must support women's participation in the labour market, encourage Member States and regions to present concrete strategies to promote the culture of female entrepreneurship, focus on the needs and conditions related to the elimination of gender stereotypes, and invest in programmes that allow the continuous training of working women and women entrepreneurs, ensuring them continuous updating and quality professional growth , with particular regard to the commercial sector.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. Many obstacles continue to stop the possibility of increasing the number of women entrepreneurs in the EU today. From the European Parliament we would like to stress, through the report we have adopted in plenary, the need to remove these brakes, which often go through the difficulty of reconciling working and family life and also, in many cases, the greatest challenges for women in accessing funding. The author of the report notes that access to social entrepreneurship is easier for women, but this requires ensuring the financing of social business initiatives and clearly defining and understanding of social entrepreneurship, as well as making a correct assessment of social enterprises.

name: Κώστας Μαυρίδης (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 One of the EU's objectives is to develop the entrepreneurship of European citizens, since the figures show that Europe has a lower rate than countries such as the USA. For example, as the explanatory memorandum to the resolution states, Europe's entrepreneurship rate stood at 12% in 2009, while in the USA it was 27%. It is expected that strengthening entrepreneurship will be able to help the economic growth and prosperity of the Member States because new jobs will be created and that initiatives towards exploiting the skills of European citizens will be increased. In favour of this resolution, it is expected that the development of women's entrepreneurship will be particularly important when we consider that only 31% of the self-employed population are women. It is imperative to combat barriers to female entrepreneurship with the ultimate aim of equal economic independence for both sexes. Adverse factors to be addressed are the usual indirect discrimination against women by financial institutions for the provision of credit, discrimination which is expressly prohibited under Directive 2004/113/EC, and all kinds of stereotypes in relation to women's competences in this field.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. A sensible promotion of entrepreneurship is essential for a functioning economy. Every company is an asset and creates jobs. It should not be decided by gender whether a company is supported or not. However, the report calls for gender support. It is important that there is equal opportunities. I strongly oppose the preference of one sex through quotas, as called for in the report, or gender-specific support. That is why I am also voting against this report.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report to encourage female entrepreneurship. Increased female entrepreneurship is a key component to facilitating future economic growth and the creation of more jobs.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. Women are under-represented in entrepreneurship (31%), particularly in traditionally male sectors such as construction. This report suggests more efforts to combat discrimination in access to finance and stereotypes that discourage women and girls from taking on science or technology.  But it is part of the current European logic of presenting the "all entrepreneurial" as a panacea for the revival of growth and jobs in Europe. The role of the public sector in job creation has been systematically ignored. As well as the impact of austerity policies on the order books of SMEs. I abstain on this text.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. The purpose of this report is to suggest ways for women to be more represented among business leaders.  In substance, this reflection is interesting. On the other hand, several measures are proposed that we consider to be completely inappropriate, concerning the plurality of identities, the questioning of family models, the introduction of quotas for so-called disadvantaged groups... This report may ultimately justify harmful measures, so I object.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament's motion for a resolution on the external factors hindering European feminism entrepreneurship. The reconciliation between private and professional life must be supported through concrete policies.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution because encouraging female entrepreneurship and equality is exceedingly important. This resolution will help combat indirect discrimination that female entrepreneurs face, as well as support and advise female entrepreneurs.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: Written. – Since the launch of the Lisbon Treaty, promoting entrepreneurship has been a political priority for Europe. To make our economy more effective and to create more new jobs, we need more entrepreneurs. Nevertheless, we still note that entrepreneurship in Europe lags behind the other major economies in the world. While in the US 21% of the population opts for entrepreneurship, in Europe only 12% of the active population opts for self-employment. Of all the self-employed and entrepreneurs in Europe, only 31% of them are women. Women often choose, even if to maintain the balance between private and professional life, for a job as an employee. This report makes a strong case for removing the obstacles faced by potential female entrepreneurs. All too often, female entrepreneurs rely on financial help from family and acquaintances. Access to credit lines for female entrepreneurs should therefore be facilitated. I also fully support the measures proposed to get rid of the stereotypes about female entrepreneurship and the promotion of female entrepreneurship through training and choice of study.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The EU still lags behind with an entrepreneurial rate of 12%. Female entrepreneurship deserves particular attention, as equal economic independence is not a given while women’s employment rate of 59% is not in line with the 75% target of EU 2020. Of all self-employed, only 31% are female. The Matera report targets the hurdles and challenges to achieve a higher female entrepreneurship rate, especially access to funding, social entrepreneurship and work/life balance. That is why I have voted in favour of the report on external factors that represent hurdles to European female entrepreneurship.

name: Angelika Mlinar (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the adoption of the report on external factors that represent hurdles to European female entrepreneurship. It is time for the Commission to duly promote programmes and funding opportunities for women in business.  The experience shared by the most of the women entering the entrepreneurial sector demonstrates that there is need for coordination and centralisation of information and technical support at the EU level. For this reason I am promoting a European Business Centre for women working  in close cooperation with Member States and companies from the private sector, which would function as a focal point to promote the Commission’s initiatives for female entrepreneurs, providing management and technical assistance, creating and boosting existing networks, and monitoring and gender-mainstreaming business initiatives and programmes.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. Entrepreneurship is a way of thinking that allows individuals to use their motivation and capacity to recognize and fully implement an opportunity. Enterprise policy has been a political priority since the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon, but the European Union is still lagging behind: in 2009, the proportion of entrepreneurs in the EU-27 was 12%, compared with 27% in China and 21% in the United States. For Europe to start growing again and create new jobs, the European Union needs more entrepreneurs. The differences between men and women are still evident in entrepreneurship; In 2012, only 31% of all self-employed citizens in the EU-28 were women. Directive 2004/113/EC expressly prohibits direct or indirect discrimination in the field of financial services, including bank loans. There is no evidence of direct discrimination in the Member States, as the refusal to provide financing to female entrepreneurs may also be the result of the economic logic in which investors seek higher returns from larger enterprises in more profitable and male-dominated sectors. However, some evidence suggests that indirect discrimination, which is also influenced by women's perception of access to finance, occurs.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: writing – I consider supporting women's entrepreneurship in Europe to be crucial in addressing a number of poverty-related issues. Compared to the US, women in Europe do not do so much, although some regions of Europe are suffering from high unemployment, which is being signed up to an increase in poverty. Women who do business are often mothers, as entrepreneurship allows them to better arrange their time and can devote themselves to children. It is natural that they are more cautious in their approach to equity financing in order not to increase business risk. I support and welcome the facilitation of women entrepreneurs' access to grants and other forms of aid, which would ultimately lead to an improvement in the economic situation of the Member States, especially their poorer regions.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. The purpose of the report is to suggest ways for women to be more represented among business leaders.   Among many measures of little interest, corrupt proposals have crept in: promoting gender equality in companies, supporting in particular "women with multiple identities", ensuring the proper distribution of household tasks and "changing the traditional distribution of roles within the family", setting up "psychological support" cells for women entrepreneurs...  However, this initiative report may justify counterproductive measures, such as equal and non-transferable paternity leave (which, for obvious economic reasons, could only lead to a reduction in maternity leave).  The few suggestions of common sense, such as the introduction to entrepreneurship in school training, are not within the competence of the Union. He therefore calls for a negative vote.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. Entrepreneurship is a strong preponderance in promoting jobs, economic growth, innovation, social development and poverty reduction in general. However, in 2012 women accounted for only 31% of entrepreneurs (10.3 million) in the EU-28 and only 34.4% of self-employed people. I am voting in favour of this report ensuring full gender integration in all future policies in the field of entrepreneurship, and the need for women to reconcile working life with their personal lives should be safeguarded, especially when they are outside the maternity period enshrined in the law. I believe that the Commission and the Member States should promote greater visibility into the financing of business activity by drawing up, among other measures, microfinance aid maps under the European Progress Microfinance Facility and develop training plans so that women have high levels of knowledge in areas predominantly dominated by men such as construction or technology.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This report aims to suggest ways for women to be more represented among business leaders.  In addition to the uninteresting measures presented, there are other, far more problematic measures such as promoting gender equality in business, supporting women with "multiple identities", ensuring the proper distribution of household tasks and "changing the traditional distribution of roles within the family", etc.  If it is an initiative report without any normative scope (which is normal given that it infringes on the competences of Member States), it promotes counterproductive proposals such as equal and non-transferable paternity leave (which for obvious economic reasons could only lead to a reduction in maternity leave).  The few common-sense recommendations, such as the introduction to entrepreneurship in school training, are not within the competence of the European Union.  So I voted against it.

name: Clare Moody (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This report is aimed at boosting economic growth, creating sustainable jobs and empowering women.  At the moment, women make up only a third of entrepreneurs. That is a huge amount of untapped talent. In particular, we need to invest in women’s and girls’ potential to contribute to the digital economy. Some estimates suggest boosting female entrepreneurship could deliver as much as GBP 60 billion to the UK economy by 2030.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This report is aimed at boosting economic growth, creating sustainable jobs and empowering women.  At the moment, women make up only a third of entrepreneurs. That is a huge amount of untapped talent. In particular, we need to invest in women’s and girls’ potential to contribute to the digital economy. Some estimates suggest boosting female entrepreneurship could deliver as much as GBP 60 billion to the UK economy by 2030.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on external factors that hinder female entrepreneurship. In Europe, the employment rate for women was 59.6% in 2014, well below the 75% target set out in the Europe 2020 strategy and above all the employment rate for men of 70.1%. In this context, women's entrepreneurship must be developed and, as requested in this text, initiatives by the Commission, particularly in the area of financial support, must be benefited.

name: Luigi Morgano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Women account for only a third of entrepreneurs in the European Union. They face specific obstacles to access to finance and bank loans, for example.  Facilitating and simplifying access to finance is therefore undoubtedly an important step that the Member States must take, but the spectrum of intervention in this resolution is rightly wider. Other measures call for the promotion of an entrepreneurial culture in education and training pathways that encourages more women to pursue careers in profitable, potentially growing sectors, while they seem to focus on sectors considered less profitable such as health care, education and community work.  In the fields of finance, science and green technology, IT through digital environments, men are still predominant. It is also appropriate to include targeted gender quotas and to use Community funds to ensure, at affordable prices, quality care for children and the elderly, by intervening across the board on improving work-life balance through the promotion of paternity leave.

name: Elisabeth Morin-Chartier (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Barbara Matera's report on external factors that hinder European women's entrepreneurship.  The promotion of women's entrepreneurship is one of the workhorses of my EPP group. It is generally accepted that, in order to boost growth in Europe and create new jobs, the European Union needs more entrepreneurs and its strategy for smart, sustainable and inclusive growth (Europe 2020) explicitly indicates that more concrete initiatives are needed to develop European entrepreneurship.  Women's entrepreneurship deserves special attention in this context, as egalitarian economic independence is still not a reality in the European Union and the employment rate of women, 59.6% in 2014 at EU-28 level, still falling short of the target set out in the Europe 2020 strategy of 75%, as well as the employment rate of men (70.1%).  With the help of this INI report, the rapporteur intends to draw particular attention to the financing needs of women entrepreneurs and to raise the issue of indirect discrimination faced by women when they start their own businesses.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 We welcome the draft report focusing on enhancing and stimulating female entrepreneurship.  We are well aware, in fact, that the ability to do business, especially innovative enterprise and social enterprise, is an important lever for rationing and supporting growth in Europe. However, women account for less than a third of the total number of European entrepreneurs and, in general, most women do not consider entrepreneurship to be one of their career opportunities.  This is, of course, a cultural problem, which the European Union must take responsibility for and which it must try to remedy. , preparing a holistic approach to female entrepreneurship, aimed at encouraging and supporting women in the choice of a career as entrepreneurs, including by contributing to the creation of an environment that allows women to realise their full potential by ensuring reconciling professional and personal life, access to childcare facilities and calibrated training.

name: Renaud Muselier (PPE)
text: In writing. The issue of women's entrepreneurship is of paramount importance to the EPP group, as well as to myself. I therefore supported a report that contributed to egalitarian economic independence and social entrepreneurship.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 We need an inclusive Europe that recognises women as protagonists, including in business.  The time has therefore come to put in place solutions aimed at overcoming the gap between men and women in an area still dominated by the male gender.  In view of the persistence of prejudices of a different nature, it is necessary for the European institutions to commit themselves to supporting initiatives, the successful implementation of which would result in a greater opportunity for women to participate in the economic life of the Community.  The identification of measures aimed at greater balance between family and working life, as well as the reduction of the prejudices that persist in access to credit, would help to lead to a wider inclusion of women in the business environment. In the light of these considerations, I have decided to support Mrs Matera's report, which deals, with knowledge and foresight, with a subject that has hitherto been relegated to the margins of the European political debate.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on external factors hindering women's entrepreneurship, because I believe that Europe needs as many enterprising citizens as possible. Such activities play an important role in boosting the economy, and entrepreneurs often contribute to the development of other sectors with their innovative ideas. It is our job to create the right conditions and motivate ambitious Europeans who want to take on the business. This report is important because it draws attention to the support of women so that they too can be employed in the world of entrepreneurs without discrimination or prejudice.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. – I have voted for this report that supports female entrepreneurship through sustainable and inclusive policies that aim to enable equal economic independence and to develop European entrepreneurship and growth.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report today because I believe that the entrepreneurial potential of women in the EU is a resource that is underexploited in all Member States, including Romania. Multiple stereotypes and gender discrimination are still a big problem in our societies that discourage women's entrepreneurship.  I support the vision of this report and support the steps that seek to establish concrete strategies at European and Member State level on promoting and encouraging women's entrepreneurship.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. In my opinion, this is not a difference in treatment – a woman today has the same opportunities as a man. Women are more likely to go down the road with family and children, and they are willing to do so. However, this path does not necessarily have to be chosen. So it is quite common for men to go into paternity leave. That is why I abstained from voting on this report.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. Statistics show that there are still fewer female entrepreneurs than male entrepreneurs. The problem is often the compatibility between home and working life, as women are stereotypically expected to manage the whole household and raise children. As women operate more often in sectors with lower business rates, their net incomes are also lower. The resolution calls for greater attention to be paid to this area and to encourage female entrepreneurship – for example by facilitating women's access to finance, education and training and enabling the reconciliation of work and private life and access to childcare services. It also calls for the entry of paternity leave in countries where it does not yet have it.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non legislative and non-binding report.  It included calls to encourage men to become more involved in the housework for example through mandatory paternity leave. It is not for any government and especially EU bureaucrats to interfere with the private lives of families, marriages and partnerships regarding who should do the housework. It included sexist assumptions that women are used as ‘fronts’ by men to get favourable financial deals; that women underrated their skills and are more likely to confess a lack of self-confidence and assertiveness and thus need psychological support programmes. UKIP believes women and men are equal and the EU has no right to say women are inferior and need demeaning hand-outs. Finally the report calls for the EU to spend more taxpayer’s money and bring forward more legislation. The only people that should decide any of these things are our elected and accountable government, not unelected bureaucrats in Brussels.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 As the report shows, there is a clear gap between men and women in the progress of entrepreneurial activities. I believe that it is up to the European Union, through the continuous updating of its policies, to support the development of female entrepreneurship. I believe in the need to increase women's businesses through subsidies or training courses on legal and technological issues. Aiming for gender equality is the foundation for achieving the growth to which we aspire so much. I therefore feel that I am voting in favour.

name: Eva Paunova (PPE)
text: in writing. – Entrepreneurship is well known as a catalyst for economic growth and competitiveness. As it stands, however, female entrepreneurs represent only a third of the self-employed in the EU, even though there are more women than men in Europe. Even if they contribute actively to social and economic development, their entrepreneurial potential is underused. As an MEP who actively supports entrepreneurship policies in the EU, I take the chance to vote in favour of the report and support the strengthening of European female entrepreneurship.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. This initiative report with no legislative impact may justify counterproductive measures, such as equal and non-transferable paternity leave (which, for obvious economic reasons, could only lead to a reduction in maternity leave). It is very intrusive in the privacy of citizens by wanting to dictate to them what behaviours they deem appropriate. The few suggestions of common sense, such as the introduction to entrepreneurship in school training, are not within the competence of the Union. So I decided to vote against it.

name: Pina Picierno (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 In the European Union, rates of disparity in business careers between women and men suggest that much more effort still needs to be done to create a culture of entrepreneurship that ensures a more balanced gender representation. In order to combat these differences, it is imperative to act first and foremost on the stereotypes that traditionally support the gender vision in our countries. Advanced democracies cannot accept that the value of women's role and their undisputed ability to operate at the same level and in the same culturally designed sectors for men should not be recognised within their own societies.  I have therefore strongly supported this report with the aim of encouraging an understanding of the factors that keep women away from the world of entrepreneurship, and of assessing the actions to be taken for a decisive change of perspective. The text highlights the critical points on which an integrated plan must be established between the Commission and the Member States. In particular, we need to ensure the advancement of the Paternity Leave Directive, devise strategies that encourage universities to encourage young girls to choose predominantly male study profiles and develop easier access to information channels on the use of European funding.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ While entrepreneurial policy has been one of the more important priorities since the Lisbon Treaty came into force, the EU still lags behind in entrepreneurship (12% in the EU-27 DČ in 2009, compared to China and the US, 27% and 21%). The EU needs a lot of new entrepreneurs, to create new jobs and positions, a new smart entrepreneurship strategy needs to be created. Women's entrepreneurship should be given special attention and ensure equality and stability, as well as economic freedom. The gap between men and women is still evident - in 2012 only 31% of women in the EU were self-employed. 30% of women in entrepreneurship work part-time, while men work 12%. It is harder for women to gather managerial experience, run a business and gain investor trust. They also start with smaller start-up capital and smaller loans. I therefore agree with the measures proposed in this report, which calls on the Commission to ensure the full integration of the gender equality aspect and to include the issue of women's entrepreneurship in its post-2015 strategy on women's and men's equality. I also support calls on the government, administration and member state bodies in charge of gender equality to work with the financial sector to ensure equality between men and women.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I fully support Barbara Matera's report on external factors that hinder female entrepreneurship in Europe. Encouraging female entrepreneurship is of great importance; can have a significant impact on the growth and development of the state economy. For this reason, encouraging female entrepreneurship is one of the highest priorities of the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality. As equal economic independence has not yet been achieved within the European Union and the employment of women within 28 countries in 2014 is only 59.6%, which is below the 75% envisaged Europe 2020 strategy, women's entrepreneurship deserves particular attention. It is also important to mention women's social or social entrepreneurship, which is increasingly popular in the world, which aims to integrate the creation of economic and social value. For all these reasons, it is of utmost importance to ensure the full integration of the gender equality aspect into all future entrepreneurship policies and for Member States to work actively with the private sector to put companies aimed at promoting gender equality and their most effective practices to be at the forefront.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union needs more entrepreneurs to return to growth and active creation of new jobs. Moreover, its strategy for smart and sustainable growth clearly emphasises the need for policy initiatives to promote entrepreneurship. Equal economic independence is still not a matter of course. Although we do not have conclusive evidence, we must continue to seriously address the possibility of discrimination against female entrepreneurs, for example in access to financial services, including bank loans. The figures show that, for many logical reasons, providers of these services still prefer larger companies from more profitable sectors traditionally dominated by men. Women do more in health, social care or education. These sectors are not so attractive in investment, but no less important. We must combat stereotypes about gender gaps in entrepreneurship and promote their appetite for entrepreneurship.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Within a Europe committed to the pursuit of economic growth and job creation, entrepreneurship plays a key role.  In this context, however, female entrepreneurship is still affected by differences in opportunity compared to that of men. Women often choose smaller companies, areas more related to health and social care, and make less use of external financing, such as bank loans and loans from providers. This is confirmed by the fact that female entrepreneurs tend to encounter difficulties in accessing finance in the form of equity participation, have a more cautious attitude to taking economic and financial risks and less financial management experience than their male counterparts.  I am in favour of this own-initiative report and believe that a greater presence of entrepreneurs can be a driving force within the market.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 There is still a high gap between the number of entrepreneurs and entrepreneurs in the European Union, with entrepreneurship being one of the pillars of a healthy developed economy and also the way in which we can combat high unemployment and weak economic growth. I welcome the effort for women to actively set up their businesses, to be able to reconcile work and private life without being put through unnecessary administrative obstacles, while at the same time found support in creating flexible jobs. At the same time, we should be reticent about directive efforts. This proposal is intended to establish a fair starting position for all and not to artificially prioritise a certain part of the population with quotas.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Personally, I strongly support more women doing business. The more entrepreneurs and entrepreneurs, the better for each state. At the beginning of this week, I visited the announcement of the "Top Women in Business" poll in my home country, and many stories of Czech businesswomen really impressed me. That is why I supported the report. At the same time, however, I could not vote in favour of proposals such as promoting gender quotas in business support or the call for men in the household to work more. Such proposals will not help female entrepreneurs at all.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted for the report developing the factors external to European women's entrepreneurship, because it deserves special attention. In order to boost growth in Europe and create new jobs, the European Union needs more entrepreneurs, both men and women. Nevertheless, we must not fall into caricature. For the sake of the debate and the message we want to get across. That is why I have opposed or abstained on a number of very dogmatic passages.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Despite entrepreneurship being identified as a political priority since the start of the Treaty of Lisbon, the truth is that the European Union is still behind in this area. Entrepreneurship is key to jobs, economic growth, innovation, development and poverty reduction in general. Indeed, it is widely recognised that, in order to resume growth and create new jobs, the European Union needs more entrepreneurs and its Strategy for Smart, Sustainable and Inclusive Growth (Europe 2020) explicitly states that more concrete policy initiatives are needed to develop European entrepreneurship.  In this context, female entrepreneurship deserves special attention, as equality in terms of economic independence is still not guaranteed in the European Union and that the employment rate of women, which was set at 59.6 % in 2014 at EU-28 level, is not consistent with either the 75 % employment target of the Europe 2020 strategy, nor with the male employment rate of 70.1 %.  This report deals precisely with the issue of female entrepreneurship, seeking to identify their obstacles and launching proposals for overcoming them. I voted in favour.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non legislative and non-binding report.  It included calls to encourage men to become more involved in the housework, for example, through mandatory paternity leave. It is not for any government and especially EU bureaucrats to interfere with the private lives of families, marriages and partnerships regarding who should do the housework. It included sexist assumptions that women are used as ‘fronts’ by men to get favourable financial deals; that women underrated their skills and are more likely to confess a lack of self-confidence and assertiveness and thus need psychological support programmes. UKIP believes women and men are equal and the EU has no right to say women are inferior and need demeaning hand-outs. Finally the report calls for the EU to spend more taxpayer’s money and bring forward more legislation. The only people that should decide any of these things are our elected and accountable government, not unelected bureaucrats in Brussels.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. I welcome the presentation of this report which aims to support jobs, economic growth and innovation through female entrepreneurship. The work-life balance that entrepreneurship can offer women is the first obstacle to success. In addition, women entrepreneurs can only reconcile work and family life if there are adequate childcare facilities and if parents actively participate in the functioning of the household. I voted in favour of this report because it encourages Member States to come up with concrete strategies and identify the obstacles to be overcome. The female entrepreneurship rate lags behind in all Member States and the differences between men and women are still notorious in business careers. In 2012, of all EU-28 citizens working on their own, only 31% were women.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. In Europe, women are estimated to account for just 31% of entrepreneurs and most often in sectors considered less profitable: education, health care and social work. Based on this observation, MEPs voted on Tuesday to adopt a text urging Member States to remove barriers to female entrepreneurship. There are many ways to achieve this: promoting an entrepreneurial culture within our societies or setting up support structures to facilitate work-life balance for women. They are twice as likely as men to work part-time. These are all proposals that are moving in the right direction. On the other hand, I do not think that the introduction of quotas is the most appropriate solution, and the debate on paternity leave is certainly not a European priority when we know the difficulty of reaching an agreement between Member States on this issue.  Women's entrepreneurship in Europe remains an important societal issue that foreshadows the advent of a more liberal, less codified and frozen Western society, which gives pride of place to individual initiative.

name: Robert Rochefort (ALDE)
text: In writing. I supported this resolution, which seeks to put an end to the factors hindering the development of women's entrepreneurship in the Union. These measures focus on the conditions for achieving a better work-life balance, the creation of networks for women's entrepreneurship, improved access to finance and the promotion of entrepreneurial culture through education and training.  I want to point out two important points in this context. On the one hand, entrepreneurship must be encouraged as it brings benefits not only to the individual but also to the community in which it operates. On the other hand, women accounted for only 31% of entrepreneurs in the EU in 2012, which is far too few. It is therefore necessary to create urgently the right conditions in order to develop female entrepreneurship and unlock the potential that resides there.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. The differences between men and women are still notorious in business careers. In 2012, of all EU-28 citizens working on their own, only 31% were women. When women start businesses, they do so more often in sectors related to human health, social action or education, while male entrepreneurs are more present in areas of the construction, transport and ICT sectors. It is not surprising that the net income of entrepreneurs was 6% lower in 2012 than that of men. In addition, women's businesses remain smaller, with only 23% of entrepreneurs employers, compared to 30% of men. The work-life balance that entrepreneurship can offer women is a first obstacle to their success, as it can lead them into a vicious circle where they create fewer opportunities to gain management experience to conduct their activities, consolidate their credit history and gain investor confidence. We continue to work to reverse this situation.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. Yesterday, in the plenary session, the European Parliament looked at the reasons why women generally start out as independents than men. A report was voted calling on the European Commission and Member States to take up the issue and encourage women to become entrepreneurs.  In Europe, women are half as likely as men to choose self-employment: they made up only 31% of the self-employed in the 28 EU Member States in 2012. The text of the adopted report reviews the barriers that prevent women from starting out as entrepreneurs. For example, women have less access to traditional equity financing, and they generally start their business with less capital and smaller loans.  The voted text therefore calls on The Member States and the European Commission to promote an entrepreneurial culture from the outset of the training of young girls, and to consider instruments - financial in particular - to help women to start as independents.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I want to point out that this question is not as unambiguous as it may appear. I fully agree with the statement that greater female entrepreneurship would make a significant contribution to our ambition to increase Europe's competitiveness. On the other hand, why are we talking only about entrepreneurship? After all, not everyone has the desire or ability to develop their own business? Many good and honest people work well in public administrations or non-governmental organisations. And it's not business. And skills or skills are needed there. However, work in public administrations or non-governmental organisations also contributes to a better Europe. I support this report, but I would like to point out that it is not in the right format. We should not just talk about female entrepreneurship. We need to talk about their greater participation in the labour market, collectively, in the labour market, which includes both business and the public and non-governmental sectors.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union, with the aim of resuming economic growth and the creation of new jobs, has adopted concrete policy initiatives in the Europe 2020 strategy for smart, sustainable and inclusive growth to develop European entrepreneurship. For its part, female entrepreneurship deserves special attention, as wage equality is still not guaranteed in the European Union. This report focuses on the financial needs of women entrepreneurs in order to reduce the indirect discrimination that many of them are still, unfortunately today, targeted during their entrepreneurial initiative. Since it is important to know these realities - so often hidden or forgotten - so that we can achieve a socially balanced, fairer and developed working Europe, I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. The European Union's priority is currently to boost growth and jobs; for this, the Union needs more entrepreneurs. The European Strategy for Smart, Sustainable and Inclusive Growth explicitly indicates that more concrete initiatives are needed to develop European entrepreneurship. It is important to focus on women's entrepreneurship, especially since the employment rate of women, 59.6% in 2014 at EU level, falls well short of the target set out in the Europe 2020 strategy.  This text draws attention to the financing needs of women entrepreneurs and raises the issue of indirect discrimination against women in the creation of businesses. It is therefore important to develop actions to fully exploit the potential of women entrepreneurs.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Greater participation of women in the world of entrepreneurship will help the growth of the European Union, bringing new workforces, new points of view, new ways of doing business.  Even today, one of the biggest obstacles facing women is home-work reconciliation, childcare or care for the elderly. Access to funds is also a problem, because women are often less likely to access foreign funding and rely only on their own resources limit their activity and possibilities.  The task of the European institutions should therefore be both to promote a financial culture and entrepreneurship among women and to create a platform for the exchange of existing best practices and possibilities.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report indicates that the rate of female entrepreneurship lags behind in many Member States and that there is actually untapped growth and prosperity potential. The report calls for concrete strategies to fully exploit the potential of women as entrepreneurs. While the focus is primarily on the private sector and entrepreneurship, positive references to the fight against gender stereotypes and a call to Member States to achieve Barcelona's objectives can be recognized. While it is true that there are many obstacles for women entrepreneurs, this report is part of the approach that believes that fostering entrepreneurship among women is key to achieving gender equality, something not shared from a progressive feminist perspective. References to the important role of the public sector and the negative effects of austerity policies in recent years are completely absent. Fearing that this report could be used to legitimize measures to increase women's business initiatives as the only solution to improve women's living conditions, giving greater weight to the financial and private sector, I abstained in the vote.

name: Christel Schaldemose (S&D)
text: Written. Equality is a social democratic issue. We have always worked for a society of equal opportunities for all and where no person is discriminated against on the basis of gender. Non-discrimination is the guiding principle. This principle must also apply to EU funds. Eu funds should be allocated on the basis of the value and nature of the projects, not on the basis of the gender of the project applicant. We would like to stress that we find it very problematic that women participate less than men in the labour market, both as employees and as entrepreneurs. A more equal distribution of maternity leave between mothers and fathers can be an instrument for increasing women's participation in the labour market. However, the EU should respect the existence of different national systems to ensure a more equitable distribution of maternity leave, where in some countries it is determined through legislation and in others by the social partners. It must remain up to each Member State which system they wish to use to ensure more equality in the labour market. We do not believe that the European Union should legislate on this.

name: Jasenko Selimovic (ALDE)
text: Written. For me, gender equality is a key issue. The fact that the proportion of women entrepreneurs is lagging behind in all Member States is a loss for society as a whole. I fully share the view of the need for a holistic approach to female entrepreneurship, and that women's access to EU funding and additional development opportunities should be facilitated in different ways. However, I do not believe that gender quotas are part of the solution. I therefore voted against paragraph 22 of this report, but nevertheless chose to end up endorsing the report as a whole because it contains other important elements of importance for female entrepreneurship.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The report aims to accommodate concerns about women's barriers to self-employment, as only 34.4% of self-employed people are women. However, while the report stresses the importance of the Commission collecting data to assess the causes, or mentioning the importance of labour and personal conciliation – once again reiterating the need to improve the current Maternity Leave Directive – the report has a strong paternalistic approach in highlighting stereotypes and focusing on boasting entrepreneurship as a way to combat discrimination and inequality towards women without going into assess structural reasons such as symbolic violence, the unequal impact of austerity policies, or the destruction of employment and public services. That's why I abstained.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D)
text: in writing. Gender equality is a topic that I consider particularly important and, in principle, all initiatives to reduce the gender gap will be supported. In this case, the approved own-initiative report, among many other measures, calls on Member States to recognise the value of entrepreneurship in the work-life balance of men and women and to remove barriers that hinder or even hinder female entrepreneurship.  In general terms, this report calls for knowledge-based action, emphasizing the importance of collecting gender-based data in order to identify flaws and opportunities. For various reasons that are based on the report, but including those set out above, I have chosen to vote positively on this initiative.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this because this crazy report calls on various things such as ‘Men to become more involved in house work’. This is in my opinion an anti-men report and does nothing to further real gender equality. In fact it harms it by masking gender tokenism as gender equality. I will never vote in favour of quotas. Merit should be the only factor in employment.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Female entrepreneurs have a massive amount of untapped potential, and systemic sexism is not helping address the fact that the EU still lags behind with an entrepreneurial rate of just 12%.
