I believe that particular attention needs to be given to female entrepreneurs: the employment rate of women in the EU is not reaching the EU 2020 target of 75% (it is currently less than 60%). If we are truly committed to seeing equality between the genders, this is not acceptable and this report addresses the challenges and hurdles that are ahead in this goal, and more specifically in relation to achieving a higher female entrepreneurship rate. This is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: in writing ‒ I consider it important to support female entrepreneurs, as entrepreneurship is an appropriate way of levelling women's private and professional lives.  Women entrepreneurs also make an important part of the EU's economic growth. Entrepreneurship also makes it possible to increase their economic independence. However, I cannot identify with the EU's support for women's entrepreneurship, which is linked to the EU's enforcement of compulsory paternity leave, or the introduction of gender quotas in all forms of targeted support provided to women, in order to ensure progress towards equality in entrepreneurship. Such decisions should remain the responsibility of the Member States. For this reason, I had to vote against this motion for a resolution on external factors, which constitute an obstacle to women's entrepreneurship in Europe.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ Women's entrepreneurship represents the potential of growth and development, which is today poorly recognized in many members of the European Union. Women face numerous difficulties on their way to their own company, such as inability to reconcile their private and work life, administrative burdens, discrimination in all spheres of business environment starting from banks to business partners, considering them to be less able to run a business, etc., which directly leads to a lack of self-confidence and ultimately the abandonment of entering the entrepreneurial environment. Also, decisions on choosing a profession are driven in advance by traditional divisions of the roles of men and women in which men opt for scientific and technological fields, and women for educational, health and social professions. It is essential to change popular positions and allow women to have work-life balance, not least by amending the Maternity Leave Directive, which calls on Member States to consider introducing paternity leave if they have not already taken this into account. Because of the problems that women entrepreneurs face today, as well as how to address them, I supported the European Parliament's resolution with a view to providing better working conditions and equal opportunities on the labour market, urging them to focus in the sectors of new green technologies and environmental entrepreneurship, which represent great potential with a favourable business environment.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ I am glad that, despite all the persistent stereotypes, there is an increasing number of women starting to realise their business interests. I am also pleased that women's participation in the workforce, as measured by their economic activity rate, has increased in the vast majority of EU countries over the last ten years. I consider it extremely positive that many women, including Slovakia, where I come from, are also becoming interested in the field, which until now has previously been the domain of men. Despite some positives, I consider the area of women's entrepreneurship in Europe to be an under-utilized potential that could make a decisive contribution to employment growth, not only at national level, but also at EU level. It regrets that women are still confronted with various social and cultural barriers when entering the business, which often prevent or restrict their entry or successful start-up. I supported the resolution of this current report because I believe that specific support measures need to be taken, which constitute an obstacle to women's entrepreneurship in the EU and will increase women's motivation to enter into entrepreneurship and support the first stages of starting up entrepreneurship.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report by my PPE colleague Barbara Matera on external factors that hinder women's entrepreneurship in Europe. This topic is close to my heart as a member of the Committee on Women's Rights, but also as rapporteur for the European Parliament on promoting youth entrepreneurship through education. The report is relevant because the gender gap is still evident in business professional life: of all EU-28 citizens who were self-employed in 2012, only 31% were women. The report identifies a number of obstacles preventing women from doing more business in Europe. These include, for example, access to funding, where the report proposes some improvements. In the vote, I supported proposals that would mean improving the report in terms of respecting subsidiarity and not interfering with the details of behaviour that are absurd at EU level. These include, for example, the call for men to participate more in housework, or the recommendation that the Commission introduce gender quotas for all forms of targeted business support. I supported the report despite these few details, which are not binding, because I consider it more important that a signal be heard from the Level of the European Parliament supporting the women's initiative and increased sensitivity to obstacles that prevent women from better aligning family and professional life.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. Statistics show that in 2012 women made up 31% of entrepreneurs in the EU (10.3 million) and that only 34.4% of the eu's self-employed are women.  These figures announce a backlog of the level of entrepreneurship among women in all Member States. This hides behind the untapped potential for growth and prosperity.  Women entrepreneurs are known to contribute to creating new opportunities for development, reducing social exclusion and strengthening social cohesion.  The report calls on the Commission and the Member States to recognise the value of entrepreneurship for the work-life balance of women and men, to remove barriers that hinder or even prevent women's entrepreneurship, and to adopt a coordinated framework of measures to support women's participation in the labour market. I agree that it is necessary to change the way in which sexual roles have traditionally been attributed in society, workplace and family.  I think it is worth pointing out that the report also calls on the Commission and the Member States, inter alia, to increase the visibility of the financing of entrepreneurial activity by drawing up microfinance aid maps under the European Progress Microfinance Facility, and to explore the possibilities of working with the private sector on investment in the so-called women sector.  As women's entrepreneurship is essential for employment, economic growth, innovation, development and overall poverty reduction, I voted in favour of the report in plenary.

name: Renato Soru (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament resolution on external factors that represent obstacles to women's entrepreneurship aims to create the right conditions to overcome obstacles and overcome challenges for achieving a higher female entrepreneurship rate that is more in line with the Europe 2020 objectives by increasing it from 59% to 75%.  Women have incredible entrepreneurial potential, which in turn involves economic growth, jobs and greater accountability for those involved in experience and social sectors in which they operate on an equal footing. Women entrepreneurs also contribute to the creation of new opportunities for development, the marginalisation of social exclusion and the strengthening of cohesion.  The resolution encourages The Member States to become aware of the existing problem and to develop concrete strategies to promote and spread the culture of female entrepreneurship, inviting them to draw up programmes to assist, support and guide the launching of innovative activities designed to create new opportunities. For these reasons, I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Joachim Starbatty (ECR)
text: Writing. The Matera report contains some good proposals, such as improving childcare and improving data collection on the role of women in self-employed occupations. However, it is going decisively too far with a targeted demand for gender-specific funding facilitation for women. This creates distortions of competition, which should be excluded, especially in the case of business start-ups. Nor can I agree with the call for compulsory paternity leave. While fathers should be encouraged to become more actively involved in parenting, mandatory regulation by the state constitutes an inappropriate interference with citizens' private lives. That is why I did not vote in favour of the report as a whole.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: in writing \ u2012 It is necessary to encourage and support women in building careers in business. The instruments should be aimed at promoting education, in particular with a view to eliminating gender stereotypes in the choice of sectors of their activity. It is necessary to facilitate access to finance and business opportunities for women entrepreneurs and to create an environment that enables women to exploit their potential and become successful entrepreneurs and innovators.

name: Helga Stevens (ECR)
text: Written. The N-VA delegation in the European Parliament abstained in the vote on this report. The N-VA is a strong supporter of equal opportunities for men and women and is working on a strong, coordinated equal opportunities policy. By abstaining, the N-VA delegation would like to point out in particular that (1) we do not agree with the recommendation to the Commission to introduce gender quotas for any support to underrepresented and disadvantaged groups; (2) the report takes excessive step on matters of private nature; and (3) the language used in certain paragraphs is very misogynistic.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ In 2012, in the 28 EU Member States, the share of women among entrepreneurs was only 31% i.e. 31%. 10.3 million, and out of the total number of self-employed in the EU, only 34.4% are women. Entrepreneurship is essential for jobs, economic growth, innovation, development and general poverty reduction. I would invoke Article 16. the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union, which explicitly refers to the freedom to conduct all EU citizens, thereby empowering and encouraging entrepreneurship, including women's entrepreneurship. I therefore support the report and call on the Commission and the Member States to recognise the value of entrepreneurship for work-life balance between women and men, to remove barriers that hinder or even hinder female entrepreneurship, and to adopt a coherent framework of measures to support women's participation in the labour market.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This report is aimed at boosting economic growth, creating sustainable jobs and empowering women.  At the moment, women make up only a third of entrepreneurs. That is a huge amount of untapped talent. In particular, we need to invest in women’s and girls’ potential to contribute to the digital economy. Some estimates suggest boosting female entrepreneurship could deliver as much as GBP 60 billion to the UK economy by 2030.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 The resolution discusses external factors that hinder women's entrepreneurial activity in the European Union. In general, entrepreneurship is important because it creates jobs, and countries with strong entrepreneurship have a better employee structure and a relatively higher income. Currently, the rate of women entrepreneurs is not satisfactory. One of the priorities of EPP women and within the FEMM committee is to develop as favourable conditions as possible for female entrepreneurship. Entrepreneurship is essential for the Union to achieve satisfactory rates of economic growth, development and employment levels. The strategy of European entrepreneurship is smart, sustainable and inclusive development. Positive steps are seen in the European economy, but further efforts are needed to make the situation far better. I support the adoption of a resolution on women's entrepreneurship, because numerous factors from the external environment, e.g. gender stereotypes and the so-called glass roof, make it difficult for women to have entrepreneurial activity.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on external factors hindering entrepreneurship among women in Europe.  Gender equality is one of the important principles of a modern democratic society. It enables women and men to participate equally in all areas of public and private life.  As in recent years, we are introducing a gender balance in the field of political engagement, so we also need gender balance in the economic field. A number of research in this field shows that gender-balanced boards achieve better results with significantly more comprehensive decisions, taking into account the wishes and expectations of both the female and male populations.  I welcome the report calling on the Commission to ensure full mainstreaming of gender mainstreaming in all future policies in the field of entrepreneurship.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 We abstained in the vote on the report on women's entrepreneurship in Europe because we felt that the report was incomplete and contained some problematic references. As ACPL, we are certainly in favour of strengthening female activity and gender parity in all areas of socio-economic life. For us, however, equality between men and women is not achieved either through policies to support private capital or through the promotion of women's entrepreneurship. Effective gender equality is achieved only through the effective fight against stereotypical perceptions, violence and inequality in the workplace and in job opportunities, since the majority of people who flood part-time jobs and flexible forms of work are women. It is also necessary to create conditions for equal participation in decision-making centres and to create modern social structures with high quality social services. It is also particularly problematic that the report makes no mention of the harmful effects of austerity policies from the point of view of equal treatment between men and women.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 Female entrepreneurship is indeed a catalyst for reducing unemployment and lifting the economy, but only when it is growing in a country with a healthy economy and not in a country in times of economic crisis, such as Greece, where businesses are shrinking and going bankrupt. The report does not correspond to the Greek reality. The EU should establish specific strategies to promote women's entrepreneurship in the light of the real needs of the Member States and not generally and vaguely as presented in the report, since many start-ups cannot adapt and grow in the local market. In addition, according to the report, the EU aims to finance women's entrepreneurship actions but at the same time refers to grants and investments in lifelong training and retraining programmes (PROGRESS), to which we are opposed.  Finally, freedom and full gender equality bring out a new role for women in today's rapidly changing economic environment, a role which inevitably undermines the institution of the family.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am convinced that it is of the utmost importance to encourage and support women in building entrepreneurship careers, and that, of course, they should also have access to finance and business opportunities. It is equally important to reconcile professional and private life, as this balance helps to unlock opportunities and become successful entrepreneurs.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. –u2012 Promoting entrepreneurship, which has always been at the top of the European Union's political agenda, is particularly important in an era of sluggd economic growth and the need to create new jobs. There is also no doubt that freedom of establishment should be equally accessible to both sexes. Unfortunately, currently, women in the EU make up only 31% of entrepreneurs. This situation is directly linked to existing barriers restricting women from being fully active in economic life.  In order to improve this situation, the EP report includes proposals on the care of children and the elderly in order to help women entrepreneurs reach their full potential and achieve a work-life balance.  Another point highlighted in this report is the increased funding of women's entrepreneurship. According to the study, women use fewer external means, such as bank loans, than men and tend to use more expensive internal financing. Less capital, on the other hand, often means simply less chance of success. I have therefore chosen to vote in favour of the EP's report on external factors hindering the entrepreneurship of European women.

name: Dario Tamburrano (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 We voted in favour of this report because it addresses the difficulties faced by women in the field of entrepreneurship in Europe. In fact, the latest data updated to 2012 show that only 31% of the self-employed are women, who therefore mostly hold dependent jobs.  The report mentions some of the main issues for which action by the institutions is required: for example, access to finance and the difficult work-life balance. An important point that is mentioned in the report is the failure to adopt the directive on maternity leave, which also touches on the issue of the division of roles between spouses.  Overcoming certain old ideologies that relegate the role of women to that of housewife is fundamental to create an entrepreneurial environment where men and women have the same career opportunities and realization from a work and family point of view.  However, we voted against the paragraph proposing the introduction of gender quotas: we believe that, in order to have a real presence of women in managerial and labour roles, we must work a priori on real equal opportunities, thus assigning roles according to their own abilities and competences through transparent and equal meritocratic criteria for all.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 It is not the only report on the agenda based on difficulties and obstacles to the establishment and financing of business. Both women and young people are having difficulties in the first steps they can take on the path of entrepreneurship, starting with education and ending with excessive bureaucracy, which we also find in European assistance programmes for these categories.  The European Commission must closely monitor the distribution of capital by gender, but at the same time reflect on the possibility of reducing time wasted from initiative or idea to implementation and financing.  It is within our power to facilitate access to information and financial resources for women or young people, and we must take this opportunity to direct the necessary finances to areas where SME ecosystems are needed managed by women or young people.  It is not complicated to set up a European Business Centre for Women. Without considerable budgetary impact we can integrate the gender and age perspective into national business strategies. I believe that we can better connect women and young people to the Structural Funds in order to break a vicious circle of inequality in the system.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I'm on the same line as Mrs. Matera. We call on the EU institutions, Member States and regional and local authorities to tackle more actively, in particular through concrete measures, stereotypes about the respective characteristics and abilities of women and men, which persist in sectors where men are the majority, such as science and technology, or innovation and invention.  In these sectors, policy makers, investors, the financial sector and the market are likely to perceive women as less credible or less professional than men, which means that women entrepreneurs are sometimes viewed with skepticism by potential clients, suppliers, partners, banks and investors, and that they must be much more tenacious to prove their knowledge. , their skills and abilities, and be able to access the funding they need.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Although in 2016 it is of the utmost important to encourage women entrepreneurs and to promote economic growth, job creation and women’s empowerment, I decided to abstain on the final vote of this report. Indeed, while I share the view that we need concrete measures to increase the level of women’s participation in the labour market, I am opposed to the introduction of quotas for men and women. I believe that these kind of binding measures are not effective.

name: Patrizia Toia (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The differences between women and men are still evident in business careers. There are many obstacles affecting the development of female entrepreneurship, including the difficulty of reconciling work and private life and differences in access to external financing, such as bank loans and loans from providers.  As the report highlights, women have enormous entrepreneurial potential and women's entrepreneurship is synonymous with economic growth, job creation and empowering women. It is therefore necessary for national governments and authorities to promote equal pay for men and women in the first place and to guarantee equal access to capital through full cooperation with the financial sector. It is up to the Commission to diligently monitor the integration of the gender perspective into the allocation of EU funds linked to entrepreneurship.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the report on the external factors hindering entrepreneurship among women in Europe, as I believe that more concrete policy initiatives need to be given to European entrepreneurship. Within this, it is women who are still economically less independent than men, according to the data, and whose unemployment rate is still higher than that of men. Incentives would thus fully exploit the potential of female entrepreneurs in the social sector.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report indicates that the rate of female entrepreneurship lags behind in many Member States and that there is actually untapped growth and prosperity potential. The report calls for concrete strategies to fully exploit the potential of women as entrepreneurs. While the focus is primarily on the private sector and entrepreneurship, positive references to the fight against gender stereotypes and a call to Member States to achieve Barcelona's objectives can be recognized. While it is true that there are many obstacles for women entrepreneurs, this report is part of the approach that believes that fostering entrepreneurship among women is key to achieving gender equality, something not shared from a progressive feminist perspective. References to the important role of the public sector and the negative effects of austerity policies in recent years are completely absent. Fearing that this report could be used to legitimize measures to increase women's business initiatives as the only solution to improve women's living conditions, giving greater weight to the financial and private sector, I abstained in the vote.

name: Ulrike Trebesius (ECR)
text: Writing. The Matera report contains some good proposals, such as improving childcare and improving data collection on the role of women in self-employed occupations. However, it is going decisively too far with a targeted demand for gender-specific funding facilitation for women. This creates distortions of competition, which should be excluded, especially in the case of business start-ups. Nor can I agree with the call for compulsory paternity leave. While fathers should be encouraged to become more actively involved in parenting, mandatory regulation by the state constitutes an inappropriate interference with citizens' private lives. That is why I did not vote in favour of the report as a whole.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Entrepreneurship and business involves own economic independence, increased self-esteem and personal growth, but also often require a lot of hours of work that often make it difficult to balance work and family. This may be one of the reasons why only 31% of European entrepreneurs are women. There are more, to which the government must face up to increase this figure. I support the proposal to promote gender equality and promote development and sustainable and inclusive growth.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. Among many uninteresting measures, corrupt proposals have crept in: - promoting gender equality in companies, - support in particular 'women with multiple identities', - ensure the proper distribution of household tasks and 'change the traditional distribution of roles within the family', - set up quotas for women for help for disadvantaged groups, - set up 'psychological support' cells for women entrepreneurs...  This report, with no legislative impact, may justify counterproductive measures, such as equal and non-transferable paternity leave (which, for obvious economic reasons, could only lead to a reduction in maternity leave). The few suggestions of common sense, such as the introduction to entrepreneurship in school training, are not within the competence of the Union.  So I'm voting against it.

name: Mihai Ţurcanu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on external factors that represent obstacles to European women's entrepreneurship, as the rate of entrepreneurship among women is low in all Member States and reflects an untapped potential for growth and prosperity. It is important to understand the European Union's need for more entrepreneurs, and its strategy for smart, sustainable and inclusive growth (Europe 2020) explicitly mentions that more concrete strategic initiatives are needed to develop European entrepreneurship. Entrepreneurship among women deserves special attention in this context, equal economic independence is not a fact achieved in the European Union, and the employment rate for women, of 59.6% in 2014 at EU-28 level, does not correspond to the employment target of 75%. I would like to highlight the negative impact of the administrative sphere on entrepreneurship. Effective regulations and legislation are needed to empower women economically. In addition, I support the implementation of work-life balance policies, as well as an equal distribution of family responsibilities and by highlighting the role of women in promoting equality.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Entrepreneurship is defined by the EU legal framework as a way of thinking that allows individuals to use their motivation and capacity to identify and fully implement an opportunity. While enterprise policy has been a political priority since the launch of the Treaty of Lisbon, the European Union is still lagging behind: in 2009, the proportion of entrepreneurs in the EU-27 was 12%, compared with 27% in China and 21% in the United States. Female entrepreneurs deserve particular attention in this context, as an equal degree of economic independence is still not a given in the European Union. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour as the improving amendments were supported by the rapporteur and included in the text of the report.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. Europe must continue to promote initiatives to create jobs. In this sense, the entrepreneurship of European women is a crucial issue to be paid attention to. The report deals with this issue in a special way, stressing the need to provide financial support to women entrepreneurs. That is why I consider it necessary to vote in your favour.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. 'This issue is close to my heart as a female politician and advocate for women's rights. In Europe, women account for only 31% of all entrepreneurs, the most often in softer sectors such as health, education and social work. This has become clear once again in the under-representation of women in Davos in recent days. I approved this report on the external factors that are an obstacle for women entrepreneurs, because I want to encourage the European Commission to promote entrepreneurship by women in all sectors.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. Women are still too absent from the business world, accounting for only 31% of the jobs in the sector. So act.  The report aims to promote the development of women's "entrepreneurship" by improving their environment through the development of childcare and paternity leave services.  Combating stereotypes affecting career development is presented as a priority, as is the fight against discrimination in access to bank loans.  I can only encourage these kinds of initiatives that apply to everything related to equality, including the professional equality of women and men. I would add that the issue of child care is a parental problem and not just a problem for women.  Entrepreneurship as the only solution to reduce unemployment in Europe is for me only a bad thing that should not make us forget that other policies are possible in the European Union.  Thus, the creation of jobs in the public sector and the impact of austerity policies on the order books of SMEs are coincidentally absent from this report.  I therefore abstained on this report.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. As a consequence of liberal policies, the painful reality shows that unemployment, poverty and inequality have female faces. In all these indicators, women appear systematically ahead of men. Trying to combat this reality with this new and modern panacea of entrepreneurship is totally illusory, intending to cure the disease with the agent responsible for the same disease. The problems, gender discrimination in employment, are fought against progressive legislation that promotes stable and well-paid jobs. We cannot promote the precariousness that generates female unemployment and then come here to defend female entrepreneurship. If we want gender equality we must create conditions for all women for full citizenship. This involves job security, combating all gender discrimination practices and quality public services that can ensure health and education for all children.  Unfortunately, it is not the current course of EU policy, but it will one day be the struggle of women and all workers.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. A sensible promotion of entrepreneurship is essential for a functioning economy. Every company is an asset and creates jobs. It should not be decided by gender whether a company is supported or not. However, the report calls for gender support. It is important that there is equal opportunities. I strongly oppose the preference of one sex through quotas, as called for in the report, or gender-specific support. That is why I am also voting against this report.

name: Henna Virkkunen (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 In recent years, almost all new jobs in Europe have been created in SMEs. However, only one third of EU entrepreneurs are women. Women entrepreneurship therefore has a lot of growth potential. We must also vigorously encourage women to become entrepreneurs and remove obstacles to entrepreneurship. This report highlighted, among other things, the difficulties for women entrepreneurs in obtaining company funding and the accumulation of housework and childcare for women. In many Member States, paternity leave is not even known yet. Historical and cultural attitudes also influence girls' choices in the field of education. We should therefore encourage girls to be more oriented towards science, mathematical sciences and technology in education. Everyone, regardless of gender, must have the same opportunities to realize themselves and their dreams.

name: Udo Voigt (NI)
text: Writing. There is no need for extra measures to promote "female entrepreneurship" because equality of opportunity and justice is guaranteed in democratic societies anyway. In addition, the boundaries to quotas for women and gender programmes are fluid. As an outgrowth of feminist fashion ideologies, the report deserves rejection rather than approval.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. I rejected the European Parliament's resolution on 'External factors which constitute obstacles to female entrepreneurship'.  The report calls on the Member States to promote an entrepreneurial education culture and training in schools and universities in order to encourage girls and women to choose careers in high-growth profitable areas such as new technologies, digital environments and IT. The report also calls on the Commission to introduce gender quotas and underlines the alleged need for motivating and psychological support for women in order to support their self-confidence. The report also calls on the Commission to communicate more actively the performance of women entrepreneurs and to award them to the public. This now means, in plain language, that this report – from start to finish – is ideological and inappropriate. It is not only an overstepping of the EU's competences, but also an insult to all women and men. A clear no from me.

name: Jarosław Wałęsa (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution of 19 January 2016 on external factors hindering women's entrepreneurship in Europe (2015/2111(INI)). Entrepreneurship is essential for growth, employment, innovation development, poverty eradication. The decision to take up a business by women is the result of a clash of internal motives m.in psychological and external considerations, based on socio-economic determinants. The female entrepreneurship rate, which illustrates women's entrepreneurship in EU countries, was 31% in 2014. Studies in this respect in relation to the female sex are carried out much less frequently than for the male sex. For this reason too, I support the establishment of a specialised institutional unit on women's activity in the EU. Its tasks would be based on supporting initiatives, from updating competitiveness information to introducing and verifying High Tech. The so-called "pre-incubators" play a minor role. This project allows support to be received before setting up a business and to introduce specialised training or exchanges of practices between potential stakeholders. This solution would allow direct interactions to be ingocerating the emergence of business partnership networks in the long term.

name: Julie Ward (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This report is aimed at boosting economic growth, creating sustainable jobs and empowering women.  At the moment, women make up only a third of entrepreneurs; that represents a huge amount of untapped talent. In particular, we need to invest in women’s and girls’ potential to contribute to the digital economy. Some estimates suggest that boosting female entrepreneurship could deliver as much as GBP 60 billion to the UK economy by 2030.  Entrepreneurship education and women’s mentorship networks have the potential to overcome gender stereotypes and provide positive role models for girls and young women, especially for those in marginalised and vulnerable communities. Having been involved in successful social entrepreneurship prior to my parliamentary life, I particularly wanted to highlight the important role that social enterprise and alternative business models, such as mutuals and cooperatives, can play in overcoming the obstacles that women face.

name: Iuliu Winkler (PPE)
text: in writing. – I voted for the own-initiative report on external factors that are obstacles to European women's entrepreneurship.  The report identifies the most important factors preventing the development of entrepreneurship among women in a European Union which, unlike the US or China, has an extremely low entrepreneurial rate (2 % in EU-27 countries in 2009, compared to the US by 21% or China by 27%). Europe's return to sustainable economic growth and the creation of new jobs depends to a large extent on the increase in the number of European entrepreneurs.  In the given circumstances, I consider it extremely important to implement measures leading to the development, in general, of entrepreneurship among Europeans and, in particular, among women in the EU.

name: Anna Záborská (PPE)
text: in writing ‒ the World Health Organization defines gender roles as "company-created roles, behaviors, activities and attributes that the company considers appropriate for men and women". But motherhood is not a gender stereotype. It is this that has the most impact on women's economic activity, whether in business or employment. A society that wants to be sustainable must highlight and appropriately value responsible motherhood, not penally punish with income shortfalls and lower pensions. The key to better empowering women entrepreneurs is accepting the fact that each of them can become a mother, not repeating the mantra of gender and stereotypes. I would therefore like to see more talk about women in similar resolutions instead of gender.

name: Θεόδωρος Ζαγοράκης (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 This report by the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality aims to support female entrepreneurs at all levels of the market. At the same time, it raises key issues for the development of business in general. Of course I voted in favour of it.

name: Pablo Zalba Bidegain (PPE)
text: in writing. I believe that one of the great challenges of the European Union continues to be gender equality in all areas and, in particular, at work. There are still clear differences between the male and female employment rate. These differences are reflected in the statistics carried out by Eurostat, which shows that in the EU 70.1% of men are part of the world of work, compared to 59.6% of women. On the other hand, it has also been shown that those countries with a higher rate of diversity and equality in enterprises are, in many cases, where higher levels of economic well-being and social cohesion have been achieved. Taking into account these claims and the high level of academic preparation and experience of a large percentage of women, I consider it completely necessary to end the difference in job opportunities between men and women. I therefore strongly support this report and consider it key to promote any action necessary to support women's entrepreneurship.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report on the external factors hindering European female entrepreneurship because I believe that entrepreneurship is fundamental to jobs, economic growth, R&D and poverty reduction in general, and that female entrepreneurship, by experiencing a backwardness in all Member States, hides an untapped potential for growth and prosperity for European societies. Moreover, female entrepreneurship deserves special attention, as equality in terms of economic independence is still not guaranteed in the EU and the employment rate of women is not in line with the 75% employment target of the Europe 2020 strategy, nor with the male employment rate.  In this sense, I think that the report clearly presents how barriers to female entrepreneurship – such as the predominance of women in unemployment, the constant disparity between men and women in business and the under-representation of women in management activities – are interlinked and difficult to overcome, and that it must be clearly differentiated from false self-employment and regarded as a powerful source of economic independence that enables women to integrate further into the market work.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This is an own-initiative report indicating that the rate of female entrepreneurship is very low in many Member States. In essence, this report focuses on the idea that the private sector and feminism entrepreneurship are the panacea for solving women's economic problems and difficult living conditions. This example includes encouraging the promotion of a culture of entrepreneurship in education and training curricula.  The report calls on states and the Commission to come up with strategies to fully exploit the potential of women as entrepreneurs and advocates that awareness-raising campaigns are needed in banks and other financial institutions to ensure equal treatment between men and women for credit, while adhering to debt and business risk which, from our point of view , is negative. Nor can we agree with the introduction of gender quotas with regard to the allocation of EU funds, which would limit access to such funds. We voted against it.

name: Marco Zullo (EFDD)
text: in writing. The report aims to solve the problems faced by women in the field of entrepreneurship, which are such as to significantly discourage the presence of women in this area at European level.  There is still a trend where women occupy more employee positions, focusing on sectors considered less profitable such as education, health care or community work. Only 31% of European entrepreneurs are women. With this report, the FEMM Committee has called on the European Commission to implement new measures to increase women's participation in entrepreneurship.  I voted in favour of this report with the strong conviction that it is necessary to overcome ancient cultural and social heritages and to implement the principles of gender equality with full awareness of the concept of equal opportunities. One of the main obstacles to be overcome is, first and foremost, access to credit, since the banking sector provides more difficult financing for women. The text also calls on the European Commission to adopt new measures to make women in a position to combine professional and family life commitments, reversing what is often the traditional division of roles between spouses.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. -u2012 Female entrepreneurship attracts women to the labour market and improves their economic and social situation. Current statistics show that only 31% of female entrepreneurs are women.  The report lists barriers that exclude women from certain professional areas and limit their entrepreneurial initiatives, such as, inter alia, work-life balance and discrimination in access to finance and the use of funds. It also notes that there is great potential for female entrepreneurship in social entrepreneurship.  I supported the report because I agree that an integrated policy to promote female entrepreneurship is essential to ensure gender mainstreaming in all future policies in the field of entrepreneurship.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: – I congratulate my colleague Plur on the approval of the report, which very well captures the basic starting points for improving the skills of young people and is thus an excellent incentive for Member States that are mindful of developing young people's skills. For me, the fact that it does not forget equal opportunities is particularly important and, from the daily reality of the report, the fact that it does not forget equal opportunities, and thus: – calls on the employment authorities and agencies to increase their activity in complying with the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities and thus help, at least in part, to eliminate the strong inequality in access to the labour market, – the report also includes the promotion of inclusive education, but also the availability of financial support for persons with disabilities. , which may not be excluded from business. I would also like to highlight one more important principle that is contained in the report, namely flexibility and student-friendlyness, which allows them to change and adjust their study focus so that they are not stigmatised by a single decision, but can find what will be most fulfilling in life in the process of study.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I am happy to support this report and the focus on young people and ensuring that they have the correct skills to gain employment. One in five of our young people are unemployed. It is higher in some countries across Europe, and yet this is not a new problem. If you look at 1995, youth unemployment was at 21% also, and that is over 20 years ago now. Today’s young people are more educated than previous generations, and yet youth unemployment continues to face challenges.  Skills development has been identified in this report, and the development of relevant skills is important. The training and education sector must move and work in this area. It must move and work in conjunction with employers, in conjunction with those who need the relevant skills but who find they do not have them in the cohort of young people available to them. So we need a renewed focus, particularly on the apprenticeship model, and to bring back the apprenticeship model. There is probably too much of an emphasis on pieces of paper and third-level education in our universities that does not provide young people with the necessary skills. I welcome the changes that have happened in my own country with the education and training boards, in which employers and those providing education and training are involved, working together to ensure young people are equipped with the necessary skills.

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI).
text: – I abstained because of what is at the very point of the report and which can be read in points A, B and C. I quote: "There are currently 4.5 million young people between the age of 15 and 24 out of work in the European Union, and the number of young Europeans between the age of 15 and 24 who are not in employment, education or training exceeds 7 million." For young people, the unemployment rate in Europe is 21.4%. Point C points out that young people have been particularly affected by the crisis. I would very much like to ask that we invite Mrs Angela Merkel and her dear pals here once and ask why, in these circumstances, they see the solution to the problem of mass influx of migrants into Europe from Asia and Africa, when there are enough problems among young People in Europe. Please give them a job opportunity.

name: Ilhan Kyuchyuk (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, I voted in favour of this extremely important report aiming to tackle one of the biggest challenges that Europe faces: the unprecedentedly high rate of youth unemployment, which reaches 50% in some Member States. Our objective must be to equip individuals with the necessary transversal competences that support active and responsible citizenship in democratic and increasingly diverse societies, acknowledging that the labour market is changing far too fast and that forecasting precisely the skills the future needs is not really possible. Students should be taught more broadly. We also have to support Member States in enhancing their cooperation and exchanging good practices in the field of education and training, in particular in implementing work-based learning. Young people must have the technical skills, entrepreneurial mind-set, language competences and confidence of course, but they need to adapt over the course of their lifetimes and achieve a sustainable school to work transition.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D).
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank you I have voted in favour, supported and even been an active representative of the issue that we are talking about for the last 1.5 years, because there are few more important issues in Europe today than young people's access to work. There are 7.5 million young people who are not employed or in education in Europe, and this is an amazing figure. If this remains the case, we cannot dream of a rich, developing, peaceful Europe.  Immediate action is needed in education, vocational training and social issues. And since the report highlights the importance of the responsibility of the Member States, the governments on this issue, I simply do not understand why the Hungarian Government is dethroning on one side, why it is destroying the Hungarian education system, and I do not understand why jobbik representatives in this House, on this very important issue, abstained, why did they not support this proposal? I therefore propose to all of us, governments and the European institutions that we consider this to be one of our most important issues in the coming years. Create jobs for young people.

name: Μαρία Σπυράκη (PPE).
text: Mr President, I would like to quote two figures which are indicative of our inability so far to act on the burning issue of youth employment. Five million young unemployed people in Europe, two million vacancies: why are we not providing young people with the skills they lack, so that these vacancies become direct jobs with a view? Member States have resources at their disposal to improve the qualifications and skills of young people who want to move on, but it is obvious that in some countries or pseudo-learning tends to become a habit. We must, here and now, press the Member States to activate the systems for monitoring and monitoring the absorption of Community funds, so that apprenticeships can develop into a job immediately. At the same time, we must encourage youth extrovert entrepreneurship by promoting young entrepreneurs in Erasmus and the cooperation of educational institutions with businesses. These are, you know, small, simple but necessary steps, but in many Member States, including my own country of origin, Greece, have not been done to a sufficient extent.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – Mr President, i would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur I also am very pleased to vote in favour of this report by my colleague Plura, because it is extremely important. Youth unemployment is one of the main curses in the European Union economy in general, and for my country, Latvia, youth unemployment has turned into a real tragedy in my country. Consequently, any leverage, any method, any move, policy and policy development to reduce youth unemployment must be welcomed. The unhappiness is that the main thing that employers now require is that the employee is 25 years old and has the same high profile. Clearly, this is not possible. And if there is no experience, not being hired, and not recruited because there is no experience—it is a vicious circle. We need to continue very seriously precisely this orientation, this vector, in order to reduce youth unemployment, not only in Latvia, not only in Eastern Europe, but also throughout the European Union, because in my opinion this problem is No 1.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE).
text: – Mr President, the higher than 20% youth employment rate in the European Union reflects the severity of the main employment challenges that we have to deal with in our countries. It also shows that here, in the European Parliament, we must constantly strive to keep these issues on our agenda. Among other points, the report rightly identifies the lack of relevant skills for available jobs, and education and training mismatches, as the main shortcomings of the labour and education policies of many Member States.  Another problem that severely affects countries in Central and Eastern Europe, and which we have to deal with urgently, is early school leaving, especially in the case of the more disadvantaged social categories like the Roma. I believe that such issues should receive even more focus in the European Semester and the employment strategies of Member States, so that we make progress towards education systems that keep students in schools, adequately prepare them for professional life and offer them vocational support tailored to the needs of the labour market.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – A Uachtaráin, arís bhí áthas orm tacaíocht a thabhairt don tuarascáil seo agus vótáil mé le mo ghrúpa sna vótaí go léir a bhí ann. Dar ndóigh, is cás truamhéalach é an méid daoine óga atá dífhostaithe san Aontas. Go háirithe, chonaic mé i mo thír féin i rith an chúlú eacnamaíochta daoine óga a bhí cáilithe go maith ag cur isteach ar jab, ag dul os comhair agallaimh agus ansin ag fáil an litir chéanna ag tosú le: ‘Is oth liom a rá nár éirigh leat an post a bhaint amach an uair seo. Bain triail as arís. Go n-éirí leat.’ Tharla seo arís agus arís eile dá lán daoine. Ní nach ionadh go raibh díomá agus déistin orthu agus chuaigh siad thar lear agus thosaigh sé sin an brain drain mar a tugadh air. Tá áthas orm a rá go bhfuil rudaí ag casadh timpeall i mo thír anois agus tá an geilleagar ag fás 6 % i mbliana agus beidh daoine óga ag teacht ar ais chun jabanna a líonadh. Dá bhrí sin, tá súil agam go dtarlódh an rud céanna sna Ballstáit eile san Aontas.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I supported this report. Youth unemployment, of course, is linked to the power of the economies of individual European states. On the other hand, the phenomenon is so strong that we must be active in this matter, and that is why I am glad that this report has been adopted. Youth employment is linked to their education and how competitive they are in the labour market. And it is clear that in today's global world, national education alone is not enough. That is why I am very happy and very strongly in support of the programmes that the European Union brings, such as erasmus. I say this from my own experience as a university teacher, that they greatly improve the quality of individual students not only in terms of language and professionality, but also in terms of, say, maturity and maturity of life if a young student spends a year or two in another country of the European Union. I also very much like the new Erasmus programme for young entrepreneurs to help young entrepreneurs. The news is good, and I'm glad it's been accepted.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE).
text: – Mr. President, I supported this report because it recognizes the key problems that many European Union countries face today, including the Republic of Croatia. Namely, according to EUROSTAT data from 2015, in Croatia the unemployment rate among young people up to 25 years in the second quarter of 2015 was as high as 43.1%, which unfortunately puts it at the very top of Europe. I believe that we can improve the situation in Europe through the proposed measures, and I call on the Commission and the competent authorities in the Member States to develop programmes and projects to help young people master the necessary knowledge and skills to be competitors in the labour market.  In this regard, I welcome the call for closer cooperation between the education sector, public administrations, businesses and civil society, in particular youth organisations. Young people will benefit from this, but the economic sector will also benefit, as it will get a skilled workforce for newly created jobs.

name: Diane Dodds (NI).
text: – Mr President, I welcome the attention given in this report to a cross-cutting approach to tackling youth unemployment, which has at its heart a focus on building a skills base. As a starting point we must recognise that the barriers facing different young people are very diverse, and therefore it is necessary to create synergies within all aspects of government, the community and business in order to maximise the transition from inactivity to opportunity. This report rightly illustrates that this overarching network should include businesses, with a particular focus on SMEs, statutory education providers and those based in the community, public career services and key relationships between the public and private sectors. Of course, we cannot ignore the expected intrusions into national competence that this report makes. However, the goal of giving young people a true stake in society is one that in the main its authors get right. The ESF Programme has a vital role to play in maximising the work of voluntary organisations who engage with disaffected young people. However, in Northern Ireland the implementation of this fund has been beset by red tape and restrictions.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, what I like about this report is that it puts forward some practical suggestions to assist the 7.5 million young people who are not in employment, education or training. In regard to the skills mismatch – and it is important to remember that this can sometimes be as much about over—qualification as under—qualification – this report proposes that we build strong partnerships between educational establishments, public authorities, local authorities and social partners, etc. to try to help integrate young people into the labour market. This can also be facilitated through second chance education.  But I am pleased to see that, while the report emphasises the need to match skills and jobs, it also emphasises the importance of a holistic education. Education is about life as well as work. I support the call to bring young innovative employers into the ongoing dialogue that I spoke of earlier, and also the idea of mentoring programmes designed to prepare young people for the transition from school to work deserves support.  Finally, the report acknowledges the importance of the creative industries and the number of jobs that can be created using traditional skills.

name: Lars Adaktusson (PPE)
text: Written. The European Parliament today voted on an own-initiative report on skills-enhancing measures to combat youth unemployment. The report mentioned several things about education policy that is not European competence. I voted against these, such as a European Youth Guarantee and investment in trainee jobs and training in countries such as Greece with high youth job unemployment. I also voted against a new European prize that would go to the best project to combat youth unemployment. Nevertheless, in the final vote, I voted in favour of the report as a whole, as it did not contain any strong proposals that would involve new EU policies in the field of education or the labour market.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU acts as a stimulus in the social field, seeking to promote increased employment and information, as well as an improvement in working conditions. Unfortunately, youth unemployment has reached alarming levels in most European countries, requiring decisive action in this area. Better management of European funds for this purpose, simplification of administrative procedures and the development of more flexible education systems are the instruments identified to increase the effectiveness of youth guarantees. I voted in favour because of the importance of establishing a dialogue between companies and workers.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I have not been able to vote in favour of this report, since although it does a good X-ray of the drama of youth unemployment in EU member countries, the recipes for addressing it are by no means appropriate to do so in my view. Instead of promoting the creation of public, stable and quality employment for young people, it proposes to encourage entrepreneurs and focus training towards market needs. That's why I abstained.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the report on skills development policies to combat youth unemployment, despite the fact that it was originally a good initiative in the context of increased unemployment among young workers. Among other things, the text proposed measures to promote skills rather than diplomas, encourage orientation from an early age or develop increased support for learning. While youth employment is indeed a priority, the measures discussed here remain very vague and unsuitable for the current economic situation in view of member states' budget cuts. Moreover, these youth employment policies must be concentrated at the regional and local level and not at the European level. Finally, all the ENF amendments were rejected and ideological demands such as those of gender theory or migrant aid were infiltrated.   Moreover, the emphasis on youth entrepreneurship in this text, which seems complicated in the current economic context, suggests a desire to clumsily lower unemployment figures.

name: Martina Anderson and Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report overall because it is largely positive and calls for increased support for young people in skills development and gaining employment, including increased public investment in education in general and in school-to-work transition in particular. This report has particular relevance for Ireland where the youth unemployment rate is almost 20%. However, I voted against aspects within the report that I believe are problematic, particularly where it calls for closer links between educational and vocational training institutions with industry in order to address the skills mismatch, because my view is that education should be provided entirely independent of industry. During negotiations on this file in the Employment and Social Affairs Committee Sinn Féin MEP Lynn Boylan successfully inserted a call for the removal of ‘barriers such as education fees for apprentices’ in the text with the support of most groups – including the EPP, which Fine Gael is part of. This was the most important aspect of the report because it is such an important issue in Ireland where the Fine Gael/Labour government have implemented education fees for apprentices.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 With this report, Parliament is trying to strengthen the debate on combating particularly high youth unemployment, especially in countries such as ours. The report stresses the need to strengthen the Youth Guarantee and the Youth Employment Initiative with additional funding, by strengthening education programmes and by creating equal opportunities for all.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. The vague proposals in this report concern learning, flexible curricula, alternating training, etc., proposals which are paradoxical with regard to budgetary restrictions imposed on Member States. Moreover, by highlighting skills, rather than diplomas, this report itself appears as an admission of the failure of national education systems. Moreover, it seems much more appropriate that policies for the integration of young people should be carried out first at the regional and local level, not at the European level. Finally, the amendments in committee have included inappropriate and dangerous concepts, such as the integration of migrants and the application of gender theory. Therefore, I voted against it.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This report proposes opening up British jobs as a matter of course to continental workers through EURES. At a time of high unemployment in the UK, particularly in my constituency of North East England which has the highest unemployment anywhere in the UK, this is clearly contrary to the interests of my constituents. Given that the majority of such positions are unskilled or semi-skilled jobs, and that the greatest shortage of jobs in my constituency lies in such sectors, the problem is far worse in the North East than elsewhere. In terms of wage compression, it is almost certain that the situation specifically in the North East must be far worse than the 1.88% drop in wages in such sectors which has recently been documented by the Bank of England. I therefore voted against this report.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. With nearly 5 million unemployed, the youth employment rate in the European Union remains at a very worrying level. This situation poses a serious threat to the union's social cohesion and economic development. I could only vote in favour of this report, because there is an urgent need to improve the employability of young people. That is why I am strongly committed to European mobility and learning, which, through their association, offers a royal path to the employment of young Europeans. We need to harness the potential of learning to create links between businesses and higher education institutions. I believe that vocational training provides young Europeans with the skills they need for a successful job integration and facilitates the transition from training to the labour market.

name: Petras Auštrevičius (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I thank Mr Plura for his well-drafted report. I believe that this document is very timely as youth unemployment in Europe is one of the pressing challenges which requires a prompt response and concrete solutions. Taking into account the fact that there are approximately 2 million unfilled vacancies in the EU, I think that the idea to get better at  making young people’s abilities and skills correspond to available jobs through improved cooperation between businesses, representatives of the education sector, employment services and authorities, needs to be implemented as soon as possible. Moreover, in order to avoid young people experiencing delays in access to the jobs market and extended episodes of unemployment, the EU should examine the best practices in the world of school career guidance systems, where schoolchildren are observed from an early school phase to the first steps in the labour market. Likewise high-quality internships could be a good solution for the smooth transition to the job market as well.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to develop individual skills and disseminate knowledge and skills to combat youth unemployment. There are now 4.5 million people in the European Union. unemployed and as more than 7 million people are unemployed. Young people living in Europe are unemployed, not studying or studying. The lack of the necessary skills for the jobs offered and the lack of education and vocational training are important factors in determining youth unemployment. The development of individual skills is one of the key elements of integrated employment and social policy and that skills can achieve long-term economic growth, increase Europe's competitiveness, combat unemployment and increase the integration of European companies. I support calls for closer cooperation between educational institutions, businesses and civil society, especially youth organisations, in order to better adapt skills to the needs of the labour market. I support calls on Member States, regional and local authorities, together with the social partners and training providers, to adopt and implement strategies for skills development and demand forecasting. It is important that education and science providers and businesses cooperate to create certificates of qualifications that accurately identify real skills.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. Gender theory, help for sacrosanct "migrants"... And it claims to fight unemployment of "young people"?

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. At present, more than 7 million young people aged 15 to 24 are not working, studying or training. For many of them, victims of the banking and liberal crisis, the lack of skills is a structural obstacle to access to sustainable employment that will enable them to lead a life project. Extremely involved in this struggle for jobs for Farciennes, I see every day the human consequences that this can engender. I have therefore, of course, supported this report, which stresses that the development of individual skills and the dissemination of knowledge and skills are one of the components of integrated social and employment policies. It is clear that schools, training organizations and, of course, businesses must make this fight for employment a priority. But the overall socio-economic context is also essential. The Commission has launched the 'Youth Guarantee' operation, which should be highlighted.  But it cannot take back with one hand what it gives with the other and must engage in a genuine policy of recovery based on investment that will reduce unemployment and poverty and finally give millions of young Europeans prospects for the future.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Commitment to youth unemployment has always been a priority in my political activity, which is why I voted in favour of the Plura report today, which also pushes for a strengthening of the Youth guarantee.  The economic crisis has created the most serious unemployment problem in the history of the Union, affecting more than four and a half million people under the age of 25. Alongside this figure is that of the 7 million NEETs, girls and boys who are not following a training course or carrying out professional activities. This is a potentially explosive situation, with negative effects in terms of career, health and social mobility for an entire generation.  Member States, regional governments and local authorities have a duty to take action by promoting strategies for the development of professional skills and by supporting higher education to enable the acquisition of skills that are fundamental to the world of work. Youth entrepreneurship must be promoted just as the positive role played by SMEs and social and solidarity-based economic actors in terms of job creation must be enhanced. Only with the constant commitment of the institutions will it be possible to avoid the creation of a lost generation.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report aims to identify the reasons for the structural obstacles young people face in finding employment, and aims to propose solutions. While most of the content of the final report is positive, as it calls for greater support for young people in skills development and employment, including increased public investment in education and, more specifically, in the transition from school to work, these aspects in the report are mere statements of intent, and the real impact on policies will be limited. The report places an excessive emphasis on the role of entrepreneurship as a solution to reducing youth unemployment. Continued references to the need to "better adjust skills to labour market needs" and the call for closer links between educational and vocational training institutions with companies to promote such adjustment skills-labor market in our view undermine content. That is why, although I cannot be in favour of the neoliberal approach to the text, I abstained in the vote on the report so as not to block important progress and positive aspects of the report.

name: Joëlle Bergeron (EFDD)
text: In writing. I voted for this report because it is clear that the fight against youth unemployment must be the workhorse of any employment policy. But let's not delude ourselves. The banalities and truths of La Palisse, the report of which this report is full, will not provide an answer to the challenge of youth unemployment, which today reaches staggering percentages in countries such as Spain.  Europe will not be able to do anything about it. And the litany of reports that have been written on the subject will not be able to do anything about it either. Unfortunately, we see that the countries that are not members of the Union - I am thinking of Switzerland or Norway - are doing better in this area than our Member States. We should ask ourselves why. It is up to the states to make the necessary efforts to boost youth employment. Through a proactive policy in favour of SMEs, which are the largest job creators. By a policy of lowering the loads and by a training policy.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report on competition policies to combat youth unemployment. The development of individual skills and the dissemination of knowledge and skills are one of the key elements of integrated social and employment policies and can enable long-term growth to be generated, European competitiveness to be promoted, unemployment to be fought and a more inclusive European society to be built, provided that skills development policies recognise the multiple dimensions of the needs and skills of unemployed young people.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. This report to combat youth unemployment actually proposes to no longer favour diplomas but rather to promote skills. This in fact reflects and endorses the failure of national education systems.  However, interesting avenues are envisaged, such as encouraging alternation or learning, anticipating the skills needs of the promising sectors or encouraging orientation from an early age. But no practical or concrete aspects, just proposals.  On the other hand, in a context of austerity wanted by the Union, I am rather of the opinion that employment policies must be carried out at regional and local level and not in Europe. The idea of developing youth entrepreneurship is certainly laudable, but nothing concrete is proposed and it comes up regularly, as if to keep young people busy.  So I decided to vote against this report.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. Unemployment, especially youth unemployment, is a tragedy that is increasingly affecting our territories. 40% of our young people are out of work and the cause is not only the economic crisis, but also the crazy policies that this Europe has implemented in recent years. Although I agree with some of the passages in this text, I absolutely cannot agree with the call for the competences of the Member States to be transferred to the Commission with regard to identifying and defining the needs in terms of professional skills in the labour market, which we have already granted too much, we must not grant more. For these reasons, I abstained.

name: Malin Björk (GUE/NGL)
text: Written. I've abstained. With youth unemployment in the EU at 21.4%, strong measures and new economic thinking are needed that emphasise public green investment for new jobs and a developed welfare sector. This report does not advocate such a new policy, but emphasises, above all, individual skills development and the promotion of entrepreneurship. At the same time, however, I note the improvements that have been made during the committee work on the report, which now places better emphasis on the rights of young people in the labour market. That's why I choose to abstain.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. U2012 After long years of crisis, Europe has not been able to stop the drama of youth unemployment. Despite the launch by the Union institutions of initiatives such as the Youth Guarantee or the Youth Employment Initiative, it is urgent to tackle this drama from all fronts so as not to thwart the opportunities of an entire generation of young Europeans. Of course, active employment policies have a role to play in helping to solve this problem. As this report points out, the learning, acquisition and recognition of skills and skills by young people, whether they are studying, working or in an unemployment or non-activity situation, plays a key role both in dealing with faster and more stable integration into the labour market, as well as in improving the transition between studies and work and the quality of jobs and careers to be developed by younger generations of our society. For all this, I voted in favour.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report, in which the European Parliament is looking for solutions to combat high youth unemployment in Europe. The high-level youth unemployment rate in our time is one of the biggest problems in the EU, where almost 5 million people are unemployed. young people are unemployed. At the same time, there are 2 million people who are in the eu-25. Vacancies. This situation poses a serious threat to the EU's social cohesion and economic development. When discussing this situation, the following factors should be taken into account: globalisation, demographic change, economic crises, new technologies and changes in work organisation. Business creation and self-employment are also an opportunity to participate in the labour market. Skill building is a multifaceted process that requires a holistic approach and a cross-border shift in sectoral policies. Changes in the labour market require more flexible education systems that enable them to complement and develop knowledge and skills at all stages of their professional careers. Access to the labour market and work continues to consist of two types of skills: general skills (adaptability, learning to learn, initiative and entrepreneurship, communication skills) and specific skills related to specific positions or work. Differences in the labour markets of the Member States also require the identification of the level of management to identify and define the most effective means of identifying and defining skills needs.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. After the end of the economic crisis, Europe is turning to growth again, which is certainly worth welcoming. Economic indicators show moderate optimism, and unemployment is slowly decreasing. However, unfortunately, what we are seeing is too slow, especially in the youth unemployment, which is still extremely high and worrying. There are still almost five million young people out of work from the EU. Solutions to reduce youth unemployment will not come overnight, as the causes of this are multifaceted and complex. One of the reasons is education systems, which are quite rigid in many Member States and do not reflect the labour market situation.  In Slovenia, this is undoubtedly the case, as is reflected in the problem highlighted by the report - on the one hand, high youth unemployment, on the other hand, vacancies. Therefore, in my opinion, it is crucial to tackle youth unemployment properly in reforming education systems and adapting them to a dynamic environment. We need more interdisciplinary skills, the transfer of entrepreneurial skills, the acquisition of practical experience during schooling, etc. At the same time, educational institutions also need to be more quickly linked to the economic sector, especially in countries with less developed vocational education systems.  I strongly agree with the initiatives put in progress by the proposed report, which is why I supported it.

name: Simona Bonafè (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The worrying level of youth unemployment is now a major challenge for the EU, which has around five million young people out of work. In addition to the lack of employment, however, we have to consider that there are about two million jobs vacant.  It is therefore clear that we are faced with a twofold problem: low employment on the one hand and mismatch between the skills of young people and those demanded by the market on the other. This context causes enormous economic and social damage to Europe. Promoting integration and employability in the labour market requires more ambitious actions and investment, as well as more targeted involvement and cooperation between Member States.
