In addition, in order to anticipate future skills demands, it will be essential to include all labour market players at all levels, by adapting school and vocational training more effectively to labour market demands. This text, which I wholeheartedly support, goes in precisely this direction.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. Most of the measures proposed in this report are difficult to implement in the current context, where Member States are forced to adopt limited budgets. On the other hand, it is clear that policies for the integration of young people must be carried out first at the regional and local level and not at the European level. I voted against it.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this document because I believe that youth unemployment is one of the worst scourges afflicting our continent and should therefore be eradicated.  It is the task of the EU and its institutions to find solutions to support the employment of a generation which, although possessing more expertise than previous generations, suffers terribly from the current economic situation. The medium to long-term future of the European economy itself depends on this.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 At the end of 2014, the EU had an average youth unemployment rate of 21.4%, or more than 7 million young people in employment. However, on the same date, 2 million jobs were vacant in the EU. This figure highlights the need to improve the link between the world of training and the world of work, to develop more flexible and interdisciplinary skills.  Cooperation, participation and partnerships are the means to open a constructive relationship with SMEs and the multifaceted European business reality and to loosen the current administrative and financial constraints relating to the start-up of new business activities, through the simplification of procedures, easy access to credit, risk capital and microfinance, guaranteed high-speed Internet connections, tailor-made multidisciplinary advice and the introduction of , where possible, incentive measures for entrepreneurs hiring unemployed young people.  It is clear how important microfinance and the European Programme for Employment and Social Innovation (EaSI) play in achieving full youth employment. Only by improving the training path and creating a network of one-stop shops where we can carry out all the administrative procedures necessary for setting up and running a business will we be able to raise the rate of youth entrepreneurship in the short term.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. This report attempts to find solutions to the structural unemployment of young people. The central idea of the text is to promote skills rather than diplomas, reflecting the failure of education systems in the Member States of the European Union. In addition, the avenues envisaged in this text are to promote learning as well as alternating training from an early age. In addition, this report promotes entrepreneurial initiatives for young graduates. The rapporteur also wants to adapt training to the needs of businesses. Although these ideas are a good idea, we consider that the Member States of the Union are the most competent in solving structural unemployment among 18-25 year olds. Promoting entrepreneurship, as this report recommends, can be effective only if it is not used as a pretext to remove the unemployed from national statistics. So I voted against this report.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 4.5 million young people in the European Union aged 15 to 24 are not currently unemployed and 7 million young Europeans are neither in employment nor are they in education or vocational training. These figures lead us to act as quickly as possible to reduce the extremely large number of young people who do not work in the labour market.  All necessary efforts should be made by the authorities to ensure that education systems properly prepare students in order to achieve their professional skills and to ensure close cooperation between representatives of the education and social services sector and between employers and pupils/students.  In order to reduce unemployment, effective policies on education, training and skills development are needed, with the support of employers, employment agencies and other stakeholders. I voted in favour of this report because investing in entrepreneurship education is one of the most cost-effective investments the European Union can make.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Abstention. The most effective way to reduce unemployment, including youth unemployment, is to return to domestic demand-oriented economic policies: more domestic demand = our businesses increase output = more employment = more income = more domestic demand, and so on in a virtuous cycle that is the opposite of the current one imposed by the EU. Not only is there no trace of this in the report, but it also envisages, as the most effective solution, the transfer of competences from the Member States to the Commission with regard to the identification and definition of professional skills requirements in the labour market.

name: Cristian-Silviu Buşoi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 At the end of 2014, the Union unemployment rate was 9.9%, while among young people it reached 21.4%, with young people being the most affected by the crisis. Although they have higher education and skills than those held by previous generations, young people face significant structural obstacles when trying to get quality jobs (according to European and national standards).  The mismatch between education and training is a major cause of youth unemployment. The EU currently has 4.5 million unemployed young people (aged 15 to 24) and more than 7 million young Europeans are not in the labour market or are not in education or vocational training. I support the EP's motion for a resolution on skills development policies to combat youth unemployment, because the existence of the alarmingly high level of youth unemployment at the same time as the existence of two million vacancies in the EU creates a situation that seriously threatens social cohesion and the ECONOMIC development of the EU.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. The economic and financial crisis of 2008 had a terrible impact on employment in the European Union and around the world. Unemployment affects a great deal of our citizens and the progress made in reducing the unemployment rate is not fast enough or effective enough.  Young people are the first victims of this conflict. In the European Union, 4.5 million young people aged 15 to 25 are unemployed and more than 7 million do not work or study. This situation can no longer last. On the one hand, we must implement the policies of growth, competitiveness and job creation that we have developed at European level and on the other, Member States must implement effective social policies. I would like to point out that many European funds can be used for employment assistance for young people and must therefore be used fully in this regard.  I voted in favour of this report.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report on skills policies to combat youth unemployment.  The numbers speak for themselves: currently 4.5 million young people aged between 15 and 24 in the European Union are unemployed and more than 7 million young Europeans in this age group do not work or attend education or training courses. These figures show us how serious the situation is and that, unfortunately, it is precisely young people who have been particularly affected by the crisis.  I believe that a Europe incapable of guaranteeing a prosperous future for its young people is a Europe with no future. Member States, regional governments and local authorities therefore implement strategies for the development and foresight of skills, which are key elements of integrated employment and social policies that can help combat unemployment and build a more inclusive European society. In addition, the youth employment initiative needs to be improved in order to facilitate the implementation of this important initiative. The report contains these elements and I have therefore voted in favour of it.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution primarily for the reason that it calls for the removal of barriers such as education fees for apprentices. This is particularly relevant for Ireland where the government has implemented successive budget cuts for apprenticeships and are forcing apprentices to pay fees in order to gain a qualification.  I am happy that my Sinn Féin colleagues and I managed to include this important call into the final resolution and hope that it will help in putting pressure on those in power to abolish fees for apprentices.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non legislative and non-binding report. The report called for the EU to spend more money to spread information on European financing instruments. UKIP opposes the EU spending taxpayer’s money especially to put out such propaganda. There was a call to create an EU award for the best project that combats youth employment – this would be a complete waste of money and nothing more than a vanity project for the EU. It called for Member States to follow EU country-specific recommendations. It also wanted the EU to interfere with Member States’ education and national curriculum, suggesting what subjects should be taught – the EU has no competence in this area. It also called for more money and support for mobility programmes such as Erasmus which advertises British jobs across the EU. UKIP is the only party against open door immigration and will protect British jobs. The only people that should decide any of these things are our elected and accountable government, not unelected bureaucrats in Brussels.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report as it is a good analysis of the current situation of youth in Europe and it points out promising ideas that should help us tackle the youth unemployment. It rightly notes that there are still almost 5 million unemployed young people but at the same time there are 2 million unfilled vacancies. The report emphasises the importance of education (whether higher or vocational) and calls for a cooperation between the Member States and sharing of good practices.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I could only vote in favour of this report on skills policies to combat youth unemployment, one of the greatest scourges of our society and one of the main challenges of the EU.  The report stresses the importance of having more flexible education systems that allow the integration and development of knowledge and skills at all stages of the professional career. It also underlines the key role played by businesses, including SMEs, social and solidarity economy actors as well as micro-enterprises in training skills and job creation for young people, and highlights the need to provide young people with an education that prepares them for entrepreneurship as widely as possible.  A number of our amendments have also been adopted and incorporated into the text. These include the important role that European funds can play when used more efficiently and strategically; the importance of high-quality training in the workplace and not exploiting trainees as a precarious, low-cost workforce; effective implementation of the youth guarantee, which can thus help to improve the employability of young people and can offer valuable work experiences.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 In the light of worrying data on youth unemployment in the Member States, which in some Member States is reaching alarming percentages, Europe needs to support the development of the new skills required by the current labour market. Member States' education systems need to adapt to these new developments through more effective training that integrates, for example, new technologies into the learning process or, also, that allows the development of transversal skills and in line with the objectives set by the Europe 2020 strategy. It is therefore a priority to invest in educational models that also associate theoretical and practical learning with theoretical learning for a smoother transition from the world of education to integration into the working world. Dealing with unemployment in Europe must be the priority for the coming years. An ageing Europe cannot afford to 'waste' the talents and competences of its young people and, in this regard, I hope that the Dutch Presidency will do everything possible to support young people and future generations. I voted in favour of this own-initiative report because it identifies the new training needs required by the labour market which will guarantee greater employment opportunities for young Europeans.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 We are in favour of the report because we believe that youth unemployment, rising to such alarming levels, is nowadays one of the most intractable problems in the EU, where there are around five million unemployed and, at the same time, two million vacancies. This situation poses a serious threat to the EU's social cohesion and economic development. The report stresses that the Commission's main priority is to give a 'new impetus to employment, growth and investment' and recalls that, in its 2015 work programme, the Commission committed itself to taking initiatives to promote integration and employability in the labour market by taking measures to support Member States in their efforts to vocationally rehabilitate young people. We must also reiterate that Parliament has regularly proposed different solutions, because it believes that youth employment, education and training must be one of the main political priorities for the EU.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 We discussed today the issue of youth unemployment and the possibilities available to combat it through the activation of YEI. Such initiatives do indeed contain positive elements that can help to combat the problem in the long term. However, we must admit that the root cause of youth unemployment is neither highlighted nor combated by half measures. It is our duty to seek and implement those policies that will give a new impetus to the European economy, helping young people to integrate more smoothly into the production process. So since today's resolution does not provide for these actions, I do not think it offers anything new and that is why I have decided to abstain.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I have chosen to support this measure. The alarming level of youth unemployment is now one of the EU's main challenges, with almost 5 million young people out of work. This situation poses a serious threat to the EU's social cohesion and economic development.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In drafting this report, Marek Plura has done an excellent job. He was good at emphasising how the revival of employment must go through the exploitation of skills, because the days of the generalists are over and everyone must create value through what they do best.  The key to a modern labour market is in skills, it is in knowledge, and the well-being of my land is a glaring example of this: good farmers, imaginative artisans, visionary industrialists have been able to exploit their respective potential and realize them by giving work to their family and employees, and creating what was not there. Congratulations to the rapporteur.

name: David Coburn (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non legislative and non-binding report. The report called for the EU to spend more money to spread information on European financing instruments. UKIP opposes the EU spending taxpayer’s money especially to put out such propaganda. There was a call to create an EU award for the best project that combats youth employment – this would be a complete waste of money and nothing more than a vanity project for the EU. It called for Member States to follow EU country-specific recommendations. It also wanted the EU to interfere with Member States’ education and national curriculum, suggesting what subjects should be taught – the EU has no competence in this area. It also called for more money and support for mobility programmes such as Erasmus which advertises British jobs across the EU. UKIP is the only party against open door immigration and will protect British jobs. The only people that should decide any of these things are our elected and accountable government, not unelected bureaucrats in Brussels.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Despite the measures that have been taken at both EU and Member State level, youth unemployment is still one of the current problems that Europe is currently face, with an estimated five million young people unemployed. Entry into the labour market and stay in a job are determined by two dimensions of skills: the essential ones (adaptability, ability to learn to learn, spirit of initiative and entrepreneurship, communication capacity) and specific skills related to certain jobs or jobs.   I support the report, which sets out a set of policies to be initiated on education, training to reduce youth unemployment, establishpartnerships with employers and local and regional entities.

name: Birgit Collin-Langen (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report because, unfortunately, the EU's measures to limit youth unemployment so far are not as successful as we have promised. This report stresses the need to adapt education systems to the needs of the labour market. I support this demand, and there is an urgent need to continue to influence the Member States to call up the funds made available and to use them effectively.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 It is now well known that the level of youth unemployment is one of the european Union's major challenges today.   In order to respond adequately to this problem, a number of phenomena must be taken into account, including globalisation, demographic changes, new technologies and modern work organisation. In this sense, education systems should be more flexible and in line with the needs of young people to enter the labour market with a well-established background of knowledge and skills. To do this, it is necessary that whatever path the young person takes is able to provide him with the basis to be a valid candidate for the positions related to his abilities.   Given that young people are the primary resource for the future of the Union, and that these initiatives will promote social cohesion, I have decided to vote in favour of the resolution.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Skills gap and skills/job mismatch have been identified as two of the main causes of youth unemployment. These represent situations whereby youths do not possess the skills required by industry, or where youths are over qualified for the jobs available. This raises a number of questions about the education systems being followed in Member States, including whether education and industry should be considered partners in education, and which skills students need besides subject and thematic knowledge. Entrepreneurship skills and vocational training have often been identified as tools to bridge the skills gap.  I have voted in favour of this report.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The alarming level of youth unemployment is now one of the EU's main challenges.  The report stresses the importance of having more flexible education systems, enabling the integration and development of knowledge and skills at all stages of the professional career. Underlines the key role played by businesses, including SMEs, social and solidarity economy actors, as well as micro-enterprises in training skills and creating jobs for young people; highlights the need to provide young people with an education that prepares them for entrepreneurship as widely as possible.  It notes the important role that European funds can play when used more efficiently and strategically as an important tool for the growth and development of universities and businesses. It also stresses the importance of high-quality training in the workplace and the importance of not exploiting trainees as a precarious and low-cost workforce. It stresses the need to simplify the administrative procedures for implementing the guarantee for young people, to assess their real employment needs and real areas of employment development, and the urgent need to remove any bureaucratic obstacles that might limit their effectiveness. I am therefore voting in favour.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I have not been able to vote in favour of this report, since although it does a good X-ray of the drama of youth unemployment in EU member countries, the recipes for addressing it are by no means appropriate to do so in my view. Instead of promoting the creation of public, stable and quality employment for young people, it proposes to encourage entrepreneurs and focus training towards market needs. That's why I abstained.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report helps to raise awareness of the continuing high levels of youth unemployment as one of the most difficult problems for the Union.  The current recovery has not, in itself, proved capable of reversing the trend and has shown the need for policy responses to better adapt skills to the needs of the labour market. Tackling youth unemployment remains a top priority; we run the risk of burning an entire generation of girls and boys with high-level profiles and curricula which, beyond all other considerations, represent added value for Europe that cannot be wasted.  The Youth Guarantee initiative has not borne fruit, because it lacks adequate resources and, above all, a 'European' strategic plan. But that is where we need to start again, strengthening it and correcting the mistakes and mechanisms that have not worked. Europe will only be a better place if there are real opportunities for growth and fulfilment for all young people.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. Youth unemployment is one of the EU's most significant problems. There are currently 5 million young people unemployed, while there are 2 million vacancies. Youth unemployment is generally more sensitive to economic conditions than general unemployment due to the less experience of young people. The parliamentary report adopted today, which I voted in favour of, makes proposals to combat youth unemployment. Among other things, changes in the labour market require a much more flexible education system. The implementation of effective education, training and skills development policies with the support of employers, employment agencies and other relevant stakeholders can make a significant contribution to reducing youth unemployment. Furthermore, it is necessary to link higher education institutions to the economic sector and to provide adequate training for recruiters, human resources managers, employment service providers, employers and workers in the education sector. The report also points out that a solution can be taken to increase young people's entrepreneurship, but this requires promoting entrepreneurship, which is the responsibility of public bodies, the education system, businesses and civil society. Finally, due to the differences in member states' labour markets, it is necessary to identify which level of governance has the most effective means of identifying and describing the necessary skills.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 5 million young people out of work and at the same time 2 million vacancies are one of the biggest challenges in the EU. The report clearly shows skills development as a multidimensional process requiring a holistic approach and more flexible education systems that enable knowledge to be deepened and skills to develop at all stages of the career. In view of the differences between Member States' labour markets, it is necessary to determine which level of management is equipped with the most effective instruments to identify and describe skills needs.  The report also calls for the promotion of best practices and for support for the integration of young people with disabilities in the field of education and employment through investment in social entrepreneurship or financial incentives for the organisations that employ them. It was also underlined that labour offices should more actively remove physical obstacles to access to their services by persons with disabilities. Young people without a job perspective are one of the EU's biggest ills and challenges – that is why I voted in favour of the document.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This report raises awareness on the high level of youth unemployment in the EU, since this causes a serious threat for the social cohesion and economic development of the EU. Further strengthening and the proper implementation of the Youth Guarantee and the Youth Employment initiative will help to tackle this problem, but so much more needs to be done. Better adaptation of skills to the labour market through meaningful training will improve employability and job stability and I believe that we need to train our young people to meet the job demands that are created in the EU. For these reasons I voted in favour of this report.

name: Daniel Dalton (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ This report recognises that due to high levels of youth unemployment in many parts of Europe innovative measures need to be taken to bridge the growing skills mismatch, something which the UK government has recognised since 2010. I welcome this report’s call for promotion of best practices and its support for the inclusion of young people with disabilities in education and employment. Importantly this report also clearly recognises the principle of subsidiarity. For all of these reasons I am happy to support this report.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Europe is currently facing a contradictory situation: statistical data show that there are around five million unemployed young people and two million vacancies, which poses a serious threat to the EU's social cohesion and economic development.  On the other hand, we must not forget that the generations of young people who grew up in an age of rapid technological advances have not only potential, talents and skills, but also values and priorities different from those of previous generations. Young people's entry into the labour market, but also the retention of a job, are closely linked to two dimensions: key skills (adaptability, ability to learn how to learn, initiative and entrepreneurship, communication) and specific skills related to specific jobs or jobs.  As such, I believe that there is a need for programmes and initiatives at European level that create a bridge between generations, openness to change, well-trained recruitment and employment services with the right skills to understand the new generation.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This initiative report is part of the Policy for Skills Development to Combat Youth Unemployment. I am convinced that our education system should better meet the needs of the labour market. Young people are a very receptive audience to new technologies that are revolutionizing our ways of life, producing and consuming. The mastery and understanding of digital media, the internet or social networks are clear examples. I am convinced that these assets represent a real added value within a company. Improving the employability of young people therefore requires the development of useful skills, through teaching and, let us not forget, continuing vocational training. Business creation and self-employment are also part of the solutions. Fully sharing the objectives of this report, I have spoken in favour.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported this report, which aims to adapt education systems to the needs of the labour market in order to combat youth unemployment in the European Union. The current situation, namely that 4.5 million young people aged 15 to 24 are currently unemployed in Europe, calls for urgent concrete measures.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. Skills Development Policies to Combat Youth Unemployment Youth unemployment among young Europeans has soared since 2008, from 14.7% to 21.4% today, representing 4.5 million young people aged 15 to 24. Although employment is mainly the responsibility of eu Member States, there is an urgent need to combine all efforts and initiatives aimed at combating youth unemployment and reducing the number of 'drop-offs' in the school system.  Several areas are concerned: certification of diplomas, validation of learning during time spent abroad, harmonization of national regulations for apprenticeships and insurance schemes.

name: Angélique Delahaye (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the Plura report on skills development policies to tackle youth unemployment. I the well-deal with the adoption of this report, which stresses that education systems should be more flexible to complement knowledge and skills at all stages of the professional career, in order to meet the needs of the labour market and to deal with a worrying youth unemployment rate. I also believe that business creation and self-employment are other ways to participate in the labour market.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The european parliament's decision adopted focuses on youth unemployment (Hungary higher than the EU average (22%) 1.5% better) and aims to give the European Union an even more effective response so that nearly half a million young people in Hungary can find jobs as soon as possible in a Europe with only two million vacancies. The decision fits the trend that the Union has finally recognised that the situation of the nearly 12 million European citizens who have been out of work for a long time must also be addressed, and that young people are particularly disadvantaged because they have either no or little experience or modern knowledge. The report basically mentions two dimensions of capabilities: the need to strengthen so-called core skills and to continue to specialise in competitive knowledge. It also emphasises the responsibility of economic life and the business-financial sector. Youth unemployment is also a challenge in terms of starting a family, not to mention the increasing challenges of competitive competences (IT skills, start-ups, etc.) in training systems, which must respond and adapt to market requirements and development, in line with local and regional specificities. With my vote, I followed the People's Party position by saying that the principle of subsidiarity is fundamental and the efforts of the Member States are indispensable.

name: Jean-Paul Denanot (S&D)
text: In writing. It is a balanced and comprehensive report on the issue of youth unemployment or how to successfully implement effective policies for the next generation.  First, there is the observation of a mismatch between the proposed school and vocational training and the realities of the labour market. There is also the quality of the orientation systems of the individual Member States which is being singled out. Similarly, the report highlights the lack of anticipation about future trades when cooperation between business leaders, trades and governments , particularly at the employment pools level, should have been organised and systematized to prepare young people for the jobs of tomorrow. The issue of youth entrepreneurship is not forgotten in the context of possible opportunities. Finally, there is - without being exhaustive - the issue of digital. If not all trades fall within this sector, all will be transformed. This increase in support must be prioritized in the political agenda.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. Youth unemployment is a dramatic phenomenon for the vitality of European nations and tends to become a structural element of our economies. However, this report does not address the root causes of the problem and does not propose reform of the Union's economic frameworks, which have a major influence on macroeconomic trends. Worse, it tries to insert harmful elements far removed from reality, such as gender theory, and seeks to favour migrants.  Finally, the European Union is not intended to change the parameters of labour markets and Member States. Any strengthening of the internal market would be a serious factor in social imbalances.  Regretting the lack of lucidity of the rapporteur and my parliamentary colleagues on this issue, I voted against this report.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the report on policy in support of skills acquisition in order to combat youth unemployment. I believe that it offers adequate and enforceable measures to help tackle this serious problem in practice. I represent a Member State where the problem of youth unemployment is extremely serious. A large part of the young population is forced to leave the state because of a lack of sufficient realization options, which leads to a decrease in the potential of the state. I agree with the proposals made in the report and believe that, given the differences in labour markets in the Member States, the exchange of good practices is a step in the right direction.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 Alarming levels of youth unemployment are nowadays one of the most intractable problems in the EU. Unfortunately, however, the ways in which the political initiatives to combat youth unemployment presented in the report do not agree with me. Firstly, the report argues that a primary factor in solving the problem to be taken into account is globalisation. The report then argues that trade unions play an important role and a beneficial role in young civil society . Finally, it insists on the usefulness of traineeships or apprenticeships abroad and supports EURES and Erasmus+.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Parliament resolution adopted today focuses on youth unemployment (Hungary higher than the EU average (22%) 1.5% better) and aims to give the European Union an even more effective response so that nearly half a million young people in Hungary can find jobs as soon as possible in a Europe with only two million vacancies. The decision fits the trend that the Union has finally recognised that the situation of the nearly 12 million European citizens who have been out of work for a long time must also be addressed, and that young people are particularly disadvantaged because they have either no or little experience or modern knowledge. The report basically mentions two dimensions of capabilities: the need to strengthen general so-called basic skills and to continue to specialise in competitive knowledge. It also emphasises the responsibility of economic life and the business-financial sector. Youth unemployment is also a challenge in terms of starting a family, not to mention the increasing challenges of competitive competences (IT skills, start-ups, etc.) in training systems, which must respond and adapt to market requirements and development, in line with local and regional specificities. With my vote, I followed the People's Party position by saying that the principle of subsidiarity is fundamental and the efforts of the Member States are indispensable.

name: Rosa Estaràs Ferragut (PPE)
text: in writing. This is 24 million jobless people in Europe, of whom 7.5 million are young people who do not work or study, there are about two million vacant positions in the EU. In addition, there are many skilled and unemployed young people whose skills do not match labour demand. To correct these mismatches, strong partnerships need to be built between the authorities in education, employment and services, the social partners and the business community in order to support the creation of action plans and strategies for quality employment. This report expresses the need for more flexible education systems to gain knowledge and skills at all stages of the career to meet labour market needs and youth unemployment. It also underlines the creation of businesses and self-employment as an opportunity for participation in the labour market, the importance of internships, the need to incorporate new technologies into the learning process, a better qualification of public employment agencies, as well as the efficient use of European funds by Member States.

name: Eleonora Evi (EFDD)
text: in writing. Youth unemployment is the biggest challenge facing the EU and, in particular, the Southern European Member States.  In addition, there are approximately two million jobs in the Union. This phenomenon threatens European social cohesion and it is therefore vital, not only to combat early school leaving, to overcome austerity policies. The Plura report identifies 'flexible' education systems, which allow the constant development of skills and knowledge throughout the professional career, as a way of combating unemployment.  We have stressed that European funds can be a useful element for the growth and development of universities and businesses, and we have called for more financial resources to inform the public about the instruments available. At the same time, however, we need monitoring and monitoring of the actual use of these resources, which were then incorporated into the report. I voted in favour.

name: Fredrick Federley (ALDE)
text: Written. 'Reducing youth unemployment in Europe is absolutely essential. The fact that millions of young people are excluded from the labour market is harmful in several ways. On the one hand, it is harmful to the economies of the Member States, with a large number of able-bodied people who are excluded from the labour market, and, on the other hand, it is harmful to companies that fail to recruit new and skilled workers, but above all it is harmful to young people themselves who are getting off to a worse start in life. This report therefore highlights a number of good things about, among other things, the need to bring the labour market and education closer together. Voting in favour of the report was obvious to me, but I voted against introducing a price for projects that are good in terms of combating unemployment. I do not believe that this is the role of the European Union and I am convinced that the Member States value more getting young people into work than to receive a prize.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. The high level of youth unemployment is currently one of the most pressing problems in the EU, with almost five million young people unemployed. At the same time, there are around two million unfilled jobs in the EU every day. To discuss this issue, the following factors need to be taken into account: globalisation, demographic change, the economic crisis, new technologies and changes in the organisation of work. Business creation and self-employed work are also an opportunity to participate in the labour market. Market entry and stay in a job are determined by two dimensions of skills: key skills (adaptability, ability to learn to learn, spirit of initiative and entrepreneurship, communication skills) and specific skills related to certain jobs or jobs. Due to differences in member states' labour markets, it is still necessary to determine the level of governance that has the most effective tools to identify and describe skills needs.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I abstained on this report because the proposals in it are, on the whole, too vague.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The report reflects on the unemployment figures that have bequeathed the European Union, focusing mainly on youth unemployment. Unemployment, in average terms, in the EU was 9.9% in 2014 (in Portugal it was around 20%), with youth unemployment at 21.4%, and in the most affected countries, such as Portugal, it was above 30%.  The report proposes measures to combat youth unemployment. There are positive aspects, such as the defence of increased qualifications, the criticism of the increase in the costs of attendance of the various degrees of education, the valorisation of local economies and traditional know-how, the affirmation of a holistic education (against the trend of specialisation), the reference to the exploitation of trainees, the defence of the fight against some forms of discrimination. However, there are also negative aspects, especially the defense of the adaptation of curricula, the programmes and the educational/training offer to the needs of the "labour market"; the overvaluation of "entrepreneurship", with the defense of its inclusion in school programs and the affirmation of mobility as a response to the problems of youth unemployment. The solution to youth unemployment is to break with the policies that have been imposed on us and break with those who impose them. This depends on the present and the future of young people.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on skills policies to combat youth unemployment. It is vital for the European Union to promote new impetus for employment, growth and investment by supporting The Member States in getting young people into the world of work. In particular, we must promote a smooth transition from education to work, linking theoretical education with practical training and ensuring the acquisition of social security rights by workers, who must under no circumstances be exploited. I believe it is important for the Member States to renewed share good practice, including through the development of monitoring and forecasting instruments in the field of work.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ As the ECB forces Ireland to borrow to burn it it is not possible to take this report seriously. These billions should be invested in creating youth employment instead of feeding the banking monster. I voted against.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: writing \ u2012 Tackling youth unemployment remains a top priority if Europe does not want to risk losing an entire young generation. The first step must be to further strengthen and properly implement the Youth and Youth Employment Initiative Guarantee. There is a need to increase the positive long-term benefits of the opportunities offered to young people, namely through meaningful training that will improve their employability and help to create stable jobs. Europe will be a better place if equal opportunities become a reality for all young people in Europe.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 Alarming levels of youth unemployment are nowadays one of the most intractable problems in the EU. Unfortunately, however, the ways in which political arrangements and initiatives are formulated to combat youth unemployment presented in the report do not agree with me. Firstly, it is argued in the report that a primary factor in solving the problem to be taken into account is globalisation. It is also argued that the role played in youth civil society by trade unions is important. Internships or apprenticeships abroad are also persistently advertised and the supposed usefulness of EURES and Erasmus+ is highlighted. Finally, the existence of NGOs as a means and tool to promote entrepreneurship is underlined and highlighted. For the above reasons, I am voting against this report in its entirety.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ It is about time to raise awareness about the high levels of youth unemployment as one of the most challenging problems in the European Union and on the need to develop policy responses, which can better adapt skills to labour market needs, as a way to reduce it. I support the important progressive proposals included in the report, mainly referring to the quality of job offers and internships and traineeships, the support of education systems and dual training systems, the value of education and training as a fundamental right. Tackling youth unemployment has to be a top priority if Europe does not want to risk losing a whole generation. A first step must be the further strengthening and proper implementation of the Youth Guarantee and the Youth Employment Initiative. It is fundamental to improve the positive long-term benefits of the opportunities offered to young people, concretely through meaningful training courses that improve their employability, and stable jobs. Europe will be a better place if we make equal opportunities a reality for all young people in Europe.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Parliament resolution adopted today focuses on youth unemployment (Hungary higher than the EU average (22%) 1.5% better) and aims to give the European Union an even more effective response so that nearly half a million young people in Hungary can find jobs as soon as possible in a Europe with only two million vacancies. The decision fits the trend that the Union has finally recognised that the situation of the nearly 12 million European citizens who have been out of work for a long time must also be addressed, and that young people are particularly disadvantaged because they have either no or little experience or modern knowledge. The report basically mentions two dimensions of capabilities: the need to strengthen general so-called basic skills and to continue to specialise in competitive knowledge. It also emphasises the responsibility of economic life and the business-financial sector. Youth unemployment is also a challenge in terms of starting a family, not to mention the increasing challenges of competitive competences (IT skills, start-ups, etc.) in training systems, which must respond and adapt to market requirements and development, in line with local and regional specificities. With my vote, I followed the People's Party position by saying that the principle of subsidiarity is fundamental and the efforts of the Member States are indispensable.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Alarmingly high youth unemployment is one of the EU's most serious problems, with 5 million unemployed young people. At the same time, there are 2 million vacancies. This situation poses a serious risk to social cohesion and economic development in the EU.  In my opinion, when discussing the situation, the following factors should be taken into account: globalisation, demographic change, economic crisis, new technologies and changes in the organisation of work. The founding of new businesses and self-employment also provide opportunities to participate in the labour market.  Changes in the labour market require more flexible education systems that enable knowledge and skills to be complemented and developed at all stages of a professional career. Two dimensions of skills enable access to the labour market and the maintenance of employment: key competences (adaptability, learning to learn, initiative and entrepreneurship, communication) and specific skills related to specific jobs or jobs.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour with the intention of providing solutions to the alarming level of youth unemployment, with almost 15 million young unemployed people. This poses a serious threat to the EU's social cohesion and economic development. More flexible teaching systems are needed to complement and develop knowledge and skills at all stages of the career to better adapt to a changing labour market. At the same time, it is necessary to link higher education institutions with the economic sector.

name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Youth unemployment is still one of the most worrying situations for the European Union today. This is a situation that threatens the future of millions of young people and their families. With this report we have taken into account the structural obstacles preventing young people from having access to the labour market, identifying the need for a holistic approach that overcomes the ineffective structural policies of the past.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 In order to accelerate and overcome the contingency of the economic crisis, Europe needs to implement all the medium and long-term financial measures and political strategies that the particularly delicate historical moment requires.  But to imagine concrete growth for our future is first and foremost to reduce the rate of unemployment of our young people: 7 million young people who are not employed or students is unacceptable, and even more so if analyses tell us that there are currently 2 million vacancies in Europe. It means that at present there is no organic and intelligent management of supply and demand in the field of work and even before that training, generating hyper-qualified young people for already saturated channels and large live and receptive sectors destined to suffer from labour shortages. It is a paradox that we must put an immediate end to. Only by giving our young people easier and more democratic access to the world of work can we think of a real acceleration of the European machine in terms of competitiveness, development and new business horizons. I therefore consider it important to support this report, stressing above all the urgent need for a new philosophy of school education: forward-looking, multidisciplinary and closely related to the landscape and needs of the professional network.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted today in favour of the report on education and training policies to reduce youth unemployment. As an MEP from the German Family Party, I would like to draw particular attention to one target group: young mothers. Their concerns, when it comes to starting or returning to the labour market, must be promoted by a special "skill policy" that also sees, recognises and makes cross-border comparable the skills that mothers and fathers acquire in parenting time.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. Within Europe, there is a significant discrepancy between regions characterised by high youth unemployment and other regions with only a small proportion of young unemployed. If social and economic cohesion in Europe is to remain in place in the future, this problem must be tackled consistently.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report as youth unemployment risks creating a lost generation. It is simply vital that young people have access to the required skills in today’s labour market. However, the UK Government needs to boost jobs, growth and investment to ensure that there are quality, stable jobs for young people.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report aims to identify the reasons for the structural obstacles young people face in finding employment, and aims to propose solutions. While most of the content of the final report is positive, as it calls for greater support for young people in skills development and employment, including increased public investment in education and, more specifically, in the transition from school to work, these aspects in the report are mere statements of intent, and the real impact on policies will be limited. The report places an excessive emphasis on the role of entrepreneurship as a solution to reducing youth unemployment. Continued references to the need to "better adjust skills to labour market needs" and the call for closer links between educational and vocational training institutions with companies to promote such adjustment skills-labor market in our view undermine content. That is why, although I cannot be in favour of the neoliberal approach to the text, I abstained in the vote on the report so as not to block important progress and positive aspects of the report.

name: Beata Gosiewska (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The development of skills at all stages of a career is essential nowadays for obtaining appropriate employment. Any changes in the education process should be adapted to current labour market needs. I support skills acquisition strategies to combat youth unemployment. In particular, any attempt to improve science programmes, as well as to promote the integration of young people with disabilities in the field of education and employment, is, in my opinion, essential in combating youth unemployment.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Combating youth unemployment should not remain a slogan.  I think it is important that investments are directed towards the vocational development of young people and that young people are educated through education systems harmonised with the requirements of the market, of the real economy. Planning vocational education and training is vital for reducing youth unemployment, just as it is important to develop innovative small and medium-sized enterprises that can provide jobs.  I appreciate the report because it stresses the importance of cross-sectoral cooperation and because it stresses the importance of developing jobs on the basis of traditional products, through trades and professions that include traditional and cultural elements. Member States and the Commission must check the efficiency of expenditure in education and training.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I, alongside my fellow Labour MEPs, voted in favour of the report on skills policies for fighting youth unemployment. Across Europe some 4.5 million young people find themselves unemployed. In the North West the figure stands at 68 000, that is 13% of all young people in our region, unable to find work. It is now more important than ever that we tackle this issue head on. In supporting the report, we have outlined our plan to support young people into the workplace. The report provides a wide ranging framework for getting our young people into work; through strengthened partnerships between educational institutes and local employers, to improving the quality of career guidance in schools.

name: Sylvie Guillaume (S&D)
text: In writing. How can we better facilitate the integration into the labour market of the five million young people aged 15 to 24 who are unemployed in the EU and the 7 million young Europeans who are not working and not studying or training? To answer this question, the European Parliament calls for an approach that focuses more on vocational education, non-formal and innovative learning, workplace training, internships and mobility.  I have therefore supported this initiative report, which is really in line with a pragmatic vision that takes into account the evolution of the labour market. More bridges need to be created between a world of education in which new teaching methods must be introduced, and that of business, with the support of all levels of public authorities.  Bringing the school and the company closer together can certainly strengthen essential skills (adaptability, learning to learn, initiative, entrepreneurship and communication), which is why it is in our best interest to encourage these new practices.

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Parliament resolution adopted today focuses on youth unemployment (Hungary higher than the EU average (22%) 1.5%). It aims to provide an even more effective response to the european Union's early-looking job in a Europe with only two million vacancies. The decision shows that the Union has finally recognised that the situation of nearly 12 million European citizens who have been out of work for a long time must also be addressed, i.e. young people who are particularly disadvantaged because they have little or no experience or advanced knowledge at all. The report mentions two dimensions of capabilities: the need to strengthen general so-called basic skills and to continue to specialise in competitive knowledge. It also emphasises the responsibility of economic life and the business-financial sector. Youth unemployment is also a challenge in terms of starting a family, not to mention the increasing challenges of competitive competences (IT skills, start-ups, etc.) in training systems, which must respond and adapt to market requirements and development, in line with local and regional specificities.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report deals with an extremely important issue, such as youth unemployment. Unfortunately, it contains elements such as the interconnection of the business world with education systems, the mobility of young people for practical exercises and for finding work or even voluntary unpaid work which do not allow us to vote for it.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as I believe there is a need for more flexible education systems that would allow for matching knowledge and skills at all stages of professional career to face the needs of the labour market and the alarming level of youth unemployment. The report underlines that business creation and self-employment also constitute an opportunity for participation in the labour market. It also calls for an efficient absorption of European funds by the Member States. There are, on the one hand, 24 million unemployed people in Europe, including 7.5 million young people not in employment, education or training (NEETs) and on the other 2 million unfilled vacancies in the EU. Many are over-qualified unemployed youths whose skills do not match the demand of the labour market. Hence the need to build up strong partnerships between local authorities, education and employment services and social partners and the business community to support the creation, implementation and monitoring of short- and medium-term sustainable and quality employment strategies.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: Writing. The Plura report deals with education and training issues to reduce youth unemployment. There are currently 7.5 million unemployed young people in the EU. These are particularly concentrated in the regions of southern Europe particularly affected by the euro crisis. At the same time, there are 2 million vacancies in the EU, which are often unfilled because the required skills are not available on the labour market. The Plura report makes proposals to adapt training more closely to demand without too much interfere with the competences of the Member States. It is also committed to promoting small and medium-sized enterprises, which create a large proportion of new jobs, and also to the acceptance and promotion of entrepreneurship. Unfortunately, the EU, and the European Parliament in particular, continue to fail to recognise the importance of the single currency for the emergence and persistence of mass unemployment. The Plura report is no exception, but it is a good report within the framework of what is politically possible and I have therefore given my assent. Incidentally, I believe that the single euro must be abolished. It leads to strife and discord in Europe.

name: Krzysztof Hetman (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on skills to combat youth unemployment, because I believe that it accurately identifies the most important issues to look out for if we want to develop the potential for young people to work in an innovative economy. First of all, the report points to an important problem facing the European labour market today: a major mismatch between young people's skills and employers' expectations and needs. As a result, although we have several million vacancies across Europe, many young people remain unemployed. Therefore, swift, decisive action must be taken to remedy this situation. In the report, Mr Plura has taken up the important issue of learning entrepreneurship from an early age.  Self-employment and starting one's own business has great potential in combating unemployment. In addition, entrepreneurial skills are versatile, shape resourcefulness and help you find and do almost any job.  It is also pleased that the report adequately emphasises the need for cooperation and coordination at all levels – between educational, training, employers and non-governmental organisations. The focus should also be on optimising the use of the instruments available at EU level: the Youth Guarantee, financial instruments and support from cohesion policy.

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Parliament resolution adopted today deals primarily with youth unemployment. It aims to provide the European Union with an even more effective response so that nearly five million young people can find jobs as soon as possible in a Europe with only two million vacancies. The Union has recognised that the situation of nearly 12 million European citizens who have been out of work for a long time also needs to be seriously addressed. In particular, young people are particularly disadvantaged because they either have little or no experience or modern knowledge. The report contains two important elements: strengthening general basic skills and the need for further continuous specialisation. They are essential for acquiring competitive knowledge. The document also emphasises the responsibilities of economic life and the business-finance sector. Youth unemployment is also a challenge in terms of starting a family, not to mention the fact that I voted in favour of the People's Party position, emphasizing the principle of subsidiarity and the indispensableity of the efforts of the Member States.

name: Mary Honeyball (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Labour MEPs supported this report as it is critical that young people have access to the required skills for the labour market. The UK Government should also be focusing on measures to boost jobs, growth and investment to ensure that there are quality jobs for young people.

name: Richard Howitt (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ In my constituency, the East of England Director of construction company RG Carter has said we face a ‘skills crisis’. The Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors found 70% of my region’s builders could not find available workers. It’s ironic that at the same time the East of England has some 50 000 young people unemployed, the recruitment firm Cooper Lomaz said last month our companies face skill shortages not just in construction, but in accountancy, food manufacturing, engineering, oil, gas and renewables, sales and marketing and IT too. The only answer is to offer high-quality traineeships and apprenticeships. I back today’s report rightly calling for better skills forecasting in the labour market, strengthened co-ordination between education institutions and local employers, and improved schools career guidance.  I call for key EU tools such as ERASMUS+ and the Youth Employment Initiative to be maximised in the East of England in particular. Finally young people are more vulnerable to exploitation, including being forced into precarious work. As a Labour MEP, I believe that if you work regular hours, you should have a regular contract, and that is why we are working to end exploitative zero-hours contracts not just in Britain, but across the EU.

name: Ian Hudghton (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ The economic crisis of recent years has had a particularly detrimental effect on youth employment in many areas of the EU. This is a welcome report and it is essential that efforts are made to address unemployment amongst young people.  In my own country the Scottish government has invested in an ambitious Youth Employment Strategy and this has contributed to the highest levels of youth employment in a decade.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The generation raised in an era of rapid technological progress has not only potential, talents and skills, but also values and priorities that differ from those of previous generations. The level of youth unemployment is nowadays one of the most challenging problems in the EU, with almost 5 million unemployed young people. At the same time there are 2 million unfilled vacancies. This situation causes a serious threat for the social cohesion and economic development of the EU. The report mentions that there are multidimensional skills which make it possible to enter the labour market and remain employed: key competences, adaptability, learning to learn, initiative and entrepreneurship, communication and specific skills related to particular posts or jobs.  The report also underlines that there is a need to determine which level of governance has the most effective tools in identifying and describing skills needs. Business creation and self-employment also constitute opportunities for youth to participate in the labour market.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the Policy Report aimed at developing skills in the fight against youth unemployment, as I believe that a large number of 4.5 million unemployed aged between 15 and 24 can certainly be reduced through quality solutions related to training, education and employment of young people, which should be among the EU's most important political priorities. The youth employment crisis must be addressed through the efficient and sustainable creation of quality jobs in Europe. It is necessary to anticipate the needs of tomorrow and to align the skills of young people with the needs of the labour market, and to enable retraining. I support this Report because I believe that young people are too precious for the current and future state of the European economy.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report because the measures it proposes on apprenticeships are a paradox with regard to the budgetary restrictions imposed on Member States. Moreover, by highlighting skills, rather than diplomas, this report itself appears as an admission of the failure of national education systems. Moreover, it seems much more appropriate that policies for the integration of young people should be carried out first at the regional and local level, not at the European level.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. – I voted against this non legislative and non-binding report. The report called for the EU to spend more money to spread information on European financing instruments. UKIP opposes the EU spending taxpayer’s money especially to put out such propaganda. There was a call to create an EU award for the best project that combats youth employment – this would be a complete waste of money and nothing more than a vanity project for the EU.   It called for Member States to follow EU country-specific recommendations. It also wanted the EU to interfere with Member States’ education and national curriculum, suggesting what subjects should be taught – the EU has no competence in this area. It also called for more money and support for mobility programmes such as Erasmus which advertises British jobs across the EU. UKIP is the only party against open door immigration and will protect British jobs. The only people that should decide any of these things are our elected and accountable government, not unelected bureaucrats in Brussels.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Today 4.5 million young people aged between 15 and 24 are unemployed in Europe. This poses a serious threat to both the economic and social future of Europe.  To deal with such a challenge, we need appropriate instruments which would help the young generation to develop the skills our labour market actually needs. I believe entrepreneurship is one of them; it is the main driving force for growth. We must boost young people’s confidence and encourage them to set up their own business. To this end, more should be done on partnership between education and businesses, for example. By applying the recommendations of this report, I think Member States could better use the potential of this new generation.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Marek Plura's report on skills development policies to tackle youth unemployment. The fight against unemployment is one of the biggest challenges of the European Union and a lifelong priority for my political group, the EPP.  I welcome the avenues developed in this report, which stresses in particular the flexibility of education systems and the need to be able to match its knowledge and skills to all professional stages in order to adapt to the needs of the labour market.  This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. This report was aimed at tackling one of the scourges of today's Europe: youth unemployment. It therefore advocates a number of measures to create jobs, including facilitating the creation of their own businesses, investing in education in line with labour market needs, promoting alternating training and urgently integrating new technologies into learning processes.

name: Jarosław Kalinowski (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 In the labour market, young people are the first victims of the economic crisis. According to research, the unemployment rate in the under-25 age category is very high in EU countries: in its August 2015 publications, Eurostat indicates that it reaches 20.4% and in euro area countries as high as 22.3%. Germany (7%) are the country with the lowest youth unemployment and the only country where unemployment does not exceed 10%. The countries with the highest levels of unemployment are the 4 southern European countries: Spain (48.8%), Greece (48.3%), Croatia (43.5%) and Italy (40.7%).  In 2012, the European Union responded to this problem by means of a plan called the 'EU Package of Employment Measures' to facilitate young people's access to the labour market through a variety of measures. It is a series of guidance documents designed to support job creation and the improvement of employment policies. The main objectives of the programme are to reduce workers' taxation, increase net profit, create new jobs through the mobilisation of EU funds, promote training adapted to the labour market and remove legal and practical obstacles to the free movement of workers. In addition, this package talks about the creation of a European labour market, the development of the economic economy, the promotion and promotion of self-employment, modern enterprises and so-called start-ups. Our colleague Mark Plura's report supports those ideas under which I also sign.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. The report calls for measures to improve the training of young people, the exchange of best practice models, the provision of skills and skills through innovative and accessible training opportunities, as well as measures to give priority to education as much as possible, and the relaxation of administrative and financial requirements. I fully agree with these measures.

name: Krišjānis Kariņš (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In the European Union, youth unemployment is a very serious problem, which must seek effective solutions so that unemployment rates do not continue to grow. The figures are self-speaking: in 2014, the EU youth unemployment rate was 21.4%, which was twice as high as the overall unemployment rate in the EU. Employment has been hit hard by the crisis and the EU therefore needs the means to improve the situation in the European Union in the field of youth employment. Young people are the future of the European Union and, in order for this future to be a success, the European Union needs policies that will promote young people's susceptibility and skills. Following all the above arguments, I supported this European Parliament resolution.

name: Tunne Kelam (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. Youth unemployment remains high in Europe, reaching 40-50% in some Member States. At the same time many jobs are vacant due to lack of qualified applicants. It is clear that one aspect of the problem is the mismatch of skills and demand on the labour market. Close cooperation between educational institutions, state authorities, and private-sector, student and youth organisations to identify shortcomings should become the norm, so as to have a functioning network that is able to discuss and find solutions.  Europe underestimates the importance of vocational training and of practical experience in both high-school and higher education. Vocational training offers should be developed in close cooperation with the private sector, and should provide a combined system of in-class learning and quality internships and apprenticeships.  Incorporating digital skills and entrepreneurship as integral part of the whole educational system will equip young people to enhance their potential better. Lastly, labour mobility remains low in Europe, whereas some parts suffer from high unemployment and other parts have unfilled jobs. Better mutual recognition of certificates and accompanying language training could give a boost and offer new opportunities especially for young people to find employment.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report, as it is critical that young people have access to the required skilled in today’s labour market. However, the UK Government needs to boost jobs, growth and investment to ensure that there are quality jobs for young people.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Parliament resolution adopted today focuses on youth unemployment (Hungary higher than the EU average (22%) 1.5% better) and aims to give the European Union an even more effective response so that nearly half a million young people in Hungary can find jobs as soon as possible in a Europe with only two million vacancies. The decision fits the trend that the Union has finally recognised that the situation of the nearly 12 million European citizens who have been out of work for a long time must also be addressed, and that young people are particularly disadvantaged because they have either no or little experience or modern knowledge. The report basically mentions two dimensions of capabilities: the need to strengthen general so-called basic skills and to continue to specialise in competitive knowledge. It also emphasises the responsibility of economic life and the business-financial sector. Youth unemployment is also a challenge in terms of starting a family, not to mention the increasing challenges of competitive competences (IT skills, start-ups, etc.) in training systems, which must respond and adapt to market requirements and development, in line with local and regional specificities. With my vote, I followed the People's Party position by saying that the principle of subsidiarity is fundamental and the efforts of the Member States are indispensable.

name: Stelios Kouloglou (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This report aims to identify the reasons why the youth unemployment rate is still increasing and to propose solutions. An alarmingly high level of youth unemployment is nowadays one of the most challenging problems in the EU. It is deplorable though that, despite the initiatives of the European Institutions to reduce youth unemployment, there are two million unfilled vacancies. The rapporteur explores two main fields that could constitute an opportunity for participation in the labour market: business creation and self-employment. Despite the fact that the report acknowledges the need for efficient and sustainable quality job creation in Europe, I decided to abstain. In my view, this position makes it possible to express criticism towards its overemphasis on the role of entrepreneurship in reducing youth unemployment.

name: Béla Kovács (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 Youth unemployment in the EU is dramatic, at 24 million, and 7 million of them do not receive any education or training. By comparison, the report praises the Commission's efforts and calls for the support of economic migrants, with no regard for the facts. The Europe 2020 strategy is also surely not to solve the problems. In addition, the report outlines good guidelines, such as skills development and helping to become an entrepreneur, so that it cannot be completely sosed, but a much stronger substance would be needed to deal with such a major problem, since youth is the future.

name: Miapetra Kumpula-Natri (S&D)
text: Written. \u2012 The policy of cuts must not be directed at education, although it is certainly under pressure in more countries. It's good to remember that it's an investment in the future! There has been more and more talk about skills and entrepreneurship. As in this report, entrepreneurship is underlined. We must remember, however, that not everyone will become entrepreneurs. We must not put too much pressure on people to do this, because entrepreneurship is not suitable for everyone. However, this does not mean that incentives cannot be created for entrepreneurship and otherwise small entrepreneurs can be made easier.  Education must not be narrow. It must be generic, beneficial to the industry. The ultimate responsibility for guiding the work must be with the company. It's part of the orientation. It should be remembered that training cannot be tailored to the needs of a single employer. An employee would suffer severely if he or she were unemployed or wanted to change jobs. It is essential to invest in digital skills and language learning in the education of young people. These will enable us to be well equipped for the labour market of the future. Moreover, apprenticeships must not become 'compulsory', cheap labour for the benefit of businesses. Although apprenticeships are becoming more common in some European countries, the same model does not fit everywhere, and this must be borne in mind! The focus must continue to be on educational institutions. Better education planning requires cooperation between society as a whole, student and youth organisations involved in planning, and NGOs and the public sector. Better planning work in cooperation will help the needs of the labour market better.

name: Gabrielius Landsbergis (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Youth unemployment in the European Union is 21%, which is slightly lower than during the financial crisis, but the figures still remain high. No longer in the first year, solutions are being sought to integrate young people into the labour market. I believe that, in addition to today's figures for young people who are not in employment, we should be seriously concerned about their competences and their education. The world is moving fast, new businesses are emerging, the development or development of which requires not only professional knowledge, but also creativity and ingenuity. Although education policy is a question of competence in the Member States, it is necessary to look at good examples of countries, where education systems allow the emphasis not only of knowledge and education, but also for comprehensive personality education, where new ways of creating an educational process are being sought.
