I would like to draw attention to the results of studies by the International Programme for the Assessment of Students (PISA), which show the shortcomings of EU countries in preparing young people for life. I voted in favour of this resolution because all the measures listed above are important to address youth unemployment. However, the EU must wake up and focus on the professional development of young people, assess whether existing education systems are the fairest and most effective way to build an educated, courageous and creative society.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the report on policies for skills development to combat youth unemployment.  The problem of youth unemployment is taking an endemic turn. One of the main measures to support their entry into the labour market would be to promote skills development. Some of the measures recommended in this report are fair and necessary. These include encouraging orientation from an early age, adapting training and making curricula more flexible to better meet employers' expectations, encouraging apprenticeships, alternating training and tutoring in business, etc.  Although good, these tracks are reworked with EU sauce and are therefore reduced to very vague proposals, without any practical or concrete input. There are only smoky theories and wishful thinking.  It is clear that policies for the integration of young people into the labour market must be carried out first at the regional and local level, not at European level. Public service networks are able to support young people in the transition to employment, in partnership with associations or private organizations, as well as with businesses.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report. Of course, it has the merit of being concerned about youth unemployment, but it is unable to make concrete proposals. All the amendments tabled by the FN MEPs were rejected.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report, although it is a commendable initiative in the fight against youth unemployment, which is growing. In the right direction, this text tends to promote skills rather than diplomas, encourage youth orientation, or support learning. Nevertheless, concrete proposals are vague, or even absent. Disconnected from economic reality, ignoring member states' budget cuts, this text defends a youth employment policy at European level, when solutions are found at local and regional level.  Finally, as is often the case, the amendments tabled by our group were systematically rejected, and the final text was polluted by ideological demands (gender theory, migrant aid), to which I am strongly opposed.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. At the time when we find almost fifteen million young people unemployed, I consider it necessary to take measures to achieve greater social cohesion and combat this serious problem affecting a large group of the European population. Skills development can become a mechanism that involves and promotes equal opportunities in the field of the labour market. The report sets out the great importance of worker mobility. To ensure that this mobility is carried out, it is necessary to offer sector-specific language courses and intercultural communication training to the unemployed in order to reduce existing language barriers. Collaboration by Member States is also considered necessary through structural reforms at all levels of education. In addition, a flexible teaching system is needed to complement and develop knowledge and skills at all stages of the professional career. In my view, this report favours the promotion of integration and employability in the labour market, so it would be appropriate for its approval to take place.

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR)
text: Writing. The Plura report deals with education and training issues to reduce youth unemployment. There are currently 7.5 million unemployed young people in the EU. These are particularly concentrated in the regions of southern Europe particularly affected by the euro crisis. At the same time, there are 2 million vacancies in the EU, which are often unfilled because the required skills are not available on the labour market. The Plura report makes proposals to adapt training more closely to demand without too much interfere with the competences of the Member States. It is also committed to promoting small and medium-sized enterprises, which create a large proportion of new jobs, and also to the acceptance and promotion of entrepreneurship. Unfortunately, the EU, and the European Parliament in particular, continue to fail to recognise the importance of the single currency, the euro, for the emergence and persistence of mass unemployment. The Plura report is no exception, but it is a good report within the framework of what is politically possible and I have therefore given my assent.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against because the EU wants to tackle youth unemployment with greater subsidies for their inclusion, education, etc. The report calls for taxpayers' money to be spent on European propaganda: 'to use more money to disseminate information on European funding instruments'.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ A lot of activities have been undertaken with the aim of strengthening youth entrepreneurship, reducing unemployment and self-employment, but they have not proved effective and we cannot be satisfied with what has been achieved because more than seven million young Europeans are unemployed, not in education and are not trained. Through a separate budget, the European Union has allocated €132.3 million to implement direct interventions towards young people through a separate budget (YEI) (YEI) (YEI). Part of the activities related to youth employment are currently financed by the ESF in 2007-2013 through the so-called direct allocation of funds to the Croatian Employment Service, but it is an open question how many of these funds have actually returned to the Croatian budget. For the Youth Employment Initiative, the European Commission paid back in early 2015 an advance of €26 million, which must be spent by May 2016, otherwise it is returned to the European Budget. I supported the report for policies aimed at developing skills in the fight against youth unemployment, as the development of entrepreneurial spirit and a positive atmosphere towards entrepreneurship starts from a young age, so it is necessary to introduce special programs in all educational institutions, from kindergarten to college.

name: Светослав Христов Малинов (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In today's plenary session, the European Parliament adopted by a large majority a resolution to address the alarmingly high levels of youth unemployment in the European Union. Given that almost five million young people are out of work, with over two million vacancies available, the measures adopted aim at educating and adapting young people to labour market needs.  The problem of youth unemployment remains one of the top political priorities. If we are to achieve greater effectiveness in combating it, cooperation between business representatives, educational institutions and organisations offering qualification and retraining courses must be a key factor. Only in this way can we achieve greater consistency between the professional training of the young and the needs of employers. Other issues that the proposal rightly focuses on include combating phenomena such as employment in the grey sector, zero-hours contracts and unpaid traineeships.  I therefore support putting the issue of high levels of youth unemployment on the agenda and call for greater engagement and adequate policies by Member States.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ youth unemployment was 21.4% at the end of 2014 , with seven million young people aged 15-24 not in employment or in education or training. These figures are alarming and may have appalling implications for the future of the Union. They show that both state and social mechanisms are failing in the process of educate young people. We do not manage the upbringing and motivation of the younger generation, despite the amount of financial resources that are poured into these policies. The wide potential of young people in follow-up to their abilities is often not used. It therefore appears increasingly urgent that the system and quality of education be reviewed in the light of the development of the digital society and the impacts of globalisation, as well as the provision of social and economic security in relation to compulsory education, training and employment for young people.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I refer to my speech of 18 January 2016 before the plenary of the European Parliament and point out that I abstain from voting on the report on skills policies to combat youth unemployment. I would also like to stress that this report is not complete.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report. This long litany of wishful thinking aims to combat youth unemployment through skills development policies. Some good ideas emerge from this text, such as the desire to encourage learning, alternating training and tutoring, or the willingness to anticipate the skills needs of the promising sectors. But these great ideas can quite be organised by the Member States, of which they are prerogatives. It seems clear to us that policies for the integration of young people into the labour market must be carried out first at the regional and local level: public service networks are able to support young people in the transition to employment, in partnership with associations or private bodies, as well as with businesses. The European Union does not need to deal with it.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this Report which  ‘Stresses that “a new boost to jobs, growth and investment” is an essential priority of the Commission and that in its Work Programme for 2015, the Commission committed to taking practical initiatives to promote integration and employability in the labour market, particularly measures to support Member States in getting young people into work; reiterates that Parliament has regularly proposed different solutions stressing that youth employment, education and training should be one of the highest political priorities for the EU’.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The level of youth unemployment has hit most European countries hard, putting a strain on their labour markets, with particularly serious effects on young people's employment opportunities, with profoundly negative consequences for the future of the younger generation. Unemployment remains, in fact, at a very alarming level, constantly increasing, with almost 5 million young people unemployed. It is essential to promote concrete initiatives to encourage integration and employment in the labour market, to implement immediately social protection measures to combat the economic and social effects of unemployment, as well as special measures to support Member States in getting young people into the world of work.

name: Jiří Maštálka (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 Today we voted on a report that deals with a really extremely important issue, and that is youth unemployment. They often complete their studies and find themselves in employment offices with no hope of future employment. This creates a slowly but surely so-called lost generation of young people. The situation in Europe is alarming, e.g. youth unemployment in Spain is 55%. The report contains some positive aspects, such as the emphasis on comprehensive education and practice in future perspective fields. However, since I do not agree that the main solution to this tragic situation is to encourage young people to do business to such an extent that the field of entrepreneurship should be taught in primary schools, I abstained in the final vote.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Young people are our most important resource, even though it is the least developed in Europe, as demonstrated by the very high rate of youth unemployment. In this context, I agree with the rapporteur on the need for more in-depth work to improve the situation of young people in Europe. I therefore support the report's recommendations on the crucial ity of education and the development of individual skills so that the youth unemployment rate in Europe falls. We must be sure that Young Europeans are well prepared to face the challenges of the twenty-first century economy and that flexible education, at all levels, is the key to the future.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. The alarming number of youth unemployment makes it necessary for us from the EU and this Parliament to continue to work to put all the facilities to reduce these levels and ensure a future for our young people. In this regard, I support the report on skills policies to combat youth unemployment, which emphasizes the need to improve skills so that young people can access and maintain employment. General skills, adaptability, learning capacity, initiative and entrepreneurship or communication, as well as specific competencies for specific positions or jobs are necessary. Moreover, we do not tire of pointing out that it is necessary to link (also financially) higher education institutions with the economic sector.

name: Κώστας Μαυρίδης (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Young people are now a vulnerable category of citizens who have been very much affected by the economic crisis affecting the EU in recent years. The figures speak for themselves, considering that 4.5 million young people aged 15-24 are currently unemployed across Europe. The problem is particularly acute in Greece and Cyprus. Unemployment rates are particularly high, with the result that the number of young people migrating abroad to seek employment is constantly increasing. Both the root cause of unemployment and an important means of combating it can be found in higher education. There is a lack of skills necessary in the available jobs because young people choose to study saturated occupations that do not meet the current needs of society. It is therefore imperative that young people obtain the appropriate qualifications required by the current labour market, while also calculating future needs. The development of skills such as adaptability and communication, essential in every profession, must be a primary concern of education systems. I therefore wish to vote in favour of this resolution in order to be part of the effort to eradicate youth unemployment in the EU.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. The report contains a number of good suggestions and legitimate concerns about what support deserves. I think it is reasonable to include vocational orientation in the curricula. I also believe that linking training centres with companies is a tried and tested means of contributing to the reduction of youth unemployment. I therefore agree with this report.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in support of this report which acknowledges the need for education systems to adapt to the needs of the labour market. The report identifies opportunities that will help combat youth unemployment and facilitate their participation in the labour market.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The main merit of this report suggesting ways to tackle youth unemployment is that it is strongly declared against cuts in education and to strengthen the creation of non-relocable green jobs. Otherwise, it reproduces the usual punctuations of the right. Starting with the development, from college, of "entrepreneurship" and "skills" professional but also of "democratic skills". Not to mention the strengthening of the private sector's guardianship of education, supposedly to the benefit of market developments and to the detriment of the fundamental and civic achievements of students. Once again there is the demand for deregulation of entrepreneurship, an EU panacea for any job seeker and in any condition. Finally, in view of the 7 million unemployed young people in the EU, highlighting the 2 million unfilled or "overqualified" positions seems particularly unconsleted and undignified. As with the presentation of the Youth Guarantee more than three years ago now, no guarantee is given beyond the words for "decent and quality jobs".  I'm voting against it.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. This is a major report that deserves our full attention. But this report contains vague proposals on learning, flexibility of curricula, alternating training, etc. They are a paradox with regard to the budgetary restrictions imposed on member states. Moreover, by highlighting skills, rather than diplomas, this report itself appears as an admission of the failure of national education systems. Moreover, it seems much more appropriate that policies for the integration of young people should be carried out first at the regional and local level, not at the European stage. Finally, the amendments in committee have included inappropriate and dangerous concepts, such as the integration of migrants and the application of gender theory. Therefore, I am voting against this report.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. I have voted in favour of the report on skills policies to combat youth unemployment. It is very worrying to know that youth unemployment in the EU affects almost 5 million young people. Young people have been particularly affected by the crisis. On the other hand, there are two million jobs to be filled. This scenario seriously threatens the EU's social cohesion and economic development. Young people are an important asset of the European economy, so it is urgent that all measures be taken to reverse this scenario.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution because it is vital to fight the high rate of youth unemployment in Europe. The resolution advocates more flexible education systems in the Union that allow for matching knowledge and skills at any stage of professional careers. In addition, this resolution calls for an organised and even spread of European funds by Member States.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: Written. – Tackling youth unemployment remains one of the biggest challenges in Europe. Despite the fact that at the end of 2014 more than 7 million young people in Europe were out of work, we also note that 2 million vacancies are not filled. It is therefore of the utmost importance that Europe and the Member States take initiatives to get more young people into work.  An integrated employment policy means that developments in the labour market must be anticipated more quickly and that the development of individual skills must be brought into line with the specific demand on the labour market. It is also advisable, in the context of cross-sector cooperation, that educational institutions and economic sectors should cooperate more intensively. I also support the recommendation in this report to intensify the European Eures jobs network and labour mobility so that young people, especially in border regions, are encouraged to take on offers of work from across the border.  Finally, it is also recommended that additional efforts be made to promote entrepreneurship among young people. In this respect, it is appropriate for all Member States to commit themselves to the Erasmus programme for young entrepreneurs.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: in writing – High youth unemployment is one of the most exciting signs of our time. The negative impact of unemployment is visible not only in the declining solvency of young people, but also in their social or moral decline. Young people must not lose their work habits because it will become increasingly difficult for them to fit into a normal way of life. It is necessary to change the approach in education, to support apprenticeship and industrial schools and their cooperation with employers, to improve their name in society and to draw attention to young people who decide to choose a school or who have not found employment in their field and can expand their application in this way. Graduates of these schools are woefully few in Europe, although their onset in working life is fast and financially interesting. Such an approach could increasingly lead to a reduction in youth unemployment and, consequently, to an improvement in their living situation.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report on skills policies for fighting youth unemployment.  Tackling youth unemployment remains a top priority if Europe does not want to risk losing a whole generation. A first step must be the further strengthening and proper implementation of the Youth Guarantee and the Youth Employment Initiative. It is fundamental to improve the positive long-term benefits of the opportunities offered to young people, concretely through meaningful training courses, that improve their employability, and stable jobs. Europe will be a better place if we make equal opportunities a reality for all young people in Europe

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 According to the Report of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, one of the eu's most serious problems is the alarmingly high youth unemployment: currently 4.5 million young people between the age of 15 and 24 are out of work and the number of young people in Europe who are not in employment, education or training exceeds 7 million. At the end of 2014, the unemployment rate in the EU was 9.9%, but for young people it was more than twice that, at 21.4%. At the same time, there are 2 million vacancies. This situation poses a serious risk to social cohesion and economic development in the EU. The report notes that the founding of new businesses and self-employment also provide opportunities to participate in the labour market. At the same time, it points out that changes in the labour market require more flexible education systems that enable knowledge and skills to be complemented and developed at all stages of a professional career. Access to the labour market and the maintenance of employment are made possible by two dimensions of skills, according to the report: key competences (adaptability, learning to learn, initiative and entrepreneurship, communication) and specific skills related to specific jobs or jobs. At the same time, it is necessary to link higher education institutions (also in financial terms) to the economic sector (industry, services).

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. To support the integration of young people into the labour market, one of the main measures would be to promote the development of skills, rather than diplomas. This idea somehow confirms the failure of national education and vocational training systems.   Other avenues are advanced, such as encouraging orientation from an early age, learning, alternating training, and tutoring in business. Although good, these tracks are therefore reduced to very vague proposals, without any practical input.   Most of these measures are difficult to implement in the current context where Member States are forced to adopt limited budgets. It is clear that policies for the integration of young people into the labour market must be carried out first at the regional and local level, not at European level.   The idea of developing entrepreneurship to encourage young people to create their own jobs is recurrent, but its scope will be marginal in a particularly difficult economic context.  Youth entrepreneurship is sometimes only an instrument used to get them out of the unemployment figures.  This report should not be supported.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. The development of individual skills and the dissemination of knowledge and skills are one of the main elements of employment policies, enabling lasting growth to be generated, competitiveness promoted and unemployment is tackled. I am voting in favour of this report, subscribing to the position advocating the establishment of higher levels of cooperation between higher education institutions and the labour market, a growing focus on entrepreneurship and new opportunities for young people. It should be noted that there are approximately 22 million unemployed in Europe, including 7 million young people who do not work, study or train (NEETs), and it is therefore essential to develop new educational skills that are linked to the needs of the labour market, especially technological ly, where there are 2 million unfilled vacancies in the European Union. Finally, I would like to stress the fact that the Youth Guarantee Programme has produced very satisfactory results. However, I believe that youth employment policies should be more focused on creating real job opportunities and not on social programs that do not address this scourge that thousands of unemployed young people live in every day.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This report on skills development policies to combat youth unemployment envisages highlighting the skills of young people rather than their diplomas, in order to facilitate their integration into the labour market, but also to encourage orientation from an early age, as well as apprenticeships or alternating training, adapt training and make courses more flexible. , and anticipate the qualification needs of the most promising sectors.  These proposals are hardly revolutionary and are, for the most part, vague. Moreover, these measures would require an impossible budgetary effort within the binding framework of the European Union.  On the other hand, if this policy is to be carried out, it is at the local and state level, not Brussels.  The punctuations listed in this text led me to vote against this text.

name: Clare Moody (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Labour MEPs supported this report as it is critical that young people have access to the required skilled in today’s labour market. However, the UK Government needs to boost jobs, growth and investment to ensure that there are quality jobs for young people.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Labour MEPs supported this report as it is critical that young people have access to the required skilled in today’s labour market. However, the UK Government needs to boost jobs, growth and investment to ensure that there are quality jobs for young people.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the fight against youth unemployment, which is one of my priorities. Currently, more than 7 million young Europeans aged 15 to 24 are not working, studying or training. Of these, 4.5 million are unemployed.  In this very worrying context, it is essential to develop the skills of young people so that they enter the labour market. European funds contribute to access to university and business training. I supported provisions calling for more financial resources to disseminate information on European financing tools and to develop, in universities and companies, the knowledge and skills needed to raise funds, study and manage funding projects.

name: Luigi Morgano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 There are, on the one hand, more than 7 million young people in the EU who are neither hired nor students or enrolled in training courses (NEETs) and, on the other, 2 million vacancies, with many over-skilled unemployed young people whose skills do not meet the needs of the labour market. My vote in favour of this resolution stresses the need to build strong partnerships between employment and training services and, at the same time, to improve cooperation and interaction between school education and vocational training, public administration, youth and student organisations and the world of work in order to maximise the quality of education and training. In order to guarantee young people greater access to the labour market, I believe it is important to review training programmes where possible, anticipating the needs of the labour market. I also firmly believe that supporting an ongoing dialogue between educational institutions and employers, as well as sharing good practice in vocational training and the development of skills-based training, including practical and entrepreneurial training, are among the most effective means of resolving skills mismatches. The employment, education and training of young people must continue to be the EU's political priorities.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Given the worrying level of youth unemployment, which affects five million young people in the European Union, and the persistent gap between the place of women in the labour market and their training, we welcome the Plura report. Indeed, by acknowledging the seriousness of a problem that could undermine economic development and social cohesion in Europe, the text promotes a holistic approach to this issue. A strategy that, taking into account the broad spectrum of phenomena, from globalisation to the economic crisis, which have determined the current circumstances, is able to overcome the strictly sectoral criterion that has characterised the implementation of policies aimed at supporting employment. The current crisis is also closely linked to European education systems, which are often far removed from the economic sector. We therefore need an education policy capable of reforming university institutions, making them closer to the needs of the production system. To this end, a link between higher education institutions and companies, including in the field of economic support, could certainly facilitate a more efficient placement of young people in the labour market. The challenges imposed by modernity also require greater flexibility of training courses, starting from the integration and updating of skills in phases even after entering the market.

name: Renaud Muselier (PPE)
text: In writing. The report on policies to combat youth unemployment received my support, with this one mentioning measures for skills development. The report generated broad consensus in committee and received equivalent approval from Parliament. It provides valuable assistance in the fight against youth unemployment, a priority for the European Union.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The alarming level of youth unemployment is now one of the EU's main challenges, with almost 5 million young people out of work. I support this report because I believe that we need more flexible education systems that allow the integration and development of knowledge and skills at all stages of the professional career. There are two dimensions of skills that allow access to the labour market and to maintain employment: basic skills and specific skills related to particular jobs or jobs. It is also necessary to determine which level of governance has the most effective tools for identifying and defining skills needs.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I welcome the report on combating youth unemployment. We voted on the adoption of a document that is particularly needed today, because the problem of the young unemployed affects many Member States, including my country, Slovakia. One of the most fundamental problems lies in the fact that supply and demand in the labour market often do not meet. We need to use practical solutions that allow them to be aligned. In this, I believe that quality and flexible education is key, ensuring that the skills that are most needed in the labour market are acquired. We can also look at the various forms of promoting entrepreneurship as an effective tool, which many European projects offer help to achieve.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. – I have voted for this report that encourages youth business creation and participation in the labour market as a means of social cohesion and economic development of the EU.

name: Момчил Неков (S&D)
text: in writing. – I come from a country where youth unemployment rates are some of the highest in Europe. Today, young people are increasingly struggling in the transition from education to work and are often willing to accept positions that do not meet their qualifications. I believe that in order to achieve smart, sustainable and inclusive growth, we need to invest in education and skills, in developing talent and creating opportunities for realisation in life. The development of basic skills and competences such as information and communication technologies (ICT), mathematics, foreign language proficiency and mobility, which allow young people to adapt quickly to changing labour market needs, must be encouraged.  Last but not least, I would like to bring to the fore the need for early career guidance to help learners make the right decision when choosing a profession. In conclusion, I would like to say that in order to find a lasting solution to youth unemployment, it is necessary for Member States to ensure that investment in quality education and training and in the development of horizontal skills is a priority.

name: Dan Nica (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Union unemployment rate was 9.9% at the end of 2014 and the youth unemployment rate was more than twice as high, reaching 21.4%.  Unfortunately, there are many overskilled unemployed young people whose skills do not meet labour market demands. Practical, entrepreneurial, programming and digital skills are indispensable for professional development, which is why I stress the importance of implementing the Entrepreneurship 2020 Action Plan and the EU Digital Skills Strategy.  We encourage Member States to urgently include new technologies in learning and to step up, at all levels and for all types of education and training, ICT training and skills development activities, including for teaching staff, in order to provide study programmes better linked to digital developments and motivate young people to study ICT and engage in related careers.  I voted for the report on skills development policies to combat youth unemployment, and I believe that giving everyone equal training and access to digital tools is more important than ever.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report in support of one of the EU's most important and necessary common policies, namely the fight against youth unemployment by developing their skills. Today's report outlines the problems and difficulties of young people in finding a job, which exists in all European countries, including Romania.  As young people have been most affected from the crisis in recent years, with the unemployment rate reaching 21.4% in 2014, every effort must be made to ensure that education systems adequately prepare students for professional development. In this respect, as the report proposes, Member States, regional and local authorities must adopt and apply, together with social partners and providers of vocational training, strategies for developing and anticipating skills in order to improve the skills of young people.  I also voted for this report because I think it is very important for the Member States to support and further develop the important role that employers and entrepreneurs play in training young people in the workplace.

name: Андрей Новаков (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the objectives set out in the report on more flexible education systems and the need for holistic education. Member States are encouraged to take part in the Erasmus for Young Entrepreneurs programme and promote it to young people so that they can gain experience abroad and acquire new skills. Erasmus+ programmes, the Youth Guarantee and the Youth Employment Initiative are important tools in the development of education and training for young unskilled and low-skilled people. Better funding is needed, as well as the rapid implementation of these schemes, followed by appropriate monitoring in each Member State; the report finds that labour mobility within the EU remains low and stresses the importance of worker mobility in creating a competitive labour market.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of this report because I believe it is very important to support young people in their career choices or in the choice of educational pathways. Traineeships in particular are a good way for young people to find their way into the world of work. Young people's employment and education should be one of the EU's top political priorities.

name: Younous Omarjee (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this initiative report on youth unemployment in Europe, a dramatic phenomenon which is reaching very high levels, while 2 million posts remain vacant in the European Union. The report calls on the Union to respond to this situation, which poses a significant threat to social peace in Europe, and to propose concrete measures to avoid it. For example, it calls on Member States to adopt social protection measures to counter the economic and social effects of youth unemployment.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. In a situation where youth unemployment is alarmingly high and, on the other hand, a large number of jobs are unfilled, it is important to make education systems more flexible so that they enable them to complement and develop knowledge and skills at all stages of their professional careers. It is also important to develop coherence between the economic sector and educational institutions.

name: Δημήτρης Παπαδάκης (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on combating unemployment, which in recent years has been a major challenge for the European Union, a challenge linked to social cohesion and economic development of the latter. What is worth noting is that this resolution, which is accompanied by an opinion from the European Parliament's Committee on Culture and Education, raises the problem of young people being unable to enter the labour market because of the weakness in the Member States' education programmes. I can only welcome the EU's now declared political direction towards integrated training for young people through continuing and lifelong learning programmes to replace a sterile education policy that ignores the needs of the labour market and cannot adapt the education systems of the Member States to reality.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non legislative and non-binding report. The report called for the EU to spend more money to spread information on European financing instruments. UKIP opposes the EU spending taxpayer’s money especially to put out such propaganda. There was a call to create an EU award for the best project that combats youth employment – this would be a complete waste of money and nothing more than a vanity project for the EU. It called for Member States to follow EU country-specific recommendations. It also wanted the EU to interfere with Member States’ education and national curriculum, suggesting what subjects should be taught – the EU has no competence in this area. It also called for more money and support for mobility programmes such as Erasmus which advertises British jobs across the EU. UKIP is the only party against open door immigration and will protect British jobs. The only people that should decide any of these things are our elected and accountable government, not unelected bureaucrats in Brussels.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The serious situation of employment policy in the European Union requires us to seek all measures to combat this phenomenon. I welcome the measures included in the resolution, such as the provision of more flexible education systems, and I hope that they will be implemented promptly. I urge the Commission and the Member States, with my vote in favour, to adopt as soon as possible the structural reforms that the new market orders us to carry out. I therefore repeat my vote in favour.

name: Eva Paunova (PPE)
text: in writing. – Europe faces a number of serious challenges that are only to be overcome by an innovative, digitally savvy and entrepreneurial society; by people who, regardless of their profession or background, have the skills and curiosity to think in new ways. As one of the Commission’s eSkills ambassadors, I firmly support policies for education and skills enhancement as way to combat youth unemployment in Europe. That is why I voted in favour of the report.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. This report is a heaping of poncifs, wishful thinking and measures unrelated to the real subject. Policies for training and integrating young people into the labour market can only be effective if they are decided at the national level, based on the realities of each country's demographics and economy. The differences between the Member States are very large on these two points, and it is counterproductive to want to deal with this problem at European level, as if the situations were the same everywhere. So I decided to vote against this report.

name: Pina Picierno (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Although young Europeans are at the heart of the Union's policies, the situation of youth unemployment in our countries today suggests that much remains to be done. Of course, the economic crisis and the contraction of demand have slowed down the achievement of ambitious economic objectives, but the current consequences go beyond the issue of unemployment itself and deeply affect a generation and its future. Youth unemployment is also destabilising social balances at European level, as it erodes social cohesion and the Community spirit. I voted for this resolution because I believe it is necessary to work actively and jointly with the aim of restoring the reality of European employment to levels of growth. This objective can be achieved by applying governance that takes into account changes in the labour market and differences in national markets together with national action aimed at providing education systems that make young people competitive and aware to face today's labour market where, in addition to a general theoretical preparation, a series of operational capacities need to be integrated to enable them to adapt to the new balance between supply and demand.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ Youth unemployment is one of the EU's biggest challenging problems at nearly 5 million, which poses a serious problem for the EU's economic development and social cohesion. In particular, globalisation, demographic change, the economic crisis, new technologies and changes in the organisation of work should be taken into account. Along with Greece and Spain, Croatia is the third country most affected by the youth unemployment rate. For the period 2014-2020, Croatia has more than EUR 132.54 million of EU Structural Funds, including: 66.36 million from the ESF Fund and 66.18 million from YEI for 2014-2015. With co-financing from the state budget, Croatia has almost EUR 150 million for the establishment of the Youth Guarantee. I am pleased to see that while they are still extremely high, youth unemployment rates are continuously declining, to which the Youth Guarantee has also contributed. In addition to the Guarantee, we need new incentives for "jobs, growth and investment", as a key priority for the Commission, which in its 2015 Work Programme committed itself to taking practical initiatives to promote labour market integration and employability. European funds, if used more efficiently and strategically, can be an excellent tool for stimulating the growth and development of universities and businesses, the way further contribute to reducing the scope of this fundamental problem of the young generation.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I support the proposal for a Policy Resolution aimed at developing skills in the fight against youth unemployment of my colleague Marek Plur. At the end of November 2015, the unemployment rate in the Union was 9.1% and the youth unemployment rate was more than double that of 20%. Croatia is particularly difficult to deal with this problem, as it is among the first three Member States of the Union for youth unemployment with as much as 45%. The youth employment crisis cannot be solved without the efficient and sustainable creation of quality jobs in Europe. Also, a lack of relevant skills (e.g. science, technology, engineering and mathematics skills) for the 2 million jobs available and a lack of education and training are important factors leading to unemployment. Despite being more educated and possessing more skills compared to previous generations, young people still face significant structural barriers to finding quality employment that complies with Union standards and national standards. Therefore, the focus should be on building a strong partnership between local authorities, education and employment services (general and specialised), and social partners and the business community in order to support the development, implementation and monitoring of short- and medium-term sustainable, inclusive and quality employment strategies and action plans.

name: Pavel Poc (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The recent financial and economic crisis has undoubtedly affected most of the population's age groups, and especially the younger ones. As average European youth unemployment has risen above 20% during the crisis and is still a problematic area for a large number of European Union states, I voted in favour of the report on policies aimed at combating unemployment skills. The report rightly highlights the need for cross-sectoral cooperation and dialogue between all stakeholders, including not only the business community, but also local authorities, social partners and civil society. We must not forget that if we want to succeed and achieve the objectives set out in the Europe 2020 strategy, it is not enough to take into account only the fulfilment of the needs of the labour market. We must ensure that young Europeans are equipped with the necessary cross-cutting competences. In this respect, we must not forget, in particular, the importance of language learning and digital literacy, which is becoming an increasingly important factor. I supported this report because we must no longer be satisfied with a situation where youth unemployment affects up to 20 million Europeans, and at the same time there are 2 million jobs that are unoccupied. While we can eliminate this marked inequality, we will only achieve this if the Member States take their share of responsibility and develop an optimal national strategy to which the European Union can subsequently contribute.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The fact that there are more than 7 million young people in the European Union without employment or further education is alarming. It is the young generation that is crucial to the future of the European economy. As a Social Democrat, I believe that further measures are needed to support them, promote education, develop individual skills and simplify the administrative and financial approach to entrepreneurship. Member States, together with the social partners and training providers, must work to improve communication and cooperation between educational institutions, administrations and businesses. From a European point of view, support for Erasmus and Erasmus plus, which are a key EU-wide instrument in ensuring vocational training and the development of cross-cutting skills, is also essential. Member States must also adopt long-term policies and invest effectively in strategic cooperation, promoting innovation and new technologies. We must not focus only on fulfilling the current needs of the labour market, but above all on the comfortable development of individuals and their equipment with cross-cutting capabilities.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 One of the EU's main challenges is the fight against youth unemployment. There are almost 5 million unemployed in the European Union, but there are also 2 million jobs that are not used. Factors such as globalisation, demographic change, the economic crisis, the advent of new technologies and changes in work organisation have put young people in serious difficulties. We therefore need new, more flexible education systems that allow the development of knowledge and skills, including cross-cutting skills, at all stages of the professional career. Developing skills and overcoming the "watertight compartments" of sectoral policies would make it easy for young people to adapt to the changing socio-economic environment. Hence the need for broad education and training that provides high-level basic skills, entrepreneurial skills, information and communication technologies (ICT), together with language skills that enable people to constantly acquire and apply new knowledge and facilitate their adaptation to changes in the world of work. For all these reasons, I support the adoption of this motion for a resolution.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I agree with the European Parliament's motion for a resolution on skills policies to combat youth unemployment. The current figures showing youth unemployment are alarming and do not expect a significant improvement in statistics. I therefore support this effective effort to reduce and try to address the negative effects of this problem. The report aptly contains key points on the youth employment problem. I consider it important that young people should not be disadvantaged by the relative lack of labour experience in the labour market and have fair conditions, as the active involvement of young people in the economic process is an important stimulus for future economic growth. Today's changing world also brings with it changing demands on young people's skills and knowledge. Quality education, support for student mobility and programmes such as Erasmus or traineeships is just an example of effective tools to reduce youth unemployment.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted for the Policy Report on Skills Development because it aims to combat youth unemployment. I am convinced that the education system should be more flexible in enabling the development of professional skills at every stage of a career. As youth unemployment is a priority issue, I believe it is imperative to adapt education systems to the needs of the labour market. In particular, I believe that France should be inspired by systems that work, for example in Germany, where learning is a sector considered in its own right and with very good opportunities.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non legislative and non-binding report. The report called for the EU to spend more money to spread information on European financing instruments. UKIP opposes the EU spending taxpayer’s money especially to put out such propaganda. There was a call to create an EU award for the best project that combats youth employment – this would be a complete waste of money and nothing more than a vanity project for the EU. It called for Member States to follow EU country-specific recommendations. It also wanted the EU to interfere with Member States’ education and national curriculum, suggesting what subjects should be taught – the EU has no competence in this area. It also called for more money and support for mobility programmes such as Erasmus which advertises British jobs across the EU. UKIP is the only party against open door immigration and will protect British jobs. The only people that should decide any of these things are our elected and accountable government, not unelected bureaucrats in Brussels.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report is considered that the alarming level of youth unemployment is one of the EU's most serious problems and a serious threat to social cohesion and economic development. To this end, I voted in favour of this report because I agree that the debate on youth unemployment should be based on the following factors: globalisation, demographic change, the economic crisis, new technologies and changes in the organisation of work. I also support business creation and self-employment as opportunities in the labour market. I also believe that a holistic approach that transcends the polarisation of sectoral policies is essential for the development of skills as a multidimensional process.  I also agree that education systems need to become more flexible so that it is possible to complete and develop knowledge and skills at all stages of the professional career. Finally, I welcome this report for setting out the need to involve higher education institutions and the economy sector, as well as the importance of identifying and describing the needs in terms of competence in the Member States, as there are differences between the various labour markets.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. The European Parliament has backed a key report this afternoon to tackle youth unemployment. In November 2015, according to Eurostat, 20% of young Europeans aged 15 to 24 were unemployed (27.8% in Brussels). Nearly 5 million young people are unemployed, while 2 million remain open. With a budget of 6 billion, the Union must be active to combat this problem which affects the economic development and social cohesion of its entire territory. I have, of course, supported this essential report, which emphasises greater flexibility in education systems in the face of an ever-changing labour market, in order to ensure a better match between the knowledge acquired and the skills needed for the labour market. Again, and it is not for want of repeating, education must work in line with companies to fight effectively against this scourge. A small step has just been taken, but clear improvements still need to be considered.

name: Robert Rochefort (ALDE)
text: In writing. Today, more than 7 million young Europeans are not working, studying or training. The youth unemployment rate is twice the unemployment rate in the EU. What future do we have in our European societies if we are not able to offer all our young people the opportunity to exploit and fully value their talents and entrepreneurial spirit? That is why I have spoken in favour of this resolution, which makes interesting proposals to combat youth unemployment. All levels of action - European, national, local - and all actors - public, private or from civil society - must participate in this effort, which must be collective and orderly. The levers of action such as education, internships, apprenticeships, lifelong learning must be activated, as well as European instruments such as Erasmus, the Youth Guarantee or EURES.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 There are currently 4.5 million young people aged 15-24 unemployed in the European Union and more than 7 million young Europeans in the same age group do not work, study and do not train. The unemployment rate at Union level was 9.9 % at the end of 2014 and the youth unemployment rate more than doubled this figure to 21.4 %. This seriously threatens the EU's social cohesion and economic development. The solution will be a new approach to factors such as globalisation, demographic change, the economic crisis, new technologies and changes in work organisation. An approach that re-focuss the economy on people and not the other way around.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. U2012 After long years of crisis, Europe has not been able to stop the drama of youth unemployment. Despite the launch by the Union institutions of initiatives such as the Youth Guarantee or the Youth Employment Initiative, it is urgent to tackle this drama from all fronts so as not to thwart the opportunities of an entire generation of young Europeans. Of course, active employment policies have a role to play in helping to solve this problem. As this report points out, the learning, acquisition and recognition of skills and skills by young people, whether they are studying, working or in an unemployment or non-activity situation, plays a key role both in dealing with faster and more stable integration into the labour market, as well as in improving the transition between studies and work and the quality of jobs and careers to be developed by younger generations of our society. For all this, I voted in favour.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. Vocational and flexible education, non-formal and innovative learning, workplace training, internships and mobility are all tools that Member States should strengthen to better develop the individual skills of young Europeans. This approach is contained in the resolution "on policies for skills development to combat youth unemployment", which was adopted yesterday in a plenary session in Strasbourg. The main message of the text, which has received very broad support, is that we now need to build more bridges between the world of education, which needs to be modernised (new teaching methods), and that of the company, which must benefit from the support of public authorities (regional, national and European). The aim is to facilitate the integration into the labour market of the five million young people aged 15 to 24 who are unemployed in the EU and the 7 million young Europeans who do not work, do not attend education or training.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. The scourge of youth unemployment today is a sad reality - unfortunately unavoidable in our European Union - already affecting some 5 million young Europeans. However, there are still 2 million jobs that remain unfilled. In order to address this reality and reduce the discrepancies between supply and demand for young work, the rapporteur proposes a set of measures in which I am reviewed. I now point out as a positive the promotion of greater articulation between educational institutions and the labour market (in particular meeting the needs of the latter) and the correct and effective channeling of European funds by Member States to encourage young entrepreneurship and, thereby, the creation of their own jobs. These are commendable initiatives which have earned my vote in favour of this matter.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. Youth unemployment continues to be a central economic and social problem. In fact, almost 5 million young people are unemployed in the EU, while at the same time almost 2 million jobs are not filled.  In order to address this problem, it is important to take account of changes in the labour market and thus adapt education systems in order to develop the knowledge and skills needed for different stages of professional careers.  In parallel with these changes, there is a need to strengthen the links between the education system, i.e. higher education institutions, and businesses.  Business creation and self-employment are also elements that can respond to the fight against youth unemployment. Finally, better absorption of EU funds by Member States is needed.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 We need to integrate the teaching that is given to young Europeans with new skills, such as entrepreneurial and communication skills, improve self-confidence, help them to open up their business and take risks and responsibilities. In addition, school-work alternation and on-the-job training must be strengthened by strengthening cooperation between educational institutions and the business world, as well as encouraging young people to participate in organisations representing their interests. Only in this way, by understanding the potential and weaknesses of these new generations, will we be able to overcome one of the scourges of the twenty-first century: youth unemployment.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report aims to identify the reasons for the structural obstacles young people face in finding employment, and aims to propose solutions. While most of the content of the final report is positive, as it calls for greater support for young people in skills development and employment, including increased public investment in education and, more specifically, in the transition from school to work, these aspects in the report are mere statements of intent, and the real impact on policies will be limited. The report places an excessive emphasis on the role of entrepreneurship as a solution to reducing youth unemployment. Continued references to the need to "better adjust skills to labour market needs" and the call for closer links between educational and vocational training institutions with companies to promote such adjustment skills-labor market in our view undermine content. That is why, although I cannot be in favour of the neoliberal approach to the text, I abstained in the vote on the report so as not to block important progress and positive aspects of the report.

name: Sven Schulze (PPE)
text: Writing. It was long overdue for us as a Parliament to draw up a catalogue of demands on what needs to be done to combat the rampant mass unemployment among young people.  What is important to me is that we design our education system in such a way that it can respond flexibly to changing requirements. And that we constantly adapt knowledge and competences to new requirements. This also applies to the entire career. The change of mentality is also important: we must ensure that young people want to start a business and risk something rather than look for a job with the state. Entrepreneurship, a desire for risk, creativity – that's what a society brings forward! We will make this change in schools if we better explain to young people how the economy works and that it is the basis of our prosperity and our options for action as a society. It is also important that we do not train past the needs of the labour market. As an engineer, the promotion of STEM subjects is therefore of particular concern to me. We need to give young people, and especially young women, an interest in this exciting training and highlight the great career opportunities in this area.

name: Olga Sehnalová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Alarmingly high youth unemployment is now one of Europe's most pressing problems. The untapped potential of the young generation is not only a loss for the European economy, but also has serious long-term socieal implications in the form of social exclusion of young people. I therefore appreciate the focus of this report and have supported the proposal.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I have not been able to vote in favour of this report, since although it does a good X-ray of the drama of youth unemployment in EU member countries, the recipes for addressing it are by no means appropriate to do so in my view. Instead of promoting the creation of public, stable and quality employment for young people, it proposes to encourage entrepreneurs and focus training towards market needs. That's why I abstained.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 Youth unemployment is one of the european Union's main challenges. Some figures give us a better understanding of the seriousness of this phenomenon: more than 7 million young Europeans, neither hired nor students or enrolled in training courses, a youth unemployment rate in the EU of 21.4% and at the same time a great many young skilled unemployed people whose skills unfortunately do not correspond to the needs of the labour market. The report voted on today seeks to put forward proposals to counter this alarming trend. In particular, it is stressed that, due to the changing labour market, we need more flexible education systems that allow the integration and development of knowledge and skills at all stages of the professional career and a review of school curricula to anticipate future market needs. It is also important for Member States to share good practice and work together to identify skills needs related to the jobs available. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 This own-initiative report once again highlights an important component of one of the european Union's greatest wounds, youth unemployment. It highlights that there are 24 million unemployed in Europe, including 7.5 million young people who do not work, study or train. In other words, 5% of the European population is made up of young unemployed people.  This problem reaches particularly high values in the outermost regions, including the Azores and Madeira. The report in question, which I voted on positively, recognises the efforts of the European Commission and the Member States and calls for further action, specifically mentioning the need for effective support for socially responsible, green and sustainable business projects. The report is extensive and includes interesting measures and I am pleased that they have been adopted by the European Parliament.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report because it calls for greater financial resources to be used to spread information on European financing instruments. This is more Commission interference that I cannot support.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Today I joined my Labour colleagues in supporting this report as it is incredibly crucial that young people have access to the required skills in today’s labour market. Tackling youth unemployment should be a top priority if Europe does not want to risk losing the potential of a whole generation. A first step must be to strengthen and implement properly the Youth Guarantee as well as the Youth Employment Initiative. It is fundamental to improve the positive long-term benefits of the opportunities offered to young people through meaningful training programmes and job placements. The UK Government needs to boost jobs, growth and investment to ensure that there are quality jobs for young people in the near future.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: in writing ‒ The fight against youth unemployment must be one of the EU's key priorities. The resolution adopted proposes a wide range of measures to be included in skills development policies to combat youth unemployment. Much attention is focused on education and investment supporting young people's entrepreneurship, at all levels of the education system. Investing in future generations is crucial to ensuring a prosperous future for Europe. Not neglecting young people is the most sensible step from older generations, and in legislation it is the responsibility of us politicians.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ The European Union faces a critical problem of youth unemployment, especially the fact that the unemployment rate varies drastically from one Member State to another. The extent of unemployment suggests that today around 4.5 million young Europeans (between 15-24 years old) are out of work and around 7 million are not in education or training. Since the causes of unemployment are numerous, it is extremely important to find an adequate way to approach each individual in order to identify the problem and define as urgent a plan as possible to solve it by enabling competitiveness in the labour market. I believe that the education system plays a big role because it represents the way to the labour market. Also, young people should be more active in dialogues between educational institutions and employers in order to be able to see their needs and react accordingly in the best possible way. It is necessary to overhaul the education system in terms of fostering entrepreneurship, understanding the economy, vocational skills, green jobs and jobs related to traditional skills, as they contribute not only to the individual, but also to the whole community.  For these reasons, given the particularly high youth unemployment rate in the Republic of Croatia, I supported the European Parliament resolution.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ there are currently around 4.5 million young people out of work in the EU. This means that around one in five Europeans under the age of 25 cannot find employment in the country where they live. I consider youth unemployment to be one of the EU's most serious problems and a serious threat to the EU's social cohesion and economic development, which is why I supported the proposed resolution in its entirety. It regrets that, despite many of Parliament's proposals, the situation of youth unemployment in several Member States has not improved significantly so far. I therefore expect these Member States to put an end to this situation as soon as possible and, with the immediate introduction of measures, ensure a dignified life and the possibility of gainful employment for young people and their families. Building on the current unflattering statistics on youth unemployment, it is our moral duty to do much more than before, because I believe that targeted investments will become one of the best and most promising investments for a better life for young people across Europe. I believe that Europe needs the potential, talent and skills of this group of people, so there is a very urgent immediate need to create jobs for young people in order to prevent long-term unemployment from developing.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. There are 4.5 million young people aged 14-24 in the EU. More than 7 million young Europeans of this age are not employed, studying or studying. At the end of 2014 the unemployment rate in the EU was 9.9% and more than twice higher among young people (21.4%). We can see that the financial and ingly-thral crisis has particularly affected young people.  The problem of youth unemployment extends mainly to two key problems. On the one hand, despite higher education and better qualifications compared to previous generations, young people continue to face significant structural barriers in finding quality employment. On the other hand, disadvantaged, discriminated and vulnerable people are often not given the opportunity to develop their talents, skills and skills, as social policy is not sufficiently taken into account.  I agree that sufficient financial resources must be allocated to education in order to solve this problem. The report promotes cooperation, participation and partnerships in the development of individual skills, the dissemination of knowledge and the creation of new jobs, growth and investment. It also highlights the key role of SMEs and social entrepreneurship in the problem and highlights the importance of equal opportunities for all young people.  I believe that the report adequately tackles the problem of youth unemployment and offers good solutions, which is why I voted in favour of its adoption.

name: Renato Soru (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the resolution on skills policies to combat youth unemployment, in response to the worrying unemployment rate of young people in Europe and Italy. At present, 4.5 million young people between the age of 15 and 24 in Europe are unemployed; At the end of 2014, the Union's unemployment rate was 9.9%, of which 21.4% was youth unemployment. I consider it a priority to solve the problem of youth unemployment in Europe, in particular through the acquisition by young people, during their training courses, of skills applicable to existing jobs and which favour their entry into the labour market. For this reason, close intersectorial cooperation between employment and education services is necessary in order to prepare students to carry out their work professionally, including by reviewing training programmes similar to market demands.

name: Bart Staes (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. This report highlights the importance of focusing on young people's skills in the fight against youth unemployment. Of course this is very important, but it is not a panacea. We will not solve youth unemployment by simply focusing on skills. Green amendments ensured that this report now also focuses on the problem of structural unemployment. We need to increase the supply of quality jobs and create structural and sustainable jobs for all.  Education is not only intended to prepare young people for the labour market, but is also very important for the personal development of young people. This can therefore lead to finding an appropriate job. Every young person is different. This must be taken into account when learning skills.  Social actors should be supported in training and job creation. We must dare to invest in sectors with a future, especially in clean technology and green jobs. And we need to give young start-ups and SMEs a boost so that they can develop their own initiatives.  Betting on equal opportunities is also important, especially for people with disabilities. Because everyone needs to be able to develop their skills to the full, I voted in favour.

name: Joachim Starbatty (ECR)
text: Writing. The Plura report deals with education and training issues to reduce youth unemployment. There are currently 7.5 million unemployed young people in the EU. These are particularly concentrated in the regions of southern Europe particularly affected by the euro crisis. At the same time, there are 2 million vacancies in the EU, which are often unfilled because the required skills are not available on the labour market. The Plura report makes proposals to adapt training more closely to demand without too much interfere with the competences of the Member States. It is also committed to promoting small and medium-sized enterprises, which create a large proportion of new jobs, and also to the acceptance and promotion of entrepreneurship.  Unfortunately, the EU, and the European Parliament in particular, continue to fail to recognise the importance of the single currency, the euro, for the emergence and persistence of mass unemployment. The Plura report is no exception, but it is a good report within the framework of what is politically possible and I have therefore given my assent.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: writing – Adequate preparation of young people for the labour market is key to combating youth unemployment. Partnerships need to be established in education and training at both national and transnational level so that young people's work skills match labour market demand. At the same time, there is a need to improve the quality of education and training, including through businesses. It is essential that young people acquire new skills for future young entrepreneurs and also participate in non-formal education in order to develop communication and decision-making skills.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ At the end of 2014, the unemployment rate in the Union was 9.9% and the youth unemployment rate was more than double that of 21.4%. Today we have almost 5 million unemployed young people, but 2 million jobs are still available. Lack of relevant skills for available jobs and lack of education and training are important factors leading to youth unemployment. The development of individual skills and the dissemination of knowledge are some of the key elements of integrated employment and social policies that can help enable long-term growth, promote European competitiveness, combat unemployment and build a more inclusive European society if skills development policies recognise the multi-layered needs and abilities of young people who are unemployed. The report encourages the creation of flexible education systems that will develop young people's professional skills, and I have therefore supported it.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Labour MEPs supported this report as it is critical that young people have access to the required skilled in today’s labour market. However, the UK Government needs to boost jobs, growth and investment to ensure that there are quality jobs for young people.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. I support this draft report, as the problem of unemployment, especially among young people, is one of the most important problems of the European Union. Unemployment is a major problem in many Member States, and it is particularly worrying that the unemployment rate somewhere stands at as high as 50%. This draft report proposes more flexibility in education and employment. Market trends are changing rapidly, and they need to be followed by an education policy that needs to respond to change and organise educational programmes according to market needs. Flexibility is among the key factors of the modern economy, so we need flexible education and employment. More work needs to be done to promote self-employment and encourage young people to move into the world of entrepreneurship. We need to make every effort to reduce the number of unemployed, especially young people, to as low a level as possible and to stop the trend of increasingly later entry into the labour market.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on skills acquisition policies in the fight against youth unemployment.  The financial crisis that engulfed the whole of the European Union years ago still shows the consequences in some Member States today. The consequences are most significant in youth unemployment, which is really worrying in some regions.  Around 5 million young people under the age of 25 were unemployed in the European Union last year. That's a huge number. In some Member States, more than 25% of young people between the age of 15 and 25 are unemployed.  I therefore welcome the report, which recognises this and notes that the development of individual skills and the dissemination of knowledge and skills are two of the main elements of an integrated employment and social policy and can enable long-term growth, promote European competitiveness, eliminate unemployment and create a more inclusive European society.

name: Pavel Svoboda (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on skills policies to combat youth unemployment, as I believe it is important to reflect this issue. This is not a legislative report, but 'only' a text by which the European Parliament contributes to the debate on this subject, yet it contains an interesting summary of the situation and proposals for possible solutions. I believe that the solution is not purely to support one sector of education, but to take a more sophisticated approach in response to the current digital economy, where the precondition for employment in the labour market is primarily the ability to make independent decisions, analyse, knowledge of foreign languages, etc. These are the prerequisites for subsequent active access to a career path.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 Elements such as the interconnection of the business world with education systems, the mobility of young people for practical exercises or to find work, but even voluntary unpaid work are the main components proposed by the rapporteur of the report to address youth unemployment in the EU.
