Obviously there is no mention of a public investment policy for industrialisation or of a state-long-term job creation policy, which will, on the one hand, train young people to work there and, on the other hand, provide guarantees for the creation of parallel industries that will absorb young unemployed people. On the contrary, it leaves the problem of youth unemployment completely in the hands of market freedom, even going so far as to accept unpaid internships as a means of gaining experience to strengthen the CV of young people.  Although GUE/NGL has tabled amendments to improve the report, elements such as the full dependence of the fight against unemployment on the already failed youth guarantee programme and the utopian 'Juncker Plan' for investment do not allow us to vote in favour of the report because we do not see anything promising in it beyond the trivial, failed policies already in place.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 Alarming levels of youth unemployment are nowadays one of the most intractable problems in the EU. Unfortunately, however, the ways in which political arrangements and initiatives are formulated to combat youth unemployment presented in the report do not agree with me. Firstly, it is argued in the report that a primary factor in solving the problem to be taken into account is globalisation. It is also argued that the role played in youth civil society by trade unions is beneficial. Internships or apprenticeships abroad are also persistently advertised and EURES and Erasmus+ are displayed. Finally, the existence of NGOs as a tool to promote entrepreneurship is underlined and highlighted.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Parliament resolution adopted today focuses on youth unemployment (Hungary higher than the EU average (22%) 1.5% better) and aims to give the European Union an even more effective response so that nearly half a million young people in Hungary can find jobs as soon as possible in a Europe with only two million vacancies. The decision fits the trend that the Union has finally recognised that the situation of the nearly 12 million European citizens who have been out of work for a long time must also be addressed, and that young people are particularly disadvantaged because they have either no or little experience or modern knowledge. The report basically mentions two dimensions of capabilities: the need to strengthen general so-called basic skills and to continue to specialise in competitive knowledge. It also emphasises the responsibility of economic life and the business-financial sector. Youth unemployment is also a challenge in terms of starting a family, not to mention the increasing challenges of competitive competences (IT skills, start-ups, etc.) in training systems, which must respond and adapt to market requirements and development, in line with local and regional specificities. With my vote, I followed the People's Party position by saying that the principle of subsidiarity is fundamental and the efforts of the Member States are indispensable.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because for the 4.5 million young unemployed people in the European Union between the ages of 15 and 24, every day without a job, the future will become increasingly uncertain, with many professions running a shortage of labour. This degree of coordination of education and training with the labour market requires an immediate response at European level. The report makes a number of proposals that would help us to do an effective and wide-ranging response to the employment crisis affecting young people. I support the point in the report calling for solid partnerships between local authorities, education and employment services, the social partners and business communities. It is also a useful point on the part of the reporter to involve young, innovative employers in the dialogue between educational institutions and employers in order to better adapt education and training to labour market requirements. In addition, I consider the recommendation to educate entrepreneurship to be of paramount importance. However, in order to achieve this objective, it is essential to reduce the administrative and financial requirements emphasised by the report, to make it easier for start-ups to access loans, risk capital and microfinance, to introduce personalised consultancy or measures to encourage entrepreneurs who may be employing young unemployed people.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Education, including in the field of entrepreneurship, is a key element in combating youth unemployment. However, education must be subordinated to market expectations and opportunities so that young graduates or vocational school pupils are able to enter the labour market faster and more effectively. In order to do so, it is necessary to ensure closer cooperation between the education sector and business, as well as the inclusion of young people and organisations representing their interests in measures to improve their situation on the labour market. The EP report properly emphasises the need to promote high-quality traineeships or so-called dual education, which allows young people to acquire and apply the knowledge necessary for the profession. As has rightly been pointed out, the new generation, which was brought up in an era of rapid technological progress, has different talents, expectations or opportunities than previous generations. It is therefore important that Member States, when carrying out their employment policies, adapt them to the changing reality. I therefore decided to vote in favour of the EP's strategy on skills acquisition to combat youth unemployment.

name: Dario Tamburrano (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report addresses the problem of youth unemployment, one of the biggest problems we have in the European Union today. Many of the amendments tabled by our fellow spokeswoman, Laura Agea, have been adopted and incorporated into the report to our great satisfaction. The incorporated amendments stressed: the important role of European funds when used efficiently; the dissemination of information on European funding instruments also in universities and businesses; the need to reduce the risks of early school leaving; effective implementation of the youth guarantee, which can help to reduce unemployment among young people by creating new job opportunities. The report also emphasises the fundamental role of education systems: they must be more flexible in order to allow the development of knowledge and skills appropriate to today's job opportunities. The role of SMEs and micro-enterprises as strategic learning workshops for young people and a possible place for training and learning is also highlighted.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. This text provides an opportunity to recall the essential role of companies, particularly SMEs, social and solidarity economy players and micro-enterprises, in training vocational skills and creating jobs for young people. It is important to highlight the need to provide young people with an education that introduces them to entrepreneurship in the broadest possible way. We must advocate for training programmes to include the development, in a safe environment, of the professional skills necessary to set up and run businesses, and for the cross-cutting entrepreneurial skills, skills and knowledge that are actually acquired through real and concrete experiences to be fostered.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report on skills policies for fighting youth employment. Today almost 5 million young people are unemployed in the EU while there are 2 million unfilled job vacancies: action is needed to bridge the gap. The report acknowledges the existing generational gap and calls for a better understanding of the digital skills of young people: rapid technological progress are not always matched by the current education and recruitment systems. The report calls for increased cooperation between local authorities, social partners and education providers to ensure a more strategic use of EU funds in this area. Over the past years, the labour market has faced tremendous changes which require more flexible education systems. In this sense, I also welcome the provisions of this report on the role of enterprises, including SMEs, in job creation, the employment of young people, but also in training, for instance thanks to professional experience throughout and after the education cycle. In this respect, for example, I believe Member States should take an active part in the Erasmus Programme for Young Entrepreneurs to encourage young people to lead business projects across the EU and develop new skills.

name: Isabelle Thomas (S&D)
text: In writing. Youth unemployment is at an unacceptable level. More than 23% of our young people are unemployed. Faced with the risk of losing an entire generation, the European Union takes its responsibilities and proposes to the Member States to implement the necessary measures.  With this conviction, I chose to vote for this report. By recognising the fundamental right to education and training, it points to the need for investment in education, a main tool for qualification and success for young people. In addition, this report stresses the need to create quality jobs: the new generation must not become that of precariousness! Above all, we call for the strengthening of the Youth Guarantee: every young person must be offered a training solution or a job. However, this position of the European Parliament, already defended in the vote on the 2016 budget, was rejected by the Commission and the Council during the budgetary procedure.  There is an urgent need, the Commission must come up with a concrete proposal: our young people will not accept to be sacrificed in the name of austerity, the Youth Guarantee must continue in 2017!

name: Patrizia Toia (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Youth unemployment is a scourge for our society. Fighting it must be our priority. We need more flexible education systems, multidisciplinarity, support for entrepreneurial culture and greater school-work links. I consider it extremely important to involve young people in decision-making, to create partnerships between local authorities, employment services and businesses. Adequate training must also be provided for local authorities in order to use European funds more effectively and strategically. I believe it is essential to ensure entrepreneurship training at all levels of education, to remove administrative and financial obstacles to business start-ups and management by simplifying procedures, and to ensure easier access to microfinance and credit.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ Although there are many vacancies in the European Union, a large number of young people remain unemployed. I believe that we need to give young people better access to the labour market through cooperation and interaction between local authorities, educational institutions and employment services, which are the main proposals for this resolution. In particular, I support the part of the report that focuses on differences in labour markets in the Member States. I also believe that the proposed exchange of good practices in vocational education and training can help countries reduce unemployment of young people, especially young people with disabilities. I believe that the importance of preserving and transferring crafts and professions containing traditional and cultural elements to young generations is also recognized. However, the necessity of acquiring skills related to science, technology, engineering and mathematics, which are essential for the professional development of an individual in the 21st century, is also not neglected.  I believe that the implementation of these recommendations will lead to a reduction in youth unemployment and that is why I supported this resolution.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the report on skills acquisition policies in the fight against youth unemployment, as there is still a high unemployment rate in the EU, where almost 5 million young people are out of work and, on the other hand, 2 million jobs are unococ between them, a really worrying and pressing problem.  I believe that this proposal is the next step towards improving the whole system, enabling the complementarity and development of the skills of young people at all stages of their careers and linking cooperation more closely between educational institutions and the economic sector. Only in this way can we reduce the gap that arises in the market between demand and job supply.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report aims to identify the reasons for the structural obstacles young people face in finding employment, and aims to propose solutions. While most of the content of the final report is positive, as it calls for greater support for young people in skills development and employment, including increased public investment in education and, more specifically, in the transition from school to work, these aspects in the report are mere statements of intent, and the real impact on policies will be limited. The report places an excessive emphasis on the role of entrepreneurship as a solution to reducing youth unemployment. Continued references to the need to "better adjust skills to labour market needs" and the call for closer links between educational and vocational training institutions with companies to promote such adjustment skills-labor market in our view undermine content. That is why, although I cannot be in favour of the neoliberal approach to the text, I abstained in the vote on the report so as not to block important progress and positive aspects of the report.

name: Ulrike Trebesius (ECR)
text: Writing. The Plura report deals with education and training issues to reduce youth unemployment. There are currently 7.5 million unemployed young people in the EU. These are particularly concentrated in the regions of southern Europe particularly affected by the euro crisis. At the same time, there are 2 million vacancies in the EU, which are often unfilled because the required skills are not available on the labour market. The Plura report makes proposals to adapt training more closely to demand without too much interfere with the competences of the Member States. It is also committed to promoting small and medium-sized enterprises, which create a large proportion of new jobs, and also to the acceptance and promotion of entrepreneurship.  Unfortunately, the EU, and the European Parliament in particular, continue to fail to recognise the importance of the single currency, the euro, for the emergence and persistence of mass unemployment. The Plura report is no exception, but it is a good report within the framework of what is politically possible and I have therefore given my assent.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I support any measure that will help reduce youth unemployment. Whereas the micro, small and medium-sized enterprises represent more than 80% of all jobs, it is important to facilitate and simplify the creation of these businesses. It is also necessary to continue improving the education system, to facilitate the mobility of young people in Europe, improving the efficiency of public administrations and improving the relationship between training and business.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. The problem of youth unemployment is beginning to take an endemic turn. One of the main measures to support their entry into the labour market would be to promote the development of skills, rather than diplomas. This idea somehow confirms the failure of national education and vocational training systems. Most of the proposed measures are difficult to implement in the current context where Member States are forced to adopt limited budgets. It is clear that policies for the integration of young people into the labour market must be carried out first at the regional and local level, not at European level! Public service networks are able to support young people in the transition to employment, in partnership with associations or private organizations, as well as with businesses. Therefore, it is not necessary for the EU to deal with it. The idea of developing entrepreneurship to encourage young people to create their own jobs is a recurring idea whose scope will be marginal in a particularly difficult economic context. Moreover, this interest in youth entrepreneurship is sometimes only an instrument used to "occupy" young people and thus get them out of the unemployment figures. I therefore vote against this report.

name: Mihai Ţurcanu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on skills development policies to combat youth unemployment, as 4.5 million young people aged 15 to 24 are unemployed and more than 7 million young Europeans are not working or are currently in education or training in the European Union.  It should not be forgotten that young people are the engine of the European economy, so there is a need for important investments in their education so that they acquire the professional skills sought in the labour market. In this respect, strong cooperation between educational institutions, businesses, social partners and authorities is needed to develop more efficient and up-to-date training programmes with a view to acquiring new skills, as well as facilitating access to training opportunities and improved systems of continuous vocational and technical education. With this in mind, professionalisation activities, such as traineeships, which are a first step in the introduction of young people into the labour market, should increasingly be favoured in all Member States. Moreover, cultivating entrepreneurship among young people can lead to a decrease in the unemployment rate for them and boost their employability.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour as reducing employment policies for young people to skills policies is not enough to combat structural youth unemployment. We need to shift from a debate about labour supply and labour demand and focus on changing economic policies which increase unemployment and inequality. This includes investing in the creation of quality jobs for young people.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. This is a topic of particular importance. Youth unemployment is an issue that we must combat to ensure opportunities for a generation of young Europeans who are now encountering great labour difficulties. The development of the youth employment initiative, aid for the creation of small businesses, the promotion of youth entrepreneurship in all sectors, the promotion of training actions for the youth unemployed as well as coordination between local, national and European authorities through employment offices in order to promote the encounter of professional opportunities is vital today. Further action is needed to help young Europeans find career exits, especially those aimed at helping those who neither study nor work. This report is responsible for pointing out policies that can help combat youth unemployment, so I think it is necessary to vote in its favour.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I have not been able to vote in favour of this report, since although it does a good X-ray of the drama of youth unemployment in EU member countries, the recipes for addressing it are by no means appropriate to do so in my view. Instead of promoting the creation of public, stable and quality employment for young people, it proposes to encourage entrepreneurs and focus training towards market needs. That's why I abstained.

name: Derek Vaughan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I was happy to vote with my Labour colleagues in supporting this report. Youth unemployment and the issues surrounding young people who are neither in education nor training are factors across the EU. Therefore, it is useful that Parliament is helping to develop a strategy to combat youth unemployment with this document. Labour MEPs supported this report as it is critical that young people have access to the required skilled in today’s labour market. However, the UK Government needs to boost jobs, growth and investment to ensure that there are quality jobs for young people. This report’s stress on identifying key skills that will be needed in the current and future market is highly important, as is its emphasis on the need for high—quality apprentices.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. 'I voted in favour of this report on skills-based policies to combat youth unemployment in the European Union. In Europe, we have 4.5 million young people out of work and 2 million vacancies that are not filled. Measures are therefore needed to bridge this gap. After all, high youth unemployment is a major threat to the economic and social future of our continent.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The least that can be said is that youth unemployment is of great concern in Europe, with the rate rising to 21.4% at the end of 2014, double the overall unemployment rate and rising to 50% in some EU states, including Greece and Spain.  The aim of the report was to identify the causes of youth unemployment and to propose different solutions to address it.   The report is far from up to the challenge. It always offers the same inadequate recipes, including starting a business as a "sustainable" way to reduce unemployment when we know that it is a dangerous approach, especially in the long term. What about the so-called need to balance the skills of young people with the demand of the market, which still demands to adapt to the needs of businesses?  The content has certainly been improved by the adoption of the majority of the amendments of my GUE group in the parliamentary committee, such as the creation of safer and more sustainable jobs, particularly in the social and solidarity economic sector and in renewable energies, or the desire to strengthen the initiative for youth employment. In the end, I chose to abstain.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Youth unemployment rates of 30% or even higher – are the mirror of an EU that promotes unemployment in order to better exploit who works. And the main victims of this exploitation are young people who suffer from precariousness and low wages. The Policies and Impositions of the European Union, particularly in recent years in the troika-intervened countries, have been condemning young people to unemployment, precariousness and forced emigration. That's the reality. The policies of labor deregulation, low wages, the unaccountability of the State for employment policies, the commodification of education, with the increase in its frequency costs and the prevalence of said acquisition of skills and market orientation to the detriment of the integral training of the individual – all this contributes to the dramatic situation experienced today by millions of young workers. False solutions, such as entrepreneurship, this new and modern fallacy of neoliberalism, or so-called mobility, are a true deception through which one intends to cure the disease with the germ causing the same disease. The solution is to break with these policies and break with those who impose them. This depends on the present and the future of young people.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. The report contains a number of good suggestions and legitimate concerns about what support deserves. I think it is reasonable to include vocational orientation in the curricula. I also believe that linking training centres with companies is a tried and tested means of contributing to the reduction of youth unemployment. I therefore agree with this report.

name: Daniele Viotti (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, which promotes policies to combat youth unemployment through the development of new skills required by the labour market. The problem of youth unemployment affects millions of young European citizens, and its reduction remains one of the priorities, otherwise Europe will lose an entire generation. Governments must commit to the proper implementation of the Youth Employment Initiative and the Youth Guarantee. It is essential to increase the long-term benefits of the opportunities we offer to this section of the population.

name: Udo Voigt (NI)
text: Writing. As long as EU policy is unable to establish effective borders against uncontrolled mass immigration, all additional measures against youth unemployment are eye-watering; therefore rejection.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. I abstained from the European Parliament's resolution on education and training policies to reduce youth unemployment. The report has light – but also a shadow: it emphasises, among other things, that one of the Commission's top priorities is to provide 'new impetus for jobs, growth and investment'. It calls for an EU award for the best projects to reduce youth unemployment, to be awarded the Europe-wide European Youth Prize. It calls for a forward-looking and results-oriented European skills strategy as a guideline for national skills strategies and their integration into national employment plans, while providing a comprehensive framework for the sectoral action plans proposed in the employment package. I see this differently and do not believe that the Commission should take action in these areas. I cannot therefore agree with my group's positive assessment.

name: Jarosław Wałęsa (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The changing macroeconomic situation of the world makes it increasingly difficult to keep up with the expectations of a rapidly changing labour market. In line with the EU Youth Strategy, the European Parliament points to close cooperation between institutions at local, regional, national, European and Member States level. It is right that youth policy must be based on promoting activity, entrepreneurship, strengthening competences, mobility and flexibility in a potential labour market.  The proposed measures to combat unemployment should be based on facilities for harmonising the education system while being able to be an active person. For this reason, an initiative should be taken to modernise the education system and thus to adapt curricula to current and future labour market forecasts.  Another equally important element is the promotion of self-employment. Actions aimed at supporting initiatives and promoting individuality. The young people community should have the opportunity to acquire and deepen the necessary knowledge aimed at setting up their own business, raising funds in order to be able to productively meet their professional objectives.

name: Julie Ward (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Together with my Labour colleagues, I supported this report as it is critical that young people have access to developing relevant skills for today’s labour market. However, the UK Government needs to boost jobs, sustainable growth and investment to ensure that there are quality jobs for young people. I also want to recall the need to promote curriculum objectives for formal and non-formal education, as well as lifelong learning, targeting all students – both theoretical modules and practical modules, such as student enterprise, including social enterprise projects, working with local communities.

name: Glenis Willmott (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Labour MEPs supported this report as it is critical that young people have access to the required skills in today’s labour market. The report includes proposals to strengthen co-ordination between education institutions and local employers, improve the quality of career guidance at schools and calling for protection for trainees and apprentices. However, the UK Government needs to boost growth and investment to ensure that there are quality jobs for young people.

name: Iuliu Winkler (PPE)
text: in writing. – I welcome the adoption of the own-initiative report on skills development policies to combat youth unemployment.  I voted for this report which emphasises the need to develop more flexible education systems that enable the completion and development of knowledge and skills at all stages of my professional career. In this report, the issue of youth unemployment is addressed taking into account globalisation, demographic changes, the economic crisis, new technologies and changes in the organisation of work.

name: Anna Záborská (PPE)
text: In writing ‒ my colleague Plura is sleeping in writing ‒ it is important that it does not allow this Parliament's interest in participating in tackling high youth unemployment in the European Union to be downed. This, especially in some Member States, is truly appalling and is declining only slowly. It is right that special attention is paid to small and medium-sized enterprises, which are the backbone of the economy. But I didn't find a single mention of family businesses in the text. It is a pity, because the everyday example of parents trying to build, maintain or expand a business they have set up or inherited through their own work is the best work experience for a young person. Family entrepreneurship not only has an economic dimension, but also develops the ethics of entrepreneurship and responsibility that extends beyond the horizon of one generation.

name: Θεόδωρος Ζαγοράκης (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, as I do for any initiative that seeks to increase jobs in Europe and reduce unemployment, especially among younger people. We must in every way support the new generations.

name: Pablo Zalba Bidegain (PPE)
text: in writing. Although the youth unemployment rate has improved in the last year, it remains significantly high, at around 20.7%, according to Eurostat data. This high number of young people without work has a negative impact on both economic growth and productivity and effective measures must be taken as soon as possible to stem this situation. Among the main risks posed by youth unemployment are the loss of talent and skills of young people (since they do not have the possibility to implement them in the world of work), the reduction of production and GDP, and the increase in economic costs, where as greater investment in social subsidies is needed and there is less money from paying taxes. That is why I fully support this report, as I am confident in an economic recovery and the EU's ability to offer young people decent work tailored to their knowledge and skills.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Youth unemployment is a long-term EU problem that requires a solution as quickly as possible. I am in favour of deeper cooperation between schools and employers, which leads to adapting teaching to the specific needs of the current labour market. Only creative teaching in schools and top-educated teachers can pass on skills to make it easier for young people to apply themselves to the labour market. I have long supported youth entrepreneurship, especially in the form of start-ups, through which fresh projects of talented young people get a chance. I consider it necessary to link theoretical teaching with practical training, which significantly facilitates the transition from the educational process to the employment process.

name: Janusz Zemke (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I support the report prepared by the European Parliament's Committee on Employment and Social Affairs. This is an important report because we still have 24 million unemployed people in Europe, including 7.5 million young people who are not studying or working. At the same time, we have more than 2 million vacant jobs in the European Union. Similar problems also occur in Poland and in my Kujawsko-Pomeranian Voivodeship. Many young people have qualifications that do not coincide with labour market demand. The report rightly emphasises the need for a greater link between the education system and businesses and institutions. There is also a need to develop on a wider scale the skills in technology, engineering and mathematics that are increasingly needed in the modern economy. In my opinion, EU measures supporting national education systems and small and medium-sized enterprises should be a broader stream for these purposes.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Report on skills policies to combat youth unemployment because I believe that the high level of youth unemployment is currently one of the most urgent problems in the European Union, with almost five million young people unemployed, a situation that seriously threatens social cohesion and economic development of the Union.  Whereas the lack of skills relevant to the available jobs and the inadequate learning and training are important factors causing unemployment among young people and whereas, without the creation of quality, sustainable and efficient jobs in Europe, it is not possible to solve the youth employment crisis, it is then of great importance to strengthen European efforts to create mechanisms to promote young employment in Europe.  In this regard, I believe that it is essential to create policies that better adapt existing qualifications to the needs of the labour market; create quality jobs and support education and training systems, which are regarded as fundamental rights. In essence, it is important to improve the long-term benefits of the opportunities offered to young people while promoting Europe's economic growth.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The report reflects on the unemployment figures affecting the European Union in the context of the so-called financial crisis, focusing mainly on youth unemployment - unemployment in the EU was 9.9% in 2014, with youth unemployment at 21.4%. It therefore proposes a number of policy definitions in terms of skills to combat youth unemployment. The report has some positive conceptions, focusing on increasing qualifications, criticising education policies aimed at increasing frequency costs, calling for more effective use of funding, valuing local economies and traditional know-how as an employability option, affirming holistic education (against the trend of specialisation), not exploiting trainees, equal opportunities for people from disadvantaged groups. However, there are some considerations that are easing the report, especially the tendency to adapt curricula and programs and the educational/training offer to the needs of the labor market. On the other hand, the appreciation of entrepreneurship and the inclusion of entrepreneurship in school programs are also issues that deserve opposition. Finally, the affirmation of mobility as a response to the problems of youth unemployment is a negative issue in the report.

name: Marco Zullo (EFDD)
text: in writing. Reducing the alarming level of youth unemployment is now one of the EU's main challenges. At the same time, there are two million jobs that are not properly trained. This situation poses a serious threat to the EU's social cohesion and economic development.  The 5Stelle Movement has worked this text by proposing amendments against youth unemployment and working to ensure that they are adopted. The report, which I voted in favour of, stresses the importance of having more flexible education systems that allow knowledge and skills to be integrated and increased at all stages of the professional career. It also highlights the key role played by businesses, including SMEs, actors in the social and solidarity economy, as well as micro-enterprises in training professional skills and creating jobs for young people. The text also highlights the need to provide young people with an education that prepares them for entrepreneurship as widely as possible. It needs to be clarified what the real employment needs are for the future and what areas of employment development for young people, focusing on the social and green economy, which are the objective of the coming years.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. \ 2012 Young people should be allowed to join the labour market. The EU faces youth unemployment directly in two ways: financial assistance and policies to acquire the necessary skills. Parliament has already adopted many financial frameworks that facilitate the position of young people in employment. It is not only the Youth Guarantee scheme, but also many other projects, including those in the field of education and training, which are now coming together under Erasmus+, which I follow as the EP's permanent rapporteur. In addition to financial assistance, we are working to improve the employability of young people in the EU by modernising and adapting education.  I supported the report because it underlines the important issues we have been talking about in the EP for many years: better response of education systems to the needs of the labour market, the importance of STEM skills, the importance of quality vocational training and the importance of the effective absorption of European funds by the Member States. It also mentions helping young people set up their own businesses. The self-employment of young people has a particular value.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I was happy to support this report. I consider the Digital Single Market to be one of the main themes of the European Parliament and the Commission for this parliamentary term. If some principles could be enforced, such as strengthening the online sales of goods and services in cross-border trade, then I would be very satisfied.  In short, we have Schengen, we do not have internal borders between states, but in the area of digital markets we still have borders and they need to be dismantled. The research that has been done clearly shows that today, for example, companies sell their goods significantly on the Internet within their nation states, but across borders this figure is very small. So for the Czech Republic, from which I come, I can say that 26% of Czech small and medium-sized companies sell on the Internet in the Czech Republic, but only 7% cross-border. It is therefore clear that the rules need to be adapted so that cross-border sales within the European Union can work online, and this material is intended to do so. That is why I supported it.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, we abstained in the vote on the report on the digital single market because, although we are committed to the decision to adapt the economy to the new digital age, we do not share the eternal mantra that greater competition and a single market are always the solution for the European economy to create sustainable and quality jobs. This report risks favouring large companies more than SMEs and citizens. We have advocated amendments to make the digital market a reflection of the society we want today. That is why we must ensure data protection and go further in defending net neutrality as basic principles for the digital equality of citizens. The Internet must be, to this day, a global space for communication, participation and democratic transformation, such as in the Arab springs. The Internet shouldn't just be a new business space.

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI).
text: – I voted in favour of the report on the digital market, but I was saddened to read in point C of the report that only 14% of small businesses use the Internet as a sales channel. I think that microenterprises are involved in this, and so before my eyes I saw my personal acquaintances and girlfriends who are at home mostly with small children, elderly parents, etc., and produce wonderful things, handicrafts, souvenirs or even Hungarian jams and syrups based on old recipes. I'd like to sell these. They could have a very good business out of this, a good livelihood. Why isn't this option used? I will not be restless, and if I go home, I will look for the right bodies and ask what the data is like at home in Hungary for internet sales for micro and small businesses, and especially what the data would be for women, because for them this would be a particularly convenient and plausifiable solution. How can this data be improved? I'd appreciate it if you'd use your hammer more frequently on the left, Mr. President.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D).
text: - Mr. President, traders based in the European Union are obliged to comply with strict european legislation rules, such as a 14-day deadline for abandoning purchases. This is fair to customers because they buy on the unseen, but it creates huge costs for the retailer. On the other hand, more than 60% of EUROPEAN Union citizens are afraid to shop online because they are unsure what their rights are in case of problems. It is very difficult for the average consumer to determine whether an online retailer is based in the European Union or not.  By introducing a recognizable label, customers will find it easier to identify who they can shop with confidence, and honest traders will be privileged in the face of competition that does not comply with European directives. The issue of delivery also needs to be regulated. It needs to be more transparent and cheaper. We can't expect a big growth in the online marketplace as long as shoppers fear they might get a brick instead of a cell phone.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D).
text: – In the wake of the digital age, the European Union must fully realise the potential and opportunities offered by the internet and e—commerce for the further development of the single market. The digital revolution provides a limitless array of opportunities to revolutionise each and every sector of the European economy and to change the life of each and every one of us. Completion of the digital single market, making it available to all EU citizens, is essential in achieving a knowledge-driven economy that would foster competitiveness and economic growth and provide highly—qualified jobs in Europe. It is important that citizens, consumers, SMEs and all those in the most vulnerable position are provided with efficient protection and affordable access to redress in the online world. Citizens need to better understand how to benefit and take full advantage of the digital revolution by using smart technologies and services. Businesses, in particular SMEs, need to be better prepared for the digitalisation of traditional industries so that Europe is equipped for the tasks and demands of the future.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the text we have voted on clearly defines the opportunities and challenges facing Europe in building a truly integrated digital single market, and I hope that the Commission will seize its input. Harmonised rules on cross-border trade must be laid down, capable of legally protecting consumers and businesses when buying and selling digital content, just as, with regard to the reform of copyright rules, rules must be put in place that focus on fair and adequate remuneration of creators and other rightholders. We need to arrive at an appropriate legal framework with regard to the fight against piracy and illegal content on the Internet, which will definitively clarify the role of intermediaries and online platforms. Only if the European Union is able to move in this direction, with particular attention being paid to the opportunities offered by Big Data, cloud computing and the Internet of Things, will the digital single market really become a driving force for growth and development capable of creating quality jobs and for young people.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – A Uachtaráin, arís thug mé tacaíocht don tuarascáil seo agus vótáil mé le mo ghrúpa sna vótaí go léir. Gan dabht ar bith is ábhar an-tábhachtach é seo agus tagann sé leis an dá ábhar a bhíomar a lua ó chianaibh, is é sin dífhostaíocht i measc an aosa óg agus fiontar agus gnó a chothú i measc na mban. Gan dabht ar bith is iontach an seans é seo don Aontas. Is féidir linn a lán jabanna a chothú gan aon chaiteachas airgid phoiblí a bheith againn. Deirtear gur féidir linn EUR 415 billiún a chothú do gheilleagar na hEorpa má éiríonn linn é seo a dhéanamh i gceart. Agus sin í an cheist: an féidir linn é a dhéanamh i gceart? Chun é sin a dhéanamh i gceart, caithfimid páirc imeartha léibhéalta a chothú, na bacanna do lucht gnó a chaitheamh amach agus é a dhéanamh níos éasca do shaoránaigh earraí a dhíol agus a cheannach ar an idirlíon.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, I was happy to support this report on the Digital Single Market because I think it provides a framework for our digital future. However, I did not support Amendment 24, even though it was an ALDE amendment.  This amendment – rightly I believe – tried to introduce a balance, in that it recognises that digitalisation increases autonomy and flexibility but, as well as that, it gives rise to new challenges, for example in regard to working time, burnout etc. However, I supported the original text because it asked the Commission to conduct a study on the spillover effects of digitalisation and how it impacts greater labour intensity, flexibility, family life etc., as well as the development of the cognitive abilities of children. I know the world is going digital, but that does not mean that all is well and that we just blindly move forward without considering the possible negative effects of digitalisation. The digital market, like any other, does not in itself guarantee good outcomes. We need to look at its effects, positive and negative. We need to accentuate the positive and mitigate and minimise the negative.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU aims to create a digital single market that expands the digital economy, while ensuring more competitive services for consumers and growth for businesses. The strategy is to facilitate online access to products and services across Europe, through a long and progressive legislative path on infrastructure investment, increased citizen participation in digital life and new rules for online commerce. To date, in fact, only 15% of citizens buy online from another country and only 7% of companies sell in another EU country. I therefore voted in favour, in view of the fact that the creation of a fully functioning digital single market could benefit the European economy and, above all, its citizens.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report by representing a clear, progressive and ambitious roadmap for a true Digital Single Market, through the removal of barriers to creating new online opportunities for citizens and businesses, especially SMEs.   The digital revolution is changing Europe radically and has great potential for the creation of millions of new skilled jobs and new opportunities for consumers. I therefore welcome the development of this motion for a Resolution to promote legislative and non-legislative measures for the benefit of consumers and to preserve the competitiveness of our social market economy.  As a socialist, I am particularly pleased with the request we sent to the Commission to seriously consider working conditions in the sharing economy and the parcel sector, as we cannot accept low levels of protection for workers. In addition, we call on the Commission to assess what protection consumers require in this area and to ensure that regulation is adapted to the digital environment.   The report also contains a powerful text on data protection, culture and media issues, digital skills, infrastructure and investment.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The digital agenda is one of the less coherent proposals of the Juncker Commission, a tailor's drawer that fits everything from copyright to working time, from digital platforms to industry automation, from audiovisual directive reform to parcel directives. In this way, their most controversial initiatives are diluted among others subject to less public scrutiny. Our proposals in this area are well known. We will support the Commission in harmonisation initiatives that improve worker protection, access to cultural production and the fair remuneration of authors. On the contrary, we will maintain our opposition to new digital monopolies, the liberalization of sectors such as parcels and the deregulation of services because of unfair competition from networked companies, whether in transport (such as Uber) or in any other area, public or private. Parliament's report contains improvements to the Commission's proposals, but its general approach remains confusing. That is why I have decided to abstain in the final vote.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this text on the Digital Single Market because it supports, through the digital economy, the federalisation of Europe and undermines areas of Member States' sovereignty.  Indeed, this report proposes to introduce a strengthened harmonisation of VAT in the field of online shipments and thus affects the fiscal sovereignty of Member States. In addition, it provides for a concentration of national operators into a few large operators at European level as well as a unification of copyright and intellectual property rules. The measures of this text, ultra-liberal and free-trade, would contribute to the loss of digital sovereignty to the Member States, to the benefit of the Chinese and American giants of the digital sector.

name: Martina Anderson and Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – As far as I can see, the Commission’s plans are still not sufficient to guarantee equal access for all to the digital single market. Many new technologies that can be introduced through the digital single market can be of huge benefit to all citizens across the EU including in Ireland. It is my view that Parliament should make sure that these technologies do benefit all of our citizens – that we don’t just put money into the coffers of massive companies. My colleagues in GUE/NGL tabled amendments in several committees while this report was being negotiated, focused mainly on users’ trust in digital services, data protection, digital workers’ rights and respecting the principle of net neutrality. These amendments would have significantly improved the report but they were rejected by other groups, which is why I could not support the overall report.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Commission has stressed that the completion of the Digital Single Market is one of its priorities. This report by the European Parliament, which I voted for, highlights the challenges that need to be addressed and notes its support for the 16 initiatives that the European Commission is expected to take. In particular, particular attention is paid to consumer protection, the protection of personal data, the strengthening of investment in infrastructures essential for the Digital Market, the maintenance of the multi-collective nature of electronic media, as well as issues which have been silenced by the European Commission such as addressing the impact on the labour market and the structure of society.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. The flagship document of this Parliament provides clear support from the European Parliament for the Commission's communication on the digital economy. Indeed, this text uses the concept of the digital economy for political purposes by supporting the construction of a European federalism without mentioning an essential and non-negotiable point in the age of globalisation and the dismantling of European OEMs: digital sovereignty. On this vital issue and in the interest of our nation, I voted against this text.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ European Union regulations are already costing jobs in my constituency.  I recently visited a business which has stopped selling to other European countries, but continues to trade with the rest of the world, thanks to such regulations. The geo-blocking proposals and moves towards a Digital Single Market are dangerous precisely because free trade will continue to be undermined.  I voted against this report.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this deliberation because it aims to remove barriers preventing innovative companies from starting and developing. The Digital Single Market can help re-create more growth and employment. It was estimated that, once completed, the Digital Single Market could create 340 billion euros of additional growth in the European Union.

name: Petras Auštrevičius (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, as I believe it provides a solid foundation for implementation of the Digital Single Market Strategy for Europe. Technology is becoming an increasingly important part of our everyday lives and will continue to be in the near future, therefore we must aim to set the right regulatory framework which would satisfy consumers’, businesses’ and states’ interests and needs.  I am very pleased that this report seeks to support digital innovation and entrepreneurship. This means that technology would not only enable consumers and businesses to have a better access to products and services but also enhance growth and jobs. Secondly, technology and innovation can help Europe to be more environmental, which is very important if we want to achieve the goals set by the Paris climate change agreement. Thirdly, digitalisation can help society and business to get easier access to information and provide a tool to modernise and improve governance and administration across the EU.

name: Inés Ayala Sender (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report by representing a clear, progressive and ambitious roadmap for a true Digital Single Market, through the removal of barriers to creating new online opportunities for citizens and businesses, especially SMEs.   The digital revolution is changing Europe radically and has great potential for the creation of millions of new skilled jobs and new opportunities for consumers. I therefore welcome the development of this motion for a Resolution to promote legislative and non-legislative measures for the benefit of consumers and to preserve the competitiveness of our social market economy.  As a socialist, I am particularly pleased with the request we sent to the Commission to seriously consider working conditions in the sharing economy and the parcel sector, as we cannot accept low levels of protection for workers. In addition, we call on the Commission to assess what protection consumers require in this area and to ensure that regulation is adapted to the digital environment.   The report also contains a powerful text on data protection, culture and media issues, digital skills, infrastructure and investment.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to remove barriers to the digital single market, to ban unjustified geo-blocking practices and price discrimination, and to promote innovation and better regulate the sharing economy. I agree with the need to facilitate the prosperity of innovation, the creation and development of new businesses through the development of electronic government services and funding at EU and national level. At the same time, the EP notes the need to develop state-of-the-art technologies such as large data sets, cloud computing, the Internet of Things or 3D printing. I agree that online shopping on the EU market must not be limited by the consumer's address or the country of issue of the credit card. MePs are convinced of this. It is necessary to prohibit such unjustified practices, as well as unfair price discrimination by geographical area, and to ensure the free movement of content, goods or services legally purchased online, while at the same time ensuring equal protection for consumers, whether purchased online or not.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report, which supports one of the Commission's flagship projects, which the Eurocrats are listening to: the Digital Single Market.  As with the single energy market, the aim is to advance the federalisation of Europe in vital areas of sovereignty, starting with taxation: in the name of market fluidisation, the project envisages greater harmonisation of VAT in the field of online shipments, moving towards a single rate, to develop cross-border purchases. On the other hand, we are moving towards a concentration of operators into a few Oligopolies at European level, which would make it impossible for states to regain their sovereignty in this strategic economy. In the end, it is our states and, with them, our fellow citizens who will be delivered to the American giants of telecoms and the Internet.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. This report welcomes the Commission's communication entitled 'Strategy for a Digital Single Market in Europe' because it believes that the creation of such a market, based on a set of rules, could have a positive influence on growth and employment and make society more inclusive. For example, e-commerce generates 500 billion euros a year in the European Union! However, we must always keep in mind that it is important to think, at every stage, about the inclusion of the weakest citizens. They cannot remain on the margins of a digital society that has too often developed without them. The social divide would be even greater. It will also be necessary to ensure the protection of consumers, the preservation of personal data, and to combat illegal content found on the net.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The digital single market represents a huge opportunity for the EU in terms of growth and jobs. Already today, the digital economy, based on creativity and innovation, is an important reality of the continent, thanks also to the EUR 500 billion generated annually by e-commerce. I voted in favour of the report 'Towards an act for the digital single market' because the challenge of Europe's competitiveness can only be played out in the field of innovative business models. the inclusiveness and neutrality of the Internet by promoting access to the internet, especially in those areas, which are largely rural, where the digital infrastructure is deficient or inadequate. Cloud computing, Big Data and the Internet of Things are great opportunities but they will also have to be considered by paying particular attention to the issue of the rights and working conditions of new digital workers, carefully assessing the repercussions that the erosion of normal working hours and the increased intensity of the same can cause. Finally, it will be important not only to eliminate unjustified geoblocking, which encourages the proliferation of the use of illegal content by consumers and unfair price discrimination, but also to encourage the development of a simplified and coherent online VAT system.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report on the 'Towards a Digital Single Market Act' initiative, which believes that achieving a digital single market, based on a common set of rules, could promote the competitiveness of the Union, have positive effects on growth and employment, relaunch the single market and make society more inclusive, offering new opportunities to citizens and businesses , in particular through the exchange and sharing of innovation.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. This report for an act on the Digital Single Market uses the digital economy to move federal Europe at the expense of states in different areas of sovereignty. Thus, it provides for enhanced harmonisation of VAT for online shipments (single rate), concentration of operations by some European operators and finally the unification of copyright and intellectual property rules to prohibit zone blocking.  This text, on the other hand, refuses to talk about such important issues as the dismantling of European telecoms equipment manufacturers for the benefit of the Chinese and americans or the lack of investment due to competition, especially in digital terms, in rural or peripheral areas. Finally, nothing is said about the problem of personal data which differ according to European or American rules, especially when we know the risks with espionage cases. So I voted against this report.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I look with concern at the proposal to create a European governance, chaired by the Commission, for the management of the digital market in Europe. Although the ongoing digital revolution requires great efforts by businesses and administrations to make the most of the potential of technology, I am firmly opposed to the imposition of top-down control of digital exchanges of goods, services and information. That is why I voted against.

name: Malin Björk (GUE/NGL)
text: Written. I've dropped my voice. The report is not clear enough on the issue of net neutrality. Unfortunately, the GUE/NGL Group's amendments to secure this were already rejected at committee level. I want new technology to benefit all european citizens. It should not be the interests of telecom companies that are the priority. I would also like to underline the importance of privacy, data security and occupational safety and health issues in this context. As for the geo-blocking issue, it has many dimensions. In a letter, the Swedish Association of Journalists stresses the problem of a responsible publisher in Sweden not being able to use geo-blocking. They write "a Swedish website may well be subject to legal review in other European countries, at least if the material is available for reading, viewing, listening in that country. Against this background, we consider it almost obvious that the owner/publisher of this website must be allowed to determine, by example through geographical blocking, in which territories a particular media content may be made available or not made available."; This is an issue that needs to be properly investigated before the time comes for legislation. I choose to abstain.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report by representing a clear, progressive and ambitious roadmap for a true Digital Single Market, through the removal of barriers to creating new online opportunities for citizens and businesses, especially SMEs.   The digital revolution is changing Europe radically and has great potential for the creation of millions of new skilled jobs and new opportunities for consumers. I therefore welcome the development of this motion for a Resolution to promote legislative and non-legislative measures for the benefit of consumers and to preserve the competitiveness of our social market economy.  As a Socialist I am particularly pleased with the request we sent to the Commission to seriously consider working conditions in the sharing economy and the parcel sector, as we cannot accept low levels of protection for workers. In addition, we call on the Commission to assess what protection consumers require in this area and to ensure that regulation is adapted to the digital environment.   The report also contains a powerful text on data protection, culture and media issues, digital skills, infrastructure and investment.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report, in which the European Parliament examines the creation of a single Digital Market for Europe. May 17, 2015 The Commission adopted a proposal for a Communication on a Digital Strategy for Europe, which provides for the implementation of 16 initiatives by the end of 2016. By contrasting the Digital Single Market and the Single Market, EU legislators have become aware of the huge opportunities for EU entrepreneurs and businesses to flourish, and to fully recover the EU labour market after the economic crisis and the measures associated with it. Innovation in the digital sector is changing citizens' communication, sharing, consumption and even behavioural habits, and therefore offers equal opportunities for businesses and citizens. Increased use of digital technologies can further increase citizens' access to information and culture, improve their employability and give them greater freedom of choice for products. This can also help to update and improve governance and administration in the EU and its Member States. In order to ensure the prosperity of innovation and the development of innovative enterprises, it is necessary to promote a dynamic economy, and the European Commission and the Member States should therefore focus on this objective. More needs to be done to promote an entrepreneurial culture, including innovative business models, and to ensure stronger links between the various successful European innovation hubs.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 As a member of CULT, I agree with EMPL's view that the teaching and training curriculum should aim at acquiring critical thinking and approach, using and thoroughly understanding new media, digital and information tools and interfaces, so that people can become active users of these new technologies, not just end-users. In order to ensure a successful transition between education and training and employment, it is of the utmost importance that people have transferable competences that enable them to make informed decisions and develop their initiative and self-knowledge, which is also essential in exploiting the opportunities offered by the Digital Single Market. I therefore propose that Member States consider the benefits of a comprehensive overhaul of the education system, curriculum and working methods in a holistic and ambitious way in order to respond adequately to the challenges of the digital revolution.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. The Digital Single Market, which is one of the fundamental pillars of EU development in the coming years, can play a very important role in reducing unemployment in the EU and accelerating the growth of the European economy.  National borders and poor harmonisation of electronic communications legislation make Europe difficult to compete with the US or China, where the development of digital technologies is taking place much faster precisely because of the absence of barriers that exist in Europe. It is therefore necessary to promote entrepreneurial culture, innovative business models and to strengthen the integration of innovation centres on the continent.  The proposal for a Digital Single Market Strategy proposed by the Commission months ago concerns regulating better access to digital services and goods for both consumers and businesses, creating a proper level playing field for innovative services and harnessing the potential for the growth of the digital economy. There are a number of barriers to cross-border online sales that affect consumers and businesses, so harmonisation of the rules is necessary.  A major problem is also geo-blocking, when the service is not allowed to all under the same conditions. The Commission is therefore proposing amendments to the Services Directive and the Internet Sales Block Exemption Regulation.  We also need strengthening eGovernment services, better access to and transparency of services, and advanced technology also plays a big role, as well as promoting developments in the field of telecommunications.  I supported the report.

name: Simona Bonafè (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The digital revolution covers all aspects of our society and implies important opportunities for entrepreneurs and businesses, as well as the creation of innovative tools available to all European citizens. In order to stimulate this transition, it is a priority for the European regulatory framework to encourage public and private investment in networks and infrastructure, focal points of the digital single market, bringing laws into line with the digital age and urgently developing a harmonised legislative framework that ensures legal certainty and regulatory coherence for investors. I supported this report where, in particular, the Commission is asked to define an inclusive strategy, including a strategy for the digital transformation of industry, a sector that largely benefits from the added value of the digital economy. Such a plan, together with a reinvigorated confidence in digital technologies, will be essential in order to increase the competitiveness of the European economy, increase the efficiency of technologies and make full use of the untapped potential.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe that the creation of a digital single market, based on a set of common rules, can promote the EU's competitiveness, have positive effects on growth and employment, relaunch the single market and make society more inclusive thanks to the new opportunities offered to citizens and businesses, in particular through the exchange and sharing of innovation. Furthermore, I believe that this would be a fundamental step towards the completion of the single market and the process of European integration.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Commission has adopted a strategy for the development of European businesses in the digital single market based on 16 initiatives to be implemented by the end of 2016. Innovation in the digital sector continues to change the way citizens communicate, share, consume and act, introducing new opportunities for both businesses and users. Greater use of digital technologies can also improve citizens' access to information and culture, increase their job opportunities and make a wider choice of products available to them; last but not least, it is able to modernise and improve governance and administration within the Union and its Member States. The legislator's action must be implemented on three fronts: accessibility, in order to improve access for consumers and businesses to digital goods and services throughout Europe; environment, to create an environment conducive to the development of digital networks and innovative services; to maximise the growth potential of the digital economy.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. This report uses the digital economy as a pretext to promote the federalisation of Europe in areas that fall within the competence of Member States. In addition, the rapporteur plans, as advocated by the European Commission, to harmonize taxation to promote cross-border shopping. It also promotes the concentration of operators, which will undermine the sovereignty of Member States in an industry that we consider strategic. Finally, it calls for the unification of national intellectual property laws. These proposals are undeniably harmful to the operators of the digital industry who will be delivered to unfair international competition. It is about preserving our jobs and our national sovereignty in a highly strategic sector.  That is why I voted against this text.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because of the perspectives it offers. The Internet and digital technologies are transforming the world we live in, on all levels and in all fields. It is precisely for this reason that the EU must take advantage of the digital revolution and provide digital opportunities for citizens and businesses.  Unfortunately, today, due to online barriers, citizens cannot benefit from a number of goods and services, so only 15% of them shop online from another country. The fully functioning Digital Single Market could contribute €415 billion a year to the EU economy and create hundreds of thousands of new jobs.  Last but not least, the increased use of digital technologies can significantly improve citizens' access to information and culture, improve their professional opportunities and offer them a wide range of products.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Vote against. According to the Commission, a single digital market for the EU will foster the competitiveness of European businesses, offer new opportunities to citizens and businesses and boost growth and jobs. In concrete terms, it is a question of creating governance of the Commission, by summoning competences of the Member States, on matters such as the Internet, the Internet of Things, the collaborative economy, copyright, telecommunications, e-commerce, networked PAs; but, by extension, also training, labour market, welfare, taxation, fundamental freedoms, etc. The call to define a regulatory framework that is 'digital proof' and technologically neutral is positive, but the text does not sufficiently refer to the need for the digitisation process not to be transformed, for SMEs and micro-enterprises in traditional economic sectors such as manufacturing, into an obligation disproportionate to their actual resources and management and market needs. It is a report entirely devoted to exalting the progressive virtues of free trade and the principle of the free movement of everything and all, but it forgets a basic question of principle: democratic control over all this.

name: Cristian-Silviu Buşoi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Digital Agenda Scoreboard shows that EU regions have very different levels of digital connectivity, internet use, human capital, integration of digital technology by businesses, and digital public services. Regions with low scores on these five indicators risk missing the benefits of the digital age. Current policies and incentives have failed to provide adequate digital infrastructure, especially in rural areas, so 44.8% of EU households do not have access to the internet quickly. I support the EP resolution motion on the preparation of legislation on the Digital Single Market, because I believe that the achievement of a digital single market, based on a common set of rules, can boost the EU's competitiveness with positive effects on jobs, relaunch the Single Market and strengthen inclusiveness, providing new opportunities for citizens and businesses, in particular through the exchange of innovations.  I also mention that the digital revolution affects every aspect of our societies, bringing with it opportunities and challenges, with the potential to further empower citizens, consumers and entrepreneurs in new ways, different from how this could be achieved before.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report by representing a clear, progressive and ambitious roadmap for a true Digital Single Market, through the removal of barriers to creating new online opportunities for citizens and businesses, especially SMEs.   The digital revolution is changing Europe radically and has great potential for the creation of millions of new skilled jobs and new opportunities for consumers. I therefore welcome the development of this motion for a Resolution to promote legislative and non-legislative measures for the benefit of consumers and to preserve the competitiveness of our social market economy.  As a socialist, I am particularly pleased with the request we sent to the Commission to seriously consider working conditions in the sharing economy and the parcel sector, as we cannot accept low levels of protection for workers. In addition, we call on the Commission to assess what protection consumers require in this area and to ensure that regulation is adapted to the digital environment.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report entitled "Towards an Act on the Digital Single Market". New digital technologies have an impact on almost all sectors that make up our society. From the agricultural sector to the financial sector to the transport sector, digital technology represents a revolution that has profoundly changed the way they operate. European legislation must therefore be adapted to these technological developments. Achieving a digital single market will promote competitiveness and job creation while providing a regulatory framework that regulates the negative aspects of such technologies.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this report which is in essence a strategic report for upcoming work on a Digital Single Market for Europe. My reasons for abstaining were that many crucial amendments, on issues of the utmost importance for citizens, were refused. This included articles on net neutrality, data protection, trust in digital services and open standards.  Net neutrality is essential to protecting consumers’ access to high-quality internet and mobile services against service providers’ increased profits. The continued neglect in enshrining this principle in the EU’s Digital Agenda was my reason for abstaining on this report.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP has voted to reject this report. The report calls for greater EU harmonisation and the instigation of EU legislation that will alter Member States’ taxation, internet, data sharing and e-commerce policies. UKIP vehemently disagrees with aspects of the text that support the continuation of the VAT MOSS regime as we believe this has been extremely harmful to UK businesses particularly small and medium-sized enterprises.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report as I also agree with some improvements that still need to be made to the proposal made by the European Commission regarding the Digital Single Market, for example in the area of the so called ‘geo-blocking’, VAT-related issues or digital skills. Overall I welcome the Commission’s Digital Single Market strategy. It will help us, among others, to modernise our market and maintain global competitiveness.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report focuses on the Commission communication on the development of a digital single market. It is a prelude to a series of legislative initiatives which, according to the Commission's work programme, are expected to be discussed in Parliament next spring. The report is therefore a first document on this subject which, for the issues it deals with, certainly deserves our support. I therefore voted strongly in favour.

name: Dita Charanzová (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ As stated during the debate in the plenary, this report has my support as it finally presents a relevant EU strategy in digital area. It should give us an impetus to promote and further develop digital economy in Europe and we should use it fully, as we are already late to the game.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 For several years, the Union has been pursuing the objective of a digital single market: a new way of guaranteeing more and more goods and services to European consumers and a tool that will enable businesses to cross national borders and expand at European level. The potential and applications of new technologies are diverse and varied, also to improve and modernise public administration and therefore the lives of citizens.
