Carrying out such a broad project implies an appropriate regulatory framework, especially with regard to the protection and protection of citizens' data, and especially at a sensitive time such as this that sees the privacy of people subject to strict controls throughout Europe. But it also involves overcoming national regulatory barriers by aiming for common rules that will help the digital single market to assert itself. Indeed, one of the causes that has held back the full development of e-commerce, which is a real engine for growth, has been legislative fragmentation. It is therefore clear that a new approach is needed to prepare a digital single market that can capture the potential for development and growth that can result from better use of information technology. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report in which the European Parliament points out, in agreement with the Commission, that governance and the timely completion of the digital single market are a joint responsibility of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission, while at the same time urging the Commission to cooperate with social actors and to seek their participation in the decision-making process to the fullest extent possible. I believe that increased use of digital technologies can improve citizens' access to information and culture, increase opportunities to find work and provide them with more choice in terms of products. It also has the potential to modernise and improve governance and administration in the EU and its Member States. Promoting a dynamic economy is necessary in order to foster innovation and for innovative enterprises to develop large-scale activities. The Digital Single Market Strategy is structured around three axes: (1) access: better access for consumers and businesses to digital products and services across Europe, (2) the environment: creating appropriate conditions and a level playing field for the development of digital networks and innovative services, (3) economy and society: maximising the growth potential of the digital economy.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 The issue of the single market has long been a starting point for building a positive framework of rules and structures for the benefit of the citizens of the Union. But in order to do so, we need to explore all aspects of the issue in the common interest of all.  The lack of references and solutions to issues of neutrality and privacy does not consider it to be in the interests of Europeans and that is why I have decided to abstain.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this measure because I believe that the Commission's strategy for a digital single market will significantly transform the European labour market, stimulating the creation of new jobs. The lack of legislative harmonisation is indeed one of the main obstacles preventing SMEs and consumers from selling or buying online throughout the Union. The use of digital technologies can improve citizens' access to information and culture, increase job opportunities and provide them with a wider choice of products. In addition, digitalisation will play a key role in public administrations by helping to improve their governance.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because, even beyond the specific merit, it is part of a path that has been affecting us all for some years now and that is strongly re-proposed for the future: a company that produces goods that affect 10% of the population, having to face competitors, will probably not find it convenient to remain in a small market and will give up producing. If, on the other hand, that market is ten times larger, the numbers can become much more interesting and, if that company can take advantage of excellence in terms of raw materials, human resources, or otherwise, it can conquer the market. This is the essence of the digital single market: a ploy to enlarge the market and ensure that those who are good can play for a much higher stake by dragging all the related with them. It is a great bet, that a land of excellence like ours cannot miss.

name: David Coburn (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP has voted to reject this report. The report calls for greater EU harmonisation and the instigation of EU legislation that will alter Member States’ taxation, internet, data sharing and e-commerce policies. UKIP vehemently disagrees with aspects of the text that support the continuation of the VAT MOSS regime as we believe this has been extremely harmful to UK businesses, particularly small and medium-sized enterprises.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. The rapid evolution of the Internet and communications has changed the way we communicate, how we do business and how we consume within the Internal Market. Despite the results achieved in physical trade, Europeans often face obstacles in the use of online tools and services, looking suspiciously at their use and facing barriers due to the legislative fragmentation that applies to online commerce. I support the Kallas/Gebhardt report, which follows the Digital Single Market Strategy presented by the European Commission, with the aim of creating a connected digital single market, creating new jobs, in an environment where digital networks and services can thrive, with better online access to digital products and services and which sees Digital as a growth engine. The Digital Single Market is estimated to represent an annual increase of between €415 billion and €500 billion in EU GDP. I believe that it is generally a good strategy, but it needs to be worked on, and the report today voted on a valuable contribution to achieving the targets that the European Commission has set out to achieve in the near future, thereby creating a connected Digital Single Market with added value for European consumers.

name: Birgit Collin-Langen (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report because action must now be taken to ensure that the EU does not miss the leap to the already moving train of digitisation. Access for consumers to legitimate digital content needs to be improved. With this proposal, we are address the problem of geo-blocking and price differences in the Digital Single Market in order to make it easier for consumers to access the internal market across borders.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this important parliament own-initiative report on the digital single market. Parliament has done an important job and produced a position with a great democratic content, the result of a long assessment of different interests and different points of view. The digital single market is a priority objective of the Juncker Commission and the hope is that all the necessary measures can really be taken as soon as possible to make it effective, innovative and competitive, with the aim of making the market modern and, above all, productive for growth and employment, which we strongly need in order to respond to the needs of our citizens and businesses.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Creators, consumers and businesses should fully benefit from the potential of the Digital Single Market. A fragmented Digital Single Market limits business opportunities for creators, as well as accessibility to content and services for end users. This own-initiative report ‘Towards a Digital Single Market Act’ is Parliament’s response to the Commission’s Digital Single Market Strategy of 6 May 2015.  The report as adopted in the joint committee has a very broad scope and refers to e-commerce, cross-border parcel delivery, geo-blocking, copyright, VAT rules, telecoms framework, audiovisual media, platforms and the role of intermediaries, data protection, e-government, opportunities for increased growth and competitiveness such as big data, standardisation, research, e-skills.  Each of these areas needs a specific approach and proposals in different legislative instruments. The Commission is proposing a step by step approach to these specific areas which I welcome.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Kallas-Gebhardt report is part of the Juncker Commission's macro-initiative for a digital single market. The report paves the way for a comprehensive set of subsequent legislative initiatives, most of which are expected to reach Parliament by 2016. The main topics covered (expansion of Europeans' participation in digital life, investment in infrastructure, reduction of geoblocking, improvement of the rules for online business, strengthening of citizens' confidence, etc.) deserve our support. Our main amendments in the ITRE-IMCO procedure have concerned the intensification of the concept of digital citizenship, actions to combat the digital divide, the coordination of public and private investments, the strengthening of guarantees of fundamental rights, specific opportunities for small and medium-sized enterprises, attention to workers' rights and environmental standards when facilitating cross-border activities , as well as the multidimensional care of citizens' trust. In view of the relatively uncriticised nature of the report and the absence of critical issues, I voted in favour.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The digital agenda is one of the less coherent proposals of the Juncker Commission, a tailor's drawer that fits everything from copyright to working time, from digital platforms to industry automation, from audiovisual directive reform to parcel directives. In this way, their most controversial initiatives are diluted among others subject to less public scrutiny. Our proposals in this area are well known. We will support the Commission in harmonisation initiatives that improve worker protection, access to cultural production and the fair remuneration of authors. On the contrary, we will maintain our opposition to new digital monopolies, the liberalization of sectors such as parcels and the deregulation of services because of unfair competition from networked companies, whether in transport (such as Uber) or in any other area, public or private. Parliament's report contains improvements to the Commission's proposals, but its general approach remains confusing. That is why I have decided to abstain in the final vote.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution promoting the creation of a digital single market based on a set of common rules, because I believe that it has the potential to promote the EU's competitiveness, have positive effects on growth and employment, relaunch the single market and make society more inclusive thanks to the new opportunities offered to citizens and businesses. In particular, in this resolution we call on the Commission and the Member States to take all necessary initiatives to: 1) encourage entrepreneurship and in particular innovative business models, 2) regulate cross-border e-commerce in such a way as to protect consumers and businesses, 3) improve access to digital content through modern copyright regulation, 4) adapt the labour market by reducing asymmetries between supply and demand for expertise.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 On 6 May 2015, the Commission adopted a proposal for a Communication on a 'Digital Strategy for Europe'. The communication proposal contains initiatives to be implemented by the end of 2016. On the positive side, the European Commission has set among its primary objectives the elimination of unjustified geo-blocking and other forms of cross-border discrimination against consumers. Strengthening confidence in digital technologies is essential for the development of a data-driven economy. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I strongly believe that legislation in the area of a digital single market should allow new opportunities for users and businesses and new innovative cross-border online services at competitive prices. It should remove barriers between Member States and facilitate access for European businesses, in particular SMEs, microenterprises and start-ups to the cross-border market. The EU digital single market has great potential, it could foster competitiveness, have positive effects on growth and jobs, make the society more inclusive, offering new opportunities for unemployed, for young people and women in the job market. So, I voted in favour this report promoting a more dynamic economy and allowing innovation to flourish.

name: Daniel Dalton (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome this report as a positive step forward for consumers and the digital industry. We need ambitious actions to complete Europe’s Digital Single Market, particularly addressing e-skills for young people, and removing artificial barriers to the development of the collaborative economy. We need a legislative landscape that is innovation-friendly and fosters entrepreneurship. Finally, although I support most of the content of this report, I do want to emphasise that I did not support a Common Consolidated Corporate Tax Base (CCCTB), harmonisation of spectrum allocation or extending the scope of the Audiovisual Media Services (AVMS) Directive to include online platforms, and my group requested that these be put to the vote separately to show our opposition to these ideas , which risk undermining the very innovation the Digital Single Market is supporting.

name: Rosa D'Amato (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The digital single market implies a more distributed, more participative, more decentralised approach to innovation, making it potentially revolutionary compared to the old model, based on traditional, expensive and impacting structures and infrastructures. But, in order for it to happen, there are important issues to be resolved quickly, starting with the digital divide (in some cases also due to the economic difficulties resulting from the crisis), passing through the level of digital literacy, technological neutrality, fair access to digital services and content, up to the necessary high-speed infrastructures / mega data capacity. Other areas that deserve attention are, for example, cyber security, the protection of personal data, dependence on the network, the upheaval of privacy and the difficulty in disconnecting the "connection" to safeguard personal life.  However, opportunities for SMEs, widespread innovation, the Internet of Things revolution and benefits in the areas of agriculture, tourism, industrial production, culture and services are undeniable contributions to the single market. It can also be used for energy and resource saving, for better efficiency and for a longer-lasting performance of products, with a view to a circular economy. Despite some reservations, therefore, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the rapporteur's position that user and business confidence in the digital environment is vital for the full unlocking of innovation and growth in the digital economy, and one solution for increasing this trust is the appropriate data protection and security standards and a high level of consumer protection and empowerment. They can be achieved through up-to-date legislation for businesses.  We must not forget that the annual revenues generated by e-commerce in the European Union amount to EUR 500 billion, giving consumers a wider range of options, especially in remote areas, and SMEs new opportunities.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This initiative report presents Parliament's position on communicating the Commission's Digital Single Market Strategy of 6 March 2015, one of the pillars of President Juncker's political programme. This report contains a number of recommendations to take advantage of the growth potential of the digital economy, by promoting the development of innovative companies in the field of new technologies or 3D printing and new forms of trade and exchange such as the sharing economy. This report also looks at online consumer protection, with the ban on geoblocking. Supporting these objectives, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. This initiative report sets out the measures needed to establish a single digital market at European level. This will help to maximize the growth potential of the digital economy and strengthen the security of digital networks and infrastructure.

name: Dennis de Jong (GUE/NGL)
text: Written. 'First, we spent months debating which parliamentary committees would be competent. Then we had to go through almost 1300 amendments from colleagues, and now that we finally have the plenary vote, the Commission's first legislative proposals are already in place in this area. In doing so, the EP is putting the horse behind the cart, because the report was intended to influence the Commission before it would issue formal legislative proposals. That is why I am voting against this report.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Europe needs to learn to take a more proactive approach to key issues such as the digital single market. In particular, other economies in the world are moving very quickly to define their future around digital, and European companies must not lag behind, especially those that represent the added value of our system: small and medium-sized enterprises. Today there is a serious economic and cultural shortcoming around this topic and much potential in both bureaucracy and data collection remains unexplored. Moreover, the applications of data science seem to be a reality now in some European countries, while in others they are still seen with some fear and mistrust. It is time to reverse the trend through targeted investments in new technologies and skills related to the digital market such as data science. In addition, another key element is the introduction of greater coherence and therefore integration between national legislative bodies in this area, especially in the area of privacy and access to sensitive information. It is essential to have this act and all the rules necessary to make Europe a leading player in digital ing so as to position itself on the most advanced technological frontier.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. Today, only 1.7% of EU businesses make full use of advanced digital technologies and only 14% of SMEs use the internet as a sales channel. In 2013, the market size of the sharing economy was about 3.5 billion worldwide, and it is estimated that it will exceed 100 billion in the coming years.  That is why the European Commission has made the completion of the digital market one of its political priorities. Sixteen initiatives will be put in place by the end of 2016 to improve EU consumers' access to goods and services while providing them with long-term high-level protection but also to remove barriers for smEs, start-ups and growing businesses, so that they can seize opportunities based on new information and communications technologies (ICTs).

name: Angélique Delahaye (PPE)
text: In writing. The creation of a digital single market will enable Europe to catch up with the United States by strengthening its industry's competitiveness against global digital giants. I therefore voted in favour of the Gebhardt and Kallas report for the creation of a digital single market. The digital revolution that is opening up will offer immense growth potential for European businesses and consumers. Confidence is the central pillar of the digital single market.  As far as companies are concerned, it is absolutely essential to provide them with a stable legal environment so that they can develop across European borders, without unjustified additional costs or legal uncertainty. Finally, the development of the digital economy must be accompanied by protection of copyright, intellectual property and a better fight against counterfeiting on the Internet.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The positive results of the Digital Single European Market, based on a common set of rules, include growth, strengthening the single market and job creation. Nevertheless, it provides entrepreneurs with the opportunity to expand their innovative ideas and to ensure the smooth functioning of the cross-border e-commerce market without obstacles. This innovative direction affects a large part of society and, more importantly, creates opportunities for growth. It is important to mention that, in the face of opportunities, there are several challenges facing all participants in the digital market. In order to ensure that this market is smooth, sustainable and accessible to all, efforts should be made to improve access to services, in particular unjustified geo-blocking. It also includes a proposal to end unfair price discriminatory on the basis of geographical location or nationality, which will directly lead to monopolies and the orientation of some consumers towards illegal content. This restriction of content undermines the rights of national minorities, as some content is not available in their mother tongue. On this issue, we need to move forward step by step, after solving the competition problems.

name: Jean-Paul Denanot (S&D)
text: In writing. The resolution submitted, in my view, places too little emphasis on the cultural issues that are central to the digital issue. Digital technologies, through the profound transformation of the tools, objects and uses they imply, directly affect the professions of creation and heritage. These technologies raise critical legal questions, the economic consequences of which are not neutral, on access to information and works and on the remuneration of authors. They also question the missions of public services, which requires clarifying - in the light of this digital revolution - the Services Directive.  In addition, given the economic and social potential of big data, the Internet of Things (particularly in the fields of health, energy and logistics), I want to stress the importance of investing in information highways that are passable and open to all. The European Strategic Investment Fund (EFSI) is a tool that must be able to be operated on this particular issue.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. The creation of a digital single market is part of a federalist integration dynamic that would impose itself on Member States through forced harmonisation. The integration strategy is clearly read through the proposal to harmonize VAT in the field of online shipments, but also the regulation of operators which will promote the consolidation of these at the european network level and finally through the harmonisation of intellectual property rules. Attached to the sovereignty of Member States in this area, which relates to freedoms and free competition on networks, I voted against this report.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because it gives indications in the right direction. With the rapid pace of digital development and the continuous emergence of new innovative technologies, we must be ready to provide thoughtful and effective future applications and clear legislation that do not harm the creative industries and hinder innovation, and which will not create difficulties and negative consequences for consumers who should enjoy the new digital revolution. Regardless of the benefits, I reiterate the importance of maintaining our focus on improving the existing system and addressing key issues in a targeted manner based on an in-depth analysis. Responding to calls for radical change, we will destroy the creative sector and inflict devastating damage on our citizens. In my country, we are witnessing high levels of unemployment and economic losses due to infringements of intellectual property rights. The independent creative sector is also highly dependent on the copyright system. If it didn't exist, there wouldn't be an independent film; cultural heritage will disappear. Recognising the importance of innovation, technological progress and the preservation of cultural heritage, we set an appropriate framework for achieving this fragile balance.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Digital Single Market is the modernised form of the oppressive and free EU, which is trying to spread to even free areas such as the Internet. The digitisation of the public sector can solve many problems and save resources but may, on the other hand, degrade the importance of personal data and increase their cost of protection geometrically. This project legitimises Community bullying against undertakings wishing to have a limited turnover and who choose, as they have every right, to trade with any country they wish.

name: Eleonora Evi (EFDD)
text: in writing. The Kallas-Gebhardt report focuses on commission communication COM(2015)0192, as part of the Juncker Commission's initiative for a digital single market. The digitisation of the different aspects of economic and social life is seen as positive, as some elements that need to be supported have been included, such as the expansion of citizens' participation in digital life, which goes hand in hand with investment in infrastructure and improved rules for e-commerce. In addition, the emphasis on the concept of digital citizenship and the fight against digital divides is positive. Apart from a few elements on which we voted against, such as the support given to the EFSI to which we are opposed, the report is not very critical. I voted in favour.

name: Fredrick Federley (ALDE)
text: Written. \u2012 Draft legislation regulating the Digital Single Market, three main areas; (1) better access to digital goods for both consumers and businesses across the Union, (2) create a level playing field so that digital networks and innovative services can be better developed, (3) ensure the growth potential of digital services. A developed digital market is an important prerequisite for job creation and growth in Europe. I have therefore voted in favour of the prosecution.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. The Commission has adopted a proposal for a Communication entitled 'A digital strategy for Europe', comprising 16 initiatives to be implemented by the end of 2016. Innovation in the digital sector is constantly changing the way citizens communicate, share, consume and even behave and therefore gives rise to new opportunities for both businesses and users. The intensified use of digital technologies can further improve citizens' access to information and culture, increase employment opportunities and provide them with a wider choice of products. It can also be beneficial for modernising and improving governance and administration in the EU and its Member States. The Digital Single Market Strategy is divided into three parts: -access: better access for consumers and businesses to digital goods and services across Europe;  -environment: creating an appropriate level playing field and level playing field for digital networks and innovative services to thrive;  -economy and society: optimising the growth potential of the digital economy in this report which I voted in favour of.  It is important that the EU budget, national budgets, and legislative framework enable this strategy to be implementationd.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report because it seeks to dismantle the sovereignty of states in the digital field.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Innovation in the digital sector constantly changes the way citizens communicate, share, consume and even behave, generating new social and economic relationships. Digital technologies can improve citizens' access to information and culture and provide them with a wider and more diverse choice of public and/or commercial products and services. Despite the potential for digital technologies, the single market has been an instrument that is promoting inequalities between Member States, degrading national production in Portugal, particularly making life difficult for micro, small and medium-sized enterprises that fail to cope with European competition and the brutal inequality of circumstances in the face of multinational hegemons. We advocate an end to geo-blocking. However, this should safeguard the right of authors and artists to a decent remuneration for their productions. We argue that data storage and management, due to the growing importance that digital technologies assume not only in the economy but also in society, must be under the purview of the State.  The liberalisation of markets is of deep concern, even if it presents itself with a social façade. The advertising of promises of jobs, growth, cohesion, is always but always belied by reality. We voted against it.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report because I believe that the proposals it contains meet the needs of both businesses and consumers. In particular, I welcome the call for actions to complete the digital single market in Europe that have positive effects on the development of EU competitiveness, promoting growth and employment. In addition, this would allow the emergence and growth of new innovative online cross-border services at competitive prices, the development of the sharing economy and the adoption of innovation-friendly strategic tools for online platforms that facilitate market access. Further measures on which we must continue to invest and work are the development of young people's e-skills in schools and universities and an action plan for e-government in public administrations.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing \ u2012 The lack of a common set of rules for cross-border online sales constitutes one of the main obstacles for SMEs and consumers to be able to sell and shop freely online throughout the European Union. Online sales of digital content remain largely unregulated, whether in EU or national legislation. At present, the consumer purchasing tangible digital content has access to a range of rights, while the consumer purchasing the same digital content supplied by electronic means does not have it. The European Commission should develop a digital industrial transformation plan to increase the competitiveness of the European economy, increase efficiency and exploit untapped potential. This will require a European approach, including a strategy for setting standards, as well as the integration of the single market within technology.

name: Anna Elżbieta Fotyga (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The pace of development of the digital market has changed our reality and the way we look at industry and the competitiveness of European businesses. I see barriers to the organisation of the digital market that hinder their unfetageed activities and further development. Polish small and medium-sized entrepreneurs, despite many difficulties, make excellent use of this opportunity. Nevertheless, the report calls for the creation of an EU-wide common consolidated corporate tax base (CCCTB), which I cannot support, all the more so in a report in which competitiveness is one of the main rationale. Taxation is one of the most important prerogatives of any country, and although there are elements of the fiscal system that are subject to EU coordination (VAT), I want this tool of state policy to remain in Polish hands. First of all, it is a report on the digital environment in the EU. I cannot agree that on this occasion there should be a demand that would lead to the loss of the possibility of active fiscal policy and, as a result, a decrease in the competitiveness of the Polish economy.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Digital Single Market is the modernised form of the oppressive and free EU, which is trying to spread to even free areas such as the Internet. The digitisation of the public sector can, on the one hand, solve many problems and save resources but, on the other hand, degrade the importance of personal data but also geometrically increase their cost of protection. This project legitimises Community bullying against undertakings wishing to have a limited turnover and who choose, as they have every right, to trade with any country they wish. For these reasons, my vote is negative on the path towards an act for the Digital Single Market .

name: Ashley Fox (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ On behalf of UK Conservative MEPs, we support the calls within this report for ambitious, targeted actions to complete Europe’s Digital Single Market, including an end to unjustified geo-blocking practices, promotion of e-skills for young people, and an e-government action plan in public administrations. Furthermore we welcome the calls for the Commission and Member States to support the further development of the sharing economy and an innovation-friendly policy towards online platforms. Finally we believe the approach to copyright and portability included in the final report is well balanced.  However, we strongly oppose the endorsement of the Common Consolidated Corporate Tax Base (CCCTB), which is not relevant to the DSM and has no place in this report, and we will continue to oppose its introduction. In addition we do not support the harmonisation of spectrum allocation, whilst we do recognise the benefits of increased coordination, nor do we support extending the scope of the Audiovisual Media Services (AVMS) Directive to include online platforms as called for in the report. These votes were all roll-called. Despite these reservations, Conservatives voted in favour of the report given our strong support for the digital single market and the significant opportunities it brings.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Today, we will be able to guarantee better access for consumers and businesses across Europe to the Digital Single Market, creating the right conditions and a level playing field for advanced digital networks and innovative services, and maximising the growth potential of the digital economy. It is very important to have a clear stand on topics such as consumer protection, data protection, big data, infrastructure and investment, media, digital skills and copyright. I welcome the fact that the report goes beyond the Commission strategy addressing issues which the Commission has neglected, such as platforms, structural changes in society and the impact of digitalisation on the employment world. I am especially satisfied that the issues of workers’ rights in the sharing economy and the parcel delivery sector were included in the report.  Finally, I believe we must make more efforts on standardisation, patents and on social protection.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the great potential of shaping a true digital single market, which opens up new opportunities to promote business options through e-commerce, while facilitating compliance with administrative and financial requirements for businesses and giving customers capabilities through e-management. These advances require a regulatory framework that facilitates the development of cloud computing, borderless mobile data connectivity, and simplified access to information and content, preserving privacy, personal data, cybersecurity, and network neutrality. We must remove national barriers to online transactions between Member States with the aim of increasing the prosperity of all EU citizens.

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report by representing a clear, progressive and ambitious roadmap for a true Digital Single Market, through the removal of barriers to creating new online opportunities for citizens and businesses, especially SMEs.   The digital revolution is changing Europe radically and has great potential for the creation of millions of new skilled jobs and new opportunities for consumers. I therefore welcome the development of this motion for a Resolution to promote legislative and non-legislative measures for the benefit of consumers and to preserve the competitiveness of our social market economy.  As a socialist, I am particularly pleased with the request we sent to the Commission to seriously consider working conditions in the sharing economy and the parcel sector, as we cannot accept low levels of protection for workers. In addition, we call on the Commission to assess what protection consumers require in this area and to ensure that regulation is adapted to the digital environment.   The report also contains a powerful text on data protection, culture and media issues, digital skills, infrastructure and investment.

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report by representing a clear, progressive and ambitious roadmap for a true Digital Single Market, through the removal of barriers to creating new online opportunities for citizens and businesses, especially SMEs.   The digital revolution is changing Europe radically and has great potential for the creation of millions of new skilled jobs and new opportunities for consumers. I therefore welcome the development of this motion for a Resolution to promote legislative and non-legislative measures for the benefit of consumers and to preserve the competitiveness of our social market economy.  As a socialist, I am particularly pleased with the request we sent to the Commission to seriously consider working conditions in the sharing economy and the parcel sector, as we cannot accept low levels of protection for workers. In addition, we call on the Commission to assess what protection consumers require in this area and to ensure that regulation is adapted to the digital environment.   The report also contains a powerful text on data protection, culture and media issues, digital skills, infrastructure and investment.

name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The digital single market is a great achievement for the European Union. This is a measure that entrepreneurs and consumers have been waiting for for years, generating a contribution of EUR 415 billion to the European economy. In Europe we have great creative excellence that awaits this measure, which will finally put an end to those obstacles that prevent companies in the sector from being able to compete on an equal footing with their competitors overseas. From this measure we expect job growth and benefits for all sectors, from services to public administration to education. For these reasons, we will continue to work towards these results as soon as possible.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. I think it is very important to adopt this report, which outlines the General Position of the European Parliament on a priority issue such as the completion of the digital single market in Europe. I would particularly like to highlight the coordination work between many parliamentary committees, which has enabled Parliament to respond with a strong and united voice to the European Commission's communication, which presents the new digital strategy as one of the cornerstones of Mr Juncker's programme. I therefore look forward to the presentation of the many regulatory strategies expected for 2016, these will be measures on which the Committee on Legal Affairs will give its opinion with the aim of implementing finally innovative reforms in the areas of digitalisation, copyright, new services.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on 'Towards a Digital Single Market Act', as it addresses two key demands that I have been making to this Plenary time and again since my election to the European Parliament: firstly, the development of an internal market that serves consumers through cheaper prices and promotes small and medium-sized enterprises and family businesses through better online access. Secondly, the issue of the internal market for parcels: we need a European market here, we need a kind of 'roaming lid for parcels'. It cannot be the case that a package from Aachen to Eupen or from Regensburg to Prague costs ten times as much as a package from Oberammergau to Flensburg – just because the others are disturbed by a national border.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. In addition to the economic benefits for businesses, EU citizens in particular will benefit from the benefits of a single digital single market. This is another example of us benefiting from common European solutions.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the Digital Single Market (DSM), a response to the European Commission's Communication on the DSM, which focused on business to customer online purchasing, transactions, and cross border parcel delivery. The report calls on the Commission to press on with the completion of a Europe-wide Digital Single Market, with emphasis on the need for everyone to have the right to access the internet and use online services, and ensuring superfast broadband is accessible to everyone.  Labour MEPs tabled a number of amendments to address the gaps on social and employment issues, digital skills, public investment and universal access and coverage, and are pleased with the report, but more work needs to be done. The Digital Single Market is a great example of how British consumers benefit from membership of the EU – indeed only last month, the Commission unveiled proposals that will allow travellers to watch iPlayer, Netflix and other digital content while abroad.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because the construction of the digital single market is now a reality and we all hope that it will be one of the great successes of the European Union, which needs success more than ever at this very moment. For it to be a success, however, we must first break down the digital divide and ensure that consumers and businesses have access to the services it offers. There are regions and areas in Europe where broadband is still not available today. In this context and under these conditions, the completion of the digital single market risks widening the gap between the most developed regions and those whose technological backwardness is lagging behind. This risks becoming even more serious if we talk about e-government than e-commerce. I see the digital single market as a great test of progress and an extraordinary opportunity for the well-being of European citizens. The aim must be to launch Europe into the future while being very careful not to create second-class citizens and second-class citizens.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The report is part of an attempt to respond to the new challenges posed by new technologies and the context of new competition that is coming. The digital economy is a lever for growth, so we doubt that everything can be solved through the rules of the 'single market'. Some parts of the text represent progress (taking into account the risks of digitization, establishing a common consolidated corporate tax base, etc.); However, on some other aspects, the report does not go far enough, especially in terms of data protection, free software use and net neutrality. For all these reasons, I abstained in the vote.

name: Beata Gosiewska (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The pace of development of the digital market has changed our reality and the way we look at industry and the competitiveness of European businesses. Nevertheless, the report calls for the creation of an EU-wide common consolidated corporate tax base (CCCTB), which I cannot support, all the more so in a report in which competitiveness is one of the main conditions. Firstly, this is a report on the digital environment in the EU, not on direct taxation, and this is one of the reasons why I cannot support a text that contains such a call. Furthermore, I cannot agree with the demand that active fiscal policies will be lost and, as a result, the competitiveness of the EU economies with the lowest CIT rates will be reduced. The argument that unfair competition within the European Union is taking place in the area of taxation is an abuse and a unilateral interpretation of the situation by some Member States, and that smaller Member States would simply lose out on harmonisation.  Finally, one of the reasons why I cannot support the presence of this provision in the final text is the result of pressure in the past on some countries that have been accused of applying 'extremely harmful tax competition'. This way of speaking to sovereign Member States with their own fiscal policies is simply unacceptable.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Digital Single Market is extremely important for the EU. Strategies addressed for the development of the Digital Single Market can lead to effective economic development. The Internet is increasing the speed of trade, but also the speed of information exchange between citizens and public administration.  The Digital Single Market must be developed taking into account social inclusion and the different level of education in the European area. That is why I believe that the development of the Digital Single Market must be done in direct correlation with the investments of cohesion funds.  At the same time, the Commission must ensure that there is a clear legal framework for combating cybercrime and the protection of personal data. Technological development is not allowed to harm consumer rights.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Along with my Labour Party colleagues I voted in favour of this Report calling for a fairer Digital Single market in the EU. Labour MEPs tabled a number of amendments to address the gaps on social and employment issues, digital skills, public investment and universal access and coverage, and are pleased with the report, but more work needs to be done. The Digital Single Market is a great example of how British consumers benefit from membership of the EU – indeed only last month, the Commission unveiled proposals that will allow travellers to watch iPlayer, Netflix and other digital content while abroad.

name: Françoise Grossetête (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report.  Ensuring a high level of data protection is essential to ensure consumer and business confidence in new digital services. Innovation and the growth of the digital economy more generally can only be done if we encourage business models that build that confidence.  Furthermore, I believe that the digitisation of industry must be seriously encouraged by the European Commission by the adoption of European or global standards. This represents opportunities for the industry and for all our SMEs that the different productive sectors cannot pass up. In addition, digital taxation must be adapted to this new economy, so there is an urgent need to develop common standards that meet the specifics of this rapidly evolving sector. Finally, access to the internet in rural or remote areas must be defended at European level. For these regions, it is an economic and social shortfall. Public-private investment in these areas must therefore be encouraged.

name: Enrique Guerrero Salom (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report by representing a clear, progressive and ambitious roadmap for a true Digital Single Market, through the removal of barriers to creating new online opportunities for citizens and businesses, especially SMEs.   The digital revolution is changing Europe radically and has great potential for the creation of millions of new skilled jobs and new opportunities for consumers. I therefore welcome the development of this motion for a Resolution to promote legislative and non-legislative measures for the benefit of consumers and to preserve the competitiveness of our social market economy.  As a Socialist I am particularly pleased with the request we sent to the Commission to seriously consider working conditions in the sharing economy and the parcel sector, as we cannot accept low levels of protection for workers. In addition, we call on the Commission to assess what protection consumers require in this area and to ensure that regulation is adapted to the digital environment.   The report also contains a powerful text on data protection, culture and media issues, digital skills, infrastructure and investment.

name: Sylvie Guillaume (S&D)
text: In writing. The European Parliament also has a say in how it envisages the development of a digital market by 2020. That is why I supported this initiative report which sets out two key priorities: improving access to the digital single market for consumers and businesses across Europe, and creating a favourable environment and a level playing field for innovative services and advanced digital networks. Unwarranted geoblocking practices and tariff discrimination must be stopped.  While stimulating this large market, we must also ensure that fair remuneration for creators is taken into account. It is not acceptable for web giants to take wealth without redistributing it and investing in cultural content. Digital technology must be the ally, not the enemy, of a vibrant and quality culture.

name: Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report by representing a clear, progressive and ambitious roadmap for a true Digital Single Market, through the removal of barriers to creating new online opportunities for citizens and businesses, especially SMEs.   The digital revolution is changing Europe radically and has great potential for the creation of millions of new skilled jobs and new opportunities for consumers. I therefore welcome the development of this motion for a Resolution to promote legislative and non-legislative measures for the benefit of consumers and to preserve the competitiveness of our social market economy.  As a Socialist I am particularly pleased with the request we sent to the Commission to seriously consider working conditions in the sharing economy and the parcel sector, as we cannot accept low levels of protection for workers. In addition, we call on the Commission to assess what protection consumers require in this area and to ensure that regulation is adapted to the digital environment.   The report also contains a powerful text on data protection, culture and media issues, digital skills, infrastructure and investment.

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 On 6 May 2015, the Commission decided on sixteen initiatives to be implemented by the end of 2016 under the title 'European Digital Strategy'. As a member of the Hungarian delegation to the People's Party, I voted in favour of the Kallas-Gebhardt report, which is the European Parliament's response to the strategy proposed by the Commission. The Digital Single Market opens up new opportunities to boost the economy through e-trade, facilitates businesses' compliance with administrative and financial standards and strengthens consumers' rights through e-governance. The digital internal market requires a regulatory framework that promotes the development of cloud computing, frontiers-free mobile data connectivity and simplified access to information and content, while guaranteeing privacy and personal data protection, cybersecurity and net neutrality. The adopted report proposes further steps to complete the Digital Single Market and address the impact of the implementation of the Digital Single Market on society and the economy as a whole.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 This is an own-initiative report on the Digital Single Market containing positive references such as the need to protect SMEs and labour rights, the need to safeguard personal data, strengthen safety and health measures for workers, and to safeguard the character of the Internet as an open, neutral, secure and inclusive platform in the interests of citizens. At the same time, however, a number of negative reports are identified, such as proposals for further harmonisation of legislation for the benefit of large companies, the promotion of the digital market as a tool to serve the objectives of EU foreign policy and the promotion of European satellite navigation systems. For Cyprus it is very negative to refer to the need for a common consolidated corporate tax base at EU level as well as a single VAT system.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report as the rapidly evolving use of the internet and mobile communications has changed the way citizens, companies and their employees communicate, access information and knowledge, invent, consume, share, participate and work. This has expanded and changed the economy, facilitating access by small and medium-sized companies to a potential customer base of 500 million customers within the EU, as well as to global markets, and allowing individuals the opportunity to develop new, entrepreneurial ideas and business models.  All Union policies and legislation in the area of the Digital Single Market should allow new opportunities for users and businesses and new innovative cross-border online services at competitive prices to emerge and grow, remove barriers between Member States and facilitate access for European businesses, in particular SMEs and start-ups, to the cross-border market, as key for growth and employment in the EU , while recognising that these opportunities will inevitably involve structural changes and taking a holistic approach, including the social dimension, and the need for the digital skills gap to be quickly filled. Building a data economy depends heavily on a legal framework that encourages the development, curation, maintenance and augmentation of databases, and is therefore dependent on a legal framework that is innovation-friendly and practical.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: Writing. The report sends a signal that the digitisation of the economy has now become the focus of the EU agenda. All parties agree that the progress made in the information and communications sector can help the private and public sectors to save time and costs. Investing in the industry can create growth and new jobs. In Brussels, ALFA is committed to ensuring that both sectors benefit from the digital revolution, that regulatory barriers are removed and that investment is made in the necessary infrastructure. The report is the first step in the right direction, which is why I voted in favour. However, the EU must be clear about one thing: if we want to create a successful European digital single market, we must take market-based measures and not create new European authorities. We need more freedom, more market and less bureaucracy. The slow liberalisation process of the last 20 years is one of the main reasons why we are lagging behind in the ICT sector today. The state must sell its shares in telecoms companies because it cannot regulate competition as the main shareholder of a telecoms company. Incidentally, I believe that the single euro must be abolished. It leads to strife and discord in Europe.

name: Brice Hortefeux (PPE)
text: In writing. If this is only an initiative report, the issue is fundamental because it paints a picture of our future economy. I am very much in favour of building a digital single market. We have the talent, we have the ideas, but we lack a unified market that, in some areas, is dominated by American companies. The reality is that we have built up a backlog that we must not only catch up with but also overcome by proposing innovative ideas in order to become the market leaders of the future. There is untapped growth potential in the digital revolution, and I am concerned that our young talent and start-ups are exporting to the United States to find opportunities that Europe does not offer. I think that we have here a pool of growth that France, through education, through training, through taxation and through a reform of the labour code, must integrate into its economic thinking and encourage to become a country that respects its traditions but also has the audacity to invest in the future.

name: Ian Hudghton (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this wide-ranging report which represents a reasonable compromise.  My own group has been instrumental in promoting the text supporting the use of open source software by public administrations and I am pleased that this is included in the final  text.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The report underlines consumer protection, data protection, infrastructure and investment, media, digital skills and copyright. It goes beyond the Commission strategy addressing issues such as platforms, structural changes in society and the impact of digitalisation on the employment world. We have to maximise the growth potential of the digital economy. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the Report on the Act "Towards the Digital Single Market" (2015/2147(INI)), since it is an extremely important document promoting and stimulating the European economy, creating it innovative and competitive in the world. This is a logical and necessary continuation of the political and economic integration of the European Union. The removal of barriers hindering the growth of the digital economy needs to continue. The report calls for a halt to the practice of blocking content, in order to encourage the free circulation of goods and services, including legally available content; supports competition in the telecommunications sector in order to provide consumers with quality service at affordable prices; The report supports innovation from the sharing economy to new forms of technological and economic innovation; supports online platforms. Platforms are the future and can be the engine of economic growth in the EU. E-government, eHealth and e-society are key tools for lowering bureaucracy and better everyday life for citizens, while e-commerce empowers and offers better choice for consumers. The report calls for setting one set of consumer policies and rights for online sales and digital content. The report aims to make the internet an open and neutral platform, an innovation and communications platform to prevent censorship and preserve freedom of expression.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this text because it gives clear support from the European Parliament to the Commission's communication on the digital economy. Indeed, this text uses the concept of the digital economy for political purposes. It obviously contributes to the construction of a European federalism without mentioning an essential and non-negotiable point in the age of globalisation and the dismantling of European OEMs: digital sovereignty.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. – I, with my colleagues, have voted to reject this report. The report calls for greater EU harmonisation and the instigation of EU legislation that will alter Member States’ taxation, internet, data sharing and e-commerce policies. UKIP vehemently disagrees with aspects of the text that support the continuation of the VAT MOSS regime as we believe this has been extremely harmful to UK businesses, particularly small and medium-sized enterprises.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ The 21st century economy is becoming more and more digitalised. In order to effectively adapt to this, we need an open market which encourages innovation and investment while deterring protectionism. I voted in favour of the report on the digital single market as it emphasises the importance of embracing changes brought about by digitalisation in an online world which has no borders.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report by my colleagues Evelyne Gebhardt and Kaja Kallas for a strategy for a digital single market. This report is the European Parliament's response to President Jean-Claude Juncker's Digital Strategy, which has made it one of the priorities of his mandate. It covers very different topics ranging from e-commerce, to copyright, VAT, the media and data protection. Digital is one of the challenges of tomorrow's world, and the European Parliament, by positioning itself on its issues, intends to prepare the Union for its leading position in all the areas covered by digital technology. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Jarosław Kalinowski (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 In the age of digital technologies, present in almost every area of our lives, legislation regulating the use, access and distribution of multimedia programs and content is of great interest. After all, this necessarily applies, to a greater or lesser extent, to almost all citizens: both private individuals, small and medium-sized enterprises, and large multinational corporations. The effective use of digital technologies provides more opportunities to find employment, access to a wider range of products, different methods of rapid exchange of information, and administrative improvements.  Last May, the European Commission published a communication entitled 'A Digital Single Market Strategy for Europe', comprising 16 initiatives to be implemented by the end of 2016, which this report, which we are voting on today, supports and extends. Among these, the greatest emphasis is placed on harmonising the rules on online sales so that they apply in all Member States, wherever the goods are purchased and sold. Such a 'cross-border' nature of the legislation will certainly make it easier for consumers to buy and possibly return or sell products.  The Digital Single Market should also mean a certain standard of quality for digital networks, the provision of internet access services and, in particular, the lifting of data restrictions.  It is hard to imagine a future today without access to the latest technologies, so we must support digitalisation in all sectors of the economy.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. The solutions that are needed to create the Digital Single Market are at the heart of the issue. The report recognises the obstacles and hurdles that entrepreneurs and consumers face at the moment if they want to take advantage of a digital Europe and aims to resolve them by the most flexible means possible without major regulatory complications. I am therefore voting in favour of this report.

name: Krišjānis Kariņš (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the European Parliament resolution on moving towards the Digital Single Market because I believe that digitisation has enormous potential to boost the economic growth of the European Union, both by promoting GDP growth, by creating a good investment environment and by creating thousands of new jobs.  If we can say that the Single Market in the European Union is already functioning in its traditional form, then there is still fragmentation in the digital market and there are 28 different laws in each Member State. This situation is unacceptable and is not in the interests of EU citizens. Uniform rules will facilitate cross-border trade, give businesses more choice for cross-border transactions and reduce administrative burdens, especially for small and medium-sized enterprises.  This resolution also stresses the need to find a solution to end geo-blocking and price discrimination by location. If a resident purchases a service or goods online, he should have the right to enjoy the service regardless of where they are, the country of issue of the credit card or nationality.

name: Tunne Kelam (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. The report points out what the EU has to accomplish to enable a well-functioning digital single market and makes good proposals to fully enhance the potential of the DSM.  Geo-blocking is one of main obstacles to be removed. Blocking content and building pricing policy based on geographical location is discriminatory and in contradiction with the nature of a digital single market that should provide services and goods equally across the EU. Similarly to geo-blocking, cross-border payments also hinder e-commerce. Instant e-/m-payments across the EU must become a reality based on common standards. The review of the Payment Services Directive comes at the right time and must be accomplished as soon as possible.  The report rightly points out the lack of digital skills among European citizens and calls for the development of a skills strategy that should especially target disadvantaged groups in the population. E-governance must be advanced. The aim should be that our citizens can fully interact with authorities also online and are relieved from the burden to introduce the same data multiple times. Lastly, digital functions only with security. I am glad that a political agreement on data protection package and an informal agreement on NIS have been achieved.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report. Labour MEPs are protecting the rights of workers in the new online economy, and calling for everyone to have the right to access the internet and use online services, be they young, old, disabled or isolated.

name: Béla Kovács (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 Eu trade legislation has largely been harmonized, but the digital market is still fragmented, even though it is justified to improve harmonisation in this area, as the share of cross-border traffic is high. Unjustified territorial discrimination and content restrictions against consumers should be eliminated and consumer protection strengthened. In the context of the digital market, too, a balance must be struck against excessive expectations, while remaining on the ground of reality. It will not solve Europe's accumulated economic woes or the problem of unemployment, but there is no doubt that the rapid growth of the number of online platforms has already led to an economic recovery in the Eu and opened up new horizons. Data protection concerns are rightly raised. The regulation should ensure that everyone has full control over the processing of their own data.  It will be difficult to find harmony between the digital world, the resulting all-out type of computerism, virtuality and the future of man as a spirited physical and spiritual being, but it is our duty to strive for it.

name: Marju Lauristin (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 It is time for Europe to get rid of the image of the "old world" in the digital sector. We need a real digital single market, a policy that supports innovation and research. Taking into account the major differences between Member States in relation to the use of digital services in e-governance and internet regulations and new business models and e-skills, EU countries should make joint efforts to overcome these differences. Europe must make a decisive leap into the digital age.

name: Constance Le Grip (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the Digital Single Market Initiative Report, an issue on which I have been very involved and I have tabled many amendments. This report should set the stage for a stable European legal environment for a more efficient European digital economy. Businesses need legal certainty to grow across borders and consumers to be able to buy and sell online with confidence across Europe.  But the creation of a single digital market must also enable us to fight against counterfeiting on the internet and defend ourselves against the American giants and tomorrow In China. For example, I voted against paragraph 73 of this report, which considered that the limited legal liability of platforms was "essential", even though Google, Apple, Facebook and amazon are now reaping huge profits from a market of 500 million consumers by circumventing taxes, flouting European rules, crushing competitors and not really participating in the financing of cultural products. , partly because of this limited legal liability that has become obsolete and aberrant.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the Report on the Digital Single Market. This text uses the digital economy as a pretext to advance the federalisation of Europe in areas of sovereignty. In the area of taxation, for example, it provides for increased harmonisation of VAT in the field of online shipments, moving towards a single rate, to develop cross-border purchases.  This report is ultra-liberal and free-trade. It deliberately ignores the vital issue of digital sovereignty to deliver our states' bound feet and fists to the American telecom and internet giants. The same is true of the sovereignty of states over personal data, the dismantling of European telecoms equipment manufacturers, to the benefit of Chinese and American companies, and the lack of investment due to excessive competition (digital divide).

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this ultra-liberal text because it uses the digital economy to increase the federalisation of Europe, notably through increased vat harmonisation on online shipments to develop cross-border purchases. On the other hand, it serves powerful financial interests by promoting the concentration of operators at European level, which will make it more difficult for France to regain its sovereignty in this area.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. The title of this report was not good enough. The content followed in this direction towards ultra-liberalism and total free trade. It uses the digital economy as a pretext to advance the federalisation of Europe in different areas of sovereignty.  Taxation is thus impacted, since a further harmonisation of VAT towards a single rate is mentioned, in order to make the market more fluid. Other measures developed by this text include the concentration of telecommunications operators into a few large European operators, as well as the unification of copyright and intellectual property rules (with a view to banning zone blockages).  The digital sovereignty of states is thus undermined and handed over to the giants - American - telecoms and the Internet. Finally, this report leads to an unacceptable loss of national sovereignty over the issue of personal data, a crucial issue for all of us. I voted staunchly against this deplorable text.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report by representing a clear, progressive and ambitious roadmap for a true Digital Single Market, through the removal of barriers to creating new online opportunities for citizens and businesses, especially SMEs.   The digital revolution is changing Europe radically and has great potential for the creation of millions of new skilled jobs and new opportunities for consumers. I therefore welcome the development of this motion for a Resolution to promote legislative and non-legislative measures for the benefit of consumers and to preserve the competitiveness of our social market economy.  As a Socialist I am particularly pleased with the request we sent to the Commission to seriously consider working conditions in the sharing economy and the parcel sector, as we cannot accept low levels of protection for workers. In addition, we call on the Commission to assess what protection consumers require in this area and to ensure that regulation is adapted to the digital environment.   The report also contains a powerful text on data protection, culture and media issues, digital skills, infrastructure and investment.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. In order to offer new opportunities for both citizens and businesses, as well as to strengthen competitiveness in the EU, it is necessary to relaunch the single market and achieve a more integrated society.  Therefore, this report considers it essential to promote a more dynamic economy that enables innovation and removes barriers to businesses, both newly created and expanding, as well as innovative companies and SMEs. This area, including new funding models for newly created EU companies. Similarly, the report aims to avoid unjustified geo-blocking, to end professional activities or business models that violate copyright, to reduce VAT-related barriers in cross-border sales and to combat illegal content on the Internet. To improve the accessibility of persons with disabilities, we have made a number of amendments which are finally reflected in the final text. Due to the great importance of all the aspects discussed above, I support this report, as it will help to positively transform some crucial segments of the labour market.

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR)
text: Writing. The report sends a signal that the digitisation of the economy has now become the focus of the EU agenda. All parties agree that the progress made in the information and communications sector can help the private and public sectors to save time and costs. Investing in the industry can create growth and new jobs. In Brussels, ALFA is committed to ensuring that both sectors benefit from the digital revolution, that regulatory barriers are removed and that investment is made in the necessary infrastructure. The report is the first step in the right direction, which is why I voted in favour. However, the EU must be clear about one thing: if we want to create a successful European digital single market, we must take market-based measures and not create new European authorities. We need more freedom, more market and less bureaucracy. The slow liberalisation process of the last 20 years is one of the main reasons why we are lagging behind in the ICT sector today. The state must sell its shares in telecoms companies because it cannot regulate competition as the main shareholder of a telecoms company.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against. The call for uniform taxation and uniform regulation is wrapped up in nice talk about the digital market. The digital market needs freedom and not more European regulation.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Technology development in recent decades has greatly improved and facilitated the business of entrepreneurs. The use of the internet and mobile communications has changed the way citizens, companies and their employees communicate, access information, share and use knowledge. In this way, it eases the way for SMEs to enter not only the European Union market, but also other global markets. However, despite the obvious progress, there is a lot of room for development that can be achieved by establishing this kind of market, primarily in e-trading, because only 15% of consumers use the possibility of online shopping from another country, while the total sales of goods and services from the Republic of Croatia to the countries of the European Union in 2014 amounted to 9 %.  The fact that only 7% of EU SMEs sell their products and services abroad speaks volumes about the potential of such a market. This is supported by the fact that only 14% of SMEs use the internet as a sales channel and there are great opportunities for improvement. The EU competition policy should be fully applied to the Digital Single Market, allowing for a level playing field for all market participants and better market control would reduce the possibility of manipulation and price discrimination against customers. Therefore, I supported this report.

name: Светослав Христов Малинов (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Through the resolution adopted today by 551 votes to 551, the European Parliament has given its support to the European Commission's Digital Single Market Strategy and has clearly shown its intention to actively participate in its implementation. From now on, we follow the roadmap of 16 initiatives to be implemented by the end of 2016. The Single Digital Market is a horizontal policy covering issues from consumer protection and unjustified geographical blocking, cross-border parcel transport and VAT, to copyright, cybersecurity and privacy. Therefore, the right framework for regulating these issues is at European level. I believe that a key objective of the new legislation should be to ensure better access for consumers and businesses to online goods and services, regardless of which EU Member State they are in. I join the call to establish cross-border e-commerce rules. It is particularly important that consumers have the same rights and protections, whether they shop online or in traditional stores. I am convinced that the single digital market will lead to a significant boost to competitiveness, growth and jobs.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The e-environment has become an integral part of our lives. It is therefore perfectly logical that the opportunities and existing potential found should be exploited in order to have a positive impact on the daily lives of Europeans. This applies to all sectors affected, from entrepreneurship and education to culture and security. At present, even with the gradual development of a supranational system at EU level – i.e. the digital single market – there are still 28 separate relevant policy-making and implementation systems that lead to certain obstacles, such as limiting consumer opportunities, as well as the more active development of safety systems due to the existence of several often fully separate systems. Maximising digitisation, greater standardisation of VAT taxation, promoting security-en-usedition efforts and putting the other steps in perspective would allow not only a huge springboard for the development of the EU economy, but also for other sectors such as information exchange, education or ecology directly through lower use of wood due to the higher degree of digitisation of several materials. The main thing, of course, is to guarantee in parallel the permanent and maximum stable existence of electricity.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ The importance and necessity of the Digital Single Market as an essential tool to facilitate and facilitate communication and build economic and business relations, not only for companies, businesses and public administrations, but also for natural persons and consumers, is now self-evident. It is a path towards increasing economic growth and, through effective communication and improving services, a path towards improving the quality of life in the States of the Union. However, I consider it important that the process should create the conditions for building modern digital networks and acquiring the necessary skills, while at the same time establishing, in particular, legislative and control mechanisms to maintain the credibility and secure protection of the personal data of users of the Digital Single Market.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the road to a legislative act on the Digital Single Market because I consider it complete and documented.

name: Marian-Jean Marinescu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for the report on the Digital Single Market because Europe urgently needs a clear legislative framework and criteria to create a functioning market in this area. Fragmentation of the single market, the fact that all 28 Member States each have their own digital rules are major obstacles to the development, in particular of SMEs and start-ups.
