Only 1.7% of EU businesses use digital technologies and only 14% of SMEs use the internet for sales. In order to increase global competitiveness, Europe must build a digital economy as soon as possible, a common set of digital rules, give free and free internet access to all SMEs and eliminate geographical gridlock and price discrimination based on geographical location or nationality.  I stress the importance of developing European satellite navigation systems, investing in fast communications networks and in the digitisation of the energy sector, meters and smart grids. Future legislation on the Digital Single Market must also create the necessary conditions for type-approval for the installation of the eCall system on motor vehicles and the extension of access to 112 emergency services to all European users.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this text. This report uses the digital economy as a pretext to advance the federalisation of Europe in areas that still belong to the Member States: taxation (with enhanced harmonisation of VAT in the field of online shipments), concentration of operators into a few large "European" operators, unification of copyright and intellectual property rules (to prohibit zone blockages) Etc. The result is an ultra-liberal and free-trade text that sacrifices the sovereignty of our states on the altar of the American telecom and internet giants.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report and note with alarm that 44.8% of households in the EU do not have access to fast internet, and that current policies and incentives have failed to deliver adequate digital infrastructure, particularly in rural areas.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the report 'Towards an act on the digital single market'. The digital single market is one of the main sectors for economic growth and the creation of thousands of new jobs, opening up new opportunities to stimulate the economy, through e-commerce, and at the same time facilitating administrative and financial compliance for businesses. A digital single market is crucial because it provides consumers with better services at better prices, contributes to business growth, strengthens the role of citizens, consumers and entrepreneurs, with easier online access to products and services across Europe and improving conditions for digital networks and services to develop.

name: Jiří Maštálka (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Report on the Digital Single Market is undoubtedly one of the most important topics of the entire current legislative period. I am aware of the modernization of the times and the accelerated development of the digital market. The Internet has become an integral part of the daily life of virtually all citizens, who use it not only to search for information, but also to buy online and share information on social networks. The inconsistency of the rules in the internal market causes a number of obstacles for both operators and users. We support net neutrality as well as the elimination of geoblocking. At the same time, however, our faction draws attention to some of the risks associated with these developments, such as the lack of protection for internet workers from home, the difficulty of adapting to new technologies for the older generation of citizens and, last but not least, the lack of protection of personal data and data. That is why I abstained in the final vote.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The role the Internet plays in the European economy varies rapidly. It is therefore increasingly important that every person in the EU has access to a fast and reliable Internet network. As the report states, almost 45% of EU citizens do not have access to the network and it must therefore be ensured that this section of the population, with access to the Internet, can also contribute to the economy of the twenty-first century. Given the changes in the digital economy, we need to ensure greater protection against illegal activities. Once security is guaranteed, the Internet can lead to greater growth. I therefore agree with Mrs Gebhardt and Mr Kallas that more work is needed to take advantage of the full potential of the digital economy.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. The Commission communication entitled 'A Strategy for Europe's Digital Single Market' makes it clear that, if we are able to create a functioning digital single market with clear rules, we will be laying the groundwork for this activity to be one of the keys to growth and employment in the future, to relaunch the single market and to make European society more inclusive , offering new opportunities to citizens and businesses. We must therefore work to create a transparent, efficient and effective digital single market, which will help us recover from the crisis in recent years and in which free competition is guaranteed, for which the Commission must ensure a safe framework and enable this sector to develop all the potential it has.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. I believe that some of the points proposed, such as the strengthening of legal certainty.B, are reasonable and necessary. Unfortunately, however, the report leaves many questions unanswered. For example, the question of financing. Infrastructure competition would also be an important point, but this too is not mentioned in the report. I therefore abstain from voting.

name: Emma McClarkin (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ Today’s vote is a welcome step towards deepening and expanding the single market. A strong digital single market brings large benefits for SMEs, consumers and to technology start-ups.  Crucially I welcome the prominent role and appreciation given to Intellectual Property Rights here. Whilst the Digital Single Market is beneficial to consumers, I am pleased to see there is recognition of the work and creativity behind these products and services, and it has steered clear of upsetting business models that currently function effectively.   However, I am wary of the direction and instruction this report gives to the AVMS review prior to the completion of the Commission’s REFIT exercise. Elements of the text, for example, risk chipping away at the country-of-origin principle, which would damage the very core of a directive that currently functions well for all; any move towards a country-of-destination approach is a slippery slope that we must remain alert to, particularly when we have yet to see the evidence on which to base this.   The outcome of the vote is a positive step for the internal market, for consumers and for SMEs but we must remain cautious of how it is shaped in actual legislation.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The report considers that "the achievement of a digital single market [...] could promote the EU's competitiveness, have a positive influence on growth and jobs, revive the single market and make society more inclusive, by providing new opportunities for citizens and businesses, particularly through exchange and innovation sharing." Beyond the fine words, it is noted that both the Commission and the rapporteurs envisage the digital revolution only in economic terms, without really taking users into account.   Some advances are still present in this text, such as the limitation of geoblocking (i.e. the inability to access certain services on the internet according to the IP address linked to a country). But the issue of roaming charges is carefully evaded, as are the aspects of net neutrality. Therefore I abstain.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. This text is a flagship document of the legislature: it provides clear support from the European Parliament for the Commission's communication on the digital economy. Indeed, this text uses the concept of the digital economy for political purposes. It obviously contributes to the construction of a European federalism without mentioning an essential and non-negotiable point in the age of globalisation and the dismantling of European OEMs: digital sovereignty. On this vital issue and in the interest of our nation, I oppose this text.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report "Towards the Digital Single Market Act".  Innovation in the digital sector is a constant that changes the way citizens communicate, share and behave. Therefore, new opportunities arise for both businesses and users. Increased use of digital technologies can help improve citizens' access to information and culture, increase employment opportunities and provide them with a wider choice of products. EU policies and legislation on the digital single market should provide new opportunities for users and businesses in a total of 500 million EU consumers. This is essential to remove barriers between Member States and facilitate access by European companies, especially SMEs and start-ups.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this initiative because the Union needs a common digital market to remain competitive in the global arena. This initiative will set rules on e–commerce, copyright, and cross-border parcel delivery, among others.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. Europe must join the digital convoy that concerns all aspects of the lives of citizens, young people, public men and businessmen as soon as possible, to the point of changing democracy itself. The digital economy is a mine of job creation, innovation and growth. We are making a technological leap by combining machines, networks, telecommunications and computers.  However, it cannot be carried out in defiance of data protection and privacy. If every European citizen has the right to internet and broadband wherever he is, he is also entitled to respect for his privacy. I am therefore in favour of a regulated digital single market that places the individual at the heart of his or her concerns.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: writing – The digital market is one huge opportunity to get the economies of the states up and running completely. Online sales and eGovernment are still underused, despite the fact that the number of people using digital technologies is constantly increasing. Today, it is not exceptional that they are controlled by children and seniors. The use of the Digital Single Market has great potential and I consider its support to be extremely necessary. Although I am in favour of an accelerated start, I consider it equally important to adopt satisfactory, consistent legislation that will 24/7, which we routinely use but which still lacks uniform regulation. I also see as an essential matter the regulation of the entrepreneurial culture in the digital sphere and the protection of consumers.

name: Anne-Marie Mineur (GUE/NGL)
text: Written. 'First, we spent months debating which parliamentary committees would be competent. Then we had to go through almost 1300 amendments from colleagues, and now that we finally have the plenary vote, the Commission's first legislative proposals are already in place in this area. In doing so, the EP is putting the horse behind the cart, because the report was intended to influence the Commission before it would issue formal legislative proposals. That is why I voted against this report.

name: Sorin Moisă (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This resolution represents Parliament’s position on Commission’s action plan for achieving a Digital Single Market.  Specifically this refers to tackling issues such as geo-blocking, the reform of the copyright regime, the faster roll-out of both mobile and wired broadband internet and to incentivising the use of e-commerce services throughout Europe.  These elements are essential for the EU’s economic competitiveness, growth and more job opportunities for its citizens. It is a balanced resolution that I believe to correctly identify the means to create a single market for digital services and therefore it has my vote.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Digital Single Market offers a huge opportunity to expand EU businesses and businesses and to fully restore the EU labour market, which has been torn apart by the economic crisis and its actions. Innovations in the digital sector are constantly changing citizens' communication, sharing and consumption habits and even behaviour, so innovation represents new opportunities for both businesses and consumers. The spread of the use of digital technologies also facilitates citizens' access to information and culture, increases their employment opportunities and makes them available a wider range of products. It also offers an opportunity to make the governance and administration of the Union and the Member States more efficient. The joint report of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy and the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection responds to the 16 proposals of the European Commission, with further details on the steps needed to complete the Digital Single Market and the impact of the implementation of the Digital Single Market on society and the economy as a whole. It points out that dynamic economic promotion is essential for innovation to flourish and for innovative companies to expand, and that this is why the European Commission, together with the Member States, should focus on this. More needs to be done to promote an entrepreneurial culture, including innovative business models, and to link many of Europe's successful technology centres. I supported the adoption of this report.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. This document gives the European Parliament the support of the Commission on the digital economy and, under the pretext of regulating the digital economy, it is playing the game of the federalisation of Europe. Thus, it provides for a harmonization of VAT to achieve a single rate. In addition, it concentrates operators on a few large European operators that would make it difficult to return to national digital sovereignty.  We therefore oppose this text, which goes against any notion of national sovereignty but towards more than a federal Europe.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. I advocate a digital market in which start-ups can grow and progress in Europe rather than having to emigrate to Silicon Valley.  We must support European start-ups by facilitating access to venture capital financing, creating a simplified tax system across the European Union and betting on a reduction in bureaucracy that facilitates the creation of new businesses. I am also in favour of new technology companies in the area of the sharing economy which contribute very positively to economic growth, job creation and wealth creation across Europe.  However, I believe that this activity should be regulated at European level. There must be a common system of payment of taxes and consumer safety should be taken into account. We cannot claim that we want an innovative Europe and at the same time block start-ups and these new forms of business.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This text gives a blank answer to the European Commission's communication on the digital economy.  The Commission is using the digital economy as a Trojan horse of forced federalisation since the text includes enhanced harmonisation of VAT in the field of online shipments and aims to introduce a single rate for cross-border purchases but also to promote major economic operators at European level, instead of national operators. , in order to undermine any strategic power of states on the issue.  Finally, there are plans to harmonize copyright and intellectual property. In short, this text clearly opposes the sovereignty of Member States and does not mention the deleterious consequences of competition policies on infrastructure investment. So I voted against it.

name: Clare Moody (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The Digital Single Market is a great example of how British consumers benefit from membership of the EU – indeed, only last month the Commission unveiled proposals that will allow travellers to watch iPlayer, Netflix and other digital content while abroad. We also need to ensure the digital economy does not leave behind people in certain workplaces, and in rural or remote communities. All EU countries, including the UK, must invest more in superfast broadband, and roll it out quicker and wider. Our future lies in being a knowledge economy. I am pleased we are taking steps at an EU level to deliver this; I hope the UK Government is taking note.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Labour is protecting the rights of workers in the new online economy, and calling for everyone to have the right to access the internet and use online services, be they young, old, disabled or isolated.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the Strategy for a European Digital Single Market. The aim is to strengthen the competitiveness of European companies in the face of global digital giants in this sector with immense growth potential. The emphasis is also on safety: citizens should be given the same protection when they buy online as when they buy from traditional stores.  As far as companies are concerned, it is absolutely essential to provide them with a stable legal environment so that they can develop across European borders, without unjustified additional costs or legal uncertainty. The role and responsibility of internet platforms and intermediaries will need to be clarified: they must be responsible for the content they broadcast. I have approved the provisions on the protection of copyright and intellectual property, in order to better combat counterfeiting and to protect rights holders, who must be able to benefit from the value created on the internet.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Given the growing importance of the digital market and the need for progressive European integration into the strategic sectors of our economies, we welcome this report. The work that the European Parliament is doing on the digital single market is crucial, aiming to reduce barriers to access to the digital market and to increase business and investment opportunities while safeguarding and, in some cases increasing, consumer rights, especially in the area of personal data protection. In addition to these priorities, the report supports new investments in digital education, in order to respond to growing demand from the world of work. I also believe that the digital single market can guarantee multiple improvement effects for European consumers, who will have real access to more competitive prices for goods and services, thanks to entry into a wider and more competitive market. The digital single market could also provide opportunities for small and medium-sized enterprises, which will benefit from new investment and business opportunities in high value-added sectors, the creation of new jobs and an extremely large and constantly growing potential market.

name: Renaud Muselier (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the Report on the Digital Single Market, considering that better market coherence must be pursued. The single market will enable a significant improvement in the distribution of digital goods and services in Europe, thereby promoting the growth of our European digital economy.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I welcome this report, which responds to the 16 proposals put forward by the European Commission and clarifies more fully the actions to be taken to complete the digital single market as well as the consequences that its implementation will have on society and the economy as a whole. The Digital Single Market Strategy is structured in three parts: improving consumer and business access to digital goods and services across Europe; creating a favourable environment and a level playing field for digital networks and innovative services to develop; maximise the growth potential of the digital economy. It is necessary to promote a dynamic economy in order for innovation to flourish and innovative companies to grow, and it is therefore on this objective that the European Commission and the Member States should focus their efforts.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 By 2016, we have reached the point where, regardless of age and social situation, the vast majority of the EU population is involved in digitalisation. The labour market is constantly growing in positions that require a high level of digital skills to fill, and the Digital Single Market provides a unique opportunity for SMEs and microenterprises to promote growth and create jobs. We cannot allow Slovakian businesses, and thus Slovakia, to be put at a disadvantage on such a priority and important subject, and I therefore support the adoption of the package of measures and the swift implementation of the action plan set out there in it.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. – I have voted for this report that will not only improve citizens’ access to information, but will also maximise the growth potential of the digital economy and will improve governance and transparency in the EU and its Member States, within a single market.

name: Момчил Неков (S&D)
text: in writing. – Achieving a Digital Single Market means, above all, ensuring growth and jobs by finally removing borders between Member States and access for business to the cross-border market. It is for this reason that I supported this report, which I find balanced and objectively reflective of reality. Nowadays, the digital revolution affects every aspect of our lives. Thanks to the Internet, we have access to all kinds of digital content and this is an integral part of our daily lives. Unfortunately, however, within the EU around 45% of households still do not have access to fast internet, and in many rural areas there is no adequate digital infrastructure.  In conclusion, I would like to point out that the promotion of digital and media literacy must be prioritised in educational institutions in order for everyone to fully reap the benefits of interconnected e-services.

name: Dan Nica (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 A digital single market must provide quality services and facilitate the daily lives of end consumers, encourage innovation and create new opportunities for businesses and citizens. The resolution on the preparation of a legislative act on the Digital Single Market develops the aspects of the actions to be taken to complete the Digital Single Market and the consequences it will have on society and the economy as a whole.  As coordinator of S&D ITRE, I support the importance of investment in infrastructure and fast and fast communications networks, efficient spectrum allocation and management and the rapid deployment of 5G technology and ultrafast broadband services, high data protection standards and the security of international data transfers, the elimination of geo-blocking and improved consumer access to content.  In order to reduce the digital divide, we call on the Commission to consider a number of legislative measures and revisions: the revision of EU telecommunications rules, the revision of the interoperability framework, including The Commission's mandates within European standardisation organisations, and a long-term strategy on the future uses of the different frequency bands that are particularly necessary for the deployment of 5G-based networks.

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report, which should be a springboard for the development and submission of 16 digital market legislative initiatives for which the EP will have codecision power and will therefore be a key actor. On the level of concrete measures, our efforts must aim, for example, at ending the practice of blocking digital content on the basis of geographical location, ensuring equal consumer protection, regardless of whether digital content has been purchased online or in a brick-and-mortar store, and finding innovative solutions in the field of cross-border delivery of consignments in order to improve services and reduce costs.

name: Андрей Новаков (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report looks at the actions to be taken to complete the Digital Single Market and the impact on society and the economy as a whole. Europe must exploit the great potential of the ICT sector to digitise industry and maintain its global competitiveness. I support this report and believe that the digital revolution affects all aspects of our societies, leading to new challenges and opportunities. It has the potential to empower citizens and entrepreneurs in a new way. Private investment in high-speed and ultra-high-speed communication networks is a requirement for digital progress.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. Geoblocking is not only a problem of consumer protection, but also one of freedom of expression. Unjustified practices of geo-blocking, such as discrimination against consumers on the basis of their IP addresses, postal address or the country of issue of credit cards, must be abolished as soon as possible. Access to goods and services must be improved for consumers. Unfortunately, there is a lack of the right approaches to be able to vote in favour of the report in this form, which is why I abstained.

name: Younous Omarjee (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. I abstained on this initiative report on the Digital Single Market because, while it gives an interesting overview of the digital situation in Europe today, and legitimately calls on the European Commission to adopt a genuine vision for a connected Europe, it proposes a digital future essentially based on deregulation and open markets.  However, such a vision will not combine the two major challenges of the digital single market, namely to take sufficient account of the role of digital economic actors, and in particular start-ups and small independent and alternative suppliers, and to enable, while protecting them, citizens to benefit from free access to new digital technologies.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The EU's digital single market has great potential to contribute to the development of businesses and businesses and would also contribute to the exit from the financial crisis. The single market will provide consumers and businesses with better access to digital goods and services and will support a level playing field for the development of digital networks and innovative services.

name: Δημήτρης Παπαδάκης (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report which provides for a strategy for the creation of a free and secure digital single market. According to a Commission survey, the Digital Single Market could contribute around EUR 520 billion to THE EU28's GDP. However, European citizens face obstacles when using online services and tools. Only 15% of citizens buy over the Internet from another EU country and only 7% of small and medium-sized enterprises sell in another EU country. The regulatory barriers that still exist and the fragmentation of the market mean the loss of goods and services for citizens and a slowdown in business growth. With the adoption of the report, we aim to remove obstacles, always with consumer protection and the strengthening of the European entrepreneurial spirit as a priority.  We must emphasise the exploitation of the full potential of the single digital market, the tackling of the problem of skills shortages, the consolidation of a climate of trust, security and certainty among consumers. I also stress the importance of high-speed Internet access for all European citizens without discrimination.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP has voted to reject this report. The report calls for greater EU harmonisation and the instigation of EU legislation that will alter Member States’ taxation, internet, data sharing and e-commerce policies. UKIP vehemently disagrees with aspects of the text that support the continuation of the VAT MOSS regime as we believe this has been extremely harmful to UK businesses, particularly small and medium-sized enterprises.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that Europe, through the creation of the digital single market, is responding effectively to the challenges that the continuous changes in digital technologies are proposing. I believe that the removal of local barriers and regulations would lead to enormous growth, resulting in the creation of thousands of jobs. It is clear that I support the resolution which, among other important innovations, provides for the modernisation of public administrations (e-governance) which will lead to a reduction in costs and an improvement in services to the citizen. I voted in favour.

name: Eva Paunova (PPE)
text: in writing. – Creating a Digital Single Market is Europe’s priority and in order to achieve it, it is crucial to improve access to goods and services by eliminating unjustified practices of blocking geographically and unfair price discrimination on the basis of nationality or geographical location. Increasing consumer confidence in online services and online stores will increase confidence in digitalisation as a whole. During my mandate as an MEP, I am committed to supporting the implementation of the DSM. I am, therefore, in favour of the report.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒I welcome the Digital Single Market Strategy for Europe, as I think that achieving a Digital Single Market, based on a common set of rules, could boost the EU's competitiveness, have positive effects on growth and jobs, relaunch the single market and create a more inclusive society, providing new opportunities for citizens and businesses.  I believe that better regulation of access to legislation set as digital would be aimed at overcoming the legal fragmentation of the single market, reducing the administrative burden, i.e. reducing the administrative burden. removing barriers for businesses, in particular innovative, small and medium-sized, start-ups and scale-ups. Citizens' and businesses' trust in the digital environment is key to the full growth of innovation and growth in the digital economy. Likewise, strengthening their trust through data protection and high-level security standards aims to achieve a better, more competitive and safer cross-border market for e-commerce for all consumers.   E-commerce brings in €500 billion a year in the European Union and is important for complementing non-online trade, while providing consumers with more choice, especially in remote areas and for SMEs with new opportunities. For all the positives of this strategy, I fully support it.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. This text supports the European Parliament's communication of the Committee on the Digital Economy. it uses it as a pretext to advance the federalisation of Europe in areas of sovereignty: taxation: in the name of market fluidisation, it provides for enhanced harmonisation of VAT in the field of online shipments, moving towards a single rate, to develop cross-border purchases; concentration of operators into a few large European-level operators, which would make it impossible for states to regain their sovereignty in this strategic industry; unification of copyright and intellectual property rules to prohibit zone blockages. This text is ultra-liberal and free-trader. It deliberately ignores the vital issue of digital sovereignty to deliver our states' bound feet and fists to the American telecom and internet giants. The same is true of the sovereignty of States over personal data, the dismantling of European telecoms equipment manufacturers, to the benefit of the Chinese and the Americans, the lack of investment due to excessive competition (digital divide). So I voted against it.

name: Pina Picierno (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The creation of a digital single market in Europe is probably one of the most important objectives to be achieved during this parliamentary term, given the impetus it can give to growth, employment and technological innovation. I voted in favour of this report, because not only did it take on board the Commission's good proposal, but it has definitely improved it, for example with regard to the impact on employment and society as a whole, which the digital revolution can bring about.  While it is true that we must do our best to 'liberate' market forces that will foster innovation, competitiveness, particularly for SMEs and competition, it is equally important to govern these changes. The rights of European consumers must be protected, ensuring the security of networks and the protection of personal data, ensuring a high quality of new jobs, defending workers' rights through the application of existing rules or the adoption of new ones, if necessary. I am also pleased with the work that has been done on recognising the value of the sharing economy and the need for its clear regulation at European level, on the protection of authors of artistic and cultural works and on the importance given to investment and the development of e-governance and networks.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ The Digital Single Market Strategy for Europe is one of the Commission's more important and complex initiatives and promises a lot about the potential for growth, innovation, competitiveness and employment. There are three fundamental objectives of this initiative: better access to the Digital Single Market for entrepreneurs and consumers, creating a favourable and level playing field for innovative services and digital networks, and maximsing the potential for the growth of the digital economy. On the other hand, what makes this report particularly important is the inclusion of new and less recognised dimensions in terms of the effects and aspects of JDT such as structural changes in society, the impact of digitalisation on the labour market and employment, and in particular labour and social rights. The call should be commended to examine the effects of digitalisation on workers' psychological condition, disruption of traditional working hours, work from home and safety at work, and cognitive abilities and development of children.  I also support the call for greater fostering the development of digital skills in the education system, as well as the demand for greater investment in youth media and online literacy. In Croatia, for example, too little is still invested in equipment, teacher education, but also raising awareness of the importance of responsible internet use, which is also related to the lack of market for much needed IT skills of workers.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I agree with MP Kaja Kallas and Evelyne Gebhardt's report on "According to the Digital Single Market Act." The focus of the report is one of the most important pillars of President Juncker's agenda for this Commission. The report is extensive and covers, inter alia, e-commerce rules, cross-border parcel delivery, geographical blockades, copyright protection, value added tax administration, telecommunications framework, audio-visual media, platforms and intermediary role, data protection, e-administration, opportunities for increased growth and competition such as big data, standardisation, research and e-capabilities. Digital technology, which knows no borders, offers us a range of possibilities, and it is up to us to take full advantage of the great opportunities it offers us. To do so, it is necessary to have the courage to overcome national barriers to telecommunications regulation, copyright and data protection rules, the application of competition rules and much more. A connected digital single market would result in additional growth of EUR 250 billion during the mandate of the next Commission, while creating hundreds of thousands of new jobs, especially for young people looking for work. Such a single market would of course contribute to the creation of a dynamic knowledge-based society. It is important to point out that such a market would greatly improve the world economy, which is digitised at lightning speed.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Innovation in the digital sector introduces new opportunities for both businesses and users. The Digital Single Market Strategy is structured in three parts: improving consumer and business access to digital goods and services across Europe, creating a favourable environment and a level playing field for digital networks and innovative services to develop and maximising the growth potential of the digital economy. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that, working together with the Commission and the Member States, we can achieve greater use of digital technologies to modernise and improve governance and public administration within the European Union. In addition, it should be borne in mind that in the future more public and private resources will be needed to strengthen cybersecurity and encryption of online communication, prevent cyberattacks and increase knowledge about basic cybersecurity among users of digital services. I hope that, through a legislative act for the digital single market, European entrepreneurs and businesses will be able to thrive and be competitive globally.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The pace of development of the digital market has changed our reality and the way we look at industry and the competitiveness of European businesses. Nevertheless, the report calls for the creation of an EU-wide common consolidated corporate tax base (CCCTB), which I cannot support, all the more so in a report in which competitiveness is one of the main conditions. Firstly, this is a report on the digital environment in the EU, not on direct taxation, and this is one of the reasons why I cannot support a text that contains such a call. Furthermore, I cannot agree with the demand that active fiscal policies will be lost and, as a result, the competitiveness of the EU economies with the lowest CIT rates will be reduced. The argument that unfair competition within the European Union is taking place in the area of taxation is an abuse and a unilateral interpretation of the situation by some Member States, and that smaller Member States would simply lose out on harmonisation.  Finally, one of the reasons why I cannot support the presence of this provision in the final text is the result of pressure in the past on some countries that have been accused of applying 'extremely harmful tax competition'. This way of speaking to sovereign Member States with their own fiscal policies is simply unacceptable.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. The digital market on the internet is a huge reserve of potential growth. It has grown strongly in recent years: more and more of us are shopping on the internet, renting and watching movies on the internet. However, the digital market is under-exploited by our companies in Europe, and the cause is very simple: there are barriers to the emergence of a single, common and European digital market.  Today, it is sometimes impossible to have a product delivered because of our place of residence, impossible to watch a video from abroad. We have just voted on a key text in the European Parliament calling for all these obstacles to be removed. In this way, our companies will be able to compete directly with the American or Asian giants. It's good for our economy, and good for our jobs.  But we must not break down barriers under any condition. The internet must remain a space of freedom, but not an area of law-free. I therefore want to develop a European-a-family digital market, where we protect copyright, where we make the major video and music platforms responsible for the content they broadcast.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP has voted to reject this report. The report calls for greater EU harmonisation and the instigation of EU legislation that will alter Member States’ taxation, internet, data sharing and e-commerce policies. UKIP vehemently disagrees with aspects of the text that support the continuation of the VAT MOSS regime as we believe this has been extremely harmful to UK businesses; particularly small and medium-sized enterprises.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report responds to the 16 proposals submitted by the European Commission on 6 May 2015 in the Communication entitled 'A digital strategy for Europe'. This communication is set out in the Digital Single Market Strategy, which is generally based on the assumption that innovation in the digital sector can contribute to the emergence of new opportunities for businesses and users.  I voted in favour of this report because it defends the involvement of the Consumer Protection Cooperation Network and the clarification of existing Community competition law. I also welcome this report for referring to the need to review the existing block exemption regulation in the field of internet sales and territorial limitations, with the purpose of being more easily applicable by retailers and consumer protection organisations. In addition, I voted in favour of the report because I consider investment in the digitisation of public administration to be important, which will allow decision-making to be closer to citizens, providing increased access to and transparency of services. I therefore support the optimisation of the growth potential of the digital economy.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. No more geoblocking that prevents watching tv shows abroad or football matches streamed on national channel sites, so no more being deprived of watching the podcast of foreign TV shows. In any case, this is the will of the European Parliament, which on Tuesday called for the rapid implementation of a digital single market around 16 proposals put forward by the Commission in May 2015. Among these, I would mention first and foremost the desire to quickly achieve extended coverage of the 4G network, which currently affects only 15% of Europeans in rural areas, under the principle of universal access. Other measures are also urgent: the removal of geoblocking and its restrictions based on IP address, the reduction of delivery fees in transnational e-commerce in order to boost online sales. It will of course take a few years before all this becomes a reality, but this promising digital revolution will allow Europe, if it makes the right choices and quickly, to generate 415 billion euros of additional wealth each year and to enter the cognitive society of the 21st century.

name: Robert Rochefort (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted for the resolution on the Digital Single Market. Indeed, downstream of this policy document, which may seem abstract, looms the adoption of 16 important and very concrete European initiatives. The challenge is to make the European Union one of the leaders of the fourth industrial revolution, with the creation of a genuine cross-border e-commerce market. If successful, this project will promote the Union's competitiveness, have a positive impact on growth and employment, and boost the single market significantly. This process will also contribute, if we are to decisively address our digital skills gap, to make our society more inclusive, by providing new opportunities for European citizens, consumers and businesses, while stimulating exchanges and sharing of innovation. To achieve this, a key word: trust, both consumers and businesses. This also raises the question of an adequate regulatory environment, particularly for platforms and intermediaries, outlined in the text. Finally, it underlines the potential offered by the sharing economy, without pouring into angelism: we recall the challenges it poses to the legislator.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. Only 1.7% of European companies make full use of advanced digital technologies and only 14% of SMEs use the Internet as a sales channel. Innovation in the digital sector is constantly changing the way citizens communicate, share, consume and even behave and therefore gives rise to new opportunities for both businesses and users. The intensified use of digital technologies can improve citizens' access to information and culture, increase employment opportunities and provide them with a wider choice of products. It can also be beneficial for modernising and improving governance and administration in the EU and its Member States.  Some of the points covered in this report relate to: online sales law; the stricter application of related secondary law; competition law relating to e-commerce; eGovernment; creating adequate conditions and a level playing field for digital networks and advanced innovative services.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report by representing a clear, progressive and ambitious roadmap for a true Digital Single Market, through the removal of barriers to creating new online opportunities for citizens and businesses, especially SMEs.   The digital revolution is changing Europe radically and has great potential for the creation of millions of new skilled jobs and new opportunities for consumers. I therefore welcome the development of this motion for a Resolution to promote legislative and non-legislative measures for the benefit of consumers and to preserve the competitiveness of our social market economy.  As a socialist, I am particularly pleased with the request we sent to the Commission to seriously consider working conditions in the sharing economy and the parcel sector, as we cannot accept low levels of protection for workers. In addition, we call on the Commission to assess what protection consumers require in this area and to ensure that regulation is adapted to the digital environment.   The report also contains a powerful text on data protection, culture and media issues, digital skills, infrastructure and investment.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. This non-legislative resolution adopted yesterday is Parliament's response to the roadmap presented in May 2015 by the Commission. The text focuses on two key objectives: first, improving access to the digital single market for consumers and businesses across Europe; second, to create an enabling environment and a level playing field for innovative services and advanced digital networks. It also has more cross-cutting objectives, such as when it asks the Commission to launch a study on the side effects of digitisation (i.e. on the development of children's cognitive abilities).  But it dismisses the most controversial issues, such as the impossibility of reconciling the principle of territoriality of copyrights and the end of geographical blockage. Finally, I supported an amendment which stated that the Commission and all Member States must rigorously defend the principle of net neutrality and which calls on the Commission in this regard to preserve the openness of the internet as a global platform for communication, production, participation, creation, cultural diversity and innovation, in the interests of citizens. , consumers and the success of European businesses as a whole.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I fully support the promotion of the development of the European digital market. Digital services and their impact on global competitiveness can only be compared at the beginning of the industrial age. Countries that were unable to respond to or encourage the development of industrial production in the 18th and 19th centuries were late in the industrial age and therefore had to struggle to catch more insight. And no natural physical sizes, such as the size of the territory, rich culture or long history, could compensate for the fact that the state was unable to start industrialization in time.  Exactly the same applies to the digital market. If we do not manage to create conditions for the development of digital businesses, the conditions that allow it is for European companies to become leaders in the global digital market, we will lose the digital race. And no sizes, such as the territory of the EU, cultural heritage or current prosperity, will help us. I therefore welcome this own-initiative document by Parliament, which highlights the main challenges of creating a digital market. In this, we not only call for administrative restrictions on business to be reduced, but we note another important element: the quality of governance. It is through digital technologies that we can and must ensure the functioning of the public administration system, which will enable Europe's competitiveness to be improved, and give citizens the basis to be proud of their home countries– members of the European Union – and the European Union as a whole.

name: Virginie Rozière (S&D)
text: In writing. The Digital Single Market is one of the main priorities of the Juncker Commission. On May 6, it unveiled its action plan to build this market. The report by Kaja Kallas and Evelyn Gebhardt urges the Commission to act in all areas of its strategy and goes even further. It calls for a complete harmonisation of the legal framework for online sales in order to better protect consumers and improve consumer confidence. It also places itself in a perspective of innovation and support for start-ups, which are essential to European dynamism.  However, the report places too little emphasis on culture and creators, which is as much a source of wealth for Europe as start-ups. It contains ambiguous provisions on geographical blocking and platform responsibility, at a time when important discussions on portability, copyright and audiovisual services are about to begin, and Europe must precisely affirm the role of digital technology in the dynamism of cultural creation.  For these reasons, and despite these reservations, I voted for this report.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. The technological revolution and digitisation that has been seen in recent times have led the European Commission to put the Digital Single Market on its list of priorities. Digital innovation and its consequent expansion to the most diverse areas of daily life are reflected in the urgent need to regulate this market in a fair and solid way, allowing not only to optimize current and future challenges, but also to enhance the enjoyment of the opportunities it offers. Furthermore, the protection of European citizens' privacy in digital matters is a fundamental issue and cannot be left out, and it is therefore necessary and urgent to regulate this market in order for the processing of digital data to ensure the security and confidence of citizens in a Digital Single Market. This resolution therefore deserved my vote in favour.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the creation of a digital single market that will enable Europe to strengthen its industry's competitiveness against the global digital giants. The EU must get on the digital train as soon as possible, catch up with the United States and build a legal and economic environment conducive to the creation of future European champions in the digital sector. The creation of a digital single market is accompanied by prospects for economic growth, many jobs and greater benefits for consumers.  I supported this text, which goes hand in hand with the development of a digital economy with copyright protection, intellectual property and better tools to combat counterfeiting on the internet. The Union must fully embark on the digital path by providing huge opportunities for growth, a stable legal framework and preserving our cultural industries.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because the European institutions must actively promote the digital revolution in all sectors, from infrastructure, to legislative harmonisation, to the digitalisation of manufacturing industry and skills. There are many issues to be discussed, but excellent work has been done to work together between the two committees and between the various political groups which have given the report a holistic approach. Now, through legislative acts, it will also be Parliament's task to better define the criteria for achieving a single European digital market.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The report is part of an attempt to respond to the new challenges posed by new technologies and the context of new competition that is coming. The digital economy is a lever for growth, so we doubt that everything can be solved through the rules of the 'single market'. Some parts of the text represent progress (taking into account the risks of digitization, establishing a common consolidated corporate tax base, etc.); However, on some other aspects, the report does not go far enough, especially in terms of data protection, free software use and net neutrality. For all these reasons, I abstained in the vote.

name: Sven Schulze (PPE)
text: Writing. As the EPP rapporteur for the opinion of the Labour and Social Committee, I have looked at the social aspects of increasing digitisation and its impact on the labour market. Three things were particularly important to me: firstly, we need to invest massively in people's digital empowerment. Best with Europe-wide standardised and certified training courses, training and job profiles. At the same time, this increases much-needed labour mobility. Secondly, we must not train past the needs of the labour market. For this reason, the most sought-after training courses in the fields of mathematics and natural sciences as well as in the technical professions must be promoted. In the case of women, we must particularly arouse interest in these supposed male occupations. Thirdly, with the European Social Fund and the Youth Employment Initiative, we have financial opportunities to actively shape digitisation in the world of work.  Let us use this opportunity to make the socially disadvantaged fit in the digital, and entrepreneurs could use the money to specifically promote their less qualified employees.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report on the 'Towards a Digital Single Market' initiative because from experience we already know that the competitiveness proposed by the European Union is totally incompatible with employment and labour rights. This proposal is made to promote consumerism at the outs and out of the world by making available to consumers the products of large companies that will be the ones that have the capacity to do business. It is totally irresponsible for the Commission and the Council to continue to delve into proposals of this kind which destroy more employment than they generate and which will also exacerbate climate change and energy waste.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 The resolution adopted today represents the European Parliament's position on the new strategy for the digital single market in Europe. I agree with the text and, in particular, with the calls to put an end to unjustified geoblocking practices, to remove barriers for small and medium-sized enterprises, to promote the development of young people's digital skills in schools, to encourage electronic public administration and to adopt innovation-friendly strategic tools for online platforms. I also hope that we will seize the opportunities offered by the sharing economy and the digitalisation of the European economy, in order to improve consumer access to goods and services and to offer new opportunities for growth for businesses.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am sympathetic to the interest of creating a single digital market. Both because of the opportunity to create new businesses, but essentially because of the opportunity to create new jobs, it seems to me that breaking down barriers between the countries of the European Union and setting common rules can greatly help digital trade in the world's largest economic community.  The European Commission's previous strategy is based on three pillars: (1) increasing consumer and business access to digital goods and services, (2) developing the conditions of networks and services so that they can thrive and (3) harnessing the growth of the digital economy. However, as pointed out in the initiative report on the vote, there are still several opportunities for improvement. Among them, I would like to set out the need to create a process so that international purchases, consequent to online purchases, can be affordable and fair.  Another point that i point out about this own-initiative report is the need to protect workers from the entities that send orders purchased online. The own-initiative report that has been voted on is important and will therefore be supported by me.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this resolution – this calls for more Commission interference within our market which I am against.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ In order to protect the rights of workers in the new online economy I voted in favour of this report calling for everyone to have a right of access to the internet and to be able to use online services without discrimination. The Commission's proposal rests on three pillars: Firstly, 'better access for consumers and businesses across Europe to digital services'; Secondly, the creation of 'the right conditions and a level playing field for advanced digital networks and innovative services'; and thirdly, the maximisation of the growth potential of the digital economy. I was especially glad to see that the Socialists and Democrats Group were able to have those involved in the parcel delivery and logistics sector included in the text as well as recognition of the rights of those working in the new and growing sharing economy. We need better provisions for data protection and proper investment in the infrastructure of the digital economy.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: in writing \ u2012 The Digital Single Market will bring a number of positives: it abolishes roaming or often pointless geo-blocking. It lays down clearer rules on cross-border online shopping, but does not place sufficient emphasis on consumer protection. I see negatively that the single market does not regulate pornography on the Internet sufficiently. However, despite this negative, I voted in favour of adopting the European Parliament's motion for a resolution on the initiative entitled 'Towards an act on the Digital Single Market'.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ The Internet and digital technology greatly make everyday life much easier for millions of Europeans. They provide easier access to information, trade development, boosting competitiveness.  The creation of a Digital Single Market would, inter alia, improve access and portability of digital goods and services, reduce discriminatory activities such as denial of access on grounds of location and nationality, facilitate easy cross-border parcel delivery when e-shopping, increase data protection by reviewing the e-privacy directive, which currently applies only to telecommunication services, and guarantee a high level of consumer protection. I welcome this initiative of the European Commission, considering that ideas are favourable for the population across Europe, as well as for citizens of the Republic of Croatia, as this would create a common market based on fair competition, stimulating growth and employment, reducing VAT and a high level of mutual cooperation using new technologies and innovations that would enable consumers to choose products as cheaply as possible. It is also important to highlight the potential of new information and communication technologies for the economy and society as a whole, not least by connecting with sectors of utmost importance such as energy, education, health, financial services, etc. Taking all the components into account, on the other hand we must not forget about consumer rights, personal data protection, copyright protection and respect for fair competition.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ I supported the resolution because I consider the Digital Single Market to be a unique chance for all EU Member States to build the conditions for an online world that is already part of the everyday lives of people and entrepreneurs. Its justification is also evidenced by the study carried out for Parliament, which shows that a fully implemented Digital Single Market could bring an annual increase in European GDP of BETWEEN EUR 415 billion and EUR 500 billion. Unfortunately, as the report notes, only 1.7% of EU businesses make full use of modern digital technologies and only 14% of SMEs use the Internet as a sales channel. I believe that the introduction of a digital single market based on a set of common rules will have a positive impact on growth and job creation and relam the EU single market. In order to overcome the legal fragmentation of the single market, reduce administrative burdens and promote growth and innovation, I expect the Commission to reconsider existing legislation as to whether it is appropriate for a given period. I am convinced that the strategy presented can bring more supply to consumers, especially in remote areas, and provide new opportunities for small and medium-sized enterprises.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report on the direction towards the Digital Single Market Act is, I think, a good basis for creating the necessary legislative framework for both digital technology providers and users in the European Union. I must applaud the fact that this is a complex compromise of many professional and political interests, which contains the opinion of the six parliamentary committees responsible. As Vice-Chair of the Committee on Education and Culture, I can state the acceptability of the resulting report in areas that I consider essential from our point of view, which is to ensure the protection of copyright, the safety and protection of children from online abuse and, last but not least, the making digital content available for education and culture purposes. I believe that copyright protection is not contrary to the availability of content to users or to the competitiveness of the European digital market. It is in the interests of EU citizens who have the right to availability, they also have the right to quality content, and this cannot be ensured without the copyright protection of creators. Ensuring digital services from child abuse, which are trusting and easily vulnerable, will also be an important legislative task. The report therefore calls on both the Commission and the Member States to take specific measures to combat the sexual exploitation of children online in order to support all initiatives that are already working for greater child safety.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. The rapidly growing use of the Internet and mobile communications has changed the way citizens, businesses and their employees communicate, access information and knowledge, invent, spend, share, collaborate, and work. This has expanded the market, changed the economy and made it easier for SMEs to access a circle of 500 million potential consumers in the EU and global markets. It also enabled individuals to develop new entrepreneurial ideas and business models.  I agree that all EU policies and legislation in the digital single market should create new opportunities for users and businesses. They should lead to the creation of new innovative cross-border services at competitive prices, remove barriers between Member States and facilitate access for European entrepreneurs to the cross-border market.  The report sets out the reasons for the urgency of the Digital Single Market and contains good proposals and measures. As such, I can mention improving consumer legal protection in the context of digital content, strengthening portability and interoperability in the circulation of legally acquired or available content, eliminating unjustified geo-blocking, data protection and fundamental rights in cyberspace, setting up innovation funds, etc.  As I am aware of the importance of the Digital Single Market and the advantages it brings, I voted in plenary to adopt the report.

name: Renato Soru (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution in which the European Parliament presents its position on the Commission's strategy for the creation of the digital single market, presented in May 2015. The development of the digital single market is worth EUR 415 billion per year to the European economy and can create 3.8 million new jobs. That is why Europe needs to act to create a genuine digital single market, harmonising the conditions of competitiveness for companies, developing innovative skills and removing existing barriers, including in the areas of financial services and taxation. We can no longer afford to play a marginal role in innovation, the development of digital networks and services. Today, the challenge is to manage Big Data, the Internet of Things, the sharing economy, fundamental games in which Europe must resume a leading role, following its vocation for research and innovation.  We must now start from this document in order to courageously create the conditions for harmonious and fast digital development, together creating the world's largest market for digital products and services and opening up even sectors that are currently closed to competition.

name: Joachim Starbatty (ECR)
text: Writing. The report sends a signal that the digitisation of the economy has now become the focus of the EU agenda. All parties agree that the progress made in the information and communications sector can help the private and public sectors to save time and costs. Investing in the industry can create growth and new jobs. In Brussels, ALFA is committed to ensuring that both sectors benefit from the digital revolution, that regulatory barriers are removed and that investment is made in the necessary infrastructure. The report is the first step in the right direction, which is why I voted in favour.  However, the EU must be clear about one thing: if we want to create a successful European digital single market, we must take market-based measures and not create new European authorities. We need more freedom, more market and less bureaucracy. The slow liberalisation process of the last 20 years is one of the main reasons why we are lagging behind in the ICT sector today. The state must sell its shares in telecoms companies because it cannot regulate competition as the main shareholder of a telecoms company.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: in writing \ u2012 The Digital Single Market is an important platform for business development in the common European market. The Digital Single Market will ensure the free movement of goods, services and investment, including through electronic services. The priority is to build fair competition in the common market while protecting consumers and their personal data. The Digital Single Market promotes cross-border e-commerce, eliminates discrimination through geo-blocking and reduces the administrative burden on entrepreneurs to fulfil their registration obligations towards state authorities.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Rapidly evolving use of the Internet and mobile communications has changed the way citizens, companies and their employees communicate, access information and knowledge. This has expanded and changed the economy, making it easier for SMEs to travel towards 500 million potential customers in the EU as well as global markets, while giving individuals the opportunity to develop new, entrepreneurial ideas and business models. In 2013, the size of the sharing economy market worldwide was around 3.5 billion, and the Commission today forecasts growth potential above 100 billion. In my view, achieving the Digital Single Market, based on a common set of rules, could boost the EU's competitiveness, have positive effects on growth and jobs, relaunch the single market and create a more inclusive society, providing new opportunities for citizens and businesses, in particular by sharing and sharing innovation. The implementation of the horizontal approach taken needs to be strengthened, including the timely adoption of 16 initiatives, as digital drivers affect every citizen and all dimensions of society and the economy. I therefore welcome the report and the Communication on the 'Digital Single Market Strategy for Europe'.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Labour is protecting the rights of workers in the new online economy, and calling for everyone to have the right to access the internet and use online services, be they young, old, disabled or isolated.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The Digital Single Market Strategy is based on three units, namely better access to internet goods and services to all citizens and businesses in the European Union, creating legislative conditions for the digital network and services, and optimising the conditions for growth in the European digital economy that the Commission is working on intensively. Better access for all legal and natural persons implies better border cooperation, lower VAT rates, high quality delivery regardless of border barriers and prevention of unjustified cross-border barriers. Creating legislative conditions for the digital network entails reviewing the legal framework and aligning it with market trends and working on trust in digital trade. In 2016, the Commission intends to create conditions for smooth data flows, launch an integrated standardisation plan and similar activities. I support this report, as it creates the conditions for a more competitive market and greater choices for consumers.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on the Single Digital Single Market Act.  In this day and age, digital technology has become part of life. She is already present almost everywhere and we meet with her every day. The internet is becoming more important day by day, displacing other media.  However, there are still many obstacles in the market, so the market needs to adapt to hasty changes in order to introduce a digital single market. Both policies and all EU legislation should adapt to this, thus enabling new opportunities for users and businesses, especially SMEs and start-ups, to help them reach capital, thus contributing to growth and employment in the European Union, which has been picking up since the last financial and economic crisis.

name: Pavel Svoboda (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the move towards the Digital Single Market Act. This non-legislative report responds to one of the fundamental agenda points of the current European Commission, which is the establishment of a digital single market in the European Union and which the report supports. The Digital Single Market covers a number of topics that fall within the competence of many committees, including the Committee on Legal Affairs. I therefore welcome the fact that the opinion of the Committee on Legal Affairs has been taken into account and the report also includes the issue of new rules on cross-border trade, where there is a need to improve the legal protection of consumers in the online environment, the issue of geo-blocking, when the problem of unfair geo-blocking needs to be resolved, or the topic of modernising copyright legislation, where there is agreement on the need to modernise these regulations in the light of the state of the current digital environment.

name: Kay Swinburne (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I support the calls within this report for ambitious, targeted actions to complete Europe’s Digital Single Market, including an end to unjustified geo-blocking practices, promotion of e-skills for young people, and an e-government action plan in public administrations. Furthermore we welcome the calls for the Commission and Member States to support the further development of the sharing economy and an innovation-friendly policy towards online platforms. Finally, I believe the approach to copyright and portability included in the final report is well balanced.  However, I strongly oppose the endorsement of the Common Consolidated Corporate Tax Base (CCCTB), which is not relevant to the DSM and has no place in this report, and the Conservative Delegation and the ECR Group will continue to oppose its introduction. In addition we do not support the harmonisation of spectrum allocation, whilst we do recognise the benefits of increased coordination, nor do we support extending the scope of the Audiovisual Media Services (AVMS) Directive to include online platforms as called for in the report. These votes were all roll called. Despite these reservations, I voted in favour of the report given our strong support for the digital single market and the significant opportunities it brings.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 We abstained in voting on this report because it advocates the creation of a European digital single market, in which new technologies will be used to further develop competitiveness and meet market needs. The aim of the above is none other than to serve the interests of large capital and multinationals. Such a policy finds us opposed, since we believe that technological development and the digital market should be used to improve people's quality of life. Particularly negative for Cyprus is the reference in the report to the need for a common consolidated corporate tax base at EU level as well as a single VAT system.  It should be noted, however, that there are also individual positive reports in the report on the need to protect SMEs and labour rights, to safeguard personal data, to strengthen safety and health measures for workers, and to maintain the Internet as an open, neutral, secure and inclusive platform in the interests of citizens.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Digital Single Market is a modernised form of the oppressive and free EU, which is trying to spread to even free areas such as the Internet. The digitisation of the public sector can solve many problems and save resources but can, on the other hand, degrade the importance of personal data but also geometrically increase the cost of protecting them. This plan legitimises Community bullying against undertakings wishing to have a limited turnover and who choose, as they have the right, to trade with any country they wish.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, as e-commerce, which generates very significant traffic in the EU, also offers many new opportunities for SMEs. I fully agree with the reporters when they ask the Commission to identify and remove barriers to e-commerce, such as the lack of common standards, inadequate consumer protection information and insufficient access to cross-border payment methods, in order to truly make the e-commerce market cross-border. In order to exploit the innovation and growth potential of the digital economy, it is essential that citizens and businesses trust the digital environment, since the business model of digital enterprises is based on the trust of users. We can ensure this through data protection and security standards and a high level of consumer protection and consumer awareness. In order to create a modern Digital Single Market, a number of other recommendations raised by the report need to be considered. These are the review of unjustified geo-blocking, the promotion of private investment in high-speed communication networks through a stable EU regulatory framework, and the promotion of digital skills acquisition and the increase in the level of general media literacy and internet literacy across Europe.  Finally, I was pleased to see that the report addressed the challenges posed by the community economy and called on the Commission to identify the obstacles to it.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The creation of the Digital Single Market is crucial for increasing competitiveness within the European Union. The Community must create opportunities for itself to compete effectively for a leading role in the technological race against the United States and Asian countries. The introduction of changes to remove barriers to the digital market will give an impetus to boost economic growth and job creation in Europe, which is estimated to bring an additional €415 billion to the EU's GDP. Above all, however, the Digital Single Market will serve Europeans, both consumers and businesses, through measures such as abolishing geo-blocking, guaranteeing clearer copyright rules, facilitating cross-border parcels, developing new business models or, finally, introducing VAT-related facilitations for cross-border sales.  In view of the great importance that the Digital Single Market has for the economic development of the European Union, I have decided to support the European Parliament's report.

name: Dario Tamburrano (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The own-initiative report is the first in a comprehensive set of legislative initiatives that will follow. Although many of our amendments during the ITRE-IMCO procedure have been diluted by compromises, we voted in favour of the report because it includes some issues that are important to the Movement, such as the broadening of citizens' participation in digital life, the reduction of geoblocking and the improvement of the rules for online business. Another point that has passed and is important to us is the paragraph calling on the Commission to promote a legal and political framework to combat cybercrime and illegal content on the Internet, such as hate speech. Among the measures proposed in this regard are: the creation of an appropriate legal basis to enable Europol to carry out its activities to combat illegal content on the Internet; special measures to combat the online sexual exploitation of children as well as all the measures necessary to make the Internet a safe environment for children as well; and collaboration with stakeholders in promoting education and awareness campaigns.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Commission has made it a priority in recent years of Community regulation of the Digital Single Market. In this respect, 16 initiatives have been launched on various sectoral aspects of the European digital market.  They are grouped into three main directions, including better access for European consumers and companies to the Digital Single Market, creating the right conditions for advanced digital networks and new services, and maximising the growth potential of the digital economy. The main problems facing Member States in these directions are consumer protection, protection of personal data and sensitive information, infrastructure and investment, digital media, digital education, copyright, e-commerce, geolocation, illegal content, interoperability and standardisation, eGovernment.  We must be aware that the digitisation process is causing structural changes in society and the employment model.
