In this context, the EU and the Member States must adapt to the requirements of the current situation.  Our priority must, however, be, first of all, ensuring that this process is carried out in favour of our citizens, creates all their potential benefits and does not adversely affect the workforce. Only under these conditions will the Digital Single Market fulfil its purpose.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. We want to improve European consumers' access to online goods and services, eliminate differences in treatment between offline and online purchases, or discrimination related to geographical blocking.  So many obstacles for SMEs and consumers remain: they explain the distressing figures of e-commerce in Europe. While only 4% of European online transactions are cross-border (compared to 42% of domestic transactions and 54% from the US), 45% of European households do not have fast internet!  There is an urgent need for an effective digital market for the economy, employment and social integration.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Digital Single Market Act report. I consider digitalisation of our economy as a viable tool which can boost growth and cut costs of our citizens and businesses without creating a public debt. Therefore I welcome the strategic proposal on the DSM adopted by the Commission in May 2015 and a report adopted jointly by the ITRE and IMCO Committees in December 2015.  As a member of the ITRE committee, which together with IMCO was the leading committee for this file, I really appreciate work done by Parliament and all colleagues involved in this task, which was definitely not easy. I consider this report as an important contribution to the Digital Single Market strategy. I also appreciate the focus on e-government, a level playing field and SMEs and start-ups in particular. The right digital environment and non-regulatory framework can help our businesses grow and be more competitive. And I really hope the EU will be able to deliver.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the report on the Act on Strategies for a More Digital Single Market, as promoting greater use of digital technologies, creating a level playing field and legislative frameworks of the network can improve citizens' access to information, increase their employment opportunities and make them more product choices. More broadly, it promotes the exploitation of the potentials and opportunities that digitalisation brings and, consequently, the competitiveness of the European economy.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The report is part of an attempt to respond to the new challenges posed by new technologies and the context of new competition that is coming. The digital economy is a lever for growth, so we doubt that everything can be solved through the rules of the 'single market'. Some parts of the text represent progress (taking into account the risks of digitization, establishing a common consolidated corporate tax base, etc.); However, on some other aspects, the report does not go far enough, especially in terms of data protection, free software use and net neutrality. For all these reasons, I abstained in the vote.

name: Ulrike Trebesius (ECR)
text: Writing. The report sends a signal that the digitisation of the economy has now become the focus of the EU agenda. All parties agree that the progress made in the information and communications sector can help the private and public sectors to save time and costs. Investing in the industry can create growth and new jobs. In Brussels, ALFA is committed to ensuring that both sectors benefit from the digital revolution, that regulatory barriers are removed and that investment is made in the necessary infrastructure. The report is the first step in the right direction, which is why I voted in favour. However, the EU must be clear about one thing: if we want to create a successful European digital single market, we must take market-based measures and not create new European authorities. We need more freedom, more market and less bureaucracy. The slow liberalisation process of the last 20 years is one of the main reasons why we are lagging behind in the ICT sector today. The state must sell its shares in telecoms companies because it cannot regulate competition as the main shareholder of a telecoms company.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I strongly welcome this report and I believe that it can foster EU competitiveness, have positive effects on growth and jobs, relaunch the Single Market and make society more inclusive, offering new opportunities to citizens and businesses. I believe that the digital single market should be principle-based and technologically neutral. It is important to guarantee the trust of citizens and businesses in the digital environment through data protection and high security standards. Free cross-border e-commerce and removal of existing regulatory barriers is essential to boost the digital economy. I also insist on the crucial principle of net neutrality, it should be applied and respected in order to guarantee neutral flow of information.  Moreover this Digital single market strategy should go in parallel with the Commission’s Google antitrust case and the Commission should make sure that the principle of non-discrimination is strictly applied by Google.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. This text is a flagship document of the legislature because it supports the European Parliament in the communication of the Committee on the Digital Economy. The digital economy here is becoming a pretext to advance the federalisation of Europe in areas of sovereignty: taxation: in the name of market fluidisation, it provides for enhanced harmonisation of VAT in the field of online shipments, moving towards a single rate, to develop cross-border purchases; concentration of operators into a few large European-level operators, which would make it impossible for states to regain their sovereignty in this strategic industry; unification of copyright and intellectual property rules to prohibit zone blockages. I therefore vote AGAINST this text.

name: Mihai Ţurcanu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The rapid evolution of the internet and mobile communications has changed the way users communicate, access information and knowledge, innovate, consume, leading to the expansion and change of the economy, facilitating small business access to a possible customer base of 500 million consumers in the EU, as well as global markets, and giving people the opportunity to develop new entrepreneurial business ideas and models.  Digital infrastructure is the backbone of the Digital Single Market, so it is necessary to develop a digital transformation plan for industry in order to increase the competitiveness of the European economy in order to increase efficiency and harness untapped potential. Confidence-building in digital technologies is also essential for the development of the data-driven economy, clarifying data ownership and data portability rules, guaranteeing citizens control over their data.  I welcome the achievement of a digital single market, based on a common set of rules that could boost the EU's competitiveness, have positive effects on growth and jobs, relaunch the single market and strengthen the inclusiveness of society, providing citizens and businesses with new opportunities, in particular through the exchange of innovations.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 On 6 May 2015, the Commission adopted a communication on a communication titled 'Digital Strategy for Europe', which includes an initiative to be implemented by the end of 2016. When comparing the Digital Single Market with the Single Market, it became clear to legislators that the former offers a huge opportunity to expand EU businesses and businesses and to fully restore the EU labour market, which has been torn apart by the economic crisis and the measures taken in the wake of it. Encouraging a dynamic economy is essential for innovation to flourish and innovative companies to expand, so the European Commission, together with the Member States, should focus on this. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour as this raises good points on: consumer rights in the digital age, where consumers should have the same high level of protection online as offline; portability; the prevention of geo-blocking; data protection and cyber security; the need for tax coordination including the Common Consolidated Corporate Tax Base; goods should be taxed the same regardless of whether they are digital or physical; innovation funding including crowdfunding; a high level of consumer rights; the need for technology-neutral future-proof solutions regarding online services and service providers, without creating a one-size-fits-all approach; and maintaining the definition of the E-Commerce Directive on intermediary liability.

name: Inese Vaidere (PPE)
text: Writing. – At a time when global economic growth rates are declining and production tends to move away from Europe, existing ones need to be used and new resources needed to speed up development. I believe that the time is right for experience and knowledge in the digital economy to be used for development, especially in the new Member States, such as Latvia, which is already emerging as a leader in the digital economy.  A digital single market based on common Rules of the European Union is needed for the digital economy to develop. A number of obstacles to SMEs, start-ups and growth companies need to be removed from the opportunities provided by new technologies such as big data, cloud computing, the Internet of Things, 3D printing and others. It is important for consumers to eliminate geo-blocking or restriction of Internet content by customer location and to strengthen online consumer protection. At present, unfortunately, not only do the availability of audiovisual material differ from one country to another, but also the rights of buyers when buying online digital content, such as telephone applications, are not protected. Cross-border parcel deliveries, which are often inadequately high or not at all, should become cheaper.  It is also essential that business on the Internet, or so-called e-commerce, develops faster, to promote citizens' trust in it by taking care of the protection of personal data and by creating common rules for economic operators and consumers across Europe.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. This own-initiative report is the answer to the European Commission's Digital Single Market Strategy last May. In this way, the European Parliament intends to express its general position on important aspects such as e-commerce rules, copyright, VAT rules, the legal framework for telecommunications, audiovisual media, data protection, e-government or opportunities for growth and competitiveness in areas such as big data, standardization or research. That is why I consider it necessary to vote in favour of that report.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The digital agenda is one of the less coherent proposals of the Juncker Commission, a tailor's drawer that fits everything from copyright to working time, from digital platforms to industry automation, from audiovisual directive reform to parcel directives. In this way, their most controversial initiatives are diluted among others subject to less public scrutiny. Our proposals in this area are well known. We will support the Commission in harmonisation initiatives that improve worker protection, access to cultural production and the fair remuneration of authors. On the contrary, we will maintain our opposition to new digital monopolies, the liberalization of sectors such as parcels and the deregulation of services because of unfair competition from networked companies, whether in transport (such as Uber) or in any other area, public or private. Parliament's report contains improvements to the Commission's proposals, but its general approach remains confusing. That is why I have decided to abstain in the final vote.

name: Derek Vaughan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I and my Labour colleagues are protecting the rights of workers and businesses in the new online economy, and calling for everyone to have the right to access the internet and use online services, be they young, old, disabled or isolated. The internet is a valuable resource for the whole community that is revolutionising the way that we operate; we cannot afford to either stifle online entrepreneurship or allow it to be compromised by business interests.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. 'I voted in favour of this act as it will promote the competitiveness of the entire European Union and give a new impetus to our internal market. We need an open market: only in this way can we successfully respond to the digitisation of the economy.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The digital sector is becoming increasingly important in all areas of each of us's lives.  That is why economic issues cannot be disconnected from other issues. This report does so, considering that the future of digital policy necessarily and solely depends on deregulation and open markets. Competition allows "consumers to have more choice." It is a classic of European politics, but unfortunately we know what it is. A real plurality of choice for a minority and "low cost" for the vast majority. The European Parliament has lost an opportunity to carry out an ambitious project that takes into account all the issues, starting with ensuring equal and universal access to digital services to really reduce the digital divide.  Concerns about the protection of digital workers or copyrights have not even been raised, let alone taken into account.  A lost opportunity to truly take into account the public interest in this important sector for the future. So I voted against it.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The digital market contains a great potential for society in general and for citizens in particular. However, like any technological advance, it is the policies that determine or not the asymmetries in the appropriation of the advantages that come from the use and generalization of these technologies. The digital single market should therefore be put at the service of large multinational companies, but at the service of a development strategy focused on improving the living conditions of people and workers. It makes no sense to talk about digitising the economy if improvements in the working conditions of companies are not associated with this phenomenon, for example with a reduction in working time made possible by the use of these technologies.  Not therefore, they will be the same as always benefiting from technological advances, perpetuating this paradox of modernity in which technological advances are accompanied by an extension of working hours.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. I believe that some of the points proposed, such as the strengthening of legal certainty.B, are reasonable and necessary. Unfortunately, however, the report leaves many questions unanswered. For example, the question of financing. Infrastructure competition would also be an important point, but this too is not mentioned in the report. I therefore abstain from voting.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. I rejected the European Parliament's resolution on 'Towards a Digital Single Market Act'. It is about the positioning of the European Parliament on the issue of a digital single market. There is a great deal of shadow in the report. Among other things, it calls on the Commission, in cooperation with the Member States, to continue to develop initiatives to promote entrepreneurship and, in particular, innovative business models. In my opinion, politicians should stay out of promoting business models, because they are not the better entrepreneurs. I do not see any point in calling for the Commission, together with stakeholders, to examine the feasibility of introducing sector-specific EU quality labels for online sales. I am also strongly opposed to further harmonisation of parcel delivery services. What is completely wrong is the diagnosis that there are "cases of market failure" in which public funds are to be used "to promote public Wi-Fi networks in larger and smaller municipalities". I also oppose the creation of an 'EU Internet Content Reporting Centre', whichever content is to be reported there. As a result, I prefer a fragmented digital market to one that the EU harmonises as it see it. Much good cannot come of it.

name: Julie Ward (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report that calls for protecting the rights of workers in the new online economy, and for everyone to have the right to access the internet and use online services, be they young, old, disabled or isolated. The internet is a common good for humanity and ensuring its good governance will help bring its benefits to all people in the world. I believe Europe has much to contribute to ensure a shared governance of the internet is based on clear, fair, inclusive and transparent rules. My views on this are informed by my active involvement with the European Internet Foundation and by my attendance at the Internet Governance Forum in Brazil, in November 2015.

name: Iuliu Winkler (PPE)
text: in writing. – I voted for the own-initiative report on the preparation of a legislative act on the Digital Single Market, which is Parliament's response to the Digital Strategy for Europe adopted by the European Commission on 6 May 2015.  The harmonisation of the European digital market with the single market represents a huge opportunity for EU entrepreneurs and businesses to prosper, but also for the EU labour market to fully recover from the economic crisis and subsequent action.  The report responds to the 16 proposals put forward by the EC and develops the aspects of the actions to be taken to complete the Digital Single Market and the consequences that the achievement of the Digital Single Market will have on society and the economy as a whole.

name: Anna Záborská (PPE)
text: in writing – The resolution 'Towards a Digital Single Market Act' supports the EU Commission's strategy and draws attention, at the same time, with concern to the divergent national approaches in the regulation of the Internet and online commerce. The resolution also points out that citizens' and businesses' trust in the digital environment is essential for the growth of the digital economy, while improving data protection, security and consumer protection standards. The resolution asks the Commission to commission a study on the effects of digitisation on family life, on the development of children's cognitive abilities, on greater work intensity and on the psychological well-being of workers. Furthermore, the text stresses that, in the event of a breach of human dignity, incitement to hatred or racism over the Internet, the ban on all audiovisual media services in the EU should be implemented equally and effectively by the Member States, in full respect of fundamental rights in the Charter of the European Union. It also asks the Commission to propose concrete measures to combat child sexual abuse via the Internet and to cooperate effectively among all stakeholders, including through the promotion of education and awareness-raising campaigns.

name: Θεόδωρος Ζαγοράκης (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this act as a member of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection of which it was also a key competence. The digital single market is a necessity for both the market and the economy and for the citizens themselves. This report, after extensive dialogue at all levels, has resulted in a text that sets out the necessary conditions for the creation of a flexible and more efficient digital framework, with multiple benefits for consumers, businesses, the economy, creativity and communications.

name: Marco Zanni (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The digital single market is one of the most promising and challenging sectors in terms of progress and creates potential efficiency gains of €260 million per year. It opens up new opportunities to boost the economy through e-commerce, while facilitating administrative and financial compliance for businesses and empowering customers through e-government. Market and government services developed in the digital single market are evolving from electronic to mobile platforms, are increasingly present and offer access to information and content at any time, place and from any device. However, this development needs a regulatory framework, and this report has precisely the task of paving the way for a comprehensive set of legislative initiatives according to the Commission's work programme. The major issues covered, such as the expansion of the participation of European citizens in digital life, investment in infrastructure, the reduction of geoblocking, the improvement of the rules for online business activities, the strengthening of confidence in the citizen, etc., certainly deserve broad support.

name: Flavio Zanonato (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the own-initiative report 'Towards a digital single market'. I believe that the digital revolution is both a challenge and a decisive opportunity for Europe and I believe that, with the report adopted today, the European Parliament is clearly clarifying what the priorities are for European citizens and businesses. This transition, in my view, has the potential to create millions of new jobs and can certainly provide new opportunities for European consumers. We cannot, however, deny the negative impacts that such changes can cause, such as, in particular, the increasing insecurity of work caused, among other things, by an ungoverned sharing economy. I particularly agree with the text adopted today, particularly where it calls on the Commission to examine carefully working conditions for these new and expanding sectors, so as to ensure adequate levels of protection for workers.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I have decided to support this report because we are increasingly using new communication technologies in our daily lives and the creation of a digital single market will make it easier for us consumers to use technology. I agree with the need to ensure the security and protection of citizens' data in a virtual environment. I consider it important to combat cybercrime and illegal content, including hate speech. I consider the digitisation of public administration in Europe to be a necessary step towards improving transparency, for example by allowing citizens access to official documents. At present, the economy is of a global nature, which is why I consider it necessary for data to be allowed to move within the digital single market not only within the EU, but also outside it.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: in writing \ u2012 I supported this report. In my opinion, the area of the Digital Single Market is very important at the moment and adapting legislation to rapidly developing digital technologies is extremely important. This report is a response to the European Commission's published digital single market strategy and calls precisely for targeted actions to help complete it. I strongly agree with the idea that e-commerce is now increasingly used by consumers and equal protection needs to be ensured, whether when shopping online or offline, and whether consumers choose to buy tangible products, services or digital content. I also agree with the view that geo-blocking needs to be stopped, which not only prevents consumers from accessing paid digital content, but also often leads to unfair price discrimination on the basis of geographical location. More up-to-date regulation of the protection of intellectual property rights and calls for sufficient digital skills for all population groups are also important. And although I lack more references to the accessibility of digital technologies for disabled people in the report, I have nevertheless given my voice to the report.

name: Damiano Zoffoli (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The digital single market really has a chance to change Europe. It has the opportunity to create thousands of jobs but, above all, to give new opportunities to all European consumers and citizens. With this report we are also asking the Commission to ensure that the conditions of workers in the delivery sector are protected. No less importantly, we are tackling the problem of geoblocking, a virtual frontier that must be eliminated.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Report "Towards the Digital Single Market Act" because I believe that aligning the European Union with the digital revolution implies the creation of a single market. The priorities and lines of action set by the Commission and approved by Parliament for the creation of a Digital Single Market are a good contribution on a path that the Union must continue to follow.  This means, among others, giving more European access to digital services and resources by opening up new opportunities for investment, growth and jobs, and new opportunities for people requalification and technological research and innovation. In a time of dismay, it is important to have a mobilising and aggregating impulse for the efforts of the 28 Member States to create a Digital Single Market, based on a European digital identity capable of projecting the strength of europe's 500 million consumers into the design, regulation and competitive dynamics of digital markets. These common references to a Digital Union should include the values of inclusion, universality and neutrality in access; cultural diversity; prevention of monopolistic movements and encouragement of SME networks; protection of privacy and appreciation of the rights of choice of individuals and communities.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 Despite the potential of digital technologies, the single market has been an instrument that fuels inequalities between Member States, degrading national production in Portugal, particularly hindering the lives of micro, small and medium-sized enterprises, which fail to cope with European competition and the brutal inequality of circumstances vis-à-vis multinational hegemons. We advocate an end to geo-blocking. However, this should safeguard the right of authors and artists to a decent remuneration for their productions. We argue that data storage and management, due to the growing importance that digital technologies assume not only in the economy but also in society, must be under the purview of the State.  The liberalisation of markets is of deep concern, even if it presents itself with a social façade. The advertising of promises of jobs, growth, cohesion, is always but always belied by reality. We voted against it.

name: Marco Zullo (EFDD)
text: in writing. The report responds to the Communication from the European Commission within the broader initiative, which sees the creation of a digital single market, which aims to give concrete form to the concept of European citizenship also at digital level. I think it is particularly important that Parliament has decided to plan the future development of the digital single market on the basis of three fundamental concepts such as equality, participation and trust, around which the very nature of 'digital citizenship' must be built if it is to be stable and to work. European citizens will only learn to exploit the potential of the digital single market if they feel that they are adequately protected and if we can ensure that the same rights apply to consumers, and in particular buyers, as they can in the daily life of trade. For these reasons, I voted in favour.  The Commission document paves the way for a comprehensive set of subsequent legislative initiatives. I hope that the proposals that the Commission will present in the coming months will take account of these principles which Parliament has so clearly wished to highlight in its position and on which I have spent my time.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. The European Union urgently needs a digital single market, as our digital economy is not developing fast enough and is not competitive with the American people who are ahead of Europe. We have been talking about a European digital union for years, but the digital world is being completely transformed in five years (as it usually takes to enforce European legislation).  I am pleased that, by the end of the current year, the European Commission aims to complete all 16 Digital Single Market initiatives. We must remove the barriers that prevent companies from exploiting the entire European market and thus offer consumers more choice. This is how the European economy and consumers win. If we want the Digital Single Market to have a chance of success, we need to start trusting citizens and businesses in the digital economy. Investments in the infrastructure of the next generation of ICT and the expansion of existing ones such as 4G and the fibre network are also key. Making high-speed Internet connections at competitive prices is key to the development of the digital market. The removal of obstacles to the cross-border development of e-commerce is essential. First and foremost, this is about the cost of cross-border parcel delivery and the different rules of taxation. I supported the report because the European economy needs a serious digital single market as soon as possible, building the success and competitiveness of the European economy on a global scale. Let the next Google, Facebook, Apple, Amazon or Steve Jobs, Bezos or Gates come out of the European Union.

name: Presidente. –
text: That concludes the explanations of vote.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the Council and Commission statements on the conclusions of the European Council (17-18 December 2015) (2015/2989(RSP)).

name: Donald Tusk
text: President of the European Council. – Mr President, the December European Council debated in fact all the major crises that confronted Europe in 2015. Whether it was the refugee and migration crisis, EMU reform or Brexit, in all of these discussions we made some progress but for sure not enough. Let us have no doubt that 2016 will also be overshadowed by these challenges. Our community is experiencing a stress test. And what is most challenging is that we are being tested on all possible fronts at the same time. Today, let me say it loud and clear. I will not rest until we work out solutions to all these challenges. Our strength comes from our unity. Therefore, keeping European unity will continue to be my main goal in 2016. Let me start with the migration and refugee crisis, an existential challenge for the EU. As you remember, I have emphasised for months, in fact from the very beginning of the migration crisis, that there is no good alternative to border protection. This is a conditio sine qua non of any effective migration policy. Unless we can guard Europe’s external border properly, we will fail as a political community. After the December European Council, we can be a bit more optimistic. The leaders’ discussion concentrated on ways and means of strengthening external border control. All leaders acknowledge that protecting Schengen requires difficult decisions. In this context, we agreed to rapidly examine the Commission’s proposal of strengthening the EU’s external borders, including the idea of the European Border Guard. This is a priority for the Dutch Presidency and we should have political agreement in the Council by June. The agreement by Greece to accept a Rapid Border Intervention Team from Frontex already in December is another indication that we have started to move in the right direction when it comes to guarding the external border. Despite political progress, I have to admit that there is a clear delivery deficit on many fronts, from hotspots and security screening in frontline countries to relocation and returns. The action plan with Turkey, although promising, is still to bear fruit. I share the sentiment expressed by Prime Minister Rutte that we have no more than two months to get things under control. The statistics over the Christmas period are not encouraging, with over 2 000 arrivals in the EU per day, according to Frontex. The March European Council will be the last moment to see if our strategy works. If it does not, we will face grave consequences such as the collapse of Schengen. For sure, this kind of alternative to our strategy is not pleasant, and so I appeal that Member States implement the strategy in full. Let me turn to the UK. In December, leaders had a substantive and constructive discussion on the UK question. Prime Minister Cameron set out his position in detail, in particular regarding benefits and free movement. He explained his request for a model based on four years and reiterated the openness to alternative solutions, but only if they achieve the same objective. Leaders voiced their concerns on specific issues, but also demonstrated willingness to look for compromises. Building on this positive debate, we agreed to work together to find solutions in all four baskets raised by Prime Minister Cameron: relations with the euro area, sovereignty, competitiveness, and on benefits and free movement. Hard work on all these baskets is progressing and, as we speak, my people are working with the Commission to bring us closer to the solution. In the run-up to the February European Council, I will table a concrete proposal for a deal with the UK to all EU leaders. Let me stress again that from the very beginning of these negotiations I have been very clear. There will be no compromise on fundamental values like non-discrimination and free movement. At the same time, I will do everything in my power to find a satisfactory solution, also for the British side. As of today, the result of the referendum is more unpredictable than ever before. Time is of the essence here, and this is why I will work hard to strike a deal already in February. It will not be easy but it is still possible. The European Council also discussed counter-terrorism in the light of the Paris tragedy. These outrageous acts have only strengthened Europe’s resolve to fight terrorism. Leaders agreed to operationalise our policies, including systematically sharing information on foreign fighters through Schengen and Europol, as well as between Member States’ authorities. Security services should conduct a joint threat analysis if it can prevent future attacks. Europol has already reported a significant rise in information exchange on foreign fighters through its new Counter-Terrorism Centre with almost every Member State contributing data. Without vigilance and real cooperation, we cannot defeat this threat and the likelihood of further attacks remains very high. I urge all States to cooperate fully. The European Council was an opportunity for the leaders to assess the state of play in building the Energy Union. There is significant progress in the level of interconnections between states on the gas and electricity markets, including the parts of Europe that have been isolated until now. When I proposed the Energy Union concept as Polish Prime Minister, this was one of my major goals. I am happy to see clear progress, but still we need more. The European Council asked for all relevant legislation to be brought forward, including on strengthening the transparency on the gas market. Talking about the Energy Union, leaders had an exchange on the Nord Stream II project. Some of them were very critical, and we also discussed the conditions that need to be met by major energy infrastructure projects. We reiterated that any new infrastructure should be fully in line with the Energy Union objectives, not to mention the obvious obligation that all projects have to comply with all EU laws, including the third Energy Package. These are clear conditions for receiving support from the EU institutions or any Member State – political, legal or financial. Now the ball is in the court of the Commission, but the political message of the European Council is clear and goes in a similar direction to the position expressed by the European Parliament. Leaders praised President Hollande and congratulated him on the successful hosting of the COP21 and on the agreement of the first ever, legally-binding global climate deal. We have asked the Commission and the Council to assess fully what the Paris Agreement implies for our own energy and climate policy mix. Last, but certainly not least, the European Council addressed economic challenges. Leaders confirmed their commitment to work towards completing EMU further, based on the Five Presidents’ report. Even if Europe is overwhelmed by the migration crisis, we cannot afford to wait with the necessary EMU reforms for better days. In this spirit, ministers were asked to advance their work rapidly on a number of areas, including the Banking Union. The European Council also emphasised the importance of deepening the single market in key areas. Delivering a digital single market and building a capital markets union is our top priority. Finally, I want to warn against the increasingly alarmist rhetoric on the future of Europe. Neither naivety nor excessive pessimism will get Europe the results it needs. As Europeans, we have to be both realistic and confident about our values and beliefs. I am reminded of Arnold Toynbee’s famous remark that civilisations die from suicide, not by murder. Europe is stronger than some may think, and we still have the power and the public mandate to do what is necessary. (Applause)

name: Jean-Claude Juncker
text: Commission President. Mr President, Mr President of the European Council, after the words of the President of the European Council, if I were to sum up in two words the conclusions of the last European Council - from migration to terrorism, from economic and monetary union to the United Kingdom, through external relations - I would say that they are the perfect reflection of a Europe in 'polycrise'. We have talked a lot in recent months about the Greek crisis, the refugee crisis and other crises, but Europe is actually facing a combination of multiple, complex, "multi-strategic" crises, coming from outside or inside the European Union, all of which are all occurring at the same time. We are clearly in a difficult situation, which calls for overcoming national selfishness and regaining the pioneering spirit of European integration, its momentum and solidarity. We can, if we wish, provide a responsible and united European response to the multiple crises we face. We can and must do so, because only more European solidarity will enable each of our countries to overcome these crises. This is essential if we are to preserve what we have benefited so far, for example our internal market or the Schengen area, and if we also want to bring elements that are still lacking to perfect European integration. Mr President, the Commission has already presented all the necessary elements to effectively manage the urgency of the refugee crisis. If they had already been implemented by the Member States, we would be in a much better situation today. That is why, when I hear that there is no European response to the refugee crisis, it is both false and true. That is not true, because the Commission, working in good intelligence with Parliament, has brought all the elements of a European response. That is true, because this response will only be effective and will have concrete results when all Member States move from words to action. Some, often very quick to criticise the Union and Brussels, as they say, must look in the mirror and see that, yes, Brussels is also them, the Member States and their governments. The lack of action by the Union is also due to the lack of implementation of the commitments made collectively on behalf of the Union. As the Council has pointed out, it is up to The Member States to accelerate our efforts to ensure that 'hotspots', relocation and resettlement are not empty concepts, but become genuine effective instruments for an orderly takeover of European migration management. I call once again on this Parliament to move forward with all the speed necessary in setting up a European border and coastguard corps.  At common borders, common management: if we do not understand this, Schengen will not survive. A Europe with internal borders is a time that today's young people did not know in their lifetime, and that is very well. That must not be changed. Internal borders, the Erasmus generation and the internet, these are things that do not go together. I am also not sure that the 1.7 million or so border workers who cross our borders on a daily basis would welcome the end of the Schengen area, nor that transport companies would like to suffer financial losses as a result of the reintroduction of borders. There are 24 million business trips to Europe a year, there are 57 million cross-border road transport a year, all of which costs money. The cost of non-Schengen is very high. It is not a program for growth and jobs, it is an anti-growth and employment agenda. Everything will have to be done to save this space, knowing that this requires a well-controlled European policy of legal migration. This is why the Commission will shortly present its proposals on legal migration and also a revision of the Dublin rules for asylum seekers. Herr President! Wenn es um den Schutz unserer Grenzen geht, dann reicht es nicht, sie nur von unserer Seite aus zu betrachten. Man muss die Grenzen der anderen, die Grenzen, die wir mit anderen teilen, auch mit deren Augen betrachten. Dann reichen nicht nur Gipfel - so wichtig diese auch sind.  Es braucht auch hartn-ckige, tagt-gliche Kleinarbeit. Nicht Arbeit an Absichtserkl-rungsformulierungen, sondern konkrete Kleinarbeit: Heizk-rper, Decken, gemeinsame Standards, gemeinsame Registrierung betreffend.  Ebenso beharrlich arbeiten wir auch mit der Turkei zusammen. Diese hat erste begràenswerte Schritte unternommen, um den gemeinsamen Aktionsplan umzusetzen. So hat sie unter anderem eine Visumpflicht fer Syrer aus Drittl-ndern eingef-hrt, und sie arbeitet daran, den Arbeitsmarkt fer syrische Flàchtlinge zu 'ffnen. Das sind sehr wichtige Schritte. Doch es bleibt noch schrecklich viel zu tun, um den Flàchtlingsstrom nachhaltig und spurbar zu reduzieren. Der gemeinsame Aktionsplan muss in Gànze umgesetzt werden, und zwar schnell! I do not like all the headlines I read day after day, but I have nothing against those headlines when they talk about hard work that produces good results. December's historic agreement on climate change demonstrated the European Union's capacity for global leadership. In Paris, the European Union worked hard for a deal that was ambitious and legally binding and that is what we have achieved, but the real work starts now. The Commission is assessing the Paris Agreement so that we can move on to agreeing on new steps. In the meantime, the EU Member States will have to continue setting the example and implementing current commitments, so we will need to collectively agree 2020 targets. Looking at the United Kingdom's relationship with the European Union, the European Council held a constructive debate on the four sneakers that the British Government set out. Let me underline what I said at the time: none of those four sneakers are simple or easy to address and we are treating each of them seriously. But let me also underline that the Commission, as I said before, wants a fair deal for Britain. The Union is stronger with Britain inside and Britain is stronger inside the Union. That is why we think that the deal we are seeking has to be a fair deal for the European Union too. The Commission is working together with colleagues and representatives at the Council in that direction. I would like to conclude by paying tribute once more to the work of this Parliament. I have been witnessing this Parliament for more than 12 months now, and I have to say that our coordinated action is producing good results. And this Parliament has helped the Commission to deliver good results. When we needed speed and when we needed flexibility, flexibility for our new proposals, Parliament was there and Parliament delivered. I am grateful for this support and confidant that we will continue in the same spirit this year and in the next few years.  (Applause)

name: Manfred Weber
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has Looking ahead to 2016, many citizens are naturally looking forward to this year, the terror challenge, migration issues, economic development, the sum of the crises that Jean-Claude Juncker and Also Donald Tusk have already mentioned. Nevertheless, i would like to begin by returning to what I also said in the December plenary speech, namely to remember the success stories, to encourage people that Europe can succeed together. I see Federica Mogherini sitting here, for example. I was a proud European politician a few days ago when I saw them together with the Iranian Foreign Minister to present the Iran deal, to make it clear that we, as Europeans, are contributing to peace in this world, that no nuclear weapons are produced. A great success for Europe - thank you for that! (Applause) In the Friday press conference of our President of the Commission, we saw the figures that the Juncker plan now epitomises. Thousands of businesses in Europe are now benefiting from the billions we have jointly committed. And Paris, as a symbol of the fight against climate change, is also a European success. That is why it is important that we remember this if we want to convince people of our project. In the December Council – this is my second point I want to raise – the debate on the United Kingdom was at the centre. I think that David Cameron has presented the ideas, the ideas very positively in the Council and has also made many friends. Many of the ideas that David Cameron is putting forward are ideas that can make Europe better if we tackle it together. I would like to express my support for what he said on competitiveness, innovation, better regulation, big and big things and small and small things. He has the full support of the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats, and we want success in this. Admittedly, it is becoming more difficult when it comes to social abuse issues. Everyone wants to fight against social abuse. However, I must also make it clear at the beginning of the year that we, as the PPE-DE, cannot tolerate discrimination against European citizens. We must succeed in this bridge. I have a fundamental question in the British debate that concerns me, because there is a great deal of discussion in London about the question of ever closer union. I understand the concerns that are also associated with this: more and more competences for Brussels, more and more power in Brussels – this is certainly being discussed critically. However, I would also ask you to read the text in its entiren way in the discussion that is taking place. It says: 'ever closer union' of 'peoples' – not of institutions, not of Brussels, not of states – of peoples.   And this is a perfect description of the idea of Europe. After the terrible wars that we have had on this continent, to say: people should come together – ever closer union of peoples. In this respect, I am also campaigning for the text to be read in full in the British debate, because it is a wonderful description of what we had as a lesson from the terrible wars of our continent. Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to raise a third point: the great issue of migration. The guiding principles are clear to us as the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats: if there is war in Syria, and 250 000 people have died, then this continent must help. There can be no border closure, where we no longer agree to help. On the other hand, we also know that the figures we have in many areas are challenging, are also too high and we need to return to reliable, sustainable figures. These are the two guardrails. I would like to make it clear on my group that we very much welcome the fact that the Commission has presented a number of legislative texts. We have a promise that, Mr President of the Commission, we will also process the proposals quickly in order to make it clear that Europe is delivering. What we need to do now is simply to implement and enforce the law. If only 40% of the 1.1 million people who have arrived, for example, in my own country, Germany – 1.1 million last year – are Syrians, then we must implement the law and ensure that those who have no reason to flee are not admitted to the European Union and also to be repatriated. We must also enforce law in a second respect. We all have the Cologne events of New Year's Eve in mind. Yes, we want to protect people, but it must be made clear that the one who breaks the law and who breaks the traditions, that is, the equality of men and women, does not respect culture in Europe, then its guest right must be forfeited and deported. That too must be clear. Thirdly, we must enforce the law on aid in the countries of origin. Mr President-in-Office of the Council, this is an appeal, above all, to the Council. If the Council decides that we are funding EUR 3 billion for Turkey, that the Commission is making proposals, that the European Parliament is rapidly amending the budget, that we – Europe – are delivering the money, and then we are witnessing the tragedy that, for example, Italy is not prepared, or only by means of counter-trades, to actually transfer these promised funds, then that will damage the credibility of Europe and the European leaders. And that is why we are calling once again: this behaviour, especially by Matteo Renzi – And I must make it so clear – damages credibility, and this loss of credibility is the cause of populism in Europe. It is not that we are making promises, but this loss of credibility is the problem behind populism. We are ready to give answers. Let's get on with it in 2016! (Applause) (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Maria Grapini (S&D)
text: Question put in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure. – Mr Weber, you remember that even in December I asked you a question and I see that you continue to give us advice and speak very nicely here. My question is: do you not think that what you have said now about the refugee and migrant policy should have been Mrs Merkel should have thought at first? We now put conditions: to respect our culture and to respect the conditions in our country, but this condition has not been put in place from the beginning. What do you think? Was there a mistake or not?

name: Manfred Weber (PPE)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. I call on everyone to think about how we deal with the migration issue. I would like to say once again that if in Syria, and please listen, when 250 000 people have now been murdered in Syria by this civil war, when almost 14 million people are now fleeing this country, because there is war there, because bombs are being thrown there, then everyone in Europe must face up to their responsibilities and say: it is precisely as a Christian continent that we must then have people fleeing these regions, also offer assistance. That is the first place where I think some people in Poland should be listening.  The second is also clear: the whole of Europe has performance limits. We will be talking about figures that we have to comply with and which we need to define in terms of performance and both points need to be seriously debated.

name: Enrique Guerrero Salom
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, the conclusions of the last Council have raised concern and disappointment in my group, a feeling that has been taking place Council after Council. And it is not because no decisions have been taken, because no agreements have been made. It has been done on important issues: emigration, terrorism, economic and monetary union. The problem is that when one reads the conclusions of the Council in June, the Council in October or the informal meetings in September and November, one must read very carefully to realize that they are not the same conclusions.  It seems that we are doomed time and time again to follow the same sequence: the Commission prepares and proposes, the Member States meeting in the Council take decisions, and the Member States in their countries ignore and fail to comply with the decisions they have taken in the Council. This is the myth of Sisyphus: we are continually returning to the original point.  Let's talk about the issues: terrorism. The issue of information sharing remains unresolved. This morning Mr Juncker pointed out to us that we were as we were in 2001 after the New York bombings. It is true that I welcome the proposal announced this morning by Mr Juncker to combat the financing of terrorism.  If we talk about emigration, hotspots are not working, relocation is not working and the moral, social and political climate within the Union is deteriorating.  If we talk about the economy, it does not exist in the Council's conclusions, but unemployment remains high, investment continues to drop and inequality continues to grow.  So are we going to settle, as Sisyphus, that he knew he was doomed to return again and again to the starting point? Let's listen to Toynbee, who you yourself just quoted: let's avoid our own suicide. If we do not avoid our own suicide, the myth of Sisyphus will also be fulfilled with us. We will be unable to move forward and that will be our political death.

name: Geoffrey Van Orden
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, too often the European Union seems more concerned with finding a role for itself, with institutional self-preservation and driving forward political integration. It tries to do too much and ends up doing little or making things worse. In fact, many other problems – economic, political, security – are consequences of the EU’s own policies. We welcome the support of other governments and sensible Members of this House for the reforms sought by the British Prime Minister. The opportunity for change should be grasped enthusiastically. MEPs should be the first to recognise that the citizens of our countries do not want ever closer union. They want national governments responsible to them for their actions. They want a European Union that costs less and which spends its resources more effectively. They want an EU that cuts red tape and removes barriers to trade and competitiveness and which moves rapidly to conclude free trade agreements with countries such as India and our transatlantic partners. They certainly do not want the whole nature of our countries changed by the massive uncontrolled influx of people from other cultures, and clearly our countries should be able to adjust their benefit systems as necessary and should be given greater flexibility in the scope and duration of suspending EU rules for public policy or national security reasons.  We should recognise how sensible David Cameron’s policy towards refugees has been, dealing with the problem at source, helping those in the refugee camps and accepting limited numbers of the most vulnerable. Perhaps the Commission should be looking at ways to reduce the pull factors and reviewing the limitations imposed by international laws such as the Refugee Convention and ECHR and, as Mr Weber said, most refugees do not come from Syria.  Terrorism is a separate matter from migration, although not entirely unrelated. We welcome the PNR agreement. This is an important breakthrough, but we still need to go further. Much of the cooperation that people want is best done between our national police and security agencies.

name: Guy Verhofstadt
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, first of all I have to tell you that I hesitated a little bit to participate in this debate because we are repeating ourselves time and again. It is the fourth or the fifth time that we have exactly the same debate, and I agree with Mr Guerrero, who used a very active comparison, namely the myth of Sisyphus. Every time we say ‘Yeah, we need European border and coast guard’, where is it? It is now months since the Commission put that proposal on the Council’s table, and still we are waiting for that. Meanwhile, everybody knows what the first thing to do is: register, monitor and secure our external borders. When I hear, Mr Van Orden, that you are praising Mr Cameron’s policy on refugees, I feel that you should go – maybe with me or a number of other volunteers – to the camps in Calais and in Dunkirk where they are living in the mud. There are pregnant women and children who are not allowed to come into Britain, in spite of the fact that their families are living in Britain. They are not allowed to come in. That is the so-called ‘open policy’ of a Conservative Government. I can tell you, it is a shame when you go there and when you see in what circumstances these people have to live. It is easy to talk about the southern borders of Europe, but you can see what is happening on the western borders of Europe. My fear is that we no longer have Schengen being applied in Denmark, in Sweden, in Austria, in Slovenia, or in Hungary, so what will happen if Germany is doing that tomorrow? That could be the end of Schengen. That could be the end of the European Union  (Applause) Yeah, OK that is what you want. You want to return to your British Empire that no longer exists, but the reality is a little bit different. The reality is that, today, this all is falling apart because of a lack of decisiveness by Member States. It is not the European Union that has a lack of decisiveness; it is the Council, which meets time and again. I hope every time that they are going to take decisions on the European border and coast guard, on the new migration and economic migration policy, on a new asylum system, on a relocation system, and on a mandatory relocation system for the refugees. What is happening? 290 people have been relocated officially of the 160 000 proposed by the European Commission, and everybody knows that even that is theoretical, because in reality there are more than one million people already inside the European Union and in need of a new system.  My plea to you, Mr Tusk, is this: you are going to have an exceptional summit on 18 February, I think, on Brexit. Well, I propose a change. Hold an exceptional summit on the refugee crisis. Brexit can wait until March or April. The most urgent thing to tackle now is to finally take decisions with the Member States on each of the four points that are necessary: a relocation system, a migration system, a new asylum system and, at the same time, the first thing to do is set up a European border and coastguard. That seems to be far more important than starting the whole discussion about the Brexit, because you will maybe find a way out of the Brexit so that Britain remains in the European Union, but we could find ourselves without a European Union if we continue like this. (Applause) (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – Mr Verhofstadt, you and I come from completely different points of view, but I always enjoy listening to you and I always respect what you say because in what you say there is a very clear, honest and logical policy. It just happens to be totally different from what I believe in. You actually do believe in closer integration, politically and economically and you know what the real meaning of ever closer union of the peoples of Europe means, and I respect that.  The people I do not respect are the people on my own side who pretend not to know what it means or that it is not happening. May I ask you a question, and extend you an invitation? When we have our referendum in Britain, will you please come and argue for the ‘stay in’ side so that we can have an absolutely honest and clear debate?

name: Guy Verhofstadt (ALDE)
text: blue-card answer. – I accept the invitation. I think the first who is laughing then is Mr Farage – he likes that, to have a debate about it. But you have to go a little bit further into your reasoning. What would the state of the British economy be without the internal market on the European continent?  What would be the weight of the City of London if they could no longer trade in euros, when 70 or 80% of all the trading in the City of London is done in euros? I think that Britain has to remain in Europe, and it is completely crazy to think that you can go back in history and do it on your own. That is not working in the globalised world of tomorrow. (Applause)

name: Inês Cristina Zuber
text: gue/NGL Group. – (20) Mr President, the centre of the Council's response to the tragedy of migrants, including refugees, is in practice to strengthen the expulsion mechanisms. On the pretext of increasing the number of refugees, the European Union is setting up a real hunt for all non-asylum seekers. These conclusions are about the increased operationality of hotspots, the hotspots that will serve to expel migrants from the territory of the European Union more quickly. There is talk of increasing the identification of migrants, of supporting countries such as Italy or Greece in so-called return operations, but which are actually expulsion operations. Turkey has promised €3 billion in return for the containment of migrants in its territories, who knows how to be able to do dignity and a violation of their rights. But it does not matter: what matters is that the European Union is to get out of the problem it has created and continues to create through destabilisation and interference in the Middle East and North Africa. What the Council should decide was to shift, yes, the funds of the Frontex agency, Europol and resources from the Internal Security Fund – in short, all the resources allocated to surveillance, border control and repression – to the reception (of this is hardly spoken of in its conclusions), to social integration (much less is spoken of in the conclusions) and to the creation of legal and safe routes. It would be a dignified and humanitarian solution.

name: Ulrike Lunacek
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, ladies and gentlemen in the stands! The December summit brought at least one clear self-criticism by governments, namely that crisis management on the refugee issue is not working. Now it has to be said that insight would be the first step towards improvement. But what we are seeing to this day – a month and a day later – is that this crisis management on the refugee issue is still not working, and that is a catastrophic picture.  The reception centres, the so-called hotspots, are still not working. The distribution of asylum seekers is still not working. 160 000 were planned, up from 290 so far. This does not at all contribute to the fact that the people can really believe that together we in the European Union will bring about solutions here. Mr President-in-Office of the Council, Mr Tusk, I also agree with Mr Verhofstadt: it would be necessary for the next summit to be one where you are finally telling the members of the Council that we are Europe together. It is not Brussels that is Europe, but each and every government, each and every Member State, and only together can we solve this.  Because what else happens: reintroducing Schengen borders is a spiral of harassment that will lead to failure. This is a retrograde step on the part of the national state. I must also criticise my own country and the Austrian Federal Government.  Now all of a clear , the Foreign Minister – playing a cynical game with the refugees – declares that the more borders, the more pressure on Greece, the sooner there will be a European solution. That is cynical. We need common solutions at European level and that is what the next summit, Mr Tusk, should do. Brexit can wait and hopefully will wait.

name: Nigel Farage
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, I am looking forward to Guy Verhofstadt, the Liberal Group leader, coming to the United Kingdom to take part in the Brexit debate. His passionate defence of a United States of Europe and a European army is, I know, sincerely held, and I am sure that the Liberal Democrats will be delighted. (Laughter) It has now been a month since the last European summit. I don’t know about a week being a long time in politics, but there has been a sea change in that month and I think that one event has woken people up to the folly of EU leaders: the Juncker common asylum plan, the Merkel call which led to a stampede. Those of us who have warned that unlimited numbers of people from different cultures without security checks would pose a threat to the cohesion of our societies were roundly abused for doing so. And then we came to New Year’s Eve: Munich, the main train station closed down because of a terrorist threat, the intelligence coming from Syria and Iraq. The very same train station that in September people had stood at holding up their placards: ‘Refugees Welcome’. That irony was not lost on me.  But it is what happened in Cologne – where we saw the mob, up to a thousand young males in the street, sexually assaulting and harassing women – which is, I think in many ways, one of the most disgraceful public order events that we have seen in modern—day Europe. And yet there was an attempt by the police and the press to cover it all up, and even the suggestion from some German politicians that German young women should change their dress and their mode of behaviour in the street, which I thought was a total insult. There is even a name for these assaults in Egypt, because they have now become commonplace and part of everyday life. We ought to have the courage to send out a message to say these assaults must never be acceptable in any European town or city and we will do our damndest to make sure that it never happens again. (Applause) When we go to the next European summit, where Mr Cameron is going to conclude his renegotiation, I have no doubt there will be a compromise on the fairly minor issue of migrant benefits and I have no doubt that he will come back from that summit with a few promissory notes for the future about Britain’s relationship. But what he is not going to be talking about is our ability to get back control of our borders, and the British people know that those young men in Cologne, in a few years’ time, will have EU passports and be free to come to Britain. To give you an idea of how big the sea change has been. Daily Telegraph commentator Allison Pearson, who had said she was undecided on Brexit because she did not have enough information, wrote this the other day: ʻAfter Cologne, the EU referendum is about nothing less than the safety and security of British women. We, the Euroclueless, need to woman up and vote for the right of our daughters and granddaughters to live as they choose and to smile in the street. No more Mrs Don’t Know – let’s get the hell out.’ I hope 2016 is our year of deliverance.  (Applause)

name: Der Präsident. –
text: First of all, I must ask for the following: we had just overlooked Mrs Lunacek's blue card, a question that should be put to her, here in the zeal of the battle. We will come back shortly afterwards. But first of all, Mr Farage, Mr Verhofstadt wanted to speak.

name: Guy Verhofstadt (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, I would just like to say that on sexual harassment his party, UKIP, has a whole record. So he should maybe use different language in this.  (Heckling from UKIP Group)

name: Nigel Farage (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, is this reasonable behaviour? We have had it more than once from this gentleman. Surely we should all be equal in this Chamber and treated fairly and with decency and courtesy and respect.  (Applause from certain quarters)

name: Der Präsident. –
text: You had not yet given me the opportunity to say anything, Mr Farage. But you quickly took the floor again in your own efficiency. Mr Verhofstadt will certainly be happy to substantiate the reason for his statement about sexual harassment in connection with your party.  If he can't, I'll call him to order. If he can, we will investigate. In any case, we have registered this first. Mrs von Storch: You had asked Mrs Lunacek a question under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card" to Ulrike Lunacek. Mrs Lunacek, a very brief question between Austria and Germany. When, at what number of migrants do you think Germany is entitled to protect its borders? How many migrants does Germany have to take in, expressed in numbers, rounded to millions?

name: Ulrike Lunacek (Verts/ALE)
text: Answer to a question about the procedure of the "blue card" to Beatrix von Storch. Mrs von Storch, you are well aware that this question of the figures does not work. How would you do that if you were in a government – which I hope will never be the case – and then say: OKAY, Germany takes in 1 million, and with the one million thin migrants you then send the German army and give the firing order, how? This does not work with the ceilings!

name: Vicky Maeijer
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. – The results of the European Council last December were not much different from those of the dozens of summits before it. Symbolic measures were put back on paper, but the only solution to stopping the asylum invasion, closing the borders, is what the European elite still does not want! And that can also be seen in the news of the past few weeks.  More than thirty-one thousand asylum seekers have already made the crossing this month. That's 21 times as much as in the whole month of January last year. Organized mass assaults in Cologne, Hamburg, Frankfurt by asylum seekers. Sexual assaults in Sweden, Belgium, the Netherlands and Austria, a suicide bombing in Istanbul by a terrorist who entered Turkey as a would-be refugee. A Dutch camera crew that was attacked in the tent camp in Calais and an attempt to stoning two transsexuals in Dortmund by immigrants.  Mr President, the balance of a year's meeting in Brussels: more asylum seekers, more terrorists, not to mention many deaths and victims of sexual assault and rape. My party, the Party for Freedom, wants the Netherlands to close its borders. We must protect our country to preserve what we have built: security, freedom, prosperity and our culture. We can't let that get destroyed.

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (NI).
text: Mr President, a single line crosses the decisions of the European Council and deepens EMU, i.e. a uniform implementation of the anti-labour policy on capital gains, competitiveness councils and fiscal councils for automatic cuts in wages, pensions and social benefits and for market integration.  These are complemented by the escalation of imperialist interventions and wars, with the counter-terrorism campaign becoming another pretext for conquering new markets for energy sources and energy routes. All this gives rise to unemployment, poverty, wars, refugee drama.  The Council decided to increase the repression against refugees and migrants, to create a hot spot for sorting the cheap workforce that crosses the smart border while the majority are intercepted or drowned in the Aegean, deported or stored in Greece.  The creation of the suppression force that will be the European Border and Coast Guard, a force that will have the right to intervene without the consent of the states, puts Greece's sovereign rights in the guillotine of Euro-Union interests and promotes aegean co-management bargains with Turkey under a Euro-NATO umbrella.  It has never ceased to be demonstrated every day that the European Union and the capitalism it serves do not change and that only the struggle of the peoples can radically reverse this situation.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Did I understand you correctly that you wanted to raise a point of order, Mr Verhofstadt?

name: Guy Verhofstadt (ALDE).
text: – Mr Zarianopoulos, you have put a question to me and I answer by saying that if you go to Google and you Google ‘UKIP and harassment’ you will have the answer to the question that you have put to me.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Okay, thanks for the hint.

name: Alain Lamassoure (PPE).
text: Mr President, let us be frank about migration problems: we have all failed. The Member States first, the largest as well as the smallest, the most open as well as the most closed, the non-Schengen countries as well as the Schengen countries and the European Union itself. The refugee relocation programme covered only 10% of the total real entries and, as was mentioned earlier, was carried out at just 1 or 2 per 1,000.  The lesson is clear: national selfishness does not work, it is no longer an option. A Member State cannot both take credit for blaming its neighbours for the problem and then turning to them for funding for its public investments across the Union. A Member State cannot both decide to accept all those who come forward and then call for help from those of its partners who have made a different political choice. Which of our Member States can hope, on its own, to deal with the problem in a country of origin, at peace or at war, or in a transit country, such as Turkey or Libya? As for the European Council, Mr President of the European Council, how can he claim to be the sovereign body of the Union and let its members back home, publicly bragging about not implementing its own decisions? Let's pull ourselves together! Divided, we experience all internal and external events; united, we have the ability to control them all.  There is a time for emotion, there is a time for reason and there is a time to return to what must be the first quality of the elected that we are: responsibility.

name: Tanja Fajon (S&D).
text: – The European Union has been going from crisis to crisis for years. Let's put out one, there's a new one.  After the December summit, I am also about not optimistic when it comes to slashing the situation with refugees and migrants. We have problems everywhere, in the movement, the return, border security, cooperation with Turkey.  In December, I called on the leaders at this place to defend Schengen, to implement the measures taken. Meanwhile, new fences have emerged, new border controls are rising, nationalist rhetoric, intolerance, xenophobia are rising. In Slovenia, my country, as well as elsewhere, people are worried that European solidarity has let us down. We're worried about what spring will bring.  Thousands of new desperate migrants along the Balkan route who will be forced to stop with fences?  We need measures that work. Three years ago, colleagues, the Union was awarded the title of Nobel Peace Prize winner. This must remain our fundamental motivation for integration, for peace, for the promotion of democracy and human rights at home and in the world. The fact is that no country will be able to cope alone with the challenges of migration, terrorism and the like.  Yes, we must be realists, pessimism will not lead us to results. Yes, we must act with one voice, not egoism, with nationalist, even radical rhetoric. But perhaps we also need to talk less and agree more, make less promise and also take more action. Dear Sirs, we are in a difficult situation. And it is a shame that for weeks and weeks, even in this institution, we are repeating the same things, while the values of Europe are falling apart. Da. Political suicide. But who will bear the responsibility? I join the call for an emergency summit and, yes, if there is no common solution, I fear that neither will the Union.

name: Anna Elżbieta Fotyga (ECR).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab The Council should find terms which, in accordance with international law, describe the link between the terrorist threat and migration policy. The Commission should review projects that pose a threat to the glorification of terrorist activities – I recall recent shocking Palestinian examples. And the third point. The UK public is closely watching the relationship between the institutions of the European Union and the Member States. In my opinion, today's debate on Polish the threat of Brexit.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, this week concludes a European semester marked by the financial blow to Greece. In the lesson of dignity and democratic courage of the Greek people to regain their sovereignty, the European Union responded with a humiliating memorandum, which enshrines the worst side of the European project. In order not to grow Euroscepticism, we must abandon Europe's project of social cuts, TTE and the war against the welfare state, and to bring back the European project towards the defence of social rights and human rights. We have an increasingly unequal Europe, which you do not talk about. A two-speed Europe, which refers southern countries to second-rate, increasingly impoverished, social rights-free citizenship. On the other hand, what moral authority can a President of the Commission have investigated for the treatment of multinationals to recommend to Spain the type of government he should form? Don't say, Mr Juncker, that Europe is responding to the humanitarian crisis when we spend more money on strengthening borders than in guaranteeing the right to asylum.

name: Laura Ferrara (EFDD).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, divisions and mistrust continue to connote the intentions and actions of European states on issues such as migration, security, economic and monetary union. Even today, Mr Juncker, you have told us about multiple crises, saying that some people are very quick to criticise Brussels rather than look in the mirror and judge their own government. I ask you, Mr Juncker, was that a reference to the Italian Government? Because in recent days we have learned in the press of his irritation with the Italian Prime Minister, Mr Renzi, who would apparently be considered inadequate, an inadequate interlocutor for Brussels. Well, for us in the 5 Star Movement, this is nothing new. Indeed, we have long denounced the lack of adequacy and credibility of a government which, moreover, is not even elected by the citizens and therefore unable to represent its needs, both at national and European level. We are therefore surprised at how the European Commission only now notices this, but more than the lack of dialogue between you, Mr Juncker, and our Prime Minister, Mr Renzi, we should be concerned about the lack of dialogue and harmony with all those citizens who are tired, who are imposed by policies from which they feel damaged. There is a clear crisis of representativeness.
