Faced with these divisions, these mistrusts, these misunderstandings, meetings and institutional decisions that are taken behind closed doors, because european Council meetings are held behind closed doors, are not recorded, nor do we know what the positions of each Member State are. So in the face of all this, in defiance of the direct democracy on which the European Union should be based, it is difficult to understand what is really happening, how things are in fact and, above all, what interests are really being protected. So, Mr Juncker, Mr Tusk, I would ask you to explain this to us better, I ask how things really stand. I'd like an answer on that.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I am confused and very concerned because only a few months ago, in here, it was said that immigration was a great opportunity for Europe. Now timidly it is admitted that it is a problem. And as you continue to discuss the problem, the immigration emergency brings us to our knees. Last year alone, one million migrants arrived in Europe and the flow continues to increase. With your crazy decisions you have brought Europe into chaos. Meanwhile, our cities are invading by thousands of illegal immigrants who take advantage of our reception and care about our laws, steal, peddle and rape. The events in Cologne are proof that the European Union has failed in the face of uncontrolled immigration. Do you really want to solve the problem? Close the borders! Do you really want to help the citizens? Use the resources to help them and not the fake refugees! Do you really want to stop the violence in our cities? Send the illegals back to their countries of origin! We need a few rules and no more blah blah blah that we keep hearing in here.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI).
text: Madam President, when the Commission announces grandiose plans to tackle immigration and terrorism, I confirm my conviction that we must either change the Commissioners, their advisers, or all together. Jihadists kill innocent people but you have decided to give three billion euros to Turkey, which helps, equips and co-targets the Islamic State. I therefore call on you to accept Turkey into the Union and, respectively, let Greece leave so that all your problems can be solved automatically. Where is the resettlement and redistribution plan? Where's the readmission plan? You are telling us that a European Border and Coast Guard Corps will be set up. Gentlemen of the Commission, spare us the obligation to listen to your nonsense. How long and money will it take to make this House operationally ready? On the basis of which Treaty and legislation will it attempt? Where will the necessary funds come from? Have you taken into account the principles of proportionality and subsidiarity? The Treaty on European Union expressly stipulates that the guarding of national borders is the exclusive competence of the Member States. In Italy you are planning the involvement of the European naval force in the Mediterranean, a force which, with the permission and coordination of Greece, may well be operating in the Aegean.

name: Esteban González Pons (PPE).
text: – Madam President, we started a very difficult year for the European Union and we know it from the beginning. The old problems are still there, as Enrique Guerrero said, even if some have new faces, such as the attack on women in Centroeuropa or the increase in racism and xenophobia. But we also have new problems, such as the procedure opened by the Commission to Poland in defence of the rule of law. And, by the way, Mr Tusk, as President-in-Office of the Council, could give the Council's opinion to this House, as we have not heard it in his first speech. Nor have we heard it in the Commission's intervention.  I am not a fortune teller, but I can say that next year we will continue to talk about immigration, because the Syria war is not over, because after winter new waves of refugees will come, because Member States are not implementing a common policy on refugees.  I am not a fortune teller, but I can say that we will continue to talk about terrorism, because it remains an imminent threat and we do not share information, because in what we have been doing for the year there have already been two very serious attacks – and I want to remind the nine German citizens killed in Turkey.  I'm not a fortune teller, but I know we'll keep talking about employment. I know we will continue to talk about the economy, we will continue to talk about the single market and we will continue to talk about fiscal and monetary union. Let's talk about China.  I am not a fortune teller, but I think we should talk and talk mainly about the United Kingdom. Because Europe without the UK loses, but the UK without Europe also loses. I think the time has come for us to tell our British friends what they were saying to the Scots: "Better together."  (He agreed to answer a question posed under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Regulation))

name: Paul Rübig (PPE)
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". I believe it is crucial to also work out what the strategy in the refugee crisis is between Spain and Greece. We should not make blanket judgments, but we should look at where the law is respected and, above all, where European law is enforced. Could you perhaps put this in a nutshell?

name: Esteban González Pons (PPE)
text: "blue card" response. – It is very important that the Commission work on refugees; He's doing it. It is very important that the Council takes the needs of Europeans seriously; I hope he's doing it. Above all, however, it is very important that the Member States implement what the European Union decides; they're not doing it.

name: Maria João Rodrigues (S&D).
text: – Madam President, we are dealing with overlapping crises but I believe that we should clearly identify the central problems which must be tackled if you want to keep the European Union, if you want to keep the union of Europeans. I believe that the two central problems are, firstly, managing the refugee crisis and, secondly, bringing down unemployment in Europe. I believe that we need to tackle these two problems together. That is why I would like to propose that three big investment initiatives should be launched which can create a lot of new jobs, particularly for young people, dealing with three main objectives. The first is to build up a real European border, the second is to adapt our societies to integrate refugees, and the third is to cooperate with the countries of origin in order to manage the flow of refugees. To build up a real European border is a big undertaking. It involves physical infrastructure, logistics and software, among other things. Adapting our towns and cities is also a big investment initiative because this means housing, education and urban planning. Thirdly, in cooperation you can bring many young people to participate in such an action. So this is the kind of proposal we should come up with.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL).
text: - Madam President, today in this House the President of the European Commission, Mr Juncker, the Commissioner for Migration, Home Affairs and Citizenship, Mr Avramopoulos, and Mr Tusk, President of the European Council, should resign. Resignation, because of the failure to manage the refugee and refugee crisis. Resignation, because the European Commission's proposal to accommodate one hundred and sixty thousand people has remained at the ridiculous figure of two hundred and seventy-two. Resignation, because under their responsibility thousands of people have drowned in the Mediterranean and millions of people survive in inhumane conditions in the fields, and because the European Union has become insolidary and cruel territory. The proposal put by the Council on the table is EUR 3 billion for Turkey. For this country to do the dirty work; to prevent refugees from reaching Europe; solidarity is left to a government that systematically violates human rights. They spend three times as much repressing refugees and refugees in Turkey as well as humanitarian aid. One more reason for all three of you to resign.

name: Peter Lundgren (EFDD).
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for A year full of failures lies behind europe, and a new year full of opportunities for new failures now lies ahead of EU cooperation.  We see external border protection as a total failure and, as a result, we are seeing mass immigration of almost biblical proportions, without any control of the people who are allowed in. And as a result, we are now seeing terrorist attacks at an increasing rate. We are seeing sexual abuse of a kind we have never seen before in Europe. The EU does not deliver what it has promised the Member States, and I strongly question whether we should pay the full membership fee from my country. As usual, you are succeeding in increasing your wages. Mr Juncker and Mr Tusk are now enjoying a €700 pay rise, giving a monthly salary of €31,272 retroactively from July last year. How can you even believe in your wildest imagination that you represent the peoples of Europe?

name: Janice Atkinson (ENF).
text: – Madam President, in December the rapes and sexual assaults and the sexual harassment of women were off the agenda and, at the Germans’ request, the subject is off the agenda this week, too. In towns across Europe, all liberal, tolerant societies are turning against the mass influx of migrants. In Germany, transgender women are stoned. In Sweden, schoolgirls are sexually assaulted at a music event. In Austria, girls are assaulted at school. And barbarians are sending their migrants on buses to Mrs Merkel who then sends them back again. That is unfair to genuine asylum seekers. German colleagues, Angela Merkel welcomed 800 000 – now you have 1.2 million. You give them passports. They bring their families. That is potentially 10 million extra. Then they can take those passports and their families and move to the UK. That is the size of my constituency in the South-East, and the Czech Republic. So how do we deal with this? We build more camps. We house them in the Middle East, in North Africa, and we support them, and eventually they may go back, because this is a clash of civilisations and when that happens, we know where that can lead.

name: Μανώλης Κεφαλογιάννης (PPE).
text: Madam President, refugee and migration flows continue unabat, in proportion to two migrants to one refugee. It is typical of Turkish Airlines, which, at FORTY euros, transport thousands of migrants from the Maghreb countries and Morocco to the European Union as the sole destination, because it is well known that these countries do not need a visa to go to the European Union. Illegal traffickers continue to act undisturbed; in the last three weeks of 2016 alone, 77 people died in the Aegean Sea, including countless young people and children. The real solution is to end the conflict in Syria, it is to return refugees to their homes and to stay safely in their homes. The solution cannot be to erect walls at the national borders of the countries of the European Union. We need solidarity and protection of the external borders of the European Union, the external borders of the peoples of Europe.

name: Knut Fleckenstein (S&D). –
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for his The air gets thinner. Even at home in Germany, the air is getting thinner, because people are realizing that we don't seem to be able to get a grip on it. Unfortunately, we are pointing to Brussels and not to the capitals of the Member States. We have a damn duty to prove that we can do it.  In the meantime, it is German ministers who stand in public opposition to the chancellor from Mr Weber's party and say: we must close the borders or have a plan for them. We all know that the closure of the border does not solve any problem, that no problem has been solved, but that additional problems are being created. However, if we really want to convince, we must offer more at home than what I can offer after this debate. When I come home and say that Mr Tusk has spoken here and said: we have addressed all the major crises, we have had a constructive discussion with Mr Cameron, we need to step up the internal market, we have dealt with the Energy Union. No, they want to know exactly what is happening? In this respect, I believe that we should stop these debates. Nor do we need a report from the Council if we simply say that we have dealt with it. We believe you, but we want to see results! Perhaps you need something like the Pope, President Tusk: lock them all up together and only let them out when they have concrete results, when the white smoke rises and real results are there. But coming together every two months to tell each other that the problems are still there, we don't need any advice. May I say one last sentence to you personally: I would like to thank you for the way in which you did a difficult job yesterday. Because we need a debate on democracy, but not Poland bashing. You made a good contribution to this yesterday. (The President cut off the speaker) (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR)
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Mr President, you have questioned the stakes in the protection of the external borders and have pursued German politics inside.  If we were to give up strict protection of the external borders, what would be the remedy? What you are specifically proposing, because you have criticised others, but I have not heard any positive response from the Socialists. What is the message, what is the Socialists' response to this problem?

name: Knut Fleckenstein (S&D)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. The response of the Socialists is the answer given by this Parliament: we must protect or control the external borders. Only then will we have a good reason to refrain from destroying Schengen. That is the task of the prime ministers and leaders: they must finally agree with each other, as they do, very concretely. And those who do not want to participate must consider whether they are well at home in Schengen. If we all start to close our borders, then we no longer have Schengen, but then we no longer need this discussion.

name: Glenis Willmott (S&D).
text: – Madam President, it makes my heart sink that, once again, here we are discussing a problem of David Cameron’s making, rather than the real challenges facing the EU. I am sure the EU leaders at the December Council felt the same. But it is important that a deal is done; that is not because I am backing Cameron’s negotiations – his priorities are not my priorities.  For example, where are the proposals to end loopholes in working rights legislation that are used by exploitative employers to undercut terms and conditions? We can take heart that some of the more damaging proposals originally floated are no longer on the table. Anti-Europeans on the Right were pushing for an attack on EU legislation on working rights – a move that would have undermined the direct benefits that working people see from our EU membership.  That these subjects are no longer under discussion will help us to make the case for Britain’s continuing membership of the EU, because this referendum is going to be about working people: the part-time check-out assistant who gets equal rights because we are in the EU; the factory worker for whom health and safety is not red tape, but a matter of life and death; the workers in companies large and small, whose businesses depend directly or indirectly on trade with Europe.  For all these people, for all working people, there are no circumstances under which they would be better off outside the EU. That is why we need to see a deal done and a deal done soon, because only then can we get on with a British referendum and put an end to the uncertainty that is bad for Britain and bad for Europe.

name: Patrizia Toia (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, europe's multiple crises run the risk that it could be the beginning of disintegration. We are well aware of this, and that is why we want to do everything possible, as you said to you too, Mr Juncker, who will do everything possible to reverse course, to save Europe. We care about today's Europe and its future, which is why we Italians, here in Parliament, and our government want adequate responses.  We want, for example, what is said about immigration, we want flexibility for growth and work to be continued, in short, we want a More United and More Progressive Europe. We are pro-European, we are ambitious, we have won the elections on a project to relaunch, not to call Europe into question, to relaunch it, and we want to be simply consistent with these commitments and promises. I have to say, moreover, and every time it has to fall a little down to reply to Weber, that I do not know who is the one who gives him the information about Italy, but I tell him to change the suggestion because he is all wrong when he talks about us and our government and I would like to say to him it would be easy for Europe's credibility to put it at risk those who , like him and his friends, I believe, wanted an ideological hostility that put citizens in difficulty, increased inequalities. We just want work and social agenda.

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D).
text: – Madam President, Mr Tusk said, in his speech, that Europe is stronger than we think. And let me tell you that's the problem, the lack of credibility. Because even those of us here today, defending the European project, find it difficult, at many times, to explain the unjustifiable. Today refugees do not occupy the big front pages of newspapers, but there is still an embarrassing reality. What are national governments waiting for to relocate the thousands of refugees who are now enduring extreme temperatures in the camps? Does anyone put themselves in their place or is they able to think that it was our own children who were in this situation? I'm addressing the Council. I'm addressing national governments. Stop making us feel ashamed and fulfill your obligations, because problems are many and solutions are urgent and necessary.

name: Илияна Йотова (S&D).
text: – I would like to thank you, Mr Juncker, for all the efforts made by the Commission to resolve the migrant crisis. At the same time, I cannot help but note one feature of all council decisions – always the use of future time.  And this is not only a grammatical feature, but also evidence of the poor results that the Council achieves.  Do you realize, Mr Tusk, that the loudest voice currently heard in Europe is about closing borders? Even the idea of a new Enhanced Security Agency is not embraced by some Member States. Moreover, Mr President, the activities of this agency will cover only Schengen Europe and not all the external borders of the Union. Why?! We don't have an answer.  There is no information on the progress of cooperation with Turkey, moreover, the data show more than modest results. Many unknowns hide the so-called "no-fly zone". voluntary resettlement from Turkey of Syrian citizens in Europe. No one's explaining that. Questions about readmission remain open.

name: Elisa Ferreira (S&D).
text: – Madam President, nineteen days ago the resolution of banks in the euro area was carried out at European level, with a completely new method – the bail-in method. And that is what I wanted to talk about, because in 2015 the European Council failed two solemn commitments. The first one that failed was to create a common credit line – it was envisaged that it would be the European stability mechanism providing that line, ensuring, if necessary, the financing of the common resolution fund – which should be ready before it comes into force. This compromise was part of the agreement with the European Parliament and is contained in the report of the five Presidents. But a second compromise, this one in 2012, still failed, at the time of Herman Van Rompuy, according to which the new single resolution mechanism would be accompanied by a common guarantee of bank deposits.  The absence of these two commitments weakens the relationship of trust in the European institutions. We hope that in 2016 the Council will be able to fulfil what it has committed itself to.

name: Μαρία Σπυράκη (PPE).
text: Madam President, there are two key conditions for dealing with the most urgent crisis since the crises we are experiencing. The migration crisis needs to be implemented by Member States' commitments and agreements on their implementation with third countries need to be supervised. With regard to the first, I would venture to say that it is time to consider how we can activate a sanction mechanism for the non-application of compulsory relocation in the Member States. I firmly believe that the imbalance in the contribution to the migration crisis is a fuse on the foundations of the Union. The young, the weak and those plagued by the crisis cannot carry disproportionate burdens over the powerful. With regard to the implementation of the agreements with third countries, it is necessary for Turkey to take much more steps. In the last fortnight alone, 30,000 people have arrived in Greece from Turkey, few of whom were refugees. Above all, irregular migrants are being re-promoted, we need a mechanism... (The President interrupts the speaker)

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D).
text: "Listening to this debate, I have come up with the idea of what we are doing here in the European Parliament. I feel that it is unworthy of us to hold the Commission or the Council responsible here for mistakes and articles made in the Member States. So here the Member States have a very serious responsibility. For example, Mrs Merkel's receptive words have been welcomed by many, but the question remains: does anyone, even a German Chancellor, have the right to invite 1 million people into a common space? Then, of course, we all struggle with that. Then some built fences and some didn't. And most importantly. Now some fences are closing again. What about the Balkans? How are we going to handle that? These are the real issues, and I think that the autonomy of the Member States must be rejected here and, yes, the Council and the Commission must stand on their heels.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: - Madam President, the European Council's firm position on the need to regain control of the external borders can only be welcomed, as I think it is clear to everyone today that the poor migration policy of the Union and some European leaders has led to huge problems that we will face not only in the coming months but probably for the whole of the next decade. We must finally come together and understand that with this scale of migration towards Europe, Member States cannot enforce rules written for use under controlled conditions rather than cataclysms.  The asylum policy was introduced to give protection as an advanced civilisation to individuals and groups at risk of life in their home countries, not entire nations. If we continue to take in migrants in this number as in the last few months, we will deepen security and social problems across Europe. In such circumstances, many more good rules will no longer be enforceable, and the positive effects of European integration will be quickly reversed.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI).
text: Madam President, immigration is still a serious problem which, unfortunately, the European Union has dealt with in the wrong way. He let it build up, allowed it to swell and now he doesn't have the courage to resolve it in the way he intended. The solution to the problem is not to erect walls at the border in order to abolish the Schengen Treaty in practice.  The solution to the problem is to stop the wars that create refugees and migrants. Until then, however, the solution must be found in Turkey and that is where the refugee screening centres, the so-called hot spots, must be established, so that these people are not allowed to come to Greece by the hundreds of thousands. Also, if there is one country in which a European Force must be established, it is Turkey. Only in this way could such a Force on the one hand not allow the official state to exploit illegal immigrants in the pursuit of resolving its national issues and, on the other hand, prevent corrupt state actors from speculating against these poor people. On the other hand, Greek coast guard forces can both supervise and monitor Greece's borders.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: – President of the Council, President of the Commission, I very much welcome the joint border control initiative presented at the Council in December 2015, but at the same time I am disappointed to hear that the agreement is to be postponed by more than seven months, that is to say, to June 2016. Here in the debate, we have heard a request from a majority of Members that this initiative be approved as soon as possible. I would like to call on you to do so, you have the competence to do so, and you also have a responsibility, and you hear that you have a great deal of support from the European Parliament in reaching an agreement as soon as possible. I want to ask you what prevents the next Council from having an extraordinary Council, because an emergency situation, perhaps as early as February, has been reached and border control started as soon as possible?

name: Jean-Claude Juncker
text: Commission President. Madam President, my dear colleagues, I understand those who feel tired from the same rehearsals every month, every week and every day. But as long as, despite President Tusk's efforts, the Member States have not translated the decisions they have taken into action, we will have to repeat that they have failed in their obligations - not all of them, but quite impressively. Therefore, there is nothing wrong with us repeating the same calls at regular intervals. Secondly, I understand in some speeches that the Commission is considered insufficiently active. Following the lines of my notebook, I can not find a statement of this type. I would just remind you that, following the priorities set out by the Commission, we are focusing on policies that are resolutely geared towards growth and jobs, which is why we launched the investment plan in November 2014, which covered EUR 315 billion. You won't have missed it - or would it? That, already, 40 billion of the 315 billion of this investment plan have been mobilized and allocated to 47 major infrastructure projects, 11 of which are in Italy, and 7,000 small and medium-sized enterprises.  Nor will you have missed the commission's ability to launch the security agenda, the energy agenda, all the actions that necessarily result from the establishment of the digital market and so on. I do not see, therefore, how the Commission, in the first year of its mandate, would have been out of work. It seems to me that we have been very active. On the few issues that were mentioned on the sidelines of the debate, I do not feel that , since someone has invited me amicably , I should resign because we cannot solve the refugee problem in good conditions. We must not give up or lose our courage, we must now ensure that the actions that have been decided are carried out. For the rest, Mr President, I have no further comments to make.

name: Donald Tusk
text: President of the European Council. – Mr President, first of all it is absolutely right that today we have a problem with implementation. When it comes to the migration crisis, I have no doubt that today we are at a very critical moment regarding the implementation of our decisions. But this is perhaps the first time when I feel that this is a critical juncture for the political system in Europe. The EU is based on an assumption that all Member States are ready to act with goodwill and to respect our common decisions. Without this method and this determination, our work has no meaning. You are absolutely right.  What is most critical today is that I have no problems reaching compromises at the level of the European Council. On the contrary, it is too easy to achieve compromise, but the next day almost no one is ready to respect our common decisions. This is a really critical moment, not only because of the matter of immigration, but for Europe as a political organisation. It is truly difficult to discipline Member States today. Neither I nor the Commission receives much thanks. I am sorry to say that if the first principle – that we are ready to respect each other and our decisions – is not respected then we will have a huge problem implementing anything at all. Maybe this is because the scale of the challenge is so unprecedented. This is the very brutal truth. Neither Europe as an organisation nor the Member States were sufficiently prepared to face this completely new – in terms of numbers – problem concerning migration. This is true. I cannot agree with Mr Verhofstadt’s assessment when it comes to our discussion about external borders. I am sorry, but the discussion about the idea of strengthening our external borders is quite fresh. If you remember, as I do, at the beginning of our discussion about the migration crisis, there was a different topical issue, not external borders. I am really satisfied with what the Commission has done in strengthening the external borders and on the quite new idea about common external border guards in Europe. As you know, some elements of this idea are still controversial for some Member States, for many reasons. It is still quite a demanding challenge to explain and to convince them that we need this new and controversial – but absolutely necessary – new measure. What we need today is to solve some problems as quickly as possible. This is why it is my intention to dedicate the February European Council meeting to the issue of the UK. I hope it will be our last European Council meeting about it. But the February meeting will also be devoted to an assessment of implementation regarding the migration crisis and our action plan with Turkey. The next European Council in March will also concern the migration crisis. Esteban González Pons asked about Poland. As I said a few days ago at a meeting with the political groups here at Parliament, the EU has a right and an obligation to engage in a tough and open dialogue with the authorities of every EU Member State where the rule of law and norms of democracy may be violated. But please do not expect me to be happy and full of enthusiasm when the procedure on Poland is launched.  You must understand that this is something really difficult for me. I know that the Commission acted in good faith. I have no doubt in that. We could discuss how some of the Commission’s measures, methods and decisions could have been tougher or softer. There was also a discussion within the Commission about timing and some procedural nuances, but the Commission took the decision. I am absolutely sure that this decision is an optimal one and I fully support it without any doubts. Believe me, seeking conflict between institutions, especially in this case, makes no sense. I am absolutely sure that we will continue to cooperate very closely also with regard to Poland.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The debate is closed. Written declarations (Article 162 OF the CRP)

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: in writing. – The Socialist MEPs have called for a change of course in the Council in order to implement the decisions taken at the summits and to avoid the failure of the European project. The conclusions of the last Council have raised concern and disappointment in my group, a feeling which has been taking place Council after Council. It seems that we are doomed time and time again to follow the same sequence: the Commission prepares and proposes, the Member States meeting in the Council take decisions, and the Member States in their countries ignore and fail to comply with the decisions they have taken in the Council. On issues, the issue of information exchange remains unresolved in the field of terrorism. As for immigration, hotspots are not working, while the refugee situation is disgraceful. For its part, the economy remains at low hours: unemployment remains high, investment continues to drop, and inequality continues to grow. Therefore, let us avoid our own suicide and call for a change of course that will end the EU's inability to move forward. Otherwise, it will mean his political death.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D)
text: in writing. It was a very complicated Council last December, at the end of a difficult, at times dramatic, and certainly contradictory year. Forced to stand still because of the profound differences of opinion between Member States, but aware that progress and decision-making is the only way for the European Union to survive, the Council of 17 and 18 December basically showed us once again that the Council is confronting, arguing, debating, highlighting and listing the problems without ever solving one. In 2015, all we did was talk about immigration and relocation. The result today is that perhaps less than 1% of migrants are relocated to other European countries. The other items on the agenda have also not seen any concrete conclusions, only the perpetuating of contradictions. The issue of sanctions against Russia is an example of this.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. – With her statement "We can do this", the German chancellor has triggered a mass rush to Germany, Austria and Sweden, i.e. to those countries with the highest monetary incentives for asylum seekers and economic migrants, which at 60 percent represent the largest group of immigrants. The result was 1.1 million registered asylum seekers in Germany in 2015 and 90,000 in Austria, unknown. According to the EU Commission, a further three million asylum seekers are expected by the end of 2016, with family admission not yet included. Such a mass influx presents the affected states with almost insoluble tasks. Education, social and health systems are overwhelmed, as are the legal system and, as a result, the national budget. It is doubtful whether there is any possibility of integration and ability for such a large number of people. Sweden has therefore already closed its borders and introduced a ceiling on Austria. Only Germany continues with its welcome culture. The EU must finally take action and protect the external borders effectively. This task, which should be a core EU competence, cannot be delegated to Turkey. If the EU's external borders cannot be effectively and sustainably protected, member states will have no choice but to take national measures – a fact that received little attention at the December Council meeting.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing – At its meeting of 17 and 18 December 2015, the COUNCIL of the EU discussed pressing issues dominated by the migration crisis, terrorism, the deepening of the economic and monetary union and the negotiation of an agreement with Britain. At the meeting, national representatives agreed to support the Border and Coast Guard, a concrete proposal of which is to be set up by the Dutch Presidency. A proposal that we must agree with, but why did it not come until December 2015? If the common, integrated protection of the EU's external borders were a theme in December 2014, Europe would not have to face uncontrolled migration - not being able to register them and infiltrating undesirable people who are dangerous from the point of view of terrorism. The solution to relations with Turkey and the agreement on helping to tackle the problem of migrants directly in Turkey have also been delayed - I believe at least one year. Although negotiations with Turkey are very complicated, but the three-billion-billion-strong aid should improve the situation of migrants in Turkish detention camps in terms of social, health, but also humanitarian, so that these migrants have no reason to flee further to Europe and to be able to return to their homeland once peace has been established in their home country.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the Council and Commission statements on the situation in Poland (2015/2989(RSP). Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to point out now that there is no catch-the-eye procedure in this block of debates and that I will not allow blue cards either. No, no, we are not allowed to have a debate on the Rules of Procedure here. We are now entering this debate. You can try as much as you want. This has been laid down in the Conference of Presidents, as has been communicated in the political groups, as your group was aware. Dear Prime Minister Szydeo, welcome to the European Parliament.  Ladies and gentlemen, the decision to debate the Commission's actions, to initiate a dialogue to assess the situation in Poland on the basis of the framework for strengthening the rule of law, is a first debate of this kind in the European Parliament. This is a completely new instrument. There has never been such a debate or procedure. The instrument was first presented by the Commission in March 2014. A so-called early warning mechanism has been set up. The rule of law, as we all know, is not a purely procedural issue, but a core body of our European democracy and our social model. That is why this debate is certainly also a central debate for future procedures of this kind. I therefore assume that we will work very concentrated lynotsand in respect. Once again, a warm welcome to the Prime Minister of Poland and also my thanks for agreeing to take part in this debate. We now come to the debate itself.

name: Bert Koenders
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, the European Union is not only a market, it is also a Union built on common values. The EU Treaties are eloquent and crystal clear. Article 2 states the values on which this Union is founded and reaffirms that these values are common to all Member States. Membership of our Union entails not only  benefits, but also responsibilities. Among the foremost responsibilities of each Member State is respect for the Union’s fundamental values, not least the rule of law, democracy, and fundamental rights. It is what makes us as Member States, and also as a Union, unique in the world. These values are shared not only because they are written on paper, but because they have been brought to life in pluralistic and open societies over the last decades, sometimes against stiff opposition. They are fundamental because they provide essential guarantees for the freedom of our citizens and the functioning of our democracies. However, neither the rule of law nor other fundamental values can be taken for granted. This continent brought forth the three most deadly and venomous political doctrines that we have known. Our ancestors fought over these doctrines and finally overcame them. We have learned our lessons the hard way, and we have vowed countless times that we would never return to those dark days, but would build a new community on this continent where freedom and peace would reign. We have been successful in this endeavour and the secret of that success is that we put democracy and the rule of law first. It was crucial then and it remains crucial today that we continue to do so.  Ensuring respect is a constant challenge that governments have to live up to, and yet we must be honest. No one country has a monopoly on virtue and no one country has a monopoly on vice. We all have deficiencies, but the true strength of our democracies is that we can identify these deficiencies, debate them, acknowledge them and fix them. That is what democracy is all about. This also implies that we are ready to have open discussions about the best way to protect these values in times of change. Today’s debate in which the Council – and I thank you for that – has been invited to speak, has been triggered by the most recent measures introduced by the newly democratically elected Polish Government, including the position of the Constitutional Tribunal, and the governance of public media.  Both the independence of tribunals and the freedom and pluralism of our media are indispensable elements in ensuring the rule of law in a democratic society. The Council has repeatedly stressed that media freedom and pluralism are fundamental values and essential pillars of democracy. This is due to their important role in ensuring transparency and to their impact on public opinion and on the participation of citizens in decision-making processes. On several occasions the Council has also highlighted the independence of the judiciary as a core value emerging from the constitutional traditions of Member States. It is not for the Presidency to pass judgment, especially not at this juncture in time. The Council has not discussed the situation, but I do want to briefly say something about Poland. Not many countries have suffered from European history as Poland has, divided, occupied, purged and ravaged, but the Polish spirit has never died. It has fought for its independence and its identity even under the Soviet yoke, and while its government was in exile, Polish soldiers helped to liberate my country in 1945, and for that I will be eternally grateful.  (Applause) And now in 2016, 11 years after Poland joined the European Union, it has thrust itself forward into the circle of big powers. It has succeeded in establishing itself as a confident and successful European political and economic power, and it has grown into a democratic state with strengthened institutions. And the Polish people have been able to do this because they could build upon a tradition, having had one of the earliest enlightened constitutions in Europe as its Constitution of 1791 attests. The Polish people deserve huge respect for what they have accomplished and in their quest for sovereignty they have found themselves at the heart of the European Union.  The Presidency is grateful for being given the opportunity to participate in this debate. Parliament has always shown great dedication to the protection of rule of law, democracy and fundamental rights in the Union. It is no secret that my country, the Netherlands, home to Grotius and host to many international tribunals, feels it must embed fundamental rights and the rule of law in its foreign and European policies. In 2013, together with Germany, Finland and Denmark, we sent a letter to our partners arguing the need for a platform to debate the rule of law. If we can talk about fish and finance, why not also talk about fundamental rights and the rule of law? That is also why we are organising a rule of law seminar on migration in Strasbourg on 2 February. We hope to have many participants from the relevant institutions.  Already two months ago the Council held its first annual dialogue on the rule of law in the Union. We will organise a second rule of law dialogue in the May General Affairs Council. We will use the outcome of the February seminar as a basis for this discussion. Our Presidency is thus committed to ensuring respect for these core values.  Of course, the Council is not acting alone in these matters of fundamental importance. On the contrary. The Commission plays in our view a vital role in monitoring developments in this field across the Union, especially in its role as guardian of the Treaties. I also wish to highlight the role played by the Council of Europe and its Venice Commission in these questions. Both the European Commission and the Venice Commission, in accordance with their roles, are looking into the developments of our discussion today, and we would suggest that this debate is carried out in an impartial and cooperative spirit, and that progress can be made after a thorough analysis of the facts.  The Vice-President of the Commission will update us on the work of the Commission and the next steps after the College’s decision last week to launch a structured dialogue with the Polish authorities, and Prime Minister Szydło, with whom I had the honour to talk today, will have the opportunity to address this Chamber and share her government’s position. I welcome her participation today which can only contribute to the necessary dialogue within our European democracy.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Before giving the floor to the Vice-President of the Commission, I would like to make a brief comment: ladies and gentlemen in the stands, ladies and gentlemen. You are welcome. I think a lot of people have travelled very far here today. However, I must point out to you that, according to our Rules of Procedure, there are no demonstrations of applause and disapproval from the stands. I would be grateful if you could maintain your neutrality. Thank you very much.

name: Frans Timmermans
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, on behalf of President Juncker and my colleagues in the Commission, I want to set out for you the reasons why the Commission has decided to assess the recent developments in Poland, and how we hope to move forward in a constructive and facts-based dialogue with Poland to prevent the emergence of a systemic threat to the rule of law. The main reason for beginning this assessment under the 2014 Rule of Law Framework is the situation concerning the Polish Constitutional Tribunal, and in particular the dispute about the nomination of a number of judges of the Tribunal. In principle, this should be an issue for the Constitutional Tribunal itself to resolve. However, as things stand, the other institutions of the Polish State have not complied with the judgments rendered by the Constitutional Tribunal on the matter. This has given rise to uncertainty regarding the functioning of the Constitutional Tribunal. Furthermore, the Polish Parliament has decided to shorten the mandates of the President and Vice-President of the Tribunal. On 28 December last year, an amendment to the law on the Constitutional Tribunal entered into force which appears to render the functioning the Constitutional Tribunal considerably more difficult. Given the central position of the Tribunal within the Polish judicial system, we risk seeing the emergence of a systemic threat to the rule of law. Concerns have also been raised as regards the new media law. The rule of law, as defined in our Rule of Law Framework, requires the respect for democracy and fundamental rights. Media freedom and pluralism are also closely connected with fundamental rights, in particular the freedom of expression. This is why the Commission considers it necessary to assess this law in the light of the rule of law. The European Union is founded on a common set of values enshrined in Article 2 of the Treaty on the European Union, which include, in particular, the respect for the rule of law. Mutual trust among EU Member States and their respective legal systems depends on the confidence that the rule of law is observed in all Member States. When national rule of law safeguards seem to come under threat, the EU needs to act. I would also note that the Constitutional Tribunal in Poland has a key role to play in ensuring that the legislative reforms currently envisaged in Poland comply with the Constitution. For this reason as well, it is essential to resolve the present dispute concerning the Constitutional Tribunal as a matter of urgency, so that the Tribunal can fully play its role as a national rule-of-law mechanism. I wrote to Poland twice on these matters on 23 and 30 December last year. However, the replies we received then were not complete and not sufficient to dispel our concerns. The Rule of Law Framework allows us to assess the matter in a structured manner together with the Polish authorities. We should make use of the Rule of Law Framework in an open and constructive manner, in a spirit of cooperation, not of confrontation. We have just received, I think an hour or so ago, another letter in answer to the letter I sent last week and we will assess it, indeed, in a constructive and cooperative manner to see what the answers are to the questions we sent last week. Obviously, I cannot go into that already now, we need to assess it carefully, as we just received the letter an hour ago. I would like to stress firstly that we are at the beginning of the process under the Framework. The Framework has a preventive nature, and the start of a detailed, factual and legal assessment in no way implies any automatic move to decisions at later stages. That will depend purely on the facts – and answering us so quickly will help to stimulate that dialogue and to have a constructive dialogue with the Polish Government. We will engage in this dialogue in an impartial, evidence-based and cooperative way. It goes without saying that the Commission fully respects the sovereignty of the Republic of Poland, and carries out its duties in an objective and non-partisan manner, as for any other Member State in line with the duties imposed on the Commission by treaties, signed and ratified by sovereign states – the Members of the European Union. Finally, we will conduct our assessment in close cooperation with the Venice Commission of the Council of Europe. I welcome that, following my suggestion, the Polish Government has itself asked for an opinion of the Venice Commission on the reform of the Constitutional Tribunal. I want to repeat, this is the spirit in which we wrote to the Polish Government last week, and I have a feeling this is also the spirit in which the Polish Government has responded to our letter of last week. We will make a careful analysis of the response and then enter into further dialogue with the Polish Government to hopefully solve this issue shortly.

name: Beata Szydło
text: Prime Minister Polish. – Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for his excellent Dear President, I would like to begin by thanking mr Minister, i would like to thank you for your comments. Dear! Thank you very much for the fact that I can talk about Poland today in the European Parliament. I thank you for this invitation, for allowing, I hope, a substantive, good, substantive debate. For me, it is very important that today we can dispel your doubts, if any, about the changes that we are making in Poland. And we are introducing them because, as a result of the democratic elections held in October 2015, the Polish people in this democratic act of elections have decided that they want the changes that have been proposed by my ruling camp – by Law and Justice – to be implemented. This is the decision of Polish citizens. Thank you for speaking here today on behalf of the Polish Government, but above all on behalf of Polish citizens, for whom freedom, equality, justice and sovereignty are inalienable values. These are values that Poles have fought for for many years and which we value above all else. It is precisely freedom, sovereignty, equality and justice that are the values on which we set the development of our state. I am very keen for you, after my speech, to be convinced that Poland is part of a united Europe in the same dimension and meaning as the countries you represent are part of it.  Dear! It seems Polish to me that these voices, which we very often receive in Poland with pain, unjust voices, voices that judge Poland, the Polish state, but also the government in an unauthorized way, that they are only the result of misinformation or are given by those who simply have bad will, but I also firmly believe that they are in a minority, because we are , Europeans, we should build our community precisely on the basis of trust, respect for diversity and building within the framework of our diversity of unity, which is the European Union. We have taken up this challenge, we have taken it up, because we are dear to the values of security and unity, and we know perfectly well that only a united Europe, strong by the strength of its countries, is able to stand up to the challenges that we also face today, which we must all talk about together with an open visor.  Poles are open to supporting Europe in difficult decisions. Poles are open to supporting Europe in addressing these challenges. We are part of a united Europe. This is a huge value for us. The Polish story, which was also mentioned here, which Mr Henderson spoke about, for which I thank you very much, is a very difficult story. This is the story that meant our way to this day. Our fathers, our grandparents, shed blood for us today to enjoy freedom so that we can be part of an equal and united Europe, but also to shed blood for the freedom of other European nations. For many years, for decades, we have had to fight for the right to express our own opinions, to build our own statehood. We have won this and we will not be able to take it away from us, because this is an idea that a united Europe has taught us. We are Europeans. We are proud of that. Poles in the elections that took place last autumn chose the program with which we went to the elections – we, the representatives of today's ruling law and justice party. They have chosen a programme that is primarily aimed at those citizens who, today, after years of transformation, including participation in the European Union, are not the best in Poland. This may be strange for you, but Poland, although it is in the European Union, although it is a large country, still faces problems such as high youth unemployment and low wages for young people. Many Polish children still dream of the only warm meal at school. There are pensioners in Poland who spend half of their pension on medicines and very often have to make dramatic choices: whether to buy a prescription or pay their bills. Such a reality is also in Poland. Many Poles feel that they have been omitted from this process of transformation. Today we want to build a Poland as the European Union is – a Poland of equality, equal opportunities. We want Poland to develop even faster on this path to equal opportunities. We have a programme in which we have proposed solutions that are applied in many European countries. We have taken good patterns from individual Countries of the European Union, because we believe that we need to learn from those who have succeeded, who are able to do so, but we also know that many Polish citizens today feel that they must finally have created a level playing field and the programme that we are implementing is precisely such a programme. This election, which made us form a government today, the decision of our citizens obliged us to make good Changes. These good changes, which we agreed on in the elections with our voters, for which we agreed with the Poles. And from the beginning of our government's work, we have been doing this. We have realized these demands, which according to Poles should form the foundations and foundations of Polish development and the state. We are doing this lawfully, respecting the Constitution, respecting laws, and finally respecting the European Treaties, because I will repeat once again: we are part of the European Union, we have been, we are and will be part of Europe, of this developing Europe, of a Europe of equal opportunity. This is how we imagine Europe that Europe will respect all Europeans, care about the development of all the countries that build it. This is our future and we want to be an active member of such a European Union.  Poland has for centuries respected the rule of law and the rule of law. Yes, we are the country that first introduced the constitution in Europe and the constitution for Poles is holiness. And there has not been, ladies and gentlemen, any violation of the Constitution in Poland recently. I must therefore say that, although I am pleased to be able to present myself here today, I can present the position of Polish, I see no reason for us to devote so many words and so much time to Polish affairs, because It seems to me that many important, extremely important issues and problems that deserve to be tilted and our attention now exist in Europe.  But I'm here because I want to engage in the dialogue that was being talked about. I want to tell you about Poland, I want to clarify all the doubts, and I firmly believe that with the goodwill I will encounter here, we will all be able to come out after this debate in the belief that Poland is a strong, well-growing member of the European Union and that we are all proud of it.  Dear! There are two doubts that have been raised here: the Constitutional Court and the media, the media law. The Constitutional Court, ladies and gentlemen, is doing very well in Poland. Works. Even today, just a few hours ago, he made one of his decisions, he works, nothing bad happens. The amendments we have made to the Constitutional Tribunal – in the Law on the Constitutional Tribunal – are in line with european standards and do not differ in any way from those proposed by other countries of the European Union. We had to amend the Law on the Constitutional Tribunal, because in June 2015 the previous Sejm, the previous ruling coalition, adopted the Law on the Constitutional Tribunal, which, moreover, was challenged by the Constitutional Court on 3 December 2015 – it was ruled that it was partially unconstitutional. And this judgment of the Constitutional Court challenging the law adopted, I recall, by the previous Sejm, by the previous ruling coalition, and the numerous opinions of experts, ordered that these errors be corrected. In violation of the Constitution, the Judges of the Court were prematurely elected to take office after the new parliamentary elections. We had to fix this – 14 of the 15 judges were to be nominated by the outgoing ruling coalition, whereas the Veneto Commission, which I will refer to here, in its 1997 opinion, explicitly states that 'the system for the selection of judges of the Constitutional Court should be aimed at ensuring more democratic representation in its composition and that the ruling party should not be able to fill all the posts of its choice'. However, this has been done, even though the President-elect has also asked that such decisions not be taken during this transition period. The president's decision not to take the oath of office in violation of democratic standards allowed the new Sejm to adopt resolutions correcting these abuses. The adoption by the Sejm of resolutions cancelling elections made in breach of democratic standards and re-election of judges is the prerogative of the Sejm, and the Constitutional Court acknowledged on 7 January 2016 that it did not have the power to assess the constitutionality of those decisions. From a legal point of view, we have 15 sworn judges of the Court in Poland – exactly as many as the Constitution provides. The vast majority of judges of the Constitutional Tribunal were still elected by the previous parliamentary majority. Only 5 out of 15 judges are those elected by a parliamentary majority supporting my government.  Law and Justice has never sought to dominate the Court. Moreover, we never wanted a majority in the Court. Our only aim was to ensure balance. I would also like to state to you that we agree that 8 out of 15 judges should be appointed by the opposition. This is a positive change in the approach to the perception of the rights of the opposition, which radically distinguishes us from our predecessors. We respect the opposition and its rights. We want dialogue, we want to solve issues that are important Polish the Polish people and for the Poles.  In order to ensure a pluralistic the nature of the Court's decision, the current Parliament has decided that, as in many other EU countries, the Court should rule in principle in full. This should not be in doubt. This is also the case in some countries of the European Union, where the Court must always sit in full. In addition, which raises doubts among some, it was considered that decisions should be taken by a qualified two-thirds majority. As decisions taken by the Constitutional Court de facto determine the shape of constitutional rules, it was considered that they should be taken by the same majority as the National Assembly adopts the Constitution.  In many countries, judges of the Constitutional Court are elected by a two-thirds majority. There are countries in Europe where some of the cases before the Constitutional Court require a two-thirds majority. Moreover, you know this very well, because many of you represent these countries. It is also worth stressing that this requirement will encourage judges to seek compromises and give their decisions a more pluralistic and inclusive character.  Finally, it is necessary to clarify the misunderstandings that have arised around the implementation of the judgments of the Constitutional Tribunal last December. It is worth pointing out clearly that the ongoing polemic around the Court is political rather than legal. The Constitutional Court is a court of law, not a court of facts. It assesses the constitutionality of the rules of law and therefore decides whether the contested rule will continue to apply. Unlike ordinary courts, however, the Constitutional Court does not assess specific actions. The standards which the Court declared unconstitutional in December have already applied and will no longer apply. They have been definitively eliminated from the legal system and this is the only legal consequence of these judgments. So there is no need to do them in any additional way.  However, I would also like to stress once again to you that the dispute over the Court now has a political rather than a substantive dimension in Poland and, as such, in my opinion, should be resolved on the basis of an agreement and political compromise in Poland. This is an internal matter Polish and that is why we should resolve this matter ourselves. I am so willing and will talk to the opposition to accept the solutions we have proposed.  Dear! As regards changes in the public media, they have been introduced by a parliamentary majority and do not in any way violate European standards for public service broadcasters.  Moreover, the changes we have started are an attempt to restore the authentic nature of apoliticality and impartiality to the public media in Poland. To date, many communities in Poland have argued that impartiality, neutrality and objectivity are not preserved. In our view, the public media requires changes that restore pluralism and equal access to all parties and introduce standards of neutrality and integrity. That's the only goal of the changes we're making. Three weeks ago, Polish parliament passed an amendment to the Broadcasting Act, which is the first stage in the reform of the public media. The Association of Polish Journalists called for reform at its extraordinary congress. In the first stage of the reform, we have sorted out the issues of ownership supervision of public media, which until now has not only been incompatible with European standards, but has also proved inefficient, leading to the financial collapse of the public media.  It was therefore necessary to separate the functions of the media market regulator, the National Broadcasting Council, from the implementation of the treasury's own powers, expressed in the appointment of the boards of media market operators. The need for such a model is clearly stated in the opinion of the 2010 Venetian Commission. The government is currently working on another amendment to the Broadcasting Act, which aims to give a new organisational form to public service broadcasters and provide a stable basis for their funding. In the case of changes made in the public media, we are following the solutions that are applied in many Countries of the European Union.  Dear! The Government of the Republic of Poland is open to dialogue and debate. We want to build an agreement in Poland with all parliamentary clubs, both opposition clubs and with those clubs that today support the Polish government in making good changes for Polish. We are open to dialogue and conversation, we are open to solving Polish problems together. I think it is important for all of us to feel the support of the European Union in these activities, that we feel that Poland, as a free and sovereign member of the European Union, can always count on support and that decisions our community, our sovereignty, remains. Dear! I am ready to answer all your questions. I am ready to provide all the information, as are all the representatives of my government. Poland is a beautiful country, Poles are a proud nation. We want to be the leader of the European Union. These are our dreams, these are the dreams of Poles. We have waited too long to enjoy freedom, justice and sovereignty, so that today we can lose these values that are important to us. This is priceless for us, for all Poles.  Thank you very much for listening to me. I firmly believe that my explanations will present you with a new quality of this information, which you have obtained about Poland. I firmly believe that it is in dialogue and agreement that we will work together to build a good future for the European Union.

name: Esteban González Pons
text: PPE Group. – Mr President, Madam Prime Minister, the Chairman of my group, Manfred Weber, is German. That is why, with all due respect, he has decided to give me, as vice-president, his turn, so that no one uses nationality as an excuse and eludes his responsibility. Madam Prime Minister, the second largest delegation of my parliamentary group is Polish. But today, with all due respect, a Polish man will not deliver our main speech, so that no one is excused for domestic policy reasons and eludes his responsibility. Madam Prime Minister, it is not normal for us in Europe to take precautions so that words do not become political weapons. No, it's not normal. A Spaniard, a Spaniard from the People's Party, is speaking to him, but in my place could be any other Member of my group, because we all think so. Europe is, first and for all, a set of democratic values and then a market. I repeat: first, a community of values and, only after, a market. That is why, on behalf of all of us, I would like to be certain that you think so: that Europe is not Brussels, that Europe is not Berlin, that Europe is not Paris, that Europe is five hundred million people that we want to live together. The Polish people have fought all dictatorships and defeated them. First, against Nazism, and the Europeans were with Poland. Then, against communism, and the Europeans were with Poland. Now all Europeans are fighting terrorism together. But authoritarianism doesn't always come from outside. Authoritarianism does not understand times or places. Its sole purpose is to end our system of values, our rights and our freedoms. The Poles know, unfortunately as well as the Spaniards, as the Portuguese, as the Italians, as the Germans, as the Romanians, as the Slovenians, as the French or as the Greeks that the worst of authoritarianism has always come from within. That the destruction of the judiciary and the control of the media can be a principle to end democracy. The problem is not Poland. The problem is authoritarianism, reproduced where it is reproduced. The mistakes of the past, even the most heinous and abominable, are there not to repeat them, not to revive them every day. The Europe of which we are all a part is based on reconciliation, not resentment. We are the Europe of respect and human dignity, the Europe founded on Roman law and Christian morality, the Europe that recognizes no more empire than the rule of law. That's what we're discussing here today. We want to clarify whether there is a possibility that any of these values could be in danger. No one here comes to prejudge or condemn. We come to discuss facts and actions and this, Madam Prime Minister, is the time to clear up the misunderstandings, if necessary. No one wants to apply to the Polish Government a pre-trial conviction, let alone the people's parliamentary group. Polish members of the Popular Parliamentary Group would never consent to this. We therefore look forward to the results of this dialogue with the Commission and I encourage the Commissioners to act with the same prudence and restraint with which they have done so far. On matters of internal order, Madam Prime Minister, you have every legitimacy to develop your government programme as you see fit. You'll be judged by Polish voters when the time comes. But as far as we all are concerned, such as the defence of the rule of law, friends should not deceive us. Good partners, with all due respect, must look at each other face to face and we must tell each other the truth. As we have told ourselves the truth with the Greek Government. As we are telling each other the truth with the British Government. So, we hope that today, here, you and we will tell each other the truth and recognize things as they are. Madam Prime Minister, this is not about the law. It's about the values. You, like any legitimate government, can change the law. But neither you nor any legitimate government can change the values. That's never, Madam Prime Minister. (Applause)

name: Gianni Pittella
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Democratic Socialists are undoubtedly on the side of the thousands of Poles who have marched for the rule of law and democracy in recent weeks. Here, Prime Minister, we appreciate the tone of your speech. We do not want to put your country on trial, nor do we want to try to overturn a democratically achieved outcome in your nation. You have every right and a duty to govern, in full autonomy of choices, but with respect for European values, principles and law. Poland is one of the pillars of the Union in its history and vocation, especially in its fight against the totalitarianism of the twentieth century. The Polish people are an example to all of us. The measures taken by your government, Prime Minister, deny this history of freedom. An independent constitutional court and the free media are the prerequisites for the rule of law. We therefore considered the European Commission's decision to be right and timely, and we would particularly like to thank Vice-President Timmermans. The European Union is not a marriage of convenience and not even a scapegoat. The Union is first and foremost a community of values, freedoms and democracy. Europe needs a free and strong Poland: think, Prime Minister, about the measures you have taken in a spirit of dialogue and confrontation, as Vice-President Timmermans said a moment ago. Poland is a great country, we will not abandon it, you will not take it down a path that is not in line with its history and tradition!

name: Syed Kamall
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, as we assembled here this afternoon I could sense MEPs chomping at the bit to lay into the Polish Government. But before you unleash a volley of words, let me make a plea for everyone to take a step back, to allow the European Commission and the Venice Commission of the Council of Europe to work with the Polish Government to address the concerns that have been expressed. Having spoken to Polish MEPs, ministers and the Prime Minister earlier today, it is clear that they have no intention of undermining pluralism and the rule of law.  When the last government passed a law to stuff the Constitutional Court with their nominees before they left office, why is it that the Commission did not open an investigation, or MEPs here did not complain? Why the sudden complaints when the new government seeks to appoint only five out of 15 judges on a constitutional court? We should welcome the constructive talks that President Duda has held with the court’s president. We should welcome the Polish Government inviting the Venice Commission to give its opinion. We should welcome the new government’s separation between the regulator and the broadcaster.  But when the new government tries to bring its practices in line with other countries and EU law, it is accused of political interference in the media. Now when I worked on the Audiovisual Media Services Directive, I was shocked by the number of MEPs from one large Member State who sat on the boards of public broadcasters and who were interfering in legislation, ignoring the obvious conflict of interest. In this Chamber, there are former national politicians who would phone editors of newspapers, or TV stations, complaining and leading some of them to be sacked. So, if you decide to gang up today on the democratically elected government of Poland, you would also be pointing fingers at the people who voted for that government. And do not be surprised if the Polish people respond by electing more Eurosceptic politicians, as in Hungary, Italy and France. So in this climate, I would appeal everyone to be careful about their choice of words.  When Mr Berlusconi came to this Parliament and made comments linking Mr Schulz to Germany’s National Socialist past, many here were offended. So I ask you to consider your reaction when a German politician goes on the media to talk about elements of a coup in Poland and compares the Polish Government to Vladimir Putin. You must realise just how offensive this is to the Polish people, who had to endure Russian imperialism, who had to endure German National Socialism, and who had to endure Soviet Socialism.  So let us, in this House, focus on the real crises facing the EU: migration, the Eurozone and low growth. And let us allow the Polish Government to work constructively with the European Commission and the Venice Commission to reach conclusions based on facts and fairness. Given the historic suffering of the Polish people at the hands of tyranny, and their noble fight for liberation from their oppressors, I have no doubt that the new Polish Government will cooperate with all those who wish to cooperate with them to ensure that Poland reinforces the freedom, the pluralism and the democracy for which the Polish people fought for so long.  (Applause)

name: Guy Verhofstadt
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, I would like to thank the Prime Minister for her presence and for the tone that she has used. I am going to try to follow your path and your example on the tone, Prime Minister – not always easy for me. You and your party won the elections, and you and your party got a strong mandate to lead your country. We respect this, and we have to respect this.  In fact, as a Liberal Democrat, I may not like all of your policies, but they are not our policies. That is your responsibility. This is how it works in a real democracy: on the basis of a broad majority. It is your right to reshape the media landscape, to reform the civil service. I can tell you that when I was Prime Minister, I did similar things myself. But that is not the point here. What makes us concerned and alarms most Members here in the House, and what a democrat never does, is the use or abuse of a huge majority to dismantle the checks and balances in the country. That does not happen. Why?  Because this is at the core of European democracy. It is a system of checks and balances that makes it possible to enact laws when these laws are in contradiction with the Polish Constitution. I think that the legislation on the Constitutional Tribunal, which your majority rushed through the Parliament – I think it was on Christmas Day – does exactly this. It eliminates, it paralyses, in fact, the Constitutional Court, and I have to tell you that this was not announced in the manifesto of your party before the elections. It is not – and I am going to be very precise – the composition or the nominations (Mr Kamall) that will be the problem; it is not the quorum, which you have increased, that will be the problem; it is not the two-thirds majority that you impose that is the problem; it is not even the enforced chronological order of cases that is now introduced as a new rule. Some of the Member States – you said it yourself – also have some of these rules, but they do not have them all together. That is precisely the point. It is the combination of all four elements that definitely paralysed the courts and made it impossible for them to do their work. I will tell you very clearly: it is fair enough, Mr Kamall, that the Polish Government has rectified the mistake made by the previous majority. But you do not rectify it by then paralysing this Constitutional Court. From your tone, it seems that you feel yourself that there is a problem. I feel it in your voice, and that is why you followed the advice of Mr Timmermans to ask for the opinion of the Venice Commission, which is a good thing. But let me say one thing, it would be a very bad thing if we brought Poland eastwards to another system.  (Jeers from the Chamber.) It is true, Mr Kamall, I have once used the word ‘Putin’,  and I know that Mr Kaczyński does not like Putin or Russia, and neither do I. He is not on the blacklist, but I am. So with these policies Mr Kaczyński is helping Mr Putin, because the inconvenient truth here is that Mr Putin does not like European unity. He has an obsession with destroying European unity, and what is happening in Poland could help him in his course. Never forget, Mr Prime Minister, history has proven that Polish unity and strength go hand-in-hand with European unity and strength, and vice-versa. But I have, in fact, no doubt and I have faith. I think there is no problem, because there are the Polish people and the Polish citizens. Knowing the Polish people, who gave rise to Solidarność, they fought against repression; they fought for their freedom, for democracy, for the freedom of religion and for the rule of law. All this they did. Well, I know that the Polish people will never accept giving up their democracy. So my plea to you, Prime Minister, is this: I would like to encourage you not so much to listen to me or to us, but to listen to the majority of your own citizens who want their country to remain in the world community of democracies in the future.

name: Gabriele Zimmer
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, Prime Minister Szydeo, I would like to thank the Rapporteur on the work she has done on this Thank you for coming here to the European Parliament today to ask yourself critical questions. As head of government, you are, of course, obliged and also the right to perform constitutional tasks and powers. No one questions that at all. It has already been said here that respect for human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law and also respect for human rights are among the fundamental principles of the EU. But that requires independent courts and also independent media. That is precisely the question we are asking you. It is a question, and I therefore think it is good that you have agreed to seek an opinion from the Venice Commission. I am sure that we will continue to discuss this further. That is why we also welcome the fact that the Commission has opened an investigation. A test procedure!
