And this test procedure, which is being applied for the first time because it did not exist in this form before, should, in principle, be applied every time doubts or questions arise in a Member State, irrespective of the Member State and regardless of the political constellations in the Member State. This must be our way of dealing with each other in a very objective and direct structural dialogue, respecting each other. It is not a question of the democratic legitimacy of the Polish Government, but of the rule of law of action. That is why we want to stay in the discussion with each other. The problems in Poland , and I would like to draw attention to this, have not fallen from the sky. Neoliberal and radical market structural reforms, which have already been a precondition for EU accession, have not brought development and prosperity for all. Disappointment, frustration and socially excluded were ignored. In doing so, however, many people in Poland and in other Eastern European countries have not primarily discussed the merits of the European Union, namely the question of values, the question of democracy, freedom, equality, but above all perceived the European Union as the subject that is partly responsible for the social divisions in society. I think that is something that needs to be discussed. You, too, cannot say with your government today: 'We have only now been elected, we are eliminating what has been done before'. There was also a government in which the PIS was represented before, and there was previously a Liberal government in which, for example, the issue of poverty reduction was not discussed at all. In this respect, I believe that there must be no double standards in the EU, that rights, fundamental rights and human rights apply to all. That is why I would also like to ask you, Mrs Szydeo, to say earlier that Poland wants to be a champion within the European Union. I would be very much in favour, I do not need German leadership. I would like to see each other deal with each other, and I believe that the Countries of Eastern Europe, Central European countries that joined in 2004, still have a great deal to do, but also have a great deal to contribute. Perhaps we have made huge mistakes within the EU in this accession process and in the subsequent process. My request would be: if you say you want to be a champion, please ask yourself the question of migration! It is not acceptable for Poland to say exactly '400 this year' – it cannot be, please not! That is one of the key issues. A second question, and a second request, is one more: I think one thing would also be important. Poland has an opt-out on the Charter of Fundamental Rights. Would it not be a good sign now, a really strong sign, if you lifted this opt-out and thereby allow Polish citizens to enjoy the full benefits of the European Charter of Fundamental Rights?

name: Rebecca Harms
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Madam Prime Minister, I would like to thank the Rapporteur on the work she has done on this You have probably already understood this, the debate here today revolves around, on the one hand, concerns about what is happening in Poland, about the rule of law in Poland. But behind this debate, you will certainly also feel the concerns about the European Union as a whole. Non-functioning rule of law, no respect for the rule of law, that would mean that little is possible in the EU. The internal market, all European legislation, the guarantee of fundamental freedoms, nothing will be possible in Europe if we do not maintain respect for the rule of law. I think it is right that you have reminded us once again of the importance and role of the Polish nation in the European Union, especially for the becoming of the European Union as it is today. As a German European politician, I would like to expressly contradict all the voices that have been heard in recent weeks asking – on the occasion of the debate on your government's legislation – whether it was at all right to admit the Poles and the other Eastern and Central European states into the EU? Were they ripe for it? I take a completely different view on this and I know very well that we owe this struggle of the Poles, which in my personal time-calculation began in my personal time in my life, that we owe this struggle of the Poles not only freedom and democracy for Poland, but a tremendous gain for democracy, stability and security throughout the European Union. But because I appreciate and appreciate this so much, it is so difficult for me to imagine that all that I have heard about developments in Warsaw since you took over the government is true, not from sharpeners, but from Polish citizens who tell us this. These are not just partisan rivals of yours. In this context, I would like to expressly welcome Mateusz Kijowski, who travelled to Strasbourg today for KOD and who also represents an important position for the further debate. I think that Guy Verhofstadt has correctly described the problems in the debate on the rule of law. It's not just about personnel decisions. It is about the impression that a government majority is resorting to a diktat and is no longer seeking the conflict between the government and the opposition. Overnight, you made certain decisions that are usually discussed for longer.  My group is strongly in favour of using this rule of law mechanism, which we have given ourselves from experience with Hungary, and of examining it. However, we would like to decide on the consequences at the end of the debate and not, as some German colleagues have done, discuss sanctions now.  What also concerns us is the question of possible selective action. As a Green Group, we have always believed that we need instruments to examine the rule of law and to try to guarantee that, because that holds the European Union together at its core. But what we do not like is the impression that party political interests sometimes protect if we had to do more to violate the rule of law. That is why we would like to see the debate on the Copenhagen Commission, a consultative commission for the European Commission that is gearing up against selectivity, continue. Thank you for your attention.

name: Robert Jarosław Iwaszkiewicz
text: On behalf of the EFDD Group. – Prime Minister, i would like to thank you very much for your Dear! As the Polish mep speaking in this debate, I would like to stress firmly that Polish affairs should be resolved in Poland and by Poles. (applause) Therefore, I regret that a few people can not come to terms with losing and woefully reporting on their country. This debate is unnecessary, the reasons for convening it are unclear and the legal basis is questionable – as the Prime Minister mentioned in her speech. Against the odds, however, there will be benefits to this debate. Eurosceptic sentiment is rising in Europe. The Italians, together with the Socialist Prime Minister, Germany and Hungary, are increasingly against EU politicians and institutions that do not deal with what they have been set up for.  We Poles have very bad experiences when it comes to the interference of foreign politicians in our affairs. When, more than two hundred years ago, Russia, Prussia and Austria – after a few slings – were concerned about the state of Polish democracy, it ended with three partitions of Polish and the loss of independence for a hundred and twenty-five years. In the last century, in turn, we barely got out of the communist system, where Soviet commissioners rushed to help. Now it appears that European Commissioners are assisting with fraternal help. For Europe, it is best and safest when Polish problems are dealt with exclusively by Poles themselves. (applause)

name: Michał Marusik
text: On behalf of the ENF Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Dear Prime Minister, i would like to thank you for your excellent work. Dear! Thank you, Mr Jarku, because we are very close in the way we think. I am speaking as a member of the Europe of Nations and Freedom group, but also as a Pole. As a Pole, I am not worried that foreign competition is criticizing us, Poland. This, after all, may mean that the Polish authorities have taken some decisions as to whether any action is clearly in line with the Polish national interest and the Polish national interest, so I should rather enjoy it. I am also not particularly worried about the positive and negative opinions that are expressed in this House, because they do not affect the situation in Poland – there we solve our problems. The problem, however, is the very fact that this debate is taking place here. This is europe's problem, because this debate is an ostentatious manifestation of the mixing of external factors in the internal affairs of sovereign states – and this is the disease of the European Union. This debate says nothing, because it cannot say anything about the political health of Polish. This debate, on the other hand, speaks very clearly and very much of the disastrous political situation of the European Union as a political project. It is an escape from all the real problems that the European Union in this form is unable to solve. So, speaking as a member of the Europe of Nations and Freedom political group, I would like to stress to you, and I urge you to finally point out that this project is exhausted, that it is only running by the force of a certain inertion. If Europe is to recover, if it is to develop and provide us with security, a new formula for the coexistence of European, sovereign and independent states must be developed – and this is our task, and we owe it to our homelands and our compatriots. (applause)

name: Janusz Korwin-Mikke (NI).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I am not a Democrat. I hate democracy, I despise democracy, but you are democrats. Then acknowledge that the people of Polish, legally and democratically, chose PiS. You wanted democracy, well, you have it. Democracy is the tyranny of the majority, so PiS, with a majority behind it, will do whatever it wants. If you think that PiS is a very bad party – I agree with that – think about how bad previous governments must have been, what a huge amount of corruption, thievery, contempt for man and suppression of freedom of expression, as I personally experience, that the tormented people chose PiS as the only party that hoped that the previous rulers would be able Polish to be put in prison, because that is where their place is. More besides, I believe that the European Union must be destroyed.

name: Milan Zver (PPE).
text: – Dear Prime Minister. When we 70 000 people did not like this when we were accepting systemic risks in the Member States two years ago. I'm sure we did the right thing. This is not just a question of Poland, but much more, it is about respecting the rule of law in general, which is a central European value. The use of the new Mechanism of the European Commission would, in my view, be even more justified than poland elsewhere, including in my Slovenia, to be honest.  It is well known that the Slovenian judiciary functions badly. According to a report by the European Court of Human Rights, Slovenia comes first after its violations and, according to Eurostat, the judiciary in Slovenia enjoys the lowest reputation.  It is not surprising, therefore, given some of the facts which point to political abuse of the work of the courts. For seven years, the two-time Prime Minister and Leader of the Slovenian Opposition, Janez Janša, was to be ousted in the courts and imprisoned for three weeks before parliamentary elections without any proof. It is true that later the Constitutional Court overturned all charges and convictions, but the political consequences remained.  Political abuse is also reflected in the recent month, in December, police raided the premises of the largest opposition SDS party and wanted to seize a server containing the electronic correspondence of thousands and thousands of members from the past 15 years. There's a lot more stories like that. This is why the European Commission has so far failed to respond to the problems with which, to the point of the eclatant violations of human rights, which we have also pointed out, and which have already been caused by people who have already violated human rights in the previous system. That is why Slovenia needs, much more than Poland, this kind of help on its way to the full rule of law.

name: Tanja Fajon (S&D).
text: – It is also not my intention today to criticise Poland or the Polish people, on the contrary, in the last 30 years Poland has been an inspiration to millions of Europeans as a story of economic and political success. And today she is an indispensable member of the Union.  This has not happened in itself, it is the result of strong and independent institutions and also critical media. Yet when the fundamental values of society are under threat, it is our duty to draw attention to this. The latest proposals by the Polish Government are of great concern. As a former journalist, I am particularly concerned about the new public media law, which is a step backwards in securing independence. Unfortunately.  I am surprised, Madam Prime Minister, that you are saying otherwise, despite very serious warnings from a range of media organisations. And you will only convince us if the next steps of this thorough reform of the public media introduce the measures and balances necessary to guarantee freedom and pluralism, and not the opposite.  I welcome the Commission's decision to examine the effects of legislative changes through the dialogue that is necessary for any search for solutions. The Commission should also not be afraid to take measures if the rule of law is at risk, be it in Warsaw, Budapest, Bratislava, Slovenia or any other Member State of the Union.

name: Ryszard Antoni Legutko (ECR).
text: – Prime Minister, i would like to thank you very much for your Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking I would like to raise four points. The first is the matter of language. I am pleased to note the tone and language that we are discussing today during this debate. It is a tone so strong and persuasive that even the honourable colleague Verhofstadt has adapted to it, which I am very pleased about. I also wanted to say, to express my hope, that this language will be maintained, because what we have had to deal with so far has been an unprecedented linguistic aggression that took place on the Polish government before this government was formed, which is, however, a kind of world record. There were statements that destroyed language and the ability to communicate. If it is said that a coup has been carried out in Poland, it means that whoever says it does not understand the meaning of the words he uses, or specifically changes that meaning. (applause) The second point is the facts. Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. I read the document that came after the College of Commissioners meeting, and that is a bad document. My question is, where does the Commission get information about the facts? Who provides this information to you, who does legal analysis? The description of the facts leaves much to be desired, but what surprises me the most is that the information came from representatives of the Polish government earlier. There is no trace of this information, as if you had thrown it all in the trash. Where do you get your information from then? From the media? How does this arise? How can such a document be created on the basis of which a decision is taken? (applause)  Gentlemen, admit that you are with the facts on the bakier – that is the truth. The third point That I wanted to talk about is the issue of double standards. This is, unfortunately, a chronic, deep and potentially fatal disease in the European Union. President Pittella and President Harms have just talked about demonstrations, how their hearts are with these demonstrators. Ladies and about, over the last eight years there have been many more demonstrations in Poland. Somehow your hearts did not bleed, I have not heard in this Room that Mrs Harms, Mr Pittella or someone else will stand with these crowds of people.  (applause) Come on they were here, they were in Strasbourg, they were in Brussels right in front of parliament. Did any of you go out, talk about what they're all about, maybe it's some people who have something important to say? I ask you, for the last eight years in Poland, and please treat this as important, I would say even the key information, we have had to deal with something like a one-party state in Poland. It was a one-party state, that is, one party controlled virtually all the institutions.  (applause) I hear suddenly here today from you that this is not about personnel matters. If my party had inserted fourteen judges into the 15-member Constitutional Court, hell would have broken out in this House. And I hear here that nothing happened, because these are personnel matters.  (applause) Where were you when journalists were kicked out of the public media en masse? All! You heard exactly what you heard. All but one has been removed. Very fast. And what, where was there any reaction? There was no reaction. Unfortunately, these double standards show that there are more equal countries in the European Union and less equal countries. There are more equal parties and less equal parties. If this continues in this way, unfortunately we will not fall victim to it here, only the European Union will fall victim. By acting in this way, you are acting against the European Union. And the last thing is to exceed competences. Mr President, Commissioner, you know perfectly well that the instrument you have used is a legally suspect instrument. The Council's legal services have criticised it in principle, it has no good justification in the Treaties, some say that there is no justification in the Treaties at all. You here in Parliament are planning to pass a resolution. I hear that there is going to be an examination of the facts, so the resolution is to be made before the facts are examined, that is, you already know exactly what the problem is. Why then investigate the facts? In other words, this whole action, as well as the construction, seems to me not only – and you have said this – not only an excess of competence, because the European Commission will not, after all, say which majority is to be decided by the constitutional court in Poland, but it is clear from your words that this is to be a kind of precedent. You want to take over the kind of competence that you do not have, and by the facts made to be able to act in this way, I would say not entirely legal, even in the future – and that is also very bad. (applause)

name: Sophia in ‘t Veld (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, I would like to welcome the Prime Minister and both supporters and opponents of the government. This shows that the European Parliament is the arena for a debate about our shared values. This is not about interfering in national matters or attacking one country or another. This is about standing up for the core values of the European project.  The Polish Government, with the majority that it has won, has the responsibility to maximise the space for opposition and criticism, not minimise it. You have to strengthen checks and balances and not weaken them. I have listened to you very carefully, Madam Prime Minister, but I am not fully reassured when I hear your party leader taking Mr Orbán as an example, who in turn takes Mr Putin as an example. I do feel that the European Commission initiative is justified, but it does seem arbitrary and there are accusations of party politics. Why Poland, not Hungary, or indeed why no questions about the state of emergency in France? The debate here shows that there is a need for an EU-wide mechanism that is based on objective and transparent criteria to assess all the Member States and EU institutions in the same way. I see Mr Timmermans smiling because he knows that we are elaborating such a mechanism here in Parliament. I would be delighted, Mr Timmermans and Mr Koenders, if the Council and Commission would take up the invitation of the European Parliament and elaborate such a mechanism for the whole of the European Union together.

name: Barbara Spinelli (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I share the concern of many of my fellow Members. The neonationalism of your government, Mrs Szydlo, the measures that many Poles believe limit the powers of the Constitutional Court and the media: all this contradicts the principles of the European project. At the same time, I would like to remind you of this: if Poland has voted for such a critical government of the Union, it is because the Union itself, through its austerity policies, has created very serious inequalities and social resentment in that country that only the right has been able to intercept. Social justice is also a European law. Finally, I would ask you not to use different criteria in Hungary, Poland, or yesterday in Italy. Governments must be treated in the same way. Poland does not have to pay a higher price just because the ruling party is part of a less powerful group than the People's Party.

name: Judith Sargentini (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President, let there be no doubt that the Greens are concerned about the legislative changes that have been made by the Polish Government about the anti-democratic tendencies. But I would also like to talk here, in the presence of the Dutch Foreign Minister, about manners with our neighbours, about organising that mutual trust that Commissioner Timmermans was talking about.  There is Nord Stream, the gas pipeline from Russia to Germany and the Netherlands. Poland is ignored and Poland's fear of Russia is being put aside. That is unwise politics, Mr Koenders. And so there was geert Wilders' Poland hotline. This has been strongly debated in this House. Prime Minister Rutte, the Dutch Prime Minister, did not want to distance himself from that hotline. The Prime Minister has been invited to come here and explain this. He refused.  This was not appreciated by Central and Eastern European countries. They felt scoured because the Dutch government remained silent. That doesn't lead to trust, Minister! Mr President, we in Europe must take the measure, read the lesson. But only then will we be successful if we are willing to recognise each other's feelings and act accordingly.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD).
text: – Ladies and gentlemen, we are facing a scandalous situation here where the European Union has initiated proceedings against Poland, which is only to end with the withdrawal of voting rights. What terrible has Poland done? That he's introducing a two-thirds quorum for constitutional court decisions? That the new government is pursuing its vision for the public media? For something that exists and what is commonly done in many other countries of the European Union? This is, of course, ridiculous and an excuse. What is wrong with the European Commission? That a party that does not love the current form of the European Union has won. That he wants to oppose the unfair dictation of migration quotas, I think that is the real reason. In my opinion, this is nothing more than blatant interference in the affairs of a sovereign country. In 1963, In besieged West Berlin, John Fitzgerald Kennedy said the famous line: "Ich bin ein Berliner." Today we need to stand by Poland, which is being unfairly attacked by the European Commission, and therefore let me finish as a proud, free citizen: 'I am Polaki.'

name: Jean-Luc Schaffhauser (ENF).
text: Mr President, Madam Prime Minister, ladies and gentlemen, Mr Schulz has told us about a coup d'etat, and even a so-called 'putinisation' of Polish politics. Oh there! Yes, the PiS is a popular party. The attack on today's Poland is an attack on a European system against democracy and against the peoples who have chosen sovereignty, freedom and independence in solidarity. Peoples who still believe in the Christian roots of humanism, and whose humanism is not the fabrication of a new European order, supreme disorder. Yes, Poland is a people of resistance to whom we owe the fall of the wall. Yes, Poland, and its people, resist, because it is conservative, it has ancient and true values: the family composed of a father and a mother, respect for life; she believes in truth, in the law, in justice. It is Catholic, not liberal in the hands of sects controlling society through finance and the media.  Colleagues, the European system is bankrupt. Its democracy is a dictatorship that forces peoples to revus whenever they say no to a treaty or simply ignores the vote against the European constitution, for example. The permanent coup is the European system. Poland, Hungary, Slovakia, the Czech Republic, the countries friendly to the Velvet Revolution, which I had gathered before the fall of the wall, are now resisting this dictatorship ready to attack, destabilize, to remove any government that does not work for the foreign powers that govern here and seek to govern the peoples of Europe.  The Alsatian that I am also resists against German arrogance. We, the patriotic French, can no longer stand, together with the Poles, that one country - Germany - decides the economy of the euro zone, immigration and the conformity of democracy to the criteria of the new European Reich. I ask this house to regain its common sense. Yes, Poland is under attack because there is a crime of social, human and Christian conservatism. Believe me, this is just the beginning. The revolt of the peoples is launched, it will sweep you away and that is what you deserve. It's about time.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: I am sorry to have to repeat that now. Ladies and gentlemen in the stands. This is strictly prohibited in our Rules of Procedure.  I would therefore be grateful if you would stop applauding. We are hospitable here. But in the Polish Parliament, you would not be money-defunding for five minutes if you behaved in this way. That is why I am now asking you once again to refrain from doing so.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (NI).
text: Mr President, Prime Minister, ladies and gentlemen, when I hear Mrs Harms or Mr Verhofstadt, I think that it is not Poland that has a problem with the rule of law and democracy, but the European institutions. When I hear the European Commission talk about Poland's so-called problem, I think that this Commission has a problem with the facts and with the realities. Did she watch the time in Polish politics before the PiS election? Did she look at the constitution of the Constitutional Court before the Election of the PiS? Do you think that the Polish people, who fought so hard for their freedom, would be willing to sacrifice it like this? I was recently reading the interview with a Polish political scientist, Piotr Kazi-ski, who is not particularly known for being close to the "Right and Justice" party and who himself asserts that there is absolutely no fascinate drift in Poland.  I would like to point out, however, that in my country- France - the members of the Constitutional Council, directly, like the leaders of the public audiovisual service, indirectly, are also appointed by the presidents of the Republic, the senate and the national assembly, which could be interpreted as a form of guardianship of power. It is therefore clear, ladies and gentlemen, that the Commission is using false pretenses to destabilise a democratically elected government. And so I am today, I say, Polish, whole-heartedly with the Polish people to uphold freedom... (The President withdraws the floor from the speaker)

name: Jan Olbrycht (PPE).
text: – Dear Prime Minister, I would like to thank you for your excellent work. Dear! Poland is our common good – the good of all Poles – and we must take care of it. We are proud of our country and the actions of Poles who have been role modeled on the European stage in recent years, although in many cases they differed on the lines of action proposed by other countries. Today we are sorry that Poland is becoming the subject of public debate in Europe. This is the first time in the history of our membership of the Union. We hope for the last time.  The Prime Minister knows very well that we did not initiate or want to organise this debate in the European Parliament. This debate, whatever the outcome, will unfortunately affect the image of Polish on the international stage. We know that you won the last parliamentary elections in Poland. We do not question the outcome of democratic elections or the right to make changes resulting from different political agendas. Very often you say in the country that the winner takes everything. If you think so, it is clear that this means that the winner not only takes control of state institutions, positions, but is also entirely responsible for changes made in the rule of law, if there are no situations of threats here, as you know that this is our view, and the winner also takes responsibility for the image of Polish in Europe and in the world. It also takes responsibility for this debate. Poles and Poland do not deserve actions that cause such controversy. We are very sorry for this.

name: Josef Weidenholzer (S&D).
text: Mr President, Prime Minister, I would like to thank the President-in-Chief for the work she has I welcome this debate today, that it is being conducted, that it is being conducted in a timely manner and that it is being conducted in a differentiated and objective manner. It is not a question of prejudging Poland – we do not want Poland bashing. Poland is an important country that has shaped European history and identity. The people of Poland have made arguably the most important contribution to overcoming the Communist dictatorship. Europe without Poland would be a torso.  That is why it does not matter what is happening in Poland. We respect the vote of the Polish people, but we are concerned when the first measures taken by the new government have caused fears among large sections of the population. The change of power is the principle of democracy. It must not lead to the rules being changed in such a way that it will no longer be possible in the future. Many people in Poland have this fear. The government's actions in the judicial and media sectors have fuelled this fear.  Respect for the inferior, for minorities, is also a principle of democracy. Here, too, there are many complaints and complaints in this direction. Poland has given us the institution of the Round Table. I would also like to remind the government that dialogue is an important value. It is important and positive that we are having this debate here in order to clarify the situation and that there is also an opportunity to take unequivocal action. The debate should be open and direct, fair and objective. Then Poland wins and then Europe wins.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the First of all, Prime Minister, I respect the fact that you are also personally confronting this sometimes grotesque inquisition. Mr Weidenholzer, you have just rightly pointed out that there should be no pre-judgment here. I just have to ask the President of this House what it is like to think that Poland is a Putin-style democracy. Is this not a prejudgment? Mr Schulz, I have galloped on a lot in my life, and I have always made sure that, if I was caught in a mistake, I have apologised for it. Do you not think that now and today is the opportunity to apologise for this? (Applause) Professor Legutko has pointed out that we have to establish a double standard here. I agree with this, and I would like to present to you a few other examples of double standards. I believe that the Commission should first of all deal with the violations of the law by the European institutions or those of the large countries, rather than with Poland. Let me give you three examples: the numerous breaches of the Maastricht Treaty by the Eurogroup, or the irregular purchase of scrap paper by the ECB, or the breach of the Dublin Agreement by Chancellor Merkel. And why is the Commission interested in the Polish Constitutional Court, but not in the fact that three former judges of the German Constitutional Court have declared the refugee policy in Germany unconstitutional? As far as media policy in Poland is concerned, Mr Oettinger, perhaps you should look at why the compulsory-fee-funded German state radio has reported for years on the euro, for months on the wave of refugees with a pink ishtication, and for days on the mass attacks by North African men on women in Cologne. Ladies and gentlemen! More than themselves, the Germans owe the fall of the Wall to the Poles. I would remind you of Solidarity, some of whom are now responsible in the government of Mrs Szydeo. First the German politicians wanted to save the world's climate, then the euro, three times Greece, the refugees of the world, and now they also want to save Polish democracy. Ladies and gentlemen! If a people does not need tutoring for freedom and democracy, it is the Polish one!

name: Cecilia Wikström (ALDE).
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr I would like to be clear in saying that, although today we are somewhat criticising what is happening in Poland, we must also emphasise that friends must always be able to discuss in a transparent manner with each other and still remain friends. Poland is a very important part of a united Europe, but fundamental human rights and freedoms must be protected in every EU country, regardless of government.  Commissioner Timmermans, it is perfectly legitimate for the Commission to look at what is happening in Poland. However, it is hypocritical that Hungary has not been scrutinised in the same way with regard to the independence of the media and the rule of law. It is high time for the Commission to treat everyone consistently and equally in terms of fundamental rights and the independence of the rule of law.  Madam Prime Minister, finally, if you continue along this path, there is a risk that we will see fundamental rights put on the back of the road in country after country. I ask you: do not start this European domino so that we see country after country fall, instead of standing up and upholding fundamental rights, but let us together defend and uphold the values and principles on which this gigantic European project is based and which we want to leave behind for future generations in a better way than when we found them.

name: Patrick Le Hyaric (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President, if I understand the explanations given to us, democracy is being reduced in order to strengthen democracy.  Poland is asking to be exempted from the Charter of Fundamental Rights in the name of improving rights. I'm making another point. What credit should be given to our debate this afternoon, when the European institutions have decided to offer three billion euros to Mr Erdogan's Turkey, which is also prosecuting journalists, imprisoning them and putting justice in check? In truth, the Europe of the market has well supplanted europe of the values of freedom, human rights and pluralism of the press.  I have been proposing, quite some time ago, to create a European observatory to ensure the pluralism of the press and the media in all countries. It is not too late to do so, it would be a step forward.  The same observatory could be set up on the issues and instruments of justice and law in each of the European countries.

name: Josep-Maria Terricabras (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, I am speaking as President of the EFA Group in this Parliament. In 2011, during the last official census in Poland, 847 000 people declared they had Silesian identity. Only four days ago, Jerzy Gorzelik called, on behalf of over 140 000 people, for the recognition of Silesians as an ethnic minority in Poland. During a debate in the Polish Parliament on this issue, the ruling party MPs threatened Silesians with persecution and even executions. Silesians are still not listed in the law of national and ethnic minorities and on the regional languages of 2005. This is a very alarming and distressing situation. Are we standing in front of a revival of aggression and oppression against minorities in Poland? It would be an anti-democratic shame.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF).
text: Mr President, Madam Prime Minister, it is your turn to come here to respond to the outrageous accusations edis by the Eurocrats, mr President, Madam Prime Minister, after Viktor Orban. In short, you are accused of implementing the programme that led you to come to power after a perfectly democratic election, a proactive programme that aims in particular to protect Poles from the crazy decisions taken by Brussels on immigration. Instead of using more and more immigrants to boost your demographics, you are instead relying on the Polish families you have decided to help, including your measure of 500 zlotys per child. After this heated debate, in which your country was violently targeted, I wanted to thank you for showing us that another Europe is possible, a Europe of sovereign nations and free peoples who refuse to give up what they are. I am pleased to see that, together with your Hungarian, Czech and Slovak neighbours, you are forming a coherent bloc in eastern Europe that rejects the Euro-globalist diktat. So long live Poland, long live Hungary, long live the free and proud peoples of our old continent!

name: Beata Szydło
text: Prime Minister Polish. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Dear! Thank you very much for all your votes. They are important, very important, and I think that in all these voices there is a fundamental thing that should come up in this House – concern for the European Union, for its future, for its shape. Poland wants the European Union to be stable, Poland wants the European Union not to be shaken by all sorts of crises. Poland does not cause these crises, but Poland wants to actively participate in the conduct of European policies that will allow us to avoid this.  Thank you for all the critical voices, for all the voices, that is, also those that have expressed support for my country and government. For us, this is very important. I have come to you to share information, and I have a feeling, so I have at least tried to use these first speeches to give detailed facts on two issues that are doubtful to many of you, namely the constitutional court and the issue of the media law. I will also admit frankly that I thought that there would be detailed questions in your speeches relating to these matters, but in fact there were not many of them. I may think that this is due to the fact that there is simply no problem, so you have nothing to ask, and our discussion is a problem for all of us, as professor Leguka has also pointed out here. It is a problem that I, too, am in trouble with because I do not agree that the European Commission should take the Polish decision that has been taken against it. But I am open to information, I believe that the future of the European Union is paramount, and we should all, as members of this great committee, ensure that the institutions that make up the European Union work as best as possible and, above all, we must very courageously discuss their competences. That is why I am ready to provide all the information, as I have done before. Yet, if you allow it, I will repeat some important facts that I think may have missed you in my earlier statement. I believe that Poland does not deserve to be judged by the European Commission at the moment, because in Poland neither human rights nor the principles of the democratic rule of law are violated, and all matters that are currently being pursued in Poland are implemented in accordance with the Constitution, the laws and treaties of the European Union. We are a sovereign state, we are a free nation. I would add such a digression that in the Polish Parliament in the stands you can clap or express your satisfaction or not, so this is different, but it is a sense of freedom, a deep sense of freedom of the Polish people. In the Polish Parliament, the public can also speak and express their emotions.  We love our freedom, we try to guard that freedom like the pupil of the eye, because we have paid too much for that freedom. Our story taught us, which was also mentioned here, that Polish affairs should be handled in our Polish home, because whenever others did it for us, we went out very badly. And it is my concern that we do not bring here things on which I am not saying that there is no political dispute between us, because political dispute is the basis of democratic debate, it is the basis of democracy, but let us have this dispute where it takes place – in the Polish Parliament. Let us fight this dispute where it is. The best proof that the Polish State is a democratic state is that, even those who are here in the European Parliament at the moment during this debate, Polish citizens can express their dissatisfaction with the government's actions during the demonstrations that were organised without hindrance. Poland is a democratic state. I am coming to you today as prime minister of a democratic state concerned that we will work together to develop a model for our functioning in the European Union, and that we do not have to have to have such debates, which I believe do not have grounds for doing so at the moment.  I also come here, I ask you, because I have a deep sense of responsibility not only for what is happening in Poland, but I have a deep sense of responsibility for what is happening in Europe. You are talking about migration – this is a serious problem – and you know that very well. Poland has accepted about one million refugees from Ukraine, people whom no one wanted to help, they are with us today and we are helping them, and this is also something that needs to be talked about, but Poland and the Polish government, because we respect the rule of law and respect the decisions taken by the previous government, is ready to participate in this further. We are participating in the discussion and in the process that the European Union is currently working out on migration. We can deal with it, we must all respond to it, and we and you, and especially here in this place in the European Parliament, are expecting it from you today. european citizens concerned for their safety. Let us work on this – this is very important, it is a great challenge for Europe. I do not want people in my country, Poland, to be afraid that anti-European fears will grow. Let us do everything to ensure that Europe develops in peace and that it is a community of sovereign, equal, justly ruled states.  Polish, the government will not abandon the programme we have committed to the electorate. There were democratic elections, Poles chose just such a program, they chose us. We won the elections, but we won them because that is what the Poles decided, and we will implement the programme that Poles are waiting for, because very often, unfortunately, they feel that there has not been enough justice for all citizens so far. We want Polish a fair, fair and equal way for all, Polish equal opportunities, Polish development. For us Poles, it is very important to face these best-growing countries in Europe. We want all central and eastern European countries to have the same opportunities. We are young members of the European Union, we have entered the European Union with the baggage of our history, all of us from Central and Eastern Europe, but we have come with great hope. We came to a Europe that was a dream for us, a great idea of freedom, integrity and equality – and we want to be in that Europe. It is not easy for us, we have a lot of difficulties, we still have to overcome many barriers, but we want to do it, we are determined.  Poland today needs to work hard to heal a country that must protect the weak and not be afraid of the strong. This was said by the tragically deceased leader of our environment, President Lech Kaczynski. In this way he defined the challenges facing Poland. These challenges are still relevant and before us, and Saint John Paul II, the great Pole, the great European, said "do not be afraid". Let us not be afraid, ladies and gentlemen, to build an equal, just Europe. Let's do it together, together. Let us make sure that every European feels that he or she has equal opportunities and is treated equally. Poland does not deserve to be censored today. Once again, in the case of the Constitutional Court, we had to amend the law, because the previous government referred further to the bill in June 2015, i.e. accelerated the work on the bill, which, more interestingly, was tabled in 2013, but nothing was done for two years, only after the elections lost by the previous president. The Constitution was violated, as ruled by the Constitutional Court. We want to ensure that there are equal rights, that the opposition has a majority in the Constitutional Court – that is our proposal.  You are talking about the media – after all, the principles on which we are currently building the media in Poland are, for example, in Italy and in other European countries. You know this, because it is at home that we do not do anything that is not available in other European countries. We can discuss a number of issues that are important today, but It seems to me that – I will say this again – we have a problem with this debate, because it also expressed concerns and had doubts about this new framework set out by the European Commission, the Polish Government in 2014, led Polish by the current President Donald Tusk, who was Prime Minister at the time, and the government in its opinion stated in its opinion , also based on the opinions of Polish analysts, Polish lawyers, but above all on the legal services of the European Council, that this new institutional framework, previously presented by the European services, is unacceptable to the Polish Government. We have a problem with this, ladies and about, and we need to solve it.  I may feel injustice today that Poland is subject to this experiment, but I am here and I believe that it is my duty to the Polish, to the Polish state, which I have the honour to direct, but also to the European Parliament, to the European Commission, to come here and to explain in fact how things are going in Poland, because that is what we all need today, but above all it is needed to build the authority of the European Union and the European institutions. (applause)

name: Der Präsident. –
text: We now come to a final round of speakers, each with one minute's speaking time.

name: Janusz Korwin-Mikke (NI).
text: – Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for his excellent I am pleased to note that Mr González Pons said that "there is no empire in Europe other than an empire of law." Even Ms. Zimmer said, "it's not about democracy, it's about obeying the law." And rightly so. Either we have democracy or we have the rule of law, because it is often the case that the law demands one and the majority demands something different and a choice has to be made. I have spoken about this hundreds of times, several times in this parliament. In Poland we have an excellent illustration. When someone argued that the changes to the Constitutional Court were against the law, PiS activists said, well, we are democratically elected and the judges are not.  I am in favour of the rule of law, of the independence of the courts, but do you know that, under the previous government, the President of that Court wrote a letter to the Prime Minister on whether the law should be considered unconstitutional. And it was a legal requirement. However, in order for the law to rule, it must be clear and understandable. Unfortunately, in Poland, under the occupation of the European Union, the law has become completely vague and incomprehensible, and besides, I believe that the European Union must be destroyed.

name: Michał Marusik
text: On behalf of the ENF Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by There is definitely no place to consider Polish or legal dilemmas. These dilemmas have been considered, are and will be within the institutions of the Polish State, so I ask you, more peace, more joy, more optimism, more faith in Europe. Not such powers have gone down in history. There was a great, eternal Roman Empire, there was a great Soviet Union and there are no of them, and Asia exists. Even if the European Union goes into history textbooks, Europe will exist. This is, after all, a few dozen nations that only want one thing: freedom and justice, so let us ask you, let us give peace to our ridiculous lots, and let us think of Europe. If there is someone here who cares about the prosperity of Europe, then let him think about what to do, not to mix into every country, not to mingle with every industry, to every company, not to mix with every family, after all, not to meddle in the affairs of every person. Let people live a free and prosperous life. May Europe be a Europe of nations, freedom and justice. Thank you! Let's believe in Europe!  And if you can say even more, because I see that time is not over for me, I ask you, I am very pleased that this debate has provoked common sense thinking in this House, because we have been stuck in our own disputes, which are detached from the reality that is shaping up to be around us and in europe as a whole and in our countries from which we have come here, so if this common sense prevails and this debate starts to be fought around reality , Europe's problems, we will surely be people smiling, happy, developing, safe.

name: Robert Jarosław Iwaszkiewicz
text: On behalf of the EFDD Group. – Prime Minister, i would like to thank you very much for your Dear! In Poland, the situation is normal and I say this as a representative of the opposition. Parliamentary democracy works, I must say 'unfortunately', signing up to what both of my previous previous ers have said. Today's debate focuses on the limits of the competences of the European Commission and the European institutions. We are dealing with the constant movement of these borders, with the addition of further competences which are not justified by EU law. The European Commission is creating a super government, a head of all heads, a overseer of national governments.  This must be made clear: there is no agreement on the European Commission's interference in the internal affairs of sovereign nation states. Keep the good advice of German or Belgian politicians for yourself. Take care of your problems, unemployment destroying your societies, immigrants who are destroying your cultures and degrading your women, the economic crisis caused by the stupidity of your politicians.  Dear Prime Minister, i would like to thank you for your excellent work. Congratulations for your speech today. I am convinced that the future Polish is only in the hands of the Poles and depends on us. Happy Birthday!

name: Rebecca Harms
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Prime Minister, I would like to thank the Prime Minister for her I was with many Polish colleagues on the Maidan in Kiev in the winter of 2013/2014.  Among them were many colleagues from your party. These colleagues have worked very hard for the rule of law, ukraine's path to the West, and in any case against the growing and returning authoritarian influence of the Kremlin and President Putin – not only in Ukraine – but also in the European Union. I have to tell you what really hurts me in your reaction in this debate is that you applaud Members who are working aggressively towards the destruction of the European Union and who are being funded for it by President Putin. You should consider what alliance you are in, and this should also be discussed in Poland. I would like to say, with a view to the general classification of our discussion, that I believe that we are once again at a point where we need to understand that we urgently need to have an urgent debate about the rules of the rule of law, about democratic rules, things that are not uniformly incorporated into European law. After all, behind the current debate on the rule of law in Poland, there is indeed a debate about what holds us together, why we simply no longer get a positive definition of what our European identity is. Why do people and states drift away from it after elections?  That is what the European Union must do with regard to Poland. Because I have got to know civil society well, I have the greatest confidence that Polish society will not allow this country to be ruled authoritarian again.

name: Gabriele Zimmer
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, Prime Minister, I would like to thank the Rapporteur on the work she has done on this I worry all the time about why I feel that what should have been named has not been put on the table. Like Rebecca Harms, I would also like to say that I was also very irritated that you had obviously suggested something in the statements about the state of the European Union – including the demands that the Union should be destroyed – or that you had shown something of yourself, which does not fit with what you said earlier. You said earlier that you are European, your party, your government, we are Europeans, we want to be champions, we want to be at the forefront. But not by re-entering the national world! What we need in the European Union is indeed a correction, it is indeed a fundamental reform. What we need is for the European Union, on the basis of fundamental rights, to find itself again, for the citizens, the people who live in our Member States, to see the European Union as an added value for themselves, something for which they want to fight, because that is precisely the alternative to national opposition, also to a return of wars and conflicts, as we have had in the past, that we can all live with dignity. That is precisely why I was hoping to get a signal from you that Poland also consciously sees itself as a bridge between Western and Eastern Europe. We are well aware, or at least some members of the Members, are well aware of the problems in many Eastern and Central European countries. We know. We know that there is much to be clarified and reworked and rearranged. But that's where your function would be. That is my request: do not withdraw, do not applaud this gentleman! These are the wrong ones, and you certainly have no added value for Poland.

name: Guy Verhofstadt
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Thank you Mr President. I have to tell you, Prime Minister, that I admire you in a certain sense, because after a few weeks you are already using all the tricks of a Prime Minister in office, for example by saying: ‘Yes, I am here to respond to your questions’, and nobody had real remarks on what is happening. I think the Commission and I myself have described what the problem is, and what the problem is with this change in the Constitutional Court. Let me explain it again, because maybe the interpretation was not good into Polish. The system is simple: you have nominated three, out of five in total, new judges to the Constitutional Court, and these three with new rules you have made – you have given a right of veto to three PiS Members. That is what you are doing. Three members of your party can block any decision in the Constitutional Court based on the new rules you have made. That is what is happening, and you do not respond to this? You find it very normal that this is happening, and the only argument you have is to say, and this is also what Mr Legutko is saying, ‘Yes, but the Platforma made mistakes’. That is true, the Platforma did make mistakes, but you were elected, you received the victory to do better than Platforma, not to make the same mistakes as Platforma. That is democracy and you do exactly the same things Mr Legutko is referring to: ‘They did things that we did not like, a one-party state, and now it is our turn to make a one-party state for the coming years’.  So, I have only one question for you, and I think you can respond to this at least, as Prime Minister. If the Venice Commission gives a negative opinion, will you follow that opinion of the Venice Commission?

name: Ryszard Antoni Legutko
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by We have two basic enemies. One enemy is ignorance, and the other is prejudice. It is very difficult to fight prejudice even with arithmetic, because it is not the case that if we have a constitutional court with a proportion of nine to six and it is to sit in a certain composition and there is a constitutional majority, then such a Court is blocked. This is some complete nonsense. It's just absurd that doesn't deserve to be answered. There is nothing wrong with such a structure, and so that you do not know how arithmetic it rotated, you will not prove it anyway, because it is a completely rational and normal construction.  And the question is also this: is this Court, which is more representative and does not allow arbitrary decision-making by five judges, as it was before, is this the Court better or worse? It is better from the point of view of standards and there is no argument capable of calling that into question. This is simply a better court. I would like to hear an argument that undermines this, because I do not know. Maybe it's somewhere, but I don't know it.  And the media issue: do we now have better or worse media? Do we have one narrative, as we have done so far, do we have many narratives? Well, we have a lot of narratives, now we have a lot of narratives. What about those journalists who were kicked out eight years ago? They're back. Does this mean that you don't have to accept them, because again there is to be one narrative? No, there is no single narrative, and that's it.

name: Enrique Guerrero Salom
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, Madam Prime Minister, in the debate we have just held there are three lines which I believe are clearly identifiable. Firstly, a rather general tribute to Poland's role in defending its sovereignty throughout history, a recognition of what Poland has done for the recovery of democracy in Europe, but at the same time a clear concern for the decisions that its government is taking in terms of the media and the Constitutional Court.  Everyone has recognized that you have enough electoral legitimacy to carry out your government program. There's no problem with that. Simply that the democratic majority does not justify circumventing democratic values, it does not justify not protecting pluralism, and pluralism defends itself in control of government and in the freedom of the media.  Several of the interveners have externalized: "I am Polish". Some I have to tell you that they were 'dangerous friendships', but I am also going to return to that expression: I will consider myself Polish, but of all Poles, 50% who have gone to vote and 50% who have not gone to vote and who by not voting has not lost their rights. And of those who have gone to vote, of the 38% that has given it the legitimacy to govern and the 62% who have not supported it.

name: Esteban González Pons
text: PPE Group. – Mr President, Madam Prime Minister, I would like to thank you for the tone and I would like to thank you for your presence in this long debate in the European Parliament. I would like the way in which you have spoken here, so favourably, of the European Union to also be followed by your party in Poland and that this Europeanist speech that you have when you come to the European Parliament will also be had by your party when we are in Poland.  I have not been reassured to hear you say that the Constitutional Court is a political body, because political constitutional courts are useless. Those of us who can trust the constitutional legal courts. Nor has it reassured me, at all, that you say that it is the Government that will guarantee the objectivity of the media. When I hear a government say it's going to guarantee media objectivity, I always imagine the bitch putting order between the chickens. The Government is the last to try to ensure media objectivity if we want the media to be free.  I repeat what I said before: it's not about the law. You are entitled to change it. These are the values; those can't be changed by anyone. This is not about Poland; it's about the Polish government. Confusing a government with a nation is one of the most dangerous exercises that can be done in politics. It's not about sovereignty; it's about the rule of law. It's not about politics; it's about freedom. As Manfred Weber said, it's about unity and not division. And I'm going to end up like Enrique Guerrero did, too. Some who do not suit him anything as a company have today proclaimed themselves Poles. All Europeans can proclaim themselves Polish, because we are Europeans. And I'm going to tell you more: we're proud to be Europeans to be Polish. We only ask you, since you have won the election, to make it easy for us.

name: Beata Szydło
text: Prime Minister Polish. – Opinion of the Venetian Commission – we are still waiting for it. I would like to remind you of what I have already said: Polish government itself has asked the Committee in Venetian for an opinion. No one had to encourage us to do so. We will, of course, look closely at it, we are waiting for it. I believe that it would also be much easier for us to use the arguments not to have this debate about Poland today if we already had this opinion, because I firmly believe that it will be an objective opinion showing that the legal situation of the Constitutional Tribunal in Poland is excellent. We have not changed the rules for the election of the Constitutional Court. The previous parliament also elected the Constitutional Court: two-thirds of the fifteen are ten – it is difficult for ten to block a group of fifteen. I think it's clear. I am presenting arguments to you, and I want to put them forward, although I believe – and I will emphasise this once again – that this debate is completely unnecessary. But I am here because I respect that the European Parliament is concerned and, I hope, objectively wants to look at this problem. Dear! I will not refer to statements that I find offensive and which, in my opinion, should not fall in this House. This is my sense of dignity as a citizen of the European Union. We are not a nationalist party and I find such words offensive. I will not comment on them. But, dear Ones, I will say once again: the Polish government was elected in democratic elections by Polish citizens and the Polish government is today leading the Polish state from the mandate of the sovereign, that is, the citizens. And it is not that the Government Polish is anything other than Poland than our homeland.  Such are democratic elections in your countries as well. I cannot imagine me to say that I do not respect the Spanish or Dutch Government, but I respect the Netherlands or Spain. Not! I respect the government of a nation that I respect and the countries that I respect. I may disagree with you, that is our right. This is the foundation and foundation of Europe, that there are different opinions, we have different opinions, we very often disagree, but we discuss. And this is a great value that is extremely important to me, to my citizens, to our citizens, Polish is very important. Because we, ladies and gentlemen, have not had the right to discuss for decades. You are talking about justice and equality, and I am very pleased about that. I believe that the European Union will look with care at the issues of the Polish economy. There was talk of Silesia. I live near Silesia, actually I can say that I feel very strongly connected with this land, I am from Malopolska, but I live on the border of Silesia and Malopolska. Silesia is a wonderful region, the Silesians are great people, but Silesia needs the help of the European Union today. Be in solidarity with Silesia, help the Polish mines. This is a big problem for us. Today's people are asking me this: will the European Union look at our problems, will it see that we need this help today, or will it leave us as it once left the Polish shipyards? Please forgive, but such questions and such bitterness is also in Poland. We explain, talk and want Poles to feel first and foremost that the European Union is with them whenever they need help. That is why I am here today too, because I believe in the European Union, I believe in Europe, I believe in civil society, which you are talking about so much here. And I must say that a civil society representative has been appointed in my government because we take this very seriously. We have a representative for civil society (this was not the case in the previous government), and I firmly believe that a good example from Polish, including in building civil society – and we have great examples from our history, we have the siphone of Solidarity, we have everything Poland has brought to Europe – that this is the foundation on which we will be able to build a common Europe of equal, sovereign states. Let us, in accordance with the will of the Polish people, implement our programme, let us govern, let us show that Poland is a country that takes the law, the constitution very seriously, very seriously.  I am European, I am proud of it, but most of all I am Polish and I am proud of it.

name: Guy Verhofstadt (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, there must be a problem of translation, because the speech was delivered in Polish and I naturally followed in English; my Polish is very bad. Did you say you would now follow the Venice Commission opinion or not? Yes or no; that I understand in Polish. Yes or no?

name: Beata Szydło
text: Prime Minister Polish. "I have no trouble translating. I understand that you are inquisitive, because you want to know Polish affairs very well, and I thank the President for breaking a little bit, but I am very pleased because I have travelled a lot of kilometres, hundreds of kilometres, to give you a full answer and to dispel any doubts. I have no trouble understanding you. I have the impression that perhaps we need to listen to each other, hear what we say to each other and want to understand each other. The worst part is to build an opinion based on stereotypes, not facts, so let's talk about facts. This opinion is not yet there. Surely this opinion, which we are waiting for, if it is delivered, will be considered very carefully by us.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Okay, but Mr Verhofstadt: you also have to deal with the answer, you have to get through that now. It's tough for you, but you've got to deal with it now.

name: Bert Koenders
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, this was a very important but also sensitive debate. I think it was very clear from the exchanges we have heard, also in the last minute. But I nevertheless think it was a very important debate. All of us, all of you, have spoken on the importance of the rule of law as a founding stone for our cooperation, with very, very few exceptions, if any.  First of all, that is a positive sign, but we all realise when we talk about the rule of law it obviously becomes very quickly not only a legal issue, but also a political issue, and that is understandable. It is an issue about sovereignty issues, about institutional balances, about political choices. Yes, the debate on the rule of law is therefore intrinsically also political and it is therefore important that you discuss it here today in the Parliament.  All of you have made clear that nobody is holy. We have to exclude double standards. We have a task in front of all of us. It is not just finger—pointing, it is ensuring that all of us in a very difficult time of the European Union look at our own foundations for the rule of law.  I speak here on behalf of the Council of Ministers. We have not met on this yet, but I have tried to assure you that on the side of the Council, the rule of law is key and we have agreed on a few areas. One is the issue of the new mechanism that the Commission and the Council have established. It is an annual dialogue on the rule of law, and the Commission adopted a Rule of Law Framework in March 2014. It is important to work now with this new mechanism and a question was raised to me, to what extent we would go in a strengthened or other mechanism. I have not seen an approved proposal yet from the side of the European Parliament; we will obviously have to look at it if that comes.  We have a mechanism right now, and you see that it is important to start working on it with full respect and dialogue between all of us from the different institutions. In that sense, I would say on behalf of the Presidency that we are committed, as you know, to assuring the respect for the core values of our Union. The Commission is currently making an analysis of the facts, it is in constant dialogue with the Polish Government, and it plays in that sense a vital role in monitoring developments in the fields across the Union, especially in its role as guardian of the Treaty. You know where the Presidency stands and you know where the Commission stands, and it was very important that you had the opportunity to talk to the Polish Prime Minister, who has gone out of her way to stand before you today and answer your questions and listen to your comments.  I have gathered from the spirit of discussion, which is sometimes sensitive, first of all that there is a need for dialogue: that everybody agrees to. A serious dialogue. Secondly, that there is – as I have heard from all sides – a need to look at the facts in an objective way and, as was mentioned by the Commissioner, in a spirit of cooperation. On that basis, it was important that the Venice Commission was mentioned. From our side, you may rest assured that the Presidency will follow this process closely, and you may rest assured that with all our collective efforts – all our critical appraisals, letters, debates and articles – in Europe we will continue to foster and strive for the rule of law. Because, ultimately, only in such a vibrant society can there be a rule of law. If one thing has become abundantly clear here in this lively debate today, politically speaking, the rule of law is colour-blind.

name: Günther Oettinger
text: Mr. The Commission. Mr President, Prime Minister, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. In the European Union, the media has an independent role. The independence of the media is a great asset and the diversity of the media is also a great asset. That is why, when it is complaints and inquiries, the Commission not only has the right to check whether the independence and diversity of the media in Europe is being jeopardised or safeguarded and strengthened. We have no less and no more to do. The new small Polish media law deals with three bodies. It is about the Board of Management, it is about the supervisory board of TVP and PR, i.e. public television and public radio in Poland. It is about the supervisory board for both companies, and it is about the media regulator. So far, the supervisory board, which consisted of seven people, has been composed as follows: a proposal from the ministers of culture, one proposal from the Ministers of the Treasury, i.e. two by the government, and five have been determined by the media regulator in an open competition procedure. The amendment adopted at the turn of the year is new, with the Supervisory Board being reduced from seven to three members and all three being determined by personal decision by the Minister of the Treasury. Secondly, the board. In future, the Executive Board may be appointed and dismissed at any time without giving reasons. This decision is again taken by the Supervisory Board, which has been appointed by the Minister of State alone. In future, the statute of TVP and PR can be changed without a media regulator and without parliament.  We are therefore also concerned whether this development, in which the government alone is moving closer to public service broadcasting, is jeopardising the independence of broadcasting, rather than the diversity of the parties. We are looking into the question. We are grateful that the government has promised us dialogue on this. We also offer to continue this dialogue if the major media law is to be presented in February or March, as announced. We ask that there should then be a chance for dialogue before it is adopted. We would be better off if the rule of law did not have to be examined retrospectively, but that a close constructive, consultative dialogue could be held between the Commission and the Member State and its government and Parliament before it was adopted.

name: Frans Timmermans
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, there are so many things to which I could react today, but given the hour I will be very brief. There are three points. The first point is: after hearing all this discussion about sovereignty, I maintain that Poland is now more sovereign, more a master of its own destiny, than in the thousand years before it became a Member of the European Union. By pooling its sovereignty with other European nations, for the first time in its history Poland has borders that are no longer disputed by its neighbours. That is true sovereignty, Madam Prime Minister. That is a true achievement of all European nations, and Poland in the first place.  Secondly, all Members of the European Union have signed, of their own free will, and ratified through their national parliaments, European Treaties, thus entering into obligations as far as maintaining the rule of law is concerned. Not just that, but you are even allowing the way you maintain those obligations to be judged by the Court in Luxembourg, to be controlled by the Commission in Brussels, to be discussed in the European Parliament, and even to be challenged by other Member States of the European Union. So when there is an issue of the rule of law, there is no hiding behind national sovereignty, because you have agreed in the Treaty you have signed and ratified that these issues can be discussed at the European level. That is a fact, Mr Legutko – a man who loves facts so much. Let me give you some more facts about the issue at hand. And by the way, Mr Legutko, you have full right to your own opinions, but sadly not to have your own facts. Let me raise a few issues.  We have no objection, Madam Prime Minister, to the principle that the composition of the Constitutional Tribunal should be balanced. We also fully agree that the constitutional law and customs of Poland should be respected. But our concern that remains is that the Constitutional Tribunal has interpreted and applied these laws, yet these judgments are only partially being followed by you. I am not referring to the judgment you have been referring to all the time, which is the one of 3 December in which the Court said that the old parliament appointed too many judges. But there is also the judgment of 9 December, in which the Court invalidated a law of the new parliament because it had cancelled all the previous appointments, including those that the previous parliament had been fully entitled to make. Please, in our dialogue that we are going to continue, react to that point. And by the way, if you so cherish the opinion of the Venice Commission – and you have asked for it; I thought you did it because I suggested it, but apparently not – then why do you not wait with the implementation of the laws until the Venice Commission has time to give its opinion? Now you have just gone along with it, so the Venice Commission will have to come afterwards.  Well, the question remains of how Poland will solve these issues because only by solving these issues of the composition can the Tribunal again fully play its role as a rule of law safeguard. We also expect clarifications and the other reforms which have been adopted concerning the Constitutional Tribunal.  The rule of law, and especially – especially – the separation of powers is of concern to all of us. We have learned, through painful European history, that we need the tripod of democracy, respect for human rights, and respect for the rule of law. None of these can flourish without the other two. You can never use democracy as an argument against the rule of law. Nor can you use democracy as an argument against respect for human rights. We learned that through painful history, and Poland has always been the greatest victim of that painful history. And now we see a free, proud, independent Poland – not in spite of the European Union, but because of the European Union. That is why I believe in maintaining a constructive dialogue with the Polish Government, because I believe we can solve these issues in conformity with the rules that all Members of the European Union have adhered to.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Ladies and gentlemen, I must ask you, too, to conclude this discussion with you, Mrs Szydeo. You have now asked for the floor again, Prime Minister. You are, of course, our guest. I cannot and will not deny you this right. However, I must point out that I would then have to re-enter a debate, but I cannot do so under the Rules of Procedure, because we have concluded the debate with what Mr Timmermans said. I therefore assume that what you are telling us now is informative. It cannot be a further contribution to the debate, otherwise I would have to give the floor to other Members.

name: Beata Szydło
text: Prime Minister Polish. – Thank you very much, Mr President, for the fact that I can still speak at the end. I just wanted to thank you very warmly, because I think this is an important debate for all of us, certainly for Polish, but I think it is also for the European Parliament, for you. Thank you very much and I would like to stress once again that Poland is a rule of law, a democratic rule of law that respects the Constitution and all the laws that are in force in Poland and also, above all, the Treaties – we are a member of the European Union.  Thank you very much for your votes. I firmly believe that the information I have provided, which you have been waiting for, will help you to form an opinion. I am, of course, always at your disposal. Finally, Mr President, if you will, because the Commissioner asked why we did not wait for the opinion of the Venetian Commission by implementing the Law on the Constitutional Tribunal, which, I would remind you once again, corrected the law that the Court itself challenged, the Constitutional Court itself. We did not wait for the opinion of the Venetian Commission, as you did here in the European Parliament, you did not wait for this opinion, but you organised today's meeting and, just as the Commission did not wait for the opinion of the Venetian Commission, but I think that everyone, ladies and gentlemen, should have a deep sense that our discussion and our joint dialogue brings us all closer to what is most valuable and what value the European Union is.  Thank you very much again for the meeting!  (applause)

name: Der Präsident. –
