text: Madam Prime Minister, I would like to thank the Prime Minister for her Thank you for your intervention. Thank you also for the thanks you have paid to the European Parliament.  I would also like to thank you, Prime Minister. The fact that you have come here and faced this debate is a good sign. This distinguishes you from many of those who applauded you here, who believe that the debate has nothing to do with this.  That is why we thank you. This makes them pleasantly different from many who applauded you. Thank you very much. The debate is closed. Written declarations (Article 162 CRP)

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. The European Commission is ready to sanction Poland for the new media law that has just been adopted. Brussels is in fact considering activating the procedure provided for in Article 7 of the Treaty on European Union, which also provides for the suspension of a Member State's right to vote in the Council in the event of a serious and persistent breach of the values laid down in Article 2 of that Treaty.  The new Polish Government has been accused of attacking media freedom and pluralism of information, because the new law reserves, among other things, the Ministry of the Treasury, and no longer the National Radio and Television Council (the equivalent of AGCOM), the power to appoint and revoke the top management of public broadcasting companies. Similar situation with the rules approved by the Renzi government regarding the governance of RAI, which grant unprecedented power to the Prime Minister, contrary to what was established by the Consulta in Judgment No. 225 of 1974. The European Commission is therefore right to try to make us clear in the case of Poland and to leave out any doubts, and it should do the same with regard to Italy: the rule of law, freedom of expression and pluralism of information are in fact too important for democracy.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. – I have been contacted by a significant number of people in Poland following their recent General Election result. The majority, but by no means all, suggest that there is no problem with democracy in Poland; indeed, that there were greater issues before the election of the current government. They assert that criticism of Poland in this regard is politically motivated. My position on this is clear: it is not for me, for MEPs, or the European Union, to intervene in Polish domestic politics. I am no expert on Polish domestic politics, I do not profess to be such, and it would be just as inappropriate for me to comment on the same as it would be for Polish politicians to interfere in the United Kingdom. This whole debate is therefore a nonsense and should not be taking place at all.

name: Ivo Belet (PPE)
text: Written. – The interventions of the new Polish Government are particularly worrying. The independence of the constitutional court and of public service broadcasting are at stake. These are fundamental values of the European Union, which are enshrined in Article 2 of the European Treaty.  It is therefore essential that the European Commission initiates a thorough review and consultation with the Polish Government in order to find a solution. The Commission, as guardian of the Treaties, is best placed to act through the mechanism for the rule of law, which was set up for this purpose in 2014.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. The attack on Poland by the EU is an unacceptable attack on democracy and on the peoples who chose the PiS (Law and Justice Party) to represent them. It is a struggle of Brussels technocrats and self-righteous people against a free and independent nation that preserves its values with conviction. The European system is the permanent coup d'etat. When we do not think like Mrs Merkel and the system, we are revoting or as here, we accuse of a crime of human, social and Christian conservatism. As if the EU had to abandon all its values that have been its foundation and identity for millennia in order to create a sile scarce and globalised Europe subject to German austerity and diktats! Poland is now showing us that another Europe is possible, a sovereign Europe as is also the case in Hungary, the Czech Republic or Slovakia. I am delighted that this debate will allow me to show my full support for Poland, its people and its leaders.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: Writing. – The new party political action of the left-wing and liberal factions weakens European unity, which is a condition for tres71; The government, which won a majority in the recent free and democratic elections in Poland, has the right to politicize without ignoring left-wing and liberal political dogmas. The democratic decision of a Member State cannot be overridden in either Brussels or Strasbourg. Europe faces urgent challenges that will determine the future of integration as a whole. The migration crisis is far from over, the terror threat is increasing and a European solution is still not being outlined; the United Kingdom is considering leaving the Union; the Greek economic crisis continues to pose a risk to the entire European economy. Instead of solving these problems, left-wing factions are ranked ahead of partisan party political debates. In the current crisis situation, this is depment of the Union's image and capacity to act.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. – I express my support for President Andrzej Duda and Prime Minister Beata Szydlo. I believe that the rule of Law and Justice will contribute to poland's prosperity and prosperity, as well as to the reform of the European Union. Commissioner Oettinger wants to put Poland under surveillance because of the new law concerning state media. Once again, we are witnessing a double standard, as the changes made are intended to depolitiate the state media and make them more objective. Aren't these the values the EU is fighting for? Of course they are, but when proposed by conservative and nationally responsible parties and to the detriment of the status quo imposed by Euro-federalists, this is already unacceptable. I call on the Commission not to interfere in the internal affairs of sovereign Member States, especially on a political basis, clearly taking the side of the loser ERA Civilian Platform. Everyone in the EQF group, in particular Law and Justice, defends the ideas of the rule of law, democracy and economic prosperity. All this within our nation states, not in a super-state like you want to create from the EPP and the Social Democrats. Our fight is to reform the Union and return to the idea of a "United Europe of Nations"!

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing – Poland is thus, after Hungary, another of the Member States whose laws adopted appear to be contrary to the common values on which the European Union stands. The EU Treaty clearly defines freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law, as well as respect for human and minority rights. However, it is not easy to use a sanction mechanism for non-compliance at all. It requires a unanimous Council decision on the existence of a serious breach of these values and a subsequent qualified majority vote in favour of the adoption of sanctions. These include, for example, the suspension of a Member State's voting rights. The use of the current mechanism vis-à-vis Poland is therefore very unlikely, as the Hungarian Prime Minister has already announced that he will not support such a proposal. The removal of the European Union's current ineribility and 'toothlessness' in the enforcement of existing law relating to its fundamental values will be addressed by the Report on the State of Democracy, the Rule of Law and Fundamental Rights in the European Union. The fact remains that, despite cohesion policy or cohesion policy, whose main instruments are European funds, regional disparities within the European Union are only being managed very slowly. Stopping them would certainly not help the situation and would go against a policy of growth, increasing competitiveness and creating jobs. These must still be one of the main priorities of the current European Commission.

name: Lidia Joanna Geringer de Oedenberg (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – As guardian of the treaties, the European Commission has the power to launch procedures to deal with systemic threats to the rule of law in an EU Member State. On this basis, it launched last week a process to monitor the state of democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights in Poland. This is a new procedure that came into force in 2014. As the European community is concerned about the actions of the Polish Government, including hastily adopted laws that do not take into account public consultations, such as those concerning the Constitutional Court or the public media, a parliamentary debate involving the Prime Minister of the Polish government, Beata Szydło, has proved necessary.  I welcome the willingness of the Polish authorities to seriously discuss and explain the decisions taken by the PiS Government, as is the Prime Minister's declared openness to dialogue both in Poland and on the EU stage. May it not be just an empty formula. I hope that, with a view to the welfare of all Poles, the parliamentary majority will now also want to cooperate with the opposition. For us MEPs, it is crucial to maintain the very good reputation of the Polish in Europe so far, which is the result of the work of many governments and built up by a great effort by Poles, which the political turmoil can irretrievably tarnish.  I hope that it is still possible to correct the government's controversial actions and that the next step in this procedure in Article 7 of the EU Treaty, which provides for the imposition of sanctions on a Member State that affect citizens more than governments in particular, will not take place.

name: Beata Gosiewska (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – In October 2015, Polish citizens elected a new government in free, democratic elections. This was a sovereign decision of the Polish People, which must be respected and which obliges us, the ruling party, to carry out the changes announced in the election campaign. Changes based on inalienable values – freedom, equality, justice and sovereignty , which will give a new and at the same time the right direction for the development of our state. All actions of the Polish Government are undertaken in compliance with the Polish Constitution and Polish and European law. The Polish Constitution, the first in Europe, is particularly important for Poles and the Constitutional Court, which was appointed to protect it, is working properly.  The government's changes to the media law are necessary to restore pluralism to the Polish media. The European Commission has exceeded its powers to interfere in the exclusive powers of the Polish Government and the internal affairs of Polish. Especially since it has so far been difficult to draw the EC's attention to Poland. It has not responded for the last 8 years of the PO-PSL coalition government, when new scandals destabilising the situation in the country were revealed every now and then, or right-wing journalists were removed en masse from the public media, nor did it respond to requests for help in identifying the causes of the Smolensk disaster, despite the fact that almost one million Polish citizens have come to the European Parliament with such petitions. Once again, I call for prudence in assessing the internal situation in Poland.

name: Benedek Jávor (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. – As I have tried many times to draw attention to in the Hungary debates, they were not about my country, but about whether we can act effectively to preserve our common Democratic Values in Europe when they are threatened. Among other things, the regrettable consequence of the eu's failure to act effectively is what is now causing concern and debate about Poland. The measures taken by the Polish Government in violation of the rule of law are eerily similar to the arbitrary measures of the two-thirds Hungarian government from 2010, we have set a negative example by electing pro-government constitutional judges and turning the public media into an undisguguished government channel. At the time, the EU was only able to give a partial answer, unable to prevent the systemic eroding of democracy in Hungary, contributing in part to the apathy that is now widespread in Hungarian society.  It has been a short time since the new Polish government was set up, but there are already signs of dissatisfaction in society: the 50,000-strong demonstration against the election of constitutional judges is a remarkable manifestation of this. The question of whether Polish society is turning to apathy on a Hungarian pattern, or whether, thanks, among other things, to more effective European action, is succeeding in curbing the Polish Government's action against the rule of law, thus proving that the EU is indeed working primarily for the interests of the electorate. Deep apathy loosens the stability of the rule of law, so the EU must do everything it can to prevent such societies from being created.

name: Agnieszka Kozłowska-Rajewicz (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – I regret and regret the fact that, in view of the controversy surrounding the legislative decisions of the recently established Government of Law and Justice in Poland and the rule of law review procedure initiated by the European Commission for this reason, a debate has taken place in the European Parliament on concerns about the observance of democratic principles in Poland. I regret that Poland, until recently the primacy of Europe, which has a re buoyant economy, energy, freshness of gaze and, above all, genuine support for the European Community, is becoming a matter of concern and concern for the other Member States. I hope that prime minister Beata Szydło's declarations during the debate about the pride of being part of the European community are transformed Polish into decisions in which the government will maintain its pro-European course and Poland will once again become active in building a strong, united Europe. At the same time, I apologise to all my fellow MEPs, who have been inundated for weeks with hundreds of emails written by supporters of the current government, for the content and form of these letters. I assure you that they are not representative of Polish society.

name: Момчил Неков (S&D)
text: in writing. – Europe is in crisis and with each passing day it is sinking deeper and deeper into the spiral of broken promises and the destruction of European solidarity. Inability, and in my view, lack of political will for a common approach mobilize the final electorate while discouraging supporters of a united Europe. In this political vacuum and context, opportunities for undemocratic actions, such as those undertaken by the newly formed Polish government, open up. It is unacceptable for the country that first began the transition in Eastern Europe to take such a step back into democratic norms by providing tools for political interference in the country's media. Political purges and appointments to the judiciary, which must ensure the protection of all civil rights and freedoms, are also inadmissible. However, I strongly believe that the model for dealing with yet another series of trampling on democratic values in Europe, sparked by centre-right parties, must be proposed by the EU. It's not ordinary citizens who should be looking for guilt. The Council must commit itself to finding a solution to growing populism in Europe as soon as possible. The world outside the EU reminds us every day that there is an alternative to peace. We cannot allow this alternative to become a daily occurrence for our citizens and destroy what has been building for several generations.

name: Kati Piri (S&D)
text: Written. It is good that the European Commission is going to examine whether the new laws in Poland are an attack on the rule of law. The situation is very worrying and clear limits must be set.  If, after Hungary, the Polish Government can also erode the rule of law with impunity, the European Union will lose not only its credibility as a champion of human rights, but also its internal effectiveness. The risk of a domino effect to other European Member States is real: if the EU does not act now, when will it? Of course, a democratically elected government has room to fill in policy in its own way, but there must be a limit to what we consider permissible in Europe. That limit should have been set in 2010 when judges in Hungary were sent early retirement, an 'independent' media council was set up to fine 'non-objective' journalists and the constituencies were adapted in Fidesz's favour.  This Hungarian issue prompted Frans Timmermans, then a minister, to discuss the principle of non-intervention within the EU together with a number of colleagues. It is now up to the Dutch Presidency to go through with this: if European core values are at stake, action must be taken.

name: Dariusz Rosati (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Dear Prime Minister, I would like to thank you for your excellent work. I would like to take this opportunity to take this opportunity to take part in the European Parliament debate on the rule of law in Poland. I ask you to answer the following questions, which have already been outlined by the Commission and Parliament: 1. Why is President Andrzej Duda violating the Constitution by not swearing in three constitutionally elected judges?  2. Why is Law and Justice (PiS) not withdrawing from the Law on the Amendment of the Constitutional Tribunal, which paralyzes its work and disrupts the mechanism of checks and balances?  3. How does PiS intend to ensure the objectivity and integrity of the media when the amendment to the Broadcasting Act provides for the full subordination of public media to the ruling camp?  I regret to say that, unfortunately, you have not addressed the doubts raised by the Commission and Parliament. These institutions have not been answered with fundamental questions, so it should be recognised that the Prime Minister has not succeeded in explaining the controversial changes made by the government you represent.

name: Algirdas Saudargas (PPE)
text: Writing. – As regards the situation in Poland, a certain context must be taken into account. Until then, the parties in power had appointed loyal individuals to their positions of responsibility. Previous judges of the constitutional tribunal were appointed before the end of the term of the former judges. In this way, the previous government ensured that if the elections were lost (as it did), the persons appointed by them would remain in the constitutional tribunal. Unlike now, this has not attracted the attention of the EU institutions and human rights organisations, and such double standards are not tolerable. However, it must be accepted that the choice of the new government to continue the negative practices that have been developed in Poland is not appropriate and should be stopped. However, the Prime Minister, Beata Szydlo, who spoke in the European Parliament, raised doubts about possible undemocratic processes in Poland. It reaffirmed that Poland will remain a responsible, solidarity-based member of the EU that respects European values and legislation. At the same time, it made it clear that in Poland, a legitimate government elected by citizens will retain its right to reform. I believe that the Prime Minister and her team are responsibly appreciative of not only the responsibility of the citizens entrusted to her, but also her commitment as part of the EU community. Yes, it is essential that the principle of the rule of law remains a fundamental principle in Polish politics. However, any concern in the future must be allayed by a respectful debate, not by unsurmeting accusations or threats, something that we have heard from many high-ranking officials in recent months.

name: György Schöpflin (PPE)
text: in writing. – It is highly regrettable that at this time the left side of the house should be focusing their attention on Poland and not on other, far more dangerous problems. The government of Poland was elected democratically and has the right to pursue policies that it regards as appropriate, whether one approves of these policies or not. That is democracy.  The EU should concentrate its efforts on resolving problems arising from terrorism, from the migrant crisis, the fate of the euro, the future of Ukraine, the future of the United Kingdom’s relationship with the EU, the collapse of state authority in the Middle East, to name but a few. Playing party politics at this time is irresponsible and raises question marks over the future of the EU itself.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: Writing. – The new party political action of the left-wing and liberal factions weakens European unity, which is a condition for tres71; The government, which won a majority in the recent free and democratic elections in Poland, has the right to politicize without ignoring left-wing and liberal political dogmas. The democratic decision of a Member State cannot be overridden in either Brussels or Strasbourg. Europe faces urgent challenges that will determine the future of integration as a whole. The migration crisis is far from over, the terror threat is increasing and a European solution is still not being outlined; the United Kingdom is considering leaving the Union; the Greek economic crisis continues to pose a risk to the entire European economy. Instead of solving these problems, left-wing factions are ranked ahead of partisan party political debates. In the current crisis situation, this is depment of the Union's image and capacity to act.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. – The debate has repeatedly raised parallels with the process of dismantling democracy in Hungary. In this context, I would like to draw attention to two aspects, as well as an important lesson for the management of the situation in Poland: 1./ The warnings and debates of the EP and the Commission so far have been almost ineffective on the policy of the Orban regime, which, apart from a few tactical legal corrections, has increased the build-up of a corrupt, authoritarian, anti-EU regime as a member of the Union. 2./ Orban today poses a more serious challenge for the EU in at least two areas than, for the time being, kaczinsky policy: a.) With its Putin-inspired eastern and energy policies, it undermines the common European aspirations of the CFSP and the Energy Union; (b) the essence of the regime is corruption, including the almost entirety of European aid for the interests of political friends and the purpose of own family businesses. One of the important messages of this parliamentary debate must be that the European institutions finally need to take more targeted, concrete action, effectively limiting the financing of the regime, mutatis mutandis, in order to restore the rule of law according to both Hungarian and Polish democratic And European values.

name: Isabelle Thomas (S&D)
text: In writing. After Hungary and the government of Victor Orbon, it is now Poland that is switching to nationalist authoritarianism: the European Union must take measures to stem the drift that threatens the rule of law. Like Fidesz, its Hungarian counterpart, Andrzej Duda's "Right and Justice" party attacked press freedom. The new President also took control of the Polish Court for Constitutional Review, in defiance of the same Constitution.  The Polish government is therefore attacking democracy and the rule of law head-on by flouting the principle of separation of powers. The European Union must respond firmly to avoid the "orbanisation" of all Eastern Europe. I am determined that we should initiate a procedure to "save the rule of law" in Poland and Hungary. Jean-Claude Juncker and the European People's Party must take responsibility: we must also severely punish Hungary! Europeans do not understand that we tolerate such excesses.

name: László Tőkés (PPE)
text: Writing. – The new party political action of the left-wing and liberal factions weakens European unity, which is a condition for tres71; The government, which won a majority in the recent free and democratic elections in Poland, has the right to politicize without ignoring left-wing and liberal political dogmas. The democratic decision of a Member State cannot be overridden in either Brussels or Strasbourg. Europe faces urgent challenges that will determine the future of integration as a whole. The migration crisis is far from over, the terror threat is increasing and a European solution is still not being outlined; the United Kingdom is considering leaving the Union; the Greek economic crisis continues to pose a risk to the entire European economy. Instead of solving these problems, left-wing factions are ranked ahead of partisan party political debates. In the current crisis situation, this is depment of the Union's image and capacity to act.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. – Donald Tusk, the conservative Polish President of the European Council, is wrong to think that Polish civilians are strong enough to resist the government's illiberal power-building. That's what we Hungarians thought. And the Orban virus is now spreading as a dangerous infection. If the European Union is able to show on its merits that such a policy has no place in our community, its spread can be prevented. If there is still a war of words and they want to stigmatise a country as a whole, not their governments, then new undemocratic, populist politicians will be strengthened. European populists, unite! If the European community and the conservative People's Party had resolved the 'Hungarian case' in a timely and meaningful manner, there would be no 'Polish case' now. S long enough that the more sober European right is still covering for Orban. Enough that the European People's Party tolerates and even supports the spread of the Orban virus. If Europe is devastated by the illiberal virus, it will be primarily the responsibility of the People's Party.

name: Janusz Wojciechowski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – High Chamber! Thank you for your interest in Poland despite the great problems in Europe, especially in Germany. I have three questions for President Juncker: Firstly, what are the treaty grounds for launching a Commission inquiry into Polish? Article 7 does not contain such a basis, other articles do not.  Secondly, I believe that the initiation of the procedure for the Polish not from newspapers, but from in-depth legal analyses of the Commission. Who developed these analyses and when will you present them?  Thirdly, the Polish constitutional court has a majority of judges by choice of the opposition, ruling by a two-thirds majority, in order of influence. What's wrong with that? How is Polish court worse than the Luxembourg court that your country intends to abolish? Have you heard of this? Why can Luxembourg sovereignly even liquidate its tribunal and Poland cannot change it? May you explain these double standards to Europeans. And on New Year's Eve next year I invite you Polish. It's democratic, nice and safe!

name: Presidente. –
text: The next item is the debate on the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the Peace Process in Colombia 2015/3033 (RSP)).

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, these are very important times for Colombia. Let me say that, for once, among many different difficult situations in the world around us and far away, this is a place in the world where we have signs of hope and change. I am very glad that you decided to organise this debate on the peace process because I am convinced that this year can be the year where we have good news after an armed conflict that has lasted for over half a century.  Two hundred and twenty thousand people have died and over six million have been forcibly displaced. Countless others have been kidnapped, and these appear to have been victims of violence. The first peace negotiations were held more than 30 years ago, and today in Havana we finally see the chance of a breakthrough. Let me say that this opportunity for peace, for good news – sometimes we do have good news, as happened a few days ago in Vienna on Iran – cannot be missed. Personally, I had been following the Colombian peace process even before becoming the Union’s High Representative. I was already in Bogotá as an Italian Prime Minister and, since I started my role in the European Union institutions, I have supported, on behalf of the European Union, my friend President Juan Manuel Santos’s courageous efforts. Over this year, our relationship with Bogotá has grown stronger in many different ways, from the visa waiver agreement to Colombia’s engagement in our mission, Atalanta.  Just a few months ago I decided to appoint Eamon Gilmore as my special envoy for the peace process to demonstrate and strengthen the EU’s active commitment to it. I was particularly glad that this decision was taken with the full support of President Santos. Eamon Gilmore’s direct involvement in the peace process in Northern Ireland and his political experience made him a perfect, ideal candidate who, as I said, has already been very well received in these first months with all the contacts he had among the parties, even in recent days. He is currently in Bogotá, and I know that he is looking forward to meeting the members of the Committee on Foreign Affairs (AFET) later this month to explain his role, share his views on the prospects and the remaining challenges of the peace process and discuss with the members of AFET the way in which the European Union can better contribute to supporting this process. Let me give you an update on the state of play. We have all seen the landmark agreement that was reached last December on the victims. This agreement offers a sound basis for truth, justice and reconciliation. We all know that reconciliation is the only possible real base for any peace process to move forward in a sustainable way. This agreement can ensure that the truth about the conflicts, its roots and each actor’s responsibilities is known and acknowledged. It can bring justice and guarantee the non—repetition of crimes, can make it possible to move beyond the conflict and look to the future and can ensure that the disappeared are accounted for. It is crucial to heal the wounds and, for those who have lost their loved ones, to grieve the loss and cope with it. The agreement can also guarantee appropriate reparations to the victims, either individually or collectively. This is probably the first time a peace agreement has given such a central role to victims. There is no other way towards reconciliation, and the culture of political divergences can be solved peacefully through politics and elections.  The agreement walks a thin line – we know that very well and the Colombians know it very well – between preventing impunity and making peace possible. It was not an easy task, but the deal has managed to strike a good balance. The two sides have also committed to making the effective protection of human rights a top priority. This includes a strong focus on human rights defenders. Their extremely precious work too often makes them the target of threats and violence. Colombia started from a difficult position in this regard, but it has also made very good progress over the past few years. In spite of a security situation that remains challenging in a number of regions, such commitments by the two sides will help consolidate progress. Of course, the Havana negotiation is not over yet. We are talking about a process that is still ongoing. Important issues still need to be addressed. Just to quote a number of them: the modalities for a definitive ceasefire and its verification, the disarmament, demobilisation and reintegration of former combatants, the arrangements for guaranteeing their physical security, and how to implement the agreement. Still, I am confident that the negotiation can not only be concluded, but can be concluded rapidly in line with the commitments taken by President Santos. As an agreement comes close – hopefully – we must also think of what comes next on how to support the peace that it is now possible to build. Experience shows that implementing a peace agreement is often the most challenging part of it. Vested interests may stand in the way. A new mentality will need to replace the old ways of doing things and all parties will have to confirm their dedication to peace, well beyond the signature of a deal or even its ratification through a plebiscite. This is why our work and Eamon Gilmore’s mandate is focused very much on the implementation phase and how we can support it with all the different means that we have. European Union engagement will not decrease once an agreement is signed and ratified – on the contrary. On land and rural development, political participation or human rights, we will keep encouraging deep change in the country along the lines that will be agreed in Havana. It is these reforms that can bring sustainable peace and not just peace in Colombia. The European Union will be with Colombia all along the way. We are together with Colombia today, we will be there at the moment when the peace agreement is signed – soon, hopefully– and we will be there to help the parties implement it fully. My colleague Neven Mimica and I have been working together to set up an EU trust fund which will pool contributions from the EU budget and from willing Member States. We are already seeing contributions coming in. We are currently finalising the preparatory work for this fund in close contact with interested Member States and, as I said, there is a growing interest in this. The trust fund will have to be ready by the time the peace agreement is concluded. It will complement Colombia’s own financial efforts in close coordination with other donors and partners of the country. We are not just offering good intentions but constant political support that is very much needed and concrete means to make this work in a sustainable way, for when the agreement is signed, for when it starts to be implemented and for future decades. Through our political support, our work with international partners and our financial assistance, the European Union is making, and will continue to make, a crucial contribution to the success of the peace process in Colombia.  These are days that are very important for Latin America, days of change, days of new challenges, and – potentially – days of reconciliation. Such change needs to be driven, encouraged and accompanied. When the opportunity for positive change arises for once, our European Union has a specific interest in playing a key role. That is what we are also doing in Colombia – and not only there – and I know that I can count on you for support in doing this because, as we focus on managing the crisis in the conflicts around us, we cannot afford to lose sight of the positive and encouraging steps that can be taken around the world, helping us stabilise , as in this case, a conflict that lasted for 40-50 years or prevent further destabilisation and conflict. Even when they look far off, they do affect the stability and the security of the world, so it is our primary interest in the European Union to support and facilitate them with the maximum of our efforts and, as I said, our political and also financial support.

name: Luis de Grandes Pascual
text: PPE Group. – Mr President, Madam Vice-President / High Representative, the fact-making relationship expressed here in detail by Mrs Mogherini saves me from repeating them. He has done it rigorously, he has done it fairly, he has done it with solidarity. It was worth it, because today is a historic day. That's why my words will be value judgments about that factual relationship. And I would like to say, as a first point and with solemnity, that, in our view, Colombia, with its conduct, has earned this support to be given to it by the European Parliament at this time, which is undoubtedly historic. This is a historic moment that has been precedent. Others have tried: to find some kind of solution through dialogue between antagonists. I would like to remind you that presidents Betancur, Gaviria, Pastrana or President Uribe himself tried before President Santos, even if he is now reluctant. But it is no less true that President Santos, if he completes this historic peace process, will have in The History of Colombia an absolutely deserved pedestal. And for our part, Mrs Mogherini, we have also made an effort to live up to the circumstances. This Parliament, so different, so different and pluralistic, has achieved a proposal for a consensus resolution from seven large political groups which, in a unique way, will adopt, in a very majority way, this motion for a resolution with the principles and values that we believe are worthy of this moment. I believe that Colombia has become credited with its conduct, I repeat, to this deference. So what's missing, Mrs Mogherini, is what I said. Resources are needed to accompany the development of this process. This process, which has culminated in justice that will not allow impunity, which will preside over equity and which will naturally allow Colombia to undertake a historic moment it certainly deserves. And we'll all be willing to help that fate.

name: Ramón Jáuregui Atondo
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, thank you very much Mrs Mogherini for your presence and for your words. I would like to tell you, first of all, that, as we all know, humanity has long shown that ending a war is much harder than starting it. Humanity has shown us that negotiating with a terrorist group at the end of violence is far harder than fighting it. You fight him police even.  I believe that, as you said, these two great conquests of Colombia in the coming months effectively mark a historic moment for Colombia, because let us not forget that they are probably ending what has been a tragic tradition of more than 50 years not only in Colombia but in many other countries in South and Central America, where , for many years, many political groups thought that violence was legitimate to achieve their political goals. Today, we are probably at the end of that tragic story and that tragic mistake, because I am one of those who thinks there was never any reason to kill; that there was never reason for violence.  I think Colombia's decision has enormous merit and the European Parliament could not be far from that decision. We have made a decision, as Mr de Grandes has just said, which is an important decision: it is timely. It is very timely because peace can come in a few months definitely. It is committed because we have talked about everything that has happened in Colombia and committed to the European Union and committed to the different political groups. And it is courageous, above all, because it is unanimous and, for the first time, in an international policy event, we unanimously decided the whole European Parliament in favour of the peace process. Peace is not perfect, we know that there are many people against it, but it is peace, and that is why it is important to remember that there are no paths to peace, that "peace is the way", as Gandhi said. This great meeting of peace, which has been able to solve so many problems, is very much news that deserves our support, very well expressed by the appointment of Mr Gilmore and by the trust fund that we have to put in place.

name: Mark Demesmaeker
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Can we still look to the future optimistically? Various crises around us around us sometimes make us doubt, but in Colombia the recent peace process with the FARC makes us hope for the end of this conflict. An aroma of peace hangs in the air. Happy.  The provisional agreements should be completed by 23 March and lead to the surrender of the weapons. In the ECR resolution, we call on the parties to clarify the ambiguities about transitional justice and recovery for victims in the meantime. The Colombian peace process must not stop here. Chapters of the ELN violence and that of the paramilitary militias must also be closed. Because a large part of the paramilitaries did not participate in the demobilisation and integration programme. Some feared militias continue to fight both FARC and government forces today. These cancers in Colombian society also need to be addressed.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, in order to explain the scope of this motion for a resolution, I must begin by congratulating the work done by the parties in Colombia to ensure that the truth, justice and reparation of victims are put at the service of non-repetition. These processes often talk about the price of peace. Colombians, their institutions and their society know perfectly well the price of war, violence, and have decided to stop paying for it. They have applied pragmatism, will and imagination to this and are achieving it. And that deserves our most determined support. A good example of how this effort can be accompanied by much more than words is the commitment and success made by Mrs Mogherini, to which I would like to thank her efforts, in this process. And it is an example of what the European Union's external action should be. I hope that this resolution will help in the same direction, because it certifies the European Parliament's support for Colombia and its citizens. An endorsement that is based on respect for its decisions, the recognition of its successes, the condemnation of violence as a tool for political action and an express reference to the implementation of international legislation aimed at preventing impunity for crimes against humanity worldwide. For these reasons, this document is an expression of active solidarity with victims. It commits to a social, political and economic process that arises from citizens and their institutions to launch a new coexistence with rights, development, social justice and reconciliation. Let us hope that it will also contribute to ending the double victimization that all Colombians have suffered, because when your country's label is stained with blood, it is associated with conflict and violence. Isolation, disdain and boycott punish those who already suffered greatly with the penalty of smear. In short, yes to this new Colombia of peace and coexistence, which is rapidly transforming a conflicting society into a country of opportunity.

name: Javier Couso Permuy
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, from the GUE/NGL Group we want to live up to this peace process which began on 19 November 2012, because it is a terrible conflict: 218,000 deaths, 70,000 missing, the country with the most trade unionists killed, the second country in the world in terms of civilian mine casualties and six million internally displaced persons.  This conflict has structural causes and has been evidenced by drafts that have been signed or prepared by the FARC and the Colombian Government on the field, political participation, the solution of the drug problem or the victims' agreement. It highlights the issues that need to be dealt with in order for this bilateral ceasefire to be consolidated by the popular route of the agreements, that is, it is based on truth, justice in reparation and guarantees of non-repetition.  We now need to dismantle paramilitary groups in the service of ultra elites and some extractive multinationals— some European ones; restore stripped land—the comprehensive solution to access to land; that the Colombian State should use its responsibility to protect its people, especially activists from social, political and trade unionist movements; ensure the presence in Colombia of the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights and, of course, provide economic support, but conditional on the signing of the peace agreement and international verification mechanisms.

name: Jordi Sebastià
text: verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, first of all thank you, Mrs Mogherini, for being here, for coming to this Parliament often to speak and also to listen to us. I believe that this motion for a resolution is a clear source of joy and I believe that this Parliament should welcome the degree of consensus we have reached. And I would like to congratulate, on behalf of my group, all those who have negotiated for clear and determined support for the peace process in Colombia. Victims deserve nothing else, and the process, all the effort that all parties involved have been making, either. And it is important that the European Union gets involved, that it shows the world that we have trade agreements, that we exchange goods and businesses, but also that we know how to transfer our aid to alleviate the suffering of people, no matter where. And that we are the benchmark of human rights, sometimes we can make it happen. We must now be involved in the fact that paragraph 8, which calls on the Member States to set up a fund to accompany the post-conflict phase, becomes a reality. I just want to draw a call for that other focus of violence, recreation and death — as one Member has pointed out - which are the paramilitary groups now called criminal gangs or 'bacrim'. These groups, created with the cooperation of the armed forces, are still the cause of much suffering and pain today, are linked to drug trafficking and act as mere gangsters. We must not forget this crucial point if we are to reach a comprehensive peace agreement in Colombia. We can't afford a loose end now that the FARC process is moving in a good direction. Let's put the problem on the agenda and give our full support to solve it, as we have done now.

name: Ignazio Corrao
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, good afternoon to the High Representative. Well, we can only agree with the support for the resolution, because – as you have already said – it is clear that this is an historic moment, an important moment, but it is also a time from which a new era begins for Colombia. And it is a new era in which we have to be very careful, because what worries me is what will happen tomorrow, because the agreement, the peace process is a good agreement, but it does not take into account many things, such as compensation for victims, where money will be taken, or many other points that have remained unresolved, which we have not put into account in the resolution because clearly as the European Parliament we want to give a strong signal , but which, I fear, may be problematic points for the future. So we welcome this new page of history with great happiness, but we know that we have to work so hard for the future in Colombia.

name: Francisco José Millán Mon (PPE).
text: – Mr President, Colombia is experiencing a crucial stage in its history, as has been said. Negotiations to reach this final agreement have recently resumed in Havana before March 23. The aim is to end more than fifty years of conflict and clashes that have caused great suffering, death, heavy casualties and large internally displaced persons.  The European Union's relations with Colombia are very important and have intensified in recent years. Mrs Mogherini has already mentioned the importance of the Multiparts Trade Agreement, which is deploying its positive effects so that for Colombia the European Union is already the second most important trading partner. I also highlight the key role played by this Parliament in obtaining the abolition of visas for Colombian citizens. The agreement signed on 2 December is proof of the momentum that the European Union wants to give to relations with Colombia and its citizens. This Parliament would like to encourage the successful completion of the so-called peace process tomorrow and to call for the European Union and its Member States to continue to support it, also contributing to the trust fund that will accompany the post-conflict phase.  We are in a moment of historical scope. Colombia is determined to leave the dark tunnel of violence. Colombia is a great country, one of the most important in Latin America, and the definitive closure of what President Santos called "historical cycles of violence" will facilitate the full deployment of its enormous potential not only domesticly, but also internationally.

name: Richard Howitt (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I have had the privilege of personally observing the peace talks in Havana at the invitation of both sides, helping contribute my own country’s experience of securing peace in Northern Ireland. As someone who has campaigned for peace and human rights in Colombia throughout my time at this Parliament, I believe an historic breakthrough can and will be achieved.  Today the suffering continues. In recent weeks, a 14-year-old girl was killed, and two Patriotic March activists have been murdered. We acknowledge the stopping of air strikes by the government and the unilateral ceasefire undertaken by the FARC, but further gestures towards peace, including on the treatment of prisoners, are still required. However, the agreement on victims was a huge achievement of the parties. It was this that persuaded me that the course of peace is now irreversible. It was an agreement which recognised the responsibility of both sides for the conflict and now their joint responsibility for peace.  Those who have attacked the peace process for so-called impunity should recognise there remains full accountability for war crimes under the jurisdiction of the International Criminal Court, and in agreement for reparations and restorative justice which enables an end to conflict. I join the High Representative in underlining our deep commitment for the EU to support the implementation of peace. As tomorrow’s resolution makes clear, we want to follow the Northern Ireland model for our support to peace initiatives to be administered independently with the full participation of both sides of civil society. We must also assist with security guarantees so that the democratic opposition can act free from persecution. There must be no repeat of the massacre of the Unión Patriótica, no more deaths, no more failed peace processes, but peace with justice, justice for Colombia. The time for peace has come.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE).
text: – Mr President, after more than fifty years of an armed conflict that has torn Colombia apart and cost more than two hundred thousand lives, the Government of Colombia and the FARC have reached an essential agreement on the creation of a special jurisdiction for peace, which will have to satisfy the rights of victims and lay the foundations for a stable and lasting peace. This agreement has a relevance that could be historic if you successfully reach the phase of its implementation. That is why, from the European Parliament, we would like to express our satisfaction with last September's agreement, but also to support the conclusion of a final peace agreement by 23 March. In this regard, Mrs Mogherini, you have appointed former Irish foreign minister Simon Gilmore as the Union's special envoy for the peace process in Colombia. And that was surely a wise decision. The Union should now deepen its support with a trust fund to accompany the post-conflict phase in Colombia, as proposed in our motion for a resolution. And I am glad to know that you and Commissioner Mimica are working on it. Like Commissioner Mimica, I come from Croatia and there we are well aware of the importance of the international community's support for reconciliation processes. Therefore, in view of this experience, I would like to stress that it is necessary for the European Union to actively accompany Colombia in this peace process.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Mrs Mogherini, I would like to congratulate you on your work in this area. We all know that a peace process, like the one that has been consolidated in Colombia, is fragile and difficult, and it is our obligation to bring together all efforts. But it should be stressed that this peace process has a very important characteristic – it was focused on the victims and not on the conflicting parties. This option is remarkable because it is a pioneering option, and the agreement signed in December shows this fact and is a pillar of this process. The European Union has made an important contribution all this way and the trade dimension is not unspicient because, in addition to the economic dimension of the agreement established with Colombia and Peru, an important commitment has also been made to work together for peace, democracy, respect for human rights and the promotion of the well-being of peoples.  That is why this resolution, which we are debating here today, combines a very important triple perspective. Firstly, it gives priority to fostering lasting peace based on the defence of people, victims of conflict and strengthening civil society. Secondly, however, it takes on the trade partnership between the European Union and Colombia, with a platform for promoting not only economic recovery, but also of values and practices of respect for peace, human rights and full democracy. Finally, this resolution welcomes the commitment spirit shown by the parties and calls for the development of a culture of non-violence and the development of trust in Colombian society. These efforts have generated new platforms for understanding and cooperation, and the European Union can and must, as it has done so far, continue to consistently support this process. (The speaker agrees to answer a question under the "blue card" procedure in accordance with Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – We live in a world where the 24-hour news cycles constantly bring us coverage of tragic global conflicts, as we see on a daily basis. Do you agree with me that the beacon of hope provided as countries like Colombia move towards peace often go under-reported in our media, and that perhaps we should better remember and recognise the progress that has actually been made as the newsreels have moved on?

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D)
text: Response according to the "blue card" procedure. Mr President, thank you very much for the question i am asked. The truth is that every day we have new conflicts, every day we have new challenges, but every time a conflict and every time a challenge is faced with quality and success, there is more hope and there is more possibility of solving others to which, however, we still can not give similar response.

name: Tunne Kelam (PPE).
text: – The conflict in Colombia has been dragging on for almost half a century, resulting in almost a quarter of a million deaths and six million displaced persons. The lengthy peace talks have now culminated in the Havana Agreement last December and I fully agree with Ms Mogherini that this is a landmark achievement we need to value. What is encouraging is that agreements have been already reached on such key issues as land reform, political inclusion of FARC members, drug crops, etc., but after the long process of violence it is just and fair that these other victims deserve the centre of attention.  Now the question is how to heal the wounds? How to make reconciliation? The December agreement foresees an integral system of truth, justice, reparation, etc., but first of all we need to reach a workable comprehensive deal by the end of March to implement a permanent ceasefire and then for FARC to lay down its arms. FARC is one of the last bastions of the twentieth century Cold War militant ideology that relied on violent revolution. They failed, but paramilitary groups, too, have seriously undermined democracy.  Finally, in all these encouraging developments one can perceive also the beneficial influence of Pope Francis, who has said we do not have the right to allow another failure. Let us hope and do everything to achieve this.

name: Agustín Díaz de Mera García Consuegra (PPE).
text: – Mr President, first of all I would like to congratulate President Santos sincerely. President Santos has been courageous and taken the risks. Courage and combined risks that have been concluded in the happy agreements of 23 September. In this regard, I am interested in highlighting, as others have done, the creation of a special jurisdiction for peace, a comprehensive agricultural development policy, a policy of political participation and some response to the problem of illicit drugs. But victims, lands, impunity, displacement and justice are, in my view, issues that deserve a higher level of commitment.  I hope that there will be a final agreement on 23 March and I hope that Colombia will have the confidence it deserves inside and abroad. The European Union trusts Colombia, it has repeatedly demonstrated this: the appointment of Eamon Gilmore as special envoy for the process, the Trade Agreement or visa liberalisation are examples that illustrate the confidence to which I have just referred.  But Colombia still has a big challenge ahead of it, as noted: the post-conflict phase and peace-building. To this end, the help that the European Union can provide is essential. That is why the momentum and commitment of the accompanying trust fund and also many other things are necessary, to which the start of negotiations with the ENL and other paramilitary forces that still disturb the peace and peaceful coexistence of Colombians is no stranger.

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE).
text: – I welcome the results of the peace process in Colombia, which alone can guarantee lasting peace after decades of violence and sacrifice. Reconciliation and peace have no alternative. I am convinced that this will enable a new quality of co-life in Colombia and unlock its rich development potential.  I would like to congratulate the political leaders and supporters of the peace process for their achievements, and I would particularly like to express my gratitude to Pope Francis and the spiritual leader of Sri Lanka, Ravi Sancar, for their essential contribution to the decision of the warring parties to exercise their political will non-violently. March should be a new page in colombia's history and for the good of its people.

name: Bogdan Brunon Wenta (PPE).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by High Representative, I would like to thank you for your excellent work. The agreement of 23 September on the establishment of a special court for peace and of 15 December on the victims of the Colombian civil war, concluded between government representatives in Bogoth and FARC guerrillas, is an important step in the three-year-long peace negotiations. Fifty years of civil war have killed hundreds of thousands of civilians, mostly civilians. The conflict forced millions of people to flee their homes. Torture and abduction, as well as the forced conscription of children into the military, were a daily occurrence for the inhabitants of these regions. The September and December Havana agreements on a special court and the compensation and identification of all victims of the conflict are therefore to be welcomed. In 2016 – this year, the year of the final peace agreement – this makes this very likely. Once the civil war is over, aid will be needed for war-ravaged regions. Therefore, it is important for the European Union to work towards the sustainable development of Colombia and to support the poorest provinces of the country, and to influence the development of government and civil administration in regions where the jurisdiction of the central government is neglib or none.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Colombia is an inglorious example in a situation where some believe that they can impose their conditions on others by violence. This is also a memento: these 45 years of civil war, those nearly a quarter of a million killed, those seven million who have been harmed is a memento for many countries around the world, including many politicians and political parties in Europe who think that reality can be changed by force, by force against their own state and their own people. We all in Europe should look at these countries and show them as a bad example, but on the other hand, of course we should enjoy that the European Union and the United States, as well as countries such as Cuba, have contributed to the fact that we can be at our fingertips from peace, and may this be the case for us to achieve this peace.

name: José Inácio Faria (ALDE).
text: – Madam High Representative, Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, 2016 could be the most decisive year in Colombia's recent history, with the signing of the peace agreement with the FARC guerrillas, scheduled for March, ending a conflict that in half a century has killed more than 220,000 people and marked Colombian society forever.  The European Union, which has always encouraged the establishment of peace negotiations, will have to offer its full support to the Government of Juan Manuel Santos in the implementation of this definitive peace agreement, as well as the complex post-conflict challenges, plans that will require enormous resources: supporting the strengthening of the economy, the reintegration of guerrillas, the transformation of guerrillas into political parties and compensation for victims , in the name of a lasting and lasting peace in Colombia. Ladies and gentlemen, I also believe that the solution to the consolidation of the peace process in Colombia will inevitably be national reconciliation, as Ms Mogherini rightly said, in the name of this lasting peace in Colombia.  I end up, Mr President, hoping and wishing this Parliament to have a different attitude to Colombia than it regrettably had with Venezuela in its recent process of democratic transition, where it was left with absence.

name: Josu Juaristi Abaunz (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, this is not the text that I or my group would draft, but I am very pleased that this Parliament is discussing a joint proposal to support the peace process in Colombia. We must congratulate ourselves on all that has already been achieved between the Government and the FARC, despite the difficulties and unforeseen events, and we must also congratulate Colombian society. And encourage the Government and the ELN to concrete dialogue between the two as soon as possible. Mrs Mogherini, in my opinion, it is essential that European aid reaches not only the Colombian State, but also the territories, the regions. May territorial peace be ensured. Finally, I would like to stress that it is at least surprising that the Spanish State, which supports the process in Colombia, and I am glad that it does so, instead denies the possibility of a democratic resolution of political conflict in the Basque Country. I want to encourage everyone and everyone to get involved in my country, too. (He agreed to answer a question posed under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Regulation))

name: Luis de Grandes Pascual (PPE)
text: "blue card" question. – Mr Juaristi, how do you have the nerve to equate a dialogue between a democratic state, which recognises mistakes, and forces that have been doing what they can — and I do not naturally want to go into assessments — with the subject of a supposed dialogue between a terrorist organisation such as ETA and a democratic state? How's that nerve, Mr. Juaristi?

name: Josu Juaristi Abaunz (GUE/NGL)
text: "blue card" response. – Thank you, Mr de Grandes, for your question. It's common sense. Any political conflict, any resolution of any political conflict, is addressed by speaking, dialogue and negotiation. That's what you're supporting in Colombia. And I think it's very good, I'm so glad you do. But in Europe, in addition to Ireland, whose peace process this Parliament also supported, there are also other processes that need the institutional support of the European Union. And also the involvement of your government. That is absolutely necessary and is the way to resolve political conflicts.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, first of all, I think it was important for the European Parliament to send a clear and forceful message to support the peace process. I think we'll make it tomorrow and it's a very positive step forward. I would also like to thank the words of the High Representative and also for the efforts she is making to accompany the process, which I think is very important. The only message I'd like to move is that it's time not to fall asleep, not to think it's all done. Partial agreements must be fulfilled, and that is very important, but there are many things to be done.  We are concerned about the issue of land, displaced persons, indigenous people, the issue of women, which is included in the motion for a resolution, and that of the femicides that have occurred in Colombia for too many years, which is also collected. And two very important things for us, Mrs Mogherini: the first, the issue of paramilitaries and their dismantling, which has been pointed out by many Members; it's a fundamental issue, because without that there's not going to be peace. And the second thing I wanted to point out to you as an essential issue is the protection of human rights defenders, who have suffered constant attacks for too many years and whose protection has to be a primary objective of the European Union. So, nothing more, simply encourage it to accompany the European Union as much as possible in all these respects so that the process is completed in good condition and as we all wish.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in Colombia at last the darkness at the end of the tunnel is a little less dark. There are no perfect peace agreements and processes, nothing will bring back the hands and horrors of history, but concluding a conflict that has lasted since the 1960s is already a small miracle. Many issues are unresolved, starting with the meaning of the expression 'restrictions of freedom for confessors', including the responsibilities of the commanders of irregular militias, sanctions for crimes against humanity and drug trafficking, compensation for victims and the participation of offenders in political life, not to mention sanctions on sponsors of war criminals. We hope that the talks in Havana will clarify them. It is essential, however, that no amnesty is tolerated for the most serious crimes and that drug trafficking is really combated, helping farmers who are often more victims than accomplices. And let us return, including on the part of the Colombian State, to the very beginning of a full rule of law and full respect for the civil and political rights of every citizen. Finally, as a Union we must also honour our economic commitments to aid, we owe it to the future of young Colombians and to the hope that newborns will never know what the word 'war' means.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Mr President, the final stage of the peace process between the Colombian government and farc rebels will be completed in May 2016. An agreement was signed on 15 December to compensate the victims of the 50-year war, while peace negotiations to limit military operations have been underway since 2012.  The peace process is expected first of all to end the oldest and longest-running conflict in Latin America, a confrontation that has left at least 220,000 people injured and led to political persecution of the opposition and trade union leaders. At the same time, compensation is provided for the victims of the conflict as well as measures to combat drug trafficking and to develop the rural economy.  It is therefore necessary to conclude peace negotiations in Colombia in order to launch investigations into the disappearances of the long-standing conflict and to set up a special committee to clarify what happened in the civil war. The peace process can, after all, lead to the formation of a democratic Colombia provided that the paramilitary organisations are dissolved.

name: Maite Pagazaurtundúa Ruiz (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, thank you, Mrs Mogherini, once again. We respect your work very much.  Of the two hundred and twenty thousand people who died in Colombia in all these years, 81% were civilians and thousands of victims have gone unnoticed for decades, not only by the strategy of concealment, but by the rutinization of violence and social and institutional indifference, as the Colombian historian Gonzalo Sánchez says. Calculations of the distribution of responsibilities for violence are substantive in terms of truth and memory, but do not attenuate the responsibility that each victim claims. And it's not about conciting hatred or revenge, it's about justice, repudiation and reflection. Victims and Colombian society need the assumption of responsibilities without impunity. Even in our careful motion for a Resolution, it is worth remembering that civil society is not participating in the negotiating table and that, so far, the degree of impunity in crimes exceeds 90%. Some sources speak of 98%. It's not just about invoking that there will be no impunity. We must be demanding in the assumption of responsibilities and in the real application of justice, which we invoke and hope for. And this applies to both Colombia and any place where human rights have been violated, for example, Spain.

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, let me start by saying what someone else in this room has said: we are not there yet. It is very encouraging. A major step – I would say a historic step – was taken in December, solving one of the most difficult parts of the negotiations in a difficult, complicated, but I think very constructive and encouraging way. But we are not there yet.  That is why I underline – as I did in introducing our debate – that our support does not focus only on the follow-up to the agreement and implementation, but also, in these coming weeks and months, on trying to accompany the negotiations, trying to support them and also trying to support the strong leadership and vision of President Santos, who is certainly taking bold and impressive steps in this direction, and also supporting the country – all of it – in this process.  Regarding the territories, I very much share the reference to the fact that we need to make sure that our support goes all the way down (for me, somehow, it is going up!) to where people live. When it comes to civil society and human rights defenders – I specifically mentioned this in my introductory remarks – this is a role for the European Union, and we know that very well, as is encouraging and supporting the country as a whole and its people as a whole.  I believe, for instance, that what we have done on the visa waiver was particularly important because it showed not only the support that the European Union was giving to the process, and the intention to support implementation of the process, but also that this is part of a bigger picture which is the excellent bilateral relations that the European Union has with Colombia, and also that this is framed into an even bigger picture which is the strategic relations between the European Union and Latin America, and in particular with some countries in Latin America with which our relations are developing in an extremely positive way, especially in the last year.  President Santos and I met probably four or five times in the last year and past couple of months. The last time was in December in Brussels where we witnessed together the signing of the visa waiver, but we were meeting regularly before that. I would say we were having a meeting every couple of months, every time that we crossed each other around the world, whether in the margins of the Cumbre de las Americas or in the General Assembly, to pass the message to him, but first of all to listen to him about what we could do to better support the process.  Even the decision to appoint a Special Envoy and to identify him or her – in this case it is him – in Eamon Gilmore came out of a conversation with President Santos, who believed this would be a positive sign, and a positive experience in negotiating the process given the experience that Gilmore has with the Northern Ireland process, and on working on the follow-up, which might be even more difficult than the process of agreeing on the agreement itself. Let me also say that I believe this is – and some of you mentioned this – an example of what the European Union’s role can be in the world. It is first of all a sign that our engagement is precious, including in places that we might perceive as being far away from us.  Our focus in these dramatic times is obviously on our neighbourhood, in our region: south, east, and I would also say north and west. It might be strange to hear this from an Italian but I believe that our work on the Arctic has to be substantial and consistent because it is probably the new frontier for many things.  Certainly we have a priority in making sure that our region becomes a little bit safer and more stable than it is now, but our added value is incredibly high, including in places around the world: in Asia, in Latin America, in Africa. Not necessarily everywhere, but in specific places where history, politics, sometimes the economy, sometimes people-to-people exchanges and culture mean that the links and ties make our position and our contribution somehow special and valuable for institutions or people.  This is one of those cases. This is the global role of the European Union. This is our strength. This is the strength of our contribution, somehow, to peace in the world. I know that these are words that sometimes we feel a little bit naive in saying but, at the end of the day, this is our interest: promoting and trying to facilitate peace in the world. But this is also the role of the European Union: investing in some models for trying to find a way out of conflicts. Some of you said that it is much more difficult to put an end to a conflict than to start a conflict. I could not agree more. That is why it is much more convenient for us to invest in conflict prevention than to try to find a way out of a conflict that has already exploded.  But there is a way – I would say a European way – of facilitating dialogue, facilitating cooperation, finding mediation, encouraging compromise also, because this comes from our history too. This will come up in the following debate on the situation in Syria and the debate after that on tensions in the Middle East.  At the end of the day, it is always the same story. European history is a history of conflicts – centuries of conflicts – that we have somehow spread around the world, dragging others into our own conflicts and wars, and which we finally managed to stop at the point when we discovered that regional cooperation and reconciliation within Europe was the way out.  That brought us peace, stability and prosperity, even if we sometimes tend to forget this today. So it is our European way that can bring hope and in some way good stories around the world. It is also the role of the European Union to invest in good stories, making them possible, and, once they do happen, making them sustainable, making them last and making them work, which is not something that we can ever take for granted.  Let me finish by saying that I really appreciate the unity you are showing in this, in the debate and in the vote you are going to take. Let me say that I am completely sure that our friends in Colombia are going to notice and appreciate this. These are exactly the kind of signs that also bring an added value to a difficult process, in terms of encouragement and political support, which is precious in these difficult times. Some of you mentioned Pope Francis. Let me conclude by quoting him on something that is also somehow a European way of seeing things. Pope Francis said that the night of violence can turn into a day with no sunset, a day of concord and justice so that there can be lasting peace. Please, we cannot afford another failure on the path to peace and reconciliation. This is the spirit, I think, in which we engage, we continue to engage, with our Colombian friends, knowing that the way ahead is still difficult and we should not take it for granted, but knowing that it is possible. I am also convinced that 2016 can be the year when this conflict finally comes to an end and Colombia can find its peace.

name: Presidente. –
text: I have received 7 motions for resolutions pursuant to Rule 123(2) of the Rules of Procedure. The debate is closed. The vote will take place tomorrow, Wednesday 20 January, at 12.30 p.m.

name: Presidente. –
text: The next item is the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the situation in Syria (2015/2517(RSP)).

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs. – Mr President, in Syria we are facing the biggest humanitarian tragedy in our region since the Second World War. Six and a half million Syrians are internally displaced, and if the fighting continues these could be the refugees of tomorrow. Around 400 000 Syrians have no access to humanitarian aid, especially in areas that are besieged. We now have 4.6 million Syrian refugees in the neighbouring countries, with chances being high that this number will continue to grow due to intense fighting on the ground. Starvation inside Syria is used as a means of warfare against the weakest and most vulnerable people on the ground, in particular against women and children. The Syrian Government has now guaranteed humanitarian access in Madaya, but this is far from being enough. In other ongoing sieges, people have been trapped for months, unable to exit, with no access to food, no access to medication and no access to basic services. Several local ceasefires reached in recent months are a reason for hope, for example in the Waer neighbourhood of Homs, but still they stopped far short. The goal of a nationwide ceasefire between the government and the opposition is an urgent one. The bombings and targeting of civilian areas and structures such as hospitals and schools, in particular by the Syrian regime and its allies, are unacceptable. This is why it is crucial that, in parallel with the efforts to start a political process, we call for all parties to cease all attacks and bombing of civilian targets, to put an end to the sieges of civilian areas and to fully respect international humanitarian law. It would be a disaster if, as we manage hopefully to start the political process, the situation on the ground does not improve; the credibility of the whole process would suffer enormously.  Some progress was made in the fight against Da’esh in Iraq, but less so in Syria. Let me say very clearly that the terrorist group cannot and will most probably not be fully defeated if the civil war in Syria continues.
