Daesh bases its own survival and its propaganda on sectarian strife and chaos in Syria and in Iraq, and only a united Syria – only a Syria that puts an end to its own civil war and finds ways to reconciliation – will defeat Daesh once and for all.  In these weeks and days, this is somehow a real condition to not only fight, but also to defeat, Daesh. We have worked hard to build such a united front outside Syria and inside Syria, with the European Union playing a crucial role first and foremost for humanitarian reasons, but also because we know very well that ending the war in Syria concerns our own security because it is clearly the condition to better fight against Daesh, and it is in our own interests. The consensus we reached in the International Syria Support Group – first in Vienna with two rounds of difficult but successful talks, and then in New York in December – led to the unanimous adoption of UN Security Council Resolution 2254 last December.  Finally, we managed to unite the international community around a roadmap, endorsing the talks in Vienna, their format and their content, and showing the Syrians and the regional actors that there is unity on the international side to indicate the way forward. The resolution calls for intra-Syrian talks between the government and the opposition. Preparations are underway and the talks are foreseen to start in Geneva next week. The resolution sets up a schedule of six months for the establishment of inclusive and credible governance in Syria and a target of 18 months for free and fair elections based on a new Syrian constitution with the clarification of the fact that wherever the election takes place it will have to see the Syrians outside Syria taking part in it too.  In parallel with the political process, the resolution also calls for the development of confidence-building measures between parties in conflict and for a mechanism of implementation and the monitoring of ceasefire. This is clearly a very ambitious calendar, a very ambitious agenda, but it is clear that we cannot afford to waste time and we have to set high objectives in order to have some hope that the process starts. As peace gets closer – as the possibility of starting this process gets real – we see that the resistance from the enemies of peace is getting even stronger. I believe we should consider the current phase as a window of opportunity that was not there in the past years. Let me say that this window might not be open forever if we miss this chance, and let me add that I believe that we finally managed to bring all the different regional actors around the same table on the Syrian conflict partly because we managed last July to find an agreement on the Iranian deal, opening the way for the possibility – although not yet the reality – of a different kind of cooperation in the region. We will discuss that in the next debate. The conditions are there again, but the way forward will be bumpy, difficult and challenging for all.  The UN Special Envoy for Syria, Staffan de Mistura, has our full and united support. We have put this issue on the agenda of all the last Foreign Affairs Council meetings – the last one took place just yesterday – and we discussed at length on how, united, we can support the process and the work of Staffan de Mistura. I am in constant contact with him; I met him just a few days ago in Brussels to discuss exactly the preparation of the talks, the way ahead, and how the European Union as such, together with the Member States, in a coordinated way, can further contribute to the implementation of the UN Security Council Resolution. Yesterday, the Foreign Affairs Ministers discussed Syria and our further work on the implementation of this resolution. The European Union and the Member States will provide support to the intra-Syrian talks and the entire transition process in terms of mediation, expertise and consensus—building. We will support the ceasefires, and once the ceasefires are in place – whether local ceasefires or a national ceasefire – we are preparing to step up our aid to the Syrian people. This also includes local governance needs, rehabilitation and reconstruction of the country, because it is key that, as we are trying to do in Iraq, liberated areas or areas in times of ceasefire or peace are immediately supported with humanitarian aid wherever the access of humanitarian aid is possible. As you know, the European Union is the biggest donor to the management of the Syrian crisis, with almost EUR 5 billion that we have mobilised so far. The Ministers also agreed yesterday on a European Union common approach and preparation towards the upcoming Syria-London conference that will be hosted in London by the UK and co-hosted by Germany, Norway and Kuwait on 4 February. We have already prepared substantial support to Turkey. We are putting together further additional comprehensive support packages for Jordan and Lebanon, not only to support them in their remarkable work in protecting and hosting refugees, but also to strengthen the resilience of the two countries, which has been tested in different ways in each country, and it is a top priority for the European Union to invest in the resilience of these two countries in order to prevent them from facing major security , social, economic or political problems that could turn the crisis in Syria into something even bigger.  In addition, we need to be ready for the fast deployment of humanitarian and civilisation aid once the conditions change inside Syria to make sure that, if and when we get to the point of something close to peace, the country can be rebuilt in all forms.  Later in the evening, we will discuss the current tensions between Saudi Arabia and Iran. Let me just reiterate that I had lengthy discussions with the Foreign Ministers of both countries to convey the message that it is vital that the Syrian talks are protected and that there is no serious spillover of these bilateral tensions over this multilateral process that has finally, and in a difficult way, started. It is also vital that together as Europeans, in a coordinated way, and together with our partners, starting with the United States but also others, we pass on the same message to all the interlocutors in the region.  All those with influence over the warring parties inside Syria should help them walk the difficult path towards peace. Confidence-building measures in particular have to be implemented immediately to create a favourable environment for the talks, and to guarantee that the process is credible and delivers to the Syrian people immediately.  This is a critical phase for the political process. What we agreed on in Vienna and New York with regional and international actors has to become reality on the ground, otherwise it will not fly. Only the Syrian parties and people can make this happen with the help of the international community, which, as I see, is ready to do that.  Last week I met with Riad Hijab, the coordinator of the Syrian opposition’s High Negotiations Committee, and I confirmed the EU’s readiness to support these talks and to provide capacity-building during negotiations and afterwards and during the political transition when it starts. We also support the work of the UN Envoy for inclusive representation in the talks and accompany him in the difficult task of arranging the way in which the talks can be organised. Only a comprehensive representation of Syrian groups will help us to reach the much needed consensus for the way ahead.  Let me also say something that is not normally mentioned: the role of Syrian society in managing the way out of this conflict. I believe the civil society inside Syria will play a major role in the implementation and monitoring of confidence-building measures, for example local ceasefires, and so the civil society in its different parts and ways needs to be brought into the discussion as early as possible, and all minorities and religious groups should have a say. Excluding this or that group on sectarian or ethnic grounds would be a non-starter. Inclusiveness is the only way forward towards national reconciliation and will be the most powerful and the most effective way to defeat Daesh: we have seen this in the past in Iraq. We have to try to avoid the mistakes that were made in previous years.  The work to build a democratic, non-sectarian, inclusive Syria has only just begun, but we are finally heading in the right direction. Peace in Syria is possible, and we have shown in the last year that some incredible things and positive things are indeed possible. The transition can start and Daesh can be defeated. The international and regional players have finally united after five years, five long years of work to make it possible, and it is now time for the Syrians to take this opportunity to start the transition, to stop the war, and to stop Daesh, and they will need to know – as we have been telling them all – that we will be at their side , continuing to work for the unity of the international community and the region to make this process possible.  I have just received news that relates to the previous discussion: if I may give the good news to plenary, Mr President, the Colombian government and FARC have just announced a Havana agreement on a bilateral ceasefire and a mechanism to implement it. We have just received a call from our ambassador in Bogotá, so do this more often!

name: Presidente. –
text: Mr Vice-President, let us open the debate on your statements on the situation in Syria. First of all, let us hear the assessments of the political groups.

name: Mariya Gabriel
text: on behalf of the EPP group. Mr President, Madam High Representative, first of all, thank you for your commitment and your clear messages. Yes, you have shown that today: the challenge for the European Union is to ensure that progress is made both politically and humanitarianly. With that in mind, I would like to draw attention to four elements. Firstly, the "Madad" trust fund and the contribution of the Member States. We know that in order to manage the humanitarian situation, we must act today, but also anticipate tomorrow. Member States must keep their promises and remember that this is also a response to the refugee crisis that occupies them so much. Secondly, in view of the Geneva talks, it is clear that developments on the ground must reflect the commitment of all parties to this political process, not only as a sign of good faith, but also to avoid any disconnect between the aspirations of Syrians and the agreements reached between the representatives involved in the negotiations ahead of the transition. Third, the crucial issue of the composition of the opposition delegation and the participants in the negotiations. Two points: on the one hand, the divisions among the members of the international support group on this issue should not hinder the process between Syrians - the December 2015 Security Council resolution is clear on this point; on the other hand, but I know that Mistura's special envoy pays special attention to it, women's participation, a key element in principle, is like an investment in syria's future. Finally, the exchange of views you had yesterday with the Minister of Foreign Affairs of Jordan, as well as the ongoing dialogue with Lebanon, are very positive points. As you said: managing crises, yes; investing in key partners in the Mediterranean, doubly yes, beyond the refugee crisis. This too is part of the situation in Syria, from which we are learning.

name: Victor Boştinaru
text: on behalf of the S&D group – Mr President, the civil war in Syria is entering its sixth year, already. And last week we witnessed in horror the tragedy at Madaya, which provided yet another sample of the madness that war, violence, confrontation can bring to a country. We lived with the image of Syrian children starving to death and we were happy when, finally, a humanitarian convoy managed to break into a besieged city, where nearly 40,000 people had been starving for months. Other cities on Syria's western border are in the same situation. I reiterate here the statement of UN Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon: "the use of starvation as a weapon is a war crime and will have to be treated this way".  It is clear that we need an immediate political solution and this can only be possible through the implementation of the Vienna Agreement and Resolution 2254, which were adopted with the substantial support of the European Union and yours. We need a political solution knowing that only it can create conditions for a lasting peace. Bombings, including Russian ones, which indiscriminately destroy civilian targets, constructions and also target in moderate opposition are counterproductive.  A political solution must involve, as you mentioned, Iran, Turkey, Russia, Saudi Arabia, the other local and regional actors, and in this respect I welcome the UN effort for confidentiality-building measures and wish success to the Donors' Conference for Syria, which will take place on 4 February.  We know very well that peace in Syria is the guarantee for the defeat of Daesh, it is the guarantee for reducing the flow of refugees, and it is also the guarantee that this madness of violence, which Daesh has generated, will be defeated. I wish you luck!

name: Bas Belder
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – I would like to raise two issues in the Syrian tragedy. The starvation of at least 400,000 civilians in besieged areas and the depriving of the Christian minority by the Syrian Kurds.  Madaya has become synonymous with deliberate starvation of the civilian population for war purposes. This includes the civilians of Fou'ah and Kafraya (near Idlib), Nubl and Zahra (near Aleppo) and Deir al-Zor, where 200,000 Syrians are besieged by islamic State. What I have heard today about what is happening there is shocking. All of these places are in areas where anti-IS coalition aircraft are flying, including those from some European countries.  My question - which I am also being supplied with from the region itself - to the High Representative: Why are food parcels only dropped here by the Russians and do you not hear about Europe?  I would also like to draw your attention to the legal status of Christians and churches in the Kurdish region of Syria. Confiscation of homes and property of displaced Christians and Kurdish attacks on checkpoints in Christian neighbourhoods in the towns of al-Hakaseh and Qamishli call for a strong, dismissive European response. I have sympathy for the Kurds, but rights are for everyone. It is not a Kurdish process in Syria, it is already suffering enough!

name: Pavel Telička
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, I would firstly, like to congratulate the Vice-President on Colombia. I will be happy to be here in a few months’ time, even at midnight, to congratulate her also on Syria. I do not want to be redundant because a lot of what she has said would be my conclusions having read through the rather large file in the last couple of days, but let me say a few words anyway. Firstly, it is clear that the five bloody years of a very bloody war has had its influence, its impact. It has had its impact primarily, of course, on the Syrians, but it can be felt across the world. We can see the devastating consequences of the Daesh terrorist attacks on the French, the Russians, the Turks, the Lebanese and the Saudis, just to mention some of them. I think that last year was a wake-up call for Europeans, in particular. The Syrian war is clearly reshaping politics across the continent, especially as the response to a surge of Syrian refugees has called even the European Union’s raison d’être into question. The November 2015 terrorist attacks in Paris have meant in reality that the threat is driving day-to-day concerns across the continent. I very much believe that we will make progress in Geneva. We cannot fail, but there are four points which I think are preconditions, and for the sake of time, I will exceptionally read them out. Firstly, all sides, including the Assad regime, Russia and Iran, must abide by the UN Security Council resolution 2254: ‘fulfil its demand to immediately cease military attacks against civilians, and to allow humanitarian aid across Syria to help all people in need, including the besieged areas’. Of course, Madaya has to be mentioned among them.  Any political situation is hardly imaginable without concrete humanitarian improvements for the people in Syria.  Secondly, that the talks have a clear agenda and deliver a real political transition towards non-sectarian inclusive governance without Assad. The EU must step up its efforts on the international scene and get all the other regional and global powers to respect the agreements made and to constructively back this process. Finally, de-escalating the broader war in Syria: this is a prerequisite for any effective campaign against ISIS. No military strategy against a group that is detached from the wider Syrian dynamics will be effective, as many of the key actors needed to defeat ISIS have their own priorities. I wish you the best of luck, and of course I am happy that that the Czech Embassy in Syria, now being the last EU embassy, will be providing a helping hand on the humanitarian side, especially on the infrastructure we have in place.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Madam President, I do not really know whether there is anyone in this Chamber who can say something substantial, something that is workable for Syria. If there is one of us, perhaps one should be sought among a handful of people in this room who, when everyone was talking about the Arab Spring, we shouted as loudly as we could that, on the contrary, a heavy frozen Arab Winter is coming. We were looked at at at the time by some people with anger. So today with the millions of refugees, with the hundreds of thousands of dead, with drownings in the Aegean, if there is still a solution, let these leaders of Europe and the world pursue it, bringing the warring sides in Syria, pro-government and opposition, to the same table. The dangers are growing with tension between Saudi Arabia and Iran, but also with the full deployment of Turkey's war machines against the Kurds within their own country. But to be fair to all, I would like to appeal to you, Mrs Mogherini, make a phone call to the former President of the United States, Mr Mogherini. Bush, and tell him everything about his politics in the region. It is every bit of an inconsistency and a policy - I say this with irony - of perceptiveness. Tell him 'five million refugees, three hundred thousand dead and thousands drowned in the Mediterranean', just so he knows we know.

name: Barbara Lochbihler
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Madam President, High Representative, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. The Vienna talks in November had raised new hopes for peace negotiations in Syria.  In the meantime, this process has already stalled again, and it is questionable whether the meeting scheduled for this month in Geneva can take place at all. It is foreseeable that the negotiations will not progress as long as there is no agreement on key critical points. One of the central preconditions of the Syrian opposition is that government forces and their allies stop both the bombing of civilians and hunger blockades.  These demands remain unfulfilled, as the cruel conditions in besieged Madaya have made clear. The EU must therefore put particular pressure on Syria's allies Russia and Iran to put an end to this war against civilians.  Furthermore, it is necessary to clarify which actors will be involved before a next round of negotiations. In particular, the EU should take a clear position on the participation of the Syrian Kurds. In principle, we should argue for an approach that is as inclusive as possible. It is also crucial to work to improve the humanitarian situation of Syrian civilians, including in neighbouring countries. At the donors' conference scheduled for February in London, the EU should ensure that sufficient resources are made available for humanitarian aid in the region and that it arrives in time for the suffering population.

name: Mario Borghezio
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, we must not Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, on the intra-Syrian talks scheduled for 25 January, I would like to know whether the High Commissioner also knows that the same meeting could in fact be postponed due to non-agreements. De Mistura himself has admitted that he does not know exactly which opposition entities will have to participate in the dialogues, so it seems to me that we are still quite far away. Of course, ambitious objectives, but we also need to know how to achieve them.  I believe that we must also speak out about those responsible for the humanitarian situation, not only denounce it, but also denounce the role, for example, of the fundamentalist ala of the Syrian opposition, turkey, you never tell us about Turkey's role, yet It seems to me that it would be interesting to know the European Union's position on the illegal trade in Syrian and Iraqi oil from Isis to Turkey through Syrian territory. , the knowledge of whether russian footage is true or true. We need to know what the situation is, we in Europe, in this area through the communications that come to us from Moscow. And then, fight Daesh and I will end: but the fight against Daesh is being done by Russia, the Russian bombing. That is the truth. Other things don't exist. That is the truth!

name: Bruno Gollnisch (NI).
text: Madam President, 200,000 human victims, 300 treasures of humanity threatened, in particular, by Islamist vandalism, the unfortunate Christians of Syria driven from their homes, killed, slit, crucified, their children forced to witness, as in Hassake, the beheading of their own. Of course, it has to stop, but for it to stop, there are a number of conditions that need to be met. The first is to discuss with the legal government of this country, whatever one thinks of it, which is an interlocutor that cannot be circumvented. The second is that Turkey, Saudi Arabia and Qatar must stop aiding the jihadist movement. The third is that all interested states, including Iran, Russia and of course the permanent members of the Security Council, must be involved. The fourth is that we must not have the naivety to believe that we will simply settle by an electoral majority resulting in free elections in which even refugees who have left the country would participate. Jihadists will never accept any such agreement! It is therefore necessary, and this is the fifth condition, that peace be restored, if necessary by force. This force must be an international force provided by Muslim states that are not parties to this conflict and guided by the permanent members of the Un Security Council. It is not the Western bombing that will bring peace to this unfortunate country.

name: Jaromír Štětina (PPE).
text: – Madam President, the Islamic State and President Assad's regime are the main players in the civil war. Meanwhile, the Assad regime stands and falls with cooperation with foreign allies. Russia stepped up militarily in September last year in support of the Assad regime at a time when Assad's opponents were gaining the upper hand. In fact, they saved the Assad regime, prolonged the war, and caused a new wave of refugees. Unfortunately, there have been voices in the European Union recently calling for cooperation with Assad and the Russian Federation. For example, Czech President Miloš Zeman has openly called for support for Assad. Even at home, in the European Parliament, there are increasingly views that cooperation with Russia in the fight against terror is needed. I consider this situation absurd and schizophrenic for two reasons. Firstly, they are challenges to cooperate with a country that is itself committing state terror. On the one hand, do we want to sanction Russia, on the other, to cooperate with it? Second, the Assad regime is far more dangerous to the average Syrian than the Islamic State. While IS has caused some 1,400 civilian deaths in 2015, Assad has killed more than 12,000 Syrians in the same period, including 2,600 children and 2,000 women. This comparison is made by the Syrian Network for Human Rights, a serious organisation working for the UN as well.  It also brings in the numbers of Syrians who have been tortured by the Assad regime. The government's violation of human rights is also out of the hands of Islamic State terrorists.

name: Josef Weidenholzer (S&D).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The events in Syria are a tremendous tragedy. Hundreds of thousands of dead, destroyed landscapes, half the population has lost their livelihoods, almost five million have fled abroad, we all know these figures. Neighbouring regions are facing unimaginable stress tests, and the wave of refugees is also becoming a test for the European Union. A swift end to the Syrian war is more necessary than ever. We all yearn for this day. For many, the UN resolution is the famous light at the end of the tunnel, because it brings all the parties to the conflict to the table for the first time. I believe that there is every hope that something will move. I would also like to take this opportunity to express my thanks to the High Representative for her efforts, which she has often made beyond the light of the public in this direction. While we are all looking forward to the next few weeks, the war continues. People are dying, some are starving, people are fleeing from the bombs that are supposed to end the war and from the barrel bombs of the regime. And Da'esh is still not defeated. It is not enough to hope for the great miracle, but we must at last keep our promises at the same time. We need safe areas where people can return. Most people want that. I saw this myself in Kobane: every day thousands of people who want to go back, even though everything is destroyed. Many people will not experience peace because they are starving. The most humanitarian type of bombardment is raisin bombers. There are still many political prisoners. We need these people to build democracy, including, for example, the Internet activist Bassel Khartabil, a democrat of the first hour. We don't know if he's still alive. And we should also consider putting in place a new marshal's plan for the region. This is the basis for people to return.

name: Marietje Schaake (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, now the Iran deal has been implemented, I call on the High Representative to involve the Islamic Republic of Iran to stop the war in Syria and to cease its support for Assad. The images of starving children in Madaya remind us of the ongoing horrors that innocent people in Syria are suffering. It is 2016 and it seems as if we have forgotten that we pledged ‘never again’. They are still being bombed by Assad and Russian airstrikes alike, and we must do more. In fact the EU must do all it can. We should all ask more of ourselves in this incredibly dire situation. We must show more leadership because, without it and without serious commitment to humanitarian aid that has to be ongoing, refugees will continue to flee from in and around Syria. It is unacceptable and also very unhelpful that we only start to consider Syria suffering a crisis when it impacts us through ISIS terror or through refugees coming to Europe. I think that has been the motive for too many Member States and it has to end. We need to do more.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, in a few weeks, the Syrians will have a very sad anniversary: five years of war. The famous promised Arab Spring has actually proved to be a nightmare for the civilian population. Syria is in chaos, to which Western governments have largely contributed by their support for the Syrian rebellion, made up of relatively moderate jihadists. The disaster of the American and French interventions in Iraq and Libya did not serve as a lesson. Even today, the number one enemy is the Syrian regime, which is accused of starving madaya's 40,000 inhabitants. But we forget to say that this city is held by Islamists from the al-Nusra Front and the Salafists of Ahrar al-Sham. I would add that, according to local newspapers, they are diverting international aid and reselling it at a gold price.  Let me also recall the suffering of the inhabitants of Foua and Kefraya, who are besieged by Islamist rebels because of their loyalty to the Syrian government. At a time when the Islamic State is retreating in Iraq and Syria, but is back on the offensive in Libya and emulsing the world, it is urgent that our nations normalize diplomatic relations with the Syrian government, with the latest report by the organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons claiming that the Syrian authorities have completely destroyed their chemical weapons stockpiles. He should encourage us to do that.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D).
text: – Madam President, recently we have seen harrowing images of starving children, women and elderly people in the Syrian town of Madaya. Starvation and siege is being used by the Syrian regime as a weapon of war and collective punishment. Food, water and medicine cannot be bargaining chips. Let us be clear: using starvation and siege as weapons is a war crime. Madaya is not the only Syrian city under siege: the UN estimates that 400,000 people are going hungry in 14 areas.  The EU should assist in ensuring that immediate access for the delivery of humanitarian assistance is possible. ISIS and its counterparts will continue to grow for as long as the international community continues to allow this starvation, torture and the massacre of millions. We must continue on the plan of action agreed on in the Vienna process. With the support of the international community, we can negotiate a political solution and a transition. Your decision, Madam High Representative, to give trade preferences to Jordan is a welcome move. I also welcome, in this respect, Saudi Arabia’s efforts in bringing all the oppositions together and forming a broad coalition of Muslim countries dedicated to fighting terrorism. We, the EU, are urging Iran and Saudi Arabia to find a way to work together to end the region’s worst humanitarian crisis. It is time to end the conflict and bring peace and prosperity to all the people of Syria.  (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – Mr Khan, your leader Jeremy Corbyn has said that ISIS has its strong points. Do you agree with him, and if so, what are they?

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: blue-card answer. – Well, all I know is that we need to deal with ISIS: they use the name of Islam in causing so much harm in the whole world, and I think the more we work together in order to eliminate ISIS the better.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, to the point where we are in this evening's debate, what we can add is to urge you – in addition to the important work you are doing throughout the local scenario – to concentrate all my efforts on making it credible that the decisions taken at the UN in December, through Resolution 2254, the roadmap that has been defined as the timetable for the , are really concrete measures in the coming weeks and days. So give you this act of confidence from parliament as a whole.  Work so that this opportunity that has opened up can really be practiced and won knowing that there are so many obstacles along the way. There is a humanitarian tragedy going on. I insist, as I said the other time when we met again in this House, there is above all the tragedy of a generation of Syrian boys and girls, especially children, on whom we should focus an effort, a real educational Marshall Plan. And then there is the increasing violence, the difficulty of implementing the ceasefire. To me they seem to be two essential conditions – I end – to overcome and work to overcome the mistrust that there are between the various groups that make up the anti-Daesh group and then above all, I believe, spread that positive climate that the Iran agreement has thrown ... (The President cut the speaker off)

name: Eugen Freund (S&D).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her We are right to complain time and again that our decisions, or even the declarations of intent of the international community, are being implemented very slowly. Unfortunately, the peace process around Syria also belongs to this category. Because you have just spoken of the good news you have received in relation to Colombia, I now have bad news. After all, there are arguments about, writes the New York Times in the evening, who the opposition should sit at the table on Monday and whether the meeting will come about at all. Dozens of Syrians die every day because we all want peace, but we only go there at a creeping pace. The last sad example is the aid measures for the city of Madaya, which have already been mentioned several times. They did not come until people died of hunger. The peace process is, of course, difficult. But, as with the nuclear negotiations with Iran, Europe needs to become even more involved in this. Not only because of the refugees, but also because of the people who are still living there! And I'm afraid - We switch to Englich now: Maybe you should start working the phones and get all these people together right away

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (S&D).
text: Madam President, the tragedy of the Syrian people continues with thousands of dead and millions of internal and external appeals. A waste of hope opened after the Vienna meetings, where with the participation of all involved we came up with a clean resolution process. But despite the granting of humanitarian aid, only last weekend we had five people killed by starvation in the town of Madaya , while Daesh murdered 135 civilians and kidnapped some four hundred.  We must take a more active role in order to implement the timetable consistently and in order to have a single and peaceful Syria, away from dangerous geostrategic scenarios that threaten the countries of the region. Finally, I would like to address the issue of the refugee crisis. It is obvious that it is not possible to de-escalation without normalisation in Syria. It is also necessary for European leaders to implement the decisions taken, in particular those concerning relocation, and not to return to their countries after each session determined to undermine the agreement by their inaction.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE).
text: - Madam President, I think it is essential to find a political solution to the conflict between all interested parties so that the situation in Syria can begin after 5 years of war gradually resolved and for peace talks to yield results. The danger daesh poses is too serious and requires communion and immediate reaction.  According to available data, Daesh attacked 35 Christian villages in February 2015 alone, kidnapping over 250 people and forcing 3,000 from their homes. The situation today is even worse. Starving, expelling and killing Christians is a grave loss for all of us, and especially for Syria, whose society must understand that respect for human rights and religious freedom is one of the cornerstones of any democratic development. We must do everything in our power to encourage all actors to take concrete action against Daesh and to achieve much needed peace.

name: Marju Lauristin (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I would first like to thank Ms Mogherini for all she is doing, but especially for this very, very cautious but nevertheless hopeful message which she brought here today concerning developments, concerning the window of opportunity. We have to use that, and in this sense I also want to say that maybe we have to start thinking more about the post-conflict future of Syria, giving a message also to the people of Syria, including people who are now here in refugee lines and camps. You said very rightly that we should not repeat the mistakes made in Iraq and Afghanistan. One of those was that these countries were not provided by the West, by the democratic part of the world, with the human resources needed to build up a new democratic Iraq. What we can do really is give a message to the young people in these refugee lines that maybe their best future, the best realisation of their hopes, will be to prepare themselves to be trained and educated in order to go back to Syria, not only to improve their own lives, but also to give a future for Syria. That could be part of this Marshall Plan because really now we need a Marshall Plan for the future Syria.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Madam President, the defeat of Daesh depends directly on the end of the civil war in Syria and the launch of the peace process for the political resolution of Syria and for the democratic formation of the State of Syria, with a new Constitution and democratic elections. At the same time, the forces that support and cooperate with the jihadists must be isolated, and this concerns primarily Turkey, Saudi Arabia and Qatar, which support and assist the jihadists.  Instead, the European Union not only tolerates Ankara's games but also gives it a dowry of EUR 3 billion for Turkey's supposed assistance in the refugee problem. In the refugee camp, where Turkey helps the slave trade that transports thousands of refugees to the Aegean islands every day, they can't stand other refugees and illegal immigrants. So if we want to approach the situation more energetically, if we want to tackle the problems, then the hot spots will have to be created where the refugees are, that is, in Turkey.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, Madam High Representative, I disagree on a few things. There is said to be no progress in Syria. Clearly, there are no ones that would be wished when we have such democratic friends as Turkey or as Saudi Arabia, who are doing not only the blind eye, but even allowing oil smuggling, and who are even now bombing their own people in Kurdistan. What we didn't see is progress from that so-called coalition that was not coordinated with governments.  We should change, I believe, the vision – that obsessive vision that the United States has – and have our own vision – of the European Union – and follow what it has set us: that we must also talk to the Syrian government. Sttafan de Mistura was complaining that intrasirian dialogue may not take take part. Syria's future is not to be marked by eer the United States or the European Union, not even Russia, the Syrians themselves and the Syrians have to mark it with that plan that is advancing in Vienna, New York and possibly Geneva.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, after so many ambiguities on the part of many of the powers involved, 400 thousand dead, 6.5 million refugees, the negotiating table that many of us wanted has finally started. There is much to be said about the requirements of the selected interlocutors: it is a pain to remember that several organisations included on the list by the Saudis present ambiguities regarding extremism and jihadism. But the real question is: do the regional players most involved really want this peace? If I were to judge the recent tension fuelled by Saudi anger after the execution of Nimr al-Nimr, I would say no. Perhaps certain priorities on the political agenda are more important, and we will discuss them again later. And let us not talk about the Turkish position. The real political issue we need to resolve is the future of Assad, which is far from being resolved. And on this issue, many people, Russia, Iran, the USA, continue to take their time.  It is undeniable, however, that the time is right for this potential cooperation, and so I wonder: what priority action should we take? We need to cut off weapons and money in Daesh. The legislation of Qatar and Kuweit is still insufficient to guarantee this objective, funding continues to arrive. Even today refineries and wells work in Syria and Iraq, trade is not interrupted for trade. If we want to defeat them, that is the high road, even if it takes difficult choices to pursue it.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI).
text: Madam President, my opinion is that the European Union is also reluctant in the case of Syria to implement the policy that guarantees the resolution of the problem. It simply prefers to deal with the issue in general, as if it were a literary activity, without taking the measures that can solve the problem. Time is running out, the humanitarian crisis in the country is getting worse every day, many civilians are losing their lives either to the ongoing fighting or to the criminal activity of Daesh, but the European Union is simply observing the facts. There are few and very simple moves to be made. First of all, those countries that support the jihadists, namely Turkey, Qatar and Saudi Arabia, must be isolated. Secondly, Russia, President Assad, the Syrian Kurds and the Syrian opposition must be invited directly to negotiations. They must decide what form the new governance of the country will take and together turn against ISIS in order to neutralize it and end this bloodshed, which does not pay any price to either civilized humanity or the European Union.

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, let me first of all say that yes, I am trying to indicate some signs of hope because I am really convinced that if we do not identify the reasons for hope on the way ahead, it is very difficult to work on the change that is needed to get to a better place. But, indeed, the way is going to be difficult and long.  Please do not expect any dramatic turning point any time soon. What we have finally done is to be on the right track, but we are far from having a solution to the war or an end to the war. However it is true that if you look back one year ago to when we had no unity within the international community, no unity in the region and no path, no process, no roadmap, no calendar, then we are certainly in a much better place today, and this allows us to have a sense of direction and to create the conditions for the talks to start, for the roadmap to be implemented, the calendar to be fulfilled.  I believe this is our role as the European Union, coordinated with all our Member States, both those that are sitting at the table and those that are not sitting there. That is also why, for me, it is extremely important to constantly put the issue of the Syrian crisis on the agenda of the Foreign Affairs Council to make sure that all 28 are fully involved in the process and that, when we are sitting there, all the European Union is present and there is constant feedback both ways.  I am glad that we can do the same with Parliament because, as you know very well, Parliament is for me a very important actor in our external action. But this is, I believe, our role: not so much setting conditions or preconditions, but trying to create the conditions for the talks to start and to be productive, in strong cooperation with the United Nations.  Many of you asked questions about the composition of the opposition’s delegation, the time, the modalities, the formats of the talks, whether the talks will happen on Monday of next week or whether they will be delayed. We have obviously discussed all of that, not just with the Foreign Affairs Ministers yesterday but I also discussed these issues personally with Staffan de Mistura just before he debriefed the Security Council yesterday.  Let me also say that there is a specific role for the UN Special Envoy, supported by the Support Group, but we have, I believe, as the European Union, to preserve the role of the United Nations in trying to define the modalities and the time of negotiations that they are going to lead. Also to guarantee that all the different actors in the region, and internationally, feel comfortable enough with the fact that the leading role of the UN guarantees that all are on an equal footing.  What is important for us as Europeans and what we are making clear is, as I said at the beginning, that in one way or another – that is in the hands of the UN Special Envoy to define – but in one way or another, we manage to find ways of guaranteeing that the entire Syrian society, all the different Syrian groups – those that were in Riyadh at the Conference and those that were not, provided that they sign up to the political process and they fight against Daesh, al-Nusra and the terrorist groups that are concentrally defined as terrorist groups – all of them find their own way of getting into the process and feel ownership. Because, as many of you said, the key point is having the Syrians decide on the future of the country and also on the present of their country – the Syrians, all Syrians, meaning also as I stressed, those that are outside the country.  What is also important is something that our colleague Mr Cozzolino said: working on the generations. We are losing generations of Syrians. They are losing their lives, they are losing their education, they are losing hope and this is something that Syria and the region will pay for, not just for years but for decades to come.  This is also why we are investing a lot of our finance, our money, but also our work in education programmes because we have to guarantee that a country that had a very high level of education for the overall population manages to continue to invest in its own future, because when the time comes that we have to work on the reconstruction of the country, we will have to have generations of Syrians ready to engage in a very difficult process of material and non-material rebuilding of the country.  So the knowledge, the competences, the experience, the education of entire generations has to be taken care of now, because otherwise we will have serious problems in five, 10, 15, 20 years from now. Also in terms of radicalisation because the young generations that are experiencing today only war, conflict, starvation, and life in refugee camps in the best option might not necessarily be the best citizens of tomorrow. So this is clearly not only a humanitarian must, but also a clear interest that we have in investing too in our own security and stability for the future.  Let me finish by saying that many questions were raised relating to debates that we will have either later tonight – the tensions between Saudi Arabia and Iran and the regional developments linked to that – and the situation in Turkey, the situation of religious minorities beginning with Christians: all things on which we have debates today, tomorrow, the day after tomorrow.  Here let me stress again one thing that I have shared with you already in the past. I very much enjoy spending time with you and exchanging views and I find it extremely useful for my work both in the Commission or in the Council as European Union High Representative, but I would suggest as a former member of parliament, not the European Parliament but a national one, I would humbly suggest that you find a way of defining a calendar for foreign policy debates that manages to focus on some key issues , that manages also to communicate to the outside world that Parliament is focusing on foreign affairs priorities month after month. This is a humble suggestion that maybe we could find a way of organising our work in order not to repeat similar discussions over the two or three days that we spend together every month.  Let me finish with one point. Someone raised a very specific point on support to Jordan in relation to trade. Let me say that we discussed this at length yesterday with Nasser Judeh, the Foreign Minister of Jordan, in a bilateral meeting and with the Foreign Affairs Council. I had the honour and the pleasure to discuss this with Her Majesty the Queen of Jordan last week in Brussels. This is going to be a proposal that I will put forward to support Jordan not only through financial support, but also with some exceptional temporary and targeted measures to increase and facilitate their trade with the European Union.  They are developing in view of the London Conference a very creative and ambitious plan to create job opportunities together for Jordanians and Syrian refugees, which I believe is going to be extremely important to making integration of Syrian refugees in the host communities sustainable in the mid-term, in the long term, without creating a conflict in these host communities, because the perspective of hosting Syrians in large numbers for a long time in a country that is surrounded by crisis and is not rich in natural resources in any particular way might create social or economic conflicts that we need to prevent.  I hope we can count on the support of this Parliament to work in this direction as well; not only financial support, direct support, for the hosting of refugees and the protection of refugees in the case of Jordan, but also trade measures that can help Jordan in the mid-term to invest in job creation and economic investment.  I will finish here, thanking you very much for the input that is for me extremely precious for the way ahead, hoping that the way forward will be as encouraging as it has been in these last three to four months, and that we will manage, in partnership with our main friends and partners in the region and on a global level , to facilitate and move this very difficult process forward, but again, finally, I think on the right track.

name: PUHEMIES. –
text: The debate is closed.  Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. – The situation in Syria is out of control. The new gruesome news of the executions of 400 civilians by the Islamic State in Deir Esor, the more than 220,000 deaths of the war since 2011 and the 4 million refugees created since then is a heavy price to pay by the Syrian people. The European Union plays a hypocritical role in supporting the US in igniting the war and turning its back on refugees seeking asylum on its territory. So far, more than 310,000 Syrians have applied for asylum in the European Union, and the governments of some Member States are concerned whether these people are Christians or are stripping them of the few valuables they have managed to bring with them to supposedly subsidize their housing. That's enough hypocrisy. The European Union must immediately stop becoming a leader in US foreign policy and must give practical support to the peace process in the region. As the Left, we stand by the refugees and the Syrian people, based on our principles of solidarity of the people.

name: PUHEMIES. –
text: The next item is the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission /High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the situation in Saudi Arabia and Iran (2015/2518(RSP)).

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. –  Madam President, before I get into the details of this topic, let me say a few words on what happened in Vienna on Saturday, where we showed that, exactly six months after having reached an agreement with Iran on their nuclear programme, Iran fulfilled the commitments we had agreed on. The IAEA verified this compliance and the international community, through the E3+3, the joint commission that I coordinate and that I, and my successor after me, will continue to coordinate for the whole duration of the agreement, verified that this has been done and therefore that the deal has been implemented. Let me reiterate that six months ago there were many people, in Europe, the region and the world, who were deeply sceptical as to whether we would ever manage to implement this agreement. They were betting on the possibility that Iran would not follow up the agreement with concrete deeds. Let me say that most of all it is a nuclear negotiation, a nuclear agreement, and this is the core of our satisfaction: the fact that we have prevented a major risk of nuclear proliferation and maybe even the possibility of a conflict in the region. This is the first reason for satisfaction, but there is another element of satisfaction linked to the fact that we have shown that multilateralism and diplomacy can work. As we saw in the previous debate, not only can it work in terms of reaching an agreement, it can also deliver in terms of implementation. So, in these difficult times there is good reason for hope. And let me also say, as I get to the real issue of our debate, though the two are closely connect, that there are two other elements for hope. One is the door that now opens for relations between Iran with the rest of the world – starting with the Europeans – and for us Europeans to engage in Iran in different ways and in different sectors. Finally, last but not least – and perhaps most importantly – this agreement could open the way to a different kind of relationship in the region.  Here we come to the issue of tonight because, after managing to hold negotiations for 13 years, with difficulties and ups and downs and a lot of scepticism, and achieving that historic result against all odds, we now have to invest in the possibility of a different kind of cooperation in the region. We are not naïve; we know very well that this will not be easy, that this will not happen overnight and that we will face obstacles and setbacks. The willingness of Iran to further cooperate on regional matters will have to be tested. But the fact that they have stated this willingness is already a step forward in respect to the past. Their will to implement the agreement they signed in July will also be tested. But just think back one year ago. Many believed we would never manage to agree on a strong deal with Iran, a verifiable and implementable deal, and we proved them wrong. If we keep working hard and together – united as Europeans and with the rest of the international community – I am sure we can keep surprising the sceptics somehow.  Dialogue among all regional powers, starting with Saudi Arabia and Iran is – we are united in believing – the only way out of the current turmoil in the Middle East. In the past few years, a struggle for regional hegemony has mixed with revamped ethnic and confessional tensions. Terrorist groups such as Daesh are fostering sectarianism to throw the region into even greater chaos and bolster their own power. International disputes between Saudi Arabia and Iran can easily play into the narrative of a war of religion between Sunni and Shia Muslims, and we know this very well. The risks of this are huge. New frictions can block the difficult path towards peace in Syria, as we have just discussed, but also in Yemen. We did not discuss that this time, but I think we will tomorrow. These frictions can destabilise Iraq and Lebanon, the two countries in the region that are most exposed to sectarian tensions. They can destabilise entire Muslim communities worldwide, from Asia to Africa, in the Horn and in the Sahel.  Bilateral tensions can, in this way, potentially inflame the region even more, prevent political processes from either starting or yielding results, and potentially inflame the war. This is why we are trying to contain and de-escalate these tensions in close coordination among ourselves as Europeans, with all the Member States. We are ensuring that we, our international partners, including the United States and, to mention just one, the Foreign Minister of Indonesia – whom I had on the phone just before her trip to Tehran and Saudi Arabia a few days ago – send a similar message to try and facilitate the containment and the de-escalation of the conflict. This shows how important this issue is in at least three continents, if not four, because potentially this could inflame communities around the world. As you may know, we reacted immediately on 2 January 2015 to the execution by the authorities of the Shia cleric, Sheikh Nimr al-Nimr, and 46 other individuals, most of whom had been convicted on terrorism charges in relation to their links to Al-Qaeda. As I expressed in the statement that I issued on the same day, the death penalty can in no way be sustainable or an efficient response to crime or terrorism. The EU opposes capital punishment under any circumstances, and we shall continue to consistently advocate for the universal abolition of the death penalty. This also refers to Iran, whose human rights record is worrying. This is the message that I conveyed, not only to the Foreign Minister of Saudi Arabia, but also to the Foreign Minister of Iran, whom I contacted at that time.  The specific case of Sheikh Nimr al-Nimr raises very serious concerns regarding issues such as freedom of expression and the respect of basic civil and political rights. These should be safeguarded in all cases. Also let me stress that, in the framework of the fight against terrorism, we have also taken an immediate position on the reactions in Iran because nothing can justify an attack on embassies or consulates, as happened with the Saudi Embassy in Tehran and the consulate in Mashhad. In the conversations I had with both the Iranian and the Saudi foreign ministers in the wake of these events, I stressed the need for Iran to abide by its international obligations. This also means ensuring the protection of diplomatic premises in all circumstances. In my phone call with both sides and in the contacts we had afterwards (we met with Mr Zarif over the weekend, among other people) the main message I passed on was to try to manage the bilateral tensions without inflaming the risk of spill-overs, especially in the region, to preserve our efforts for peace in Syria and Yemen and to avoid further destabilisation in the area , especially with regard to Iraq and Lebanon. I was given reassurances by both sides on the need to find a way of preserving this process. As we have said, for the Syria process to begin and have some chance of succeeding, it must be supported by all the regional players. For the same reason, to try to find common ways of protecting the process, early this year I discussed the situation, and the risks of it degenerating, with the UN special envoy for Syria, Staffan de Mistura, the Secretary-General of the Arab League, ministers of many Arab and African countries, and with some Asian ministers. We are also coordinating messages and actions, not only with our partners, but first and foremost among Europeans. This was the case yesterday at the Foreign Affairs Council, where we discussed and agreed on common lines in this regard.  Finding a negotiated solution to the current conflicts in the Middle East is in everybody’s interest, especially everyone in the region. Protracted war can only benefit terrorists of all kinds, and it can only let instability spread further well beyond the borders of the Middle East; we in Europe know that very well. This is not a zero-sum game, and this is the other strong message we are passing on to our Iranian and Saudi friends. If the wars in Syria and in Yemen and the tensions in the region do not stop, everybody will lose. There is not a single place in the region that can benefit from the escalation of tensions. The only alternative to a win-win solution, where everybody sees their interests recognised, is chaos and further chaos. It took us months to gather all regional powers around the same table to discuss peace in Syria. As we said, the same goes for Libya, a country from which we had encouraging news today since we managed to unite the region’s international actors in a process along similar lines to that which we put together for Syria. We cannot afford to waste any of these positive trends and we cannot afford to expose them to tensions that need to stay contained – if possible at a bilateral level. The European Union will keep doing all that we can to promote dialogue, and fight sectarianism. This is because we have learned our own EU lesson. I said this in the previous debate, about Colombia. This is the EU lesson. It is only regional cooperation that brings peace and prosperity, and we have experienced this for 60 years now. Only through this kind of regional understanding, cooperation and partnership did we manage to overcome centuries of war and conflict and experience peace in our region. This is our way. We believe it is regional cooperation – and never confrontation or competition – that is beneficial for all. This is particularly true for an area of the world like the Middle East.

name: Cristian Dan Preda
text: on behalf of the EPP group. Madam President, Madam High Representative, ladies and gentlemen, as we know, the tensions between Saudi Arabia and Iran have reached a new climax. Saudi Arabia and some of its Sunni Arab allies severed diplomatic relations with Tehran earlier this year after protesters, angered by Riyadh's execution of a prominent Shiite leader on January 2, attacked the Saudi embassy in Tehran. The execution of 47 people, including Sheikh al-Nimr, by beheading and shooting, is the largest execution by Saudi Arabia since 1980. It is not necessary to recall the fact that we categorically reject the death penalty and, as the High Representative said, this commitment must be kept. We must also remember that Iran's record of capital punishment is not at all glorious. Last year, even as progress was made on nuclear power, Iran recorded 1,084 executions. That is why I am glad that we were able to add Iran to today's debate, because the initial proposal from our left-wing friends - communists, socialists, liberals and greens - was to discuss only Saudi Arabia and to criticise what is happening there. I believe that we are now facing a new phase of confrontation between Shiites and Sunnis. I know that we find it difficult to accept the political strength of this religious divide. I believe that this is a mistake and that we must take very seriously what the High Representative also said, which is our attempt to resolve this conflict, because it is a conflict that will have dramatic consequences for us in the years to come.

name: Richard Howitt
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, tonight we should welcome the implementation of the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action and, as rapporteur, the High Representative will have this Parliament’s further support to pursue a new path of cooperation with Iran. But that now includes efforts to de—escalate tensions, recognising the fact that Europe has common interests with both Riyadh and Tehran in energy security, conflict resolution and the fight against terrorism, but also common differences on the death penalty, democratic standards, justice on religious minorities and restrictions against women. Both countries should refrain from allowing external financing, which can destabilise other countries and, directly or indirectly, support extremist groups. I would like to ask Mrs Mogherini again which human rights safeguards have been applied to the EU’s counter—terrorism agreement with the Gulf States, given that some of the people the Saudis executed have been identified by human rights groups not as terrorists, but as political dissidents. I also ask her to respond to the legal opinion which suggested that targeting of civilians in Yemen means that continued arms sales to Saudi Arabia are in breach of the EU’s Code of Conduct. I hope and believe we have succeeded in halting a nuclear arms race in this region, and urgent action is now needed to stop one in conventional arms too. In many countries, Shia and Sunni Moslems cohabit peacefully. In Europe, we should be respectful about religious differences within Islam, which have existed for centuries, but should also be determined to seek political cooperation, which is needed for the future. Both Iran and Saudi Arabia can have a role to play in the region that does not have to be at the cost of the other. Each could be part of a new collective security structure in the Middle East, and each could be a partner of the European Union. Whilst others are severing diplomatic ties, we should be intensifying them.

name: Bas Belder
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Let us be sober. Neither the Wahhabi kingdom of Saudi Arabia nor the Shiite Islamic Republic of Iran are currently contributing to the humanitarian urgency of a stable Middle East. Both Riyadh and Tehran are fighting the Islamic State, but with differing goals.  And that Islamic State also has Europe, our continent, in its sights. Which brings me to the vision of a German expert on Saudi politics. Because the jihadists have ever-improving networks internationally, the West must continue to cooperate with Saudi Arabia if it is to effectively fight al-Qaida and the Islamic State. You should know that, too. The intelligence services of several Member States of the European Union are familiar with Riyadh. High Representative, to what extent does the European rapprochement with Iran - you would almost speak of some kind of embrace if I hear you - threaten a joint fight against jihadism with Saudi Arabia, because that is at odds.

name: Beatriz Becerra Basterrechea
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, Mrs Mogherini, what unsells Saudi Arabia and Iran is more than what separates them. Journalists and bloggers detained for peaceful activities, impunity in gender-based violence and discrimination, institutionalized torture, champions in executions per capita: almost even so far this year, with half a hundred each. This is how the United Nations and major NGOs describe Iran and Saudi Arabia. In addition to these shocking similarities, there is another very significant one: the power of oil. Saudi Arabia's energy dependence and obscure businesses such as arms sales have hurt our defense of human rights. We've already fallen into that trap and now we can make the same mistake with Iran. Iran's abandoning its nuclear program is good news for international security and peace, but it cannot be an excuse to lower our human rights demands. Regaining our trade leadership, yes, but without giving up our influence to ensure that the Iranian government complies with its international agreements. Let us not forget Saudi Arabia's choice: energy dependence equal to lack of commitment to human rights. Success in the European Union's relations with Iran will not only have to be measured based on the number of contracts our companies achieve, but above all on how we have improved the lives of Iranians, who suffer systematic violation of their human rights by their government, especially those affecting more than half of their population , women. Oppressed, discriminated against, veded, annulled. It is necessary to insist and insist until concrete results are achieved, such as the United Nations special rapporteur entering Iran and doing his work.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, Mrs Mogherini, the world's largest oil exporter has executed at least 2,200 people in recent decades. Most of them were denied adequate assistance during the trial and forced to sign documents—including confessions—that they did not understand. The number of justices has soared dramatically since King Salman's throne arrived last January. And now it looks like we have a problem.  The problem is that for too long you have had Saudi Arabia as a preferred partner in the region thanks to the juicy infrastructure and arms contracts of Spanish, French, British or German companies, which have paid with clamorous official silences for the systematic violation of human rights, as a strategy of buying wills that includes European governments and media, as the Wikileaks leaks demonstrated. Or, for example, Saudi Arabia's entry into the United Nations Human Rights Committee thanks to the support of the Government of Great Britain.  Mrs Mogherini, with these executions, the invaluable partner of European multinationals is intended only to tie sectarian fire in the region. He's doing international politics with these deaths. You have to make a decision: continue to give Sakharov awards to Saudi activists as they look the other way to do business, or take steps defined by democracy and respect for human rights, even if it cost them some contracts in Iran and Saudi Arabia.

name: Alyn Smith
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, I would like to thank Ms Mogherini and welcome her to Parliament again. In the time available, I would mention Iran only insofar as to welcome progress and say I am very much looking forward to welcoming Iran back in from the cold. We, the EU, have a huge incentive and a huge potential to engage with the forces of progress within the Republic. Ms Mogherini, many congratulations thus far and continue with your efforts.  It is all the more concerning that, as we see progress with Tehran, we see the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia actually deteriorating: we see increasing repression at home, we see a real budget crisis which is driving much of the domestic politics of the Kingdom and we see disastrous military interventions in its near abroad, especially in regard to Yemen. EU engagement with the Kingdom of course is very different state by state, but my own state, the UK, has since 2010 sold GBP 5.6 billion worth of arms to Saudi Arabia. These are being used in Yemen with disastrous consequences. This is been harshly criticised by Edward Santiago, the head of Save the Children’s Yemen office. He said that the UK gives the impression that diplomatic relations and arms sales trump the lives of Yemen’s children: harsh criticism there.  Turning back to the EU, we do have a community of values enshrined in laws and international agreements. It is a very concrete question, Ms Mogherini, and I will write to you tomorrow. I think there is a considerable degree of dubiety over the legality under our laws, under our international agreements, of arms sales to Saudi Arabia, especially as they are being used in Yemen. What assessment have your services made of that legality? If there has been no assessment, do you not think that perhaps there should be?

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, all the interlocutors are the same, but some interlocutors are more equal than the others, especially if they have the largest oil reserves in the world and so many billions of dollars to invest. This paraphrase by Orwell describes well the tolerance of the whole West in the face of violations of human rights and civil and political rights and freedoms, in the face of extremist preaching and the role in bloody proxy wars that inflame the Middle East. All almost in silence. And now these 47 death sentences, which have led to an unprecedented escalation, how to interpret them? An attempt to show muscle to strengthen support around Saud's home? Will we raise the price of oil in total collapse because of the return of trade in Iranian production? Or even force allies to take sides, also influencing the American election campaign and urging the various candidates to disavow obamian openness on nuclear agreements?  These are questions that are still unanswered, but the only certainty is that it is increasingly essential for us to demand from our allies total intransigence in the fight against terrorism, against the financiers of terrorism and its preachers; consistency with our principles and values, in particular against the death penalty; and also demand that the Member States stop the flow of arms of which Arabia was the world's leading importer in 2014, otherwise the blood of the victims in Yemen and elsewhere will also fall on the stars of our flag.

name: Josef Weidenholzer (S&D).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The conflict between Saudi Arabia and Iran is in danger of entering a hot phase. There are already proxy wars in Syria and Yemen. An armed conflict would drive the whole region to the abyss. This would have unimaginable consequences for Europe as well. That is why no one can be interested in this developing. I welcome the fact that Iran has finally become part of the international community again after the conclusion of the nuclear negotiations. It is important that states operate in such a fragile region, not stateless actors and not failed states. No one can be interested in destabilising. Two points in a moment: all the activities aimed at unbalance the region by supporting actors such as Da'esh are dangerous, and we must not spread the cloak of silence about it. Secondly, stability cannot be achieved through repression, stability is achieved in the long term through democracy and the rule of law. The election in Iran will show whether the country is on the right track. Unfortunately, Saudi Arabia is still a long way from these developments. The last events have also clearly proved this to us. We cannot decide where Saudi Arabia is going, but we have it in our hands by finally restricting our arms supplies to Saudi Arabia.

name: Klaus Buchner (Verts/ALE).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The aim of our policy must be to achieve peace and human rights in the Middle East. What is happening in this region is of central importance to us in Europe in particular, because most of the refugees come to us from Syria and from this region. The fact is, on the contrary, that human rights are being trampled underfoot in both Saudi Arabia and Iran, and that both countries are engaged in wars, not only in Yemen, but also indirectly through finances in Syria and Iraq. In other words, we now have a chance as the EU, because Saudi Arabia is moving somewhat away from the US towards Europe. We have a similarly favourable situation in Iran. In other words, we can now more easily get our demands through, and that is logically peace. That means, firstly, stopping engagement in these wars, secondly, human rights and, thirdly, stopping arms exports to these countries.

name: Victor Boştinaru (S&D).
text: – Madam President, the recent escalation of tensions between Iran and Saudi Arabia represents a deeply worrying development that hangs over a region and so marked by serious crises and risks exacerbating the confrontation between the Sunns and the Siths, at regional and global level.  The only way out of the crisis is for the EU to make its own contribution to putting the two sides at the negotiating table. We must prevent the Vienna process on Syria from being compromised and Iraq will once again become a theatre of confrontation between the Sitheths and the Unsunites. The nuclear deal with Iran has confirmed the dividends of peace, of the negotiations, and the European Union is entitled to play pragmatically in relations with the two sides to prevent further escalation.

name: Damiano Zoffoli (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the nuclear agreement has undoubtedly changed the scenario in the Middle East. American hostility and closure towards Iran and their alliance with the Saudis have been founding elements of Middle East policy for years. Even if an open war between Iran and Arabia is ruled out, it is certain that in this region, in addition to the unresolved Israeli-Palestinian issue, the rivalry between Iran and Arabia and the divisions between Shiites and Sunnis will be increasingly decisive.  The European Union played a key role in the negotiations on Iran's nuclear deal with High Representative Federica Mogherini, for which we once again thank her. This agreement, which is one of the few signs of hope to date, must be only the first step towards a widered dialogue with Iran, which includes regional issues such as relations with Syria, Yemen, Lebanon, Iraq and Afghanistan, which the latest Saudi action aims to call into question. Europe, which is engaged in stabilising the region in order to prevent terrorism and the tragedy of immigration, which is the result of wars, must prevent provocations from wherever they come from putting the laborious search for peace in Syria in crisis. We must reiterate our strong opposition to the use of the death penalty in all circumstances. All this, however, requires more European Union, more Union and more Europe.

name: Ana Gomes (S&D).
text: – Madam President, the execution of Sheikh Al-Nimr and 46 others was an irresponsible provocation, which could only escalate regional and global tension swaying in order to obstruct the Vienna talks on Syria. Failing to protect the Saudi Embassy and Consulate, the Iranian authorities, for their part, have fallen into the trap of Rump's most sectarian and warmongering sectors.  The European Union must invest in dialogue with Tehran, especially now that the agreement on the nuclear programme is being fulfilled and sanctions have been lifted, and for this I would like to congratulate it warmly on its leadership, Mrs Mogherini, in this process. In the European Union we can and should criticize Tehran when it is necessary, particularly on human rights, but we must not stop working with Iran – where there is, after all, a functional state – to end the war in Syria and to fight Daexe and other terrorist organizations that radiate there, with Saudi, Qatari sponsors, other Gulf countries and Turkey , which is no longer possible to be ignored by European governments, which have to have consequences for the relationship with these countries.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the High Representative for reporting in this House on the current state of relations between Saudi Arabia and Iran. We are particularly concerned, not least in the light of the debate that has just begun, at the possible postponement of the Peace Conference on Syria, especially in view of the awareness that the hope for peace lies in the dialogue between all the actors involved, a dialogue which, of course, cannot ignore the cooperation between the two regional powers deeply involved in the events in Syria.  Secondly, there is no risk that the escalating diplomatic tensions between the two states could overshadow the great achievement of the Iran nuclear agreement. Finally, we are pleased that you have highlighted the issue of human rights and the constant effort to abolish the death penalty, because they are not secondary or party issues, but must consistently be part of our action towards all partners, in any circumstances in which they are put at risk.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – Madam President, the recent developments in Saudi-Iranian relations have a great potential to further destabilise the Middle East. The execution of the Shia cleric al-Nimr was an irresponsible act by the Saudi Government, further exacerbating sectarianism. Iran, on the other hand, has failed in its duty to protect the Saudi embassy from a mob attack. The decision of Saudi Arabia to cut off diplomatic and indeed any kind of relations with Iran, however, is disproportionate. A different path, nevertheless, is possible.
