name: Laura Agea
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner Bienkowska, as draftsman of the opinion that the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs has given on the report on personal protective equipment, I would like to point out that the opinion was adopted unanimously by the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs and that there have been many indications, because we, as the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, believe that the issue of worker safety is extremely important. We have indicated that ad hoc tools were given for those who use them, that account should be taken of different conformitys, of different user conformations, of adequate information, a language quite comprehensible to those who use these tools. We regret that the involvement of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs in relation to the report has been minimal and that the important indications, especially on the communication, which was to be given to the users of these instruments, have been extremely limited. However, we reserve the right to check exactly what the conditions of the report are and, if necessary, to give our opinion the report an okay.

name: Pascal Arimont
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has I am speaking to you as the PPE-DE negotiator on this proposal for a regulation on personal protective equipment. The European internal market is characterised by high standards of consumer protection worldwide. I would even say and say that nowhere is a consumer as well protected as or by the EU. Specifically, this regulation is about very high standards for safety helmets, earmuffs, bicycle helmets, sunglasses and warning vests. It's not about the self-crocheted pot holder, it's not about rinsing gloves.  This regulation therefore concerns each and every one of us. When I buy my young daughter a bicycle helmet, when my father, as a do-it-yourselfer, puts on a respirator, or when countless workers on the building, i.e. everyone has to be able to rely on the guarantee of optimal protection – all over Europe. We therefore need high binding standards to protect the consumer from poor quality articles. For us as the GROUP of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats, however, it was also important to support small and medium-sized enterprises in the manufacturing industry to be able to implement these new requirements in concrete terms. And this without too much bureaucratic burdens, because small and medium-sized enterprises simply lack the time for excessive paperwork. So what are the best uses of the best rules if no one is able to implement them afterwards? In this context, I particularly welcome our agreement on a simplified recertification procedure. This means that if a manufacturer does not change the product and the product still complies with all legal requirements, then he should not have to pay for this approval again.  So here we can show that we can do both. On the one hand, protect consumers throughout Europe efficiently from fraud and poor quality and, on the other hand, dispense with excessive bureaucratic requirements. That is why I am very much and explicit in support of this report.

name: Kerstin Westphal
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The regulation of personal protective equipment is certainly not an issue with which we MEPs receive great recognition from consumers. Sometimes it is considered a niche issue. Nevertheless, it is an issue in which many important points are dealt with. It is precisely safety, as has just been mentioned by my colleague, which has been promised and which is also being complied with accordingly. protective equipment, for example for firefighters, helmets, fire-resistant clothing; but also for the foresters, who must have cut-proof trousers. Protective clothing, which requires no less than 224 million workers in the European Union. But it is not only about protective equipment for professionals, it is also about protective equipment for private use. Yes, Mrs Ford, it is also a question of oven gloves, and safety must also be guaranteed here. Because wherever safety is on the packaging, safety must of course also be included. We have managed to do that. In the negotiations with both the Council and the Commission, we have been constantly aware of the danger of being too bureaucratic. That is why we have taken out a number of things, such as the rinsing gloves, but also sportswear, which has simply lost nothing. In addition, we have also achieved some facilitation for manufacturers: they get legal certainty and can now be confident that their type tests will be extended easily and quickly. Consumers and manufacturers, as well as market surveillance authorities, have been given a great deal of legislation with this regulation. I recommend the negotiating package of my group for adoption.

name: Daniel Dalton
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, I welcome the revision of the cableways legislation, which will cut red tape for businesses that want to sell into the EU. They will also make it easier for national authorities to check safety regulations, and it stops the protectionist measures employed by some Member States. But the Commission got it wrong by including historic cableways, and I am delighted that they have now been excluded from the scope of this regulation. This is great news for Bridgnorth Cliff Railway in Shropshire, which next year celebrates its 125th birthday. It originally started as a way to help local people avoid climbing the 200 steps between the high and low town in Bridgnorth, but it has evolved into a major tourist draw and a vital source of income for the town. It already complies with national health and safety legislation, so it is safe, but forcing it to comply with new one—size—fits—all rules on replacement parts would likely have led it to being shut down, given the expense of trying to get its custom—made parts to fit the new requirements. It’s great to see that in this case at least, a one—size—fits—all approach has been stopped in its tracks and historic tourist attractions like Bridgnorth Cliff Railway can continue to be enjoyed by future generations.

name: Dita Charanzová
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, Madam Commissioner, these three files might not be the sexiest topics, especially at this point of time. But, because of the work of all us involved in the negotiations, every European citizens will be a little safer after tomorrow’s votes. Citizens will know that when they go to work, take a hot shower or take a ski lift to the top of a mountain – no matter where they are in Europe – the highest safety standards will apply. I am also happy that common sense prevailed in these negotiations. So, for instance the historical cableways like the one in Prague – the Petřín cableway – are excluded from the regulation. For me, these files are good examples of where European harmonisation just makes common sense. Unless there is a justifiable reason that a technical standard should be different between one Member State and another, common technical regulations help to increase competition in the marketplace. Lower over-regulation and make our lives easier and safer. Madam Commissioner, I would like to encourage the Commission to continue to use its legislative powers to harmonise where it makes sense and the benefit is clear. Such acts are vital to a well-functioning single market.

name: Jiří Maštálka
text: for the GUE/NGL group. – Madam President, as has been said, it is perhaps a pity that it is so late in the evening and we are dealing with this issue, which is certainly of interest to the citizens of the European Union. The Commission's objective, as has been said, is to replace the original 1989 Directives with a regulation that would ensure the compulsory and uniform use of PPE in all Member States.  It should be noted that this is of significant economic importance for the European market, estimated at around EUR 10 billion in 2010 and continues to grow, stimulated in particular by modern technologies, technological innovations such as new fibres, smart fabrics and nanomaterials. I believe that most of the proposed changes are positive. However, I find some problematic. For example, the inclusion of personal heat, damp and water protective equipment or the variety of language regimes chosen for the different information to be educating, or the inconsistency between the 10-year retention period for technical documentation and the five-year period for the validity of the certificate of conformity. The key issue of this proposal, in my view, is how to strike a balance between protecting the interests of consumers and producers, especially small and medium-sized enterprises, and promoting the use of personal protective equipment in global policy to prevent risks in the workplace. I believe that with this regulation we will contribute to the safety of our citizens.

name: Margot Parker
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, ‘harmonisation’ and ‘European Union’ are words that go hand in hand. It is no surprise, therefore, to see a debate on three legislative reports aiming to increase harmonisation between Member States. The one-size-fits-all approach of EU regulation is far from perfect, and these regulations in discussion are no exception. The UK Government, for example, has highlighted concerns at the Personal Protective Equipment Regulation and announced that it opposes this regulation passing. Yet, as we all know too well, the UK will be forced to accept it. I am sure that we could all agree that prosperous, mutually beneficial and efficient trade between nations is desirable by all. But it is the growing number of harmonised regulations: are they really necessary? I am afraid I am not yet convinced.

name: Cristian-Silviu Buşoi (PPE).
text: – Madam President, as rapporteur from the PPE Group for Mrs Stihler's report, I would like to thank and congratulate the three rapporteurs, Mrs Ford, Mrs Stihler and Mr Antonio Lódez, for all the work she has done over the last few months.  The new regulation on gaseous fuel-consuming appliances is an example of legislation, harmonising the Union, ensuring both the free movement of gas-consuming appliances and the placing on the market or putting into service of gaseous fuel-consuming appliances meeting higher consumer safety standards, thereby also lessising the safety risks related to gas and ensuring at the same time, the more rational use of energy. From simple portable stoves to large power plants for very large buildings, in the European Union the current stock of gas-consuming appliances is 470 million, growing, selling more than 30 million units each year.  I am pleased and very grateful that the rapporteur, Mrs Stihler, has embraced the idea of introducing and amending the text from the point of view of consumer safety, adding changes to the precautions that should have been and which should be considered in order to avoid and prevent the intoxication of people with gas, including carbon monoxide, and the leakage of any substances that could cause health and safety problems , carbon monoxide poisoning being a leading cause of death associated with the use of gas-consuming appliances. The new legislation will clearly benefit European citizens.

name: Lara Comi (PPE).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, the completion of the single market is a major political objective, which we must pursue with every effort, and we have been in this direction for years now. Strengthening the harmonisation of national legislation in the various sectors remains a fundamental step, which not only unifies and simplifies the regulatory framework for market players, but also guarantees higher levels of consumer protection and also improves the lives of our citizens, and that is also our objective. As rapporteur for the report on the strategy for the single market in goods and services, for which we have shared many comments together, we are pursuing this approach, highlighting the need to effectively remove the concrete obstacles that take place in the harmonisation of the system. We often talk about an economic union, but in reality there is no economic union at three hundred and sixty degrees, and so one of the objectives we set ourselves is to harmonise the system more and more and remove these obstacles. The three reports, on which I congratulate the rapporteurs, which we will adopt tomorrow go in precisely this direction: that of making harmonisation more effective by moving from directive to regulation. This is the real step forward, it is what I, as a Parliament and as a Commission, will increasingly have to use, so that the regulation is adopted as soon as possible, very quickly in the individual Member States. That, in my view, is the real meaning of Europe and also of the role of the European Parliament. These are areas, as we have seen in the three reports, which are different but also very significant from an economic point of view. Therefore, the hope is that by improving its rules, the positive effects can also be produced on the employment and economic front, which is what concerns us today.

name: Paul Rübig (PPE).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I believe that it is also a question of achieving economic effects in harmonising and, above all, regulating market access for small and medium-sized enterprises in particular. That is why it is actually clear that the regulation on cable cars will play an essential role here, because they are, of course, very much used in tourism, but will also have great significance for smart cities in the future. Especially with the smart cities you will see that the cable cars naturally produce very little noise, also very little particulate matter, so that the cable car can also be used well over bridges, over corresponding obstacles. It is clear that the uniform level of safety can also reduce road accidents, and that the free movement of goods clearly shows that Europe can make proper use of the internal market and that, of course, new additional jobs can also be created, because this high European safety culture is, of course, also an export hit. Our cable car manufacturers have already worked on the markets worldwide, making an important contribution to life and safety. Billions of dollars are being generated here in this area. STOA, the Science and Technology Options Assessment, has considered cable cars to be important for sustainable transport and sustainable mobility in the studies. This sustainability, together with e-mobility, will play a much greater role in the future.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Madam President, firstly I think that everybody agrees that these are not headline topics, but they are nevertheless very important for consumers. I think it is fantastic that we have MEPs here in the House who are prepared to give their time, energy and expertise in dealing with issues like this when they get very little publicity out of it. But they can be sure of one thing. Their work is actually going to save the lives of European citizens because of the harmonisation of standards and ensuring that everything is done according to spec. We are covering three areas here: cable installations, gas appliances and protective equipment. Obviously, in relation to cableways, we have 60% of the world’s cableways – 17 500 in Europe. In my own country, the little island, Dursey Island, is dependent on a cable car to connect it with the mainland, so obviously, the higher the standard, the greater the security. In relation to gas appliances, we have 30 million stoves, boilers and cookers in Europe. Again, these can lead to major accidents. Carbon monoxide, in particular, is the highest killer in relation to these. In my own country we have had a very successful carbon monoxide awareness campaign. Again, having strong legislation here, harmonised across Europe, is very sensible and of course helps us to complete the single market. Regarding the final area – personal protective equipment – I think all we have to do is listen to Vicky Ford, who showed us what can happen with inferior products which can come onto the marketplace. So, by having standards set here and by ensuring they are applied, it will encourage both the producers that there is a legal framework which they can work by, and also consumers that they have the highest possible standards, which they will be able to see on the labels on the various appliances they buy.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that today we are debating a subject which is extremely important, which can cover all the subjects and not just those covered by these documents, because harmonisation of legislation at European level is clearly an extremely important factor. It would be appropriate to imagine a Europe where, of course, the rules were the same for all and all European citizens were equal in the face of the rules, because this would help – I believe – also to have a more comprehensive vision of Europe and which perhaps represented all European citizens more.  Today, in particular, we are voting and discussing in this plenary session the harmonization of the rules on cable way installations, and therefore on everything that concerns the installation of mountain stations in our Europe, I believe that we are taking a great step forward in the protection of all our stations, because it is clear, for anyone who has a certain type of competence in the field of , as at distances, often very limited by kilometres, i.e. one kilometre away in general, two ski resorts, perhaps one in France and one in Italy, have regulations that are completely different and which, moreover, place them in a position of unfair competition with each other. I therefore believe that an important step forward is being taken today and that issues such as these, namely the harmonisation of European legislation, should to some extent slowly affect all sectors of our economic society.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I also want to join the previous speaker, in principle everything important has already been said. Let me just say that I also consider this issue to be extremely important. I want to say to the Commissioner that I consider it important what at first glance seems like a mere formality, that regulations are being approached from directives. I have been responsible in the Czech Republic for five years for the implementation of directives into the national legal order and I know well what differences then exist between national regulations. This means one directive and twenty-eight different implementations. Therefore, if we want to create a truly single market with uniform rules, then, in my opinion, it is much better to apply a regulation that simply applies as one piece of legislation to the whole territory of the European Union. So the transition from directives to regulation is, in my view, extremely important in this case and, of course, in the content of what we are debating today and what will hopefully apply today is much better than the existing legislation in several fragmented directives. Colleagues have already talked about individual products, about the uniform rules for the requirements for these products. I particularly want to thank the rapporteurs and I want to comment on the discussions in the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection, where it has been possible to rationalise what requirements should be, in particular, for products which take the form of personal protective equipment. I think that's a very good thing. Thank you and support the proposal.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Madam President, we are discussing a very serious issue which concerns both consumer safety and the safety of workers themselves.  It is obvious that economic globalisation and the liberalisation of trade have led to the transfer of production to developing countries. There, the attempt to reduce costs and make businesses a greater profit has resulted in a weakening of safety standards. As a result, we have goods and many appliances in Europe that have proved dangerous, in particular gas appliances, which were imported from China and caused too many accidents due to a carbon monoxide leak. In countries with energy poverty such as Greece, which has been hit by the memorandum, these incidents are unfortunately becoming even more dramatic. It is important that these measures are taken.

name: Elżbieta Bieńkowska
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank the Members very much for all their comments on this package. This is the first time in my short (one-year) experience in the Commission that I have heard so many unanimous positive opinions, so I want once again to warmly thank the rapporteurs for cooperating so closely and ensuring consistency throughout the three texts, as well as with the new legislative framework package.  Let me just very shortly stress three key points. With those three regulations, we will have a simpler, fairer and more modernised legal framework. Replacing the directive with regulations will make life less burdensome for companies and we will be better equipped to fight non-compliant and potentially unsafe products, which is essential for our citizens and for protecting honest companies. Members, I therefore call again on your strong support for this package and would like to thank you very much, especially the rapporteurs, for your efforts.

name: Vicky Ford
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, our single market is meant to make it easier to trade across the 28 countries of 500 million consumers, and sometimes we do not need a one-size-fits all approach – but sometimes we do. Tonight we have been talking about keeping people safe from gas boilers so that they do not die from carbon monoxide problems, fall off a chairlift when it collapses or die or become injured because of personal protective equipment. Rules that we have had in Europe for 25 years have now been simplified, modernised and clarified. By being at the table involved in the detail, we have negotiated a better position. On my own report I tabled 146 amendments to the Commission proposal. 117 of those are in the final legislation, including a new procedure to make it easier for small companies. We have made it less bureaucratic whilst maintaining safety, and done in a manner that should not increase costs for consumers or manufacturers. I hope this will make it easier to trade. My colleague from UKIP said she did not understand why we need this legislation. She has not talked in a single debate or tabled a single amendment. When it comes to making the rules by which our businesses and consumers trade, I would rather be at the table negotiating a deal, because in Europe, if we are not at the table, we risk being on the menu.

name: Catherine Stihler
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, I would like to thank all the rapporteurs. The warm words that we have heard this evening from colleagues have been really touching. I would like to say to Mr Kelly that we do all this work and get very little recognition, yet tonight we are trying to save lives. That is something that the few of us who are in this Chamber this evening should remember. Why we are here, even at ten minutes to midnight, is really important. On the value of the single market, Ms Ford is absolutely right that we work together, we come up with a compromise and then we sit at the table. If UKIP had their way, they would have us leave the EU, have no say and we would still have to pay for the privilege. It is not a workable solution. We need to make sure that the UK remains in the European Union, that we have our say and that we influence policies that influence the single market. I think it was the previous Dutch Presidency, all those years ago, which described the EU as this beautiful thing, this beautiful piece of process, but something very precious and something that we need to make sure we keep working upon. The fact that we have a single market with 500 million consumers, covering 28 countries, and tonight we can sit and make decisions that impact all of those people in a sensible, positive way, is something that is very precious and worth defending.  Thank you for your time this evening. Thank you for all your support. It has been a privilege working with people who want to make sure the single market works for our citizens.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, I believe that, like everyone else, I am delighted with this joint work with Mrs Stihler and Mrs Ford. I think we've all done a good job, all the components, although there's always some exception; there's always someone who doesn't want to participate in this, but, well, it's normal now. In our case I think we have taken a huge step in the internal market, which is what I joined this committee for. I am new to it, and I am very proud that with this report I have been able to work with the two rapporteurs and I think I have learned a great deal from both of them.  I would simply like to detail some four important points on the final report of which I have had the honour of being rapporteur. There is more information for consumers, with a reinforced mention of the producers' website in the recitals and articles; the wording of the article on the braking system for cable transport systems remains true to the principle of technological neutrality and will allow fair competition between all actors in this market; a new recital on sanctions - I would like to mention here an alternative rapporteur, Lucy Anderson, who has insisted very much on this issue – who has succeeded in strengthening the sanctions system of the proposal for a regulation; and finally, we have addressed Member States' concerns about historic facilities, which are often of high tourist interest. As head of the Group of the European People's Party for this report, I also thank the shadow rapporteurs for their cooperation in this package on harmonisation of the internal market, which allowed all the amendments which were in conformity with the powers of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection to be positively valued, reaching a very satisfactory result from which all members of the IMCO Commission can be proud.

name: PUHEMIES. –
text: The joint debate is closed.  The vote will take place tomorrow. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Eva Paunova (PPE)
text: in writing. – The internal market of the European Union is an area of prosperity and freedom, giving 500 million Europeans access to goods, services, jobs and business opportunities of 28 Member States. While the construction of an internal market requires continuous efforts, the further deepening of the single market could yield significant gains for EU consumers and businesses if the remaining barriers are eliminated.  The Commission proposals for a regulations on appliances burning gaseous fuels, personal protective equipment (PPE), and cableway installations, update and align with the New Legislative Framework on the marketing of products. The PPE rules are now in need of updating to reflect the new developments in technology. I thus welcome the proposal, which lays down requirements for design and production of PPE to ensure the health and safety of users and the free movement of PPE in the EU market.  Apart from the harmonised approach, the new legislation does not imposing excessive burdens for businesses. This simplified and modernised legislation is needed especially for facilitating the inclusion of the Small and Medium enterprises in the market. A harmonised internal market will facilitate greater economic growth. With the three reports we are taking a step towards a more effective Single Market which will be both business and consumer friendly.
